title: Walgreens makes takeover bid for drug distributor AmerisourceBergen

content: Shares of companies across the health care industry, from health insurers to distributors, pharmacy-benefit managers and drugmakers, dropped in premarket trade on Tuesday after Amazon AMZN, +1.11% Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A, +1.04% BRK.B, +1.43% and JPMorgan Chase JPM, +1.82% announced plans for a new company to improve their employees' health care. The news hit pharmacy-benefit managers, pharmacy chains and drug distributors among the hardest, with CVS Health Corp. CVS, -0.80% shares dropping 7.6%, Walgreens Boots Alliance WBA, -3.14% shares dropping 5.7%, Express Scripts Holding Company ESRX, -0.93% dropping 4.8% and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% shares dropping 4.3%. Several health insurers' shares also fell significantly, including UnitedHealth Group UNH, -2.06% which dropped 7.2%, Anthem Inc. ANTM, -0.80% which dropped 7%, as well as Aetna Inc. AET, -0.25% and Humana Inc. HUM, +0.48% The moves reflect investor concerns that the Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan initiative could shake up the status quo, especially given the three companies' large size and influential nature, and the potential interest of other employers in joining them. U.S. health care costs continue to rise year over year despite efforts to curb them, and many experts believe the fault lies with too-high prices. The SPDR S&P Biotech ETF XBI, +0.83% declined 1% in premarket trade, as did the Health Care Select Sector SPDR XLV, +0.76% Shares of the ETFs have surged 15.5% and 12.3% respectively over the last three months, compared with a 10.9% increase in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% and a 13.2% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% Read the full story: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan health initiative send industry shares plummeting
title: Health care company shares drop sharply on entry by Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan

content: Hospital systems are trying something new in an effort to shake up U.S. drug pricing and combat longtime drug shortages, starting their own nonprofit generic drug manufacturer, the New York Times reports. The Thursday news seemed to herald doom for generic drug manufacturers like Mylan NV MYL, +1.65%  , Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. TEVA, +0.29%  and Endo International PLC ENDP, +1.71%  , and their shares fell in heavy trade. The VanEck Vectors Generic Drugs ETF GNRX, -1.31%  declined 1.3% in extremely heavy trade. But many industry observers say it’s easier said than done. Setting up shop in the generic industry will be difficult and take some time, they say, factors that limit the risk to generic drugmakers. The hospitals also plan to focus on select drugs, another factor that should limit industry damage, experts said. About 300 hospitals have signed on to the initiative, which is led by the Utah-based nonprofit hospital system Intermountain Healthcare and aims to manufacture generic drugs for hospital use, according to the Times report. They would eventually consider selling to others as well, the report said. The group will focus only on drugs “where there are problems,” Intermountain Healthcare Chief Executive Marc Harrison told the Times, especially situations in which old drugs’ prices have been hiked substantially or where there are shortages of key products. Executives wouldn’t specify which products, though, for fear of competitors undercutting them — at least in the short term — on price, according to the Times. Getting started in the generics business is doable, but it’ll realistically take about 18 to 24 months to make a product and get it approved, Spencer Perlman, director of health-care research at Veda Partners, told MarketWatch. That timeline would make it difficult to quickly enter a new market as a shortage or pricing issues arise, and could give rivals a head start to undercut them on price, he said. Also, on the whole generic drugs are less expensive than new, complex drugs called biologics, though there are some clear exceptions to the rule. See: Lost beneath headlines of five-figure drug costs — pharmaceutical price growth is weakening Though a generic drugmaker could make cheaper versions of those drugs, called biosimilars, “there is an exponentially higher level of sophistication that is required to replicate a biologic,” Perlman said. Related: These drugs could cut American health costs by $250 billion (if only we could take them) Because the hospital initiative is expected to focus on select drugs, Wall Street analysts said it represents minimal impact to generic drugmakers as well as the drug supply chain. “We believe there are certain situations where the hospitals’ solution could be successful, particularly in providing a more reliable supply for certain products that have frequent shortages,” said RBC Capital Markets analyst George Hill. “The hospitals’ solution could also be successful to address large increases in drug prices, depending on how quickly the new company is able to react and ramp up competition.” But for drugs with FDA exclusivity, “it is less likely the company will provide any competition or price relief,” he added. Others questioned whether hospitals could even swing it, financially. “We believe that start up costs associated with setting up an actual generics company (with scientific, regulators, and legal departments and plants) may prove cost prohibitive to hospitals,” said Mizuho analyst Irina Koffler. Generic competition has already been ramping up, spurred by encouragement from the FDA and faster-than-usual approvals, so it’s possible that generics manufacturers may already be working in areas of shortage or over-pricing, Koffler said. Read more: Teva’s new plan is to raise drug prices, but it won’t be easy and Mylan sees opportunity in rival Teva’s weakness However, some of the industry’s pricing and shortage problems have persisted for many years, such as with IV saline solution, which the FDA added to the drug shortage list in 2013. Meanwhile, the generic drug industry has been struggling because of lower generics prices, slower sales, more competition and consolidation among purchasing groups. These challenges might even compound shortage issues. Teva — the largest generic drugmaker — announced a slew of cost cuts late last year, including plans to raise prices on some products and discontinuing others. Shares of generic drugmaker Perrigo Co. PRGO, +0.90%  declined 0.6% in Thursday trade, and Teligent TLGT, -1.75%  shares dropped 6.5%. Drug distributors McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  , Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94%  and AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  dropped 1%, 1.8% and 0.9%, respectively. The VanEck Vectors Generic Drugs ETF has surged 11% over the past three months, compared with a 9.3% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  and a 12.8% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07%  . More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage
title: Why hospital entry won’t hurt the generic drug business

content: This year’s flu season is expected to be the worst in recent history. But Wall Street sees a silver lining: More prescriptions and patients going to the hospital could provide a lift for various health care companies. Specifically in the cough, cold and flu category, prescriptions grew nearly 20% year-over-year in December, according to a recent report by Raymond James analysts. That demand is also expected to continue “as experts anticipate flu season getting worse over the next couple months,” RBC Capital Markets analyst George Hill said. For the drug supply chain, “catching cold is a good thing,” Hill said, citing CVS Health Corp. CVS, -0.80% Walgreens Boots Alliance WBA, -3.14%  and Rite Aid Corp. RAD, +0.60%  as particular beneficiaries. Other drug supply chain companies include distributors AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94%  and McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% Read: This year’s flu season could be the most deadly in years — and the most expensive Flu season is typically a trend that affects prescription drug volume at this time of year. For example, an active flu season drove prescribing in 2013, while a weak flu season in late 2011 and early 2013 did the opposite, Raymond James analysts noted in a recent report. Hospitals also experienced growth this past December, with the flu likely driving higher emergency room and inpatient admissions, according to a J.P. Morgan hospital survey released on Wednesday. J.P. Morgan Because of the flu’s geographic spread, high flu activity could be expected at hospital chains HCA Healthcare Inc. HCA, -0.15% LifePoint Health Inc. LPNT, -1.67%  and Universal Health Services UHS, -2.45% according to BMO Capital Markets analyst Matt Borsch. However, flu-related business won’t necessarily be profitable across the board, RBC Capital Markets analyst Frank Morgan said. For acute care hospitals, flu is a “lower-revenue and lower-margin business," he said; it’s also a headwind for the senior housing industry. Related: Why the flu vaccine could be getting better CDC via J.P. Morgan One group that certainly don’t benefit from flu season: Health insurers. The severe season “will drive hospital admissions, creating a short-term headwind for Payers and tailwind for Providers,” said BMO Capital Markets’ Borsch. “While we expect impact on both sides will be modest, recent comments by CNC imply it may be material,” referring to Centene Corp. CNC, +6.50% It also likely played into UnitedHealth Group Inc.’s UNH, -2.06%  slight medical-loss ratio miss recently — the measure represents how much an insurer spends on health services — and higher guidance for the measure, said Leerink Partners analyst Ana Gupte. (UnitedHealth reported fourth-quarter profit and revenue that beat expectations on Tuesday.) Related: Running scared this flu season? 7 things you shouldn’t touch — including soap Centene and WellCare Health Plans Inc. WCG, +1.77%  could have higher flu activity among members based on their regional footprints, while for Molina Healthcare Inc. MOH, +2.64%  it may be slightly lower, Borsch said. “That said, flu impact does not change our bias for Payers over Providers and we remain specifically bullish on CNC (our top pick),” Borsch said. The Health Care Select Sector SPDR XLV, +0.76%  has risen 5.5% over the last three months, compared with a 9.3% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  and a 12.8% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Got the flu? Investing in these companies may make you feel better

content: Online retailer Amazon.com Inc., which is reportedly mulling a larger entry into health care, is notorious for its low prices. But when it comes to medical distribution, incumbent industry leader Cardinal Health Inc. said that price is actually its advantage. Because of the distributor’s scale and size, the “price we’re selling at today is significantly, and I mean significantly, lower that what else is out there,” Chief Executive Mike Kaufmann said, adding that “it would be hard” for someone else to beat it. See more: Is Amazon getting into the pharmacy business? This is what you need to know For example, when Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94%  ships gloves to a medical facility, it ships pallets of them rather than boxes, Kaufmann said. Medical products also can’t be commoditized like other retail areas, Cardinal Health management said, since doctors can have very specific preferences. They also suggested that Amazon AMZN, +1.11%  would be at a disadvantage because much of Cardinal Health’s medical segment profits are outside of the U.S. Read: There’s a surprisingly messy backstory to Amazon’s health care quest The remarks, made Monday at the J.P. Morgan Health Care Conference in San Francisco, the largest industry conference of the year, illustrate the way that Amazon’s potential entry into the sector continues to cast a pall over Cardinal Health and other health-care distributors. In a presentation at the conference, Kaufmann — the company’s newly-minted CEO — emphasized the range of services that Cardinal Health offers, including medical and surgical products “distributed five times a week in semi-truck loads,” inventory management services and generic and specialty medications, among other things. Shares of Cardinal Health and rivals AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  and McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  have been pressured by reports of a possible Amazon entry — even though Amazon hasn’t even confirmed an interest in the space, and it’s unclear what shape such a move would take. Amazon did not immediately return MarketWatch’s request for comment. Related: Amazon wants to disrupt the neighborhood pharmacy—but its sketchy health products could get in the way In November, Morgan Stanley declared Cardinal Health most at risk in the case of an Amazon entry, followed by McKesson, because of their earnings exposure risk. Cardinal Health stock fell significantly between April and late November, but has recovered somewhat since then. Cardinal Health shares rose 3% on Monday and have declined 1% in the past three months, compared with a nearly 8% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  and an 11% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07%  . More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’
title: Cardinal Health fires back at Amazon health-care threat: You can’t beat our prices

content: Online retailer Amazon.com Inc. has a reputation for a take-no-prisoners approach in its disruption of new industries. However, in its entry into health care distribution, which is rife with regulatory complexity, the online retailer has stumbled quite a bit, records obtained by MarketWatch show. Amid speculation about Amazon AMZN, +1.11%  having bigger health care ambitions, the paper trail also reveals a surprisingly chaotic backstory to Amazon’s work in this area, suggesting its dominance there is not as inevitable as has been assumed. Amazon was denied a pharmacy board license in California early this year because it did not meet a regulatory requirement, for example, and applied for one in Maine, even though the state doesn’t license device distributors. The records show that “in the short term, Amazon doesn’t have the ability to disrupt this supply chain,” Nicodemo Fiorentino, a pharmaceutical and medical device regulatory expert, told MarketWatch. “Right now it’s a mess.” Related: Amazon wants to disrupt the neighborhood pharmacy—but its sketchy health products could get in the way The threat of Amazon’s health care expansion — especially into the realm of pharmaceutical drugs — has pressured stocks of companies in the pharmaceutical supply chain for months. But when asked about its health care plans, Amazon has previously cited its practice of “declining to comment on rumors and speculation.” Recent applications for licenses from state pharmacy boards, 13 total as of late June, seemed to confirm that Amazon was expanding into health care. They included general manufacturer or wholesaler licenses, licenses that specify medical devices and ones that specify drug distribution, and were issued as early as October 2016. Read: Is Amazon getting into the pharmacy business? This is what you need to know But Amazon told MarketWatch that the licenses were for Amazon’s professional-use products, which are sold to hospitals and medical and dental offices and include such products as syringes, point-of-care tests and dental tools. The program is currently available in many, but not all U.S. states, according to Amazon’s website. States have different licensing requirements for companies that want to distribute health care products. But what a license actually covers varies by state, and some states — about half — don’t even license non-resident device distributors, Fiorentino said. Maine is one of those states. In various parts of its Maine pharmacy board application, Amazon said that it is interested in distributing prescription medical devices. Why Competing With Netflix and Amazon Is Impossible Maine then canceled Amazon’s license application — possibly because the state simply doesn’t license device distributors, Fiorentino said. Amazon also faced trouble in Utah, failing to provide fingerprints for two individuals as part of the company’s application. Utah’s licensing division thus gave Amazon a conditional denial in April, saying the application was incomplete, records show. In California, the state’s pharmacy board wouldn’t process Amazon’s licensing application any further because it had not met a regulatory requirement for its three Indiana facilities. See: Amazon is pressuring drug stocks without lifting a finger The crux of the problem: Indiana does not license medical device wholesalers, and California’s licensing process requires companies to have what’s called a “home state license.” There are ways — albeit complicated and/or expensive — to move past this, and Amazon can always reapply for the California licenses, Fiorentino told MarketWatch. But the company now needs to disclose its California denial on state license applications, like it did on the Maine one, and that does hurt them, he said. The Indiana facilities could prove problematic for licensing in other states too, he added. “Between Maine and California, it’s like — whoever is in charge of this process for Amazon, do they actually know what they’re doing?” Fiorentino said. Amazon has struggled to break into highly regulated markets, including China and has a limited presence in U.S. alcohol distribution, Mizuho analyst Ann Hynes has noted. Read: Is Amazon serious about getting into pharmacy? This analyst isn’t so sure This should make Amazon look less threatening to pharmaceutical supply chain rivals like distributors McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% Fiorentino said, since “Amazon lacks the capability to even operate in this area,” at least for now. More from MarketWatch S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you
title: There’s a surprisingly messy backstory to Amazon’s health care quest

content: Shares of generic drug manufacturers rose Friday following a report Amazon.com Inc. has held conversations with Mylan NV and Sandoz, a Novartis AG unit, about potentially entering the pharmacy market. Meanwhile, drugstores, pharmacy-benefit managers, and distributors are seeing their stocks fall amid concerns that Amazon will provide new competition and disrupt their business models. CNBC reported late Thursday that the Mylan and Sandoz have engaged in “high level” talks and added that it is still unclear what Amazon’s AMZN, +1.11%  pharmacy ambitions are. “This means that Amazon may be simultaneously exploring either opening a retail pharmacy or drug distribution business,” analyst Brian Nowak at Morgan Stanley wrote in a note to clients. He said the next potential signposts to watch for are Amazon opening a pharmacy inside a Whole Foods Market store and a filing for pharmacy and drug licenses. Don’t miss: Amazon’s getting into the pharmacy business is a ‘matter of when, not if.’ Also read: Amazon wants to disrupt the neighborhood pharmacy--but its sketchy health products could get in the way. Mylan’s MYL, +1.65%  stock shot up 4.4% to a three-week closing high, while Novartis’ NVS, -0.49%  shares edged up 0.3%. Time (EDT)Mylan N.V.10:0011:0012:001:002:003:004:00 US:MYL $40.25 $40.50 $40.75 $41.00 $41.25 Among others in the generic drug business, shares of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries TEVA, +0.29%  hiked up 3.0% and Endo International ENDP, +1.71% ENDP, +1.71% ENDP, +1.71% rallied 1.4%. Among drugstore chains, shares of Rite Aid Corp. RAD, +0.60%  slumped 4.5%, Walgreens Boots Alliance WBA, -3.14% shed 1.8% and CVS Health Corp. CVS, -0.80%  dropped 1.9%. Shares of distributors were mostly lower, as McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% was down 0.9% and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% gave up 0.5%, while Amerisource Bergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% erased early losses to close up 0.2%. Pharmacy-benefit manager Express Scripts ESRX, -0.93%  is considered by some to be a potential partner for Amazon, but its stock fell 1.2%. “The economics around generic drugs are unique within the supply chain and might make them more attractive for Amazon than trying to sell other brand or specialty drugs where prices are set and then negotiated by pharmacy-benefit managers,” wrote Needham analyst Kevin Caliendo in a note to clients. He added that Amazon “still likely will need to acquire a mail order pharmacy or small pharmacy benefit manager to get the licenses needed to distribute and/or dispense drugs on a state-by-state basis.” Amazon’s stock fell 1.2% Friday. It was still up 55% so far in 2017, compared with an 18 % gain for the S&P 500 index SPX, +1.38% Here's what winning Amazon's new HQ will do to real estate prices More from MarketWatch Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots
title: Mylan and Teva stocks rise on report about Amazon’s pharmacy aims

content: Amazon.com: books, music, movies, apparel, food — and prescription medicine? A report earlier this year that the massive online retailer was mulling a pharmaceutical-industry entry has had observers all aflutter. Amazon’s AMZN, +1.11% nearly $14 billion acquisition of Whole Foods, announced in June and closed just over two months later, sparked speculation that the grocery chain might soon house pharmacy locations. Though Amazon itself has not confirmed a potential expansion into pharmaceuticals, the possibility has sent stocks of pharmaceutical middlemen south on more than one occasion. “Amazon has shown that they have mastery of the technology and innovative approaches to really transform how the marketplace delivers product,” said Linda Pissott Reig, who co-chairs the FDA section of the Pittsburgh-based law firm Buchanan, Ingersoll & Rooney PC. The move could also have wider implications for consumers. Amazon could use de-identified big data to then see if, for example, “a patient with depression is also seeking out self-help books, or particular products,” she said. “Amazon, with a giant marketplace, has a lot of ability to collect information.” Related: Amazon wants to disrupt the neighborhood pharmacy—but its sketchy health products could get in the way Why the prospect of Amazon’s entry to this new market is important: After transforming such industries as publishing, consumer electronics and cloud services — and decimating key players along the way — Amazon has built a reputation for dominance. But part of the wide interest in an Amazon pharmacy is that the highly regulated drug business has never been particularly transparent. At best, U.S. drug pricing is complex; at worst, it’s dysfunctional. Those who are skeptical of Amazon’s potential pharmacy entry have noted Amazon’s difficulty breaking into highly regulated markets, including alcohol distribution in the U.S. Industry leaders have brought up similar points. For one, CVS Health Corp. CVS, -0.80% Chief Executive Larry Merlo told Wall Street analysts in August that his industry was “highly regulated, so the barriers to entry are high.” CNBC, which first reported on Amazon’s pharmacy plans in May, reported Friday that Amazon would make a decision before Thanksgiving. Given that time table, expect the question to crop up again this earnings season. Read more: Amazon’s Whole Foods deal pummels pharmaceutical stocks Amazon is buying Whole Foods: What you need to know What companies could be affected: Though Amazon’s involvement could presumably affect any and all parts of the pharmaceutical supply chain, including drug makers, it’s most threatening to retail pharmacy chains like Walgreens Boots Alliance WBA, -3.14%  , CVS and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT, +1.37%  , according to Leerink Partners analyst Ana Gupte. That’s because Amazon is expected to begin getting cash-pay and mail-order customers, eventually moving into the pharmacy-benefits manager and retail pharmacy business, Gupte said. CVS, though, might be able to leverage its pharmacy-benefit manager unit to reduce its risk, said Leerink Partners analyst David Larsen. Anticipated competition from Amazon could also prompt pharmacies to diversify their offerings, Morgan Stanley analyst Ricky Goldwasser said this summer, including offering lab services like blood tests. Middlemen called pharmacy-benefit managers (PBMs), which work with drug makers to negotiate prices on behalf of health insurers and employers, are another player expected to be affected. They are not a well-known part of the U.S. pharmaceutical system but have come under scrutiny in the last year amid public outrage over drug costs. Because PBMs negotiate discounts from drugs’ total cost, critics charge that they also push prices higher to make their discounts appear more favorable. Leerink Partners Amazon poses “both an opportunity and a threat” for Express Scripts Holding Company, the largest stand-alone PBM, Gupte said. Express Scripts announced on Tuesday that it will buy privately-held medical benefit management company eviCore healthcare for $3.6 billion, a move that some saw as a response to the Amazon threat. Meanwhile, PBMs that are part of UnitedHealth Group UNH, -2.06% and Humana Inc. HUM, +0.48% will be more shielded, Gupte said. Drug distributors such as McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  , AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% will likely have less exposure in the near term, according to Leerink’s Larsen. See: Amazon is pressuring drug stocks without lifting a finger and Amazon could push more pharmacies into offering lab tests Reasons for skepticism: A recent report that Amazon had obtained approval to become a wholesale distributors in several states sent pharmaceutical supply chain stocks down again in late October. But scrutiny of those approvals by the investment firm Jefferies found something important: Correspondence between two state pharmacy boards and Amazon showed that those state licenses could only be used for medical device and supplies distribution. That doesn’t rule out a pharmaceutical entry, but it does suggest that Amazon is starting with other, potentially easier medical products. Read: Amazon homing in on medical devices/supplies, not pharma: Jefferies Mizuho analyst Ann Hynes is another skeptic. Before acquiring Whole Foods this year, Amazon had talked about entering the grocery industry for more than a decade, Hynes noted. By contrast, Amazon hasn’t mentioned pharmacy on its earnings call in the past decade, Hynes said. In addition, even after CNBC reported on the online retailer’s purported plan, the company did not list any pharmacy-related jobs, Hynes said. And, if the company did decide to move into pharmacy, “there is no obvious asset to buy,” Hynes said. Read: Amazon’s getting into the pharmacy business is a ‘matter of when, not if’ | Also: Is Amazon serious about getting into pharmacy? This analyst isn’t so sure Amazon would need to either build or buy pharmacy capabilities, Gupte said, and could target a smaller player like specialty pharmacy Avella or acquire a larger entity. Many companies might also want to partner with Amazon, Leerink’s Gupte said, including the Blue Cross Blue Shield PBM unit Prime Therapeutics, “to enhance its drug discounts and mail penetration.” So might Express Scripts and Walgreens, Larsen said. Walgreens shares fell 3.4% in Oct. 9 trade after the CNBC report, CVS shares declined 3.5%, Wal-Mart shares rose 2.7% and shares of Express Scripts plummeted 4.9%. Shares of the companies have dropped 13.4%, 11.7%, risen 12.4% and dropped 1.9% over the last three months, respectively, compared with a 4.5% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  . More from MarketWatch BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid 2 sexy ways to get paid to save
title: Is Amazon getting into the pharmacy business? This is what you need to know

content: U.S. stock-market indexes ended at records and near session highs on Tuesday, finding support on another round of strong earnings, with technology shares leading the way. Investors focused on a number of corporate earnings and positive economic data. Trading volumes were expected to thin out this week as investors prepare for the long weekend following Thanksgiving holiday. What are the main benchmarks doing? The S&P 500 index SPX, +1.38%  rose 16.89 points, or 0.7%, to close at a record 2,599.03. Nearly all the main sectors traded higher, with the technology and health-care stocks leading the gains. The Nasdaq Composite COMP, +1.64% advanced 71.76 points, or 1.1%, to finish at 6,862.48, also setting a record. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07%  rose 160.5 points, or 0.7%, to post an all-time closing high of 23,590.83, with 26 of its 30 components trading higher. Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78%  was leading the gains, up 1.9%. The three equity benchmarks are up between 16% and nearly 28% for the year, helped by factors such as an expanding U.S. economy, growth in corporate profits and bets that the Trump administration will deliver tax cuts and other business-friendly policies. What are strategists saying? “Today’s gains have all of the hallmarks of short covering by traders who positioned conservatively after two weeks of declines,” said Michael Antonelli, equity sales trader at Robert W. Baird & Co. Antonelli noted that historically the week of Thanksgiving is positive. What could help drive markets? The Chicago Fed national activity index rose to 0.65 in October from 0.36 in September. Sales of previously-owned homes jumped to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 5.48 million in October. Read: Will millenials give housing shares and the broader stock market a boost It appeared investors shrugged off news that Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen would leave the central bank, rather than stay on as a Fed governor after the confirmation of Jerome Powell. Yellen’s decision was widely expected. Check out: MarketWatch’s Economic Calendar At 6 p.m. Eastern, Yellen is scheduled to take part in an event with former Bank of England Gov. Mervyn King at New York University’s business school. Which stocks look like key movers? Technology stocks were the biggest winner on Wall Street. The Technology Select Sector SPDR ETF XLK, +1.98%  rose 1.1%. Specialty retailer Signet Jewelers Ltd. SIG, +0.76%  tumbled more than 30% after posting weaker-than-expected earnings before the open. Home-improvement chain Lowe’s Cos. LOW, +2.18%  shares fell 1.1% after disappointing results. Discount retailer Dollar Tree Inc. DLTR, +1.05%  gained 2.4% after its stronger-than-anticipated results. Packaged-foods heavyweights Hormel Foods Corp. HRL, +1.96%  and Campbell Soup Co. CPB, -0.23% also released results. Campbell shed more than 8%, while Hormel jumped 3.4%. Medical-device maker Medtronic PLC MDT, +2.24% posted earnings before the open as well, beating forecasts. The stock rallied 4.8%. Shares in Intuit Inc. INTU, +1.42%  traded 3.8% lower. The maker of TurboTax and other accounting software posted better-than-expected quarterly results late Monday, but some analysts said the company’s guidance was disappointing. Agilent Technologies Inc. A, +0.75%  fell 0.1% after the maker of scientific equipment late Monday posted better-than-anticipated quarterly earnings but gave a profit forecast that fell short of expectations. Earnings preview: Analyst surveys point to a strong quarter for Salesforce Shares in AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  rose 2.6% after the drug distributor late Monday agreed to buy independent wholesaler H.D. Smith for $815 million. What are other assets doing? European stocks SXXP, +0.44% ended higher, with Germany’s DAX index closing at a two-week high. Asian markets mostly closed with gains. Gold futures US:GCZ7  regained some ground lost in a steep Monday selloff, while oil futures US:CLJ8  rose modestly. The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, -0.02% was slightly weaker. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Stock-market indexes post another round of records after strong earnings

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said late Monday it agreed to acquire independent wholesaler H.D. Smith for $815 million cash. The pharmaceuticals distributor, which plans to issue long-term debt for the deal, said it expects the acquisition to add slightly to earnings in fiscal 2018, and now expects revenue to grow by 8% to 11%. AmerisourceBergen said it expects the acquisition to add about 15 cents a share to earnings in fiscal 2020. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect full-year fiscal 2018 earnings of $6.06 a share and revenue of $164.94 billion, a 7.7% increase from the previous year. The company expects the deal to close in early 2018. AmerisourceBergen shares were flat at $77.46 after hours.
title: AmerisourceBergen to acquire H.D. Smith for $815 million

content: The possibility of online retailer Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +1.11% entering the pharmaceutical industry has sent the stocks of drug distributors and pharmacy-benefit managers quaking in recent months, but a new report from Jefferies analysts suggests that Amazon is instead homing for the medical devices and supplies industries. Correspondence between two state pharmacy boards and Amazon reveals that those state licenses can only be used for medical device and supplies distribution, the Jefferies report said, based on information that was obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. This direction was likely chosen to avoid "the more comprehensive regulatory requirements associated with the Wholesale Drug Distribution Act," Jefferies analyst Brian Tanquilut said. That has created an overhang on stocks like AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% Express Scripts Holding Co. ESRX, -0.93% CVS Health Corp. CVS, -0.80% and Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc. WBA, -3.14% ; "Unfortunately, we believe only time will refute these investor concerns," he said. Amazon shares have surged 15% over the last three months, compared with a 4.5% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% and a 6.6% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% Read the full story: Is Amazon getting into the pharmacy business? This is what you need to know
title: Amazon homing in on medical devices/supplies, not pharma: Jefferies

content: Generic drugmakers and drug distributors' shares sunk in Thursday trade after Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. TEVA, +0.29% reported worse price erosion for generic drugs in the latest quarter and lowered its 2017 guidance. Teva shares plummeted nearly 18%, while fellow generic drugmakers Perrigo Co. PRGO, +0.90% and Teligent Inc. TLGT, -1.75% fell 1.3% and 4.2% respectively. The VanEck Vectors Generic Drugs ETF GNRX, -1.31% fell 0.3%. Shares of drug distributors, which are also affected by cheaper generic drugs, also dropped: McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% shares fell 1.7%, AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% dropped 3.6% and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% dropped 1.8%. Thursday marks the second occasion that Teva earnings have sparked a selloff for generic drugmakers and the pharmaceutical supply chain. Teva shares have plummeted 62.8% over the last three months, compared with a 4.2% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%
title: Generic drugmakers, distributor shares slide after Teva reports worse pricing environment

content: The stocks of companies in the pharmaceutical supply chain dropped in Thursday afternoon trade after a report by the St. Louis Post-Dispatch that online retailer Amazon AMZN, +1.11% has obtained approval to become a wholesale distributor in a number of states. Amazon has received approval in at least 12 states, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported. Speculation about an Amazon pharmacy entry has swirled since a CNBC report on the subject earlier this year, but Amazon has repeatedly declined to comment on or confirm any interest in pharmacy. Such a move would likely threaten a number of industry players, including drug wholesalers, pharmacy chains and pharmacy-benefit managers, middlemen that negotiate drug prices. Rite Aid Corp. RAD, +0.60% shares dropped 5.6% in Thursday afternoon trade, CVS Health Corp. CVS, -0.80% shares dropped 4.8%, Express Scripts Holding Company ESRX, -0.93% shares dropped 3.5%, McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% shares dropped 3.4%, AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% shares dropped 4.4%, Walgreens Boots Alliance shares dropped 3.7% WBA, -3.14% and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% shares dropped 2.5%, compared with a 0.2% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% Many of the stocks have plunged in the last several months on concerns about Amazon.
title: Drug stocks drop after report that Amazon has obtained pharmacy licenses

content: Have you ever heard a CEO drone on during a conference call with analysts? There’s jargon, there’s mangled English and there’s double-speak. It turns out that executives’ comments and behavior during those calls can be linked to subsequent stock performance. That was the finding of a study by S&P Global Market Intelligence Quantamental Research on what’s called natural language processing (NLP). As an example, here’s Stephen J. Luczo, Seagate Technology PLC’s STX, +2.87% former chairman and CEO (and now executive chairman) on a quarterly earnings call April 26: “I think from our perspective, we’ve always viewed this business as attractive in terms of its core business of selling into OEMs as well as servicing cloud service providers at one level, but really the opportunity to, I think, as architectures evolve and different customer needs evolve, to have the capability to optimize the devices either at the device level, at the subsystem level or the systems level, and if you do not have the software capability to do that, you really cannot take advantage of what we think would be a potentially significant long-term trend.” And here’s how the stock performed between April 25 and Oct. 9: FactSet His abuse of the English language was not enough, by itself, to signal problems with Seagate’s business (sliding sales) or the company’s shares. The research was led by David Pope, managing director of Quantamental Research, and Frank Zhao, its director. Here’s a link to the full research report. The scope of the work encompassed S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  companies’ earnings calls during four calendar quarters, through the second quarter of 2017. It tracked the tone of language, for example highlighting “troubling words,” such as “litigation” and “adjusted.” Also see: This company is parsing earnings calls to identify the speech patterns that move stock prices The researchers scored the complexity of the language used by executives. They went further, using the recorded transcripts to track executives’ pauses, repetition of words and other factors to incorporate the “tone” of the call into their statistical analysis. “Academic research shows when management is trying to hide bad news, they use language that is not easily understood. In so doing, they eat up time, so there is less time for the Q&A with the analysts on the call,” Pope said in an interview Oct. 9. “Only 20% of communication is verbal,” he said, highlighting the importance of the analysis of earnings call “metadata” for pauses and other indicators. Complexity of language and analyst engagement This scatter graph plots the percentage of sell-side analysts who were called upon to ask questions against the complexity of language used during the earnings calls that took place in the second quarter: S&P Global Market Intelligence Quantamental Research Seagate Technology is highlighted for having a high “complexity” score for the language used by executives, who called upon only 14% of analysts for questions. Meanwhile, Franklin Resources Inc. BEN, +1.67%  is highlighted for having a low complexity score, and executives invited 92% of analysts to ask questions. Here are the 10 S&P 500 companies that were highest in the rankings of calls for complexity and analyst engagement during calls that took place in the second calendar quarter: Company Ticker Composite percentile (higher is better) Date of conference call Total return - last close before the call through Oct. 9 Hormel Foods Corp. SLB, +2.48% 5.70% 4/21/2017 -9.3% Realty Income Corp. O, +0.37% 5.75% 4/26/2017 -2.2% Baker Hughes, a GE Co. BHGE, -1.07% 5.81% 4/25/2017 -0.3% Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. CMG, +1.13% 6.45% 4/25/2017 -34.1% Source: S&P Global Market Intelligence Quantamental Research “The big picture is that firms whose executives exercised more analyst selectivity [i.e., called on a smaller proportion of Wall Street analysts] underperformed by about 2% relative to those firms whose executives called on a greater proportion of their analysts,” Zhao said. “This observed relationship shows that management’s transparency, using the analyst selectivity ratio as a proxy, may have potential power to forecast future stock returns,” he said. Earnings call sentiment changes by industry Here’s a heat map, ranking the 24 S&P GICS industry groups in the S&P 500, by the change in sentiment determined from Pope and Zhao’s research: S&P Global Market Intelligence Quantamental Research The research is part of S&P Global Market Intelligence’s products offered to institutional investors. For retail investors, the research results underline the importance of paying attention to how companies communicate with their shareholders and analysts. Clear communication and transparency can be a good sign if you own a company’s shares or are considering an investment. title: There’s a link between CEOs who torture the English language and poor stock performance

content: Whether online retailer Amazon plans to enter the pharmacy-services space has been the subject of speculation for months, and Leerink analyst David Larsen is now going public with his position on the will-it-or-won’t-it question. “It’s a matter of when, not if,” Larsen said, adding that he expects an announcement in the next year or two. “While AMZN AMZN, +1.11% is likely still researching what its ultimate strategy should look like, with [approximately 75 million] Amazon Prime lives, seemingly unlimited resources, and highly advanced technology capabilities, we believe [Amazon] can create disruption to the existing market.” As such, Larsen said he’s more cautious about pharmacy-benefit managers and retail pharmacies, both major players in the pharmaceutical supply chain. Pharmacy retailers such as Walgreens Boots Alliance WBA, -3.14% and RiteAid Corp. RAD, +0.60% face the biggest threat for now, he said, while companies like CVS Health Corp. CVS, -0.80% may be able to leverage pharmacy-benefit-manager services to reduce risk. CNBC reported later Friday that an Amazon entry is “very much an ‘if’ and not a ‘when,’” adding that the company will decide by Thanksgiving whether to move into the industry. Don’t miss: Every time this happens, Amazon crushes another legacy retailer Express Scripts Holding Co. ESRX, -0.93%  , the largest stand-alone pharmacy-benefit manager, may be willing to partner with Amazon since it “has been facing deteriorating mail volumes for years and [Amazon’s] technology in our view could be the strategy needed to improve performance,” Larsen said. So might Walgreens, he said, through some kind of retail partnership. Drug distributors like McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  , AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% are likely to have less exposure in the near term, according to Larsen. See: Amazon’s Whole Foods deal pummels pharmaceutical stocks The easiest initial target for Amazon would likely be generic medications, which are lower-cost than so-called specialty medications and make up a majority of prescriptions, Larsen said. An estimated 5% to 10% of U.S. individuals pay cash for their prescriptions, he said, and Amazon could potentially offer a drug discount program to those customers. There also might be an avenue into specialty pharmacy through an acquisition, Larsen said, based on conversations with specialists from consulting services firm MEDACorp. Amazon’s acquisition of Whole Foods in June sparked investor concerns that the store’s physical presence would provide Amazon an opening into the pharmacy category. Read more: Amazon is pressuring drug stocks without lifting a finger And: Is Amazon serious about getting into pharmacy? This analyst isn’t so sure But Larsen’s analysis suggested that Amazon’s mail capacity and online services constitute a greater advantage, though he did note that the company could open pharmacies inside Whole Foods stores. “We’re surprised to learn that it would take just [one or two] years to build a [pharmacy-benefits manager],” Larsen said. “There is significant mail capacity and there are claims platforms available that [Amazon] could use.” Further, “we do not believe that Amazon has to win a massive amount of [market] share to keep pressure on the pharmacy supply chain,” Larsen said, “rather ongoing reimbursement competition and discussions on drug pricing may be enough to keep pressure on the group.” Related: Amazon could push more pharmacies into offering lab tests Not all of Wall Street is sold, though. Mizuho analyst Ann Hynes has long maintained she doesn’t see any sign that Amazon has plans to get into pharmacy services. The company doesn’t appear to have posted any pharmacy-related jobs, and it hasn’t mentioned the industry on any of its earnings calls over the last decade, according to Hynes. The Health Care Select Sector SPDR exchange-traded fund XLV, +0.76% has risen 5.3% over the past three months, as compared with a 5.6% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  . Read on: Amazon has gotten so big the government might do something about it More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots
title: Amazon’s getting into the pharmacy business is a ‘matter of when, not if’

content: Given the precarious health of the global economy, owning quality stocks is paramount. Among my favorite high-quality companies right now is pharmaceutical powerhouse McKesson. McKesson MCK, +0.15%  is one of the top three drug distributors in the U.S. McKesson, Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94%  , and AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% collectively control more than 90% of the pharmaceuticals distribution market. The fact that all three companies are of similar size is critical to the stability of their industry — and accordingly to McKesson’s long-term earnings growth. That’s because when an industry is dominated by a few companies of different sizes, a smaller player may feel it is at a competitive disadvantage and launch a price war (forgoing short-term profitability) to gain additional market share — and thus undermine a predictable pricing structure. The wireless sector in the U.S. is a great example of this. There are four major players, but AT&T T, +0.25%   and Verizon Communications VZ, -0.37%   are double the size of T-Mobile TMUS, +0.28%  and Sprint S, +0.41%  . After Sprint’s overture to buy T-Mobile was blocked by regulators, T-Mobile initiated a price war that, combined with its creative marketing, allowed it to steal customers from both Verizon and AT&T — a win for consumers, but it flatlined AT&T and Verizon earnings. Back to drug distributors. Since all the players are approximately the same size, a price war is unlikely — though there may be healthy short-term flare-ups of competition. Read more: Amazon is pressuring drug stocks without lifting a finger My firm has owned both Cardinal Health and McKesson (more than once) in the past and knows these businesses well. Think of these companies as railroads for prescription- and generic drugs in the U.S. Pfizer, PFE, +0.54%   for instance, doesn’t want to deal with hundreds of pharmacies, nor does it have the scale to do so. Instead, Pfizer pays McKesson a small fee to distribute its drugs to pharmacies and hospitals. TimeMcKesson Corp.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:MCK $140 $150 $160 $170 The drug distribution industry was affected by a deceleration of price inflation for pharmaceuticals during the second half of 2016 — it was election season, and pharma companies did not want to give politicians any extra ammunition. (Mylan MYL, +1.65%  and a few others had done plenty of that already.) You may hate this as an consumer, but price inflation for pharmaceuticals is a fact of life. We are less likely to see EpiPen-like increases going forward, but on its most recent earnings call McKesson projected mid- to high-single-digit price inflation for branded drugs. How to invest in the future of health care Here’s how we view McKesson: an oligopoly-like business with a high return on capital, a terrific balance sheet (it could pay off all of its debt in one year), and great cash flows. It is organically growing revenue 5% to 6% a year and returning cash to shareholders through share buybacks and dividends. Let’s focus on cash flows a bit more. McKesson generates about $3 billion a year of free-cash flows — cash earnings that are left after a company has paid all of its ongoing expenses and invested in fixed assets (equipment, buildings, etc.) required to maintain its current earnings power. The beauty of McKesson’s business is that it doesn’t consume a lot of capital, so incremental growth doesn’t cost much. The company can grow revenue and net income 5% to 6% a year without much incremental investment. McKesson’s management has several options for what it can do with $3 billion of free-cash flows. It can increase the dividend (McKesson pays a small dividend of 0.8% that it has promised to raise over time); it can buy back stock if it is cheap (McKesson has done some of that); it can pay down debt (the company has little debt, so paying that down is not a high priority); or, finally, it can make acquisitions that will add to McKesson’s growth. (McKesson has made acquisitions from time to time.) If McKesson management spends its cash wisely on dividends, buying back stock, or making acquisitions, then 5% to 6% organic growth will accelerate to the mid-teens. If McKesson management spends its cash wisely on dividends, buying back stock, or making acquisitions, then 5% to 6% organic growth will accelerate to the mid-teens. McKesson is a growing, high-quality business, and we paid only about 10 times earnings, or less than half of what the stock market is paying for the privilege of owning Coca-Cola KO, +0.25%   I would like to zoom in deeper on what may appear to be a small analytic shift that we’ve been making at my firm, though it’s one we believe is highly significant: We have become dogmatic about quality. It is now an uncompromising filter in our analysis. If a company doesn’t pass our quality filter, we stop — we don’t bother with the valuation and growth dimensions. Passing the quality test doesn’t mean a company is a buy, but it earns a stock the right to be examined for valuation and growth. Read:  This rocky stock market requires an all-terrain portfolio So, how does one invest in this overvalued market? Our strategy is spelled out in this fairly lengthy article. Vitaliy Katsenelson is chief investment officer at Investment Management Associates in Denver, Colo, which owns shares of McKesson. He is the author of “Active Value Investing” (Wiley) and “The Little Book of Sideways Markets” (Wiley). Read more on Katsenelson’s Contrarian Edge blog. title: This drug industry leader could be healthy for your stock portfolio

content: New Mexico sued several major pharmaceutical companies and wholesale drug distributors on Thursday, arguing the corporations are partly to blame for rampant opioid addiction rates in the state. The lawsuit, filed in state court in Santa Fe County, follows the lead of half a dozen other states that have also sued over the opioid crisis. All claim pharmaceutical companies played down the addictive risk of the painkillers in their marketing to the public and doctors, causing them to be widely prescribed for chronic pain and fueling addiction. Most of the other states to sue, including New Hampshire, South Carolina, Ohio and Oklahoma, have focused their claims solely on the pharmaceutical companies. Dozens of cities and counties, meanwhile, have filed litigation against distributors, claiming they unlawfully sold painkillers into the regions and failed to monitor and report suspicious orders. New Mexico is going after both camps. Thursday’s suit names drugmakers Purdue Pharma L.P., Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. TEVA, +0.29%  , Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55%  , Endo International PLC ENDP, +1.71%   and Allergan PLC, distributors AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  , McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  , and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94%  , and various subsidiaries. An expanded version of this report appears on WSJ.com. Popular on WSJ.com: All the nudes that’s fit to print: Burning Man has a newspaper war Amazon seeks prime location for its second headquarters More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date
title: New Mexico sues drugmakers, distributors over opioid crisis

content: Months ago, a report that Amazon has plans to enter the pharmacy business struck fear into investors’ hearts. The company’s Whole Foods acquisition sent the stocks of many in the pharmaceutical supply chain plummeting. But in the time since, “we do not see any signals that suggest AMZN AMZN, +1.11% is building up capabilities internally to enter the pharmacy market,” said Mizuho analyst Ann Hynes, who reiterated buy ratings for CVS Health Corp. CVS, -0.80%  and Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc. WBA, -3.14% and a neutral rating for Rite Aid Corp. RAD, +0.60%  . “We are simply not convinced that Amazon is a real competitive risk for pharmacy.” Shares of pharmaceutical middlemen Walgreens, CVS, McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  , AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% fell after Amazon’s mid-June Whole Foods acquisition on concerns that the online retail giant might pivot Whole Foods into a pharmaceutical distributor. While Amazon has yet to confirm whether it’s weighing an expansion into the pharmacy market, many on Wall Street believe the company needs some type of physical store presence to do so. See more: Amazon’s Whole Foods deal pummels pharmaceutical stocks And yet, Amazon has not listed any pharmacy-related job postings in the last 10 weeks, Hynes said, except for postings that appear related to Amazon’s existing businesses. There have also been “very few” new postings in that period of time, she said, which is notable given that “if Amazon is serious about entering the pharmacy market... any entrance would need to be organic (there is no obvious asset to buy) and any investment would be significant.” Read: Is Amazon serious about getting into pharmacy? This analyst isn’t so sure One July 17 posting for a position that would “own and operate the security and compliance elements of a new healthcare initiative” could be related to an Amazon initiative to sell basic medical products to health care providers, Hynes said, but it isn’t a very detailed post. Previous behavior by the company suggests that it would explore a new industry before a large acquisition, she said, “so do not consider entering the market through M&A as an imminent threat either.” Others on Wall Street are more enthusiastic about an Amazon pharmacy entry. Opinion Journal: How Regulators Helped Amazon Retail pharmacy is a $200 to $300 million market that Amazon could disrupt by “eliminating 70,000 retail locations and related staffing and other expenses, replaced by automated distribution centers with efficient pharmacist oversight,” said Bernstein analyst Lance Wilkes in August. Another advantage Amazon could have is “an easy-to-use user interface, which we believe is an Amazon strength which leverages the existing Amazon capabilities.” The company could achieve this by partnering with large pharmacy-benefit managers or disrupting both the PBM and retail pharmacy business model, Wilkes said. Related: Amazon could push more pharmacies into offering lab tests A possible Amazon entry “is still an overhang on the retail sector,” Mizuho’s Hynes said, citing the performance of CVS and Walgreens shares since a mid-May CNBC report that Amazon was mulling a pharmacty entry. Amazon also hasn’t mentioned pharmacy on its earnings calls in the last decade, according to Hynes. Before it acquired Whole Foods, the company talked consistently about entering the grocery industry for more than a decade, she said. Amazon shares have declined 4% over the last three months, compared with a 1% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  . In the last three months, CVS shares have risen 2%, McKesson shares have plummeted 6%, AmerisourceBergen shares have plummeted 12%, Cardinal Health shares have dropped 7%, Walgreens shares have risen 0.4% and Rite Aid shares have plummeted 29%. Express Scripts Holding Company ESRX, -0.93%  shares have risen nearly 4% over the last three months, and shares of UnitedHealth Group Inc. UNH, -2.06%  , which has a pharmacy-benefit manager unit, rose nearly 8%. title: Amazon is pressuring drug stocks without lifting a finger

content: Editor’s note: This has been updated to reflect Mylan’s earnings, published on Wednesday. Dividend-chasing is in vogue. Given low interest rates, many investors say they have no other choice. Such thinking leads to costly mistakes. It just badly hurt those who had bought shares of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries TEVA, +0.29%  because of its high dividend yield. This isn’t just an issue for Teva investors, of course. There are many companies whose share price is being held up by dividend chasers. Take what happened in this case, however, as a reminder to review your portfolio and then sell those dividend-paying stocks where underlying businesses are deteriorating. In the case of Teva, the warning signs were certainly there, but investors who were focused on the dividend missed them. Click here to see an annotated chart. The chart also shows the points when the “smart money” was selling into the strength generated by dividend chasers. On the surface, the dividend yield looked attractive. Not only did the company pay a good dividend, but it was passing other screens that many investors use. These include the longevity of the dividend, dividend growth and the payout ratio, which is the share of net income that is paid in dividends. The chart shows the point when the dividend yield reached 4.5%. But all wasn’t well at Teva, which is best known for its generic-drug business but also has a branded (or not generic) drugs unit. Prices on generic drugs have been under pressure, and its main branded drug, Copaxone, was facing patent challenges. While Teva’s business showed signs of improvement at the end of 2016, that quickly disappeared, and it became clearer that competitors would succeed in a long-running patent battle over Copaxone, a treatment for multiple sclerosis. Read: Teva shares fall as court invalidates patent infringement claims Anyone who looked forward could see the risk to the stock price and the dividend because profits could plunge. The stock price, however, generally remained in the $30s as dividends provided the support. Read: Why Teva stock isn’t moving on its major Huntington’s disease drug approval Only when the company missed fiscal second-quarter profit expectations and slashed its full-year outlook earlier this month did the stock plunge. It now trades comfortably under $20. Ask Arora: Nigam Arora answers your questions about investing in stocks, ETFs, bonds, gold and silver, oil and currencies. Have a question? Send it to Nigam Arora. The most common question I am being asked now is why the stock is falling so much. Many investors are shocked that a large-cap blue-chip stock in a business like generic drugs can fall so much on the news. After all, generic drugs aren’t going out of fashion. Read: Weaker generic drug prices hit makers, wholesalers Here are three reasons that explain the magnitude of the fall. •The stock shouldn’t have stayed as high as it did prior to the fall based on fundamentals. The main reason the stock stayed so high was the dividend chasers. •In addition to its genetic business, Teva’s popular Copaxone drug has been a significant contributor to its bottom line. The drug is now coming under generic attack. •Under one scenario, Teva stock can fall to $10. This scenario involves stronger competition for Copaxone and continued deterioration in the generic drug business. Read: Teva’s stock has tumbled over 8 sessions and Morgan Stanley says it could fall 16% more Of course, there is nothing static in the stock market. Things can change on a dime. There is a scenario under which Teva stock can jump back to $30. It involves a new CEO liked by Wall Street, less-than-expected competition for Copaxone and a reversal in the decline of generic drug prices. Other stocks could be at risk Here are the key lessons that investors may want to learn from what happened with Teva: •First and foremost, pay attention to the underlying business. •Stop chasing dividends. •Take a close look at your screens. Your screens may be backward-looking. •Even if you add some readily available forward-looking data, you get no edge because everyone has the same data. Investors need to go beyond the screens and look at the trends in the underlying businesses. •Other stocks are at risk. Makers of generic drugs like Mylan MYL, +1.65% Perrigo PRGO, +0.90%  and Dr. Reddy’s Laboratories RDY, -0.30%  also could see their share prices slump because prices of generic drugs keep falling. On Wednesday, Mylan shares skidded after the company cut its earnings guidance and projected sharp price declines for generic drugs. It also said it would delay its launch of a generic version of Copaxone. Also at risk are companies that act as middlemen such as AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% McKesson MCK, +0.15% Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% and Express Scripts ESRX, -0.93%   because middlemen generate large profits from generic drugs. The bull market and the fashion of dividend chasing is artificially levitating many other stocks across various sectors. Be forewarned. Nigam Arora is an investor, engineer and nuclear physicist by background, has founded two Inc. 500 fastest-growing companies, is the developer of the adaptive ZYX Global Multi Asset Allocation Model and the ZYX Change Method to profit from change in trading and investing. He is the founder of The Arora Report, which publishes four newsletters. All recommended positions are reviewed daily. Nigam can be reached at Nigam@TheAroraReport.com. title: Teva just showed investors the big risk in chasing dividend yields

content: Lower prices for generic drugs, though a boon for consumers, have been challenging drugmakers and other companies in the pharmaceutical supply chain—a trend that isn’t expected to go away soon. Generic drugmaker Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. was the latest casualty this earnings season, reporting generics revenue that was below expectations on Thursday. The NYSE-listed stock TEVA, +0.29% plummeted 17.8% on Thursday and extended its losses on Friday, dropping 9.6% in heavy morning trade. Shares of Teva rivals also fell on Thursday and continued to fall Friday, including Mylan MYL, +1.65%  , Perrigo Co. PRGO, +0.90% , Celltrion 068270, -2.37% , Taisho Pharmaceutical Holdings 4581, +0.10%  , Teligent Inc. TLGT, -1.75% and Dr. Reddy’s Laboratories Ltd. 500124, -1.30% . The VanEck Vectors Generic Drugs ETF GNRX, -1.31%  dropped 4.1% in Thursday trade. Teva cited accelerated price erosion, decreased volume and more Food and Drug Administration generics approvals as among the factors that hurt its generics business performance. See: Teva’s stock plunges on heavy volume after profit miss and slashed outlook The company, which issued downbeat 2017 guidance early this year and warned of headwinds, cut its adjusted earnings-per-share outlook to $4.30 to $4.50 from $4.90 to $5.30 on Thursday. Shares of drug distributors, which are also affected by poor generic price trends, also dropped on Thursday. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% stock plummeted 10.5% in Thursday trade and extended its losses on Friday morning, dropping 1.5%. The company, which reported a third-quarter profit beat and revenue miss early Thursday, said that generic deflation is a big headwind, has not yet eased from high single digits and that the trend may continue into fiscal 2018. The prediction appeared more negative than one made by Cardinal Health on Wednesday. The rival drug distributor said that it expects price deflation to continue through 2017, though to a less extreme extent than in the first half of the year. Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% stock fell 2.3% on Thursday, but was down just 0.5% on Friday. McKesson Corporation MCK, +0.15% stock fell 2.7% on Thursday but was up 0.2% on Friday. Cardinal Health also issued downbeat fiscal 2018 EPS guidance on Wednesday, and has previously said 2018 outlook would reflect generic deflation. Read: Cardinal Health stock drops 7% on downbeat fiscal 2018 guidance Generic EpiPen Coming, and More Generic drugs, with their lower prices, also tend to have thinner margins for pharmaceutical companies that are more easily affected by competition. Over time, their prices tend to go down, though the industry has also been criticized for large price increases on certain products. Read: Why did these generic drugs’ prices jump as much as 85%? After several drug pricing scandals in recent years, the FDA announced in late June that it plans to promote drug competition, including expedited review for generic drug applications. Teva shares have dropped 32.1% over the last three months. The VanEck Vectors Generic Drugs ETF has declined 3.1% over the last three months, compared with a 3.5% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% This story was first published on August 3. It has been updated.
