content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% raised its outlook for the current year as the drug wholesaler reported better-than-expected results for the three months ended in June. The Valley Forge, Pa., company raised its per-share earnings estimate to $5.52 to $5.57 for the fiscal year ending in September, from its previous estimate for per-share profit of $5.44 to $5.54. AmerisourceBergen said the improved outlook reflected its performance in the latest quarter. However, the company also expects its gross profit for the quarter ending in September will remain under pressure from weaker generic pricing trends as well as lower contributions from new generic drugs. In the latest quarter, pharmaceutical distribution revenue grew 8% to $35.4 billion and revenue in its other businesses increased 2.8% to $1.6 billion. The company's performance has been helped by its acquisitions of MWI Veterinary Supply Inc. and PharMEDium Healthcare Holdings Inc. For the period ended June 30, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $349.8 million, or $1.56 a share, up from $214.2 million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding litigation-settlement gains and other items, adjusted per-share earnings rose to $1.37 from $1.20. Revenue increased 7.7% to $36.88 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected per-share profit of $1.27 and revenue of $36.71 billion. Write to Tess Stynes at tess.stynes@wsj.com More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000
title: AmerisourceBergen raises outlook as profit beats

content: The post-Brexit blues didn’t last long. As anyone who has followed the market knows, global equities went on a roller-coaster ride in the wake of Britain’s surprise vote to leave the European Union on June 23. Taking a cue from Europe, stocks in the U.S. rallied hard in the run-up to the results as investors went all-in that the vote would be to “stay,” as indicated by bookmakers, despite polls that showed the result too close to call. The S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  ended at 2,113.32 on June 23, just hours before results began rolling in. The shock “leave” victory triggered a sharp two-day selloff for U.S. stocks; the benchmark ended the following Monday, June 27, at 2000.54, a 5.3% drop from the pre-Brexit high. But the S&P 500 then rebounded and has since eclipsed its old all-time high. On Thursday, the S&P 500 recorded its fourth straight record close at 2,163.75, up 2.4% from its June 23 close and more than 8% from the post-Brexit closing low, even as companies warn that post-Brexit fallout is a key concern in their earnings calls. On Friday, stocks were struggling to hold on to gains. Which stocks were the biggest winners and losers? Here’s breakdown based on FactSet data: Winners—June 27 to July 14 Company Ticker Close—6/27 Close—7/14 Price Change American Airlines AAL, +2.18% $25.27 $35.88 42.0% Seagate Technology STX, +2.87% $20.87 $29.19 39.9% Endo International ENDP, +1.71% $13.69 $17.68 29.1% Freeport McMoRan FCX, +4.90% $10.13 $12.95 27.8% United Continental UAL, +2.30% $37.75 $47.85 26.8% Navient Corp. NAVI, -0.53% $11.01 $13.74 24.8% Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63% $33.36 $40.98 22.8% Western Digital WDC, +1.62% $42.18 $51.75 22.7% Nucor Corp. NUE, +2.98% $46.31 $56.79 22.6% CarMax Inc. KMX, +2.14% $45.70 $55.40 21.2% Source: FactSet Airlines are among the big winners. Of course, airlines were among the hardest hit in the immediate aftermath of Brexit. American Airlines Group AAL, +2.18% for example, dropped 16.8% in two sessions. But shareholders who didn’t dump American in the post-Brexit carnage saw a rise of more than 18% between the June 23 close and Thursday’s close. Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63%  was among firms discussing Brexit concerns in its earnings conference call, saying the sharp drop in the British pound led it to scale back 6 percentage points of its U.S./U.K. capacity for the winter. Airlines and other travel stocks were under pressure Friday after a terror attack in France left more than 80 people dead. As for those investors who just held on to stocks in the wake of the Brexit vote, these shares performed best overall: Winners—June 23 to July 14 Company Ticker Close -- 6/23 Close -- 7/14 Price Change Seagate Technology STX, +2.87% $24.48 $29.19 19.2% American Airlines AAL, +2.18% $30.33 $35.88 18.3% CarMax KMX, +2.14% $46.98 $55.40 17.9% Newmont Mining Corp. content: Walgreens Boots Alliance said sales edged up in its latest quarter as it filled more prescriptions, though revenue fell short of expectations as shoppers bought less outside of the pharmacy. Shares in the company, down 2% this year through Tuesday's close, slipped 0.6% in premarket trading. The largest U.S. drugstore chain, formed when Walgreen and Alliance Boots merged at the end of 2014, has been working to reshape itself amid lower reimbursement rates and as the fast-changing U.S. health-care marketplace prompts consolidation. It is in the midst of completing its $9.4 billion acquisition of Rite Aid Corp., which Walgreens said Wednesday is on track to close in the second half of this year. Earlier this year it teamed up with United Healthcare Inc.'s pharmacy-benefit manager OptumRx, and last month Walgreens shook up its senior management ranks to lead what it says is the next phase of its evolutions. Also last month, the company pulled the plug on its three-year partnership with embattled blood-testing firm Theranos as regulators weigh sanctions against the firm for voiding certain test results. In its latest quarter, the Deerfield, Ill., company said overall sales at stores open at least a year grew 3.9%, better than the 3.7% analysts expected and up from the 2.2% pace -- the lowest in three years -- logged in the second quarter. Sales in Walgreens' pharmacy business jumped 6% on a comparable basis, nearly double the prior quarter's rate, as it filled 4.5% more prescriptions thanks to rising Medicare Part D volume. At the front end, where the company sells items from snacks to greeting cards to beauty products, sales inched up 0.1% after declining 0.3% a quarter earlier. Walgreens reiterated Wednesday that it is trying to beef up retail sales through new beauty offerings that it will continue to roll out this year. Over all for the period, Walgreens reported a profit of $1.10 billion, or $1.01 a share, down from $1.30 billion, or $1.18 a share, a year earlier. Excluding merger-related items and a change in the fair value of warrants exercised to buy a stake in AmerisourceBergen, among other things, per-share profit rose to $1.18 from $1.02. Revenue edged 2.4% higher to $29.50 billion. Analysts projected $1.04 in adjusted earnings per share on $29.71 billion in sales, according to Thomson Reuters. The company lifted the low end of its profit forecast for the year by a dime, now expecting to report $4.45 to $4.55 in adjusted earnings per share. Walgreens said the guidance assumes no impact from the pending Rite Aid deal. Write to Lisa Beilfuss at lisa.beilfuss@wsj.com
title: Walgreens revenue falls short of estimates

content: Drug wholesaler AmerisourceBergen Corp. swung to a profit for the March quarter but cut its earnings guidance for the current fiscal year amid continued generic-drug pricing pressures in the sector. Shares fell 7.5% to $78 in recent premarket trading as the company's second-quarter revenue also missed expectations. For the fiscal year ending in September, AmerisourceBergen lowered its per-share earnings guidance to $5.44 to $5.54, from its previous estimate for per-share profit of $5.73 to $5.83. Chairman Chief Executive Steven H. Collis said in prepared remarks Thursday that the reduced forecast reflects challenges from weaker generic pricing trends as well as lower contributions from new generic drugs. Contributions from the company's acquisitions of MWI Veterinary Supply Inc. and PharMEDium Healthcare Holdings Inc. helped AmerisourceBergen's performance in the March quarter, Mr. Collis stated. "In addition, we have extended our contract with our largest pharmacy retail customer for an additional three years, and our large pharmacy benefit manager customer has extended their contract for an additional year," he said. For the period ended March 31, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $604.1 million, or $2.68 a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of $513.4 million, or $2.33 a share. Excluding one-time items, adjusted per-share earnings rose to $1.68 from $1.45. Revenue increased 9.3% to $35.7 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected per-share profit of $1.59 and revenue of $35.83 billion. Write to Tess Stynes at tess.stynes@wsj.com
title: AmerisourceBergen shares slide on lower outlook

content: U.S. stocks will be getting less support as the S&P 500 enters a more than month-long period in which companies cannot repurchase their shares, but some stocks are more vulnerable than others. Under Securities and Exchange Commission rules, companies are required to pause share buybacks during a so-called blackout period, which lasts about five weeks before each respective company’s earnings report until about 48 hours after results are announced. Looking at the S&P 500 Buyback Index, which tracks the top 100 stocks with the highest buyback ratios on the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% Jonathan Krinsky, chief market technician at MKM Partners, noted that companies with relatively large buyback programs have slipped during their March-to-May blackout periods over the past two years compared with the broader S&P 500. And Krinsky said he thinks this year will be no different. “With the S&P 500 Buyback Index having outperformed the SPX by [about] 5% since the February lows, we think that trend could reverse,” Krinsky said. That said, Krinsky took note of eight stocks that appear particularly vulnerable to blackout periods given their higher than average reliance on buybacks and recent weak performance trends. “Presumably without the help of corporate buybacks, they could underperform in the months ahead,” Krinsky said. Company/ticker Earnings report scheduled Blackout start Year-to-date performance Monsanto Co. MON, -0.05%   April 6 March 2 -7% United Rentals Inc. URI, +2.14%   April 19 March 15 -13% AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%   April 21 March 17 -16% Ameriprise Financial Inc. AMP, +0.67%   April 25 March 21 -12% Express Scripts Holding Co. ESRX, -0.93%   April 26 March 22 -21% American International Group Inc. AIG, -0.18%   April 28 March 24 -14% Moody’s Corp. MCO, +1.48%   April 29 March 25 -4% 21st Century Fox Inc. FOXA, +2.26%   May 4 March 30 +3% Of those companies, AIG and Monsanto ranked among the top 10 companies spending the most on share buybacks over the fourth quarter, according to FactSet data. In the fourth quarter, AIG spent $3.22 billion on buybacks, while Monsanto spent $2.55 billion. They didn’t, however, make it to top 10 lists of companies that got the most for their money. title: These stocks are most vulnerable to the buyback ‘blackout’

content: “Momentum stocks trade at an extreme premium to value stocks. Their valuation spread is the highest since 1980, except for during the tech bubble.” That’s what J.P. Morgan Chase JPM, +1.82%  analyst Dubravko Lakos-Bujas wrote in a report Tuesday, as he discussed the signs of slowing economic growth in the U.S., “resulting in a more dovish” Federal Reserve as well as the “stabilizing/weakening” of the dollar. According to Lakos-Bujas, those combined factors are “providing implicit relief to [emerging markets] and commodity-linked equities.” And that could mean quite a bit to investors, as beaten-down stocks could rebound and soar. The “momentum stocks” to which Lakos-Bujas refers are part of a group that has performed quite well over the past several years. Momentum investing means you stick with the winners, rather than trying to decide which companies’ stocks are undervalued and primed for higher investment returns. There are plenty of good arguments to make for either strategy. Also see: Oil prices turn lower as traders question merit of ‘output freeze’ The idea is that the current stock market volatility, trading patterns and valuation within an industry group might set up a moment stock to underperform, even if the company has being doing well in increasing sales and earnings. An appearance on one of Lakos-Bujas’ lists doesn’t necessarily mean that J.P. Morgan Chase’s sell-side analysts have a certain rating on a stock — or any rating at all. J.P. Morgan provided its clients with two big lists of momentum stocks to avoid, and momentum stocks “at a reasonable price.” Here are five big companies the analysts included among momentum stocks to avoid: General Electric Co. GE, -1.46%  The stock has returned 17% over the past 12 months, with dividends reinvested, which compared to a negative 4% return for the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% according to FactSet. GE trades for 18.8 times the consensus 2014 EPS estimate, while the S&P 500 trades for 15.4 times the weighted aggregate 2016 EPS estimate. GE’s stock features a dividend yield of 3.26%. Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +1.11%  The stock has returned 34% over the past 12 months. Investors don’t value Amazon by traditional measures, such as price-to-earnings, because the company under founder and CEO Jeff Bezos always focuses on investment to grow sales and market share. Amazon disappointed investors with its fourth-quarter results, because of rising delivery costs. Other recent events include a new $5 billion stock-buyback plan. The company is reportedly considering opening hundreds of brick-and-mortar stores. Walt Disney Co. DIS, +1.93%  The stock has returned a negative 11% over the past 12 months and trades for 15.7 times the consensus 2016 EPS estimate. The huge success of “Star Wars Episode VII: The Force Awakens” helped Disney set an EPS record for its fiscal first quarter ended Jan. 2, while its revenue grew 14% from a year earlier. McDonald’s Co. MCD, -1.28%  The stock has returned 28% over the past 12 months, and trades for 21.9 times the consensus 2016 EPS estimate. The company has certainly changed investors’ opinions after years of slow growth. It grew fourth-quarter comparable sales by 5% during the fourth quarter and has tremendous momentum, driven by the successful rollout of all-day breakfast. The shares have a dividend yield of 3.02%. Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.02%  The stock has returned 23% over the past 12 months and trades for 29.5 times the consensus 2016 EPS estimate. The company increased its global comparable-store sales by 8% during its fiscal first quarter ended Dec. 27, but disappointed investors on a weaker-than-expected outlook for the fiscal second quarter. content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. lowered the upper end of its guidance for the current year as the drug wholesaler reported that it swung to a profit during the quarter ended in December. For the fiscal year ending in September, AmerisourceBergen lowered the upper end of its per-share earnings estimate by seven cents and now expects per-share profit between $5.73 and $5.83. Chief Executive Steven H. Collis said in prepared remarks Thursday that the outlook reflects reduced expectations regarding prices of generic drugs and contributions from generic drug introductions as well as the effect of an early contract renewal. AmerisourceBergen in November completed its $2.58 billion acquisition of PharMEDium Healthcare Holdings Inc., which includes four compounding facilities that provide personalized medications to hospitals. In the latest quarter, pharmaceutical distribution revenue rose 7% to $35.2 billion. Nonpharmaceutical sales more than doubled to $1.6 billion, thanks to AmerisourceBergen's acquisition last year of MWI Veterinary Supply Inc., which distributes animal-health products in the U.S. and U.K. For the period ended Dec. 31, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $330.4 million, or $1.46 a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of $199.5 million, or 91 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding one-time items, adjusted per-share earnings rose to $1.27 from $1.14. Revenue increased 9.3% to $36.7 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected per-share profit of $1.25 and revenue of $36.86 billion. AmerisourceBergen has been forming ventures and collaborations with other health-care-related companies to increase bargaining power with drugmakers. AmerisourceBergen also said it reached a long-term distribution agreement on Thursday with Publix Super Markets Inc. Financial terms weren't disclosed. In 2013, AmerisourceBergen began an alliance with U.S. drugstore-chain operator Walgreen and European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH, which have since merged. Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc.'s pending $9.4 billion deal for drugstore chain Rite Aid is expected to close in the second half of this year, pending regulatory and other approvals. Write to Tess Stynes at tess.stynes@wsj.com
title: AmerisourceBergen tops profit views, trims outlook

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. said Wednesday Chief Executive Steven Collis will succeed Chairman Richard Gozon next year, and the drug wholesaler also adopted measures to make it easier for certain shareholders to nominate directors to the board. Collis will take on the chairman role following Gozon’s retirement at the annual stockholder meeting in March. He has been chief executive since July 2011 and a director since May 2011. The company ABC, +1.29%  also said Jane Henney will become the board’s lead independent director. She has served as a director since January 2002. Graphic embed is no longer available. AmerisourceBergen said it has changed its bylaws to allow for so-called proxy access, joining a growing list of big companies making similar moves. The new rules stipulate that a shareholder or group of them who have owned at least 3% of shares outstanding for three years can nominate directors to the board—two of them or 20% of the board, whichever is greater. An expanded version of this report appears at WSJ.com. title: AmerisourceBergen CEO to take chairman role; company adopts proxy access

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% issued earnings guidance for its recently started fiscal year that topped expectations as the drug wholesaler posted revenue growth of 12% for the latest quarter. For the year ending in September 2016, the company forecast per-share earnings of $5.73 to $5.90, while analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected per-share profit of $5. AmerisourceBergen said revenue for its most recently completed quarter in September increased to $35.47 billion from $31.58 billion a year earlier. Analysts had projected revenue at of $34.47 billion. In the latest quarter, pharmaceutical distribution revenue rose 10%. Nonpharmaceutical sales more than doubled, thanks to AmerisourceBergen's acquisition earlier this year of MWI Veterinary Supply Inc., which distributes animal-health products in the U.S. and Britain. Overall, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $364.3 million, or 1.56 a share, up from $67.8 million, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding write-downs, legal settlement impacts and other items, per-share earnings rose to $1.17 from $1.10. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected per-share profit of $1.18. In 2013, AmerisourceBergen began an alliance with U.S. drugstore-chain operator Walgreen and European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH, which have since merged. On Wednesday, Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc. agreed to buy Rite Aid Corp. for about $9.4 billion, in a move that would create a drugstore giant as companies across the U.S. health-care industry look for ways to bulk up. title: AmerisourceBergen issues upbeat outlook

content: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, Inc. will hold a press conference at 8.00 a.m. Eastern to respond to allegations lobbed at the company regarding its relationship with specialty pharmacies and its accounting practices. Valeant VRX, +2.91% VRX, +2.65%  declined to do so for MarketWatch ahead of the press conference. TimeValeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc.15 Jan29 Jan12 Feb26 Feb12 Mar26 Mar US:VRX $20.0 $15.0 $17.5 $22.5 Citron Research, John Hempton, ProPublica and The Wall Street Journal have said there is a tangled web of organizational ties between Valeant and specialty pharmacy network company Philidor RX, Philidor network member R&O Pharmacy, and other specialty pharmacies that may or may not be legally and financially related to Philidor and/or Valeant. Valeant shares fell as much as 40% at their worst level on Wednesday after Citron, a short selling firm, issued a scathing report, alleging that Valeant was shipping product to R&O and then falsely claiming the revenue. Citron’s report, which called Valeant a “pharmaceutical Enron,” cited a report that was published on Monday by the Southern Investigative Reporting Foundation, SIRF, that revealed the previously undisclosed relationships with specialty pharmacies. Valeant responded to Citron with a statement that said all sales to Philidor and its network pharmacies are “accounted for as intercompany sales and are eliminated in consolidation.” That would imply financial ownership of Philidor and an organizational connection with a distribution channel that had not been, until Monday, ever mentioned in Valeant’s financial statements or filings with the Canadian or U.S. securities regulators. Valeant had already responded to SIRF’s findings on its earnings call on Monday by saying that it has a “contractual relationship” with Philidor to fill prescriptions on its behalf, that it recently bought an option to buy the pharmacy, and that it also consolidates Philidor’s results with its own based on a variable interest entity (VIE) relationship. According to the guide to VIEs produced by Valeant’s auditors, PricewaterhouseCoopers, a reporting entity must consolidate any other entity in which it has a controlling financial interest. That means Valeant already has voting control, most likely more than 50% of Philidor’s voting interest. That’s because under the VIE model, if Valeant is consolidating Philidor’s results, it must have the power to direct Philidor’s most significant economic activities and the ability to share in its profits. If all this is true, Valeant has a lot of explaining to do about why this is the first time anyone has ever heard of Philidor, and the special accounting for its revenues and inventory that’s required for such an entity. In addition, it’s not clear just how big of a channel the pharmacy network is, although Valeant said on its call that less than 5% of its inventory sits in specialty pharmacies. Two other large pharmaceutical firms, Allergan, plc. AGN, +1.59% and Endo International Inc. ENDP, +1.71% CA:ENL issued statements this week clarifying that they don’t depend to any great extent on the pharmacy network distribution channel. On the Monday call, Valeant Chairman and Chief Executive J. Michael Pearson, responding to questions about revenues from recent acquisition Salix, said that Valeant knows how much inventory is at its big three distributors—McKesson MCK, +0.15% AmerisourceBergen Corporation ABC, +1.29% and Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% —because it has data sharing agreements with them. However, in its last annual report, the company says it uses third-party data to estimate the level of product inventories and product demand at other wholesalers and retail pharmacies. Pearson said information about anyone other than the big three is limited: “We don’t know how much inventory there is in some of the other distributors,” he said, “because there were no agreements in place to tell us that.” The SIRF article also highlights a court filing made by R&O Pharmacy and filed with the California District Court in September, in which the small regional pharmacy asks the court to block a demand for $69 million from Valeant for products that R&O said it had never received. The demand suggests R&O is a separate, third-party, non-affiliated company. But if R&O is actually owned by the Philidor organization, it would also be owned by Valeant. Valeant should also explain when, and to what extent, it is actually in the business of providing “back-end services, including call center, claims adjudication, IT and logistics support, as well as compliance/HIPPA regulation guidance, to other pharmacies, including R&O Pharmacy” as it says its consolidated entity Philidor is providing to its network of pharmacies. It’s also worth noting that Salix had a significant accounting restatement just before it was acquired by Valeant. Valeant revealed in its June 30 quarterly filing that the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the related accounting issues and possible securities law violations by Salix relating to disclosures of inventory amounts in the distribution channel and its disclosures. title: Valeant must untangle web of allegations on Monday call

content: On April 6, 2015, CNBC host and best-selling author Jim Cramer wrote an article: “Jim Cramer’s Picks — Here are 49 Stocks to Buy Right Now,” published on TheStreet.com. Cramer made a strong case for the 49 stocks. “Every single one of these companies reported excellent last quarters, and with no exceptions their charts are pretty much perfectly made for this downturn,” Cramer wrote. Even if there was a correction or downturn, Cramer wrote that these stocks would do well. David O. England, a retired finance professor from Carbondale, Ill., decided to test Cramer’s stock buy list. On April 6, England bought $1,000 of each security on Cramer’s list in a paper-trade account (not including commissions) at the close of the following day. Tim Cook at WSJDLive: Apple Products in Customers' Lives England bet Cramer a dinner at the 17th Street BBQ restaurant in Murphysboro, Ill., one of the best rib houses in the country. If Cramer’s picks were profitable, England would pay. If Cramer’s picks were unprofitable, Cramer would pay. But Cramer never responded to the wager after repeated email and phone calls. (Here is the original MarketWatch column describing the rules of “The Cramer Challenge”) Absent Cramer’s cooperation, England went ahead and tracked the portfolio’s performance. England kept a weekly record of the results for the last six months. He also had the results audited by an independent third party. The final result? Even after the most recent 1,000-point Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07%  rally, Cramer got a failing grade. Although Cramer promised his picks could survive any downturn, these stocks didn’t survive during the market’s brutal third quarter. Only 14 of Cramer’s 49 stock picks closed higher after six months than their April trading price, a paltry 28% success rate. Click here to see the final performance results. Bottom line: England won the bet. (Note: The final results of Cramer’s picks are at the bottom of this column.) Cramer did not respond to e-mailed requests this week seeking comment about the recommended stocks’ performance. And England points out that he is not attacking Cramer personally, but takes issue with the quality of his stock picks. “It bothered me that so many experts publish buy lists,” England says, “but you never hear about the list again. I wanted readers to know that buying stocks based on a list is often a recipe for disaster.” Here are five other lessons that England shared: 1. Be careful about buying stocks based on a list. It’s better if you do your own homework. 2. In a downturn or bear market, even shares of “good” companies can go down, and by a lot. Look at Apple AAPL, +0.78%  or Wal-Mart WMT, +1.37%  , for example. 3. Be cautious about following anyone, especially well-known gurus. It’s okay to listen, but in the end you have to do your own research. But to blindly buy stocks based on a recommendation from a guru, a stockbroker, or a friend, usually leads to losses. 4. If you think about it, the list of 49 stocks are just 49 tips, and if there is anything you should know, never buy stocks based on tips. It’s rare that a tip works out. And if you buy based on a tip, will that person tell you when to sell? For example, if you had bought those 49 stocks, when do you sell? 5. Instead of “buy” lists, market gurus should call these “watch” lists. It would save investors of lot of time and aggravation. After all, Cramer’s 49 picks were supposed to protect you from a downturn. Unfortunately, these 49 stocks did no such thing. content: The S&P 500 finally nailed its longest winning streak of the year yesterday. That is five straight trading days of gains. What happens next depends on how brave investors are feeling. The index SPX, +1.38% closed at 1,987.05, a 1.8% gain yesterday, butting up against the 2,000 level, which has been a psychological wall hard for investors to scale. Hence, the debate about whether this latest run higher means that markets have shut the door on the volatility that struck in later summer, and which has been haunting it ever since. There’s a “65% chance this market has turned the proverbial corner,” Kent Engelke, chief economic strategist at Capitol Securities Management, told MarketWatch yesterday. Less optimistic is Mark Newton, a partner at Greywolf Execution Partners. Speaking to WSJ MoneyBeat’s Paul Vigna, Newton noted that since the year 1900, every single time the stock market has been off by 6% or more heading into October — that’s 22 times — it has failed to get back to positive ground by year’s end. Nine of those times, it has done even worse. Check out MoneyBeat here. Count former Pimco chief Bill Gross, who’s now at Janus Capital, as among those unwilling to take on that risk right now. In an interview with Bloomberg, he says investors need to sit this market out and get “cold water splashed on their faces.” But then, our call of the day sees the end of 2016 delivering big gains for global markets. As our chart of the day shows, any caution comes just as the VIX seems to be calming down. Maybe investors don’t give a ballyhoo about the angst on Wall Street anyway. As Convergex strategist Nick Colas notes, the average American investor is fairly apathetic about what’s going on the stock market, based on Google search terms since July. (h/t to Reformed Broker’s Josh Brown) Searches for the term “stockbroker” are down 6% over the past three months, notes Colas. But searches for political terms are up 50%, with — you guessed it — Donald Trump in the lead. Key market gauges There’s a bit of a pullback going on, with futures on the Dow US:YMZ5  and the S&P US:ESZ5  heading south, with earnings season starting to weigh on the minds of traders. The Nikkei NIK, +1.40%   got a boost from hopes that the Bank of Japan will deliver some easing moves at its meeting Wednesday. Europe SXXP, +0.44%  is limping early. Crude oil CLZ5, -0.17%  is lower ahead of U.S. inventory data. Gold US:GCZ5  is flat, and the dollar DXY, +0.00%  has lost some ground. The call Citigroup analysts weighed on stocks in a note released this morning, saying it’s “time to be brave (again).” A team led by Robert Buckland says the global bull market is “aging, but not finished.” They expect a 20% gain for global stocks by the end of 2016. Note they’re neutral on U.S. stocks, saying buy Europe, ex-U.K and Japan into the recent selloff. For one thing, they say global equities are pricing in a lower earnings-per-share outlook, which should protect prices against “inevitable negative EPS revisions.” Less sanguine was Bill Gross, who told Bloomberg a 10% drop for U.S. stocks is coming our way. He says downbeat economic data isn’t conductive to a rally such as what the market saw in 2013. The chart Crossing Wall Street’s Eddy Elfenbein has given the “all-clear” after the CBOE Volatility Index VIX, -12.68% known as the VIX, closed at 19.54 yesterday. “That doesn’t mean the market is about to surge higher, but it probably signals that the elevated volatility is behind us,” he writes. A VIX below 20 usually means less stress in the market, and it hasn’t closed under that level since August 20, when it closed at 19.1. Crossing Wall Streett All clear? Also check out Beware of the next VIX trick Earnings PepsiCo PEP, -0.03%  earnings beat profits, after stripping out accounting charges in its Venezuelan unit. All eyes turn to Alcoa’s AA, +1.22%  third-quarter results, due after the close Thursday. Here’s what to expect from Alcoa, which could kick off the weakest set of earnings reports in six years. The buzz SABMiller UK:SAB US:SBMRY  reportedly rejected the informal takeover offer from InBev BUD, +0.28% ABI, +0.33%  Bloomberg reports. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29%  is buying sterile preparations provider PharMedium for $2.58 billion. DuPont’s US:DD   chairman and chief executive Ellen Kullman has stepped down. The EU’s top court has struck down the Safe Harbor data agreement, which could prevent thousands of U.S. companies from being able to transfer customer data from Europe to their home servers. IBM IBM, +0.60%  has set up a new business unit to capitalize on the artificial intelligence boom, with its Watson software as the key hook. BP says it BP, +2.37% BP., +1.67%  will pay $20.8 billion to settle civil suits from the U.S., five states. An American Airlines AAL, +2.18%   pilot died mid-flight early Monday during a routine red-eye from Phoenix. The Apple AAPL, +0.78%  Watch Hermès is now on sale. From $1,100 to $1,500. As MacWorld reports, this marks a first for Apple when it comes to the amount of branding from another company it has used in one of its products. Bloomberg Markets 50 most influential list is out. The chart Crossing Wall Street’s Eddy Elfenbein who has declared an “all-clear” warning after the CBOE Volatility Index VIX, -12.68%  , known as the VIX, closed at 19.54 yesterday. “That doesn’t mean the market is about to surge higher, but it probably signals that the elevated volatility is behind us,” he writes. A VIX below 20 usually means less stress in the market, and it hasn’t closed under that level since Also check out Beware of the next VIX trick The economy The U.S. trade deficit jumped 16% in August to $48.3 billion, after a strong dollar cut exports back to the lowest level in three years. The deficit was expected to rise to $48.1 billion. Imports were up 30%, with part of that tied to the release of iPhones and other consumer electronics. The quote “If that was my mom or my dad, I’d walk through hell and high water. And today it happened to be high water.” — Pastor Wayne Reeves of New Life Ministries in Summerville, South Carolina, breaks an interview to retrieve a casket unearthed from a cemetery in the flood waters. title: Why now is the time to ‘be brave’ with stocks

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said on Tuesday it was buying PharMedium Healthcare Holdings for $2.58 billion from private equity investor Clayton, Dubilier & Rice. The pharmaceutical company expects the acquisition of the provider of compound sterile preparations (CSPs) to hospitals to be completed during the first quarter of 2016, and to increase fiscal 2016 earnings per share by 22 cents to 26 cents. AmerisourceBergen expects the deal to generate synergies of $30 million by fiscal 2018. "PharMedium's impressive track record of growth and proven ability to consistently deliver high quality CSPs in key therapeutic areas make them the undisputed leader in an important growth area of the U.S. healthcare market," said AmerisourceBergen Chief Executive Steven Collis. AmerisourceBergen's stock, which edged up 0.6% in premarket trade, had lost 12% over the past three months, while the S&P 500 has slipped 4%.
title: AmerisourceBergen to buy sterile preparations provider PharMedium for $2.58 billion

content: Health care tends to be a top-performing sector of the stock market. But this year is different, which means you might be able to buy shares cheaply and profit handsomely in the long run. Here’s how the 10 sectors of the S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38%  have performed this year, along with three-, five- and 10-year total returns, with dividends reinvested: S&P 500 sector Total return - 2015 Total return - 3 years Total return - 5 years Total return - 10 years Consumer Discretionary 4% 66% 148% 174% Health Care 2% 82% 151% 168% Consumer Staples -3% 41% 93% 172% Information Technology -3% 39% 98% 133% Industrials -4% 40% 96% 127% Telecommunications Services -7% 3% 51% 94% Financials -9% 51% 71% -4% Utilities -11% 30% 64% 90% Materials -15% 17% 42% 95% Energy -22% -11% 26% 40% S&P 500 -4% 42% 90% 98% Source: FactSet The consumer-discretionary sector has performed best this year, and we took a detailed look at this group earlier this month. The health-care sector has done nearly as well, but during August, when the S&P 500 declined 6.3%, it sank 8.1%, making for the worst performance of all the sectors, according to S&P Capital IQ. Read: Apple and ‘frenemies’ cut out the middle man What’s surprising is how well health-care companies boosted earnings. Here are the 10 sectors again, this time ranked by weighted growth of earnings per share: S&P 500 sector Second-quarter EPS growth Health Care 14.71% Telecommunications Services 11.84% Consumer Discretionary 10.45% Financials 9.64% Materials 7.76% Information Technology 6.15% Utilities 4.45% Consumer Staples 1.70% Industrials 0.11% Energy -55.76% S&P 500 0.14% Source: S&P Capital IQ S&P Capital IQ senior analyst Lindsey Bell said in a report Wednesday that it’s “hard to reconcile the sector’s recent decline.” She said health care has been a driver of earnings growth “for the past several quarters, posting double-digit growth in each of the previous five quarters (including growth of more than 20% in fourth-quarter 2014 and first-quarter 2015).” Big increases in people signing up for health insurance and Medicaid “should result in higher utilization and help most health-care sub-industries report solid sales and EPS growth.” Still, Big Pharma could be hurt by the strong dollar, she said. Read: BMW shares skid on report of higher-than-allowed emissions According to S&P Capital IQ, the S&P 500 health-care sector is trading for 16.8 times earnings, below its 15-year average of 17.1. So we’re going to present two lists of health-care stocks. The only stock on both lists is Gilead Sciences Inc. GILD, +0.82% which has had amazing success with its Harvoni hepatitis C medication, which is far less expensive than the company’s older Sovaldi treatment. Harvoni sales during the second quarter more than made up the revenue lost from the predictable decline in Sovaldi sales. The low P/E for Gilead might be explained by investors’ disbelief that the company can continue its amazing run. Among 23 sell-side analysts covering the company, 18 rate Gilead “buy,” one analyst rates the stock “overweight” and three have “neutral” ratings. title: Health-care stocks may be your best bet today

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% raised its guidance for the current year as the drug wholesaler swung to a profit during the quarter ended in June. For the year ending in September, the company increased its per-share earnings estimate to $4.92 to $4.97 from its previous estimate for per-share profit of $4.85 to $4.95. In the latest quarter, pharmaceutical distribution revenue rose 10% to $32.8 billion, again boosted by the Walgreen Boots Alliance generic-pharmaceutical business. In 2013, AmerisourceBergen began an alliance with U.S. drugstore-chain operator Walgreen and European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH, which have since merged. Nonpharmaceutical sales more than doubled to $1.5 billion, thanks to AmerisourceBergen's acquisition earlier this year of MWI Veterinary Supply Inc., which distributes animal-health products in the U.S. and Britain. For the period ended June 30, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $214.2 million, or 89 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of $12.8 million, or six cents a share. Excluding antitrust litigation settlement gains and other items, per-share earnings rose to $1.20 from $1.01. Revenue increased 13% to $34.23 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected per-share profit of $1.15 and revenue of $33.98 billion. title: AmerisourceBergen swings to profit, raises outlook

content: It’s much easier to buy stocks from a list than to find your own candidates. But can you make money this way? David O. England, a retired finance professor from Carbondale, Ill. who now offers investing classes and workshops, decided to test a recent stock “buy” list from well-known CNBC host and best-selling author Jim Cramer. And he’s challenging Cramer to put a meal where his mouth is. On April 6, 2015, “Jim Cramer’s Picks — Here are 49 Stocks to Buy Right Now,” was published on TheStreet.com. In the article, Cramer makes a strong case for these 49 stocks. “Every single one of these companies reported excellent last quarters, and with no exceptions their charts are pretty much perfectly made for this downturn,” Cramer wrote. Even if there is a correction or pullback, Cramer says these stocks will do well. Cramer writes, “This is THE list. Go forth and conquer.” To test Cramer’s picks, on April 6, England spent $49,000 in a paper-trade account, i.e. he bought $1,000 of each security not including commissions at the close of the following day. England is tracking Cramer’s performance on his website. He keeps a weekly record of the results, and after six months, he will publish the final results. The wager To make it interesting, England is betting Cramer a dinner at the 17th Street BBQ in Murphysboro, Ill., recently cited as one of the best rib houses in the country. The bet includes a round-trip (coach) airplane ticket. If Cramer’s picks are profitable (more stocks up than down) at the end of six months, England pays. If the picks are unprofitable, Cramer picks up the tab to send England to New York for ribs. Of course, this depends whether Cramer accepts the wager (so far, no word from Cramer). The purpose I asked England why he is tracking Cramer’s buy list. “I want hard-working people to know if they should buy stocks based on buy lists,” England says. “The bull market is getting long in the tooth so is it time to jump into new positions or take profits? I have tracked buy recommendations in the past and most have been bloodbaths.” He adds: “I am keeping an open mind on Cramer’s picks. If he hits a home run with his stocks, I will publicly praise him and treat him to dinner. If his picks are unprofitable, I’ll write about the dangers of buying stocks from buy lists without having a system.” What kind of system? “If you don’t rely on buy lists,” England says, “then you should learn how to do your own stock scans. I think people should be empowered to make their own financial decisions. Perhaps Cramer is an excellent stock-picker. I am not challenging him as a person, only the quality of his buy recommendations. I can’t wait to see who’s right.” The lesson There are many lessons to learn from this challenge. First, test the stocks by paper trading. Knowledgeable investors, meanwhile, can buy call options rather than individual stocks. The best idea is never to buy stocks based on tips or recommendations — even if they come from pros. U.S. GDP Swings to Contraction in First Quarter People will immediately invest $20,000 after hearing a stock tip from a stranger or unknowledgeable friend, but spend a month researching a $400 TV. If you feel compelled to buy any of the 49 stocks on Cramer’s list, or any other, first analyze and test whether the picks are credible. For reference, here are the 49 stocks Cramer recommended in his April 6 column: AutoNation AN, +2.03%   AutoZone AZO, +1.80%   CarMax KMX, +2.14% Cracker Barrel Old Country Store CBRL, +1.03%   Costco Wholesale COST, +2.63%   CVS Health CVS, -0.80%   Darden Restaurants DRI, +1.03%   Dillard's DDS, +0.96%   Dick's Sporting Goods DKS, +2.10% Dollar Tree DLTR, +1.05%   Dollar General DG, +0.66%   Hanesbrands HBI, +0.22%   Jack in the Box JACK, +0.25%   Jarden US:JAH   L Brands LB, +1.43%   Kroger KR, +1.35%   Kohl's KSS, +1.47%   Macy's M, +2.30%   Ross Stores ROST, +2.39%   Under Armour UA, +1.13%   Urban Outfitters URBN, +1.59%   Actavis ACT, +1.36%   AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29%   Boston Scientific BSX, +2.40%   Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94%   Cerner CERN, -1.09%   Cigna CI, -0.34%   Edwards Lifesciences EW, +2.01%   Humana HUM, +0.48%   Medtronic MDT, +2.24%   McKesson MCK, +0.15%   Perrigo PRGO, +0.90%   UnitedHealth Group UNH, -2.06%   Hormel Foods HRL, +1.96%   J.M. Smucker SJM, +0.58%   Mondelez International MDLZ, +2.81%   Monster Beverage MNST, +1.72%   Toll Brothers TOL, +1.36%   D.R. Horton DHI, +1.29%   Lennar LEN, +0.31%   Analog Devices ADI, +1.36%   Avago Technologies AVGO, -0.44%   Cypress Semiconductor CY, +2.05%   Qorvo QRVO, +2.79%   Skyworks Solutions SWKS, +1.41%   CyberArk Software CYBR, +2.04%   FireEye FEYE, +0.59%   Fortinet FTNT, +2.49%   Palo Alto Networks PANW, +2.61%     More from MarketWatch Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds

content: LinkedIn Corp. shares lost nearly a quarter of their value after the social media website for professional networking issued a disappointing forecast for the quarter and year. After Hours After being down as much as 25%, LinkedIn US:LNKD  shares fell 19% to $204.70 on heavy volume. The company forecast adjusted earnings of 28 cents for the second quarter, and $1.90 for the year, well below Wall Street estimates. Visa Inc. V, +2.25%  shares declined 1.4% to $65.10 after the payment network reported quarterly results. Gilead Sciences Inc. GILD, +0.82%  shares advanced 2.4% to $102.90 on heavy volume after the biotech topped Wall Street estimates for earnings and revenue for the quarter. First Solar Inc. FSLR, +2.39%  shares fell 4.6% to $56.90 on moderate volume following an after-hours trading halt. The solar power company reported a wider-than-expected loss for the quarter. DreamWorks Animation SKG Inc. US:DWA  shares fell 5.1% to $56.62 on moderate volume after the company posted a loss for the quarter and missed Wall Street revenue estimates. Expedia Inc. EXPE, +3.85%  shares rose 4% to $97.99 on moderate volume after the travel website’s revenue rose higher than expected. FireEye Inc. FEYE, +0.59%  shares advanced 3.5% to $97.50 on moderate volume after the cybersecurity company raised its sales guidance for the year. These stocks made notable moves in Thursday’s regular session: Gainers Taser International Inc. US:TASR  reported better-than-expected first-quarter profit and sales. The stun-gun maker said earnings more than doubled to $7.2 million, or 13 cents a share, from $3.4 million, or 6 cents a share, a year ago. Rockwell Automation Corp. ROK, -0.29%  on Thursday said it earned $1.59 a share in the fiscal second quarter on an adjusted basis, ahead of $1.42 a share projected by analysts. Martin Marietta Materials Inc. MLM, +2.73%  reported its first quarterly profit since 2008 and projected a strong outlook for the year on strong economic activity and construction growth. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  reported fiscal second-quarter adjusted earnings of $1.45 a share, better than $1.19 forecast by analysts, and announced an additional $1 billion in share buyback. New York Times Co. NYT, +2.77%  reported first-quarter profit and sales that missed Street consensus estimates, and announced that it expects advertising revenue to fall in the second quarter. Decliners Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78%  was the worst performer on the Dow with shares extending losses for a second day. A component for Apple Watch supplied by a contractor was found to be defective, disrupting the supply of the new product. Reports also surfaced suggesting that its heart-rate monitor may not work on darker skin. Yelp Inc. YELP, +1.14%  reported late Wednesday that its first-quarter loss narrowed to 2 cents a share from 4 cents a share loss in the prior year period. On an adjusted basis, Yelp earned 10 cents a share, missing analysts’ consensus estimate of 16 cents. Avon Products Inc. AVP, -1.05%  posted first-quarter revenue that was down 18%, citing the impact from a strong dollar and weak sales in North America. Harman International Industries Inc. US:HAR  reported fiscal third-quarter adjusted earnings of $1.22 a share, falling short of analysts’ estimate of $1.27 a share. Analysts at J.P. Morgan lowered Varian Medical Systems Inc.’s VAR, +0.92%  stock rating to neutral from overweight, citing the company’s subdued outlook and a decline in imaging orders during the fiscal second quarter. Zimmer Holdings Inc. US:ZMH  said its first-quarter earnings fell to $177.1 million, or $1.02 a share, from $221.5 million, or $1.29 a share, a year earlier. Excluding expenses and one-time items, the orthopedic-device maker earned $1.58 a share. Salesforce.com Inc. CRM, +3.03%  are lower after surging 12% in the previous session after reports surfaced that the cloud-computing computer run by Chief Executive Officer Marc Benioff could be a takeover target. Baidu Inc. BIDU, +0.04%  reported adjusted first-quarter earnings of $1.22 a share on revenue of $2.05 billion, with $277.7 million in traffic acquisition costs. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast $1.19 a share and revenue of $2.08 billion. Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, +2.47%  posted better-than-expected profit and sales but the integrated oil giant’s results still show signs of the plunge in oil prices. ConocoPhillips COP, +0.95%  said its first-quarter earnings fell less than expected. Time Warner Cable Inc. US:TWC  posted weaker-than-forecast first-quarter profit and sales, on the heels of collapsing bid by the media company to be acquired by rival Comcast Corp. title: LinkedIn shares sell off after hours on disappointing outlook

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. said its revenue rose 15% in the latest quarter, buoyed by strong demand for its specialty products and growth from its collaboration with Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc. The drug wholesaler's revenue rose to $32.7 billion, slightly exceeding expectations of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $32.25 billion. AmerisourceBergen's board also authorized the repurchase of an additional $1 billion of the company's shares as part of its previously announced strategy to mitigate the potentially dilutive impact related to the exercise of the warrants held by affiliates of Walgreens Boots Alliance. For the year ending in September, the company raised its per-share earnings estimate to $4.85 to $4.95 and revenue growth view to 12% to 13%, from its previous estimate for a per-share profit of $4.45 to $4.55 and revenue growth of 10% to 11%. In 2013, AmerisourceBergen began an alliance with U.S. drugstore-chain operator Walgreen and European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH, which have since merged. In the latest quarter, pharmaceutical distribution revenue rose 14% to $31.8 billion, again boosted by the Walgreen generic-pharmaceutical business and sales of hepatitis C drugs. Nonpharmaceutical sales soared 72% to $986.1 million, thanks to a month of revenue from the recent acquisition of MWI Veterinary Supply Inc., which distributes animal health products in the U.S. and Britain. For the period ended March 31, AmerisourceBergen reported a loss of $513.4 million, or $2.33 a share, compared with a year-earlier profit of $180.1 million, or 76 cents a share. Excluding warrant expenses, antitrust litigation settlement related gains and other items, per-share earnings rose to $1.45 from $1.06. Analysts expected a per-share profit of $1.19. Shares rose 2.3% to $115 in recent premarket trading. Write to Tess Stynes at tess.stynes@wsj.com Access Investor Kit for AmerisourceBergen Corp. title: AmerisourceBergen's lifts outlook, boosts buybacks

content: AmerisourceBergen is a distributor of drugs and health supplies based in Chesterbrook, Pa. It runs 26 U.S. pharmaceutical distribution centers, four U.S. specialty distribution centers, and two Canadian distribution hubs, in order to maximize supply chain efficiency. With some recent moves and some good growth, the stock appears to be a good one to check out for the space. The last time I wrote about this S&P 500 constituent, the company announced it was acquiring MWI Veterinary Supply for $190 per share. The acquisition is expected to add an additional $0.08 in earnings this year. I also was long the stock at the time that AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29%  announced the deal. The acquisition of MWI Veterinary Supply is expected to close soon, and as a result, several firms are raising their earnings estimates and upping their price targets and ratings on ABC stock. But most recently, UBS upgraded AmerisourceBergen to a buy from neutral. This firm's upgrade is based on the thesis that AmerisourceBergen has the "greatest leverage" to U.S. biosimilars, calling it "the pony to ride" to capture the upside related to the $65 billion in biologics that will be facing biosimilar competition over the next five years. What is a biosimilar? A biosimilar is a biological product whose approval is based on evidence it is highly similar to an already approved biologic, known as the reference product. While biosimilars have been used in Europe and Japan for a while, up until recently, there was no regulatory pathway in the U.S. But just this month the first biosimilar version of a drug received FDA approval in the U.S. And going forward, Amerisource Bergen is well leveraged to this business. Currently, three companies generate about 85%-90% of all revenue in the wholesale drug-distribution industry, AmerisourceBergen,Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% and McKesson Corp MCK, +0.15% While AmerisourceBergen is not the largest competitor, is does have some the best revenue growth. What are some other factors driving growth for AmerisourceBergen? For one thing, the company is reaping the benefits of its 10-year contract with Walgreen WBA, -3.14%  to provide branded and generic drug products. AmerisourceBergen entered into a strategic agreement with Walgreen Boots Alliance in 2013, and clearly this relationship is paying off. Yet another factor driving results is sales momentum related to the sale of products to treat hepatitis C. New hep-C treatments are now available from Gilead Sciences GILD, +0.82% AbbVie ABBV, +0.40%  and Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% The company is bucking the trend of companies experiencing earnings difficulties and appears poised to outperform going forward. But AmerisourceBergen is not just a great growth story, it even pays a nice dividend yield of 1.0%. So let's take a closer look. Data from Best Stocks Now app AmericsourceBergen is a large-cap, $25 billion market-capitalization drug company. Its risk profile is conservative, and I own it in my conservative growth portfolio. Data from Best Stocks Now app AmerisourceBergen does not appear cheap on a valuation basis and rates a value grade of “D+,” but it is the growth story that makes the stock interesting. Its estimated 5 year annual growth rate is 11%, but that growth is rapidly accelerating due to strong growth in generic drugs and biosimilar agents, its partnership with Walgreen, and new drug availability in the hep-C segment. Data from Best Stocks Now app AmerisourceBergen receives a momentum grade of “B” and a performance grade of “A.” The stock has been a consistent outperformer relative to the Index. More recently, it is up more than 77% over the last year. And year to date, it is up an impressive 26.2%. Data from Best Stocks Now app AmerisourceBergen is ranked number 164 out of the more than 4000 companies in the Best Stocks Now universe. It receives a rating of weak buy with a stock grade of “B+.” There are huge opportunities in the drug-distribution segment given the growth in generics and biosimilars, new drug discoveries, and pharmacy alliances. AmerisourceBergen appears well positioned to capture these growth opportunities. Disclosure: Gunderson is long ABC, GILD, MCK and WBA. content: In an environment where many companies are missing their earnings estimates or guiding down due to external factors such as commodity exposure and currency impact, AmerisourceBergen Corporation just reported a pretty solid quarter, beating estimates by $0.17. But does that make them a good investment? The company upped their outlook for the year to $4.45-$4.55 from their prior view of $4.36-$4.50 and guided up revenue well above the Wall Street consensus. In fact, AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% is experiencing its best growth in five years. AmerisourceBergen is a distributor of drugs and health supplies based in Chesterbrook, Pa. It runs 26 U.S. pharmaceutical distribution centers, four U.S. specialty distribution centers, and two Canadian distribution hubs, in order to maximize supply-chain efficiency. Much of the upward revision came about as a result of its announced acquisition of MWI Veterinary Supply US:MWIV  for $190 per share, which the company expects to add an additional $0.08 in earnings this year. I wrote about MWIV in my book back in 2001. I also was long the stock at the time that AmerisourceBergen announced the deal. Three companies generate about 85%-90% of all revenue in the wholesale drug-distribution industry, Amerisource Bergen, Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% and McKesson Corp MCK, +0.15% While AmerisourceBergen is not the largest competitor, is does have some the best revenue growth, with a 21% jump from 2012 to 2013. What are some of the other factors driving growth for AmerisourceBergen? For one thing, AmerisourceBergen is reaping the benefits of its 10-year contract with Walgreen WBA, -3.14%  to provide branded and generic drug products. AmerisourceBergen entered into a strategic agreement with Walgreen Boots Alliance in 2013, and clearly this relationship is paying off. Yet another factor driving results is sales momentum related to the sale of products to treat Hepatitis C. New Hep-C treatments are now available from Gilead Sciences GILD, +0.82% AbbVie ABBV, +0.40% and Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% The stock hit a new high after rising on these strong earnings results. AmerisourceBergen is bucking the trend of companies experiencing earnings difficulties and appears poised to outperform going forward. So, let's take a closer look. Data from Best Stocks Now app AmericsourceBergen is a large-cap $21 billion company. Its risk profile is conservative, and I own it in my Conservative Growth portfolio. Data from Best Stocks Now app AmerisourceBergen does not appear cheap on a valuation basis and rates a value grade of “C+.” But it is the growth story that makes the stock interesting. Its five-year annual growth rate is 12.3%, but that growth is rapidly accelerating due to strong growth in generic drugs, its partnership with Walgreen, and new drug availability in the Hep-C segment. Data from Best Stocks Now app AmerisourceBergen receives a momentum grade of “A-” and a performance grade of “A.” The stock has been a consistent outperformer relative to the index. More recently it is up more than 45% over the last year. Data from Best Stocks Now app AmerisourceBergen is ranked number 50 out of the more than 3900 companies in the Best Stocks Now universe. It receives a rating of strong buy with a stock grade of “A.” There are huge opportunities in the drug-distribution segment given the growth in generics, new drug discoveries, and pharmacy alliances. AmerisourceBergen appears well positioned to capture these opportunities. Disclosure: Gunderson is long ABC. title: The best way to get into the drug-distribution space

content: Cardinal Health Inc. raised its outlook for its fiscal year ending in June after the company posted forecast-topping results in its December quarter. Cardinal now expects to post $4.28 to $4.38 a share in earnings, up from its previous guidance for $4.10 to $4.30 a share in earnings. "Although we experienced some continued challenges in the Canadian market, we saw real progress in most of our business lines and customer channels," said Chief Executive George Barrett in a news release. The Dublin, Ohio, company, which provides pharmaceuticals and medical products, was dealt a blow in 2013 when the drugstore chains that have since combined into Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc. agreed to get their branded and generic pharmaceutical products from rival AmerisourceBergen Corp. Drug wholesalers have been forming ventures and collaborations with other health-care related companies, in an effort to boost their bargaining power with pharmaceutical companies and expand internationally. Cardinal Health agreed to form a joint venture with CVS Caremark Corp., in which the drugstore-operator and pharmacy-benefits manager source generic drugs as consumers increasingly are using the less-expensive medicines. For its fiscal second quarter, the company posted a profit of $289 million, or 86 cents a share, compared with $278 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding special items, earnings were $1.20 a share. Revenue grew 15% to $25.5 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters recently projected earnings of $1.10 cents a share on revenue of $23.5 billion. Revenue in the company's pharmaceutical segment grew 16% to $22.6 billion as it grew its existing and new customer bases. The medical segment's revenue grew 4% to $2.9 billion, driven by acquisitions and growth from existing customers. title: Cardinal Health beats profit forecast, ups outlook

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. said Wednesday that its revenue rose 15% in the December quarter, buoyed by strong demand for its specialty products and gains from its collaboration with Walgreen Boots Alliance Inc. Results beat expectations, sending shares up about 3% in premarket trading. The company also raised its earnings outlook for the year ending in September to $4.45 to $4.55 a share, up from its previous range of $4.36 to $4.50 a share. Drug wholesalers like AmerisourceBergen have been forming ventures and collaborations with other health-care related companies to increase their bargaining power with pharmaceutical companies. In 2013, AmerisourceBergen began an alliance with U.S. drugstore-chain operator Walgreen and European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH, which have since merged. Earlier this month, the company agreed to buy MWI Veterinary Supply Inc. for $2.5 billion, expanding into the growing area of animal health. In its fiscal first quarter, pharmaceutical distribution revenue grew 15% to $33 billion, primarily due to the new Walgreen generic-pharmaceutical business, strong sales of hepatitis C products, and organic sales growth in its health systems and alternate-site customers. Within the segment, the specialty group saw revenue grow 26% due to good performance in the blood products category and increases in sales to community oncology practices. Nonpharmaceutical revenue also grew 15%, mostly due to demand for the company's consulting business. Overall, AmerisourceBergen reported a loss of $200 million, or 91 cents a share, compared with a profit of $41.3 million, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding special items including those related to the MWI transaction, earnings rose to $1.14 a share from 80 cents the year before. Revenue grew to $33.6 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected per-share earnings of 97 cents and revenue of $31.6 billion. Shares of AmerisourceBergen have risen 42% in the past 12 months as of Tuesday's close. content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — U.S. stocks ended Monday’s session with losses for the second straight trading session, as a renewed assault on oil prices eroded investor confidence ahead of the start of fourth-quarter earnings season. Energy, technology and financials, which collectively comprise nearly half of the S&P 500, led the losses. The S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  fell 16.55 points, or 0.8%, to 2,028.26, as nine of 10 main sectors finished lower. Energy sector lost 2.8%, while the technology sector was down 1.3%. Telecoms were the only bright spot, ending 0.6% higher. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% which opened with a 40-point gain, fell as much as 130 points at session lows. The blue-chip index closed down 96.53 points, or 0.5%, at 17,640.84, with more than two-thirds of its 30 components closing in negative territory. Chevron Corp. CVX, +1.73%  and Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, +2.47%  led losing stocks, both down about 2%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite COMP, +1.64%  slumped 39.36 points, or 0.8%, to 4,664.71, as big losses in Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78%   dragged the index lower, in spite of a string of announced mergers and acquisitions among biotechnology companies. Meanwhile, as investors turned away from equities, havens such as government bonds and gold rallied. The 10-year Treasury yield US:10_YEAR which moves inversely to prices, fell 3 basis points to 1.91%. Gold prices US:GCG5  gained $17 to $1,233. Kim Caughey Forrest, investment analyst at Fort Pitt Capital, was not perturbed by the volatility. “Investors are reacting and sometimes overreacting to news, which is how markets are supposed to work. As long-term investors, we were a lot more nervous when markets kept marching in 2013 and 2014,” Forrest said. “Another slide in oil is bad news, because it is indicative of bigger issues in global economy. So, markets will react to that. Long-term investors should pay attention to stocks in their portfolios and periodically evaluate if the story behind why they own the stock is still intact. But for the most part, selling when everyone else is selling is a bad strategy,” she added. John Manley, chief equity strategist at Wells Fargo, noted that the momentum for the fourth-quarter earning expectations has shifted to less positive, as energy companies’ profits will be hit. “Investors are asking questions, like, how can oil fall 50% and not have repercussions, when the price is about 20% below the level at which most energy companies cut their capital expenditures,” Manley said. “However, we still believe that consumer spending, which dwarves capex spending, will benefit from lower oil prices and therefore will be net positive for the economy. We are in a period of higher volatility, but would consider any pullback of 8-12% as a buying opportunity,” he added. Oil still a worry: Oil futures plunged Monday, with the U.S. benchmark trading below the $46-a-barrel threshold for the first time in nearly six years after Goldman Sachs cut its crude outlook, predicting prices will remain low for a lengthy period. The investment bank slashed its Nymex 2015 crude forecast to $47.15 a barrel, from $73.75 a barrel, and cut its Brent estimate to $50.40 a barrel, from $83.75 a barrel. Société Générale also cut its oil-price forecasts. Read: Energy stocks brace for many quarters of earnings pressure In response, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for February delivery CLG5, +0.00%   fell $2.29, or 4.7%, to close at $46.07 a barrel after trading as low as $45.90. Meanwhile, Brent North Sea crude oil for February LCOG5, -0.53%   the global benchmark, lost $2.68, or 5.4%, to $47.43 a barrel, its lowest finish since March 2009. See Need to Know: Engage sick bags as stormy markets show no signs of calm In other markets, the Stoxx Europe 600 index SXXP, +0.44% initially surged, but later trimmed gains and closed up 0.5% after CNBC reported, citing sources, that the ECB is planning a quantitative-easing program that could be based on contributions made by central banks to the ECB. Read more on European stocks. Stocks to watch: Alcoa AA, +1.22%  kicked off the fourth-quarter season with better-than-expected results. Shares 1.4% in after-hours trade Monday, after the aluminum giant posted profit and sales that rose more than expected. Merger Monday: Shares of Foundation Medicine Inc. FMI, -1.44%  nearly doubled to $46.74 after Roche Holding AG ROG, -0.86% RHHBY, -0.61%  said it would pay $1.03 billion for up to a 56.3% stake in the maker of molecular-diagnostics tests. Roche will pay $50 a share, a 109% premium over Foundation’s closing price of $23.93 on Friday. Shares of NPS Pharmaceuticals Inc. US:NPSP  jumped 8.2% after Dublin-based Shire PLC SHPG, +3.36% SHP, +2.01%  said it would buy the specialty drug maker in a $5.2 billion deal. Tekmira Pharmaceuticals Corp. US:TKMR  surged 57%. The company announced late Sunday that it will merge with OnCore Biopharma Inc. to develop a cure for hepatitis B. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  said it would buy MWI Veterinary Supply Inc. US:MWIV  in a deal valued at $2.5 billion. MWI shares rose 8.2%. Tiffany & Co. TIF, -0.38%  shares fell 14%, after the jewelry retailer posted a 1% drop in holiday-period sales. Other markets: In Asia, the Hang Seng Index HSI, +0.24%  extended a winning streak to four sessions, while Japanese markets were closed for a public holiday. The euro EURUSD, +0.0000%  slipped on those reports about the ECB quantitative-easing program. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Slumping oil drags U.S. stocks lower ahead of earnings

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of MWI Veterinary Supply mwiv were indicated higher in premarket trade Monday, after the company said it agreed to be acquired by AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% in a deal valued at $2.5 billion. AmerisourceBergen will pay $190 for each MWI Veterinary share, which represents an 8.2% premium to Friday's closing price. AmerisourceBergen will launch a tender offer for MWI Veterinary shares no later than Jan. 26. The companies expect the deal to close during the quarter ending in March 2015. MWI Veterinary's stock was up 5.8% in very light trading ahead of the open, while AmerisourceBergen's stock was still inactive. MWI Veterinary's stock has rallied 24% over the past three months through Friday, while the S&P 500 has gained 7.3%.
title: MWI Veterinary's stock set to rally after buyout deal with AmerisourceBergen

content: Cardinal Health Inc. said its revenue edged down 2% in the September quarter, hurt by the expiration of its contract with Walgreen Co. The company was dealt a blow last year when Walgreen and European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH agreed to get their branded and generic pharmaceutical products from rival AmerisourceBergen Corp. Drug wholesalers have been forming ventures and collaborations with other health-care related companies, in an effort to increase their bargaining power with pharmaceutical companies and expand internationally. Late last year, Cardinal Health agreed to form a joint venture with CVS Caremark Corp., in which the drugstore-operator and pharmacy-benefits manager source generic drugs as consumers increasingly are using the less-expensive medicines. The Dublin, Ohio-based company provides pharmaceuticals and medical products to more than 100,000 locations, while also offering direct-to-home distribution of medical supplies. For its first quarter ended Sept. 30, the company posted a profit of $266 million, or 78 cents a share, compared with $339 million, or 99 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding special items, earnings fell to $1 a share from $1.10. Revenue fell to $24.07 billion from $24.52 billion. Excluding the impact of the Walgreen contract expiration, revenue would have grown 13%, the company said. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters recently projected earnings of 96 cents a share on revenue of $22.43 billion. Revenue in the company's pharmaceutical segment fell about 3% to $21.21 billion because of the expiration of the Walgreens contract in the prior-year quarter. Excluding the impact of the Walgreens contract expiration, the segment's revenue would have grown 15%, the company said. Segment profit rose 4% to $451 million, driven by growth from new and existing customers. The medical segment's revenue increased 5% to $2.85 billion, driven by acquisitions, while profit climbed about 6% to $113 million. The company backed its outlook for full-year earnings. title: Cardinal Health revenue slips 2%

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. said its revenue increased 29% in the fourth quarter, driven by strong top-line gains in its pharmaceutical distribution business. For the recently started fiscal year, the drug wholesaler expects earnings of $4.36 to $4.50 a share on revenue growth of 7% to 8%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters recently expected full-year earnings of $4.38 a share on revenue growth of 5%. Drug wholesalers have been forming ventures and collaborations with other health-care-related companies to increase their bargaining power with pharmaceutical companies and expand internationally. Last year, AmerisourceBergen began an alliance with U.S. drugstore-chain operator Walgreen Co. and European drug company Alliance Boots GmbH. The onboarding of all the new Walgreen-branded pharmaceuticals business and a chunk of the generic pharmaceuticals business helped drive up revenue this quarter, the company said. Earlier this year, the company launched its specialty drug-distribution joint venture with Profarma Distribuidora de Produtos Farmaceuticos SA, and completed its acquisition of a 19.9% stake in the Brazilian drug wholesaler. For the period ended Sept. 30, revenue rose to $31.59 billion from $24.47 billion. Pharmaceutical distribution revenue rose 29% to $31.02 billion. Overall, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $67.8 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with a profit of $51 million, or 22 cents a share, a year earlier. The company's cost of sales rose 29% to $30.72 billion, while its operating expenses increased 47% to $665.3 million. Excluding special items, per-share earnings from continuing operations rose to $1.10 from 81 cents. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected per-share profit of $1.05 and revenue of $30.78 billion. Write to Erin McCarthy at erin.mccarthy@wsj.com Access Investor Kit for AmerisourceBergen Corp. title: AmerisourceBergen revenue tops estimates

content: McKesson Corp.'s second-quarter profit rose 16% as the drug wholesaler reported a surge in revenue. Fuelled by the low-margin, high-revenue business, McKesson--along with fellow drug wholesalers Cardinal Health Inc. and AmerisourceBergen Corp.--have set their eyes beyond the U.S. for expansion. In the latest period, the San Francisco company's distribution segment posted revenue growth of 37% to $44 billion, largely driven by contributions from its increased stake in German drug distributor Celesio AG and market growth. Overall for the period ended Sept. 30, McKesson reported a profit of $469 million, or $1.99 a share, down from $404 million, or $1.74 a share, a year earlier. Excluding acquisition-related expenses and other items, adjusted earnings from continuing operations rose to $2.79 a share from $2.30 a share. Revenue increased nearly 36% to $44.76 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expected a profit of $2.73 and revenue of $42.99 billion. The company's medical-surgical segment revenue rose 4%. Through Tuesday's closing, the company's stock was up nearly 25% for the year. Cardinal Health and AmerisourceBergen report results on Oct. 30. The company affirmed its profit forecast for the year that ends March 31. content: Walgreen Co. on Tuesday said same-store sales rose 5.2% in July, as strong pharmacy sales helped to offset weaker front-end traffic. Overall sales increased 6.1% to $6.39 billion. Walgreen in June pulled its goals for fiscal year 2016, saying key decisions still need to be made about its partnership with European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH, while also highlighting a number of pressures that hurt its pharmacy operations in the May quarter. Walgreen has an option to buy the rest of Switzerland-based Alliance Boots between February and August of next year. Executives intend to brief investors in the coming weeks on whether the company plans to acquire the remaining stake, how it would structure a deal and where the combined company would be based. Meanwhile, the company has faced lower third-party reimbursements, fewer brand-to-generic drug conversion and generic drug price inflation, all of which have hurt margins. A shift in consumers' drug purchases toward generics has led pharmacy companies to take steps to improve their performance, highlighted by the alliance between Walgreen and Alliance Boots with drug wholesaler AmerisourceBergen Corp. On Tuesday, Walgreen said same-store sales in the pharmacy section increased 7.6% in July. Same-store prescriptions filled increased 3.7%. Pharmacy sales accounted for 66.5% of total sales for the month. During July, same-store sales rose 1.1% in the front end of the store. Same-store customer traffic decreased 2.6%, while basket size increased 3.7%, Walgreen said. Write to Anna Prior at anna.prior@wsj.com Access Investor Kit for AmerisourceBergen Corp. content: Cardinal Health Inc. said its fiscal fourth-quarter revenue declined, hampered by the expiration of the drug wholesaler's contract with Walgreen Co. Its results for the period still topped consensus estimates. The company was dealt a blow last year when Walgreen and European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH agreed to get their branded and generic pharmaceutical products from rival AmerisourceBergen Corp. Drug wholesalers have been forming ventures and collaborations with other health-care related companies, in an effort to increase their bargaining power with pharmaceutical companies and expand internationally,. Cardinal Health has formed a joint venture with CVS Caremark Corp., in which the drugstore-operator and pharmacy-benefits manager source generic drugs as consumers increasingly are using the less-expensive medicines. The Dublin, Ohio-based company provides pharmaceuticals and medical products to more than 100,000 locations, while also offering direct-to-home distribution of medical supplies. For the most recently ended period, the company posted a profit of $234 million, or 68 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier loss of $586 million, or $1.72 a share. Adjusted earnings were 83 cents a share, up from 79 cents a year ago. The year-earlier period included an $832 million write-dow tied to the company's nuclear pharmacy services division. Revenue dropped 10% to $22.9 billion. Excluding the impact of the Walgreen contract expiration, revenue was up 12%, the company said. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters recently projected earnings of 81 cents a share on revenue of $21.9 billion. Revenue in the company's pharmaceutical segment decreased 12% to $20.1 billion and segment profit slid 5% to $377 million, due to continuing impact of the expiration of the Walgreen contract, the company said. Excluding that impact, fourth-quarter revenue grew 13%. The medical segment's revenue rose 4% to $2.8 billion, driven by existing customer growth and acquisitions, though profit edged down 8% to $96 million. Looking to the recently started year, Cardinal expects earnings excluding items of $4.10 to $4.30, versus the consensus view of $4.25 a share. Access Investor Kit for AmerisourceBergen Corp.
