content: TripAdvisor shares jump on quarterly results beat (5:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of TripAdvisor Inc. TRIP, +0.69% rallied late Wednesday after the travel website's quarterly earnings and revenue topped Wall Street estimates. Shares rose nearly 15% to $70.20 on moderate volume after-hours. The company reported second-quarter earnings of $67 million, or 46 cents a share, up from $62.3 million, or 43 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding one-time items, TripAdvisor would have reported earnings of 52 cents a share. Revenue rose to $246.9 million from $197.1 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected 50 cents a share on revenue of $229.9 million. Angie's List cuts loss; revenue in line (4:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Angie's List Inc. ANGI, +0.37% on Wednesday reported a second-quarter loss of $14.3 million, or 25 cents a share, on revenue of $59.2 million, compared with a loss of $23.4 million, or 41 cents a share, on $36.5 million in sales in the same period a year ago. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast the online professional-services referral company to lose 25 cents a share on $59.2 million in sales. Angie's List also estimated its third-quarter sales in a range of $65.5 million to $66.5 million, while analysts had forecast the company's revenue at $65.5 million. Angie's List's shares fell 6% in after-hours trading. Earlier in the day, Angie's List's stock took a hit on a report that eBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% was testing a similar service in the United Kingdom. Facebook blows past estimates, shares soar (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Facebook Inc. FB, +4.42% on Wednesday reported a second-quarter profit of $333 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with a loss of $157 million, or 8 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $1.81 billion from $1.12 billion. Adjusted profit was 19 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet on average expected the social network to report a profit of 14 cents a share, on revenue of $1.62 billion. The company said it now has 1.15 billion monthly active users, up 21% from the year-earlier period. Shares of Facebook soared 16% in after-hours trading. Qualcomm earnings jump, beating targets (4:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Qualcomm Inc. reported a sharp jump in profits for its third fiscal quarter on Wednesday afternoon, beating Wall Street's expectations thanks to strong sales of its mobile device chipsets. For the period ended June 30, Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% reported net income of $1.58 billion, or 90 cents per share, compared to net income of $1.2 billion, or 69 cents per share, for the same period last year. Adjusted earnings came in at $1.82 billion, or $1.03 per share, for the recent period. Revenue grew 35% to $6.24 billion. Analysts were expecting adjusted earnings of 91 cents per share on revenue of $6.05 billion, according to FactSet. Qualcomm shares edged up a fraction in after-hours trading following the report. EA surges to highest level in nearly 5 years (1:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Electronic Arts Inc. EA, +1.60% surged more than 10% to $26.23 by Wednesday afternoon -- setting the highest level for the stock since October of 2008. Late Tuesday, the videogame publisher, mostly on gains from mobile and other digital channels. Several analysts raised their price target on the stock, which is up more than 80% since the first of the year. Drew Crum of Stifel Nicolaus raised his target to $30 from $27, calling the results "a good start" to the fiscal year ahead of the launch of the Xbox One and PlayStation 4 game consoles. Michael Pachter of Wedbush Securities kept his price target at $30, but removed the stock from the broker's "Best Ideas" list. "I continue to really like this stock, but the share price has risen to the point where I can't see any near-term catalysts that would drive it 20% higher, which is our criterion," he wrote in a note to clients. Apple upgraded by BMO on margin forecast (10:32 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% was upgraded to an outperform rating by BMO Capital Markets on Wednesday morning following the company's third fiscal quarter report,. In a note to clients, analyst Keith Bachman cited the company's gross margin guidance of 36%-37% for the current September quarter as the main driver of his upgrade. "While we still have some concerns about December quarter margins, we believe that the September-quarter gross margin guidance plausibly supports our view that the new mid-range iPhone will be in the ~$450 price range with approximately 38% to 40% gross margins," he wrote. Apple's shares were up 5% to $439.90 in morning trades. Tech stocks rise as Apple, EMC flex muscles early (9:39 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Tech stocks showed some strength in early trading Wednesday, with Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% shares rising more than 5%, and EMC Corp. EMC, +9.92% up by more than 7% after both companies reported upbeat quarterly results. Also edging higher was Facebook Inc. FB, +4.42% which was up by 8 cents a share at $26.22 ahead of the social-networking leader's earnings report, due after the close of trading. The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +1.64% rose 24 points to 3,603. Apple up 4% in premarket after results (7:57 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% rose over 4% in premarket trading on Wednesday after the company posted results that beat targets. Reporting fiscal third-quarter numbers late Tuesday, Apple earned $6.9 billion, or $7.47 a share, down from $8.8 billion, or $9.32 a share, a year earlier. But that EPS number beat the $7.31 a share that analysts had been expecting as sales of the iPhone came in ahead of Wall Street estimates. IPhone shipment numbers also beat Wall Street's targets, but the average selling price of the device fell. Mizuho Securities cut its target on Apple to $520 from $550, but kept a buy rating. At Oppenheimer, analysts maintained an outperform rating, but said they see "limited upside" to their current target of $460. Caterpillar shares fall in premarket after results (7:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Caterpillar Inc. CAT, +1.53% reported its second-quarter profit fell to $960 million, or $1.45 a share, from $1.70 billion, or $2.54 a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell to $14.62 billion, from $17.34 billion a year earlier, the construction-equipment company said Wednesday. Analysts had expected earnings of $1.69 a share on revenue of $15.09 billion, according to FactSet. Caterpillar blamed its disappointing results to currency translation and hedging losses, dealer machine inventory reductions, and declines in inventory. The company revised its full-year 2013 revenue estimates to a range of $56 billion to $58 billion, from a range of $57 billion to $61 billion. It also revised its full-year earnings per share outlook to $6.50 from $7.00. Shares in Caterpillar were down 1.06% in premarket trading. General Dynamics profit rises to $640 million (7:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - General Dynamics GD, +1.67% reported its second-quarter profit rose to $640 million, or $1.81 per share, up from $634 million, or $1.77 per share, a year earlier. Revenue fell to $7.91 billion, down from $7.2 billion a year earlier, the aerospace and defense company said Wednesday. Analysts had expected earnings of $1.62 a share on revenue of $7.72 billion, according to FactSet. Ford shares rise on strong second-quarter earnings (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% reported its second-quarter profit rose to $1.23 billion, or 30 cents a share, from $1.04 billion, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $38.1 billion, from $33.3 billion a year earlier, the automotive company said Wednesday. Analysts had expected earnings of 37 cents a share on revenue of $34.94 billion, according to FactSet. Ford attributed its rise in earnings to strong sales in North America, and recovering sales in South America. The company left its full-year outlook unchanged, noting expectations of a 10% profit margin. Shares in Ford were up 3% in premarket trading. PepsiCo affirms core EPS guidance as earnings rise (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- PepsiCo Inc. PEP, -0.03% reported its second-quarter profit rose 35% to $2.01 billion, or $1.28 a share, from $1.49 billion, or $0.94 a share, a year earlier. Core earnings per share rose 17% to $1.31, the soft-drinks giant added Wednesday. Revenue rose 2% to $16.81 billion, from $16.46 billion a year earlier. Analysts had expected earnings of $1.19 a share on revenue of $16.79 billion, according to FactSet. The company reiterated expectations of 7% growth in core earnings per share, assuming constant currencies, but said it now expects foreign-exchange effects to have an unfavorable impact of approximately 2 percentage points on its full-year core EPS performance. Shares in PepsiCo were up 1.8% in thin premarket trading. AmerisourceBergen third-quarter profit falls (7:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Wednesday its fiscal third-quarter profit fell to $168.5 million, or 71 cents a share, from $181.3 million, or 71 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. The company said adjusted per-share earnings from continuing operations were 73 cents. Revenue rose 13% to $21.9 billion from $19.3 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings of 75 cents a share on revenue of $21.4 billion. AmerisourceBergen expects 2013 adjusted per-share earnings from continuing operations of $3.06 to $3.11 and maintains its revenue growth view of 11% to 13%. Eli Lilly net income up 31%, sales up 6% (6:53 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Pharmaceutical group Eli Lilly and Company LLY, +0.47% on Wednesday reported rising net income and revenue, citing growth in key products that helped offset patent expiries that affected its Zyprexa sales. For the second quarter, Eli Lilly said net income rose to $1.206 billion, or $1.11 a share, from $923.6 million, or 83 cents, in the year-ago period. Adjusted income rose 36% to $1.255 billion, or $1.16 a share. The company was expected to post earnings of $1 a share in the period, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Total revenue rose 6% to $5.93 billion from $5.601 billion in the year-ago period. The company also raised its 2013 EPS guidance to $4.28 to $4.38 per share, or an adjusted $4.05 to $4.15 per share. WellPoint profit rises 24% in second quarter (6:20 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Managed health-care firm WellPoint Inc. WLP on Wednesday reported a 24% rise in second-quarter profit to $800.1 million, or $2.64 a share, up from $643.6 million, or $1.94 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings per share rose to $2.60 from $2.04. Total revenues picked up 16% to $17.8 billion from $15.4 billion last year. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected earnings of $2.07 a share on revenue of $17.8 billion. The company said it expects full-year net income to be at least $8 a share and operating revenue to be in the range of $70 billion to $72 billion. Additionally, the firm said in the release that the Board of Directors on Tuesday declared a dividend for the third quarter of $0.375 a share. title: Drug-servicing companies have contrasting earnings reports

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 7.1% as the drug wholesaler posted higher operating expeneses tied to its recent deal with Walgreen Co. (WAG). For the year, the company narrowed its per-share earnings estimate and now expects $3.06 to $3.11 from its earlier estimate of $3.04 to $3.14. AmerisourceBergen also affirmed revenue growth view. Walgreen and Alliance Boots GmbH recently agreed to get their branded and generic pharmaceutical products from AmerisourceBergen, in exchange for the two companies having the right to buy a minority position in the drug wholesaler. This is expected to begin in September. Meanwhile, AmerisourceBergen agreed in April to sell its contract packaging business, AndersonBrecon $308 million in cash, and its Canadian pharmaceutical business to health-care supplies distributor Kohl & Frisch Ltd. for an estimated $80 million to $100 million, while retaining its Canadian specialty business. For the quarter ended June 30, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $168.4 million, down from $181.3 million. Per-share earnings were flat at 71 cents. Excluding one-time items such as a last-in-first-out expense, earnings were 73 cents a share, down from 74 cents a year earlier. Revenue increased 13% to $21.9 billion, driven by a 16% increase in AmerisourceBergen Drug Corp. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently projected earnings of 74 cents on revenue of $21.33 billion. Gross margin fell to 2.57% from 3.46%. Total operating expenses increased 25% to $427.8 million due to transaction costs related to the deal with Walgreen and Alliance Boots. Shares closed Tuesday at $57.63 and were inactive premarket. title: AmerisourceBergen earnings fall on higher expenses

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Wednesday its fiscal third-quarter profit fell to $168.5 million, or 71 cents a share, from $181.3 million, or 71 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. The company said adjusted per-share earnings from continuing operations were 73 cents. Revenue rose 13% to $21.9 billion from $19.3 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings of 75 cents a share on revenue of $21.4 billion. AmerisourceBergen expects 2013 adjusted per-share earnings from continuing operations of $3.06 to $3.11 and maintains its revenue growth view of 11% to 13%.
title: AmerisourceBergen third-quarter profit falls

content: Walgreen Co.'s WAG same-store sales rose 2.3% in June, boosted by continued improved performance in the pharmacy section, though the drugstore chain reported another drop in same-store customer traffic. In a note to clients, analysts at SunTrust Robinson Humphrey recently said Wall Street expected a 3.1% increase in same-store sales. On Wednesday, Walgreen said that a calendar shift negatively impacted June same-store sales by 1.5 percentage points. Walgreen and its rivals have seen sales hurt by a wave of generic drug introductions over the past year. Generic drug introductions over the past 12 months had a negative impact of 1.8 percentage points. The shift in consumers' drug purchases toward generics has led pharmacy companies to take steps to improve their performance--including a recent alliance by Walgreen and European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH with drug wholesaler AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Walgreen also reported that the percentage of former Express Scripts Holding Co. ESRX, -0.93% prescriptions returning to its pharmacies continued to increase in June, but didn't provide further details. The company reported that in the front of the store, total sales rose 2.2% in June while same-store sales edge up 0.8%. Walgreen reported a 2.9% decline in same-store customer traffic and basket size grew 3.7%. In the pharmacy section, total sales were up 2.9%, while same store-sales improved 3.3%. Same-store prescriptions rose 5%. The company said a calendar shift negatively impacted pharmacy same-store sales by 2.3 percentage points and prescriptions filled by 2.3 percentage points. Total drugstore sales increased 2.5% to $5.79 billion in June from a year earlier. Shares closed Tuesday at $44.46 and were inactive premarket. The stock is up 20% so far this year. title: Walgreen same-store sales rose 2.3% in June

content: As we approach all-time highs in the S&P 500, we wanted to look at the top 10 most overbought names in the index. As expected, these names are compiled in the defensive sectors such as consumer goods, health care and some consumer services. These names have lead since the second part of the rally took hold in mid December. On the chart page attached below, we show the defensive sectors’ divergence from the aggressive, more cyclical sectors. The most overbought names are in ascending order, some of which happen to be on our strongest 20 S&P list, as money continually chases defensive, higher-yielding stocks as investor look for yield. The Kroger Co KR, +1.35%   Hormel Food HRL, +1.96%   John & Johnson JNJ, +0.55%   AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29%   Health Care REIT US:HCN   Kimberly-Clark Corporation KMB, +0.61%   Kellogg K, +1.74%   GIS, +1.60%  General Mills Celgene CELG, +0.90%   H&R Block HRB, +1.03%   If we get a meaningful pullback it would not be unexpected for these names to revert the hardest, as investors have significant gains in these names. Another reason would be the further away the price deviates from its mean, the greater the risk of falling to its mean. We haven't seen evidence yet of a rotation into cyclical stocks just yet and the current trend could remain much longer than anyone can predict. However, this could be a potential trade setup for a nice mean-spread trade that would have these two sectors realign to their historical mean. We will be watching closely and will alert readers if and when the trade is ready. Click here to see all charts. title: The 10 most overbought names in the S&P 500

title: Cardinal Health beats earnings forecasts by 25%; shares jump

content: Cardinal Health Inc.'s CAH, +0.94% fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 3.6% amid a tax benefit and as stronger margins offset lower pharmaceutical sales revenue. For the fiscal year, the company raised its per-share earnings estimate to $3.67 to $3.71, from its previous estimate for $3.42 to $3.50. The company's board also authorized a 10% increase in Cardinal's quarterly dividend to 30.25 cents a share. Cardinal Health was dealt a blow in March as Walgreen Co. WAG and European drug giant Alliance Boots GmbH formed an alliance with rival drug wholesaler AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% that could give the companies an advantage in demanding lower prices from drug makers. The distribution pact with AmerisourceBergen replaces Cardinal's contract with Walgreen that expires in August. Last year, Cardinal also lost its contract with pharmacy-benefits manager Express Scripts Holding Co. ESRX, -0.93% to AmerisourceBergen. For the latest quarter, Cardinal's pharmaceutical segment reported revenue declined 10% mostly on the nonrenewal of the Express Scripts contract and brand-to-generic conversions, though segment earnings were up 12%. For the quarter ended March 31, Cardinal Health reported a profit of $345 million, or $1 a share, up from $333 million, or 95 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding deferred tax liability impacts and other items, adjusted earnings from continuing operations rose to $1.20 from 94 cents. Revenue decreased 8.8% to $24.55 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently projected earnings of 95 cents on revenue of $24.72 billion. Gross margin rose to 5.3% from 4.5%. The medical segment improved 3% with a boost from acquisitions. Segment profit grew 12%. Walgreen has been one of Cardinal's two largest customers, along with CVS Caremark Corp. (CVS), where Cardinal also faces a near-term contract renewal battle. "Our organization is successfully innovating and adapting our business lines and portfolio to an evolving market, with a focus on establishing a strategic edge in areas of higher growth," Chief Executive George Barrett said Thursday, pointing to the company's recent $2.1 billion acquisition of AssuraMed Holding Inc., which sells medical supplies directly to patients. The deal is expected to provide Cardinal with reach into a growing home-care market. While Cardinal has a medical segment that distributes an array of medical, surgical and lab products, that business has been focused on hospitals and other professional customers. Shares closed Wednesday at $43.94 and were inactive premarket. title: Cardinal Health profit rose 3.6%; dividend raised

content: NetSuite loss widens, but sales jump (4:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - NetSuite Inc. N on Thursday reported a first-quarter loss of $13 million, or 18 cents a share, compared with a loss of $7.7 million, or 11 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $91.6 million from $69.3 million. Adjusted profit was 4 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet on average were expecting a profit of 3 cents a share, on revenue of $91 million. Starbucks raises 2013 profit outlook (4:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Starbucks SBUX, -0.02% late Thursday raised its fiscal 2013 profit outlook after topping Wall Street's earnings for its fiscal second quarter on the strength of its U.S. business and a decline in coffee futures prices. For the quarter ended March 31, Starbucks said profit rose 26% to $390.4 million, or 51 cents a share. Analysts had expected 48 cents. Revenue rose 11% to $3.6 billion, while same-store sales grew 6%. Operating margins climbed to 15.3% from 13.5%. For its September 2013 fiscal year, Starbucks said it would earn between $2.12 to $2.18 a share. Its old forecast was $2.06 to $2.15 a share. However, Starbucks maintained its outlook for margin improvement, revenue and same-store sales growth. Starbucks shares fell 1.6% to $59.50 in late trade. Ahead of the report, the stock was trading near its five-year high of $62. Expedia posts bigger loss, but results beat Street (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Expedia Inc. EXPE, +3.85% on Thursday reported a first-quarter loss of $104.2 million, or 77 cents a share, compared with a loss of $3.3 million, or 2 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $1 billion from $816.5 million. Adjusted profit was 25 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet on average were expecting the online travel site to post a profit of 23 cents a share, on revenue of $967.5 million. Shares of Expedia were up more than 4% in after-hours trading. Amazon earnings fall, but beat Street forecasts (4:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Amazon.com reported a drop in net income for the first quarter, though widely beat Wall Street's earnings forecast. For the period ended March 31, Amazon AMZN, +1.11% reported net income of $82 million, or 18 cents per share, compared to net income of $130 million, or 28 cents per share, for the same period last year. Revenue rose 22% to $16.07 billion. Analysts were expecting earnings of 7 cents per share on revenue of $16.14 billion, according to FactSet. Operating income came in at $181 million - beating the company's previously forecasted range. Amazon's shares rose 1.5% in after-hours trading following the report 2.2% to $274.70. Fusion-io shares surge on results, forecast (10:00 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Fusion-io FIO jumped nearly 19% to $19.72 in early trades on Thursday after the company and issued a forecast that was also higher than Wall Street's estimates. The company, which sells data-storage technology, said it expects revenue of about $110 million in the current quarter compared to $107 million expected by analysts. "Fusion-io's March quarter report should help quell investor concerns that the sky is falling," wrote Edward Parker of Lazard Capital, who added that the company's "core business is growing nicely." The stock had slid more than 17% in the three months since its last earnings report; Thursday's gains put Fusion-io shares back near the $20 mark the stock was trading at in late January. Akamai, F5 boost tech stocks; Qualcomm, Zynga fall (9:46 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Tech stocks rose to mostly gains on Thursday morning, led by sharp post-earnings jumps at Akamai Technologies AKAM, +1.33% and F5 Networks FFIV, +1.40% along with a decent gain from Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% Offsetting those gains were big drops at Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% Zynga ZNGA, -0.54% and Citrix Systems CTXS, +1.20% The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +1.64% rose 0.5% to 3,287 while the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index SOX, +2.24% rose 0.8%. Qualcomm fell nearly 5% came in below Wall Street's targets, while Zynga slid nearly 9% . Apple shares rose 1.6% to $412 in early trades Zynga shares drop over 9% in wake of forecast (8:25 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Shares of social-games maker Zynga Inc. ZNGA, -0.54% fell over 9% in premarket trading after the company reported a surprise profit for the first quarter, but disappointed with a revenue forecast. Zynga shares fell by that same amount in late trading the day prior. The company said it has pulled the plug on several games and projected a revenue range of $225 million to $235 million for the first quarter, well below expectations. Exxon Mobil Q1 earnings rise as sales fall (8:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, +2.47% earned $9.5 billion during the first quarter, or $2.12 per share, up from $9.45 billion, or $2.00 per share in the first quarter of 2012. Total revenue fell to $108.81 billion from $124.053 billion in the first quarter of 2012. The company reported production decreased 3.5% on an oil-equivalent basis. Analysts had expected EPS of $2.05 on revenue of $109.53 billion. The company declared a second-quarter dividend of $0.63 per share Wednesday. Exxon's stock nudged upward by 0.53% on the day. 3M stock drops on disappointing earnings report (8:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Industrial company 3M MMM, +1.38% reported earnings of $1.129 billion, or $1.61 per share, in the first-quarter, beating its first-quarter of 2012, when it reported earnings of $1.125 billion, or $1.59 per share. 3M's sales for Q1 were $7.63 billion, up from $7.49 billion a year ago, with the company's largest sales growth coming in the health-care and consumer sectors. Wall Street analysts had expected EPS of $1.65 on revenue of $7.81 billion, according to FactSet. Shares were down 3.6% in pre-market trading on the news. UPS reaffirms full-year earnings guidance (8:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- United Parcel Service Inc. UPS, +1.93% said Thursday it earned $1.04 billion, or $1.08 a share in the first quarter, compared with $970 million, or $1.00 a share, a year earlier. Adjusted earnings totaled $1.04 a share. Revenue increased to $13.43 billion from $13.14 billion. Wall Street analysts expected UPS to earn $1.00 a share on sales of $13.47 billion, according to a survey by FactSet. The package-delivery company said it benefited from a stronger-than-expected post-holiday season and it reaffirmed its 2013 guidance for full-year adjusted EPS of between $4.80 to $5.06. United Continental reports Q1 net loss of $417 mln (8:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- United Continental Holdings Inc. UAL, +2.30% reported Thursday a first-quarter net loss of $417 million, or $1.26 loss per share, from a loss of $448 million, or $1.36 loss per share, from a year-ago quarter. The company reported an adjusted loss of 98 cents per share. The airline company's revenue was up 1.4% to $8.7 billion from $8.6 billion in the quarter a year earlier. Wall Street analysts expected the company to have a loss of $1.09 a share on sales of $8.7 billion, according to a survey by FactSet. United Airlines said consolidated passenger revenue was up 0.7% year-over-year for the first quarter. First-quarter 2013 consolidated load factor was 81.1%, an increase of 3 points versus the first quarter of 2012, as available seat miles declined. United Continental shares were down 0.15% in premarket. Bristol-Myers Squibb affirms full-year EPS view (7:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. said Thursday its first-quarter profit fell 45% to $609 million, or 37 cents a share, from $1.1 billion, or 64 cents a share, a year earlier. Net sales fell 27% to $3.83 billion, from $5.25 billion a year earlier. Adjusted earnings were 41 cents per share, the pharmaceutical giant said. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings per share of 41 cents on revenue of $3.88 billion. The company confirmed its 2013 EPS guidance range of $1.54 to $1.64 and its guidance for adjusted EPS of $1.78 to $1.88, assuming current exchange rates. Bristol-Myers Squibb shares were down 0.3% in pre-market trading. Dow Chemical first-quarter profit up, sales fall (7:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dow Chemical Co. DOW, -0.77% said Thursday first-quarter net income rose to $550 million, or 46 cents a share, from $412 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier. Adjusted earnings were 69 cents a share. Quarterly net sales fell to $14.4 billion from $14.7 billion a year ago mainly due to a 13% decline in sales in the Feedstocks and Energy business. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings per share of 61 cents on revenue of $14.84 billion. "We have previously stated that our business plans did not call for material macroeconomic improvements in 2013 versus 2012. Given persistent volatility and uncertainty, this remains the right mindset for operating the Company," said Andrew Liveris, chief executive officer and chairman. Shares were up 0.34% after the report in premarket trade. AmerisourceBergen Q2 profit fell to $45.63 million (7:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corporation ABC, +1.29% said Thursday its second-quarter profit fell to $45.63 million, or 19 cents a share, from $212 million, or 81 cents a share, from a year-ago quarter. The company reported adjusted earnings per share of 87 cents. The pharmaceutical services company's revenue rose 4.1% to $20.5 billion from $19.7 billion in the year-earlier quarter. Wall Street analysts expected the company to earn 88 cents a share on sales of $21.45 billion, according to a survey by FactSet. AmerisourceBergen shares were down more than 3% in premarket trading. ConocoPhillips first-quarter profit falls (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - ConocoPhillips COP, +0.95% said Thursday it earned $2.1 billion, or $1.73 a share, in the first quarter, down from $2.9 billion, or $2.27 a share, a year earlier. Adjusted earnings were $1.42 a share, said the firm, the world's largest independent exploration and production company, based on production and proved reserves. Wall Street analysts had expected it to earn $1.42 a share. The company said that consistent with prior guidance, second-quarter 2013 production from continuing operations is expected to be between 1,440 and 1,470 million barrels of oil-equivalent a day. First-quarter total production was 1,596 MBOED, including continuing operations of 1,555 MBOED, it said. Combined production from its Eagle Ford, Bakken and Permian fields was up 42% over a year earlier, and oil sands production averaged 109 MBOED, up 30% over the first quarter of 2012. Time Warner Cable earnings rise 5% (6:33 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Time Warner Cable Inc. TWC, +0.00% on Thursday reported first-quarter net income of $401 million, or $1.34 per share, up from $382 million, or $1.20 per share in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, income rose to $423 million and $1.41 per share compared to $414 million and $1.30 per share. Revenue came in at $5.48 billion, up from $5.13 billion last year. Analysts polled by FactSet expected earnings of $1.37 per share on revenue of $5.49 billion. title: AmerisourceBergen shares dip as drug distributor's earnings fall short

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal second-quarter earnings fell 78% as losses on discontinued operations masked the drug wholesaler's revenue growth. The company said it now expects full-year earnings from continuing operations to be in the lower half of its range of $3.04 to $3.14 a share, while it raised its revenue growth forecast to between 11% and 13% from its March guidance of a 8% to 10% revenue increase. AmerisourceBergen's profit had improved in recent quarters, thanks in part to the introduction of major generic drugs and a string of acquisitions that expanded its international presence. While generics carry lower prices, they tend to have higher profit margins. Last month, Walgreen Co. WAG and Alliance Boots GmbH agreed to get their branded and generic pharmaceutical products from AmerisourceBergen, in exchange for the two companies having the right to buy a minority position in the drug wholesaler. AmerisourceBergen also has agreed in recent weeks to sell its Canadian pharmaceutical distribution business for an estimated $80 million to $100 million to health-care supplies distributor Kohl & Frisch Ltd., while retaining its Canadian specialty business; and said it will sell its contract-packaging business, AndersonBrecon, for $308 million in cash. The deals are part of AmerisourceBergen's ongoing efforts to refocus its operations. For the quarter ended March 31, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $45.6 million, or 20 cents a share, down from $212.1 million, or 82 cents, a year earlier. Earnings from continuing operations rose to 89 cents a share from 85 cents. Revenue jumped 4.1% to $20.5 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had most recently forecast earnings of 88 cents on revenue of $21.33 billion. Gross margin edged up to 3.49% from 3.45%. Shares closed Wednesday at $55.82 and were inactive premarket. The stock has climbed 29% over the past year. Wall Street analysts expected the company to earn 88 cents a share on sales of $21.45 billion, according to a survey by FactSet. AmerisourceBergen shares were down more than 3% in premarket trading.

title: 6 gut checks before the stock market's opening bell

content: An earlier version of this column had incorrectly quoted Apple’s stock price for Tuesday. The story has been corrected. SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) — Apple Inc. marked the one-year anniversary of the announcement of its first dividend by closing marginally lower while Lululemon Athletica Inc. attracted attention for the wrong reason: pants that are too sheer. Top Tickers Trending $AAPL: When Apple AAPL, +0.78%  said on March 19, 2012 that it was initiating a quarterly dividend, the stock rallied 2.7% to $601.10. Exactly six months later, Apple hit its historic high closing price of $702.10. Now, six months on, with investors clamoring for the company to explain what it will do with its $137 billion cash hoard, the stock closed at $454.49, down about 35% from its September peak. EUROPE IN CRISIS • Unemployment sky-high and rising in Spain • Matthew Lynn: Global chaos, gold bullishness • Lynn: How Thatcher would play the crisis • Come on, ECB: Tell us what you really think Overnight, Apple’s biggest rival Samsung Electronics Co. 005930, +0.37%  said that it is working on a watch that has similar functions as a smartphone. That will undoubtedly pressure Apple to not only beat Samsung to market and offer a device that can offer superior features. As expected, the news prompted some speculation that Samsung is once again trying to steal Apple’s thunder if not its idea. But before the narrative gets too twisted, there are a couple of important facts to remember. Samsung has been making watches since 1983 and smartwatches have been around for a while. $MSFT: Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10%  shares recovered from earlier losses to close slightly higher. The Wall Street Journal reported that regulators are investigating Microsoft’s business relationship with partners that allegedly bribed foreign government officials in return contracts. “Lawyers from the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission are examining kickback allegations made by a former Microsoft representative in China, as well as the company’s relationship with certain resellers and consultants in Romania and Italy,” the Journal reported. The probe is the early stage and Microsoft has not been accused of any wrongdoing, the newspaper said. $LULU: Lululemon Athletica LULU, +3.68% shares are paying a steep price after the maker of athletic clothing for women announced a product recall on Monday that affects forecasts for first-quarter same-store sales and revenue. The recall is for its Luon pants and cropped pants, which are made from nylon and Lycra spandex and are considered too transparent. In a statement titled “Black Luon Pants Shortage Expected,” the company said the move will affect about “17% of all women’s bottoms.” $C: Citigroup Inc. C, -1.11%  trended online. The bank’s price target was raised to $53 from $46 on Tuesday by Deutsche Bank. The bank also agreed to pay $730 million on Monday to settle allegations it misled investors during the financial crisis. $BA: Boeing Co. BA, +2.46%  sparked chatter after Ryanair Holdings PLC announced an agreement with Boeing on Tuesday to buy 175 new Next Generation 737-800 airplanes in a deal valued at almost $15.6 billion. Gainers S&P: Brighter Outlook for China Property Market AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  rose 3.6% while Walgreen Co. US:WAG  added 5.4%. Walgreen and Alliance Boots announced on Tuesday an agreement to buy pharmaceutical products from AmerisourceBergen, a drug wholesaler, as they gained the right to buy a minority position in the company. Shares of Skullcandy Inc. US:SKUL  gained 7.5%. The headphone maker said Monday it hired Hoby Darling, a digital executive from Nike Inc. NKE, +1.53%  as chief executive and president. Decliners Affymax Inc. AFFY, +0.65%  shares plunged 64%. The biotechnology company said Monday it will reduce its workforce by 75% and may sell itself. Both actions are linked to an investigation of Affymax’s antianemia drug Omontys, which it recalled after it led to fatal reactions in some first-time users. Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94%  shares slid 8.2%. The stock was downgraded to neutral from buy at Lazard Capital Markets following Walgreen’s deal with AmerisourceBergen. “This morning, WAG announced a new relationship with ABC that, among other things, includes a 10-year distribution agreement between the retailer and that wholesaler. As such, CAH will be losing the WAG business, which represents $20 billion plus revenue. We had roughly estimated WAG represents about 7.5% of CAH EPS,” Tom Gallucci, an analyst at Lazard, said in a note. Lululemon Lululemon store. Chesapeake Energy Corp. CHK, +1.00% shares are off 5.1%. The natural-gas producer said Monday that it is looking into selling $2.3 billion in bonds to finance a debt buyback. Cliffs Natural Resources Inc. CLF, +5.30%  shares shed 6.6%, down for a second day. An analyst at Bank of America cut the price target on Cliffs to $25 from $30, Benzinga reported Monday. The stock of the iron-ore producer is the biggest loser so far in 2013, down 47% year to date. After an initial spike from the resignation of Chief Executive John Riccitiello, Electronics Arts Inc. EA, +1.60%  shares fell 8.3%. In addition to announcing the departure of Riccitiello, the videogame publisher late Monday said its fourth-quarter results are likely to come in on the low end of its forecast. Juniper Networks Inc. JNPR, +1.16%  shares declined 5.3% after Goldman Sachs downgraded the networking gear maker’s stock to sell from neutral. title: Tuesday movers: Apple marks anniversary in red

title: AmerisourceBergen jumps, Cardinal tumbles on Walgreen deal

content: Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% agreed to acquire closely held medical-supplies provider AssuraMed for $2.07 billion as the drug wholesaler looks to diversify its offerings. AssuraMed currently serves more than one million patients nationally with more than 30,000 products. The company bought Invacare Corp.'s (IVC) domestic medical supplies business for $150 million last month. Including that business, Cardinal Heath said AssuraMed had 2012 revenue of $1 billion. After the transaction is complete, Cardinal Health will supply ostomy, diabetes, insulin therapy, urological, wound care and incontinence products to the home-healthcare market. "This is a platform opportunity for Cardinal Health products and services which will be increasingly important as the delivery of care migrates to more cost-effective settings," said Chairman and Chief Executive George Barrett. Cardinal Health expects AssuraMed to add two cents to three cents a share to its fiscal 2013 adjusted earnings, assuming the deal closes by early April. The company also estimates its will boost fiscal 2014 adjusted earnings by at least 18 cents a share. Cardinal has previously disclosed the loss of its contract with pharmacy-benefits manager Express Scripts Holding Co. ESRX, -0.93% to rival AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Two of Cardinal's huge drug-distribution customers, Walgreen Co. WAG and CVS Caremark Corp. CVS, -0.80% have contracts set to end this summer. The company earlier this month reported its fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 16% as improved margins helped to offset weaker revenue at its pharmaceutical division, which was caused partly by generic-drug introductions. Shares closed Wednesday at $45.44 and were inactive premarket. The stock has risen 8% over the past year. title: Cardinal Health to buy AssuraMed for $2.07B

content: Cardinal Health Inc.'s CAH, +0.94% fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 16% as the drug wholesaler reported improved margins that helped to offset weaker revenue at its pharmaceutical division, which was caused partly by generic-drug introductions. For the year, the second-biggest drug distributor in the U.S. by sales raised the lower end of its forecast for per-share earnings from continuing operations and now expects $3.42 to $3.50, compared with its prior estimate for $3.35 to $3.50. A wave of introductions of major generic drugs has been a mixed benefit for the industry, including Cardinal and competitor McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% Generic drugs carry higher margins than branded drugs but can hurt sales as they command lower prices. McKesson has seen generic conversions weigh on sales in recent quarters. Cardinal also previously had disclosed the loss of its contract with pharmacy-benefits manager Express Scripts Holding Co. ESRX, -0.93% to rival AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Two of Cardinal's huge drug-distribution customers, Walgreen Co. WAG and CVS Caremark Corp. CVS, -0.80% have contracts set to end this summer. Combined, the drugstore chains accounted for a major chunk of Cardinal's revenue in the past fiscal year. Such big wholesale contracts also draw lots of attention when they come up for renewal. However, Cardinal Chief Executive George Barrett has played down such big contracts, saying they tend to be high volume but worth less on the bottom line. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, Cardinal Health reported a profit of $303 million, or 88 cents a share, up from $262 million, or 75 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding restructuring- and acquisition-related charges and other items, adjusted earnings from continuing operations rose to 93 cents a share from 81 cents. Revenue decreased 6.8% to $25.2 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently projected earnings of 86 cents a share on revenue of $24.61 billion. Gross margin rose to 4.9% from 4.1%. The company said revenue at its pharmaceutical business, its largest by revenue, declined 8% to $22.7 billion, driven primarily by brand-to-generic conversions and the loss of the Express Scripts business. However, segment profit grew 12% to $441 million on stronger performance from its generics business and the addition of new customers. The medical business, which provides medical and surgical products and services to hospitals, doctors' offices and other health-care providers, is the smaller of Cardinal Health's core businesses. The segment reported revenue increased 3% to $2.5 billion with a boost from last year's acquisition of FutureMed and an additional sales day. Segment earnings rose 11% to $94 million. Shares closed Monday at $43.66 and were inactive premarket. Excluding restructuring- and acquisition-related charges and other items, adjusted earnings from continuing operations rose to 93 cents a share from 81 cents. Revenue decreased 6.8% to $25.2 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently projected earnings of 86 cents a share on revenue of $24.61 billion. Gross margin rose to 4.9% from 4.1%. The company said revenue at its pharmaceutical business, its largest by revenue, declined 8% to $22.7 billion, driven primarily by brand-to-generic conversions and the loss of the Express Scripts business. However, segment profit grew 12% to $441 million on stronger performance from its generics business and the addition of new customers. The medical business, which provides medical and surgical products and services to hospitals, doctors' offices and other health-care providers, is the smaller of Cardinal Health's core businesses. The segment reported revenue increased 3% to $2.5 billion with a boost from last year's acquisition of FutureMed and an additional sales day. Segment earnings rose 11% to $94 million. Shares closed Monday at $43.66 and were inactive premarket. title: Cardinal Health Q2 net up 16%; margins widen

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Another batch of earnings reports did little to shake the health-care sector from joining in on the broader market rally Thursday, though two notable firms stumbled thanks to some jittery investors. Varian Medical Systems Inc. VAR, +0.92%  was off more than 4% to $71.71 in recent action in the wake of the company’s earnings first-quarter report issued late Wednesday. Varian was virtually in line with expectations on most counts, but a concern over a drop-off in its oncology business put a chill on its shares. How DNA Can Be Used to Store Data The maker of various medical devices used to treat cancer said that while revenue for its oncology products was up 8%, orders were off 2% from a year ago, dropping 4% in markets outside North America. “Oncology customers took delivery during the quarter as expected but order placements were slower than anticipated,” Dow Wilson, the company’s chief executive said in a prepared statement. “We believe the order slowness is principally a timing issue and that the market fundamentals remain sound.” Varian said net income for the quarter was $95.3 million, or 86 cents a share, compared with $90.2 million, or 79 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales were $678.4 million against last year’s $625.3 million. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings of 87 cents a share on sales of $676.7 million. In a note to clients, Lazard Capital Markets analyst Sean Lavin said the drop in oncology orders was unexpected, as he predicted a 2.9% gain and the consensus was for a 6.7% increase. “With shares at an all-time high, they may slide some, but the fundamentals of the business remain intact and our estimates and company valuation move very little,” Lavin said. Meanwhile, recording first-quarter earnings that were slightly higher than expected didn’t seem to help drug distribution giant AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  , as shares dipped by nearly 2% to $45.43. Investors got a bit skittish, however, when the company missed revenue projections. AmerisourceBergen said net income for the period was $168.6 million, or 71 cents a share, compared with $162.1 million, or 62 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales were $21.47 billion against last year’s $20.36 million. The company’s adjusted earnings of 69 cents a share were two cents ahead of the FactSet estimate, but revenue was off slightly from the $21.67 million expected. title: Investors get jittery on two health-care companies

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 4% as the drug wholesaler reported broad revenue growth that received a boost from recent acquisitions. The company has been benefiting from introductions of major generic drugs recently amid a patent cliff among branded drug makers. Though generics carry lower prices, they tend to have higher profit margins. AmerisourceBergen also has expanded its international presence through a string of acquisitions, including its purchase last year of World Courier Group Inc. The company also picked up a high-volume deal with pharmacy-benefits manager Express Scripts Holding Co. (ESRX) in July. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $168.6 million, or 71 cents a share, up from $162.1 million, or 62 cents a share, a year earlier. Earnings from continuing operations were 69 cents, up from 51 cents. Revenue increased 5.7% to $21.5 billion, driven by 4.8% growth in its pharmaceutical segment and 9% growth at its specialty unit. Other revenue, which includes contributions from its consulting business and recent acquisitions, more than doubled. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently projected earnings of 67 cents on revenue of $21.69 billion. Gross margin rose to 3.13% from 2.87%. Shares of AmerisourceBergen, which affirmed its guidance for the fiscal year, closed Wednesday at $46.18 and were inactive premarket. The stock is up 7% this year. title: AmerisourceBergen posts 4% higher profit

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — The major portions of President Barack Obama’s health-care overhaul bill won’t take effect until 2014, but in the coming year the medical industry will start to prepare for the onslaught of new policyholders scheduled to hit the system in little more than 12 months. As the bill — formally known as the Affordable Care Act and popularly referred to as Obamacare — starts to kick in, investors should watch a number of stocks that could either sink or soar. MarketWatch Week Ahead: Merry Christmas Cliff The fortunes of insurers, care givers, device makers, drug distributors, pharmaceutical companies and biotechnology firms rest largely on which sector they occupy in the health-care spectrum. If they sink, chances are others in their sector will suffer as well unless mitigating factors help keep their shares humming. The same goes for Obamacare winners; all boats in a particular sector are likely to be lifted if the rash of new policies smiles on them. Analysts agree the biggest winners in Obamacare will be hospitals, followed by insurers and drug distributors/pharmacy benefit managers. Medical-device makers, on the other hand, could suffer as a new tax imposed on them under the law threatens to eat into their bottom line. As more companies in the system become acclimated to the law, they likely will cut down on the use of health consultants and services groups. Provisions of the law that affect drug makers and biotech labs already, for the most part, have been enacted — including taxes on some drugs coupled with higher reimbursements. Going forward, these two sectors should see a largely neutral effect, though there could be a net gain for some companies, analysts say. MARKETS | • The Tell: Market news and analysis • | Canada section • Columns: Stocks | Oil | Gold | Bonds | Dollar  TOOLS AND DATA | • My Portfolio: Know where your funds are? • Real-time currency exchange rates • After-hours stock screener But there are exceptions too. There are some medical-device makers which could cut a swath based on demand for their products. And some hospital companies could see their windfalls limited in states that opt out of Obamacare’s Medicaid expansion program. One caveat: as with most legislative mandates, they can always be pushed back. Les Funtleyder, president of the investment advisory division at Poliwogg, a health-care investment specialist, says he wonders if states will be able to set up health-insurance exchanges by October 2013, or whether they’ll have to be delayed. The exchanges are a critical cog in the new system, as they are expected to be used to add millions of new policyholders to insurers’ rolls. “I think we’re going to have this conversation in the middle of 2014 and early 2015,” Funtleyder said. Here’s a list of five prospective winners, once Obamacare is implemented: 1. HCA Holdings Inc. HCA, -0.15% : The largest hospital operator in the nation, HCA is in prime position to reap the rewards of Obamacare. As more individuals become insured, hospitals stand to wipe billions of dollars in bad debt off their books that they have incurred for years by treating uncovered indigent patients in their emergency rooms. For some hospitals, it amounts to as much as 20% of revenue. “That should drop significantly by covering the uninsured as long as states go along with the Medicaid provisions,” said Jeff Jonas, an analyst with Gabelli & Co. Due to its sheer size, HCA stands to gain more than most but it also is setting itself up to take advantage. The company operates 263 hospitals and surgery centers in 20 states. It also recently announced a secondary offering of shares, as a number of private investors are liquidating their stake in the company which has traversed in and out of the public market. One note of caution, though. HCA has significant holdings in Texas, which has opted not to take part in the law’s Medicaid expansions. Seventy HCA facilities are listed in Texas. But Jonas says most states are likely accept the provisions. “It’s essentially free money for the first few years,” he said. title: Five stocks that may win from Obamacare

content: Obama has been re-elected; “Obamacare” is the law of the land. It doesn't matter if you agree or disagree with Obamacare, you might as well generate big profits from it. Obamacare has been profitable for us. We bought Amerigroup Corp. US:AGP at $22.05, and, as of this writing, the stock is at $91.44 — this is a whopping 315% return. It wasn't long ago when we aggressively bought Tenet Healthcare THC, +1.76% at $20.40. Yesterday THC hit a 52-week high of $27.60. Here are 26 ways to profit from both the long and the short side. Hospital stocks The best way to profit on the long side from Obamacare is to buy hospital stocks as utilization rates will increase and uncollected receivables will go down. Under Obamacare, the pool of paying patients will increase. It is estimated that currently about 30 million Americans are uninsured. The increase in the number of paying patients will be huge. By law, hospitals have to serve all patients who show up at their emergency rooms including indigents as well as those with no insurance. Hospitals also have difficulty collecting from low income Americans who may have no insurance or are underinsured. Some hospitals aren't able to collect as much as 30% of their billings. The earnings of some hospitals may increase by as much as 25%. Our favorite stock in this sector is THC. Other hospital stocks on our list buy are Community Health Systems CYH, -3.65% HCA Holdings HCA, -0.15% LifePoint Hospitals LPNT, -1.67% and Universal Health Services UHS, -2.45% Medicaid HMOs These HMOs focus on Medicaid and other government programs and will be big beneficiaries of Obamacare. We own AGP but it is not suitable for those not in the stock. AGP is being bought by WellPoint US:WLP Other names on our buy list are Centene Corp. CNC, +6.50% Molina Healthcare MOH, +2.64% and WellCare Health Plans WCG, +1.77% Medicare Part D Medicare Part D is a private plan which provides prescription drug coverage for those eligible for Medicare. Government payments received by insurance companies for this program are likely to see reductions. Humana HUM, +0.48% is our top pick to short sell, but we will wait for this stock to meet all of our six screens before acting. Branded pharmaceuticals In the long run, branded pharmaceuticals will be hurt. Obama will be under intense pressure to reduce rising health care costs in Medicaid and Medicare. Branded drugs are a sitting duck simply because Big Pharma sells them for far less abroad than in the United States. Large-cap pharmaceutical stocks are in favor these days. The market participants perceive them as safe. The reasoning goes that people will always be using drugs irrespective of what happens in Europe, China or to the U.S. economy. It doesn't hurt that these stocks also pay high dividends. Buying high dividend stocks is the rage. However Bush tax cuts expire at the end of this year; if there is no compromise in Washington, income-tax rate on dividends will jump and high dividend stocks will give up some of their recent gains. Secret to making money by short selling is to sell short stocks that are popular and whose fundamentals are likely to deteriorate. We are short Market Vectors Pharmaceutical ETF PPH, +0.96% We have recently taken profits on Lilly LLY, +0.47% but we plan to short it again. Two other stocks to short on our list are Merck MRK, -1.13% and Pfizer PFE, +0.54% Generic pharmaceuticals In the short run, Obamacare is positive for generic pharmaceutical companies such as Teva TEVA, +0.29% Mylan MYL, +1.65% and Dr. Reddy’s Labs RDY, -0.30% In the long run, these companies will suffer as there will be intense pressure on the prices they can charge. There is an opportunity here on the long side in the medium term, but it will become a short opportunity in due course. Medical devices Obamacare levies a tax on medical devices. Further pressure on medical device companies such as Medtronic MDT, +2.24% Stryker SYK, +1.87% St. Jude Medical US:STJ and Zimmer Holdings US:ZMH to reduce prices will increase. . We plan to short sell these companies when they meet our six screens. Testing laboratories There will be more medical tests as more patients are insured. In the short run, implementation of Obamacare is positive for testing companies such as Quest Diagnostics DGX, +0.79% and Laboratory Corp. of America LH, +0.14% In the long run, Obamacare is very negative for these companies because they will come under heavy pressure to reduce rates. These are some of the best ways to profit from the short side in the long-term. Drug distributors As more pharmaceuticals are used, the ruling is positive for drug distributors such as McKesson MCK, +0.15% Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% and AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% Obamacare will prove to be a gold mine for astute traders and investors on the long side and the short side. The key to making money will be the timing of entries and exits using a proven method such as ZYX Change Method. If you cannot short, consider the inverse ETF RXD, +0.26% Disclosure: Subscribers to The Arora Report are long THC, AGP and RXD, and short PPH; further we plan to initiate positions in the names in this column as they meet our six screens. title: 26 ways to profit from ‘Obamacare’

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — A slew of earnings reports had largely positive effects on a broad array of health-care stocks Thursday, though a triple-digit market rally didn’t hurt matters much. As the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07%  gained a percentage point to 13,232.62, various health-care indexes moved up anywhere from slightly less than half a point to more than 2%. The day’s trading produced a few strange results as the rally seemed to lift all boats, regardless of earnings performance. Perhaps the most notable example of this was HCA Holdings Inc. HCA, -0.15% the hospital giant that reported growth in earnings and sales but missed analyst forecasts on both counts. Investors, however, were buoyed by the company’s growth and pushed shares a penny past the $30 threshold at the close, a gain of more than 5%. Weidner: NYSE Was Correct in Closing for Two Days The company said third-quarter net income came to $360 million, or 78 cents a share, compared with $61 million, or 11 cents, earned in the same period a year ago. Revenue for the Nashville, Tenn.-based hospital operator was $8.06 billion against last year’s $7.26 billion. On an adjusted basis, HCA’s earnings would have been 77 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had predicted earnings of 79 cents a share on sales of $8.07 billion, on average. Meanwhile, drug-distribution behemoth AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  managed to get the same benefit, rising nearly 4% to $40.90 despite missing on earnings and sales for the fourth quarter ended Sept. 30. The company said net income was $163.5 million, or 67 cents a share, on sales of $19.45 billion, compared with income of $147.3 million, or 55 cents a share, on sales of $20.35 billion for the same period a year ago. With adjusted earnings of 65 cents a share for the period, that fell short of FactSet estimates of 68 cents a share; the company was expected to ring in $20.2 billion in revenue as well. But in its earnings release, AmerisourceBergen said it plans to shed its AndersonBrecon pharmaceutical packaging business in order to focus more on other operations. The Valley Forge, Pa.-based company also pegged its earnings target for fiscal 2013 and said its board declared a dividend increase and approved a new $750 million authorization for stock repurchases. Read more on AmerisourceBergen. Meanwhile, shares of Cigna Corp. CI, -0.34%  ended up with a boost somewhere between that of HCA and AmerisourceBergen, though the insurance giant reported better-than-expected earnings and sales. Cigna credited an increase in policyholders and premiums during its third quarter. Cigna said net income was $466 million, or $1.61 a share, compared with $183 million, or 67 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales for the period were $7.39 billion against last year’s $5.46 billion. Adjusted income was $1.69 a share. The FactSet-compiled consensus estimates called for earnings of $1.36 a share on sales of $7.34 billion. Cigna’s shares traded up 4.5% to $53.27. Read more on Cigna. But one company that didn’t get any break from investors Thursday was Pfizer Inc. PFE, +0.54% part of the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The drugmaker said third-quarter sales fell 16%, and dipped below estimates, as a number of its exclusive patents expired, including its popular cholesterol drug Lipitor. Lipitor revenue, for one, plunged by 71% worldwide from the third quarter of 2011. The company reported double-digit percentage losses in 18 other drugs from last year. Pfizer reported net income of $3.21 billion, or 43 cents a share, compared with the $3.74 billion, or 48 cents a share, for the 2011 quarter. Quarterly sales generated by the New York-based company were $13.98 billion against last year’s $16.61 billion. Adjusted income was 53 cents a share, a penny ahead of FactSet’s consensus estimates, but sales fell short of the $14.7 billion forecast. Shares fell 1.3% to $24.55 at the close. Read more on Pfizer. Another drug maker, Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. US:WPI  , found the earnings environment a little more hospitable, as its shares were up 2% to $87.71. The company said net income was $76.7 million, or 60 cents a share, for the third quarter compared with $68.1 million, or 54 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales were $1.29 billion against last year’s $1.08 billion. Adjusted earnings were $1.35 a share, 7 cents ahead of analyst forecasts. Sales were expected to come in at $1.27 billion. Three other smaller health-care firms saw their shares surge after reporting earnings, led by Gentiva Health Services Inc. US:GTIV  , a provider of home health care and hospice services. Gentiva shares jumped by more than 21% to $11.36 after the company said adjusted third-quarter income was 4 cents ahead of estimates. Gentiva’s revenue was a little light of forecasts at $424.4 million, but the company raised its fiscal 2012 outlook to a range of $1.20 to $1.30 a share. That’s up from its previous forecast of $1 to $1.20 a share. Catamaran Corp. US:CTRX  , a pharmacy benefit manager, jumped by nearly 9% to $51.20 after the company adjusted third-quarter income was a penny ahead of estimates. But Catamaran bumped up its fiscal outlook to a range of $1.09 to $1.13 in adjusted earnings per share, up from $1.07 to $1.09 a share. And Mednax Inc. MD, +0.34%  gained more than 6% to $73.41 after the company beat estimates by 4 cents in adjusted earnings per share. title: Rally, earnings cluster drive health stocks up

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 11% as the drug wholesaler's lower input costs masked weaker pharmaceutical-distribution revenue. AmerisourceBergen boosted its dividend by 62%, to 21 cents a share, with the increase costing the company about $19.7 million a quarter. The company also approved a new $750 million share-buyback program, which will be added to another authorization with $97 million remaining, bringing the total to $847 million. According to FactSet, AmerisourceBergen's market value is about $9.93 billion. The company also said it is pursuing the sale of AndersonBrecon, its contract pharmaceutical-packaging business, so that it can focus on its distribution, specialty and manufacturer services businesses. The company has solicited buyers and is currently reviewing initial bids for the business. Income from AndersonBrecon represented four cents of the total $2.80 in per-share earnings for fiscal-year 2012. AmerisourceBergen is likely to benefit from the continuing introductions of big generic drugs this year, which tend to carry higher margins. It has also expanded its reach outside the U.S. with a string of acquisitions, including its $520 million purchase of World Courier Group, which closed in April. In July, the company picked up a high-volume deal with Express Scripts Holding Co. (ESRX) to distribute about $18.5 billion in medication each year. AmerisourceBergen came under federal scrutiny in August, when prosecutors and federal agents issued two subpoenas to the company related to its procedures for monitoring the distribution of narcotic painkillers and other controlled medications. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $163.5 million, or 66 cents a share, up from $147.3 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. Earnings from continuing operations rose to 65 cents from 53 cents. Revenue fell 4.4% to $19.45 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently projected earnings of 68 cents a share on revenue of $20.21 billion. Gross margin widened to 3.7% from 3%, as input costs fell 5.1%. The pharmaceutical-distribution segment's revenue fell about 6% to $19.1 billion. For 2013, the company said it expects per-share earnings from continuing operations of $3.06 to $3.16. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters recently projected earnings of $3.14 a share. Shares closed Wednesday at $39.44 and were inactive premarket. The stock is up 6.1% so far this year. title: AmerisourceBergen's profit rises 11%; shares gain

content: Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% said Wednesday that the government is seeking information in a process that could lead to civil fines following a recent settlement over allegations the drug wholesaler didn't do enough to stop misuse of prescription painkillers from a Florida distribution hub. The Dublin, Ohio, company reached the settlement with the Drug Enforcement Administration in mid-May over the Lakeland, Fla., center. Cardinal agreed to a two-year suspension of its license to ship controlled substances from that facility and also agreed to improve its procedures. Cardinal didn't pay a fine in May, but the deal "did not foreclose the possibility of the U.S. Department of Justice seeking civil fines for historical conduct covered by the settlement agreement," Cardinal said in a regulatory filing Wednesday. "In that regard, we are responding to civil subpoenas from two local offices within the DEA and the U.S. Department of Justice related to our distribution of controlled substances," the company said. Cardinal also said it is not yet possible to "reasonably estimate a range of possible loss." The government has been closely scrutinizing the nation's pharmacy-supply chain, including drug wholesalers and retail pharmacies, amid a soaring problem with prescription painkiller abuse. In 2008, Cardinal was blocked from shipping out controlled substances at three facilities due to DEA allegations the company wasn't doing enough to spot illegitimate purchases. Cardinal eventually paid a $34 million settlement payment but did not admit any wrongdoing. ISI Group analyst Ross Muken noted that the 2008 fine "related to a much broader suit than they may face today," and he sees "minimal financial impact" if Cardinal winds up paying a fine. The company also noted in Wednesday's filing that the DEA confirmed, as part of May's settlement, that it wasn't planning further administrative actions at any other Cardinal facilities based on conduct prior to the settlement. Cardinal competitor AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% disclosed earlier this month that it received subpoenas from the U.S. Attorney's Office in New Jersey and the DEA seeking documents on the company's internal controls. In 2007 the DEA suspended all controlled-substance shipments for several months at an AmerisourceBergen facility in Orlando, Fla., until the company installed a more-robust order-monitoring program. Cardinal shares recently traded down 0.7% to $39.60. title: Cardinal Health subpoenas could lead to fines

content: Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% said its board approved a new share repurchase program of up to $750 million of the company's shares. The three-year share repurchase authorization replaces a program approved in November 2010 of the same value, of which $200 million remained. The new program expires on Aug. 15, 2015. Cardinal Health's market value is about $13.8 billion. Earlier this month Cardinal Health reported a rise in fourth-quarter earnings as it benefited from improved margins, though its revenue was flat. The company remains the second-biggest drug distributor in the U.S. by sales, though it has recently lost some business as Express Scripts Holding Co. ESRX, -0.93% chose rival AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% to distribute about $18.5 billion in medication annually. title: Cardinal ok's $750 million share repurchase plan

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Amid a broad Wall Street selloff, shares of Cigna Corp. climbed Thursday as second-quarter earnings exceeded forecasts and the health insurer raised its outlook for the rest of the year. Cigna CI, -0.34%  said net income eased to $380 million, or $1.31 a share, down from the $391 million, or $1.43 a share, reported a year ago. Revenue reached $7.46 billion in the latest quarter against the prior year’s $5.51 billion. On an adjusted basis, earnings would have come to $1.49 a share, or 7 cents ahead of the consensus projection among analysts polled by FactSet Research. Quarterly sales also had been projected at $7.22 billion, on average. Fitness Buddy, iFitness Pro review The company said it expects full-year adjusted income in a range of $5.25 to $5.60 a share, up from its previous estimate of $5.20 to $5.55 a share. The FactSet-derived consensus had been for $5.51 a share. Shares of Cigna traded up 4% to $41.86 by session’s end, bucking the broader bearish trend gripping U.S. stocks Thursday. Cigna doesn’t appear to be facing the same headwinds that other insurers reported during the quarter, analysts said. This earnings season has buffeted the shares of many managed-care providers due to higher utilization rates, along with uncertainty over federal spending trends. “Given the multiple earnings reports that have highlighted increasing macro challenges (sharper uptick in outpatient, broadly higher utilization in Medicare Advantage, etc.), we were pleased to see that [Cigna] doesn’t seem to be encountering trends they haven’t expected in their pricing assumptions,” wrote Jefferies & Co. analyst David Windley in a note to clients. TimeCigna Corp.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:CI $200 $150 $175 $225 “This, along with the higher earnings per share, should relieve pressure on the stock ... and perhaps the group,” he said. Also Thursday, shares of drug distributor Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94%  slipped nearly 4% to $40.89, as investors shrugged off a strong earnings report. The company apparently remains in the throes of investor backlash after losing an $18.5 billion contract to handle distribution for Express Scripts Holding Co. ESRX, -0.93% the pharmacy-benefits giant. TimeCardinal Health Inc.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:CAH $60 $70 $80 The pact, awarded Wednesday to rival AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% took another bite out of Cardinal’s shares. Cardinal reported net income of $236 million, or 68 cents a share, up 17% from the $203 million, or 58 cents, earned in the final three months of fiscal 2011. Sales generated by the Dublin, Ohio-based company were $26.76 billion, all but unchanged from a year ago. The company’s adjusted earnings of 73 cents a share came in a penny ahead of the FactSet-compiled consensus. Meanwhile, shares of SurModics Inc. SRDX, -0.39%  soared by 14% to $17.53. The medical products company beat analyst estimates on earnings for the third quarter ended June 30, and revised higher both its revenue and income outlook for fiscal 2012. TimeSurmodics Inc.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:SRDX $25 $30 $35 Late Wednesday, SurModics said net income was $3.06 million, or 17 cents a share, down from the $3.84 million, or 22 cents a share, posted in the year-ago third quarter. Sales were $14 million against last year’s $13 million. Adjusted earnings would have been 18 cents a share, ahead of the 14-cent consensus from analysts polled by FactSet. The company also raised its full-year revenue estimate to a range of $51 million to $52 million, up from $47 million to $51 million previously. The earnings outlook for SurModics also was raised, to a range of 56 cents to 59 cents a share, up from 45 to 53 cents a share.
