content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Thursday’s session are Trinity Industries Inc., Hill-Rom Holdings Inc. and Western Digital Corp. It’s another heavy-duty day for corporate earnings, with United Technologies Corp. UTX, +1.10% 3M Co. MMM, +1.38%   and Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, +2.47%  heading up Thursday’s roster. Also on deck are Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +1.11% Facebook Inc. FB, +4.42% Hershey Co. HSY, +0.72% Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.02% Waste Management Inc. WM, +1.13% Raytheon Co. RTN, +2.26% BorgWarner Inc. BWA, +3.25% Precision Castparts Corp. PCP, +0.00% Tenneco Inc. TEN, +2.91% International Paper Co. IP, +2.00% Kimberly-Clark Corp. KMB, +0.61% Dow Chemical Co. DOW, -0.77% Occidental Petroleum Corp. OXY, +2.87% McGraw-Hill Cos. MHP, +0.00% Moody’s Corp. MCO, +1.48% AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% Amgen Inc. AMGN, +0.01% Celgene Corp. CELG, +0.90% Gilead Sciences Inc. GILD, +0.82% Mylan Inc. MYL, +1.65%  and Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. WPI, +0.00% among others. TimeUnited Technologies Corp.15 Jan29 Jan12 Feb26 Feb12 Mar26 Mar US:UTX $125 $130 $135 On the eve of reporting results, United Technologies reached a deal to sell its Hamilton Sundstrand industrial businesses — Milton Roy Co., Sullair Corp. and Sundyne Corp. — for $3.46 billion. The transaction with Carlyle Group LP CG, +1.67%  and BC Partners is expected to close in the fourth quarter, pending regulatory approval. Proceeds will be used to repay part of the short-term debt that United Technologies took on to finance the pending acquisition of Goodrich Corp. GR, +5.88% the Hartford, Conn.-based company said. “This represents another significant step forward in our ongoing portfolio transformation,” said Louis Chenevert, chairman and chief executive of United Technologies, in a statement. Also late Wednesday, Standard & Poor’s said it will make a pair of changes in the composition of its S&P MidCap 400 and S&P SmallCap 600 indexex, both effective after the close of trading on July 31. SolarWinds Inc. SWI, +0.24%  will take the place in the S&P MidCap 400 of Gen-Probe Inc. GPRO, -1.03% which fellow MidCap 400 component Hologix Inc. HOLX, -0.08%  is about to acquire. And HealthStream Inc. HSTM, +0.53%  will replace GeoResources Inc. GEOI   in the S&P SmallCap 600, as the acquisition of GeoResources by Halcon Resources Corp. HK, +0.62%  nears completion. Along with reporting second-quarter results, Trinity Industries TRN, +1.27%  revised higher its profit outlook for 2012. The Dallas-based company now sees full-year earnings in a range of $2.95 to $3.10 a share, up from management’s prior forecast of between $2.55 and $2.70 a share. For the second half, Trinity said it’s aiming for a profit of $1.45 to $1.60 a share, a range that would include about 8 cents to 10 cents a share of costs expected to be incurred as the company makes changes in part of its production capacity. Along with reporting results for the third quarter ended June 30, Visa Inc. V, +2.25% said its board authorized a new $1 billion buyback program covering Class A common shares, running through July 2013. In the latest quarter, the Foster City, Calif.-based company bought back about 4 million Class A shares at an average price of $115.51 each, for a total cost of $461 million, Visa’s results showed. Read more on Visa’s quarterly results. Continuing a recent pattern of increases, the board of Oneok Inc. OKE, +2.32%  declared a quarterly dividend of 33 cents a share, an 8% increase over the energy company’s previous payout. It’s payable Aug. 15 to stockholders of record as of Aug. 6, the Tulsa-based company said. The dividend’s adjusted to reflect Oneok’s recent two-for-one stock split. TimeHill-Rom Holdings Inc.15 Jan29 Jan12 Feb26 Feb12 Mar26 Mar US:HRC $80.0 $82.5 $85.0 $87.5 $90.0 Along with reporting results for the third quarter ended June 30, Hill-Rom Holdings HRC, +1.28%  lowered its outlook for fiscal 2012. “We have experienced further deterioration in our North American capital business and have updated our outlook accordingly,” said John Greisch, Hill-Rom’s President and CEO, in a statement. As revised, the Batesville, Ind.-based company expects to generate earnings of 53 cents to 55 cents a share on an adjusted basis for the fourth quarter, with revenue pegged at $413 million to $421 million. This would yield an adjusted profit of $2.21 to $2.23 a share for fiscal 2012, on revenue ranging around $1.62 billion. Hill-Rom’s management previously had been looking for earnings of $2.45 to $2.50 a share for fiscal 2012. Separately, Hill-Rom said it agreed to buy Michigan-based Aspen Surgical Products, a privately held supplier of surgical consumable and specialty medical products, in a deal valued at $400 million. TimeCrocs Inc.15 Jan29 Jan12 Feb26 Feb12 Mar26 Mar US:CROX $12 $13 $14 $15 $16 Along with reporting a consensus-beating profit for the second quarter, Crocs Inc. CROX, +1.18%  projected third-quarter earnings would be between 42 cents and 44 cents a share on revenue of $300 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research, on average, have been looking for the Niwot, Colo.-based footwear maker to post earnings of 42 cents on revenue of $321 million. And for the year, Crocs is shooting for earnings in a range of $1.50 to $1.54 a share. Recapping the company’s performance for the second quarter, President and CEO John McCarvel said: “Conditions in Europe, including currency headwinds, and slower-than-expected retail sales in the Americas resulted in slightly lower growth than expected.” However, management is “very encouraged by continued strong growth of Asia, sell-through of our products in key wholesale accounts, our international retail performance, all driven by customer enthusiasm for our new products,” McCarvel said in the Crocs earnings release. Providence Service Corp. PRSC, +1.30%  lowered its financial forecast for the second quarter, pegging earnings in a range of 10 cents to 11 cents a share on revenue of about $279 million. Previously, the Tucson, Ariz.-based company had been aiming for a quarterly profit of 17 cents a share on revenue of about $275 million. Providence Service cited, among other factors, higher-than-forecast expenses for claims under its self-funded employee health plan as well as costs incurred as the company weighed strategic alternatives. Providence Service will formally report financial results for the June quarter after the close of trading on Aug. 8. Continuing a recent pattern of secondary offerings, Newcastle Investment Corp. NCT, -3.57%  will put up for sale another 20 million common shares. The New York-based company plans to use net proceeds for investments in excess mortgage-servicing rights, non-agency residential mortgage-backed securities, senior living facilities and other real estate-related assets. Underwriters will have a 30-day option to buy up to 3 million additional shares if investor demand warrants. In the three months ended March 31, Newcastle had nearly 105.7 million weighted average common shares outstanding on a fully diluted basis. Texas Capital Bancshares Inc. TCBI, +1.64%  commenced a public offering of nearly 1.8 million common shares, filing a registration statement and prospectus with the Securities and Exchange Commission, with underwriters having a 30-day option to buy up to an additional 15% of common stock if needed to satisfy investor demand. The Dallas-based company said it plans to put net proceeds to use in funding Texas Capital Bank’s growth. Word of the secondary offering came as Texas Capital Bancshares reported higher net income for the second quarter late Wednesday. Wednesday earnings recap TimeWestern Digital Corp.15 Jan29 Jan12 Feb26 Feb12 Mar26 Mar US:WDC $80 $90 $100 Western Digital WDC, +1.62%  posted a net profit of $745 million, or $2.87 a share, for the fourth quarter ended June 29, up sharply from $158 million, or 67 cents, earned in the final three months of fiscal 2011. The Irvine, Calif.-based company likewise showed a big jump in quarterly revenue — to $4.75 billion from the prior year’s $2.4 billion. On an adjusted basis, Western Digital would have earned $3.35 a share for the latest quarter. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast, on average, a profit of $2.47 a share and revenue of $4.25 billion. The company shipped 71 million hard-disk drives during the latest quarter, with CEO John Coyne saying that “demand was in line with our forecast.” Akamai Technologies Inc. AKAM, +1.33%  reported a second-quarter profit of $44 million, or 24 cents a share, off from $48 million, or 25 cents, earned in the comparable period during 2011. Quarterly revenue improved to $331.3 million from the prior year’s $319.4 million. On an adjusted basis, the Cambridge, Mass.-based company said it would have earned 43 cents a share for the latest quarter. The FactSet-derived consensus forecast had been for earnings of 37 cents a share on $326.2 million in revenue. content: The Supreme Court has just upheld most of President Obama’s health care overhaul. There is excellent coverage of the ruling by Russ Britt and Robert Schroeder in their piece Supreme Court upholds health-care overhaul. Here is how I think investors can profit from the ruling. Hospital Stocks The best way to profit on the long side is to buy hospital stocks. By law, hospitals have to serve all patients who show up at their emergency rooms, including indigent patients, as well as those with no insurance. Hospitals also have difficulty collecting from low-income Americans who may have no insurance or are under-insured. Some hospitals are not able to collect as much as 30% of their billings. As a result of the new law, the pool of paying patients will increase. It is estimated that currently about 30 million Americans are uninsured. The increase in the number of paying patients will be huge. The earnings of some hospitals may increase by as much as 25%. Hospital stocks to consider are Tenet Healthcare THC, +1.76% Community Health Systems CYH, -3.65% HCA Holdings HCA, -0.15% LifePoint Hospitals LPNT, -1.67% and Universal Health Services UHS, -2.45% Under the ZYX Change Method a buy signal is issued when all six screens are met. All of the hospital stocks mentioned here are currently meeting five to six screens. Commercial HMOs The changes are a mixed blessing for commercial HMOs. On the one hand, they will get more patients. On the other hand, there will be more competition as insurance exchanges under the law are implemented. The exchanges will make it easier for consumers to shop and compare insurance. The law will also allow individuals to easily become parts of groups and get lower rates. From a valuation perspective, stocks such as WellPoint WLP Aetna AET, -0.25% Cigna CI, -0.34% Humana HUM, +0.48% and UnitedHealth Group UNH, -2.06% are inexpensive deserve serious consideration on any dip from here. All of the HMO stocks mentioned here are currently meeting four to five screens of the ZYX Change Method. Medicaid HMOs These HMOs focus on Medicaid and other government programs. The Supreme Court has ruled that states can opt out of Medicaid expansion. According to the Supreme Court, if a state accepts the expansion funds, it has to obey the new rules. However, a state can refuse to participate in the expansion and still not lose all of its Medicaid funds. At this time, there is no way to know how various states will respond. If most states accept expansion funds, the biggest opportunity will be in Medicaid HMOs. The names include Amerigroup AGP Centene CNC, +6.50% Molina Healthcare MOH, +2.64% and WellCare Health Plans WCG, +1.77% Temporarily, we are suspending our ratings on these stocks. We simply need more time to analyze the Supreme Court ruling. However we have advised subscribers to hold AGP. AGP is a long-term position in ZYX Buy Change Alert being held long from an average price of $22.05. Currently, 55% of the full core position size is held. Partial profits have been taken as high as $74.60. Branded Pharmaceuticals In our analysis the Supreme Court ruling is neutral for pharmaceutical stocks such as Merck MRK, -1.13% Pfizer PFE, +0.54% and Eli Lilly LLY, +0.47% in the short-term, but negative in the long-term. Long-term investors may consider establishing short positions in pharmaceutical stocks on any big up moves. These are one of the best ways to profit from the short side in the long-term. Generic Pharmaceuticals In the short run, the ruling is positive for generic pharmaceutical companies such as Teva Pharmaceuticals TEVA, +0.29% Mylan MYL, +1.65% and Dr. Reddy’s Laboratory RDY, -0.30% In the long run, these companies will suffer as there will be intense pressure on the prices they can charge. Medical Devices The new law levies a tax on medical devices. In the short run, the ruling is negative for medical device companies such as Medtronic MDT, +2.24% Stryker SYK, +1.87% St. Jude Medical STJ, -0.32% and Zimmer Holdings ZMH Opportunities abound in specialty device companies that are on the cutting edge. Examples are Intuitive Surgical ISRG, +2.59% and MAKO Surgical MAKO Testing Laboratories There will be more medical tests as more patients are insured. In the short run, implementation of the law is positive for testing companies such as Quest Diagnostics DGX, +0.79% and Laboratory Corp. of America LH, +0.14% In the long run, the law is very negative for these companies because they will come under heavy pressure to reduce rates. These are one of the best ways to profit from the short side in the long-term. Drug Distributors As more pharmaceuticals are used, the ruling is positive for drug distributors such as McKesson MCK, +0.15% Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% and AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% In summary, the health care overhaul will prove to be a gold mine for astute traders and investors in the coming year both on the long side and the short side. The key to making money will be the timing of entries and exits using a proven method such as ZYX Change Method. Disclosure: Subscribers to ZYX Buy Change Alert have long positions in THC, AGP, and MAKO. Subscribers to ZYX Global Multi Asset Allocation Alert have a long position in RXD. title: How to profit from the health-care ruling

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Thursday that its board authorized a new $750 million share repurchase program, effective immediately. The plan follows a completed , previous $750 million share repurchase program, which was authorized on August 11, 2011.
title: AmerisourceBergen sets $750 million share buyback

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal second-quarter earnings fell 1.1% as severance and acquisition costs masked the drug wholesaler's revenue growth. AmerisourceBergen had reported improved profits in recent quarters on the strong performance of its generic drugs and specialty pharmaceuticals. The company will likely benefit from continuing introductions of big generic drugs this year, which tend to carry higher margins, and a streak of acquisitions that have expanded its reach outside the U.S. AmerisourceBergen also agreed last month to pay $520 million in cash for World Courier Group Inc., whose focus is helping pharmaceutical companies test complex treatments. For the quarter ended March 31, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $212.1 million, down from $214.4 million a year earlier. On a per-share basis, earnings rose to 81 cents from 77 cents, due to a reduction in shares outstanding. The most-recent quarter included $6.1 million of employee severance costs and $2.9 million of acquisition costs. Revenue increased 1.6% to $20.1 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had most recently forecast earnings of 81 cents on revenue of $20.05 billion. Gross margin slipped to 3.46% from 3.48%. Revenue at its drug business was relatively flat, while specialty group revenue grew about 6%. The company also backed its full-year guidance. Shares closed Wednesday at $37.85 and were inactive premarket. The stock is up 1.8% so far this year. title: AmerisourceBergen profit falls 1.1% on severance

KLAC, +2.29%  and Ingram Micro Inc. IM, +0.23% among many other companies. TimeWaterfront Philippines Inc.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 PH:WPI PhP0.50 PhP0.75 PhP1.00 PhP1.25 PhP1.50 Bidding to raise bolster its competitive standing in the top ranks of producers of generic drugs, Watson Pharmaceuticals WPI, +0.00%  said it agreed to acquire Actavis Group, a privately held company that had 2011 revenue of about $2.5 billion. Terms call for Watson to make an upfront payment of 4.25 billion euros, with additional consideration contingent on Actavis achieving certain 2012 performance targets. The contingent payment, if fully earned, would result in the delivery of up to 5.5 million common shares of Parsippany, N.J.-based Watson during 2013. Watson also said it expects that the combined company’s “substantial” free cash flow will enable debt to be paid down quickly. Pending completion the Actavis acquisition, Watson said it would have projected pro-forma revenue of about $8 billion for 2012. Teradyne TER, +1.96%  forecast sizable sequential improvement in profit and revenue as the No. Reading Mass.-based company reported first-quarter financial results. For the second quarter, the company sees net income from continuing operations in a range of 31 cents to 37 cents a share along with an adjusted profit of 53 cents to 62 cents a share, also from continuing operations. And Teradyne projected quarterly revenue in a range of $490 million to $530 million. Also late Wednesday, H&R Block Inc. HRB, +1.03%  announced plans to cut about 350 full-time jobs and close down some 200 of its company-owned offices. The Kansas City-based company will take a charge of 6 cents a share against results for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2012 in conjunction with the moves, which it said should yield savings of up to $100 million by the end of fiscal 2013. H&R Block also forecast below-consensus earnings from continuing operations and revenue for fiscal 2012, which ended April 18. Along with reporting lower profit and revenue for the fourth quarter ended March 31, Xilinx Inc. XLNX, +1.25%  issued an upbeat revenue forecast for the first quarter of fiscal 2013. The San Jose, Calif.-based chipmaker said it expects revenue to increase 1% to 5% on a sequential basis, implying a range of roughly $564.6 million to $587 million. Analysts polled by FactSet Research have, on average, been looking for Xilinx to generate revenue of $555.5 million. Along with reporting results for the first quarter, TriQuint Semiconductor Inc. TQNT  issued a warning in which revenue’s pegged to come in softer than normal for the Hillsboro, Ore.-based company for the second quarter. TriQuint expects to incur a loss of 10 cents to 15 cents a share for the June quarter, on revenue in a range of $170 million to $185 million. The loss would reflect “weak” revenue and an increase in litigation costs, the company said. “We anticipate a challenging second quarter in the mobile devices market,” said Ralph Quinsey, president and chief executive, in a statement. TriQuint also said it anticipates returning to “normal revenue levels” in the second half of the year. Along with reporting results for the third quarter ended April 1, Emulex Corp. ELX, -4.29%  forecast a net profit of 9 cents to 11 cents for the fourth quarter as well as earnings on an adjusted basis in a range of 21 cents to 23 cents a share. The Costa Mesa, Calif.-based company also projected revenue of $126 million to $130 million for the final three months of fiscal 2012. “We look forward to a strong finish to the fiscal year and are optimistic that we will be able to show double digit year-over-year revenue growth for the second consecutive year, and have the opportunity to surpass the half-billion-dollar annual revenue mark for the first time,” said CEO Jim McCluney, in a statement. Results for the second quarter ended March 31 left management at Parametric Technology Corp. PMTC  “disappointed,” said James Heppelmann, president and CEO. The Needham, Mass.-based company also issued a third-quarter forecast calling for net profit of 15 cents to 20 cents a share, earnings on an adjusted basis of 28 cents to 32 cents a share and revenue of $300 million to $315 million. The company also pegged full-year targets of 76 cents to 84 cents a share for net profit, $1.42 to $1.50 a share for adjusted earnings and a range of about $1.26 billion to $1.28 billion for net revenue. Late Wednesday, the board of Dow Jones Industrial Average component Chevron Corp. CVX, +1.73%  declared a quarterly dividend of 90 cents a share, an 11% increase. The dividend’s payable June 11 to stockholders of record as of May 18, the San Ramon, Calif.-based company said. The board of Oceaneering International Inc. OII, +3.46%  approved a 20% increase in the quarterly dividend on common stock, to 18 cents a share. The new dividend’s payable June 20 to holders of record as of June 1, Houston-based Oceaneering International said. The company also reported first-quarter results late Wednesday. Wednesday earnings recap TimeCrocs Inc.May 17Jul 17Sep 17Nov 17Jan 18Mar 18 US:CROX $7.5 $10.0 $12.5 $15.0 Crocs CROX, +1.18%  reported a first-quarter profit of $28.3 million, or 31 cents a share, up from $21.5 million, or 24 cents, earned in the same period during 2011. Quarterly sales generated by the Niwot, Colo.-based maker and marketer of plastic shoes reached $271.8 million, up nearly 20%, as gross margin widened to 53.3% from 52.6%. Analysts polled by FactSet had been looking for earnings of 26 cents on revenue of $266.7 million, on average. However, Crocs issued a second-quarter outlook shy of consensus estimates. Akamai Technologies Inc. AKAM, +1.33%   reported a first-quarter profit of $43 million, or 24 cents a share, down from $50.6 million, or 26 cents, earned during the year-ago period, as revenue rose to $319.4 million from $276 million. On an adjusted basis, Akamai would have earned $75 million, or 41 cents a share, for the latest quarter. The consensus of analysts surveyed by FactSet had been for Akamai to earn 38 cents a share on $311 million in revenue. Separately, the Cambridge, Mass.-based provider of Web content distribution technology and services said Paul Sagan would step down as CEO by the end of 2013. LSI Corp. LSI, -0.35%  reported a first-quarter profit of $75.2 million, or 13 cents a share, up from $10.2 million, or 2 cents, earned in the first three months of 2011. Quarterly revenue generated by the Milpitas, Calif.-based company jumped, reaching $622.4 million. Excluding stock-based compensation costs and other adjustments, per-share earnings would have doubled to 20 cents a share, LSI’s results showed. The results exceeded a forecast that LSI management issued in March. LSI also projected second-quarter revenue above analysts’ consensus. content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) — Corporate earnings will command the attention of investors in the coming week with about one-third of the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average reporting quarterly results. “We’re looking at the big industrials for indicators of global growth,” said Mark Luschini, chief investment strategist at Janney Montgomery Scott. Economic data in the past week have indicated a cooling off in the manufacturing sector as the Federal Reserve said March industrial production levels were unchanged from February, and manufacturing gauges in the New York and Philadelphia regions declined. Also, slowing growth in China and a possible recession in Europe threaten to throw cold water on U.S. exports. MarketWatch Week Ahead: Apple and the Fed Among the big earnings reports beginning Tuesday are Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78%  along with Dow components AT&T Inc. T, +0.25%  , United Technologies Corp. UTX, +1.10%  , and 3M Co. MMM, +1.38% Other Dow DJIA, +1.07%  components reporting include Boeing Co. BA, +2.46%  and Caterpillar Inc. CAT, +1.53%  on Wednesday, Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, +2.47%  on Thursday, with Chevron Corp. CVX, +1.73% Procter & Gamble Co. PG, +0.56% and Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% wrapping up the week on Friday. Other high-profile earnings include Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35%  on Monday, and Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +1.11%  on Thursday. Of the 106 companies on the S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38%  that have reported earnings this season, 83% have reported earnings above consensus Wall Street estimates, according to John Butters, senior earnings analyst at FactSet Research. If that rate holds, it will be the highest upside surprise rate during earnings season in three years, Butters said. One nonearnings factor that may color the week is the first round of the French presidential election on Sunday, where front-runners Nicolas Sarkozy and challenger François Hollande are expected to go to a runoff election. “There may be a little spillover from France but it will be more of the same from earnings,” said Luschini. “The numbers have been exceeding by a sizable amount, so either management was good at keeping expectations low or analysts were too cautious.” Luschini said Tuesday and Wednesday will be busy days for economic data and Fed watching. On Tuesday, Case-Shiller home-price data come out, along with April consumer confidence data and March new-home sales. Then, on Wednesday comes durable-goods orders for March, and the Federal Open Market Committee announcement followed by a news conference from Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke. “Anybody and everybody will be trying to interpret where the Fed’s psyche is at the moment,” Luschini said. Financial stocks, which are the best performing sector with regards to earnings expectations this season, will continue to be a focus. Over the past week, the blended earnings growth rate in the S&P 500 improved to 2.2% from 1% in the previous week. That was fueled by a 12.8% blended earnings growth rate from financial firms, according to Butters. Now that the big banks have reported earnings, focus will turn to their regional counterparts, said Kevin Fitzsimmons, managing director of equity research at Sandler O’Neill. On Monday, Zions Bancorp ZION, +1.07%  and SunTrust Banks Inc. STI, +2.22%  report quarterly results. On Tuesday, Regions Financial Corp. RF, +1.64%  reports. That follows a week where Bank of America Corp. BAC, +2.04%  and Citigroup Inc. C, -1.11%  met or exceeded earnings. The previous week, J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. JPM, +1.82%  and Wells Fargo & Co. WFC, +1.81% surpassed Wall Street expectations. The sector has benefited from a reduction in credit costs and nonperforming assets as well as modest loan growth, and that comes when first-quarter seasonal costs such as payroll expenses are higher and improving margins remain an uphill battle, Fitzsimmons said. Still, even if strong earnings extend to this week’s regional banks, Fitzsimmons doesn’t expect a huge rally in the sector. “The group has had such a run over the last six months, we’re not seeing any dramatic stock moves,” Fitzsimmons said. Year-to-date, the Financial Select Sector SPDR ETF XLF, +1.36% which tracks the financial stocks in the S&P 500 Index, is up 17%; and the KBW Bank Index BKX, +1.30% which tracks the 24 leading U.S. banks, is up 21%. On Monday, S&P 500 companies Ameriprise Financial Inc. AMP, +0.67% ConocoPhillips COP, +0.95% Eaton Corp. ETN, +1.09% Hasbro Inc. HAS, +0.57% Texas Instruments Inc. TXN, +1.94% and Xerox Corp. XRX, -0.24%  will report quarterly earnings. Then, on Tuesday, comes reports from Ace Ltd. ACE, +3.23% Aflac Inc. AFL, +0.48% Air Products & Chemicals Inc. APD, +1.24% Amgen Inc. AMGN, +0.01% Baker Hughes Inc. BHI, +4.27% C.R. Bard Inc. BCR C.H. Robinson Worldwide Inc. CHRW, +2.20% Coach Inc. COH, +6.26% DeVry Inc. DV, +2.94% Edwards Lifesciences Corp. content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% agreed to pay $520 million in cash to acquire World Courier Group Inc., a provider of transportation and logistics services to the biopharmaceutical industry. Drug wholesaler AmerisourceBergen made a number of acquisitions last year that bolstered the services it can offer its customers. Most recently, it acquired CVS Caremark Corp.'s (CVS) TheraCom LLC unit, which provides support services to the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. World Courier, with projected 2012 revenue of about $500 million, is based in Stamford, Conn., and has over 137 offices, 13 storage depots and 2,500 employees in 52 countries. President and Chief Executive Steven H. Collis said the addition of World Courier's services "provides an established platform for the introduction of our specialty services outside North America." AmerisourceBergen expects to close the deal during the fiscal third quarter ending June 30, and it said the acquisition will be neutral to fiscal 2012 earnings and should add between 6 cents and 10 cents in fiscal 2013. The company reports in January its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 1% as growth in pharmaceuticals and specialty businesses contributed to a 2.4% revenue increase. Shares closed Monday at $36.55 and were inactive premarket. The stock is down 1.7% so far this year. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh
title: Amerisource buys World Courier for $520 mln

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Tuesday it'll pay $520 million in cash to buy World Courier Group, a privately held transportation and logistic firm in the biopharmaceutical sector. AmerisourceBergen said the deal will be neutral to its 2012 earnings and add 6 cents to 10 cents a share to its 2013 profit.
title: AmerisourceBergen buys biopharma firm for $520 mln

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Shares of AmerisourceBergen Corp. tumbled by nearly 4% Monday after the drug distribution giant’s chief financial officer resigned, prompting at least one analyst to downgrade the company’s shares. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29%  dropped $1.39 to $37.21 at the close after Michael D. DiCandilo left unexpectedly to “pursue other interests,” according to a company press release. Markets Rise on Greek Debt News DiCandilo left after 21 years with the company and the last 10 as its CFO. Tim G. Guttman will now serve as acting CFO; he has been vice president and corporate controller since 2002. Read more about the CFO’s departure. The news prompted Robert W. Baird & Co. analyst Eric W. Coldwell to downgrade AmerisourceBergen shares to neutral from outperform. “We weren’t expecting this transition, and it comes on the heels of [AmerisourceBergen’s] first quarterly [earnings-per-share] miss in over four years,” Coldwell wrote in a note to clients. Coldwell put adjusted earnings for the company’s first fiscal quarter, which ended in December, at 62 cents a share, a penny below estimates. Coldwell also noted the CFO change comes after Chief Executive R. David Yost retired in July and was replaced by Steven H. Collis. “CFO leadership transition follows change at CEO position last July, and other headwinds; we’re moving to sidelines,” Coldwell wrote. The company also reaffirmed its own fiscal 2012 forecast of earnings between $2.74 and $2.84 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expect earnings of $2.81 a share. The share drop kept AmerisourceBergen from taking part in a broader market rally, which extended to most parts of the health sector. The Chesterbrook, Pa.-based company’s two main rivals, McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94%  each posted gains — McKesson up slightly to $81.80 and Cardinal climbing 1.2% to $42.40. More from MarketWatch Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Related Topics Health Care Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: AmerisourceBergen shares fall on rating dip

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Chief Financial Officer Michael D. DiCandilo has left the drug wholesaler to pursue other interests. DiCandilo, a more than 21-year veteran of Amerisource Bergen, had been financial chief for the past 10 years. Corporate Controller Tim G. Guttman will serve as interim CFO until a successor is chosen. President and Chief Executive Officer Steven H. Collis, who was named CEO last March, said "Mike departs the Company with an impeccable record of service." A company representative declined to comment beyond the details in the press release. Guttman was previously a finance executive at Syncor International, and held financial planning and financial services managerial positions at Walt Disney Co.'s (DIS) consumer products business, Pizza Hut Inc. and PepsiCo Inc. (PEP). The company, which affirmed its 2012 guidance, in January reported that its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 1% amid sales growth in pharmaceuticals and specialty businesses. Shares closed Friday at $38.60 and were inactive in recent premarket trading.
