title: AmerisourceBergen financial chief departs

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Shares of Edwards Lifesciences Corp. jumped nearly 6% Tuesday, sitting atop the S&P 500 index, as the coronary device maker reported positive test results from a new product. The Irvine, Calif.-based company’s shares traded up $4.40 to $82.67 at the close, after touching a session high at $83.96. Edwards EW, +2.01%  said that results from a trial of its Sapien transcatheter heart valve reduced the mortality rates in patients with the severe heart condition known as aortic stenosis. Lipitor Exclusivity Loss Knocks Pfizer's Earnings Stenosis is the blockage of the aortic valve that usually results in operative mortality on an average of 30 days. Using the Sapien device in a trial of 822 patients, Edwards said the mortality rate after 30 days was 8.2% and was 23.6% after one year. This is the second trial of the Sapien device; the first, with 104 patients, yielded mortality rates of 8.7% and 29.1%, respectively. Also Tuesday, shares of McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  climbed nearly 4%. Late Monday, the drug distribution giant reported adjusted income for the third quarter ended Dec. 31 that beat analyst expectations and announced it would repurchase another $650 million in stock. McKesson said net income for the quarter was $300 million, or $1.20 a share, on sales of $30.84 billion. In the same period during fiscal 2011, the company earned $155 million, or 60 cents a share, on sales of nearly $28.25 billion. The company also said adjusted income would have been $1.40 a share, or 2 cents ahead of the consensus estimate in a poll of analysts by FactSet Research. The share buyback is part of a $1.5 billion repurchase effort. McKesson helped lift shares of other major drug distributors, including Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% up 1%, and AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% marginally higher. There also were several gainers among insurers, led by UnitedHealth Group Inc. UNH, -2.06% which tacked on 1.4% to $51.79. In all, the stocks helped the health-care sector stay in positive territory — the only sector in the S&P 500 that managed to remain in the black in Tuesday’s trading. More from MarketWatch Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics Health Care Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: Edwards Lifesciences jumps on test results

content: Reuters SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) — Stock investors no longer have doubts about dividends, and that’s reason for some doubt. Shares of high-quality, cash-rich, large-cap companies that yield more than the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index SPX, +1.38% are the new favorites in many portfolios. But many of these success stories have been discovered, boosting share prices and trimming yields. INVESTING COMMENTARY IN TRADING DECK Back to 1987 for stocks? Our Trading Deck has been home to a spirited debate over whether we're in for a crash. • L.A. Little: Don't worry | Michael Gayed: Worry • The warning signs of a 1987-style crash • Hulbert: Stocks as overvalued as at 2007 high At this point, investors might do better scouring the S&P 500 for companies that wouldn’t show up on a screen for above-average yielders, but which still enjoy dominant, “wide moat” positions in their business. “It’s kind of a crowded trade,” said Paul Nolte, managing director at investment firm Dearborn Partners, about the popularity of the high-quality dividend strategy. “Valuations on high-dividend payers are at the upper-end of their historical ranges.” Indeed, money has cascaded into dividend-focused mutual funds and exchange-traded funds. Dow Jones Select Dividend Index Fund DVY, +1.04% for example, saw assets grow to around $10 billion from $6 billion a year earlier, according to the ETF Industry Association. Similarly robust asset growth was seen at Vanguard Dividend Appreciation VIG, +1.26%  and SPDR S&P Dividend SDY, +0.94% It’s easy to see why dividends are in demand. They’re an alternative to bonds’ paltry payouts, and cushion volatility. Plus, these stocks offer potential for capital appreciation. Without dividends, the S&P 500 was flat in 2011; including dividends the market returned 2.1%. The yield-rich Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07%  fared even better, up 5.5%. And the 10 highest-yielding Dow components, the so-called Dogs of the Dow, returned 12.2%. “Any time we see a big surge in the popularity of dividends in the market, that means prices have been marked up and it’s tough to find bargains,” said Josh Peters, editor of Morningstar’s DividendInvestor newsletter. Off the beaten path Owning financially healthy companies that reward shareholders with meaningful income is certainly still a viable investment idea. Large-cap stocks with little or no debt, that pay consistent dividends, and which grow those payouts over time, have been excellent decisions. And 3% or 4% in cash payments every year is nothing to ignore. Read more: How to elude the Fed's attack on savers. Last year, for example, the average S&P 500 dividend payer gained 1.4%, compared to the average 7.6% decline for non-payers, according to S&P. Performance was even better for S&P’s “Dividend Aristocrats” — companies with that have boosted payouts for at least 25 consecutive years, such as AT&T Inc. T, +0.25% Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% McDonald’s Corp. MCD, -1.28% and Procter & Gamble Co. PG, +0.56% Research S&P's Dividend Aristocrats. Many investors now are hoping such dividend magic will apply to Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% which earlier this week reported blowout earnings. Apple’s chief financial officer said the company is considering ways to be proactive with a cash hoard approaching $100 billion. Read more: Apple's growth rate will not last. Apple isn’t paying a dividend, but if it did, the dividend world would spin. “If Apple came out with a policy that was going to give the stock a yield of 4%, you bet I would look at it,” said Morningstar’s Peters. Read more: Is Apple the cheapest growth stock? But investing in a company that might pay a dividend isn’t a solid approach; nor is buying the highest yield. Companies in financial trouble often sport unusually fat yields after the shares have taken a beating, and their ability to maintain the dividend is questionable. Near 0% Yields Ahead on Deposit Accounts? Better to focus on dividend-paying companies in robust financial health, and then consider how that quarterly payment could grow. The dividend might not be terrific now, but a well-run operation with a high return on investment is often the kind of company given to dividend hikes. And dividend investing is a long-term strategy; the goal is to “clip coupons” year after year. “Think in terms of what the yield could be, rather than what it is,” said Don Taylor, manager of Franklin Rising Dividends Fund FRDPX, +1.52% Ideally, these businesses boast a “wide moat,” meaning they stand apart from competitors because they invest shareholder capital wisely, minimize borrowing, grow revenue streams through smart expansion, and retain cash-generating assets such as patents or other intellectual property. It’s also crucial that dividend investors choose companies with plenty of cash to cover the dividend — derived from an earnings-based measure called the payout ratio. Nowadays, with companies banking cash as a buffer against economic uncertainty, the average payout ratio of S&P 500 members is under 30% of earnings, compared to a historical 52%, according to S&P. One upside to this stinginess is that companies have room to loosen their purse strings. Howard Silverblatt, the senior index analyst at S&P, estimates that 70% of the S&P 500 payers will boost their dividends this year. 10 for the money In searching for attractively priced, profitable companies that wouldn’t necessarily appear on a high-yield screen, MarketWatch enlisted the help of two researchers: Morningstar’s Peters and David Trainer, president of investment researcher New Constructs Inc. in Nashville. Morningstar’s analysis included wide moat companies with dividend yields below 2.1%, a cash surplus and no debt. New Constructs’ methodology, meanwhile, dug into financial statements to unearth companies with high excess return on invested capital, increasing economic earnings, low debt-to-total-capital, and high free-cash-flow yield (total cash flow divided by enterprise value). Strong stewardship of capital also suggests that management is acting in shareholders’ best interests. “You’ve got to have decent return on invested capital to afford a dividend,” Trainer said. “If you’re not making money, you can’t sustain a dividend very long.” Here are 10 wide-moat companies, culled from the two screens, that are debt-free and have a history of dividend increases: 1. Texas Instruments Inc. TXN, +1.94%  shows up on Trainer’s screen. The computer and mobile telephone chip-maker sports a a 2.1% yield — slightly more generous than the S&P 500. Its shares trade at a discount to Morningstar’s fair value estimate of $38. 2. Stryker Corp. SYK, +1.87%  makes both Morningstar’s and Trainer’s list. The orthopedic and medical equipment company recently yielded about 1.5%, with a low payout ratio of about 23%. The shares trade below Morningstar’s estimate of $63. Trainer’s screen also gives top marks to Stryker for profitability and valuation. 3. Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, +1.30%  shows up on Morningstar’s screen for many of the same criteria as Stryker. The communications-technology leader yields about 1.5%, with a payout ratio of around 27%. Plus, the shares are discounted to Morningstar’s fair value of $62. Said Nolte: “Qualcomm is a cash machine.” 4. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% makes Trainer’s screen for earnings strength and a cheap valuation. The pharmaceutical distributor’s shares yield about 1.3%, the dividend is growing, and the stock price is below Morningstar’s $45 fair value. 5. Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95%  recently began paying a dividend, and the shares yield about 1.2%. The technology bellwether’s payout ratio is a low 15%, leaving plenty of room for potential dividend growth, and the stock trades at a healthy discount to Morningstar’s fair value of $26 a share. 6. Expeditors International of Washington Inc. EXPD, +2.73%  comes up on Morningstar’s screen. Recently the shares yielded 1.1%, with a payout ratio of 27%. Morningstar’s fair value on the shipping company’s stock is $61. 7. Franklin Resources Inc. BEN, +1.67% yields 1%, but the company’s 12% payout ratio and pristine balance sheet means there’s plenty of room to grow the dividend, or to continue special cash dividends that line shareholders’ pockets. Morningstar’s screen gives high marks to Franklin Resources on valuation, and the shares are priced far below Morningstar’s $137 estimate. The company is also one of the S&P 500’s Dividend Aristocrats. 8. Oracle Corp. ORCL, +1.71%  is another relatively new dividend payer. The shares yields 0.9%, while the company’s payout ratio is around 11%. The business software leader has a high return on invested capital, according to Trainer’s screen. Free-cash-flow yield and price-to-economic-book value are also attractive. Oracle also appears on the Morningstar screen based on valuation and profitability. Its shares trade at a steep discount to the researcher’s $41 fair value price. Going forward, Oracle could increase its dividend at a “better-than-normal clip,” Nolte said. “You’re getting 1% on your money, big deal, but if you’re compounding that at 10%, that starts to add up over years.” 9. Visa Inc. V, +2.25%  has a 15% payout ratio, according to Morningstar’s screen, even after a substantial dividend hike last year. The credit- and debit-card payment processor’s shares yield 0.9%, and trade slightly below Morningstar’s $105 fair value estimate. 10. National Oilwell Varco Inc. NOV, +2.45%  also is a new dividend payer that doesn’t provide much yield, recently 0.6%, but the drilling-rig equipment supplier has already increased its payout. The company still has plenty of available cash — the payout ratio is just 10% — and the shares are discounted to Morningstar’s fair value of $97. These types of top-drawer stocks combine value characteristics with growth potential. Said Nolte: “You have, from a total return perspective, the ability to grow principal in addition to growing income. And because you’re below the radar, you’re not in that crowded trade and have the opportunity to pick them up at better valuations.” More from MarketWatch This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics Mutual Funds Investing U.S. Stocks Exchange Traded Funds
title: 10 income-paying stocks that beat the crowd

content: Robert Half International posts 72% higher profit (5:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Robert Half International Inc. RHI, +1.87% reported late Thursday its fourth-quarter profit jumped 72% to $42.6 million, or 30 cents a share, from $24.8 million, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 rose 14% to $973.5 million from $851.6 million. The results fell shy of Wall Street expectations. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had, on average, predicted the Menlo Park, Calif.-based accountant placement agency would earn 31 cents a share on $986 million in revenue. Robert Half shares fell as much as 4.3% to $28.49 in after-hours trade. DeVry profit falls sharply on write-down (4:58 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- DeVry Inc. DV, +2.94% reported late Thursday its fiscal second-quarter profit fell to $9.3 million, or 13 cents a share, from $88.9 million, or $1.25 a share, a year ago. The results include $55.8 million in one-time impairment charges stemming from its Carrington Colleges Group and a $2.2 million one-time gain. The combined one-time items trimmed 79 cents a share from DeVry's bottom line. Revenue for the quarter fell 5% to $524 million from $551 million. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had predicted the for-profit education provider would earn $1.01 a share on $537 million in revenue. DeVry shares fell 8% in after-hours trade to $36.50. Amgen net slips, offers strong sales outlook (4:36 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Amgen Inc. AMGN, +0.01% reported late Thursday fourth-quarter net profit slipped to $934 million, or $1.08 a share, from $1.02 billion, or $1.08 a share, a year ago. Adjusted to exclude one-time items the company earned $1.21 a share in the latest quarter, up from $1.17 a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended Dec. 31 rose 3% to $3.97 billion from $3.84 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast the company would earn $1.22 a share on $3.92 billion in revenue. The company said it expects revenue in 2012 between $16.1 billion and $16.5 billion, well above the $15.5 analysts had been looking for. Shares of the Thousand Oaks, Calif.-based biotech company rose 1.6% to $69.19 in after-hours trade. The stock is up 20% over the past 12 months. Freescale reduces loss despite sales decline (4:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Freescale Semiconductor Holdings trimmed its losses for the fourth quarter despite a decline in sales from the same period last year. For the period ended Dec. 31, Freescale FSL, -0.26% reported a net loss of $6 million, or 2 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $88 million, or 36 cents a share, for the same period the previous year. The company said non-GAAP earnings for the period were $18 million, or 7 cents a share. Revenue slipped 14% to $1.01 billion. Analysts were expecting earnings of 3 cents a share on revenue of $1.03 billion, according to consensus forecasts from Thomson Reuters. Compuware earnings fall 36.5% (4:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Compuware Corp. CPWR, -11.67% on Wednesday reported a fiscal third-quarter profit of $21.6 million, or 10 cents a share, on revenue of $253.1 million. During the same period a year ago. Compuware earned $34 million, or 15 cents a share, on $247 million in sales. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast the business-software company to earn 14 cents a share on $261.1 million in sales for the quarter ended Dec. 31. Starbucks profit up 10% on strong sales growth (4:17 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Starbucks SBUX, -0.02% said late Thursday fiscal first-quarter profit rose 10% to $382.1 million, or 50 cents a share, up from $346.6 million, or 45 cents a share, in the same 2011 period. Revenue rose 16% to a record $3.4 billion. Comparable store sales worldwide were up 9%, helped by successful holiday-season sales, a 7% increase in customer traffic and a 2% gain in average receipt price. The report card topped analysts' forecast, according to FactSet. "Starbucks is firing on all cylinders and taking full advantage of the many global opportunities that lie ahead," CEO Howard Schultz said in a statement. Starbucks backed its previous target for revenue to grow 10% this year and plans to open 800 new stores worldwide. It expects to earn between $1.78 to $1.82 a share in fiscal 2012. Starbucks shares, trading at record highs, are up 47% over last 12 months. Verisign swings to fourth-quarter profit (4:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Verisign Inc. VRSN, +1.86% on Thursday reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $54 million, or 34 cents a share, on revenue of $204 million, compared with a loss of $41 million, or 23 cents a share, on $178.8 million in sales in the same period a year ago. Excluding one-time items, Verisign would have earned $64 million, or 40 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast VeriSign to earn 14 cents a share on $203.8 million in revenue. Motorola swings to loss; tablet shipments 200K (4:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Motorola Mobility Holdings swung to a loss in the fourth quarter, mostly on larger losses in its mobile device business. For the period ended Dec. 31, Motorola Mobility MMI, +0.45% reported a net loss of $80 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with net income of $80 million, or 27 cents a share, for the same period the previous year. The company said non-GAAP earnings for the period were $61 million, or 20 cents a share. Revenue was flat at $3.4 billion. The company said it shipped 5.3 million smartphones for the quarter -- in line with an earlier pre-announcement. Tablet shipments totaled 200,000 units. Motorola Mobility is in the process of being acquired by Google Inc. GOOG, +2.71% Covance slides 9% on financial outlook (1:49 PM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of pharmaceutical research services provider Covance Inc. CVD, -0.27% tumbled 9% to $43.00 on Thursday, the day after it released a lackluster quarterly earnings report and said that it sees 2012 earnings per share coming in between $2.50 and $2.80. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had estimated the company would post earnings of $2.92 a share, on average. Covance also announced its board had authorized a share buyback program of up to $300 million. Time Warner Cable: Online vids no substitute yet (1:31 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Time Warner Cable Inc. TWC, +0.00% Chief Executive Glenn Britt said Thursday that online video services such as Hulu and Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35% have not yet been shown to be meaningful alternatives to its own video service, but the situation is evolving. "The average TV in America is on for some very large number of hours a day," Britt said during the company's earnings call. "... Most people watch a lot of TV, and they like these packages of linear networks. And the services we are talking about are not at this point a substitute for that. Having said that, there are people who don't watch TV very much, and they are quite satisfied with just being able to watch a few shows now and then. We all know a lot of those people, and I think that affects our perception of what is really going on in terms of the mass market." EntreMed rallies in wake of Celgene deal (1:29 PM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of EntreMed Inc. ENMD rallied 23% to $2.89 on Thursday in the wake of news that partner Celgene Corp. CELG, +0.90% was acquiring fellow cancer-therapy developer Avila Therapeutics for $350 million in cash and up to $575 million in future milestone payments. Avila's lead drug candidate is AVL-292, which belongs to a class of therapeutics known as kinase inhibitors. EntreMed has also been developing cancer treatments based on kinase inhibitors. Celgene is a significant stakeholder in EntreMed, which derives most of its revenue from royalty payments on sales of Celgene's drug Thalomid. Earlier this week, EntreMed announced that it had secured $10 million in strategic financing to help develop its kinase inhibitor drug ENMD-2076. Celgene also released its 2011 earnings report on Thursday, which showed that sales of Thalomid fell 13% to $339 million. Mead Johnson shares gain on earnings report (11:18 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Mead Johnson Nutrition MJN shares rose 4% to $75.35 Thursday morning after the maker of Enfamil infant formulas and Choco Milk reported fourth-quarter earnings. Its profit that excluded charges of 52 cents a share and sales of $911 million came in slightly ahead of analyst targets, a FactSet survey shows. Mead Johnson issued a 2012 profit forecast that fell shy of Wall Street's view. Mead Johnson said it would earn between $3 and $3.10 a share against the $3.16 a share analysts projected ahead of Thursday's report. Mead Johnson made 65% of its total company sales in Latin America and Asia last year. Its shares have gained 25% over the last year, outrunning the 2% gain for the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% Zimmer Holdings shares jump on earnings beat (11:12 AM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Zimmer Holdings Inc. ZMH climbed 5% to $60.50 in early trading Thursday after the medical products maker reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings. Zimmer said net income was $156.6 million, or 87 cents a share, compared with the $34.9 million, or 18 cents a share, reported a year ago. Sales were $1.17 billion against last year's $1.13 billion. Adjusted earnings were $1.36 a share, two cents ahead of the projection from analysts polled by FactSet Research. The company said it now expects adjusted full-year 2012 earnings to fall within a range of $5.20 to $5.40 a share. The FactSet estimate had been for $5.23. J.C. Penney rises on expense cuts, outlook (10:59 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of J.C. Penney were on the rise Thursday, gaining almost 11% after the retailer detailed plans to cut expenses, pour hundreds of millions of dollars into overhauling its stores and issued a relatively rosy profit outlook for the year. Penney is looking at trimming $900 million in costs with a goal of lowering its expenses to below 30% in the next two years. It is also said it will undertake a "transformation" of its stores, spending $800 million in cash from operations this year alone. Finally, it said it expects earnings for fiscal year 2012 "to meet or exceed" its 2010 bottom line of $1.59 a share, or $2.16 a share, on an adjusted basis. Shares of Penney JCP, -0.98% added $3.74 to $38.02 in morning action. Covidien shares soar on earnings report (10:58 AM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Medical-products maker Covidien PLC COV, -6.04% soared in early trading Thursday after reporting better-than-expected quarterly earnings. Covidien was up nearly 4% to $51.28 in recent action after the Irish firm said first-quarter net income was $494 million, or $1.02 a share, compared with $427 million, or 86 cents a share, from a year ago. Adjusted income was $1.13 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected earnings of $1.03 a share. Time-Warner Cable shares up on results, buyback (10:39 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Time-Warner Cable TWC, +0.00% jumped more than 7% Thursday morning to $74.05 after the cable carrier reported better-than-expected results for the fourth quarter and announced a $4 billion share buyback plan. The company added 51,000 net new subscribers during the quarter. "We don't believe it to be an exaggeration to say that the company beat expectations on all fronts," wrote Vijay Jayant of ISI Group in a note to clients following the results. Caterpillar shares jump on earnings surprise (10:08 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Caterpillar Inc. CAT, +1.53% shares jumped as much as 4% at the open Thursday after the blue-chip heavy machinery maker topped fourth-quarter earnings expectations. The company, whose equipment is used extensively in construction and mining operations, reported net income for the quarter of $2.32 a share, well above the $1.75 a share analysts polled by FactSet Research had been looking for. The gains come on the back of strong global demand for earth-moving equipment in the mining sector, evidenced in part by the company's record-high order backlog of nearly $30 billion. Caterpillar shares were last trading 3.3% higher at $112.63. The stock is up nearly 18% over the past 12 months and up 24% since Jan. 1. Owens-Illinois shares gain on outlook (10:04 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Owens-Illinois OI, +1.59% shares surged 6% to $24.66 in opening trades Thursday after the world's largest glass container manufacturer topped Wall Street's fourth-quarter view. Looking ahead, Owens-Illinois said it's negotiated higher prices on a significant portion of its contracted business for this year. It also said shipments should be consistent with last year. Shares of Owens-Illinois are off to a strong start this year, having gained 27% after stumbling in 2011. Tech stocks rise with Netflix, LSI; SanDisk falls (9:40 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Tech stocks opened to gains Thursday morning, led by strong upticks by Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35% and LSI Corp. LSI, -0.35% both of which surged upwards following earnings reports on Wednesday afternoon. SanDisk SNDK shares fell more than 10% after the company issued disappointing projections for the current quarter and fiscal year. The Nasdaq Composite COMP, +1.64% was up 0.2% to 2,824 while the Morgan Stanley High-Tech Index was flat near the open. Netflix shares surge 20% in early trading (9:39 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35% shares surged as much as 20% to $113 Thursday following the video provider's better-than-expected fourth-quarter results. Late Wednesday, Netflix said it earned $41 million, or 73 cents a share, on revenue of $876 million, compared with a profit of $47 million, or 87 cents a share, on $596 million in sales in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast Netflix to earn 54 cents a share on revenue of $857.3 million. Mark Mahaney, an analyst with Citigroup, raised his rating on Netflix's stock to buy from neutral saying the company is showing signs of stabilizing its business after the upheavals of 2011. Nucor posts 4th-quarter profit on 25% higher sales (9:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Nucor Corp., NUE, +2.98% the Charlotte, N.C., steelmaker, swung to a fourth-quarter profit from a year-earlier net loss on 25% higher sales. Earnings were $137.1 million, or 43 cents a share, against a loss of $11.4 million, or 4 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Sales reached $4.83 billion from $3.85 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 29 cents a share of profit on $4.75 billion of revenue. First-quarter earnings should exceed the fourth-quarter level, Nucor said. Consol praised for cutting natural gas spending (8:57 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Consol Energy CNX, +1.38% drew praise Thursday from analyst Lucas Pipes of Brean Murray Carret & Co. for cutting its 2012 capital spending target by $200 million at it scales back its investment in natural gas production in the face of low prices. "We believe that Consol's decision...was a sensible decision, which should be rewarded by investors," Pipes said in a note to clients. Overall, Consol's fourth-quarter results came in "roughly in line with our estimates," he said. Shares of Consol Energy rose 5% to $37.70 in premarket trades. Sherwin-Williams net falls on tax settlement cost (8:34 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sherwin-Williams Co. SHW, +1.78% said Thursday its fourth-quarter profit fell to $14.6 million, or 14 cents a share, from $72.9 million, or 67 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The company booked 70 cent a share related to a tax settlement loss and 3 cents a share in costs for acquisitions and currency translation. Sales increased to $2.07 billion from $1.9 billion. Wall Street analysts expected Sherwin-Williams to earn 83 cents a share on revenue of $2.05 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. The Cleveland paint maker expects first-quarter profit of 56 cents to 74 cents a share, compared to the analyst estimate of 70 cents a share. For 2012, it's forecasting earnings of $5.37 to $5.67 a share, compared to the Wall Street target of $5.56 a share. Bristol-Myers Squibb's income rises 76% (8:09 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. BMY, +1.09% Thursday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $852 million, or 50 cents a share, up from $483 million, or 28 cents, in the year-ago period. The drug maker saw revenue rise 7% to $5.5 billion from $5.1 billion in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings came in at 53 cents a share, compared to 47 cents a share on a year-ago basis. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research expected earnings of 55 cents a share on revenue of 5.5 billion. The New York-based company said it expects earnings for 2012 to range between $1.90 and $2.00 for the full year. Shares of Bristol-Myers Squibb were down 0.1% in pre-market trade. 3M 4th-period net up 2.8%; outlook affirmed (8:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- 3M Corp., MMM, +1.38% the St. Paul, Minn., technology company, reported on Thursday that fourth-quarter net income rose 2.8% on 5.7% higher sales and it affirmed its outlook for the year. Earnings were $954 million, or $1.35 a share, versus $928 million, or $1.28, in the year-earlier quarter. Shares outstanding fell 2.8% to 707.5 million. Sales reached $7.09 billion from $6.71 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimates of $1.31 a share of profit on $7.09 billion of revenue. For the year, 3M estimated earnings would range $6.25 to $6.50 a share. That compares with the FactSet estimate of $6.33 a share. United Continental narrows loss, revenue up 5.5% (8:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- United Continental Holdings Inc. UAL, +2.30% said Thursday its fourth-quarter loss narrowed to $138 million, or 42 cents a share, from $325 million, or $1.01 a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding $247 million in special items, the Chicago-based airline earned 30 cents a share, in the latest period. Revenue increased by 5.5% to $8.93 billion. Wall Street analysts expected United Continental to earn 13 cents a share on revenue of $8.93 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. UAL ended the year with $8.3 billion in cash and undrawn lines of credit. Caterpillar profit up 60% on record sales (7:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Caterpillar Inc. CAT, +1.53% said Thursday its fourth-quarter profit jumped 60% to $1.55 billion, or $2.25 a share, from $968 million, or $1.47 a share, in the year-ago period. Breaking out the impact of its Bucyrus acquisition, Caterpillar earned $2.32 a share. Revenue increased 35% to $17.24 billion, an all-time quarterly record. The Peoria, Ill.-based maker of bulldozers was expected to earn $1.76 a share on revenue of $15.95 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Looking ahead, Caterpillar expects 2012 earnings of about $9.25 a share, ahead of the analyst estimate of $9.07 a share. AutoNation 'pleased' with quarterly results (7:45 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Automotive retailer AutoNation, Inc. AN, +2.03% Thursday reported fourth quarter net income of $69.4 million, or 49 cents per share, versus $67.3 million, or 45 cents per share, in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were forecasting quarterly net profit of $69.1 million, or 49 cents per share. Total revenue hit $3.67 billion from $3.24 billion in the year-ago period. AutoNation's new vehicle unit sales advanced 10% on a same-store basis and rose 13% overall. Mike Jackson, chairman and chief executive officer, said: "We are pleased with our strong year-over-year growth across all areas of our business." AutoNation said that it set a record for adjusted EPS from continuing operations for the quarter, which hit $0.51, a rise of 13% compared to the year-ago period. Raytheon's earnings rise 18% (7:42 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Raytheon Co. RTN, +2.26% Thursday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $543 million, or $1.58 a share, compared with $459 million, or $1.26 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue declined 6% to $6.5 billion from $6.9 billion in the fourth quarter last year. Adjusted earnings were $1.74 a share, up from $1.55. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research expected earnings of $1.34 a share, on revenue of $6.7 billion. The Waltham, Mass.-based company said it expects adjusted earnings for 2012 to come in between $5.45 and $5.60 on revenue between $24.5 billion and $25 billion. Nokia swings to loss on 21% lower sales (7:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Finnish mobile-phone maker Nokia Corp. NOK, +0.74% (FI:NOK1V)swung to a fourth-quarter net loss of 1.07 billion euros ($1.4 billion), or 0.29 euro a share, compared with net income of 745 million euros, or 0.2 euro a share, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted net income was 0.06 euro a share versus 0.22 euro. Sales fell 21% to 10 billion euros from 12.65 billion. Nokia did not provide targets for 2012, saying this will be a transition year, "during which our devices-and-services business will be subject to risks and uncertainties." Nokia sold 19.6 million units in the closely watched smartphone segment in the fourth quarter of 2011, down 31% from the year-earlier quarter. Nokia launched its first Windows smartphones in October and CEO Stephen Elop said in a Thursday statement that the range accounted for "well over 1 million" of the units sold in the fourth quarter. Analysts polled by Bloomberg estimated Nokia would sell 1.3 million Windows smartphones. While "we progressed in the right direction in 2011, we still have a tremendous amount to accomplish in 2012," Elop said. McCormick & Co. profit dips, sales up 13% (7:31 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- McCormick & Co. MKC, +0.42% said Thursday its fourth-quarter profit fell to $131.7 million, or 98 cents a share, from $133.6 million, or 99 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Breaking out a one-time charge of 5 cents a share for transaction costs, McCormick earned $1.03 a share in the latest quarter. Sales rose to $1.11 billion from $979.5 million. Wall Street analysts expected McCormick to earn 98 cents a share on revenue of $1.08 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. The Sparks, Md.-based spice maker expects 2012 profit of $3.01 to $3.06 a share, compared to the analyst estimate of $3.10 a share. AmerisourceBergen profit rises (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said on Thursday that its fiscal first-quarter profit rose to $116 million, or 62 cents a share compared to $160.5 million, or 57 cents a share a year ago. Revenue for the quarter came in at $20.36 billion, compared to $19.89 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the firm to earn 63 cents a share on revenue of 20.02 billion. Baxter profit rises 9%, sales up (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Baxter International Inc. BAX, +1.86% said Thursday its fourth-quarter profit rose 9% to $463 million, or 82 cents a share, from $423 million, or 72 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings totaled $1.17 a share in the latest quarter. Revenue increased 3% to $3.59 billion. Wall Street analysts expected Baxter to earn $1.17 a share on revenue of $3.58 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Baxter expects first-quarter earnings of 98 cents to $1 a share, before special items, compared to the analyst estimate of $1.04 a share. For 2012, Baxter forecasts earnings of $4.47 to $4.57 a share, against the estimate of $4.62 a share. Lockheed Martin net off 29% on 4.3% lower sales (6:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Lockheed Martin Corp., LMT, +0.78% the Bethesda, Md., aerospace-and-defense major, reported fourth-quarter net income fell 29% on 4.3% lower sales. Net income fell to $683 million, or $2.09 a share, from $961 million, or $2.67, in the year-earlier quarter. Continuing operations generated profit of $2.14 a share against $2.28 a year earlier. Shares outstanding fell 9.2% to 326.7 million. Sales slipped to $12.21 billion from $12.76 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of $1.95 a share of profit on $12.3 billion of revenue. For 2012, LMT expects to earn $7.70 to $7.90 a share from continuing operations on revenue of $45 billion to $46 billion. FactSet's survey is looking for $7.78 a share of profit on $46.2 billion of revenue. Time Warner Cable net up: $4B buyback planned (6:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Time Warner Cable Inc., TWC, +0.00% the New York provider of cable-TV and other services, reported that fourth-quarter net income rose 44% on 4% higher revenue, said it would buy back as much as $4 billion of stock and lifted the quarterly dividend 17%. Profit reached $564 million, or $1.75 a share, from $392 million, or $1.09, in the year-earlier quarter. Adjusted net was $1.39 a share versus 99 cents. Revenue rose to $4.99 billion from $4.8 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Ressearch produced consensus estimates of $1.19 a share of profit on $4.97 billion of revenue. The new dividend is 56 cents a share, up from 48 cents, payable March 15 to holders of record Feb. 29. Logitech shares off 10% after outlook cut (3:37 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Logitech International SA(CH:LOGN)fell nearly 9% on Thursday in the wake of a fall in fiscal third-quarter net profit and sales and a cut in its fiscal 2012 full-year outlook. Reporting late Wednesday, the computer-mouse maker said net income fell 15% to $55.33 million against $65 million in the year-ago period, while sales fell 5% to $715 million from $754 million in the year-ago period. Guerrino De Luca, Logitech chairman and acting chief executive officer, said since the company last provided its full-year at the end of October, the euro has weakened considerably. "In addition, webcams and remotes continue to be impacted more than expected by product portfolio and market weakness. Consequently, we have lowered our outlook for fiscal-year 2012 sales and operating income," he said in a statement. For the fiscal year ending March 2012, the company now expects sales of $2.3 billion and operating income of $60 million, with the gross margin for the full year still seen at around 33%. Hyundai Motor posts 38% rise in Q4 net profit (2:03 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Hyundai Motor Co. HYMLF, -11.11% reported Thursday a 38% rise for its fourth-quarter net profit compared to a year earlier, as stronger overseas sales were boosted by a slide in the South Korean won. Manufacturing-related disruptions among Japanese rivals also helped to offset weaker sales at home. Net profit for the three months ended in December totaled 2.002 trillion won ($1.79 billion), compared to 1.451 trillion won a year earlier, the company said in a statement. The result was below expectations of 2.24 trillion won, according to a poll by Bloomberg News. Hyundai share were quoted 1.1% lower in late trading Thursday following the results' announcement. Samsung F&M poised to rise, says Citi (12:40 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Samsung Fire & Marine Insurance Co. stands to benefit from new management, including the appointment of a new chief executive last month and a chief financial officer transferred recently from Samsung's life-insurance business, Citigroup analysts said Wednesday. Management appears to be adopting a strategy which is more about growth than risk-control and includes a plan to add 30,000 salesmen, more than doubling the existing 27,000, Citi said. Samsung F&M is due to release earnings Tuesday, though Citi said the results are likely to disappoint because of claims related to the Thailand floods last year and tax adjustments. Shares of Samsung F&M SZVZF traded 0.4% higher in Seoul early Thursday afternoon. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 1% as the drug wholesaler reported sales growth in pharmaceuticals and specialty businesses. The company made a number of acquisitions last year that bolster the services it can offer its customers. Most recently it acquired CVS Caremark Corp.'s (CVS) TheraCom LLC unit, which provides support services to the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. AmerisourceBergen also is likely to benefit from continuing introductions of big generic drugs this year, which tend to carry higher margins. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $162.1 million, or 62 cents a share, up from $160.5 million, or 57 cents a share, a year earlier. The latest period included $3.6 million of acquisition-related impacts. Revenue increased 2.4% to $20.35 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently projected earnings of 63 cents on revenue of $19.99 billion. Gross margin was flat at 2.9%. Revenue at its drug business rose 2.1%, while specialty group revenue was up 3.9%. Shares of AmerisourceBergen, which affirmed its full-year guidance, closed Wednesday at $39.72 and were inactive premarket. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle
title: AmerisourceBergen profit ticks higher in fiscal Q1

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said on Thursday that its fiscal first-quarter profit rose to $116 million, or 62 cents a share compared to $160.5 million, or 57 cents a share a year ago. Revenue for the quarter came in at $20.36 billion, compared to $19.89 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the firm to earn 63 cents a share on revenue of 20.02 billion.
title: AmerisourceBergen profit rises

content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Thursday’s session are Teradyne Inc., Covance Inc. and Netflix Inc. It’s another busy day on the earnings front. Three more Dow Jones Industrial Average components — AT&T Inc. T, +0.25% 3M Co. MMM, +1.38%  and Caterpillar Inc. CAT, +1.53%  — are on deck to release quarterly financial results. Also due to report are Eaton Corp. ETN, +1.09%  , Precision Castparts Corp. PCP, +0.00% Briggs & Stratton Corp. BGG, +0.47% Nucor Corp. NUE, +2.98% AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Celgene Corp. CELG, +0.90% Mead Johnson Nutrition Co. MJN  , Zimmer Holdings Inc. ZMH Lockheed Martin Corp. LMT, +0.78%  , Raytheon Co. RTN, +2.26% Juniper Networks Inc. JNPR, +1.16% VeriSign Inc. VRSN, +1.86% KLA-Tencor Corp. KLAC, +2.29% Rambus Inc. RMBS, +0.67% Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.02% Sherwin-Williams Co. SHW, +1.78%  and Ryland Group Inc. RYL among many others. Late Wednesday, Standard & Poor’s said it would add Medidata Solutions Inc. MDSO, +0.48%  to the S&P SmallCap 600 index in place RightNow Technologies Inc. RNOW  after the close of trading on Friday. New York-based Medidata provides software services for life-science organizations. Oracle Corp. ORCL, +1.71%  is close to completing the acquisition of RightNow, necessitating the change. Along with reporting fourth-quarter financial results, Teradyne TER, +1.96%  raised its revenue outlook for the first quarter. As revised, the North Reading, Mass.-based company sees revenue for the March quarter in a range of $360 million to $400 million. Teradyne also noted “strong” sequential growth in fourth-quarter orders. Along with reporting fourth-quarter results, Covance CVD, -0.27%  said its board authorized a buyback program for up to $300 million in common stock. The move came as the Princeton, N.J.-based company forecast 2012 earnings of $2.50 to $2.80 a share, including a first-quarter profit pegged “in the low 60-cent range.” Covance noted currency translations as well as stock repurchases and higher spending on information technology as factors that would affect its 2012 results. In particular, Chairman and CEO Joe Herring said Covance has decided to fund four projects that would increase the company’s capital spending on IT to about $90 million for this year, some 50% higher than in 2011, and “will lead to a significant increase in operating expense over the next two years.” The board of Ball Corp. BLL, +1.33% cleared the repurchase of up to 30 million common shares, the Broomfield, Colo.-based company said. In addition, Ball’s board voted to increase the company’s quarterly cash dividend by 43%, to 10 cents a share. It’s payable March 15 stockholders of record as of March 1. The board of Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan Inc. POT, -2.17%  approved a doubling in the company’s dividend on common stock, declaring a quarterly payout of 14 cents a share payable May 3 to stockholders of record as of April 12. It’s the second such dividend increase recently, Potash Corp. said. The board last January cleared a substantial dividend increase to go with a three-for-one stock split. Underwriters sold 1.95 million shares of Sequenom Inc. SQNM  on top of its previously announced secondary public offering of 13 million shares of common stock, the San Diego-based company said. All shares were offered at a price of $4.15 each. Net proceeds are expected to be used for general corporate purposes, including research and development, capital spending, working capital and administrative expenses. Wednesday earnings recap Netflix NFLX, +3.35%  reported fourth-quarter earnings of $41 million, or 73 cents a share, down from $47 million, or 87 cents, earned in the final three months of 2010. Quarterly revenue generated by the Los Gatos, Calif.-based video-rental provider jumped to $875.6 million from $595.9 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had been looking for earnings of 54 cents a share on revenue of $857.3 million. Along with providing updated figures on video-streaming subscribers, Netflix said it expects to take a loss of $9 million to $27 million because of increased investment in its international markets, particularly the recent launch of its streaming service in the United Kingdom. Read more on Netflix. SanDisk Corp. SNDK  reported a fourth-quarter net profit of $281 million, or $1.14 a share, down from $485 million, or $2.01 a share, earned in the year-earlier period. Quarterly revenue rose to $1.58 billion from the prior year’s $1.33 billion. On an adjusted basis, the Milpitas, Calif.-based company would have earned $1.29 a share; analysts’ consensus had been for a profit of $1.26 a share on revenue of $1.57 billion. But on a conference call, SanDisk’s executives forecast below-consensus revenue of $1.3 billion to $1.35 billion for the first quarter, reflecting weaker demand from certain customers. The company also forecast 2012 revenue of $6.2 billion to $6.6 billion, with the bulk of its year-over-year revenue growth to be in the second half. Wall Street currently expects $6.64 billion in full-year revenue for SanDisk. LSI Corp. LSI, -0.35%  posted a fourth-quarter net loss of $1.8 million, narrower than the prior year’s loss of $13.4 million. On a per-share basis, the loss was breakeven for the latest quarter as opposed to 2 cents a share for the year-earlier period. LSI’s revenue reached $523.1 million from $470.7 million, as earnings on an adjusted basis would have been 10 cents a share for the latest quarter. Analysts’ consensus stood at $526.7 million and 11 cents a share, respectively. The Milpitas, Calif.-based company also steered analysts and investors higher on revenue for the first quarter, pegging it in a range of $550 million to $590 million, well ahead of the consensus view of $510.7 million. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Thursday: Teradyne, Covance

content: N/A
title: Dreamworks, McKesson see analyst action Wednesday

content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trading in Wednesday’s session are Adobe Systems Inc., Weight Watchers International Inc. and Powell Industries Inc. Cisco Systems Inc. CSCO, +2.95% part of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, likely will come in for the most scrutiny among companies reporting financial results Wednesday. Other notables include General Motors Co. GM, +2.45% Ralph Lauren Corp. RL, +1.60% Macy’s Inc. M, +2.30%   99-Cent Only Stores NDN Wendy’s Co. WEN, +0.75% Dean Foods Co. DF, -0.12% Green Mountain Coffee Roasters Inc. GMCR Kelly Services Inc. KELYA, +0.90% KELYB, -0.24% Computer Sciences Corp. CSC, +3.70% Harvest Natural Resources Inc. HNR, +0.00% Ashland Inc. ASH, +1.04% OM Group Inc. OMG, -2.11% Rock-Tenn Co. RKT  and Pike Electric Corp. PIKE among others. Adobe ADBE, +1.67%  said it’s cutting 750 jobs, mainly in North America and Europe, as part of a restructuring to align its businesses around digital media and digital marketing. The company expects to take pre-tax charges of about $87 million to $94 million against fourth-quarter results. As a result, Adobe revised its quarterly earnings forecast to a range of 30 cents to 38 cents a share, down from 41 cents to 50 cents a share previously. The San Jose, Calif.-based company reiterated its revenue outlook for the fourth quarter in a range of $1.08 billion to $1.13 billion. Also late Tuesday, Powell Industries POWL, -1.68%  said it will restate financial results for the second and third quarters of fiscal 2011, after having discovered accounting errors pertaining to its Canadian operations. The errors reflect inaccurate recording of customer change orders, an erroneous journal entry recorded in accounts payable, incorrect close-out of costs on certain jobs and the application of an incorrect manufacturing overhead rate, Powell said. In addition, the company will record a non-cash impairment charge of 61 cents a shares against fourth-quarter results for the remaining intangible assets recorded in connection with the acquisition of Powell Canada. As a result, management revised Houston-based Powell’s full-year outlook and now sees a net loss in a range of 20 cents to 25 cents a share on revenue of about $560 million. On an adjusted basis, Powell pegged full-year earnings at between 51 cents and 56 cents a share. International Paper Co. IP, +2.00%  priced $900 million of 4.75% senior unsecured notes due 2022 as well as $600 million of 6% senior unsecured notes due 2041. Memphis-based International Paper said it will use net proceeds, together with other committed debt financing and available cash, to finance the acquisition of Temple-Inland Inc. TIN, +0.00% a deal scheduled to be completed in the fourth quarter or the first quarter of 2012. The board of Allstate Corp. ALL, +0.20%  approved plans to issue $1.25 bilion in preferred stock and senior unsecured debt to fund the Northbrook, Ill.-based company’s new $1 billion share-repurchase program and repay maturing debt. Stock will be bought back via open-market purchases and may include an accelerated repurchase program, the insurer said. The program is expected to be completed by March 31, 2013. The board of Sigma-Aldrich Corp. SIAL  approved an increase of 10 million shares in the company’s stock-buyback authorization. This brings unused authorization to more than 12.37 million shares, the company said. Shares repurchased are held as treasury shares, in keeping with St. Louis-based Sigma-Aldrich’s efforts to offset the dilutive impact of stock-based compensation. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  priced $500 million of 3.5% senior notes due 2021. The Valley Forge, Pa.-based said it intends to use net proceeds from the public offering for general corporate purposes. It’s expected to close Nov. 14. The board of Mesa Laboratories Inc. MLAB, +3.59%  declared a quarterly dividend of 13 cents a share on common stock, up 8.3% from the previous quarter’s payout. The dividend’s payable Dec. 15 to stockholders of record as of Nov. 28, the Lakewood, Colo.-based company said. Tuesday earnings recap Weight Watchers WTW, +1.51%  raised its 2011 forecast as the company reported strong growth in earnings and revenue for the third quarter late Tuesday. As revised, the New York-based company sees full-year earnings in a range of $4.05 to $4.10 a share; the projected range previously stood at $3.85 to $4.05 a share. Activision Blizzard Inc. ATVI, +2.26%  reported third-quarter results and pegged full-year earnings at about 85 cents a share on revenue of $4.25 billion, up from the 68 cents a share and $4.18 billion previously forecast. Management cited the strong launch of “Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3.” Read more on Activision Blizzard’s results and forecast. Along with reporting results for the second quarter ended Sept. 30, Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. TTWO, +0.33%  said it expects to generate earnings of 20 cents to 30 cents a share on sales of $225 million to $275 million for the fiscal third quarter. This would be less than analysts’ consensus forecast calling for 34 cents a share and $310.4 million, respectively. At the same time, the New York-based company reiterated its full-year financial outlook. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Wednesday: Adobe, Cisco, Allstate

content: Oneok profit up 9%; ups forecast (4:58 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Natural gas distributor Oneok OKE, +2.32% late Tuesday reported third-quarter profit rose 9% from the same 2010 period. The company also increased its 2011 earnings forecast. Net income for the recent quarter was $60.3 million, or 57 cents a share, up from $55.3 million, or 51 cents a share. For the full year, the Oklahoma-based company said it expects to earn between $345 million to $365 million. Its old forecast was $325 million to $345 million. Oneok shares closed at $73.76, down 3%, ahead of the report. Synchronoss earnings jump 67% in third quarter (4:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Synchronoss Technologies, Inc. reported a 67% surge in earnings for the third quarter on growing demand for its transaction management services used by wireless carriers. For the period ended Sept. 30, Synchronoss SNCR, -0.57% reported net income of $3.57 million, or 9 cents a share, compared to net income of $2.14 million, or 5 cents a share, for the same period the previous year. On a non-GAAP basis, the company said it would have earned 23 cents a share for the period. Revenue jumped 33% to $59.2 million. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 21 cents a share on revenue of $58.3 million, according to consensus estimates from FactSet Research. Pitney Bowes posts profit gain, but warns on sales (4:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Postage meter manufacturer Pitney Bowes Inc. PBI, -0.73% on Tuesday reported a third-quarter profit of $172.8 million, or 85 cents a share, up from $88.9 million, or 43 cents a share a year ago. Adjusted for one-time items, profit from continuing operations came to 56 cents a share. Revenue fell 3% to $1.3 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings, on average, of 54 cents a share with sales of $1.33 billion. "Our revenue performance this quarter reflects the impact of sustained economic uncertainty on most of our global customer base. This weakness is affecting the buying confidence of some of our customers," Chairman and CEO Murray Martin said. The company also warned that its revenue for the year would decline more than it originally forecast. Sanmina-SCI earnings drop 42% (4:38 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sanmina-SCI Corp. SANM, +0.77% on Tuesday reported a fiscal fourth-quarter profit of $18.1 million, or 22 cents a share, on revenue of $1.7 billion, compared with earnings of $31.4 million, or 38 cents a share, on $1.69 billion in sales in the same period a year ago. Excluding one-time items, the electronics contract manufacturer would have earned $38.7 million, or 47 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast Sanmina-SCI to earn 41 cents a share on $1.66 billion in revenue. MetroPCS shares drop as earnings fall (11:01 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- MetroPCS Communications Inc. PCS shares on Tuesday fell 61 cents, or more than 7%, to $7.89 after the provider of discount wireless-phone service provider reported quarterly results before the market opened. The company reported a third-quarter profit of $9.3 million, or 19 cents a share, compared to earnings of $77.2 million, or 22 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose 18% to $1.2 billion. However, analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters had forecast MetroPCS to earn 23 cents a share on sales of $1.22 billion. Amedisys falls 19% on earnings, execs to leave (10:46 AM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- An extensive write-down reported in its third-quarter earnings, and the announcement that two key executives are leaving, sent shares of home health care company Amedisys Inc. AMED, +0.20% plunging by more than 19% at one point Tuesday. The company said it would take a non-cash goodwill charge of $574.1 million due to a decline in market capitalization, earnings results and recent forecasts, and added it won't be able to fully measure the fair value of the goodwill until the fourth quarter. Amedisys lost $423.7 million for the period, or $14.73 a share, and had reported earnings of $21.6 million, or 76 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales were $374.9 million against last year's $404.7 million. The company said Chief Operating Officer Mike Snow would be leaving, and Chief Financial Officer Dale Redman will move to the role of executive vice president and treasurer until he retires in 2012. Valero shares steady despite energy sector drop (10:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Valero Energy Corp. VLO, +2.76% fell 0.8% to $24.37, despite deeper losses in the energy sector on Tuesday. The refiner said its third-quarter profit quadrupled to $1.2 billion, or $2.11 a share, from $303 million, or 53 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue increased to $33.7 billion, from $21 billion. "We were able to capitalize on favorable refining margins and attain our highest refinery utilization since the third quarter of 2007," the company said. Wall Street analysts expected Valero to earn $1.80 a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. American Tower lifts outlook; shares rise (10:23 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of American Tower Corp. AMT, +0.72% rose more than 2% Tuesday, coming close to a 52-week high, after the cell-tower operator raised its financial outlook for the year. The Boston-based company said earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization will now be about $20 million higher than originally expected for 2011, totaling about $1.59 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research were looking for Ebitda of $1.57 billion. The company added it was on track to convert to a real estate investment trust entity by Jan. 1. Shares of American Tower climbed as high as $56.98 on Tuesday, coming close to its full-year high of $57.28. The stock was one of the few gainers, with the benchmark Standard & Poor's 500 Index SPX, +1.38% off 2%. Dunkin' shares drop 6%; 22mln share sale planned (10:14 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Dunkin' Brands Group DNKN, -0.20% shares dropped 6% to $27.32 in early trades Tuesday, the biggest single-day decline since Aug. 2. Dunkin' said shareholders plan to sell 22 million shares in a secondary offering. The owner of the Dunkin' Donuts chain and Baskin Robbins ice cream shops won't receive any proceeds from the stock sale expected to be completed before yearend. Dunkin' on Tuesday posted a $7.4 million third-quarter profit, 61% less than the same 2010 period. Profit fell due to costs associated with the company's July 27 initial public offering and costs to retire debt. U.S. sales at stores open one year rose 5.6% over the year-ago period. Dunkin' said sales were strong for K-Cups used in Green Mountain Coffee Roasters GMCR Keurig machines. Energy stocks fall hard with broad equities market (9:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy stocks fell Tuesday on fresh fears tied to European sovereign debt. The NYSE Arca Oil Index(XX:XOI)dropped 4%. The NYSE Arca Natural Gas Index(XX:XNG)fell 3.5%. The Philadelphia Oil Service Index OSX, +2.53% dropped 5.6%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% moved down by 240 points. HCA third-quarter profit falls 75% (8:08 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- HCA Holdings Inc. HCA, -0.15% said Tuesday its third-quarter income plunged to $61 million, or 11 cents a share, from $243 million, or 55 cents a share, in the year ago period. The number of shares outstanding rose to 527,515 from 439,032. On an adjusted basis, the Nashville, Tenn., healthcare firm said it earned 60 cents a share with revenue of $7.31 billion, up from $6.93 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of 43 cents a share, on average, with sales of $7.98 billion. Shares of HCA had yet to trade premarket. AmerisourceBergen net up; sees higher '12 profit (7:42 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp., ABC, +1.29% the Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical-services provider, reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose 4.3% on 3.5% higher revenue. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, profit reached $147.3 million, or 54 cents a share, from $141.2 million, or 50 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Shares outstanding fell 4.4% to 271.4 million. Revenue rose to $20.41 billion from $19.72 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of 56 cents a share of profit on $20.20 billion of revenue. For fiscal 2012, ABC expects to earn $2.74 to $2.84 a share, up from fiscal 2011's $2.54. FactSet's survey is eyeing $2.81. AmerisourceBergen sees revenue for the current year ranging from level with fiscal 2011 to modestly higher. FactSet's survey sees fiscal 2012 revenue up less than 1% to $80.28 billion. Thomson Reuters profit nearly doubles, keeps view (7:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Thomson Reuters Corp. TRI, +0.31% said Tuesday its third-quarter profit nearly doubled to $659 million, or 44 cents a share, from $356 million, or 32 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted profit increased to 56 cents a share, from 45 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue climbed 6% to $3.45 billion. Revenue from ongoing businesses increased 8% to $3.26 billion. Wall Street analysts expected the information solutions and services firm to earn 54 cents a share on revenue of $3.27 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Thomson Reuters said it continues to remain on track to deliver its financial objectives for the year as provided in February. The company expects revenue to increase by the mid-single digits in 2011. Archer Daniels quarterly profit climbs 33% (7:26 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Archer Daniels Midland Co. ADM, +1.33% said Tuesday its fiscal first-quarter net income rose to $460 million, or 68 cents a share, from $345 million, or 54 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, the Decatur, Ill.-based seed-processing company said it earned 58 cents a share in the latest period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of 67 cents a share, on average. The firm blamed high corn costs and weak oilseed margins for the "difficult" quarter. Shares of ADM had yet to trade premarket. Pfizer 3rd-quarter net jumps; '11 outlook lifted (7:21 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Pfizer Inc., PFE, +0.54% the New York health-care major, reported third-quarter net income jumped on 7.5% higher revenue, and it lifted its estimates of adjusted earnings for 2011. Profit for the quarter quadrupled to $3.74 billion, or 48 cents a share, from $866 million, or 11 cents, in the year-earlier period. The latest adjusted net was 62 cents a share. Revenue reached $17.19 billion from $16 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 55 cents a share of profit on $16.43 billion of revenue. Revenue fell 3% in the U.S. and rose 15% internationally, the company said in a Tuesday statement. Pfizer now expects to earn $2.24 to $2.29 a share in 2011, up from its previous estimate of $2.16 to $2.26. FactSet's survey is estimating $2.25. Sandvik 3rd-quarter net off 60%; 500 job cuts set (4:49 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Sandvik AB, SDVKY, +2.56% SDVKF, +0.00% (SE:SAND)the Sandviken, Sweden, engineering group, reported third-quarter profit fell 60%, hurt by special items, on 22% higher sales. Earnings fell to 626 million Swedish kronor ($96 million), or 0.53 krona a share, from 1.58 billion kronor, or 1.33, in the year-earlier quarter. Sales reached 23.53 billion kronor from 20.24 billion. The mining-and-construction and tooling divisions "registered high demand" but "the trend for some of Sandvik Materials Technology's product groups weakened," President and Chief Executive Olof Faxander said in a Tuesday statement. As part of a September 2011 plan to save 500 million kronor over two to three years, the company has identified 500 job cuts, of which 365 are in Sweden, Sandvik said. At the end of the third quarter, Sandvik employed 49,455 people. Royal DSM 3rd-quarter net doubled, sales up 5% (3:44 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Royal DSM, RDSMY, -0.08% KDSKF, +1.18% (NL:DSM)the Heerlen, Netherlands, life-sciences and materials-sciences company, reported third-quarter net income more than doubled on 5% higher sales. Net income reached 171 million euros ($236.2 million), or €1 a share, from €79 million, or €0.46, in the year-earlier quarter. Profit from continuing operations before special items rose 38% to €0.94 a share from €0.68. Sales rose to €2.32 billion from €2.21 billion. The improvement came despite "a very strong Swiss franc and a weak U.S. dollar," DSM said in a statement. Feike Sijbesma, chairman of the management board and chief executive, warned that in the third quarter, DSM saw weaker electronics-and-electrical and building-and-construction markets. But he said the company's portfolio is relatively resilient and geographically diverse, and the balance sheet is "solid." Credit Suisse net up 12%; targets more cost cuts (2:29 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Credit Suisse Group, CS, +1.27% (CH:CSGN)the Zurich financial-services firm, on Tuesday reported third-quarter net income rose 12% and said it would make more cost cuts that would require more job cuts. Earnings reached 683 million Swiss francs ($777.6 million), or 0.53 franc a share, from 609 million francs, or 0.48, in the year-earlier quarter. On a core basis, pretax profit from continuing operations rose 38% to 1.04 billion francs as revenue climbed 8.5% to 6.82 billion francs. Underlying net income for the quarter, excluding fair-value gains on the company's debt and other special items, was 441 million francs. Return on equity rose to 8.7% from 7%. The cost-saving steps CS began in 2011's second quarter should now generate 1.2 billion francs of savings this year, up from the estimated 1 billion, the company said. Most of the savings will come in the investment-banking division, it said. The moves involve paring 4% of the overall group's staff and will cost 550 million francs instead of the estimated range of 400 million to 450 million francs. And by the end of 2013, Credit Suisse now is targeting another 3% headcount reduction, it said.
