title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp., ABC, +1.29% the Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical-services provider, reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose 4.3% on 3.5% higher revenue. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, profit reached $147.3 million, or 54 cents a share, from $141.2 million, or 50 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Shares outstanding fell 4.4% to 271.4 million. Revenue rose to $20.41 billion from $19.72 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of 56 cents a share of profit on $20.20 billion of revenue. For fiscal 2012, ABC expects to earn $2.74 to $2.84 a share, up from fiscal 2011's $2.54. FactSet's survey is eyeing $2.81. AmerisourceBergen sees revenue for the current year ranging from level with fiscal 2011 to modestly higher. FactSet's survey sees fiscal 2012 revenue up less than 1% to $80.28 billion.
title: AmerisourceBergen net up; sees higher '12 profit

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose 4.3% as the company's drug business continued to drive revenue growth. The U.S. drug wholesaler has reported improved profits in recent quarters on the strong performance of its generic drugs and specialty pharmaceuticals. AmerisourceBergen agreed last month to pay $250 million for CVS Caremark Corp.'s CVS, -0.80% TheraCom LLC unit, which provides support services to the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. AmerisourceBergen may potentially lose its biggest client, Medco Health Solutions Inc. MHS who has agreed to sell itself to Express Scripts Inc. ESRX, -0.93% in a $29.1 billion deal expected to close in the first half of 2012. Its current Medco contract goes through March 31, 2013. Fitch Ratings in August lifted its rating on AmerisourceBergen a notch to A-minus, which is four steps above junk territory, citing the company's consistent cash generation and strong hold on the drug distribution market. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $147.3 million, or 54 cents a share, up from $141.2 million, or 50 cents, a year earlier. Revenue jumped 3.5% to $20.41 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had most recently forecast earnings of 56 cents on revenue of $20.18 billion. Gross margin edged up to 3.03% from 3.01%. Revenue at its drug business rose 6%, while specialty group revenue fell 5%. The company expects full-year earnings $2.74 to $2.84 a share while analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters currently expect $2.81. Shares closed Monday at $40.80 and were inactive premarket. The stock has risen 24% over the past 12 months. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle
title: AmerisourceBergen profit rises 4.3%

content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trading in Tuesday’s session and Exelixis Inc., DirecTV Group Inc. and Leap Wireless International Inc. Companies on deck to report financial results include blue chip Pfizer Inc. PFE, +0.54%  as well as Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. WPI, +0.00% Myriad Genertics Inc. MYGN, -0.40% AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% HCA Holdings Inc. HCA, -0.15% Tenet Healthcare Corp. THC, +1.76% Entergy Corp. ETR, -0.28% FirstEnergy Corp. FE, -1.10%  , Hertz Global Holdings Inc. HTZ, +0.81% Dunkin’ Brands Group Inc. DNKN, -0.20% Archer Daniels Midland Co. ADM, +1.33% Emerson Electric EMR, +1.49% Oshkosh Corp. OSK, +1.35% Baker Hughes Inc. BHI, +4.27% Rowan Cos. RDC, +4.43% Valero Enery Corp. VLO, +2.76% Marathon Oil Corp. MRO, +5.29% Marathon Petroleum Corp. MPC, +1.80% Williams Cos. WMB, +0.32% Williams Partners LP WPZ, -0.03% and TransCanada Corp. TRP, +2.63% among others. Standard & Poor’s said New York-based Signature Bank SBNY, +0.56%  will take the place of Kinetic Concepts Inc. KCI, +5.80%  in the S&P MidCap 400 index, effective after the close of trading on Nov. 4. In addition, Opnet Technologies Inc. OPNT, +0.68%  will replace Signature Bank in the S&P SmallCap 600 index. A deal to take Kinetic Concepts private is close to being completed, S&P said. Exelixis EXEL, -0.94%  said it would drop efforts to secure a special protocol assessment for cabozantinib, its prostate cancer treatment, from the Food and Drug Administration. Such an assessment is a declaration from the FDA that a firm’s design for a clinical trial will be capable of supporting a drug-efficacy claim before the trial begins. Instead, Exelixis said it will pursue a late-stage clinical trial without the FDA providing any guiding comments. The trial will begin by year’s end, the company said. Also late Monday, DirecTV Group DTV, +0.36%  said it reached a new carriage agreement with Fox Networks, owned by News Corp. NWS, +1.90% NWSA, +2.40% which is also the parent of MarketWatch, publisher of this report. El Segundo, Calif.-based DirecTV said as a result of 10 days of “challenging” negotiations, it will continue carrying such cable networks as FX, National Geographic Channel, Nat Geo Wild, Speed, Fuel TV, Fox Soccer, Fox Soccer Plus and Fox Deportes as well as Fox’s regional sports networks, Fox Broadcasting, Fox local stations, Fox News Channel and Fox Business Network. The parties didn’t disclose terms of their carriage agreement. Also on the entertainment front, MGM Resorts International MGM, +2.70%  said it reached an agreement with U.K.-based Bwin.Party Digital Entertainment PLC (BPTY) to launch a business initiative in the event online poker is ever legalized in the U.S. If federal legislation is enacted, Bwin.Party and MGM Resorts would roll out an online platform offering leading technologies and processes to ensure the integrity of the game and the security of player accounts and information. Monday earnings recap Andarko Petroleum Corp. APC, +2.56%  reported a second-quarter net loss of $3.05 billion, or $6.12 a share, wider than the energy company’s year-earlier loss of $26 million, or 5 cents a share. Andarko cited its recent $4 billion settlement with BP PLC BP, +2.37%  to settle claims over the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster in the Gulf of Mexico as the factor behind the sizable loss. Excluding the BP settlement as well as hedging contracts and other items, the company would have posted a profit of $323 million, or 66 cents a share, up from an adjusted profit of $125 million, or 25 cents, a year earlier. Quarterly revenue climbed 25% to $3.2 billion from the prior year’s $2.55 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had, on average, been looking for earnings of 67 cents a share on $3.31 billion in revenue. Anadarko also said total production averaged 660,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day during the latest quarter, up 4.9% from the year-ago period. Leap Wireless LEAP  reported a third-quarter loss of $68.8 million, or 90 cents a share, much narrower than the $533.3 million, or $7.06 a share, it lost in the same period during 2010. The wireless reseller’s quarterly revenue reached $763.3 million from $638.1 million a year earlier, as Leap showed a big improvement in its so-called churn rate — 3.8%, down from 5.5% in the same period a year earlier. Along with reporting results for the second quarter ended Sept. 30, Triumph Group Inc. TGI, -0.59%  raised its full-year profit outlook, now pegged at about $4.50 a share for continuing operations and on an adjusted basis. The Berwyn, Pa.-based supplier of aerospace components and other equipment also affirmed projected revenue in a range of $3.2 billion to $3.5 billion for fiscal 2012. For the second quarter, Triumph Group generated net earnings of $58.5 million, or $1.13 a share, up from $41.5 million, or 83 cents, earned during the same period in fiscal 2011, as sales rose 3% to $790.5 million. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Tuesday: Exelixis, DirecTV, Leap

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) — Third-quarter financial results start to roll in next week, and there are a few things investors can do to help limit their exposure to earnings misses, analysts at RBC Capital Markets said Friday. Knowing what steps to take is particularly important, given that among all of the reporting seasons, the third quarter has “produced the deepest slide on average for companies that miss their earnings expectations” — down more than 4% within 10 days after their announcement, the firm’s analysts wrote in a research note. Are We Headed for a Double-Dip Recession? The latest quarterly reporting season faces extra challenges, with the benefit of a weak dollar “starting to roll off” and the “concentration of solid earnings growers” moving higher, according to RBC. Also, consensus earnings-per-share estimates only have been modestly reduced over the past three months. So look for stocks with modest earnings-growth expectations, low volatility in recent earnings-per-share growth and higher earnings transparency, the analysts said. Based on those factors, RBC provided a list of companies more likely to have a more challenging time in the upcoming reporting season, as well as companies with a higher probability of surpassing quarterly expectations. The analysts pointed out, however, that “both of these lists are intended as a starting point for investors looking into the earnings prospects of S&P 500 SPX, +1.38%  companies; therefore, we suggest investors take a deeper dive into these names before making an investment decision.” The companies with a less favorable outlook heading into earnings, according to RBC Capital, include the following: COMPANY NAME & TICKER EXPECTED REPORTING DATE Schlumberger Ltd. SLB, +2.48%   10/21/2011 Marathon Oil Corp. MRO, +5.29%   11/02/2011 Valero Energy Corp. VLO, +2.76%   11/01/2011 Halliburton Co. HAL, +1.93%   10/17/2011 Baker Hughes Inc. BHI, +4.27%   11/01/2011 Google Inc. GOOG, +2.71%   10/13/2011 Cliffs Natural Resources Inc. CLF, +5.30%   10/28/011 D.R. Horton Inc. DHI, +1.29%   11/11/2011 Western Digital Corp. WDC, +1.62%   10/19/2011 Union Pacific Corp. UNP, +2.81%   10/20/2011 The companies with a favorable outlook heading into earnings, according to RBC Capital, include the following: COMPANY NAME & TICKER EXPECTED REPORTING DATE Stericycle Inc. content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% signed a deal to buy CVS Caremark Corp.'s CVS, -0.80% TheraCom LLC unit for $250 million, expanding the drug wholesaler's consulting services offerings and pharmacy benefit reimbursement capabilities. The acquisition of TheraCom LLC, which provides support services to the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries, is set to close by year's end. TheraCom generates about $700 million in annual revenue and the deal is expected to slightly boost AmerisourceBergen's 2013 earnings. AmerisourceBergen in July reported that its fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 13% as higher sales from its drug business boosted revenue and improved margins. CVS Caremark last month reported second-quarter earnings at the high end of its expectations as the hybrid pharmacy retailer and benefit manager benefited from increased revenue in its drug management business. Shares of AmerisourceBergen and CVS closed Monday at $38.91 and $34.40, respectively. Neither were active in recent premarket trading. content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% board authorized a new $750 million stock-repurchase program, after the U.S. drug wholesaler completed a prior $500 million program that was authorized in September 2010. A number of companies have initiated or approved additional buyback programs as a way to appeal to investors. AmerisourceBergen said to date for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, the company has spent $598 million to repurchase stock. The company, which has about 267 million outstanding shares, said it may repurchase the shares from time to time, subject to market conditions. Last month, AmerisourceBergen reported its fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 13% as higher sales from its drug business boosted revenue and improved margins. Shares were up 1.6% to $35.81 in premarket trading. Through Wednesday's close, the stock is up 3.3% this year, ahead of the broader market. title: AmerisourceBergen OK's new buyback program

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Thursday it plans to buy back up to $750 million of its own stock. "The new share repurchase program and the $598 million repurchase of common stock so far in fiscal 2011 demonstrate our continued commitment to delivering long-term shareholder value," the Valley Forge, Pa., pharmacy services firm said.
title: AmerisourceBergen OK's $750 million stock buyback

content: KALGOORLIE, Australia (MarketWatch) -- A regional executive at gold titan Barrick Gold Ltd. ABX, +0.48% said Tuesday the company is undervalued and would like to see increased investment in gold stocks. Gary Halverson, regional president for the Toronto-headquartered mining company, told reporters on the sidelines of a mining conference in Western Australia that investment in gold exchange traded funds continues to rise but on a fundamental basis he would like to see some of that money invested in stocks. "At the end of the day, we need to have a compelling case," Halverson said. Barrick, the world's largest producer of the precious metal by output, is always looking for acquisitions but doesn't "feel compelled to jump" into a deal, he said. "If something comes along that is the right fit...then we would pursue that," Halverson said. title: Barrick executive says company is undervalued

content: Drug wholesaler AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% will "make every effort" to extend its relationship with its biggest client, pharmacy-benefit manager Medco Health Solutions Inc. MHS as Medco is acquired by one of its competitors, AmerisourceBergen's chief executive said Thursday. The drug wholesaler also anticipates it will be hard to meet its long-term goal of 15% per-share earnings growth in the upcoming fiscal year due to stronger-than-expected fiscal 2011 results that create tough comparisons, Chief Executive Steven Collis said on an earnings call. He said the company, which will release formal guidance in early November, could see 7% to 10% earnings per share growth in fiscal 2012. The current fiscal year runs through September. Chief Financial Officer Michael DiCandilo added that AmerisourceBergen is "by no means" reducing its earnings expectations in dollars. Instead, the company is far outpacing its original fiscal 2011 expectations with help from three specialty generic drugs. That performance will be hard to repeat, in part because AmerisourceBergen exhausted its supply of one drug that won't be available again for about a year. The company's shares recently traded down 2.1% to $38.18. On the Medco front, after Express Scripts Inc. ESRX, -0.93% announced plans last week to buy its pharmacy-benefit manager competitor for $29.1 billion, it raised questions about whether AmerisourceBergen could lose Medco as a customer when their current contract expires after March 2013. Drug wholesalers distribute both brand-name and generic drugs to health-care providers. Pharmacy-benefit managers, or PBMs, help employers and health-insurance companies administer prescription drug benefits, process claims and control costs by securing discounts from drug makers. Medco last year got nearly two-thirds of its drugs from AmerisourceBergen and represents about 18% of AmerisourceBergen's sales. But it only represents about 5% of earnings, Collis told analysts, due to factors like very competitive pricing. He also noted the companies' relationship centers around branded drugs, not generics. "As a combination of the two PBM businesses evolves we will, of course, make every effort to extend our relationship well into the future," Collis said. AmerisourceBergen is not assuming it will lose Medco's business, believes it's done a great job serving Medco and expects "to be considered very strongly" going forward, Collis also said. AmerisourceBergen has "a longstanding and excellent working relationship with Medco" and a "solid contract" that will remain in place through its end date, the executive said. He added he does not believe the contract is subject to early termination as a result of the PBM consolidation. The Valley Forge, Pa., wholesaler reported early Thursday that fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 13%, topping analyst expectations, and it boosted its full-year earnings guidance while backing its revenue outlook. title: Amerisource aims to extend relationship with Medco

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 13% as higher sales from its drug business boosted revenue and improved margins. The company raised its full-year earnings estimate to $2.52 to $2.56 a share from its April forecast of $2.41 to $2.49, and backed its revenue guidance. The U.S. drug wholesaler has reported improved profits in recent quarters on the strong performance of its generics and specialty pharmaceuticals. Last week, Express Scripts Inc. (ESRX) agreed to buy Medco Health Solutions Inc. (MHS) in a $29.1 billion deal expected to close in the first half of 2012. Medco is AmerisourceBergen's biggest client, representing 18% of its revenue in 2010. While the Medco contract goes through March 31, 2013, its potential loss could hurt future earnings. For the quarter ended June 30, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $184.4 million, or 66 cents a share, up from $163.2 million, or 57 cents, a year earlier. The year-earlier quarter included a 5-cent per-share benefit from litigation gains. Revenue rose 2.9% to $20.16 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had most recently forecast earnings of 59 cents on revenue of $20.17 billion. Gross margin rose to 3.24% from 3%. Revenue at its drug business was up 4%, while specialty group revenue dropped 2%. Shares closed Wednesday at $39.01 and were inactive premarket. The stock has risen 35% over the past year. title: Thursday’s biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — One thing seems clear — Wall Street loves the idea of pharmacy-benefit managers Express Scripts Inc. and Medco Health Solutions Inc. joining forces. Investors liked it so much that they not only rewarded Express ESRX, -0.93%  and Medco MHS  in Thursday trading, they also boosted the shares of what will become the companies’ chief rival in the sector, CVS Caremark Corp. CVS, -0.80%   Markets Hub: Markets Up on Euro News, Earnings Medco, which will be bought by Express for $29.1 billion in cash and stock, was up more than 14% at the close, climbing $8.05 a share to $63.83. Express was up 5.4% to $55.36. And CVS joined the party with a 2.4% gain to $37.82. Read more about Express Scripts’s deal to buy Medco. But there are reservations among investors, primarily over possible antitrust concerns. In pharmacy-benefit management, Medco, Express and CVS are the big three public companies and there have been calls recently for CVS to divest some of its holdings. Those concerns might not have been obvious, but they showed up in Medco’s stock price, which soared more than 24% as Thursday trading began but fell as the day wore on. The deal prices Medco shares at $71.36 a share, more than $7 a share higher than what investors were paying. “This timing no doubt takes into account what is likely to be a tough regulatory approval process,” Carol Levenson, analyst at Gimme Credit, said in a note to clients. By the numbers • The 10 best things government has done for us • 4 things Republicans used to believe • The 10 most walkable U.S. cities • 3 cities where you can barely walk anywhere • 2 Greek stocks worth a look (Trading Deck) • Arends's 10 reasons for an enduring crisis • Dow 67,585.69? Modeling inflation (Trading Deck) • 7 billion reasons markets will change direction • 3 U.S. market sectors that bulls must own • 5 ETFs the bears can't touch (Trading Deck) • 5 ways to improve the U.S. retirement system • Reeves's 5 reasons to doubt shopper (TD) • 10 CEOs who think a bit like Steve Jobs • 12 lessons from the life of Steve Jobs • 23 flat-tax countries, Albania to Ukraine (The Tell) • 5 myths surrounding Occupy Wall Street • 6 things no one will tell you about MF Global • Top 10 DJIA dividend payers (InvestorPlace) • One stock a week is all you need (Trading Deck) • Five money moves of a Buffett disciple • 3 portfolio-repair stocks (Investor Place) • 10 cities with the worst credit scores (The Tell) • The 10 poorest U.S. states (blog) • 5 cities where home prices will rise this year • 5 housing markets with best, worst outlooks • The 10 cheapest markets for home buyers • 10 most expensive U.S. cities to buy a home • 10 fees that could decimate your retirement Levenson said that the debt St. Louis-based Express Scripts will incur will be “staggering” and added that the deal was “something of a shocker,” further noting that the 28% premium on Medco’s stock is modest. “At this relatively modest premium and given the considerable stock portion, this deal could be beaten by another all-cash bidder, perhaps one with fewer regulatory hurdles,” Levenson said. The “drag” on Medco’s stock also could be due to a key piece of business that the former unit of Merck & Co. Inc. MRK, -1.13%  is losing. Medco said it will not renew its pact with one of its largest customers, UnitedHealth Group Inc. UNH, -2.06%  , which is likely to do the work that it was contracting Medco to do. Analysts, however, said that was expected. “We believe the stock was already pricing in a high probability of the contract being brought in-house by [UnitedHealth],” David Larsen of Leerink Swann said in a note to clients, “and while we view this as an incremental negative, we believe the bigger story is [the merger], which will overshadow both earnings and the [UnitedHealth] contract loss in our view.” One company that may lose Medco as a client is drug distributor AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  The company’s shares fell 6% to $39.26 as it appeared it would lose Medco, its biggest client, as a result of the merger. Pharmacy-benefit managers like Medco and Express serve as the last conduit in the drug pipeline before medications reach the retail pharmacist. They not only bring medications from drug makers and drug distributors like Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94%  and McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  , they help process claims for the pharmacist. PBMs often exist within larger organizations; Merck and Medco formed a giant union before splitting in 2003. CVS also operates drug stores in addition to serving as a PBM. Walgreen Co. WAG  recently divested its PBM business and now, UnitedHealth appears ready to take on that function. Medco and Express, however, are probably one of the few in the sector that are nearly pure-play PBMs. Express now has 17% of the market while Medco has 14%. CVS has 21% and that has come under fire for anticompetitive practices by consumer groups. In April, five organizations, including Consumers Union and the Consumer Federation of America urged the Federal Trade Commission to investigate the company’s practices, saying the merger has “harmed consumers.” “By reducing choice, raising prices and violating patient privacy, the combination of CVS Caremark poses profound problems for consumers,” the groups said. Some analysts said, however, that the Medco-Express merger actually could bring down prices for consumers. The companies said in their press release announcing the deal that it should save costs by creating efficiency in the supply chain. “The cost and quality of health care is a great concern to all Americans; this is the right deal at the right time for the right reasons,” George Paz, Express’s chairman and chief executive, said in a written statement. “Companies like ours have a responsibility to provide the leadership and resources required to drive out waste in health care and provide the best care in the world.” More from MarketWatch Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Express-Medco shares lifted along with CVS

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Drug wholesaler AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% faces the loss of a key customer as a result of Express Scripts Inc.'s ESRX, -0.93% deal to buy Medco Health Solutions Inc. MHS, +0.00% for $29.1 billion. Medco is AmerisourceBergen's biggest client, representing 18% of the Valley Forge, Pa., company's revenue in 2010. No other customer accounted for more than 5%. While the Medco contract goes through March 31, 2013, its loss could cause a decline of 15 cents a share in AmerisourceBergen's per-share earnings, analysts say. A spokeswoman for AmerisourceBergen did not immediately return a request for comment. AmerisourceBergen shares recently fell 6.1% to $39.19, after declining as much as 11% Thursday. Earlier this month, the company's stock hit an all-time high of $43.47. "Losing 18% of revenue calls earnings into question," said A.J. Rice, equity analyst at Susquehanna Financial Group, though he said the company can probably mitigate losses with cost cuts and share repurchases. Drug wholesalers distribute both brand-name and generic pharmaceuticals to healthcare providers. Medco last year got nearly two-thirds of its drugs from AmerisourceBergen. The planned merger presents a challenge to the three drug wholesalers, which includes Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% and McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% because it shrinks the number of pharmacy-benefit managers in the U.S., likely leading to price concessions from drug wholesalers as contracts are renewed. Cardinal Health, though, could benefit from AmerisourceBergen's possible loss, as it currently has a contract with Express Scripts that is set to expire in mid-2012. Corey Kerr, a Cardinal Health spokeswoman, declined to provide any specifics about the contract value. She also declined to comment on the Express Scripts and Medco deal. If Express Scripts moves the Medco business to Cardinal Health, Raymond James equity analyst John Ransom said in a note, it could potentially lift the drug wholesaler's earnings-per-share 5 cents to 10 cents, assuming that there is additional pricing pressure on the combined contract. But it is not a lock that Cardinal Health would be the winning bidder, even given its relationship with Express Scripts, he said. There also is the potential for Express Scripts to choose multiple distributors. "All distributors would likely be active in bidding for this contract, with AmerisourceBergen's specialty capabilities providing a theoretical competitive edge," Ransom said. Shares of Cardinal Health rose 2.1% to $46.49 in recent trading, while McKesson shares gained 0.2% to $82.47. title: Amerisource faces loss of client if Medco bought

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% fell 5% to $39.78 on Thursday on worries that the company's lucrative contract with Medco Health Solutions mhs could be in jeopardy now that it is being acquired by Express Scripts ESRX, -0.93% Earlier Thursday, Express Scripts announced it was buying prescription-benefits manager Medco for $29.1 billion in cash and stock. Amerisource is Medco's primary supplier of pharmaceutical products for its mail-order business.
title: AmerisourceBergen slides on Medco worries

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- News that Express Scripts ESRX, -0.93% plans to buy rival Medco Health Solutions mhs for $29.1 billion in cash and stock also moved shares of fellow pharmacy-services companies. Shares of drug-distribution giants McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% were off 2%, while AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% shares fell 7% to $38.93. Shares of CVS Caremark Corp. CVS, -0.80% meanwhile, rose 5% to $38.75 while UnitedHealth Group UNH, -2.06% climbed 2%. Medco shares soared 15% to $64.09 as Express Scripts' stock jumped 6% to $55.85.
title: Medco takeover moves pharmacy-services stocks

content: Tengion plunges 20% on clinical trial setback (10:43 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Tengion Inc. TNGN plunged 20% in early trading Friday after it announced a delay in a key clinical trial for its bladder cancer product Neo-Urinary Conduit, or NUC. Tengion said that due to various patient complications, interim results from the trial will not be available until 2012. On Thursday, Tengion reported a narrowed adjusted quarterly loss of 41 cents a share versus $1.04 a share. Analysts at Leerink Swann lowered their rating of the stock to market perform from outperform on Friday, citing concerns about the NUC program and the company's cash position. Agilent shares rise 6% on upbeat earnings (10:12 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Agilent Technologies Inc. A, +0.75% shares rose $3, or more than 6%, to $53.45 Friday following the company's upbeat second-quarter earnings report. Before the market opened, Agilent reported earnings of $200 million, or 56 cents a share, on revenue of $1.68 billion. Excluding one-time items, Agilent would have earned 74 cents a share, while analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters had forecast the company to earn 65 cents a share on $1.6 billion in sales. The maker of electronics testing and measurement equipment also said that for its third quarter it expects to earn between 71 cents and 74 cents a share on sales in a range of $1.64 billion to $1.66 billion. Analysts had forecast Agilent to earn 66 cents a share on $1.59 billion in sales for its third quarter. CA shares fall 10% as earnings miss forecasts (10:02 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CA Inc. CA, +1.25% shares fell as much as 10% Friday after the business-software company reported fiscal fourth-quarter results that fell short of analysts' forecasts. Late Thursday, CA said that for its fourth quarter it earned $188 million, or 37 cents a share, on revenue of $1.13 billion. Excluding one-time items, CA would have earned 48 cents a share, while analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters had forecast the company to earn 50 cents a share. CA also said it plans on selling its Internet security business to venture capital firm Updata Partners. Energy stocks flat after losing week (9:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy stocks traded flat on Friday after piling up losses earlier in the week. The NYSE Arca Oil Index XOI, +2.04% fell less than 0.1% to 1,292. The NYSE Arca Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% rose 0.2% to 667. The Philadelphia Oil Service Index OSX, +2.53% dipped 0.1% to 263. Among energy stocks on the move, Valero Energy Corp. VLO, +2.76% rose 2.3% and Peabody Energy Corp. BTU, +0.05% dropped 1.4%. Crude oil futures traded near $99 a barrel. S&P: Portugal banks facing new core capital needs (9:40 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Standard & Poor's Ratings Services said Friday most Portugal banks will likely need to take "decisive actions" to meet new minimum core capital requirements. The Bank of Portugal said Thursday it had approved a new regulation requiring banks to meet a minimum core Tier 1 capital ratio of 9% after the end of 2011 and 10% from 2012 onwards. The requirements are part of the bailout package for Portugal that was recently announced. "In our opinion, the 2012 target is much more challenging than that of 2011, given that most Portuguese banks have already been implementing measures to exceed the 8% minimum core capital target ratio for year-end 2011 set by the Bank of Portugal on April 7, 2011," said Standard & Poor's credit analyst Alicia Fernandez. Nvidia downgraded by Needham to hold (9:04 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Nvidia Corp. NVDA, +4.63% was downgraded to a hold rating by Needham & Co. on Friday morning after the chip-maker reported better-than-expected results for the first quarter and issued a revenue forecast for the current period that was also above expectations. In a note to clients, Needham analyst Rajvindra Gill said he has concerns about the company's core graphics chip business that are not fully offset by its momentum in tablets and smartphones. "While Nvidia has several interesting new markets, we believe there remains significant risk to the core business," he wrote, adding that the stock is already up about 30% for the year. AmerisourceBergen ups dividend by 15% (8:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Friday it's increasing its quarterly dividend by 15% to 11.5 cents a share from 10 cents a share. Shareholders of record as of May 24 will receive the payment on June 6. Dillard's quarterly profit rises 57% (8:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dillard's Inc. DDS, +0.96% said Friday its net income rose to $76.7 million, or $1.31 a share, from $48.8 million, or 68 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The number of shares outstanding decreased to 58.5 million from 72.3 million. The retailer said sales in the recent quarter was $1.47 billion, compared to $1.45 billion a year ago. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of $56 million, on average, with sales of $1.46 billion. Shares of Dillard's were indicated higher in early trading. LSE profit rises 68% (2:56 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- London Stock Exchange Group PLC(UK:LSE)said Friday that its fiscal-year net profit rose 68% to 151.6 million pounds ($246.9 million) as revenue grew 7.4% to 674.9 million pounds. The group said growth in sales from its data and technology operations more than offset a drop in trading revenue. Lower operating expenses also helped drive growth in the bottom line, it added. The LSE said the pipeline of companies seeking to raise capital on its markets is encouraging and that trading on its derivatives platforms increased in April, while U.K. equities trading fell due to the holidays in the month. ThyssenKrupp profit beats view, sticks to targets (2:55 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- German steelmaker ThyssenKrupp AG(DE:TKA)on Friday reported second-quarter net income rose to €272 million ($387 million), versus €206 million in the year-ago period. Earnings per share was €0.58 versus €0.45. Net sales rose to €12.27 billion against €10.11 billion in the year-ago period. A survey of analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires was foreasting earnings per share of €0.46. Order intake in the second quarter rose to €12.85 billion against €10.73 billion in the year-ago period. ThyssenKrupp said it was sticking to its fiscal 2010/2011 targets. EADS swings to loss on exchange rate fluctuations (2:38 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French aerospace group EADS(FR:EAD)said Friday that it swung to a first-quarter net loss of 12 million euros ($17 million) from a year-earlier profit of 103 million euros, while revenue rose 10% to 9.85 billion euros. The parent of Airbus said the loss was driven by accounting revaluations of dollar and sterling cash assets due to fluctuations in exchange rates. Adjusted earnings before interest and taxes rose to around 230 million euros from around 150 million euros a year earlier. The group said Airbus is considering a further increase in its single-aisle production rate, which is already scheduled to rise to 40 aircraft per month by the first quarter of 2012. Reported Ebit for the quarter jumped to 192 million euros from 83 million euros. Analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires had been expecting Ebit of 88 million euros on revenue of 9.2 billion euros. Credit Agricole profit more than doubles (2:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French bank Credit Agricole SA(FR:ACA)said Friday that its first-quarter net profit jumped to 1 billion euros ($1.42 billion) from 470 million euros as revenue grew 10% to 5.3 billion euros. The group said growth in both French and international retail banking helped drive the top line growth, while a 24% fall in impairment charges to 822 million euros also helped the quarter's performance. Analysts had been expecting a net profit of 1.03 billion euros in the quarter. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Friday it's increasing its quarterly dividend by 15% to 11.5 cents a share from 10 cents a share. Shareholders of record as of May 24 will receive the payment on June 6.
title: AmerisourceBergen ups dividend by 15%

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 18% as the pharmaceutical wholesaler and consulting-service provider reported a bigger-than-expected contribution from its specialty generics business helped boost margins. For the year, the company raised its per-share earnings forecast to $2.41 to $2.49 from its prior view of $2.31 to $2.41 and affirmed its revenue growth estimate. The third-largest U.S. drug wholesaler has reported improved profits in recent quarters on strong performance in its generic pharmaceuticals and specialty distribution and services businesses. For the quarter ended March 31, AmerisourceBergen reported a profit of $214.4 million, or 77 cents a share, up from $181 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier. The latest period included an inventory-related charge of $13.5 million, while the prior year included a $10.7 million charge. Revenue increased 2.4% to $19.76 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently forecast earnings of 69 cents on revenue of $19.95 billion. Gross margin rose to 3.48% from 3.2%. Revenue at its drug business was up 4%, as specialty group revenue dropped 2%. Shares closed Wednesday at $42.03 and were inactive premarket. The stock is up 37% in the past year. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you 2 sexy ways to get paid to save
title: AmerisourceBergen FY 2Q profit rises 18%

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Hewlett-Packard Co.’s shares climbed Monday evening when the technology bellwether said it will lift its quarterly dividend, while Texas Instruments Inc. shares fell after the chip maker said one of its factories in Japan was damaged in the devastating earthquake, and that it expects a related loss in quarterly revenue. H-P shares HPQ, +1.06%  shares rose 0.9% to $41.87 after the company said its board of directors has authorized a 50% increase in its regular quarterly dividend to 12 cents a share, from 8 cents a share. The higher dividend rate will begin after H-P pays its next dividend of 8 cents a share in May, according to the company. It also said the amount of future dividend increases will be determined annually, but that H-P “currently intends for the year-over-year percentage increase to be in the double digits,” subject to the board’s approval. TI TXN, +1.94%  fell 2.1% to $33.85. The company cautioned that it expects revenue losses in the first and second quarters after its manufacturing site in Miho, Japan suffered substantial damage. The company plans to restore production at the plant, about 40 miles northwest of Tokyo, in stages. It expects to return to full production by mid-July with full shipment capability possible in September. PM Report: Japan Death Toll & Nuclear Risks Rise The Miho plant accounts for 10% of Texas Instruments’ output as measured by revenue, according to the company. “TI is moving quickly to shift production to other fabs, and so far has identified alternate manufacturing sites for about 60% of Miho’s wafer production,” the chip maker said. TI’s factory in Aizuwakamatsu, about 150 miles north of Tokyo, was also damaged in the earthquake, but the equipment there has already been restarted and full production is estimated by mid-April, assuming a stable power supply, it added. TI’s third fab in Hiji, about 500 miles south of Tokyo, was not damaged and is currently running at normal capacity. Dole Food Co. released quarterly financial results, and its shares pulled back in low volume during the evening session. Late-traded shares of Dole DOLE  fell 5.7% to $13.50 in scant volume. The shares closed the regular session 3.4% higher. Dole Food said fourth-quarter adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization came in at $21 million, down from adjusted EBITDA of $68 million a year earlier. The company said earnings during the most recent period were hurt by lower fresh-fruit earnings because of higher costs in Latin America, and lower pricing in Asia bananas compared with 2009. JAPAN IN CRISIS | MarketWatch Topic: Disasters   Japan's defense ministry releases video footage of smoking reactors at the crippled Fukushima nuclear power plant.  Power shortages to hit profits Tokyo Electric Power says electricity supply capacity will fall short of demand at least through the summer, and analysts weigh the impact.  NEWS ANALYSIS AND MARKET REACTION • Overseas investors bought Japan stocks • Fukushima No. 3 reactor core leaked: report • Uranium bull unfazed by Japan crisis • • • Japan quake could cost $308 billion: Tokyo • Japan banks may offer loans to Tepco • Disaster raises fear of quake cluster Revenue totaled $1.56 billion, up from $1.53 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected revenue of $1.55 billion. Meanwhile, shares of AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% held steady after the drug distributor said Chief Executive David Yost will retire July 1. The company said Chief Operating Officer Steven Collis will succeed Yost. Before the start of late trading, U.S. stocks dropped as investors grappled with ongoing assessments of the financial impact from last week’s devastating earthquake and tsunami in Japan. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07%   fell 51 points, or 0.4%, 11,993.16, with shares of component General Electric Co. GE, -1.46%  down 2.2%. Read about U.S. stocks dropping as GE, utilities get hit by nuclear doubts. The S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38%  fell 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, +1.64%  gave up 0.5%. More from MarketWatch Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: H-P shares up, TI down in late trading

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said late Monday that Chief Executive David Yost will retire July 1 and the company has named Chief Operating Officer Steven Collis to succeed him.
title: AmerisourceBergen names Steve Collis new CEO

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Shares of AmerisourceBergen Corp. climbed on Friday after the drug distributor reported record revenue for the first quarter as well as earnings that exceeded Wall Street forecasts. Valley Forge, Pa.-based AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29%  said net income was $160.5 million, or 57 cents a share, up from $151.3 million, or 52 cents, for the same period a year ago. Revenue reached $19.89 billion during the three months that ended Dec. 31, up 3% from $19.34 billion for the year-earlier first quarter. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the company would earn 54 cents a share, on average, on sales of $19.86 billion. AM Report: Mixed Jobless Report The company also reaffirmed its full-year forecast of earnings in a range of $2.31 to $2.41 a share. The FactSet-derived consensus stands at $2.38 a share. AmerisourceBergen’s shares added more than 3% at the close to $36.56. Meanwhile, shares of health insurer Aetna Inc. AET, -0.25%  rallied to a 52-week high of $38.10 on an intraday basis as the insurer released a 2011financial forecast that far exceeded estimates. See story on Aetna earnings. Aetna said it expects earnings of $3.70 to $3.80 a share for the year, while the average profit estimate compiled by FactSet had been $3.27 a share. Shares traded up more than 14% from Thursday’s close at one point, and ended the day up 12.5% to $37.42. Elsewhere in health care, shares of Stericycle Inc. SRCL, -0.37%  traded up nearly 6% to $83.63 after the company reported fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of 69 cents a share, up from 55 cents a year ago. Analysts had expected earnings of 64 cents a share. Also higher, shares of Sirona Dental Systems Inc. SIRO  jumped more than 10% to $49.88. The company said adjusted earnings were 96 cents a share for the first quarter ended Dec. 31, while analysts had been looking for earnings of 78 cents a share prior to Friday’s report. And shares of dialysis-center operator DaVita Inc. DVA, -0.09%  climbed by more than 2% $76.56 after the company said it was acquiring DSI Renal Inc. for roughly $690 million. Privately held DSI Renal operates 106 dialysis centers and has revenue of about $360 million a year, DaVita said in a press release. Trading lower, Life Technologies Corp. LIFE, -1.85%  dropped by more than 4% to $52.52 after brokerage CLSA downgraded the biotech-tools company to underperform from buy. More from MarketWatch Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Related Topics Health Care Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: AmerisourceBergen shares up on earnings

content: O'Charley's shares fall after results (1:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- O'Charley's Inc. CHUX shares fell more than 2% Friday after the restaurant company reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $20.6 million, or 97 cents, versus a net loss of $15.2 million, or 72 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue slipped 1.4% to $183.5 million and same-store sales at O'Charley's company-operated restaurants declined by 1.4% in the latest quarter. "The results in the fourth quarter and in fiscal 2010 were disappointing to all," David Head, chief executive of O'Charley's, said in a statement. "During the quarter, we closed a number of underperforming restaurants and also made reductions in our overhead costs. These were extremely difficult decisions that we felt were necessary in order to improve our competitive positioning and as a continuing step on the road to profitable growth." O'Charley's shares fell 2.4% to $6.53 in afternoon action on Friday. Aetna shares jump on 2011 outlook (11:12 AM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- A strong 2011 outlook for health insurer Aetna Inc. AET, -0.25% pushed the company's shares higher by more than 13% at one point Friday after it posted earnings. Aetna said net income was $215.6 million, or 63 cents a share, compared with $165.9 million, or 40 cents a share from the same period a year ago. Sales were $8.54 billion vs. last year's $8.76 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the company to earn 62 cents a share for the quarter. Aetna said 2011 earnings should come in at $3.70 to $3.80 a share. That was well above the FactSet forecast of $3.27 a share. Aetna shares were up more than 8% to $36.03 in recent action. Stericycle shares rise over 5% on upbeat results (10:54 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Stericycle Inc. SRCL, -0.37% climbed Friday morning in the wake of better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings. Late Thursday, the medical waste management company reported that net income rose to $50 million, or 57 cents a share from $44.6 million, or 52 cents a share the same quarter a year ago as revenue rose to $393.5 million from $313.5 million. Income, excluding items, was 69 cents per share, compared with 55 cents a year ago. Analysts, on average, expected a per-share profit of 64 cents, according to FactSet. Shares of Stericycle climbed 5.7%. Quest Software slips following results (10:45 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Quest Software Inc. QSFT slipped more than 6% to $24.95 on Friday morning following the company's fourth-quarter report. License revenues climbed more than 11% for the period, though earnings declined as expenses rose. Aaron Schwartz of MKM Partners wrote in a note to clients that the company's growth outlook was ahead of expectations, "but the year will be somewhat of a transformational year as distribution initiatives and reinvestments will bring downward earnings revisions." Quest provides software to help corporations manage their IT networks. Clorox profit falls, volume drops (8:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Clorox Co. CLX, +2.15% said Friday its second-quarter profit fell to $21 million, or 15 cents a share, from $110 million, or 77 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Clorox booked a $258 million impairment for the impact of goodwill in the latest quarter. In the latest quarter, it reported a loss of $163 million in continuing operations, and a $177 million gain on the sale of its auto businesses. Breaking out the goodwill impairment and other items, Clorox said its adjusted earnings rose to 68 cents a share, from 66 cents a share. Revenue fell to $1.18 billion, from $1.22 billion. Wall Street analysts expected Clorox to earn 46 cents a share, on revenue of $1.19 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Clorox sees 2011 earnings of $3.85 to $4.00 a share, compared to the Wall Street target of $3.99 a share. Clorox said volume declined 2% primarily due to a comparison against high year-ago shipments of Clorox disinfecting wipes and other disinfecting products resulting from the H1N1 flu pandemic last year. GameStop sets new $500 mln stock and debt buyback (8:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- GameStop Corp., GME, -10.81% the Grapevine, Texas, videogame retailer, plans to buy back as much as $500 million of stock and debt in the next 18 months. In a Friday statement, the company said the board's new authorization replaces a $300 million plan put in place in September. Under that earlier authorization, $138.4 million remained available, GameStop said. Tyson Foods profit nearly doubles, beating target (7:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Tyson Foods Inc. TSN, +0.36% said Friday its first-quarter profit rose to $298 million, or 78 cents a share, from $160 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding a one-time gain of 3 cents a share, Tyson earned 75 cents a share, in the latest period. Sales increased to $7.62 billion from $6.64 billion. Wall Street analysts expected Tyson to earn 62 cents a share on revenue of $7.17 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. The Springdale, Ark.-based meat producer said its chicken, beef and pork segments produced operating income in or above their normalized ranges during the quarter. Looking ahead at 2011, Tyson said it expects challenges, but the balance of the year has the "potential to be comparable" to 2010. Operating margin during the fourth quarter rose to 6.9% from 3.2%. Aimco posts higher per-share FFO (7:29 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Apartment Investment and Management Co. AIV, +0.42% on Friday reported a fourth-quarter loss of 33 cents a share, compared with a loss of 6 cents in the fourth quarter of 2009. Funds from operations, a key profitability metric for real estate investment trusts, rose to 31 cents a share from 14 cents. For 2011, Aimco sees FFO in the range of $1.46 to $1.56 a share. PPL Corp. net income more than doubles (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- PPL Corp. PPL, +0.43% said Friday its fourth-quarter profit more than doubled to $355 million, or 73 cents a share, from $153 million, or 40 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations increased to 83 cents a share, from 52 cents a share. Wall Street analysts expected the power producer to earn 58 cents a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. PPL Corp. expects 2011 earnings of $2.40 to $2.60 per share, compared to the Wall Street estimate of $2.63 a share. PPL said about half of its 2011 earnings will come from its regulated businesses, up from a 27% contribution in its ongoing profit in 2010. Simon Property's net income rises (7:25 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Simon Property Group Inc. SPG, -1.00% before Friday's opening bell reported fourth-quarter net income of $217.9 million, or 74 cents a share, up from $91.5 million, or 32 cents a share, in the same quarter of 2009. The Indianapolis-based company said funds from operations was $1.78 a share, compared with $1.40 in the year-ago period. For 2011, the real estate investment trust forecast FFO in the range of $6.45 to $6.60 a share. PulteGroup reports wider quarterly loss (7:17 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- PulteGroup Inc. PHM, +1.41% Friday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $165.4 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with a loss of $116.9 million, or 31 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. The latest quarter included charges totaling $196 million. Consolidated revenue dropped to $1.2 billion from $1.7 billion, the home builder said. AmerisourceBergen net up 6.1%, revenue up 2.9% (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp., ABC, +1.29% the Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical-services provider, reported fiscal first-quarter net income rose 6.1% on 2.9% higher revenue. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, earnings reached $160.5 million, or 57 cents a share, from $151.3 million, or 52 cents, in the year-earlier period. Shares outstanding fell 3.6% to 280.7 million. Revenue climbed to $19.89 billion from $19.34 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of profit of 54 cents a share on revenue of $19.89 billion. For fiscal 2011, AmerisourceBergen expects to earn $2.31 to $2.41 a share. FactSet's survey estimates $2.38. Revenue should grow 2% to 4% from fiscal 2010's $77.95 billion, the company estimated. Aon posts 17% quarterly growth in net profit (6:49 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Aon Corp. AON, +0.62% reported fourth-quarter net income of $231 million, up from $198 million earned in the final three monthys of 2009. Earnings per share came in at 68 cents a share, off from the prior year's 71 cents; there were 20% more weighted average common shares outstanding in the latest quarter. Quarterly profit from continuing operations increased 33%, to 68 cents a share from the prior year's 51 cents, while profit from continuing operations excluding special items would have been 84 cents a share, according to the provider of risk-management, insurance and human-resources services. The consensus estimate among analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had been for Chicago-based Aon to earn a profit of 81 cents a share on an adjusted basis. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 40% to $2.91 billion; Aon closed on the acquisition of Hewitt Associates on Oct. 1. Aetna earns 53 cents, declares 15-cent dividend (6:30 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- U.S. insurer Aetna Inc AET, -0.25% on Friday reported fourth-quarter net income rose to $215.6 million against $165.9 million in the year-ago period. On a per share basis, the company earned 53 cents against 38 cents, whch included 10 cents per share of net realized capital gains. Operating earnings were 63 cents against 40 cents, which Aetna said was largely due to higher commercial underwriting margins and a reduced number of shares outstanding. Revenue slipped to $8.54 billion against $8.76 billion in the year-ago period. A survey of analysts polled by FactSet Research were calling for Aetna to earn 62 cents on revenue of $8.32 billion. The company declared a quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share and Aetna projects full-year 2011 operating earnings per share of $3.70 to $3.80. Weyerhaeuser swings to profit (6:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Weyerhaeuser Co. WY, -0.06% said Friday that it swung to a fourth-quarter net profit of $171 million from a loss of $175 million a year earlier. Earnings per shares in the quarter were 32 cents, compared to a loss of 83 cents a share a year earlier. The number of shares outstanding more than doubled in the intervening period due to the payment of a special dividend. Revenue for the quarter rose 14% to $1.66 billion. Weyerhaeuser said that, excluding one-off gains of $119 million in the latest quarter, it earned 10 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had been expecting earnings of 5 cents a share on sales of $1.55 billion. The forest products company said it has sold 82,000 acres of timberlands in southwestern Washington to the Hancock Timber Resource Group, for around $200 million. The deal will contribute around $150 million to its first-quarter earnings. Europe stocks open higher; LVMH off after results (3:10 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- European stocks opened higher on Friday as markets awaited key U.S. non-farm payroll data later. Shares of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA(FR:MC)fell 2.5% after full-year results, while shares of truckmaker Volvo AB(SE:VOLVB)fell 1.2% after fourth-quarter results. Shares of Wm. Morrison Supermarkets PLC(UK:MRW)rose 2.7% in London after a broker upgrade. Oil stocks were also weaker across the board. The Stoxx Europe 600 index(ST:SXXP)rose 0.4% to 286.06, while the French CAC 40 index(FR:PX1)rose 0.4% to 4,053.12 and the German DAX 30 index(DE:DAX)rose 0.2% to 7,210.46. In London, the FTSE 100 index(UK:UKX)rose 0.2% to 5,995.70. Volvo swings to profit of SEK3.23 billion (2:21 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Swedish truckmaker Volvo AB(SE:VOLVB)on Friday reported that it swung to a fourth-quarter profit of 3.23 billion Swedish kronor ($500 million) against a loss of 1.99 billion kronor in the year-ago period as orders for trucks nearly doubled. The company said net sales rose to 73.4 billion kronor against 59.8 billion in the year-ago period. A survey of analysts by Dow Jones Newswires was forecasting net profit of 3.87 billion kronor on sales of 74.4 billion kronor. Volvo said it ended the year strongly, with Europe continuing to improve, and North America now "definitely recovering," while emerging market growth continued at a strong pace. Japan, though, remains weak, it said. Volvo said net order intake for trucks rose 63% in the fourth quarter against the prior year -- up 123% in North America and 79% in Europe. Chief Executive Officer and President Leif Johansson said he was confident in the group's short and long-term outlook. LVMH profit gains on strong watches, jewelry sales (2:00 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Luxury goods group LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA(FR:MC)on Friday reported profit from continuing operations rose 29% to €4.32 billion ($5.89 billion) against €3.35 billion in the year-ago period. Group share of net profit for the full year 2010 rose 73% to €3.03 billion, against €1.78 billion in 2009. Revenue for the group rose 19% to €20.32 billion against €17.05 billion in the prior-year period. A survey of analysts polled by Dow Jones forecast profit from continuing operations of €4.4 billion on sales of €20.3 billion. Revenue was strongest among watches and jewelry, up 29% on the year-ago period, while fashion and leather goods rose 20% and wines and spirits gained 19%. LVMH said it declared a dividend of €2.10 per share, an increase of 27%. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, earnings reached $160.5 million, or 57 cents a share, from $151.3 million, or 52 cents, in the year-earlier period. Shares outstanding fell 3.6% to 280.7 million. Revenue climbed to $19.89 billion from $19.34 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of profit of 54 cents a share on revenue of $19.89 billion. For fiscal 2011, AmerisourceBergen expects to earn $2.31 to $2.41 a share. FactSet's survey estimates $2.38. Revenue should grow 2% to 4% from fiscal 2010's $77.95 billion, the company estimated.
title: AmerisourceBergen net up 6.1%, revenue up 2.9%

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — A litigation charge took a bite out of McKesson Corp.’s third-quarter earnings, as the pharmaceutical distributor said Monday that profit fell more than half. San Francisco-based McKesson MCK, +0.15%  said net income was $155 million, or 60 cents a share, compared with $326 million, or $1.19 a share, in the year-ago quarter. Sales were $28.25 billion compared with 2009’s $28.27 billion. The company said earnings were affected by a litigation charge, without which it would have reported earnings of $1.12 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had predicted earnings of $1.11 a share. Shares of McKesson ended trading Monday up 1.4% to $75.17. digits: iPad Loses Market Share to Android McKesson said the litigation charge represents an increase to its reserves set aside for possible future complaints against the company over the Average Wholesale Price issue. McKesson and other major drug distributors such as Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94%  and AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  have come under fire in recent years over whether they have properly set the average wholesale price for the products they bring to market from pharmaceutical manufacturers. The three firms collectively control more than 90% of the distribution market. In November 2008, McKesson agreed to pay out $350 million in claims, but other cases remain pending. “As a result of these discussions and the company’s periodic review of these claims, the litigation reserve has been increased by a pre-tax charge of $189 million,” the company said in a press release, adding that the charges are “without merit” and it plans to “vigorously” defend them. McKesson added that it is raising its full-year adjusted earnings projection to a range of $4.82 to $5.02 a share. The projection of analysts polled by FactSet calls for earnings of $4.83 a share when the company’s fiscal year ends in March. The figures exclude litigation reserve charges as well as full-year benefits from its acquisition of U.S. Oncology in December. McKesson said the benefit of U.S. Oncology’s results will show up in its distribution business’s fourth-quarter results. More from MarketWatch 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000
title: McKesson earnings fall on litigation charge

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% on Thursday reiterated its fiscal 2011 financial outlook for a 7% to 12% rise in earnings per share. That growth would put 2011 earnings per share in a range of $2.31 to $2.41. "Also unchanged are our key assumptions supporting the diluted earnings per share range for fiscal year 2011, including: revenue growth of between 2 percent and 4 percent; operating margin growth in the low to mid single-digit basis points range; and free cash flow in the range of $625 million to $700 million, which includes capital expenditures in the $150 million range," the company said in a press release.
title: AmerisourceBergen reiterates FY 2011 outlook

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Shares of Kendle International Inc. jumped as much as 13% Tuesday after the clinical researcher posted per-share earnings that were more than triple what Wall Street expected. After the close Monday, Kendle KNDL  reported third-quarter net income of $1.5 million, or 10 cents a share, compared with $8.8 million, or 59 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales for the Cincinnati-based company were $112.6 million vs. last year’s $133.8 million. Markets Hub: Stocks Wobble, Gold At Highs Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the company to report earnings of 3 cents a share. Shares of Kendle were up $1.11, or 11.7%, to $10.62 in recent dealings. It was one of the few big gainers in an otherwise dreary day for stocks. Coventry Health Care Inc. CV.H, +0.00%  gave back some of its gains over the past two days on better-than-expected earnings and ratings upgrades. Shares of the managed-care provider lost 3.6% to $25.57. Most other managed-care providers were in the red, though Aetna Inc. AET, -0.25%  managed a meager gain to hit $31.38. Drug distributors and pharmacy-benefit managers also were in the red with AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  off 1.3% to $31.05 in recent action. Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94%  was the one gainer, adding 1.9% to $35.87, as the company continues to be the subject of merger speculation. Medical device makers, however, bucked the negative tide and were mostly in the black on Tuesday. St. Jude Medical Inc. STJ, -0.32%  was up 1.2% to $39.31. More from MarketWatch S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Don’t ever do this with your credit card Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics Health Care Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: Kendle shares jump on earnings news

content: Australia's Westpac profit rises 84% (6:01 PM ET) SYDNEY (MarketWatch) -- Westpac Banking Corp.(AU:WBC) WEBNF, -0.22% said Wednesday that its fiscal-year net attributable profit climbed 84% to 6.3 billion Australian dollars ($6.3 billion). The lender said that higher core earnings, a 55% drop in impairment charges and a lower effective tax rate contributed to the result. Net interest income rose 2% to A$11.8 billion compared to the year-ago period, with volume growth offset by a lower net interest margin. Cash earnings rose 26% to A$5.9 billion. "We are well positioned to meet the challenges in an operating environment, which although improving, remains uncertain," said CEO Gail Kelly. Primerica net income drops to $40 million (5:04 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Life insurer Primerica PRI, -0.31% Tuesday posted third-quarter net income of $40 million, or 52 cents a share, down from $124 million in the year-earlier period. The results reflect the consolidation of Germany's Ratiopharm since August. Sales of the company's Copaxone multiple-sclerosis medication rose 4% in the quarter to $808 million, Teva said in a Tuesday statement. Sales of Azilect for Parkinson's disease added 28% to $81 million. Gross-profit margin widened to 58% from 54.3%; adjusted margin reached 62.5% from 58.2%.
