title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Tuesday that its fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose to $141.2 million, or 50 cents a share, compared to $130.1 million, or 44 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Valley Forge, Pa.-based pharmaceutical services company rose to a record $19.7 billion, up 5.3%. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected profit of 48 cents a share on revenue of $19.6 billion. For the full fiscal year, the company posted earnings of $2.22 a share on revenue of $78 billion.
title: AmerisourceBergen profit up

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Shares of Centene Corp. tumbled more than 6% Tuesday after the health insurer reported earnings that fell short of expectations, while shares of Cardinal Health pared gains after the drug distributor dispelled rumors of a takeover. Centene CNC, +6.50%  reported net income of $22.6 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with $21.3 million, or 48 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Revenue was $1.12 billion vs. last year’s $1.04 billion. Markets Hub: Ford Earnings, But Fed's Top News Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the company would post earnings of 47 cents a share on sales of $1.15 billion. A higher medical-loss ratio for the company was reported during the quarter, as costs comprised 84.2% of revenue, compared with the 83.7% reported a year ago. At the close, Centene was off $1.63 to $22.81. It led a widespread selloff of health insurers for the day. The momentum from Centene apparently dragged Amerigroup Corp. AGP  shares down 3.8% to $41.32. WellPoint Inc. WLP  dropped 2.3% to $55.94 after the company’s shares were cut to hold from a buy rating. Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94%  had been up more than 5% on speculation of a possible takeover, but those gains subsided as the company tried to quash those rumors in a press statement released Tuesday. “While it is our longstanding practice not to respond to market rumors and speculation, we are making an exception in this limited situation. Cardinal Health is not in discussions with any party regarding an acquisition of Cardinal Health. We do not expect to have further comment on this matter,” the company said in the statement. Cardinal shares were up 1.8% to $32.98. The company reports earnings on Thursday. Another major drug distributor, McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  went back and forth over the break-even mark and ended marginally higher, adding 23 cents to $61.91. McKesson reported earnings late Tuesday of $327 million, or $1.25 a share, but said that was affected by a one-time gain. McKesson said without the sale of discontinued operations, earnings would have been $1.03 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected earnings of $1.09 a share. And the other major drug distributor, AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29%  , was up on the Cardinal news, but gave back some of its gains and ended the day up 1.3% to $32.43. The company is due to report earnings Nov. 2. More from MarketWatch Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics Health Care Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: Centene shares tumble on earnings miss

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Shares of Immucor Inc. lost more than a fifth of their value at one point Thursday, plunging as the medical lab-equipment maker revised its financial forecast below analyst estimates. Immucor BLUD  said it now expects earnings for fiscal 2011 to come in at $1.08 to $1.18 a share, on sales of $320 million to $332 million. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had called for the company to have earned $1.24 a share by the time its fiscal year ends in May, on sales of $344.9 million. In recent action, Immucor shares traded down more than 18% to $16.64. At their weakest intraday level of $15.01, the shares touched a 52-week low. Immucor made the revised forecast as part of its first-quarter earnings report released after Wednesday’s close. The company said net income for the three months ended Aug. 31 was $21.4 million, or 30 cents a share, up modestly $21.3 million, or 30 cents, earned during the same period a year ago. Sales generated by the Norcross, Ga.-based company totaled $83.6 million compared with last year’s $83.1 million. The FactSet-derived consensus estimates for the quarter called for earnings of 30 cents a share on sales of $85.1 million. In a conference call with analysts Thursday morning, Chief Executive Gioacchino De Chirico said the company expects a 3% to 4% drop in industry volume. Immucor sells systems used to screen and process blood prior to transfusion. Market data indicate there will be lower blood demand than expected, De Chirico said. “While our fiscal 2010 financial performance was in line with expectations, there was a decline in the overall industry volume that was not evident in our numbers,” De Chirico said, according to transcripts of the call. “In fiscal 2010, we did not see the economic impact in our financial performance, primarily because of the substantial price contribution we had in 2010, the large number of instruments that went live and the delay in our customers adjusting their orders.” Also among health-care stocks, insurers made up for a lackluster showing on Wednesday. Cigna Inc. CI, -0.34%  , HealthNet Inc. HNT, +0.00%  and Coventry HealthCare Inc. CV.H, +0.00%  led the way, with shares of all three up more than 2% in recent transactions. Major drug distributors also were in the black, with AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29%  in the strongest position, up 1.8% to $31.90. C, -1.11% More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics Health Care Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: Immucor loses 20% on revised forecast

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — Shares of LifePoint Hospitals Inc. tumbled Thursday, a day after its stock soared nearly 11%, as talk of a possible leveraged buyout subsided. LifePoint LPNT, -1.67%  fell nearly 5% to $34.90 at the close. Early Thursday, LifePoint announced that it planned to buy back $150 million in shares, as part of a previously announced repurchase program. In a news release, LifePoint said it already has repurchased $45 million in common stock, and that its program would continue through February 2011. LifePoint did not discuss whether its repurchase was in preparation for a buyout, and at least one analyst said it doesn’t appear that is the case. FedEx Delivers Disappointment “While [LifePoint] has periodically been the subject of such speculation, there is no indication that the new buyback announcement was made in response to an approach from an outside party,” Susquehanna Financial Group analyst A.J. Rice said in a note to clients. Amid a broader market selloff, shares of most health-care stocks were down Thursday. Drug distributors McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94%  all gave back some of their gains, with Cardinal losing the most ground, down 1.3% to $32.56. And health insurers were marginally in the red, with Coventry Health Care Inc. CV.H, +0.00%  dipping the most, down 2.6% to $21.07. More from MarketWatch What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics Health Care Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: LifePoint tumbles after buyout talk subsides

content: Corrects story to show that Blue Valley Ban Corp paid its first TARP dividend SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- The number of banks missing payments on the bailout money they got from the U.S. government has jumped and the Treasury Department is starting to get tough. Saigon National Bank may be among the first lenders to be affected, as the Treasury flexes its muscles. In August, 123 financial institutions missed dividend payments on securities they sold to the Treasury Department under the Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP. That’s up from 55 in November 2009, according to Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Of the 123, seven institutions have had a particularly tough time making TARP dividend payments. These are Anchor Bancorp Wisconsin ABC, +1.29%  , Blue Valley Ban Corp BVBC, -12.87%  , Seacoast Banking Corp. SBCF, -0.23%  , Lone Star Bank, OneUnited Bank, Saigon National Bank SAGN  and United American Bank UABK, -1.46%  , according to KBW. Saigon National is the only institution to have missed seven consecutive quarterly TARP dividend payments. The other six have missed six consecutive payments, KBW noted. Blue Valley paid its first TARP dividend in February 2009, but then missed the next six. The government used TARP to support the U.S. financial system at the height of the mortgage-fueled crisis in 2008, funneling billions of dollars into the country’s largest banks, including Bank of America BAC, +2.04%  , Citigroup C, -1.11%  , Wells Fargo WFC, +1.81%  , J.P. Morgan Chase JPM, +1.82%   Most of the big banks have repaid the TARP money they got and the Treasury has collected about $10 billion in dividend payments from the effort. However, the rising number of smaller banks that are struggling to meet dividend payments shows the program hasn’t been a complete success. Skipping six straight TARP dividend payments is an important threshold because Treasury gets the right to appoint two directors to the offending banks’ boards when that happens. Now Treasury is starting to exert this right. “We are exploring a number of options on how to properly exercise our contractual rights so to best protect the interests of taxpayers,” Treasury spokesman Mark Paustenbach wrote in an email to MarketWatch. “Once a director has been appointed, that information will be made public.” Treasury is focusing on banks where it invested more than $25 million. At first, it may send observers to board meetings to see whether new directors can help. Trade the FTSE 100 Reshuffle, Says HSBC At Saigon National Bank, which serves the Vietnamese business community in Southern California, this process has already begun. “They’ve asked for approval to appoint two observers to attend our board meetings," Roy Painter, chief financial officer of Saigon National, said in an interview. The observers haven’t turned up at any board meetings yet and Treasury hasn’t discussed any further details, including who the observers are, how they were picked and when they will start, Painter added. Painter also noted that Saigon National has been raising capital over the past year. He declined to comment further. If Treasury decides to appoint two directors to a bank’s board, it will hire an executive-search firm to track down the best candidates, according to a list of frequently asked questions that Paustenbach emailed to MarketWatch. These directors won’t be government employees. Compensation and expenses related to these new board members will be paid by the bank involved, according to the FAQ. Government-appointed directors won’t represent Treasury either. Instead, they will have the same fiduciary duties and obligations to shareholders of the bank that the other directors have, the FAQ said. The new directors also won’t be able to force banks to pay TARP dividends. “The board of directors, using its best business judgement, decides when and how to deploy the institution’s capital, including whether to make dividend (or interest) payments,” Treasury said in the FAQ document. Treasury has discussed its options with Anchor Bancorp Wisconsin, according to Chris Bauer, chief executive of the bank. “We’ve had dialog with them. They are in the process of determining what approach they will take. Nothing’s finalized yet,” he said in an interview. “We are ready to work with them and do the right thing -- they made a significant investment in the company,” Bauer added. “Our next board meeting is in October. They have to make a decision before that.” Still, Bauer warned that having government-appointed directors on the boards of TARP banks could create problems. If the Treasury’s investment in a bank is being analyzed by the board, there may be a conflict of interest if government-appointed directors are involved in the discussions, he explained. Such problems wouldn’t be as big if the government just sent observers to monitor board meetings, he added. “As a board member, you have legal and fiduciary responsibilities to shareholders,” Bauer said. “You could get into situations that are fairly complex.” More from MarketWatch My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition
title: Treasury getting tough on TARP deadbeats

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) — A series of notes indicating that conditions may be improving for U.S. “Big Three” pharmaceutical distributors led to sharp gains Wednesday. McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15%  , AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29%  and Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94%  saw their shares climb, with McKesson’s 5.4% rise to $62.98 leading the way. AmerisourceBergen tacked on more than 4% to $30.25 while Cardinal Health was up nearly 4% to $32.98 at the close. News Hub: Midnight Runners of Central Park Analysts had been noting that the three companies, which control more than 90% of the drug distribution network in the U.S., had been undervalued. But a report from Lazard Capital Markets analyst Tom Gallucci released Wednesday noted that recent data showed pharmaceutical sales took a turn higher in August. Gallucci quotes IMS Health, which noted that pharma sales were up 1.9% year-over-year, nearly double the rate of the second quarter’s average. He says new prescriptions were up 6.6% on an unadjusted basis. Gallucci said flu-vaccine sales will face difficult comparisons year-over-year, but noted that pharmaceutical distributors should confront less earnings pressure as their earnings are weighted toward generic medicines. MARKETS | • The Tell: Market news and analysis • | Canada section • Columns: Stocks | Oil | Gold | Bonds | Dollar  TOOLS AND DATA | • My Portfolio: Know where your funds are? • Real-time currency exchange rates • After-hours stock screener In an interview, Gallucci said it wasn’t just the IMS report that prompted the movement in stock prices. Sentiment had been declining throughout the health-care sector and may be on the rise, as price-to-earnings ratios for some had been as low as 10. “We’ve had horrible sentiment toward health care for a while,” Gallucci said. “We sort of said for the last several months that sentiment was worse than the fundamentals.” The analyst maintained his “buy” rating on McKesson and AmerisourceBergen shares, and a “hold” on Cardinal. He also noted that elsewhere in health care, most other sectors were up. Hospital shares rose with Lifepoint Hospitals Inc. LPNT, -1.67%  leading the way by leaping more than 10% to $36.69. A massive sale of options figured prominently Lifepoint’s move, according to a report from Dow Jones Newswires, but analysts were puzzled over the gain. Medical-device makers also rose, with Boston Scientific Corp.’s BSX, +2.40%  1.5% move to $5.41 leading the way. Insurers weren’t participating in the rally for the most part. WellPoint Inc. WLP  was the worst performer, losing 1.5% to $54.64 at the close. More from MarketWatch Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Related Topics Health Care Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: ‘Big Three’ pharma distributors post sharp gains

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- A series of events culminated in sharp share movements for the "Big Three" in pharmaceutical distribution Wednesday as McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% and Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% all made significant moves higher. McKesson made the sharpest rise, climbing 6% to $63.31 in recent action, while AmerisourceBergen rose nearly 5% and Cardinal was up 3%. Several analysts noted that values of all three companies were well below normal price-to-earnings ratios, as well as data that showed pharmaceutical sales growth of 1.9% for the month of August, more than double that of the entire second quarter.
title: Bulls multiply for pharma dealers; shares up

content: Aetna posts profit rise, lifts outlook (11:05 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Aetna Inc. AET, -0.25% said late Tuesday its second-quarter profit totaled $491 million, or $1.14 a share, from $347 million, or 77 cents a share, in the same quarter a year before. Analysts had expected earnings on average of 73 cents a share on sales of $8.4 billion, according to a FactSet Research survey. Total revenue for the quarter was $8.55 billion, slipping from $8.67 billion in the year-ago period. "We expect the remainder of 2010 will reflect the impact of business investments for future profitable growth, as well as the need to prepare for health care reform and regulatory changes," said Chief Financial Officer Joseph Zubretsky, who added that the insurer was raising its expected full-year operating results to a range of $3.05 to $3.15 a share. The forecast previously called for $2.75 to $2.85 a share. Cephalon second-quarter profit rises to $89 mln (5:02 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cephalon Inc. CEPH said late Tuesday that its second-quarter profit increased to $89.1 million, or $1.11 a share, from $84.8 million or $1.11 a share in the year-ago period. Excluding one-time items, the biotech company would have reported earnings of $2.05 a share. Revenue rose to $726 million from $548 million a year ago. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated a quarterly profit of $1.75 a share on revenue of $695.4 million. The company expects total sales will be between $2.6 billion and $2.7 billion for 2010, compared with an analyst consensus estimate of $2.73 billion. International Game profit up on tax benefit (4:34 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch)-- International Game Technology posted an increase in fiscal third quarter profit, boosted largely by a tax benefit and some international growth even as its domestic operations slumped, the slot machine maker said Tuesday. IGT IGT, +0.94% earned $92.1 million, or 31 cents a share on the period, up from $60.6 million, or 20 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. But, excluding items, the company would have earned 21 cents a share, down from 23 cents. Revenue slipped to $490 million from $517 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by FactSet Research had been for the company to earn 21 cents a share on revenue of $509 million. Shares were flat in after-hours action. Aflac quarterly profit jumps 85% (4:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Aflac Inc. AFL, +0.48% said late Tuesday that second-quarter net income came in at $581 million, or $1.23 a share, up 85% from a year earlier when the insurer made $314 million, or 67 cents a share. Operating earnings, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses and other items, were $639 million, or $1.35 a share, in the latest quarter. Aflac was expected to make $1.33 a share, according to the average estimate of 19 analysts in a FactSet Research survey. Aflac shares slipped less than 1% to $50.30 in after-hours trading Tuesday. Ace quarterly profit climbs 25% (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Ace Ltd. ACE, +3.23% said late Tuesday that second-quarter net income came in at $677 million, or $1.98 a share, up 25% from a year earlier when the insurance and reinsurance company made $535 million, or $1.58 a share. Excluding net realized investment gains and losses, Ace said it made $688 million, or $2.01 a share, in the latest period. Ace was expected to make $1.84 a share, according to the average estimate of 20 analysts in a FactSet survey. Ace nudged up a profit forecast from January. The insurer expects full-year operating profit of $6.25 a share to $6.75 a share, but results may be at the top end of that range, it said. "Slow economic recovery in the major developed economies of the United States, Europe and Japan and competitive global insurance markets impacted total premium growth, and I expect these conditions will be with us for some time," Ace Chief Executive Evan Greenberg said in a statement. "However, we continue to identify and realize opportunities for profitable growth as a result of our on-the-ground local presence globally and a broad specialty-oriented product capability." DreamWorks Animation profit slips on higher costs (4:12 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- DreamWorks Animation SKG DWA said Tuesday its second-quarter profit declined 6% as expenses increased. The maker of animated films also announced that its board of directors has authorized a new $150 million stock buyback program. DreamWorks Animation said it earned $24 million, or 27 cents a share in the latest three months, compared with a profit of $25.6 million, or 30 cents a share, in the same period last year. DreamWorks Animation said revenue rose to $158.1 million from $132 million, with the increase driven by the theatrical successes of "Shrek Forever After" and "How To Train Your Dragon." Cost of revenue climbed to $98.7 million from $74 million. Leaky BP well shut in as kill plans continue (2:41 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- BP PLC's [S: bp] containment system continues to keep its leaky Macondo well shut in, as preparations continue to kill the well in coming days, U.S. officials said Tuesday. National Incident Commander Thad Allen said pressure inside the well continues to rise slowly and that the well cap appears to be stable. Meanwhile, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is preparing a report on how much oil remains in the Gulf of Mexico. Much of the oil is evaporating or biodegrading in the water, but about 600 miles of coastline have been affected. Zoran shares down; firm sees 3rd-quarter loss (2:13 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Zoran Corp. ZRAN shares fell 7.7% in Tuesday trades. The Sunnyvale, Calif., producer of chips for technology applications like TVs, digital cameras and mobile phones narrowed its second-quarter loss to 13 cents a share from 27 cents a year earlier. Revenue fell 9.1% to $93.4 million. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of a loss of 7 cents on revenue of $92.2 million. The results were mixed, "with digital cameras once again outperforming expectations, while [digital TV] continued to face challenges," President and Chief Executive Levy Gerzberg said. The company said it's gaining market share in digital cameras, printer imaging is "recovering," and it is starting to ship a highly integrated Blu-Ray solution. Zoran expects a third-quarter loss of 9 cents to 11 cents a share, or an adjusted 3 cents to 6 cents. Revenue should come in at $98 million to $103 million. FactSet's survey is looking for a loss of 2 cents on $101.3 million of revenue. Volterra off; adjusted net beats, revenue in line (1:52 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Volterra Semiconductor VLTR shares fell 14% in Tuesday trades. The maker of low-voltage power-supply chips reported second-quarter net income jumped to 34 cents a share from 4 cents in the year-earlier period. On an adjusted basis, excluding stock-based compensation, earnings quadrupled to 40 cents a share. Revenue moved up 77% to $40.2 million. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research had produced consensus estimates of 37 cents of profit on $40.1 million of revenue. Thermo Fisher Scientific shares slump 9% (1:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. TMO, +0.26% slid 9% after the lab equipment company earlier Tuesday lowered its revenue guidance to a range of $10.60 billion to $10.75 billion for the rest of the year, compared with an earlier range of $10.65 billion to $10.80 billion, citing currency fluctuations. Thermo Fisher also reported its second-quarter net income rose to $237 million, or 57 cents a share, from $207 million, or 49 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding one-time items, adjusted earnings came in at 84 cents a share, in line with the consensus forecast from analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Revenue climbed 7% to $2.65 billion. Energizer shares up 9.3% after earnings report (1:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Energizer Holdings Inc. ENR, +12.35% jumped 9.3% after the battery and personal care products company earlier Tuesday reported third-quarter net income surged to $104 million, or $1.47 a share, from $72.7 million, or $1.13 a share, in the same quarter last year. Sales also rose to $1.08 billion from $997.5 million a year ago. Idenix falls on financial forecast (11:52 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Idenix Pharmaceuticals IDIX shares fell Tuesday after the biotech group said it had sufficient funds and royalties to only fund operations until mid-2011. Shares of Idenix were down 12% at $5.28. The Cambridge, Mass.-based company said as of the end of the second quarter it had $51 million in cash and cash equivalents. The company also expects continued royalties on sales of its drug Tyzeka. Idenix reported a narrowed quarterly loss of 23 cents a share versus 28 cents, but revenue fell to $1.3 million from $2.4 million. BP to take $10 billion tax credit from spill (10:46 AM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- As part of its second-quarter earnings report, oil giant BP PLC said Tuesday that it will reduce its contributions to U.S. tax coffers by $9.9 billion, due in large part to the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. BP indicated in its report that it is taking a $32.2 billion charge against earnings for the Gulf response efforts, which allows them to take the tax credit. "We have followed the IRS regulations as they're currently written," outgoing BP Chief Executive Tony Hayward said in a conference call. Lexmark gains highlight tech sector's advance (9:37 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Gains from printing and imaging company Lexmark International Inc. LXK highlighted trading in tech stocks Tuesday, as the company shares climbed $3.79, or more that 11%, to $38.74. Before the market opened, Lexmark reported a second-quarter profit of $85.1 million, or $1.07 a share, on $1.03 billion in revenue. Other gains came from Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% and Dell Inc. DELL The Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ rose 9 points to 2,305. Legg Mason down 3.5% after earnings (9:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Legg Mason Inc. LM, +2.44% fell about 3.5% in Tuesday's premarket after the asset manager reported a 4% fall in second-quarter profit. The Baltimore firm also said late Monday assets under management fell 6% to $645.4 billion at June 30, driven in part by net outflows of $23.1 billion, $8.7 billion of which was long-term assets. "In our view, the company's turnaround continues to proceed at a slower pace than many investors had expected, resulting in growing investor fatigue, driven primarily by continued outflows and declining assets under management," wrote analysts at FBR Capital Markets in a note. Yahoo adjusts page views after error (9:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Yahoo Inc. YHOO on Tuesday said ComScore SCOR, -1.07% the audience measurement firm it uses, said it made an error in June calculations. Based on the corrected numbers, on a month-over-month basis, Yahoo!'s U.S. page views were down 4.7% versus the reported 7.4% and U.S. duration was down 4.3% versus the reported 6.4%. ComScore is in the process of reviewing the aggregate European Union and Worldwide data to be reported, which could be impacted as well, Yahoo said. "Yahoo believes the factors that led to the error have been corrected and continues to have confidence in comScore data," the Sunnyvale, Calif. company said. AK Steel swings to profit as sales double (8:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - AK Steel, AKS, +5.84% the West Chester, Ohio, steelmaker, swung to a second-quarter profit from a year-earlier loss as sales doubled. The company earned $26.7 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with a loss of $47.2 million, or 43 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales reached $1.6 billion from $793.6 million. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 10 cents a share of profit on $1.52 billion of sales. Shipments nearly doubled to 1.45 million tons. The average selling price per ton in the quarter moved up 2.7% to $1,101 from $1,072. Third-quarter shipments should rise 3%, while selling prices fall 5%, from the second quarter, AK Steel estimated. Office Depot reports narrower second-quarter loss (8:33 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Office Depot Inc. ODP, +0.94% said Tuesday its second-quarter net loss narrowed to $18.7 million, or 7 cents a share, from a loss of $82.6 million, or 31 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales fell to $2.7 billion, from $2.8 billion. Wall Street analysts expected a loss of 17 cents a share, and revenue of $2.75 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Invesco profit drops, adjusted net up (8:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Asset manager Invesco Ltd. IVZ, +1.68% said Tuesday that its second-quarter profit fell to $40.8 million, or 9 cents a share, from $75.7 million, or 18 cents a share, in the year ago period. Revenue was $787 million. On an adjusted basis, which excludes almost $80 million in charges associated with the acquisition of Morgan Stanley's MS, +1.98% retail asset management business, profit rose to $125.4 million, or 27 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected, on average, profit of 27 cents a share on revenue of $774 million. Assets under management on June 30 were $557.7 billion, an increase of $100 billion. The acquired business added $114.6 billion of assets during the quarter. The Atlanta-based firm said it saw long-term net inflows of $13.9 billion during the quarter. Level 3 Communications loss widens (8:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Level 3 Communications Inc. LVLT on Tuesday said its second-quarter loss widened to $169 million, or 10 cents a share, from a loss of $134 million, or 8 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Breaking out 3 cents a share for debt payments, the company lost 7 cents a share. Revenue dipped to $908 million, from $942 million. Wall Street analysts expected the company to lose 12 cents a share, on revenue of $909 million, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Looking ahead, Level 3 said it continues to expect core network services revenue to grow sequentially for the rest of the year. In the third quarter, expenses will grow as a result of "typical seasonal increase in utility costs," the company said. Paccar triples second-quarter profit (8:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Paccar Inc. PCAR, +2.59% said Tuesday its second-quarter profit tripled to $99.6 million, or 27 cents a share, from $26.5 million, or 7 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales climbed to $2.22 billion from $1.6 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were expecting a profit of 19 cents a share on sales of $2.06 billion. "Paccar's results reflect the benefits of higher truck and parts sales and improving financial services profits worldwide," said Mark Pigott, chairman and chief executive. "Our customers are benefiting from increased freight tonnage, which has resulted in higher fleet utilization rates, resulting in positive gains for our aftermarket parts sales." Shares of Bellevue, Wash.-based Paccar closed Monday at $47, up 1.8%. Valero Energy swings to a profit of $1.03 a share (7:57 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Valero Energy Corp. VLO, +2.76% said Tuesday it swung to a second-quarter profit of $583 million, or $1.03 a share, from a loss of $254 million, or 48 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The San Antonio, Texas-based refining giant said its operating income rose to 93 cents a share, from a loss of 36 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue increased to $21.77 billion, from $17.38 billion. Wall Street analysts expected Valero to earn 65 cents a share, on revenue of $21.55 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Looking ahead, Valero said third-quarter product margins and feedstock discounts "have continued at relatively good levels, although down from the second quarter in most of our regions." Valero said it's "cautiously optimistic that global economic expansion will drive growth in refined-products demand." U.S. Steel narrows its second-quarter loss (7:57 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- U.S. Steel Corp. X, +4.92% said Tuesday its second-quarter loss narrowed to $25 million, or 17 cents a share, from a loss of $392 million, or $2.92 a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose to $4.68 billion from $2.13 billion. For the third quarter, the Pittsburgh steel maker forecast a profit as the U.S. and European economies work through a gradual and uneven recovery process. Shares of U.S. Steel feel about 5% in premarket trading to $46.60. Occidental net income climbs by 56%, production up (7:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Occidental Petroleum Corp. OXY, +2.87% said Tuesday its second-quarter net income rose to $1.1 billion, or $1.31 a share, from $682 million, or 84 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Occidental's revenue rose to $4.76 billion, from $3.69 billion. Daily oil and gas sales volumes rose to 747,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day, compared with 719,000 barrels of oil equivalent, in the year-ago period. Wall Street analysts expected Occidental Petroleum to earn $1.36 a share on sales of $4.95 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Lockheed quarterly net earnings up 12.4% (7:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Lockheed Martin Corp. LMT, +0.78% said Tuesday its second-quarter profit rose to $825 million, or $2.22 a share, from $734 million, or $1.88 a share, in they year-ago period. Sales rose 3% to $11.44 billion from $11.07 billion. The Bethesda, Md., military contractor announced last month plans to divest and realign some of its IT businesses. Excluding discontinued operations and a hefty tax benefit, earnings were $727 million, or $1.96 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a profit of $1.79 a share, on average. For the full year, Lockheed Martin raised its guidance by 15 cents to a range of $7.15 to $7.35 a share, primarily because of stock buybacks. Cummins Inc. profit more than quadruples (7:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cummins Inc. CMI, +1.52% said Tuesday its second-quarter net income rose to $246 million, or $1.25 a share, from $56 million, or 28 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose 32% to $3.21 billion. Wall Street analysts expected the engine maker to earn 91 cents a share, on revenue of $2.8 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Cummins cited manufacturing productivity improvements and performance in international markets. The company said it now expects to earn 12% earnings before interest and taxes on $13 billion in sales in 2010. Analysts expected $12.2 billion in 2010 sales. Amerisource Bergen posts higher profit, lifts view (7:33 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Amerisource Bergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Tuesday that its fiscal third-quarter earnings rose to $163.2 million, or 57 cents a share, from $118.8 million, or 40 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. On an adjusted basis, the Valley Forge, Pa.-based pharmaceutical-services company would have earned 52 cents a share in the latest period. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for 49 cents a share. Revenue rose to $19.6 billion from $18.4 billion. Amerisource Bergen also raised its full-year profit forecast to a range of $2.16 to $2.20 a share and boosted its revenue-growth assumption to a range of 8% to 9%. Analysts were expecting $2.11 a share, according to FactSet. Nasdaq OMX net up 40%; buyback funds doubled (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Nasdaq OMX Group Inc., NDAQ, +3.27% the New York securities-exchange operator, reported second-quarter net income rose 40% and allocated an additional $100 million to its stock-buyback program. Profit was $96 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $69 million, or 33 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Adjusted earnings per share were 52 cents against 47 cents. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of 49 cents a share. Driving the results were higher revenue from transactions, "growing demand for co-location and listed-company corporate services," and more listed companies stemming from "continued strength of the IPO market," Chief Executive Bob Greifeld said in a Tuesday statement. With the additional allocation, Nasdaq now has $200 million available for buybacks. L-3 Communications net income rises by $3 million (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- L-3 Communications Inc. LLL, +2.65% said Tuesday its second-quarter net income rose by 1.3% to $228 million, or $1.95 a share, from $225 million, or $1.90 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income totaled $2.04 a share, in the latest quarter. The New York-based surveillance system military contractor said its sales rose to $4 billion, from $3.9 billion. Wall Street analysts expected L-3 to earn $1.93 a share, on revenue of $4 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Looking ahead, L-3 Communications lowered its 2010 profit outlook to $8.05 a share to $ 8.25 a share, from its earlier view of $8.13 a share to $8.33 a share, because of one-time charges such as debt retirement costs. CIT profit up 46%, debt reduced (6:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- CIT Group Inc. CIT, -0.06% said Tuesday that its second-quarter net profit rose 46% to $142.1 million, or 71 cents a share, from $97.3 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier. Total interest income for the period fell 5.3% to $993.5 million, but the decline was more than offset by a 36% rise in other income to $750.3 million. The provider of financing to small businesses said gains on the sale of assets helped offset a higher provision for credit losses in the quarter and added that it had paid down $3 billion of debt as total assets declined by $3.1 billion to $54.9 billion. Corn Products swings to $37 million profit (6:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Corn Products International CPO, +0.00% on Tuesday reported a second-quarter profit of $37 million, or 48 cents a share, compared to a net loss of $85 million, or $1.13 a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding costs tied to the acquisition of National Starch and other charges, second-quarter earnings were 75 cents a share. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a mean forecast of 60 cents. The Westchester, Ill.-based company said net sales rose 10% to $1 billion, boosted by higher volumes and stronger foreign currencies. The company boosted its full-year 2010 adjusted earnings outlook to a range of $2.55 to $2.75 a share, up from a previous forecast range of $2.25 to $2.60. The revised outlook would put second-half 2010 earnings in a range of $1.17 to $1.37 a share. Thermo Fisher cuts sales view; Q2 earnings rise (6:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. TMO, +0.26% on Tuesday reported second-quarter net income of $237 million, or 57 cents a share, compared to $207 million, or 49 cents a share, earned in the year-earlier period. Excluding one-time items, adjusted earnings came in at 84 cents a share. The consensus forecast was for earnings of 84 cents a share, according to a poll of 13 analysts conducted by FactSet Research. Revenue climbed 7% to $2.65 billion. Looking to the rest of the year, the company reiterated its guidance for adjusted earnings per share in the range of $3.40 to $3.50. But it lowered its revenue guidance to between $10.60 billion and $10.75 billion from an earlier range of $10.65 billion to $10.80 billion, citing currency fluctuations. Teva Pharmaceutical profit up 53% (5:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Teva Pharmaceutical Industries TEVA, +0.29% the Jerusalem drug maker, said Tuesday that its second-quarter net profit rose 53% to $797 million, or 88 cents a share, from $521 million, or 58 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue in the latest quarter rose 12% to $3.8 billion. Adjusted earnings in the latest quarter were $1.08 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had been expecting adjusted earnings of $1.04 a share on sales of $3.82 billion. The company said its performance was particularly strong in North America, where it had nine new product launches during the quarter. Norsk Hydro profit more than doubles (2:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Aluminum producer Norsk Hydro(NO:NHY)said Tuesday that its second-quarter net profit more than doubled to 503 million Norwegian kroner ($81.6 million) from 211 million kroner a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 12% to 19.78 billion kroner. The group said underlying earnings before interest and tax were 1.11 billion kroner, compared to a loss of 618 million kroner a year earlier. Analysts had been expecting underlying EBIT of 914.2 million kroner. The group said the results were attributable to a mixture of higher volumes, firm margins and tight cost controls. The group said global demand strengthened in the second quarter and that it continues to expect demand in its main upstream and downstream markets to grow around 12% in 2010. KPN sticks to targets as profit rises 25% (2:24 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Dutch telecoms group KPN(NL:KPN)said Tuesday that its second-quarter net profit rose 25% to 464 million euros ($603 million) as revenue and other income for the period slipped 1.7% to 3.35 billion euros. Profit was ahead of the consensus forecast of 449 million euros, while revenue was broadly in line with the 3.36 billion euro consensus. The firm said revenue fell in its Dutch telecoms business, in part due to regulation, which was partly offset by an increase in revenue at its international mobile business. The group stuck to its earnings and revenue targets for the year and said it will pay an interim dividend of 0.27 euros a share as the first step towards its targeted dividend for the year of 0.80 euros. BP swings to Q2 net loss of $17.2 billion (2:23 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- Embattled U.K. oil giant BP Plc BP, +2.37% (UK:BP)on Tuesday reported a $17.2 billion loss in the second quarter, as it booked $32.2 billion in charges linked to its response to the catastrophic Gulf of Mexico oil spill. In the same period a year ago, BP had posted a profit of $4.39 billion. BP also named Robert Dudley as its new chief executive, replacing Tony Hayward. BP's so-called replacement cost loss amounted to $16.97 billion in the second quarter compared to a profit of $3.14 billion in the same period a year ago. Danone profit slips as sales rise; lifts outlook (2:08 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- French food group Danone(FR:BN)on Tuesday reported first half net profit fell 10% to €838 million ($1.09 billion), against €932 million in the same period a year ago. On a diluted, per share basis, the company earned €1.38 against €1.50 a year ago. Sales rose 7% to €8.36 billion against €7.52 billion. As a result of the mid-year performance, Danone said it would increase its outlook for 2010, targeting sales growth of 6%, a stable operating margin and free cash flow growth of at least 10%. But the company also assumes "the financial, economic and social crises will continue to weigh on consumption trends in Europe." SAP's second-quarter profit up 15% (1:54 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- German business software giant SAP AG SAP, +1.13% (DE:SAP)said Tuesday its second-quarter net profit rose 15% to 491 million euros ($638 million) from 426 million euros in the same period a year ago. Total revenue increased 12% to 2.89 billion euros from 2.58 billion euros. Analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires expected net profit of 525 million euros and revenue of 2.75 billion euros. Software revenue rose 17% to 637 million euros, while software and software-related service revenue surged 16% to 2.26 billion euros. "The top line results were driven by continued growth in software revenue, strong support revenue, mainly from the majority of our customers who endorsed Enterprise Support, and double-digit growth in subscription revenue," said Werner Brandt, CFO of SAP. Deutsche Bank Q2 net profit up 9%; revenue falls (1:34 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- Deutsche Bank AG DB, +1.60% (DE:DBK)said Tuesday its second-quarter net profit rose 9% to 1.17 billion euros ($1.5 billion) from 1.07 billion euros. Pre-tax profit increased 16% to 1.5 billion euros from 1.3 billion euros. Analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires expected net profit of 1.03 billion euros and pre-tax profit of 1.56 billion euros. Net revenue fell 10% to 7.16 billion euros from 7.94 billion euros. "In a quarter which was characterized by increased investor uncertainty and higher market volatility, Deutsche Bank's investment banking business followed the industry-wide trend of weaker profitability," said Josef Ackermann, chairman of the management board. Revenue at the Corporate and Investment Bank unit fell to 4.7 billion euros from 5.3 billion euros in the second quarter of 2009. In sales and trading, revenue dropped to 2.1 billion euros from 2.3 billion euros. UBS swings to second-quarter profit (1:00 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- UBS AG UBS, +0.40% (CH:UBSN)said Tuesday it swung to a second-quarter net profit of 2 billion Swiss francs ($1.9 billion) compared to a loss of CHF1.4 billion in the same period a year ago. Operating income rose to CHF9.19 billion from CHF5.77 billion. Analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires expected net profit of CHF1.26 billion and revenue of CHF8.27 billion. "Concerns about the sustainability of the global economic recovery may leave markets volatile and with little direction," UBS said. "We believe that this could lead to more subdued client activity levels across our businesses." In addition, the bank expects that its portfolio management fee income will be lower than in the second quarter due to the lower level of invested assets at the end of June. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: An earlier version of this story gave an incorrect figure for Cephalon's expected revenue for the second quarter, which was $695 million, according to FactSet Research. SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Tuesday's session are BP PLC, Lockheed Martin Corp. and Aflac Inc. Lockheed LMT, +0.78% is expected to report earnings of $1.79 per share and revenue of $11.5 billion for the second quarter of 2010, according to FactSet Research. Aflac AFL, +0.48% is expected to report earnings of $1.33 per share and revenue of $4.9 billion for the second quarter of 2010. BP PLC BP, +2.37% on Tuesday named Robert Dudley as its new chief executive, replacing Tony Hayward, as it reported a $17.2 billion quarterly loss and took $32.2 billion in charges linked to its response to the Gulf of Mexico spill. The loss compared to a profit of $4.39 billion earned in the year-earlier period. Occidental Petroleum Corp. OXY, +2.87% is expected to report earnings of $1.37 per share and revenue of $5 billion for the second quarter of 2010. MARKETS | • The Tell: Market news and analysis • | Canada section • Columns: Stocks | Oil | Gold | Bonds | Dollar  TOOLS AND DATA | • My Portfolio: Know where your funds are? • Real-time currency exchange rates • After-hours stock screener Alcoa Inc. AA, +1.22% said Monday it priced $1 billion in notes to buy back notes with upcoming maturity dates. Alcoa intends to sell $1 billion in 6.15% notes due Aug. 15, 2020. Expected proceeds of $993 million will be used to pay off its 6.5% notes due 2011, 6% notes due 2012 and 5.375% notes due 2013. Sanmina-SCI Corp. SANM, +0.77% shares were down 6.7% to $14.80 in after hours trading and light volume of less than 50,000 shares exchanged, but had been down by as much as 12%. Sanmina-SCI swung to a profit $22 million, or 26 cents a share, from a net loss of $42 million or 52 cents a share a year ago. Fluor Corp. FLR, +2.45% reported late Monday second-quarter net income fell to $157 million, or 87 cents a share, from $169 million, or 93 cents a share, a year ago. The company cited weaker results from its oil and gas division for the decline. Revenue for the three months ended June 30 fell 2.7% to $5.15 billion. The results nevertheless topped the 71 cents a share analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected. DreamWorks Animation SKG Inc. DWA is expected to report earnings of 22 cents per share and revenue of $140 million for the second quarter of 2010. E.I. DuPont de Nemours & Co. DD, +2.74% is expected to report earnings of 93 cents per share and revenue of $7.1 billion for the second quarter of 2010. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% is expected to report earnings of 49 cents per share and revenue of $19.3 billion for the second quarter of 2010. CIT Group Inc. NDAQ, +3.27% is expected to report earnings of 49 cents per share and revenue of $3.8 million in the second quarter of 2010. U.S. Steel Corp. BRCM is expected to report earnings of 63 cents a share and revenue of $1.6 billion for the second quarter of 2010. Cephalon Inc. CEPH is expected to report earnings of $1.75 per share and revenue of $695 million for the second quarter of 2010. Massey Energy Co. content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies made noteworthy moves in the U.S. stock market on Thursday: Advancers AmeriCredit Corp. ACF, +0.00% shares climbed more than 21% after General Motors Co. said it would buy the car-financing giant for $3.5 billion. Shares of Leucadia National Corp. LUK, +1.25% AmeriCredit's biggest shareholder, rose 7%. Read about effort to fill void created in 2006. F5 Networks Inc. FFIV, +1.40% shares rose 14% after the maker of products to manage computer network traffic reported quarterly results and a forecast that beat expectations. Janus Capital Group Inc. JNS shares rose almost 12% after the investment manager reported second-quarter earnings rose more than 90%, topping expectations. JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU, +0.74% shares were up 8.5% after the carrier reported a 50% jump in quarterly profit. Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, +1.30% shares rose more than 8% after the developer of wireless chips hiked its profit and revenue outlook for 2010. Regional Banks rose after Fifth Third Bancorp FITB, +0.60% reported its first profitable quarter in four and SunTrust Banks Inc. STI, +2.22% cut its second-quarter loss. Fifth Third shares rose more than 10%; SunTrust shares gained 9.6%; Marshall & Ilsley Corp. MI gained 9.5%; and Regions Financial Corp. RF, +1.64% gained 6.5%. Union Pacific Corp. UNP, +2.81% shares rose 4.8% after the railroad reported quarterly results that beat Wall Street's expectations. United Parcel Service Inc. UPS, +1.93% shares advanced more than 5% after the world's biggest package delivery firm hiked its outlook. Shares of rival FedEx Corp. FDX, +2.26% also gained, up 6%. VF Corp. VFC, +0.61% shares moved up 6% after the globe's largest apparel company raised its outlook for the year. Xerox Corp. XRX, -0.24% shares climbed 7.4% after the maker of printers hiked its outlook and reported a profitable second-quarter that topped analysts' forecasts. Decliners AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% shares dropped 7.4%. Laboratory Corp. of America Holdings LH, +0.14% shares fell almost 5% after the lab-testing company reported second-quarter results. Medco Health Solutions Inc. MHS fell 8.1% after the pharmacy benefits manager reported results roughly in line with expectations. Netflix's NFLX, +3.35% shares were off 13.5% after the film subscription service reported second-quarter results under Wall Street's expectations. SolarWinds Inc. SWI, +0.24% shares dropped 23% after the network software maker projected third-quarter results beneath analysts' expectations. Western Digital Corp. WDC, +1.62% shares fell 6.7% after the hard disk drive maker warned its fiscal first-quarter results would not meet expectations. Quest Diagnostics Inc. DGX, +0.79% shares slid 4.6% after it on Wednesday cut its 2010 forecast, citing a slowdown in visits to doctors' offices. title: Thursday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Tenet Healthcare Corp. was at the helm of a sectorwide rally in health care early Tuesday, but its gains fizzled as a strong market rally turned lukewarm by session's end. The NYSE Healthcare Index was up 0.8% to 5,760.28 at the close. Tenet THC, +1.76% was up nearly 7% at one point early in the session, due largely to the company's depressed stock price. Tenet ended the day up 4.1% at $4.32. Other big gainers in the hospital sector were Community Health Systems CYH, -3.65% up 2.4% at $32.21. On the losing side was Lincare Holdings LNCR off 8.3% to $26.43. Lincare fell after Garp Research cut its rating on the company's shares to neutral from buy. Insurers' gains faded as the day wore on. Sector leaders UnitedHealth Group Inc. UNH, -2.06% and WellPoint Inc. WLP added 2% and 1.4%, respectively, but HealthNet HNT, +0.00% stumbled 1% to $23.98 after the company settled a privacy suit with the state of Connecticut. Hospira Inc. HSP, +0.18% and CareFusion Corp. CFN, +0.80% led medical-device makers, gaining 1.7% and 1.3%, respectively. Most of the rest of the sector was up marginally, while Boston Scientific Corp. BSX, +2.40% lost 1.8% to $6.03. The drug distributors were up marginally, with AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% rising 1.4% to $31.34. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: Tenet gains, but health-care rally fizzles

content: Editor's Note: This is a free edition of The Technical Indicator, a daily MarketWatch subscriber newsletter. To get this column, including 100 technical stock picks every month, click here. CINCINNATI (MarketWatch) - With just over one week remaining in the second quarter, the Standard & Poor's 500 Index is struggling to escape major resistance. The specific area holds at the 200-day moving average, a level that's served as a magnet over the past five sessions. The S&P 500's SPX, +1.38% hourly chart details the past three weeks. As illustrated, the index tried to break higher on Monday, briefly rising on China's revised currency policy. Nonetheless, the rally was greeted with selling pressure, sending the S&P to close near session lows. From current levels, initial support spans from 1,105 to 1,111, bracketing the early-June peak and the 200-day moving average. Meanwhile, the Dow industrials' DJIA, +1.07% near-term view is similar. Like the S&P, the Dow briefly rallied at Monday's open, but reversed to close near session lows. Looking ahead, initial support holds around 10,430, and is followed by the Dow's 200-day moving average, currently 10,346. And the Nasdaq Composite's $COMPX near-term backdrop is the weakest. In fact, this was the only major benchmark to violate the early-June peak -- the 2,307 mark -- with Monday's reversal. From current levels, initial support holds at 2,289, and is followed by a deeper floor at the 2009 close of 2,269. Widening the view to six months adds color. As illustrated, the Nasdaq stalled just shy of its 50-day moving average on Monday, arguably contributing to its sharp reversal. Stepping back slightly, and taking in the entire chart, the May breakdown inflicted significant technical damage, and an extended basing period would normally be expected before the next sustainable upturn. Moving to the Dow, it topped just above its 50-day moving average on Monday before plunging 152 points into the close. On this wider view, initial support holds at the 2009 close of 10,428 and is followed by the 200-day moving average, currently 10,346. And the S&P 500's six-month backdrop is equally conflicted. In Monday's action, the S&P topped intraday at 1,131 -- just four points under its 50-day moving average -- and subsequently plunged straight back to its center of gravity at the 200-day moving average, in blue. The bigger picture As detailed above, each major U.S. benchmark challenged its 50-day moving average on Monday. Specifically: The S&P topped Monday at 1,131, just under its 50-day moving average of 1,135. The Dow topped at 10,594, slightly above its 50-day moving average of 10,573. The Nasdaq topped at 2,341, just under its 50-day moving average of 2,347. And upon reaching resistance, each benchmark reversed sharply to close near session lows. Bearish price action. Against this backdrop, the SPDR Trust S&P 500's SPY, +1.28% six-month view highlights familiar technical territory. Consider the following inflection points: Resistance at the S&P's 200-day moving average, currently 1,111. Resistance at the S&P's 50% market-crash retracement of 1,121. With these areas detailed, the S&P 500 remains uncannily trapped by this band. Specifically, the index closed last Tuesday at 1,115, Wednesday at 1,114, Thursday at 1,116, Friday at 1,117 and Monday at 1,113. So collectively, the S&P has cleared headline resistance at the 200-day moving average, a move that "should" have drawn market bulls off the sideline. But as always, it's not just what the markets do, it's also how they do it. And by this measure, the current recovery attempt has technical issues. To start, total volume remains lackluster, and recent strength has been driven by uninspiring sector leadership. And more technically, the S&P hasn't closed atop the 1,121 resistance. So all told, the S&P remains trapped by an unusually tight resistance band -- the 1,111-to-1,121 area -- and a guarded approach remains advisable until more convincing signs of stabilization emerge. Tuesday's watch list The charts below highlight names well positioned technically. These are intended as radar screen names - sectors or stocks positioned to move near term. For the original comments on the stocks below, check out The Technical Indicator Library. Aluminum sector rallies on China's revised currency policy Drilling down to sectors, the aluminum names perked up on China's revised currency policy: Alcoa, Inc. AA, +1.22% Aluminum Corporation of China ACH, +3.57% and Century Aluminum CENX, +2.10% Fundamentally, the currency adjustment signals confidence in China's economic recovery, also raising aluminum's cost of production in China to the benefit of worldwide producers. And from a technical standpoint, the group has responded accordingly. As illustrated, each has cleared a multi-month downtrend, and its 20-day moving average, signaling a near-term trend shift. Moreover, Monday's rally came on increased volume, improving the chances of a sustainable upturn. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold FCX $68.08 $67.00 $71.30 Similarly, Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold FCX, +4.90% is a large-cap name coming to life. With Monday's rally, the shares have spiked atop a three-month downtrend tracking the 20-day moving average. The breakout came on increased volume -- improving the chances of further gains -- and an uptrend is in play barring a violation of the 20-day. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC $32.42 $32.00 $33.25 Initially profiled May 13, AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% remains well positioned. Earlier this month, the shares broke to all-time highs, clearing resistance at the May peak. By comparison, the subsequent pullback has been orderly, placing the shares at an attractive entry near first support. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Tenaris SA TS $38.19 $37.30 $38.80 Tenaris SA TS, +3.31% is a large-cap manufacturer of steel pipe products. Technically speaking, the shares have sustained a break atop the 20-day moving average signaling a potential trend shift. Its backdrop would further strengthen on a close atop the late-May peak, around $38.80, a move that would mark a "higher high," neutralizing the former downtrend. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance AK Steel Holding Corp. AKS $14.26 $13.75 $14.60 AK Steel Holding Corp. AKS, +5.84% is a mid-cap name showing signs of life. As illustrated, the shares are holding tightly to the 20-day moving average, raising the flag to a potential trend shift. Moreover, Monday's rally was driven by increased volume, improving the chances of a more decisive breakout. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Questcor Pharmaceuticals QCOR $10.89 $10.50 $11.60 Initially profiled May 24, Questcor Pharmaceuticals QCOR has returned 21% and remains well positioned. Earlier this month, the shares knifed to all-time highs on increased volume. Since then, it has sustained its gains, and while near-term extended, a pullback toward the breakout point, around $10.50, would mark a high risk/reward entry. content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CVS Caremark CVS, -0.80% shares fell 5% in pre-market trades on Monday after Walgreens wag said it will not participate as a provider in any new and renewed prescription drug plans awarded after June 7 to CVS Caremark's pharmacy benefit manager. Current CVS Caremark plans in which Walgreens is already a pharmacy provider will not be affected. Walgreens cited CVS Caremark's "management practices toward Walgreens." AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% shares rose 4%.
