content: ANNANDALE, Va. (MarketWatch) -- Though there are surprisingly strong statistical reasons for "selling in May and going away," many nevertheless find it difficult to actually do what the strategy calls for -- sitting on one's hands from now until Halloween. It is especially hard to do now, in fact, with the bull market defying all odds and continuing to chug along. Money managers tell me that the worst crime that they can commit, at least in the eyes of many of their clients, is being out of the market when it is rising.   TRADING STRATEGIES: MAY Searching for great deals As the market climbs, good deals are harder to find. Let our panel of experts help you find value even in an arguably frothy market. • Kee: How to profit from May's market fall • Gilani: Stay and play the VIX in May • Lowell: Balancing shorts, bonds and coal • Kahn: Solar stocks show signs of life • Hulbert: Retail, leisure, food picks for summer • Cordier: Oil bull running out of gas • Lancz: Unlikely financials have merit • Murphy: Three biotech picks for May • Whalen: Short-term, low-yield bonds • Horowitz: May's value sectors • Auer: Money not easy, but still possible •   • See the full special report As a result, many choose to thumb their noses at the historical odds and stay in the market between May Day and Halloween. If you're just such an investor, this column is directed at you. It turns out that there are ways of increasing those otherwise poor odds. That at least was the finding of recent study that appeared last August in the Financial Review, an academic journal. Entitled "The Halloween Effect in U.S. Sectors," the study was written by Ben Jacobsen and Nuttawat Visaltanachoti, both from New Zealand's Massey University. The researchers searched for seasonal tendencies among 49 different industries and 17 separate sectors in the U.S. stock market over the period from 1926 through 2005. They found a handful of sectors and industries whose returns in the summer were no worse than those in the winter. Provided you focus on stocks within those groups, therefore, and assuming the future is like the past, there is no reason the odds of success will be any worse this summer than they would be during the winter months. Which industries and sectors have the best odds of success between May Day and Halloween? According to this new study's authors, they fall broadly within the consumer-related sectors such as food and agriculture, leisure, multimedia and retailing. The winter months' best-performing industries, in contrast, are those in the manufacturing and production sectors, such as durables, chemicals, construction and machines. With this research in mind, I searched the Hulbert Financial Digest's database for highly recommended stocks that fall within the food and agriculture, leisure, multimedia and retailing sectors. To find such stocks, I started by identifying those advisers who had beaten a buy-and-hold in the stock market over the last 15 years -- a long enough period to identify those with genuine ability. Of the nearly 200 monitored advisers, 27 were able to jump over this high hurdle. I next determined which stocks in the favored industry sectors also are currently recommended by at least three of these 27 advisers. They are, in alphabetical order: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Comcast Corp New CMCSA, +2.67% CVS Caremark Corp. CVS, -0.80% H.J. Heinz Co. HNZ Hasbro Inc. HAS, +0.57% Kellogg Co. K, +1.74% Kraft Foods Inc. KFT McDonald's Corp. MCD, -1.28% Sara Lee Corp. SLE, +0.51% Sysco Corp. SYY, +0.99% TJX Companies Inc. TJX, +1.08% Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT, +1.37% Walt Disney Co. DIS, +1.93% More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Related Topics Investing U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: Retail, leisure, food picks for summer portfolios

content: Air China first quarter profit $318 million (11:03 PM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Air China Ltd.'s(HK:753)(CN:601111) AIRY shares were up 1.1% in Friday morning Hong Kong trade, after the carrier said its net income for the first quarter more than doubled from a year earlier because of a rapid rebound in demand for air travel. Profit for the three months ended March 31 totaled 2.17 billion yuan ($317.9 million), up 121% from the 981.2 million yuan in the year-earlier period. Revenue climbed to 14.70 billion yuan, up 31% from 11.24 billion yuan. Net profit for the year ended Dec. 31 totaled 5.03 billion yuan, compared with a net loss of 9.15 billion yuan the previous year. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected, on average, 2009 net profit of 4.69 billion yuan. However, the carrier's Shanghai-listed shares fell 2.5%, with some analysts saying the strong results had been priced in, given the stock's recent outperformance. Costco hikes quarterly dividend to 20.5 cents (10:03 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Costco Wholesale Corp. COST, +2.63% said late Thursday its board of directors are raising the quarterly dividend on its shares to 20.5 cents from 18 cents previously. The Issaquah, Wash., warehouse retailer said the new dividend will be payable May 21 to shareholders of record at the close of business on May 7. Honda operating profit to rise 90%: report (7:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Honda Motor Co.(JP:7267) HMC, +0.90% is likely to report a 90% gain in operating profit for its full fiscal year, according to a report published Friday. Honda is expected to post a 360 billion yen ($3.9 billion) operating profit, according to a report in the Nikkei business daily. That result would top prior expectations for a 69% gain in operating profit, thanks to strength in emerging markets and better-than-expected sales of models including the CR-V sport utility vehicle, according to the report. Honda is expected to report results on Wednesday. Eastman's first-quarter profit jumps to $101 mln (5:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Eastman Chemical Co. EMN, +1.34% late Thursday reported its first-quarter net income jumped to $101 million, or $1.37 a share, from $2 million, or 3 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue rose to $1.56 billion from $1.13 billion a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had projected earnings of $1.19 a share on revenue of $1.38 billion. Rambus swings to first-quarter profit of $151 mln (4:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Rambus Inc. RMBS, +0.67% late Thursday reported it swung to a first-quarter net income of $150.9 million, or $1.28 a share, from a loss of $17.4 million, or 17 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue surged 492% to $161.9 million from $27.3 million a year earlier, thanks to a licensing agreement with Samsung. "The Samsung agreement was a transformational event driving record revenues this quarter," said Chief Executive Harold Hughes in a statement. Chubb reports quarterly net income of $464 mln (4:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chubb Corp. CB, -1.08% said late Thursday that first-quarter net income was $464 million, or $1.39 a share, up from $341 million, or 95 cents a share, in the first quarter of 2009. Operating income, which excludes after-tax realized investment gains and losses, was $381 million, or $1.14 a share, in the first quarter of 2010. That was down from $514 million, or $1.43 a share, in the first quarter of 2009. The insurer was expected to make $1.06 a share, according to the average estimate of analysts surveyed by FactSet. The impact of catastrophes in the first quarter of 2010 was $344 million, before taxes. That compared to $26 million, before taxes, in the first quarter of 2009, Chubb said. Amex quarterly net income more than doubles (4:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- American Express Co. AXP, +1.16% said late Thursday that first-quarter net income came in at $885 million, more than double the result from a year earlier when the credit card giant made $437 million. Net income attributable to common shareholders was 73 cents a share in the latest period, versus 31 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue, after interest expense, came in at $6.61 billion versus $5.93 billion a year earlier. Amex was expected to make 62 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 18 analysts polled by FactSet. "Cardmember spending was up 16 percent, rebounding strongly from the recessionary lows of last year," Kenneth Chenault, chief executive of Amex, said in a statement. "Credit metrics also continued the improvement that began in the second half of 2009." Federated reports profit rise (4:20 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Federated Investors Inc. FII, +1.55% said late Thursday that its first-quarter profit was $42 million, or 38 cents a share, compared to $35 million, or 34 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Total revenue fell 25% to $233 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected, on average, profit of 44 cents a share on revenue of $253 million. Total managed assets at the Pittsburgh-based asset manager were nearly $350 billion, a 14% drop from the first quarter of 2009 and a 10% fall from the fourth quarter. Capital One reports quarterly profit of $636.3 mln (4:19 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Capital One Financial COF, +1.64% said late Thursday that first-quarter net income came in at $636.3 million, or $1.40 a common share. The company reported a net loss of $172.3 million, or 44 cents a common share, a year earlier. The credit card and banking company was expected to earn 55 cents a share, according to analysts polled by FactSet Research. Managed provision expense dropped 20% by $368.6 million from the prior quarter, the company noted. Capital One shares surged 5.5% to $48.00 in after-hours trading Thursday. Microsoft net rises 35% in third quarter (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% said Thursday its fiscal third-quarter net income rose to $4.01 billion, or 45 cents a share, from $2.98 billion, or 33 cents a share in the same period last year. The software giant said revenue for the period ended in March rose 6% to $14.5 billion. Microsoft said the results included a $305 million revenue deferral related to a promotional program for its Office suite of applications. Wall Street analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected Microsoft to post third-quarter earnings of 42 cents a share, and $14.4 billion in revenue. Amazon earnings jump 68% in first quarter (4:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Amazon.com Inc. reported a sharp 68% gain in first-quarter earnings Thursday afternoon, as the online retail giant continued to grow its sales and gain share in the e-commerce market. For the March quarter, Amazon AMZN, +1.11% reported net income of $299 million, or 66 cents a share, compared to net income of $177 million, or 41 cents a share, for the same period the previous year. Revenue grew 46% to $7.13 billion. Analysts were expecting earnings of 61 cents a share on revenue of $6.87 billion, according to consensus forecasts from Thomson Reuters. Hershey shares rise 6% after first-quarter results (11:46 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch)-- Shares of Hershey Co. HSY, +0.72% rose almost 6% to $47.50 after the chocolate company's first-quarter earnings topped analysts' expectations. The chocolate company also boosted its 2010 forecast and now expects double-digit profit growth and a sales increase of at least 6% this year. Hershey posted earnings of $147.4 million, or 64 cents a share, compared to $75.9 million, or 33 cents a share, a year earlier, which beat analysts expected earnings of 47 cents on net sales of $1.29 billion. Textron shares rally 8% after quarterly results (11:12 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch)-- Shares of Textron TXT, +2.38% rallied more than 8% to $23.46 on Thursday after the maker of Cessna planes and Bell helicopters posted better-than-expected first-quarter results in its industrial division, which makes golf carts, tools and plastic fuel systems. Earnings in the company's defense division also rose. Textron posted a loss of $8 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier profit of $86 million, or 35 cents a share. Revenue dropped 13% to $2.21 billion, coming in below the Thomson Reuters consensus estimate of $2.38 billion. Baxter, Affymetrix lead drug stocks lower (10:05 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Baxter International BAX, +1.86% and Affymetrix Inc. AFFX led drug stocks into negative territory early Thursday as shares of both companies took sharp hits after they released their respective quarterly earnings reports. Baxter shares dove 17% to $48.91, while Affymetrix shares sank 12% to $7.21. The NYSE Arca Pharmaceutical Index $DRG was off 1.3% at 298.65 while the NYSE Arca Biotechnology Index $BTK of which Affymetrix is a component, fell 2% to 1182.40. Janus slips on earnings miss, Intech outflows (9:58 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Janus Capital Group Inc. JNS were off nearly 7% in early trading Thursday after the investment manager reported first-quarter net income of 17 cents a share, which missed the consensus analyst estimate by a penny. The Denver-based firm said outflows in its long-term products totaled $1.9 billion during the quarter, while outflows in its quantitative-investing unit, Intech Investment Management, were $4.3 billion. "A mixed quarter for Janus, but given its Intech issues and current valuation, the stock is likely to be a bit weak and we remain at hold," wrote Deutsche Bank analyst Michael Carrier in a note Thursday on Janus' quarterly report. Nokia, Qualcomm, eBay lead broad tech losses (9:42 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Technology stocks slumped in early trading Thursday, led by big losses from Nokia Corp. NOK, +0.74% Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, +1.30% and online retalier eBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% All three company's gave quarterly forecasts that disappointed the market. The few notable gainers included flash-memory developer Sandisk Corp. SNDK and Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35% The Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ home to many leading tech stocks, fell 30 points, or 1.2%, to 2,473. Nucor Corp. swings to a profit (9:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Nucor Corp. NUE, +2.98% said Thursday it swung to a first-quarter profit of $31 million, or 10 cents a share, from a loss of $189.6 million, or 60 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose 38% to $3.65 billion. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 11 cents a share and revenue of $3.7 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Blackstone loss narrows, adjusted beats estimates (9:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Blackstone Group L.P. BX, +1.36% on Thursday said it saw a first-quarter loss of $121.4 million, or 36 cents a share, compared to a loss of $231.6 million in the year-ago period. Total revenues at the firm leapt to $701.2 million, from $44.9 million, boosted by rises in performance fees and allocations and investment income. Blackstone reported economic profit after tax -- a measure that does not include certain costs -- of $360 million, or 32 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research expected, on average, that figure to be profit of 21 cents a share, on revenue of $640 million. Reliance Streel & Aluminum profit doubles (9:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatcg) -- Reliance Steel & Aluminum Co. RS, +3.14% said Thursday its first-quarter net income more than doubled to $44.7 million, or 60 cents a share, from $20.1 million, or 27 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales fell 7% to $1.45 billion. Reliance Steel was expected to earn 64 cents a share on revenue of $1.49 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Janus swings to profit, misses estimates (8:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Asset manager Janus Capital Group Inc. JNS reported Thursday a first-quarter profit of $31.3 million, or 17 cents a share, compared to a loss of $818.1 million, or $5.22 a share. The year-ago period included impairment charges of $856.7 million, or $5.21 a share. Revenues jumped to $246.9 million from $170.3 million in the first quarter of 2009. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research expected, on average, a profit of 18 cents a share on revenue of $254.7 million. In the latest quarter, Denver-based Janus saw net outflows of $1.9 billion, and had total assets under management of $165.5 billion as of March 31. The firm saw net inflows in all its long-term fund categories except its quantitative-investing unit, Intech Investment Management, which saw net outflows of $4.3 billion in the quarter. Peabody Energy's first-quarter profit falls (8:17 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- Peabody Energy Corp. BTU, +0.05% reported Thursday its first-quarter net profit fell to $133.7 million from $170 million in the year-ago period. In the three months ended March 31, revenue rose to $1.52 billion from $1.45 billion. The firm is targeting 2010 EBITDA [earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization] and adjusted earnings per share up to 47% and 64% higher than 2009 respectively. It expects to benefit from increasing pricing and metallurgical coal volumes in Australia. Sherwin-Williams net income edges down (8:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Sherwin-Williams Co. SHW, +1.78% said Thursday its first-quarter net income fell to $32.6 million, or 30 cents a share, from $37.3 million, or 32 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Cleveland-based paint maker said sales rose 1% to $1.57 billion. Excluding a charge of 10 cents a share for health care expenses, the company earned 40 cents a share. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 40 cents a share and sales of $1.54 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Union Pacific net income climbs 43% (8:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Union Pacific Corp. UNP, +2.81% said Thursday its first-quarter net income rose to $516 million, or $1.01 a share, from $362 million, or 72 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The railroad's revenue rose 16% to $3.8 billion. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 92 cents a share and revenue of $3.76 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. "Although the strength and timing of a sustained economic recovery are still uncertain, we are feeling better about our 2010 growth opportunities," the company said. "Our plan is to remain flexible and run a safe, efficient network that generates significant volume leverage." Southwest Air swings to net on 12% higher revenue (8:01 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) - Southwest Airlines, LUV, +1.83% the Dallas carrier, swung to first-quarter net income from a year-earlier loss on 12% higher revenue. Southwest earned $11 million, or 1 cent a share, compared with a loss of $91 million, or 12 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. On an adjusted basis, the first-quarter bottom line was profit of 3 cents a share compared with a year-earlier loss of 3 cents. Revenue reached $2.63 billion from $2.36 billion. A survey of analysts had been looking for profit of 3 cents a share in the quarter. Demand for business travel improved modestly as the quarter progressed, Chief Executive Gary C. Kelly said in a Thursday statement. The load factor - the percentage of seats filled with paying passengers - widened to 75.9% from 69.9% in first-quarter 2009. Questar jumps on possible spin-off plan (7:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Questar STR, +1.88% shares jumped 11% to $51.01 in pre-market trades on Thursday after the company said it's considering a possible tax-free spin-off of its natural gas and oil exploration and production business. The new company would include Questar E&P Company, Questar Gas Management, and Questar Energy Trading. After the spin-off, Questar Corp. would remain a natural gas company comprised of subsidiaries Wexpro Company, Questar Pipeline, and Questar Gas Company. "If consummated, we believe the spin-off would create two top-tier companies in their respective market segments," the Salt Lake City company said. The spin-off transaction may occur in the second half of 2010. Verizon earnings fall 75%, largely on health costs (7:37 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - Verizon Communications Inc. VZ, -0.37% on Thursday reported a 75% drop in first-quarter earnings, mostly owing to a large onetime charge for retiree-health care costs. The New York-based company said net income attributable to shareholders fell to $409 million, or 14 cents a share, from $1.65 billion, or 58 cents, a year earlier. Revenue climbed 1.2% to $26.91 billion. Excluding onetime costs, Verizon would have earned 56 cents a share, matching Wall Street's consensus. The nation's largest wireless operator gained a net 1.5 million customers, though only 423,000 fell into the most valuable postpaid category. Verizon also added 168,000 FiOS television customers. Baxter International profit up 2%; lowers guidance (7:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Baxter International BAX, +1.86% on Thursday said first-quarter net income rose to $525 million, or 86 cents a share, from $516 million, or 83 cents a share, in the same period last year. Excluding a one-time, tax-related special charge of $39 million, earnings rose to $564 million, or 93 cents a share. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus forecast of 93 cents. The Deerfield, Ill.-based medical-products firm said global sales rose 11% to $3.1 billion. Baxter lowered its full-year 2010 sales growth forecast to 1% to 3%, excluding the impact of foreign exchange, from a previous estimate of 5% to 7%. It lowered its full-year earnings forecast to $3.92 to $4 a share, from $4.20 to $4.28. The company cited the impact of the recently passed U.S. healthcare legislation and pressures on the plasma market. For the second quarter, Baxter expects sales growth of zero to 2% and earnings of 90 to 93 cents. AmerisourceBergen net up; outlook for year higher (7:27 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) - Amerisource Bergen Corp., ABC, +1.29% the Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical-services company, reported that fiscal second-quarter net income rose 26% on 11% higher revenue and it raised its earnings outlook for the year. Earnings for the quarter ended March 31 reached $181 million, or 63 cents a share, from $143.4 million, or 47 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Shares outstanding fell 5.7% to 287.2 million. Revenue advanced to $19.3 billion from $17.31 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of 54 cents of profit. Amerisource Bergen lifted its estimate of fiscal 2010 earnings to a range of $2.01 to $2.10, compared with $1.69 from continuing operations in fiscal 2009. It affirmed its assessment that revenue would grow 7% to 8% for the year. Raytheon profit flat (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Raytheon Co. RTN, +2.26% said Thursday its first-quarter profit was $445 million, or $1.16 a share, from $452 million, or $1.12 a share, in the year-ago period. Profit from continuing operations was $1.18 a share, the Waltham, Mass.-based military contractor said. Net sales were $6.1 billion, from $5.9 billion in the first quarter of 2009. Analysts surveyed by Fact Set Research had expected profit of $1.10 a share on sales of $6.2 billion. Diamond Offshore net income drops 20% (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Diamond Offshore DO, +2.95% said Thursday its first-quarter earnings fell to $290.9 million, or $2.09 a share, from $348.6 million, or $2.51 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue dipped to $860 million from $886 million. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of $1.94 a share and revenue of $847 million, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Diamond Offshore said it'll reduce its special dividend by 50 cents to $1.38 a share. Philip Morris profit climbs 15% (7:13 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Tobacco company Philip Morris International Inc. PM, -0.39% (FR:PM)said Thursday that its first-quarter net profit rose 15.4% to $1.7 billion, or 90 cents a share, from $1.48 billion, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. Net revenue for the quarter increased 17.3% to $15.59 billion from $13.29 billion. The group said its results were helped by currency movements and said total cigarette shipment volumes rose 0.7% to 204.7 billion units, driven by growth in Asia. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had forecast earnings of 91 cents a share in the latest quarter. Philip Morris also reaffirmed its forecast for 2010 earnings in a range of $3.75 to $3.85 a share. PNC Financial net income rises, upbeat on year (7:07 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- PNC Financial Services PNC, +1.20% on Thursday said first-quarter net income rose 26% to $671 million, against $530 million in the year-ago period. Net income attributable to shareholders fell 27% to $333 million, against $460 million in the year-ago period. On a per-share basis, the company earned 66 cents, against $1.03. A survey of analysts at FactSet Research was forecasting net income of $333 million. Adjusted for redemption of TARP preferred shares and after-tax integration costs, the company would have earned $1.31 a share against $1.11 and net income would have been $744 million in the first quarter. Revenue for the group was $3.76 billion against $3.69 billion. Provisions for credit losses narrowed to $751 million against $880 million in the year-ago period, which the company said is a sign that the pace of credit deterioration eased at the end of 2009. "While there is still uncertainty about the economic environment and potential regulatory changes, we believe PNC is well positioned for another good year," said James E. Rohr, chairman and chief executive officer. Fifth Third Bancorp loss widens (6:56 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Cincinnati bank Fifth Third Bancorp FITB, +0.60% said its first-quarter loss widened to $72 million, or 9 cents a share, from $26 million, or 4 cents a share. The prior year period included $121 million in benefits from surrending bank-owned life insurance policies. Analysts polled by FactSet expected a loss of 18 cents a share. Marriott International returns to profit (6:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Hotel operator Marriott International MAR, +1.55% said it returned to a first-quarter profit of $83 million, or 22 cents a share, with revenue rising to $2.63 billion from $2.5 billion. Marriott lost $23 million in the prior-year period. The company's expecting second-quarter earnings between 25 cents and 29 cents a share on fee revenue between $275 million to $285 million, annual earnings between 95 cents and $1.05 a share on fee revenue between $1.15 billion to $1.18 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet expected first-quarter earnings of 20 cents a share, second-quarter earnings of 23 cents a share and annual earnings of 95 cents a share. Continental says disappointed with widening losses (6:33 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- U.S. airline Continental CAL, -0.62% on Thursday said its first-quarter net loss widened by 7.4% to $146 million, against $136 million in the year-ago period. On a per-share basis, the company reported a loss of $1.05, against $1.10 a year ago. Excluding $10 million of severance and aircraft-related special charges, the net loss was $136 million, or 98 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expected the company to report a loss of 86 cents a share. Total operating revenue for the group rose 7% to $3.17 billion, against $3 billion in the year-ago period. "I'm disappointed with our first quarter results, which were impacted by the weak economy and the challenges we experienced with weather related closures of our Newark Liberty hub," said Jeff Smisek, chairman, president and chief executive officer. "However, the year-over-year increase in our revenue reflects the slowly improving global economy and benefits from our membership in Star Alliance." Nokia's Q1 earnings miss forecast, cautious on Q2 (6:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Nokia Corp. NOK, +0.74% (FI:NOK1V), the world's largest maker of mobile phones, on Thursday posted first-quarter net profit attributable to equity holders of 349 million euros ($465 million), or 9 European cents a share, up from 122 million euros, or 3 cents a share, earned in the year-earlier period. On an adjusted basis, excluding special items totalling 322 million euros, earnings came in at 14 cents a share compared to 10 cents a share a year earlier. Sales rose 3% to 9.52 billion euros. On a sequential basis they fell 21%. The consensus forecast was for earnings of 14 European cents a share on sales of 9.69 billion euros. At the core device and services division, sales climbed 8% to 6.66 billion euros. In the second quarter, Nokia forecast sales at its devices and services division in the range of 6.7 billion euros to 7.2 billion euros and an adjusted operating margin between 9% and 12%. Nokia shares fell 6% in Helsinki. ABB net income falls 29%, cautiously optimistic (2:42 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Swiss-based ABB(CH:ABBN) ABB, +0.76% said net income for the first quarter fell 29% to $464 million, against $652 million in the year-ago period due to lower large orders and overall weakness in the power infrastructure business. The company earned 20 cents per share, against 29 cents per share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research were forecasting net income of $557 million. Revenue for ABB fell 4% to $6.93 billion, against $7.2 billion, while orders fell 12% to $8.07 billion against $9.15 billion. The company said the first quarter was "challenging" on the power side, but there are some "encouraging signs of growth" in the short-cycle business, mainly in power automation markets. Thanks to cost cuts, profitability remains within the target range and the company is "cautiously optimistic" that momentum will build for the short cycle business, while a similar trend is forecast for the larger late-cycle business later in the year. Credit Suisse profit up 2% as inflows improve (2:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss bank Credit Suisse(CH:CSGN) CS, +1.27% said Thursday that its first-quarter net profit edged up 2% to 2.06 billion Swiss francs ($1.92 billion) from 2.01 billion francs, helped by lower costs and taxes, as well as a strong trading performance in the fixed-income side of its investment bank. The group said core net revenue fell 6% to 8.96 billion francs and net new assets were 26 billion francs in the quarter, compared to 8.8 billion francs a year earlier. Profit matched the consensus forecast of analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires. "Market conditions in the second quarter to date have remained similar to those in the first quarter and we are confident that our business model will enable us to continue to generate high-quality results in good as well as in more challenging conditions," said CEO Brady Dougan. Remy Cointreau 4th-quarter revenue doubles (2:10 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) - Remy Cointreau REMYF, -0.41% (FR:RCO), the Paris producer of champagne and spirits, reported that fourth-quarter revenue doubled to 219 million euros ($293 million) from 109.7 million in the year-earlier quarter. For the fiscal year ended March 31, turnover rose 13% to 807.8 million euros. The growth reflects particular strength in Asia and the favorable comparison to fourth-quarter 2009 due to the company's exit from Maxxium, Remy Cointreau said in a Thursday statement. All divisions reported higher revenue in the quarter, due particularly to "strong growth" in China and Southeast Asia, while "the U.S. proved more resilient and there was a marked recovery in Europe," the company said. (Repeats to complete headline.) Actelion 1st-quarter net per share up 31% (1:36 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) - Actelion Pharmaceuticals Ltd. ALIOF, +0.00% (CH:ATLN), the Allschwil, Switzerland, drugmaker, reported Thursday that first-quarter net income per share rose 31% on 24% higher revenue. Earnings reached 1.09 Swiss francs ($1.02) a share from 0.83 Swiss franc in the year-earlier quarter. Adjusted earnings were 1.38 francs versus 1.05. Revenue rose to 501.7 million francs from 405.6 million. In particular, Actelion noted that sales of Tracleer, generically bosentan, for pulmonary arterial hypertension, rose 19% in local currencies to 405.2 million francs. The company affirmed its outlook for adjusted earnings before interest and taxes to grow nearly 20% in local currencies during 2010. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) - Amerisource Bergen Corp., ABC, +1.29% the Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical-services company, reported that fiscal second-quarter net income rose 26% on 11% higher revenue and it raised its earnings outlook for the year. Earnings for the quarter ended March 31 reached $181 million, or 63 cents a share, from $143.4 million, or 47 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Shares outstanding fell 5.7% to 287.2 million. Revenue advanced to $19.3 billion from $17.31 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of 54 cents of profit. Amerisource Bergen lifted its estimate of fiscal 2010 earnings to a range of $2.01 to $2.10, compared with $1.69 from continuing operations in fiscal 2009. It affirmed its assessment that revenue would grow 7% to 8% for the year.
title: AmerisourceBergen net up; outlook for year higher

content: Pre-open movers U.S. stock futures traded slightly lower Friday as investors balanced worries over Google and Advanced Micro Devices results with better-than-forecast reports from Bank of America and General Electric. See Indications for more. Global markets Europe stocks wavered between gains and losses, with airlines lower as European air space was shut for a second day due to volcanic ash. The British pound was lower as polls following a televised debate showed that the third-party Liberal Democrats won convincingly, raising the specter of a hung parliament. Chinese developers fell on measures taken to curtail speculation. See Europe Markets for more. See Asia Markets for more. Broker action Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% was cut to neutral from buy at Goldman Sachs, as the broker said investors now have a more realistic view for margins. Goldman kept AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% at buy and McKesson MCK, +0.15% at neutral. Breaking news - See News Viewer for the latest Bank of America Corp. BAC, +2.04% said its first-quarter profit fell to $3.2 billion, or 28 cents a share, from $4.2 billion, or 44 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell 11% to $32 billion. Per share earnings are after preferred stock dividends and accretion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had estimated, on average, profit of 9 cents a share on revenue of $28 billion. General Electric GE, -1.46% said first-quarter profit attributable to shareholders dropped 32% to $1.87 billion, or 17 cents a share, as revenue fell 5% to $36.61 billion. Earnings drops at GE Capital, technology infrastructure and NBC Universal offset growing profits at energy infrastructure. From continuing operations, the industrial bellwether said it earned 21 cents a share, compared to FactSet-compiled estimates of earnings of 17 cents a share on revenue of $37.3 billion. GE said it may evaluate additional restructuring that will improve earnings power going forward. Oracle Corp. ORCL, +1.71% said it'll pay $17 a share in cash to buy Phase Forward Inc. PFWD The deal values the Waltham, Mass. maker of drug development and patient care software at a premium of 30% over its closing price of $13.08 a share on Thursday. New construction of U.S. houses expanded for the third straight month in March, the Commerce Department estimated Friday. Starts rose 1.6% in March to a seasonally adjusted 626,000 annualized units, strongest than the 610,000 pace expected by economists surveyed by MarketWatch. This is the highest level of starts since November 2008. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% was cut to neutral from buy at Goldman Sachs, as the broker said investors now have a more realistic view for margins. Goldman kept AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% at buy and McKesson MCK, +0.15% at neutral.
title: Cardinal Health cut to neutral by Goldman Sachs

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Chuck Carlson, editor of the DRIP Investor newsletter, says that the economy is reverting to a "two yards and a cloud of dust" grind-it-out mentality, but that even with slower potential advances, some setbacks are still on the horizon. During an appearance on the "Your Money with Chuck Jaffe" podcast, Carlson said his firm is currently about 85% invested -- keeping some of its cash on the sidelines because it is waiting for another correction before being fully invested -- and that he likes the technology, health-care and consumers staples sectors. Carlson's newsletter is published by Horizon Investment Services, which also publishes the Dow Theory Forecasts newsletter, and which has its own proprietary stock analysis system. "We have had confirmed new highs by the Dow Jones industrials DJIA, +1.07% and transportation averages saying that the primary trend in this market is bullish right now," Carlson said. "But that doesn't preclude markets from pulling back," and possibly sooner than later, he added. Carlson said the passage of health-care legislation in Washington should help health-care stocks, which are in a sector that was looking promising without the new legislation. "Markets don't like uncertainty," Carlson explained. "If nothing else, whether you like the health care reform or not ... the uncertainty of whether it's actually going to happen has been reduced." Listen to Carlson's views on tech, health care stocks. He added: "It's interesting that people are fearful of health-care stocks when, in fact, there is going to be another $1 trillion dropped into health care over the next 10 years." Carlson suggested Amerisource Bergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% and Hospira Inc. HSP, +0.18% as health-care stocks worth buying now. He also pointed out that one area that the Quadrix system does not currently like is big pharmaceutical companies, saying that brand-name stocks like Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% and Pfizer PFE, +0.54% are actually stocks to sell or avoid right now. "There will certainly be some winners and losers in that world, but ultimately ... it should provide a boost to a lot of players in that group," Carlson said. Among technology stocks, Carlson's picks included International Business Machines IBM, +0.60% Hewlett-Packard Co. HPQ, +1.06% Oracle Corp. ORCL, +1.71% and Cognizant Technology Solutions CTSH, +1.04% Another area Carlson discussed during his interview was financial services, where he said it's not yet time to be investing with the big-name banks; for investors looking to make a financial-services play, Carlson recommended the insurance business, singling out AFLAC AFL, +0.48% and The Travelers Cos. TRV, +0.05% as possible buys. During the "Hold It or Fold It" segment of the program -- when guests issue opinions on stocks requested by audience members -- Carlson suggested selling Barrick Gold Corp. ABX, +0.48% but said he would buy Newmont Mining Corp. NEM, +1.77% in the same space. He put "buy" recommendations on Google GOOG, +2.71% Chipotle Mexican Grill CMG, +1.13% General Mills GIS, +1.60% Big Lots BIG, +2.64% and Ross Stores ROST, +2.39% and slapped "holds" on Emerson Electric EMR, +1.49% Principal Financial Group PFG, +2.54% and Clorox CLX, +2.15% MarketWatch columnist Chuck Jaffe hosts the "Your Money" podcast, interviewing money managers on their market outlook and including picks and pans on stocks that the MarketWatch audience wants to know about. If you'd like to submit a stock or fund for future review, send your name, hometown and the ticker symbols you are interested in to cjaffe@marketwatch.com. title: Carlson: Tech, health care will weather storms

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Hospital and nursing home operators are sharply up while health insurers are mixed, with the nation's biggest carriers in the red. Is this what the House and President Barack Obama had in mind? Well, not exactly, and Monday's stock movements don't tell the whole story, analysts say. But they are an indication of what could be coming down the road in health care. The best indicator of how Sunday's vote by the House will affect the health-care industry probably could be seen in hospital stocks. The sector rallied strongly, and for good reason, says Dave Shove, analyst for BMO Capital Markets in New York. 'We view the event as being much more significant as a driver of investor sentiment.' Tom Gallucci, Lazard Capital Markets "They may be one of the larger beneficiaries because the growth of the uninsured has really hammered them," Shove said. Indeed, hospitals in many cases have had to accept patients regardless of their ability to pay and it's a problem that has left many companies in shambles, such as Tenet Healthcare. THC, +1.76% Now, fueled by the prospect of $940 billion in government assistance to help pay for the care it will be giving, Tenet shares were up more than 9% at the close. Health Management Associates HMA rose even more, climbing 11.3%, as both it and Tenet have been trading below the $10 level for several years. A number of others in the group posted sizable gains and included acute care hospital operators Community Health Systems CYH, -3.65% LifePoint Hospitals Inc. LPNT, -1.67% and Universal Health Services Inc. UHS, -2.45% All three jumped by roughly 6%. Yet Lazard Capital Markets analyst Tom Gallucci is holding back on the euphoria. Gallucci said in a note to clients Monday that he is maintaining his buy rating on Community Health, as well as his hold designations on LifePoint, Health Management, Tenet and Universal Health. "The legislation will result in a limited fundamental impact on our universe of coverage in the near to intermediate term, given that the bulk of the bill is implemented in 2014 [and] beyond," Gallucci wrote. "As such, we view the event as being much more significant as a driver of investor sentiment." Meanwhile, insurers seemed to be taking it on the chin, though that could be deceiving, says Shove. While UnitedHealth UNH, -2.06% HealthNet Inc. HNT, +0.00% and Humana Inc. HUM, +0.48% were all down Monday, those stocks and others had been enjoying solid gains in the days and weeks leading up to Sunday's vote. "With all stocks, everything is relative to their valuations and what they've done recently," Shove said. He added that the industry is about to get a number of new patients as the bill promises to insure 32 million more Americans, but many of those will be unprofitable patients. "In our point of view, we think that's a wash," Shove said. More negative Robert Zirkelbach, spokesman for America's Health Insurance Plans, says that's more of a negative, adding the industry is vehemently opposed to the bill. For one, the bill doesn't provide enough incentive for the uninsured to enroll in a plan right away because the penalties aren't stiff enough. In the first year, the tax penalty is $95, a tariff that many would be willing to pay against much higher priced health insurance. When the penalties rise to $750, that still may be cheaper than getting insured, he says. "We have a health-care cost crisis in this country. And this is going to make it worse," Zirkelbach said. Others on Wall Street feel more assured, however, that whatever Congress plans to throw at insurers already has been thrown. The House's sidecar "reconciliation" bill has yet to be approved by the Senate, which could drastically alter it. "However, we continue to believe money will rotate back into health-care stocks now that the uncertainty of 'reform' is lifted, boosting valuations longer-term, and the worst-case 'public plan' is off the table," Citigroup analyst Charles Boorady said in a note to clients. Help for tech As for other aspects of health care, medical technology faces a slightly smaller fee than expected, as that was reduced at the last minute in House negotiations, BMO's Shove said. And the reform legislation seems bound to help the fate of any firm in or around the pharmaceutical industry with drug benefits expected to stay the same or improve. Drug distributors such as Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% and AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% were all up Monday. Similar gains were enjoyed by pharmacy benefit managers Medco Health Systems MHS and Express Scripts. ESRX, -0.93% Drugmakers enjoyed modest gains on Monday, with giants such as Pfizer Inc. PFE, +0.54% and Eli Lilly & Co. LLY, +0.47% posting 1% gains. "Pretty much everybody gets a pony, except for the taxpayers," said Les Funtleyder, analyst for Miller Tabak in New York, noting that those making more than $250,000 will have to help finance some of the reforms via higher taxes. Funtleyder says, however, that it won't be known for some time whether the legislation has been effective as many of the reforms come into effect in four years. Costs could well continue to soar. "This doesn't do much about costs," he said. "If costs continue to be unsustainable, we're going to have to come back and recast health care again." title: Hospitals gain, insurers fall after vote

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Health insurers hung on to gains Wednesday after President Barack Obama exhorted lawmakers to move forward with a health care-reform plan that included tougher regulation of the nation's carriers. Meanwhile, a number of drug distributors lost ground after the speech, with many down more than 1%. Most major insurers had been up 1% or more ahead of the Obama speech but started losing ground afterward. WellCare WCG, +1.77% led the sector, climbing more than 4.5% after Stifel Nicolaus raised its rating on the company's shares to buy from hold. The company's stock has dropped in recent weeks on a lowered outlook, but an improved picture for Medicare and Medicaid programs has helped temper that. WellCare had been up more than 6% at one point. Amerigroup Inc. AGP still managed to retain gains of 1.4%, while Cigna Corp. CI, -0.34% and Aetna Inc. AET, -0.25% were both up close to1% . The nation's biggest carrier, UnitedHealth Group Inc. UNH, -2.06% was up 0.4% while top rival WellPoint Inc. WLP tacked on roughly 0.7%. HealthNet Inc. eked out gains of 0.9%, and Humana Inc. HUM, +0.48% ended the day unchanged. But Obama's proposals to eliminate "wasteful" subsidies of pharmaceutical companies took a bite out of drug distributors. Drug distribution giants McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% and AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% dropped more than 1.5% while Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% lost 1.1%. Pharmacy benefit manager Medco Health Solutions was off 1.4%. And hospitals and nursing facilities were mixed despite posting healthy gains earlier in the session. Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% was up more than 1.1% while HealthSouth Corp. HLS, +0.00% dropped 1.5% in afternoon dealings. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: Insurers, distributors lose ground after speech

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Rich Moroney, editor of the Dow Theory Forecast and Upside newsletters, says that health care and consumer-discretionary stocks are on the rise, and that there are still good buys in technology, though the sector on the whole is slowing down. During an appearance on the "Your Money with Chuck Jaffe" podcast, Moroney said that health-care companies in general "are scoring well" on the proprietary Quadrix system that forms the basis for his newsletters' picks. "Their momentum scores are holding up because they are more defensive companies that tend to perform well in recessions," he said. "Their value scores are attractive because people are scared about the prospects for health-care reform." Among the biotech stocks with the best scores right now, Moroney pointed out AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Hospira Inc. HSP, +0.18% and Cantel Medical Corp. CMN During the "Hold it or Fold it" portion of the podcast -- where Jaffe's guests gives recommendations on stocks suggested by listeners -- Moroney also praised Stryker Corp. SYK, +1.87% Baxter International BAX, +1.86% Abbott Laboratories ABT, +1.16% and Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% suggesting that all have good prospects over both the short and long haul. On the consumer discretionary side, Moroney said that while it would seem surprising given the current economy to find retail companies with good prospects, it's the off-price sellers and discounters that have been rising to the top of the Quadrix system. He pointed out that Ross Stores ROST, +2.39% and TJX Cos. TJX, +1.08% are standouts in this area, and he also put a "Buy" recommendation on General Mills GIS, +1.60% in the consumer-staples sector. Among technology stocks, Moroney had buys on IBM Corp. IBM, +0.60% and BMC Software BMC, -2.86% and suggested in "Hold It or Fold It" that both Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% and Research in Motion RIMM are stocks with good long-term prospects, although he said he might prefer a slightly better purchase point rather than jumping in right now. Listen to why Moroney expects health-care stocks to lead the market. "In a lot of sectors today, the values are in the higher-quality companies, the companies that have good track records have good operating momentum, have good financial strength," Moroney said. "The stocks that have led since March have been the most speculative, most high-risk stocks. To some extent, that made sense; those were the companies priced for bankruptcy back in March. "Now," he added, "after nine months of months of outperformance by lower-quality high risk stocks, I think -- especially with the market acting a little bumpy here -- the appeal of a high-quality stock like IBM will become quite clear over the next nine months." Among the sectors and stocks Moroney does not favor are financials and materials companies. He put "Sell" recommendations on both Citigroup C, -1.11% and Bank of America BAC, +2.04% MarketWatch senior columnist Chuck Jaffe hosts the "Your Money" podcast every Monday, interviewing money managers on their market outlook and including picks and pans on stocks that the MarketWatch audience wants to know about. If you'd like to submit a stock or fund for future review, send your name, hometown and the ticker symbols you are interested in to cjaffe@marketwatch.com .
