content: Boston Properties quarterly FFO $146.1 mln (6:51 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Boston Properties Inc. BXP, -0.15% a big owner of office buildings in the U.S., said late Tuesday that fourth-quarter funds from operations came in at $146.1 million, or $1.04 a share. That compares to a loss from operations of $0.6 million, or one cent a share, for the same quarter in 2008. Net income available to common shareholders was $53.3 million, or 38 cents a share, in the latest quarter, the real estate investment trust said. Full year 2010 funds from operations will likely be between $4.10 and $4.25 a share, the company added. Pactiv posts 31% higher profit (5:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Pactiv Corp. PTV the maker of Hefty trash bags, reported late Tuesday fourth-quarter net income rose to $72 million, or 54 cents a share, up from $55 million, or 41 cents a share, a year earlier. Earnings from continuing operations came in at $71 million, or 53 cents a share. Sales fell 3% to $854 million from $883 million a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected the company would earn 50 cents a share on $842 in revenue. Pactiv said it expects to earn from 38 cents to 42 cents a share in the first quarter of 2010. Shares of Lake Forest, Ill.-based company fell 12 cents, or 0.5%, to close at $23.33 ahead of the report. The stock is up 8.8% over the past 12 months. QLogic third-quarter profit mostly flat (4:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- QLogic Corp. QLGC, +0.12% late Tuesday reported a fiscal third-quarter net income of $28.6 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $30.8 million, or 24 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. On an adjusted basis, QLogic would have earned 31 cents a share. Revenue slid to $149.1 million from $163.7 million in the same period a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast the networking-equipment company to hand in earnings of 28 cents a share on revenue of $147.2 million. Gilead's quarterly earnings up sharply (4:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Gilead Sciences GILD, +0.82% late Tuesday reported its fourth-quarter net income attributable to Gilead rose to $802.2 million from $560 million in the same quarter a year earlier. The company earned 87 cents a share attributable to Gilead common shareholders, up from 59 cents a share a year ago. Excluding various items, the biotech company would have earned 93 cents a share. Revenue also increased to $2.03 billion from $1.43 billion in the year-earlier period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast Gilead to report earnings of 82 cents a share on revenue of $1.92 billion. McKesson swings to gain in third quarter (4:22 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% reported third-quarter net income of $326 million, or $1.19 a share, a swing from a $20 million loss, or 7 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Reporting after Tuesday's close, the San Francisco-based drug distributor said revenue was $28.3 billion versus $27.1 billion for the year-ago period. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected earnings of $1.18 a share on sales of $27.6 billion. McKesson shares ended trading Tuesday up 1.5% to $62.35. Calamos reports quarterly net income of $4.7 mln (4:19 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Calamos Asset Management Inc. CLMS said late Tuesday that fourth-quarter net income came in at $4.7 million, or 23 cents a share, versus a net loss of $26.1 million, or $1.34 a share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue was $81 million, up from $67 million a year ago. Operating profit was $36.1 million and the operating profit margin was 44.4% versus 32.1% a year earlier. "Our global and international equity strategies turned in outstanding results, helping us capitalize on growing market demand for global equity strategies," Chief Executive John Calamos said in a statement. "As the recovery continues and investors consider adding more equities to their portfolios, we anticipate demand to strengthen, further enhancing potential growth in this area of our business." Sanmina-SCI swings to a $59 million profit (4:17 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sanmina-SCI Corp. SANM, +0.77% on Tuesday reported a fiscal first-quarter profit of $59 million, or 74 cents a share, on revenue of $1.48 billion. During the same period a year ago, the electronics contract manufacturer reported a loss of $26 million,or 29 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, Sanmina would have earned $18 million, or 23 cents a share. By that measure, analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters had forecast Sanmina to earn 13 cents a share on $1.4 billion in revenue. For its fiscal second quarter, Sanmina estimates it will earn between 22 cents and 27 cents a share, excluding one-time items, on revenue in a range of $1.45 billion and $1.55 billion. Molex swings to a profit for the second quarter (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Molex Inc. said Tuesday afternoon that it swung to a profit for the second fiscal quarter as sales rose. For the period ended Dec. 31, Molex MOLX reported earnings of $19.3 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with a loss of $87.2 million, or 50 cents a share, for the same period last year. Excluding a restructuring charge, the company said it would have earned $41.4 million, or 24 cents a share, for the recent period. Revenue rose 9% to $729 million. Analysts were expecting earnings of 22 cents a share on revenue of $709.2 million, according to consensus forecasts from Thomson Reuters. Yahoo posts fourth-quarter sales decline (4:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Yahoo Inc. YHOO on Tuesday reported fourth-quarter net income of $119 million, or 11 cents a share, compared to a loss of $278 million, or 22 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. The results included charges of 4 cents a share related to the company's search deal with Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% and restructuring. Net revenue fell to $1.26 billion from $1.38 billion, Yahoo said. Wall Street analysts on average had been expecting Yahoo to post earnings of 11 cents a share, and $1.23 billion in net revenue, according to Thomson Reuters data. Fimalac revenue climbs on Fitch growth (12:40 PM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Fimalac(FR:FIM), the French owner of Fitch Ratings and Algorithmics, said after the Paris close that fiscal first-quarter revenue rose 2.9% to 140.9 million euros, or 9.7% growth on a comparable basis. Fitch comparable revenue grew 14.4%, while Algorithmics revenue dropped 7% as licenses signed in December will be booked in future quarters. Fimalac booked a 249 million euro gain on selling 20% of Fitch to Hearst Corp. (Corrects spelling of Hearst.) Energy stocks fall with crude prices, broad market (9:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy stocks fell with the broad market on Monday, as crude futures dropped below $75 a barrel on jitters tied to China and Japan. Among the major energy stock benchmarks, the NYSE Arca Oil Index XOI, +2.04% dropped 1% to 1,037. The NYSE Arca Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% dropped 1.3% to 541. The Philadelphia Oil Service Index OSX, +2.53% subtracted 1% to 198. Baker Hughes BHI, +4.27% rose 3.6% to $46.20. Weatherford WFT, +0.88% dropped 8.5% to $16.25. Peabody Energy BTU, +0.05% rose 1.1% to $45.91. Cooper Industries posts higher profit (9:11 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Cooper Industries PLC CBE, +50.00% said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose to $128.8 million, or 76 cents a share, compared to $111.1 million, or 65 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of 67 cents a share, on average. The manufacturer said it expects 2010 earnings from continuing operations of $2.70 to $2.90 a share, excluding restructuring and unusual items. U.S. Steel swings to loss (8:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- U.S. Steel Corp. X, +4.92% on Tuesday reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $267 million, or $1.86 a share, compared to a profit of $290 million, or $2.50 a share, in the year-ago period. Net sales were $3.4 billion, a drop from $4.5 billion in the fourth quarter of 2008. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected on average a loss of $1.56 a share on revenues of $3.1 billion. Peabody Energy earnings fall 68% (8:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Peabody Energy Corp. BTU, +0.05% said Monday its fourth-quarter net income fell by 68% to $92.2 million, or 34 cents a share, from $293.1 million, or $1.09 a share in the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations fell to 41 cents a share from $1.04 a share. The St. Louis coal producer said revenue fell to $1.55 billion from $1.89 billion in the year-ago period. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 29 cents a share and revenue of $1.48 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Looking ahead, Peabody said higher expected seaborne metallurgical and thermal coal prices are anticipated to benefit its results beginning in the second quarter. Grainger earnings per share down 7% (8:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Grainger GWW, +1.73% said Tuesday that it earned $97 million, or $1.27 a share, compared to $108 million, or $1.37 a share, in the year-ago quarter. Sales were $1.63 billion compared to $1.59 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated, on average, earnings per share of $1.21. J&J reports lower fourth-quarter profit (8:10 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% early Tuesday reported fourth-quarter 2009 net income of $2.21 billion, or 79 cents a share, compared with $2.71 billion, or 97 cents a share, for the 2008 period. Excluding various items, J&J would have posted adjusted earnings of $1.02 a share v. 94 cents. Sales increased 9% to $16.6 billion. A poll of analysts by FactSet Research pegged J&J at earnings of 97 cents a share, on revenue of $15.71 billion. J&J also said it now sees the company posting 2010 adjusted earnings of between $4.85 and $4.95 a share. Sherwin-Williams earnings per share up 38% (7:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Sherwin-Williams Co. SHW, +1.78% said Tuesday that it earned $65 million, or 58 cents a share, in the fourth quarter compared to $50 million, or 42 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Sales were $1.6 billion compared to $1.7 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Resesarch estimated, on average, earnings per share of 52 cents. For 2010, the paint maker sees earnings per share of $4.05 to $4.45. FactSet analysts, on average, forecast earnings per share of $4.00 for 2010. FPL Group net income falls 14% (7:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- FPL Group Inc. FPL, +1.97% said Tuesday its fourth-quarter profit fell to $349 million, or 85 cents a share, from $408 million, or $1.01 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings at the Juno Beach, Fla., power producer fell to 79 cents a share from 90 cents a share. Earnings at its Florida Power & Light unit climbed to 45 cents a share, from 38 cents a share, because of unseasonably warm weather. FPL Group's total revenue fell to $3.66 billion from $4 billion. Analysts expected earnings of 74 cents a share and revenue of $4.05 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. FPL Group expects 2010 adjusted earnings of $4.25 a share to $4.65 a share, compared to the Wall Street target of $4.40 a share. FPL Group said it, "does not expect a rapid recovery of the Florida economy." Travelers 4th-quarter net income rose 60% (7:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Travelers Cos., TRV, +0.05% the New York insurer, on Tuesday reported fourth-quarter net income rose 60%. Earnings reached $1.29 billion, or $2.36 a share, from $801 million, or $1.35, in the year-earlier period. Shares outstanding fell to a weighted-average 540.1 million from 590.3 million. Revenue reached $6.46 billion, up 11%. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of earnings of $1.47 a share on revenue of $5.8 billion. (Corrects earnings increase in headline and text.) Verizon posts loss; adds 2.2 million mobile users (7:36 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Verizon Communications Inc. on Tuesday swung to a fourth-quarter loss, as the company incurred a onetime charge for workforce reductions, raised spending to attract wireless subscribers and lost more customers in its traditional wireline business. Yet New York-based Verizon VZ, -0.37% also gained a net 2.2 million wireless subscribers in the fourth quarter to push its nation-leading total to 91.2 million. The net loss attributable to Verizon shareholders totaled $653 million, or 23 cents a share. That was down from net income of $1.24 billion, or 43 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Revenue climbed 9.9% to $27.1 billion, though sales rose a much smaller 0.2% if adjusted for the acquisition of the regional wireless phone company Alltel in January 2009. Excluding one-time costs, Verizon said it would have earned 54 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected adjusted earnings of 55 cents a share on revenue of $27.32 billion. Regions Financial 4th-quarter loss narrows (7:31 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Regions Financial Corp. RF, +1.64% the Birmingham, Ala., banking- and financial-services provider, reported a narrower fourth-quarter net loss, reflecting higher provisions for possible losses on bad loans plus securities sales designed to reduce risk. Regions, which has $142 billion of assets, reported a loss of $543 million, or 46 cents a share, against a loss of $6.22 billion, or $8.97, in the year-earlier period. The loss attributable to common-share holders was 51 cents a share versus $9.01. Excluding the loss on the securities sales, the latest net loss was 46 cents a share. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of a loss of 37 cents for the quarter. The net interest margin, the difference between what a bank takes in on loans and pays out on deposits, was flat at 2.72%. EMC earnings per share up 54% (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- EMC Corp. EMC, +9.92% said Tuesday that it earned $426 million, or 20 cents a share, in the fourth quarter compared to $270 million, or 13 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Sales were $4.1 billion, compared to $4.0 billion last year. Adjusted earnings per share were 33 cents. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated, on average, earnings per share of 30 cents. For 2010, EMC sees earnings per share of 78 cents and sales of $16 billion. FactSet analysts also see 2010 earnings per share of 78 cents. AmerisourceBergen posts 44% EPS gain; lifts view (7:24 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Pharmaceutical group AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% on Tuesday reported fiscal first-quarter net income of $151.3 million against $111 million in the same period a year ago. The company earned 52 cents a diluted share, a 44% gain over 36 cents in the same period a year ago. A survey of analysts from Dow Jones Newswires was expecting the company to earn 46 cents a share. The company reported an 11.5% gain in revenue to $19.3 billion against $17.3 billion in the year-ago period. The company increased its fiscal year 2010 diluted EPS guidance to a range of $1.89 to $1.98, a 12% to 17% increase over the $1.69 diluted EPS from last year. MGIC net loss widens to $280 million (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- MGIC Investment Corp. MTG, +1.01% on Tuesday said its fourth-quarter net loss widened to $280.1 million, or $2.25 a share, from a loss of $275.6 million, or $2.23 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Milwaukee-based mortgage insurance firm fell to $405.5 million from $411.5 million. The financial firm said the weak economy, higher unemployment and lower home prices resulted in an increase in delinquent inventory and elevated incurred losses. Wall Street analysts expected MGIC to lose $3.18 a share, with revenue of $394 million, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Corning profit rebounds, sales rise 41% (7:13 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Specialty materials group Corning Inc. GLW, +1.94% said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter net profit jumped to $740 million, or 47 cents a share, from $249 million, or 16 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter rose 41% to $1.53 billion and the group said earnings excluding one-off items were 44 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had, on average, been expecting adjusted earnings of 42 cents a share. The company said the second half of the year as a whole had been strong for LCD glass demand and that it had seen a resurgence in demand for emissions control products as the auto industry rebuilt supply. The group said it expects a mild economic recovery for the developed world in 2010, along with continued growth in China. Baker Hughes 4th-period net off 81% (6:31 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Baker Hughes Inc., BHI, +4.27% the Houston energy-services giant, reported that fourth-quarter net income fell 81% on 24% lower revenue. Earnings were $84 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with $432 million, or $1.41, in the year-earlier period. The latest period reflects 16 cents a share of costs of reorganization, severance and acquisitions, as well as an increase in the allowance for doubtful accounts. Revenue fell to $2.43 billion from $3.19 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of 35 cents a share of profit on $2.31 billion of revenue. DuPont returns to profit as it ups 2010 outlook (6:08 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Chemicals giant DuPont DD, +2.74% returned to profitability in the fourth quarter and increased its 2010 earnings outlook. The Dow Jones Industrial Average component swung to a profit of $441 million, or 48 cents a share, with revenue rising to $6.81 billion from $6.07 billion. Volumes grew 10% while raw material, energy and freight costs dropped by around 20%. DuPont had taken a $535 million restructuring charge in the fourth quarter of 2008. DuPont increased its full-year 2010 earnings guidance to a range of $2.15 to $2.45 per share versus the previous guidance of $2.10 to $2.40 per share. Due to strong pension fund performance, the company now expects pension expense to be about 10 cents per share, lower than originally anticipated. In addition, the company is estimating a first-quarter 5 cents per share exchange loss resulting from devaluation of the Venezuelan currency. Analysts polled by FactSet expected quarterly earnings of 41 cents a share and 2010 earnings of $2.28 a share. Novartis Q4 profit rises, new CEO appointed (2:49 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis AG NVS, -0.49% (CH:NOVN)reported Tuesday a fourth-quarter net profit of $2.3 billion compared with $1.5 billion in the same period a year ago. Net sales at the Basel, Switzerland firm rose 28% to $12.93 billion. The increase was 20% in local currencies. The "core EPS," which strips out various items including amortization of intangible assets and impairments, was $1.26, compared to analyst estimates of $1.19 on sales of $11.95 billion. Novartis said it expects to increase group net sales in 2010 at a mid-single-digit percentage rate in local currencies based on the rapidly growing contributions of recently launched products and targeted investments in emerging growth markets. Daniel Vasella, chairman and CEO of Novartis, will step down, and Joe Jimenez, currently division head of the pharmaceutical business, has been appointed as the new chief executive, Novartis also said. (Corrects quarterly net profit figure.) De La Rue banknote volumes improve (2:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. banknote printer De La Rue(UK:DLAR)said Tuesday that trading since Sept. 26 has been strong, with banknote and paper volumes showing an increased run rate compared to the first half of fiscal 2010 and well ahead of the comparable period a year earlier. The group said its cash processions solutions arm has continued to experience difficult trading conditions, while performance in security products and identity systems has been broadly in line with the first half of the fiscal year. The group said its trading outlook remains in line with previous expectations and that, as previously noted, banknote volumes should remain at similar levels, but the unusually strong margin mix in currency may not be repeated. Sage cuts debt as software market remains subdued (2:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. business software company Sage Group(UK:SGE)said Tuesday that trading in the three months to Dec. 31 was consistent with management expectations across all its regions as subscription revenue growth continued to offset subdued markets for software and related services. The group said net debt at Dec. 31 was 392 million pounds ($636 million), compared to 439 million pounds at the end of September, reflecting strong cash generation. CEO Paul Walker said Sage had seen no change to its operating environment over the period. KPN's Q4 profit up, share buyback announced (2:27 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- Dutch telecom group KPN(NL:KPN)said Tuesday its fourth-quarter net income rose to 1.08 billion euros ($1.52 billion) from 296 million euros in the same period a year ago. KPN Group revenue and other income for existing operations, excluding disposed operations at Getronics, fell 6.9% to 3.37 billion euros from 3.62 billion euros. Its reported revenue dropped 9.3%. The firm confirmed its outlook for 2010 and announced a new 1 billion euros buyback program for 2010. Severn Trent: water consumption has stabilized (2:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. water utility Severn Trent(UK:SVT)said Tuesday that trading since the start of October has been in line with its expectations and that the decline in Water consumption has now stabilized. The group said it estimates that the year-on-year impact on revenue will be around 5 million pounds ($8.1 million) to 10 million pounds, compared to the 15 million pounds to 20 million pounds previously indicated. The group said bad debt levels remain around 2.3% and that it expects net capital expenditure for the year will be around 610 million pounds to 630 million pounds, in line with expectations. The group said the prolonged cold weather has caused an increase in leaks, but that the additional cost of repair isn't material. Siemens AG's Q1 profit up, but revenue down 8% (1:25 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- German industrial conglomerate Siemens AG SI (DE:SIE)said Tuesday its fiscal first-quarter profit rose to 1.48 billion euros ($2.09 billion) from 1.20 billion euros in the same period a year ago. In the three months ended on Dec. 31, 2009, revenue fell 8% to 17.35 billion euros from 19.63 billion euros. Analysts were expecting a profit of 950 million euros on sales of 17.9 billion euros. Ongoing weak customer demand impacted new orders, which fell 11% on an organic basis, from 22.2 billion euros in the prior-year period to 19.0 billion euros, but were slightly above the level of the immediately preceding fourth quarter of 2009, said Siemens, which makes products ranging from gas turbines to trains to magnetic resonance imaging systems. After a double-digit percentage decline in orders in fiscal 2009, Siemens expects a mid-single-digit percentage decline in organic revenue in fiscal 2010 "due to the stabilizing effect of its strong order backlog." Siemens also projects total sectors profit between 6.0 billion euros and 6.5 billion euros in fiscal 2010, and an increase of approximately 20% in income from continuing operations compared to some 2.5 billion euros in the prior year. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Pharmaceutical group AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% on Tuesday reported fiscal first-quarter net income of $151.3 million against $111 million in the same period a year ago. The company earned 52 cents a diluted share, a 44% gain over 36 cents in the same period a year ago. A survey of analysts from Dow Jones Newswires was expecting the company to earn 46 cents a share. The company reported an 11.5% gain in revenue to $19.3 billion against $17.3 billion in the year-ago period. The company increased its fiscal year 2010 diluted EPS guidance to a range of $1.89 to $1.98, a 12% to 17% increase over the $1.69 diluted EPS from last year.
title: AmerisourceBergen posts 44% EPS gain; lifts view

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Having your industry under Congress' microscope can be a good thing. Just ask the 51 health-care companies in the Standard & Poor's 500. The stocks of 90% of these companies were within 10% of 52-week highs, while more than four-fifths are within 5% of that mark, as of Friday's close. And 28 of the companies, more than half, continued to touch new highs this week, all hitting a new closing threshold since Monday. While some of this remarkable performance is due to the overall S&P 500 index hitting its own new annual highs this week, analysts and reform advocates say the performance of these companies over the last few months can be partly attributed to the diluting of proposals for overhauling the nation's health-care system. Some of it also may be due to a market overreaction that occurred when Congress first started tackling the issue, says Les Funtleyder, health-care analyst for Miller Tabak & Co., and author of "Healthcare Investing: Profiting From the New World of Pharma, Biotech and Health Care Services." "Reform won't be as bad as people think because people have a tendency to misprice risk," Funtleyder said. "In this case, it got mispriced to the lower side." The best performing companies that have reached new 52-week highs in the last few days include three of the nation's largest insurers, goliaths UnitedHealth Group Inc. UNH, -2.06% and Wellpoint Inc. WLP along with Humana Inc. HUM, +0.48% Wellpoint has broken past $66 after languishing in the mid-$40 range just three months ago. A similar pattern shows up in the chart of UnitedHealth, now heading toward $34 after dropping to around $24 in October. All six insurers in the S&P hit a rough patch at the same time in October as it was uncertain whether they faced the prospect of competing against the government to offer health insurance. Since then, they've all moved up. "I would tell you that 90% of the share performance over the last [few] months has been due to the news that reform is not going to put these companies out of business," said David Shove, analyst for BMO Capital Markets. "They were valued as if this business was going to go away." Two of the other six, Cigna Corp. CI, -0.34% and Coventry Health Care Inc. CV.H, +0.00% hit 52-week closing highs this month and remain within 5% of those marks. The sixth, Aetna Inc. AET, -0.25% hit its 52-week high nearly a year ago and remains 9% below that mark. But Aetna has been making the same upward progress in the market as other insurers. The company suffered a setback when it reported earlier this week that it expects 2010 earnings to be below that of 2009, but it has rebounded and threatens to climb again. Does an improving stock market mean that health-reform legislation has lost its bite when it comes to regulation? U.S. Rep. John Garamendi, D-Calif., thinks so. "What it's saying is a lot of folks are betting Congress will bring 30 million people into the insurance market without protections," said Garamendi, "and without a proper regulatory environment." Garamendi, formerly California's insurance commissioner and currently active in enacting health-care overhaul, criticized the Senate's version. He says the body developed a health-care bill without a public option and without proper safeguards for consumers. Others aren't so sure a watered-down Senate bill is the only reason for rising health-care firm fortunes. "It's an easing of fear that health-care reform may not turn out as bad for them as they thought," Paul Ginsburg, president of the Center for Studying Health System Changes, said. "There certainly are positive aspects of reform for these companies." Ginsburg said the ultimate fallout of the bill will be more drugs for companies to sell, and more patients being covered. Insurers, however, aren't the only health-care companies to reap big benefits over the last few months. A baker's dozen of medical device makers and pharmaceutical companies hit new highs this week, while seven others are within 5% of that level. Among the big winners are Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% Pfizer Inc. PFE, +0.54% Medtronic Inc. MDT, +2.24% Millipore Corp. MIL, -3.92% and Stryker Corp. SYK, +1.87% Others are King Pharmaceuticals KG, +4.65% Watson Pharmaceuticals WPI, +0.00% Hospira Inc. HSP, +0.18% Varian Medical Systems Inc. VAR, +0.92% Thermo Fisher Scientific TMO, +0.26% Zimmer Holdings Corp. ZMH and Waters Corp. WAT, +0.04% The legislative effect on these stocks isn't as clear; in fact, medical device makers should be suffering if that were the case. Device makers face the prospect of an added tax on their revenue under current proposals. But device makers also haven't developed a large number of new products of late, says Miller Tabak's Funtleyder, and it still hasn't hurt them. "The tax is certainly not a good thing for them," he said. "But they're likely to sort of tread water." For pharmaceuticals, the rise in that industry's fortunes may be more cyclical, says Douglas Christopher, analyst for Crowell, Weedon in Los Angeles. The industry has been out of favor with investors for some time now due to patent issues and a worrisome regulatory climate outside the overall health-care effort in Congress. Now, he says, fundamentals are beginning to point to more reasonable growth. The industry is valued a notch or two below where it should be, with price-to-earnings showing room for about 5% to 8% growth. Has the health-care overhaul movement had any effect? "I guess it may have held it back from moving higher than it has," Christopher said. "It's been a strong performer, despite that." Other companies that have touched 52-week highs this week are, in the biotech sector, Biogen Idec Inc. BIIB, +0.74% and Life Technologies Corp. LIFE, -1.85% In health-care services, Davita Inc. DVA, -0.09% Lab Corp. of America LH, +0.14% and PerkinElmer Inc. PKI, +1.14% reached new plateaus. The only hospital firm in the S&P 500, Tenet Healthcare THC, +1.76% hit a new high while medical suppliers Patterson Cos. Inc. PDCO, -0.27% Baxter International Inc. BAX, +1.86% and Dentsply International Inc. XRAY, +0.72% did the same. Among pharmaceutical distributors, AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% reached a new level for the last 12 months, as did pharmacy benefit manager Medco Health Solutions Inc. MHS More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 2 sexy ways to get paid to save
title: Health-care overhaul pushes stocks higher

content: N/A
title: Buying Health-Care Stocks

content: Adobe swings to fourth-quarter loss (4:09 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Adobe Systems Inc. ADBE, +1.67% on Tuesday reported a fiscal fourth-quarter loss of $32 million, or 6 cents a share, compared to net income of $245.9 million, or 46 cents a share in the same period last year. The San Jose-based maker of design software said revenue for the period ended in November fell to $757.3 million from $915.3 million. Excluding special items, Adobe said earnings for the quarter were 39 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had estimated Adobe would report earnings excluding special items of 37 cents a share, and $752.5 million in revenue. Pitney Bowes gives full-year forecast (9:16 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Pitney Bowes Inc. PBI, -0.73% on Tuesday reaffirmed its 2009 adjusted earnings forecast of $2.19 to $2.31 a share, but changed its outlook for earnings from continuing operations to a range of $1.98 to $2.12 a share. The revision reflects an expected fourth-quarter charge of 13 cents to 15 cents a share related to its transformation program, which is expected to result in the elimination of up to 10% of its workforce. For 2010, the Stamford, Conn.-based postage-meter and mail-management company said it expects to post adjusted earnings of $2.30 to $2.50 a share and earnings from continuing operations of $1.75 to $2.11 a share. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of $2.26 a share for 2009 and $2.39 a share for 2010. AmerisourceBergen sees better-than-expected profit (8:43 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Tuesday that it expects to post a December-quarter per-share profit several cents above the consensus of 43 cents, citing revenue growth of more than 10% in the quarter as well as the sale of generic pharmaceuticals. The drug-distribution giant also predicted full-year earnings at the high end of its previously announced forecast range of $1.82 to $1.92 a share. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a full-year profit of $1.90 a share. FactSet Research posts higher quarterly profit (7:14 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- FactSet Research Systems Inc. FDS, +0.49% said Tuesday that its first-quarter earnings rose to $36.1 million, or 74 cents a share, from $35.6 million, or 73 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue dipped to $155.2 million from $155.6 million. On average, analysts polled by FactSet were expecting earnings of 74 cents a share and sales of $155.9 million. The Norwalk, Conn.-based financial-information provider said it expects to report a second-quarter profit of 73 cents to 75 cents a share on revenue of $154 million to $158 million. Magellan lifts 2009 earnings forecast (6:42 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Health care management group Magellan Health Services Inc. MGLN, +0.09% on Tuesday lifted its earnings guidance for 2009 and provided its first forecast for 2010 results. Magellan said it now expects to report earnings of $2.77 to $2.95 a share for 2009, compared to its previous forecast of $2.41 to $2.70 a share. For 2010 the group is expecting to report revenue in the range of $3 billion to $3.2 billion and earnings of between $2.73 and $3.29 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting earnings of $2.62 a share on average for 2009 and $2.91 a share for 2010. Greenbrier agrees modified contract with GE (6:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- The Greenbrier Cos. GBX, +0.20% said Tuesday that it has agreed with a subsidiary of General Electric Co. GE, -1.46% to modify the terms of an order for railcars. Greenbrier, which has been renegotiating the contract for months, said that under the new agreement GE will buy up to 6,000 railcars, with the first 3,800 tank cars and hopper cars to be built by July 2013. Under the terms of the original contract, Greenbrier was to manufacture up to 11,900 railcars over an eight-year period, with the last 8,500 dependent on Greenbrier fulfilling certain contractual agreements. Greenbrier said the "blended purchase price" on the first 3,800 units is an increase from the original contract and that delivery has been extended by 27 months. Greenbrier will also have first refusal rights on future railcar orders through 2018 and has signed a new five-year maintenance deal worth $25 million a year. The company said the new deal will maintain production at or above current levels for at least two years. Serco reaffirms guidance (2:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. services company Serco Group(UK:SRP)on Tuesday reaffirmed its guidance for double-digit revenue growth and a 0.3 percentage point increase in its adjusted pretax profit margin for 2009. The company also noted that its acquisition of SI International is expected to add around 10% to its revenue and to lift its adjusted operating profit margin to around 5.7% from 5.3%. Over the medium term, Serco expects revenue to grow to around 5 billion pounds ($8.1 billion) and adjusted operating profit margin to reach around 6.3% by the end of 2012. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Tuesday that it expects to post a December-quarter per-share profit several cents above the consensus of 43 cents, citing revenue growth of more than 10% in the quarter as well as the sale of generic pharmaceuticals. The drug-distribution giant also predicted full-year earnings at the high end of its previously announced forecast range of $1.82 to $1.92 a share. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a full-year profit of $1.90 a share.
title: AmerisourceBergen sees better-than-expected profit

content: Glu Mobile cuts losses for the third quarter (5:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Glu Mobile reduced its net loss for the third quarter as the maker of mobile games was able to scale back its costs. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Glu GLUU, +1.89% reported a net loss of $3.99 million, or 13 cents a share, compared to a loss of $56.9 million, or $1.93 a share, for the same period the previous year. On a non-GAAP basis, the company said its net loss for the quarter would have totaled 3 cents a share for the recent quarter. Revenue fell 18% to $19.6 million. Analysts were expecting a loss of 12 cents a share on revenue of $18.9 million, according to consensus forecasts from Thomson Reuters. Pitney Bowes lifts net profit, narrows outlook (5:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Pitney Bowes Inc. PBI, -0.73% reported late Tuesday third-quarter net income rose to $103 million, or 50 cents a share, from $98 million, or 47 cents, a year ago. Excluding one-time items, earnings from ongoing operations fell to 55 cents a share from 67 cents. Revenue for the three months ended Sept. 30 fell 12% to $1.36 billion from $1.55 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had predicted the Stamford, Conn.-based postage meter and mail management company would earn 57 cents a share on $1.41 billion in revenue. The company narrowed its full-year earnings outlook to $2.19 to $2.31 a share from a previous range of $2.09 to $2.21. Pitney Bowes shares rose 0.6% ahead of the report to close at $24.67. The stock is down 2.3% from where it traded 12 months ago. Montpelier reports quarterly net income of $148M (5:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Montpelier Re Holdings MRH said late Tuesday that third-quarter net income came in at $148 million, or $1.68 a share, up from a net loss of $142.2 million, or $1.69 a share, a year earlier. Operating profit, which excludes net realized investment gains and losses, came in at $62 million, or 71 cents a share, in the latest period. Montpelier Re was expected to make 72 cents a share, according to the average estimate of five analysts in a Thomson Reuters survey. Con-way third-quarter profit slides (4:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Con-Way Inc. CNW, +7.14% late Tuesday reported its third-quarter net income fell to $13.5 million, or 27 cents a share, from $40.5 million, or 81 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Net income applicable to common shareholders was also $13.5 million in the quarter. Revenue totaled $1.13 billion, down from $1.37 billion a year ago. Kraft lifts profit forecast; still eyeing Cadbury (4:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Kraft Foods KFT the world's No. 2 food maker, late Tuesday reported third-quarter net income of $824 million, or 56 cents a share. In the year-earlier quarter, Kraft earned 34 cents a share, excluding a huge gain from the sale of the Post cereals business. Sales fell 5.7% to $9.8 billion. Analysts had forecast Kraft would earn 48 cents a share on sales of $10.3 billion, according to FactSet Research. Kraft also said it was still interested in buying Cadbury and raised its 2009 profit forecast by 4 cents to $1.97 a share. But the company trimmed its sales outlook. Kraft shares, one of 30 stocks in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, closed Tuesday at $27.54. Hartford reports quarterly net loss of $220 mln (4:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hartford Financial Services Group HIG, -0.41% reported a third-quarter net loss of $220 million, or 79 cents per common share, versus a net loss of $2.63 billion, or $8.74 per common share, a year earlier. Core earnings, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses and other items, came in at $660 million, or $1.56 per common share, in the latest period, Hartford said. Hartford was expected to make a profit of $1.11 a share, according to the average estimate of 18 analysts in a Thomson Reuters survey. Hartford forecast 2009 core earnings of 85 cents per common share to $1.05 per common share. That was up from the insurer's previous guidance for 2009 core earnings of zero to 20 cents per share. Hartford shares rose 3.3% to $26.67 in after-hours trading. Unum reports quarterly profit of $221.1 million (4:07 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Unum Group UNM, +0.68% said late Tuesday that third-quarter net income came in at $221.1 million, or 66 cents per common share, more than double a year earlier when the disability insurer made $108 million, or 32 cents per common share. Excluding net realized investment gains and losses, Unum said it made $211.6 million, or 64 cents per common share, in the third quarter of 2009, compared to $216.9 million, or 64 cents per common share, in the third quarter of 2008. Unum was expected to make 64 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 15 analysts in a Thomson Reuters survey. Unum stuck to its previous guidance for full year 2009 operating earnings to be in a range of $2.50 and $2.60 per common share. Vornado's net, FFO rise (9:41 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Vornado Realty Trust VNO, -0.33% on Tuesday said its third-quarter net income rose to $126.3 million, or 69 cents a share, from $22.7 million, or 14 cents a share, in the same period the prior year. Funds from operations, adjusted for comparability, rose to $221.4 million, or $1.18 a share, from $193.3 million, or $1.17 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected FFO of $1.17 a share, on average. Energy stocks slip with broad market (9:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy stocks fell in early action on Tuesday. The NYSE Arca Oil Index XOI, +2.04% fell 1.5% to 1,043. The NYSE Arca Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% dropped 1.5% to 484. The Philadelphia Oil Service Index OSX, +2.53% dropped 1.5% to 186. Expeditors International posts lower profit (9:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Expeditors International EXPD, +2.73% said Tuesday that its third-quarter profit fell 33% to $57.7 million, or 27 cents a share, from $85.6 million, or 39 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue for the transportation company declined to $1.04 billion from $1.56 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a profit, on average, of 29 cents a share on revenue of $1.01 billion. Marathon Oil net income falls 80% (8:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Marathon Oil MRO, +5.29% said Tuesday its third-quarter net income fell to $413 million, or 58 cents a share, from $2.06 billion, or $2.90 a share in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income fell to 61 cents a share from $2.76 a share. Revenue fell to $14.5 billion from $22.3 billion. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 59 cents a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Marathon said its Athabasca Oil Sands Project expansion is on track to begin mining operations in the second half of 2010. Marathon plans spud three additional wells in the Marcellus play in West Virginia by the end of the year. Diebold loses 11 cents a share, cuts 2009 view (8:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Diebold Inc. DBD, +7.32% said Tuesday that it lost $7 million, or 11 cents a share, in the third quarter. In the same period a year ago, Diebold earned $47 million, or 70 cents a share. Earnings from continuing operations were 37 cents a share compared to 72 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue fell to $645 million from $869 million. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated, on average, earnings per share of 41 cents and sales of $737 million. Diebold lowered its 2009 earnings-per-share forecast to $1.34-$1.39 from $1.34-$1.52. Revenue guidance was cut to a decline of 13%-9% from a previously forecast drop of 13%-7%. FactSet analysts expect 2009 earnings per share of $1.75. Cablevision profit more than triples (8:31 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Cablevision Systems Corp. CVC, -0.36% said Tuesday that third-quarter profit more than tripled on improved results at its cable television systems and networks. The company said net income was $98.9 million, or 33 cents a share, compared with a profit of $30.9 million, or 10 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. Revenue rose to $1.84 billion from $1.75 billion. Analysts were expecting a profit of 26 cents a share on sales of $1.82 billion, according to a poll taken by Thomson Reuters. HCP results hit by impairments, litigation (8:21 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- HCP HCP, -0.68% on Tuesday said third-quarter funds from operations, a key profitability measure for real estate investment trusts, fell to 11 cents a share from 70 cents in the year-ago period. The S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% constituent said the latest quarter's FFO was 52 cents a share before impairments and a charge related to an accrued liability in connection with a jury verdict in the Ventas litigation. For the full year, HCP forecast FFO in the range of $1.65 and $1.71 a share, after impairments and litigation provision. MasterCard swings to profit (8:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- MasterCard Inc. MA, +2.82% reported Tuesday a third-quarter profit of $452 million, or $3.45 a share, compared to a loss of $194 million, or $1.48 a share, in the year-ago period. Net revenues rose 2%, to $1.36 billion. Excluding special items, profit was $3.48 a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected, on average, profit of $2.94 a share on revenue of $1.35 billion. Credit card company MasterCard said it saw a 7.6% year-on-year increase in the number of transactions processed, to 5.8 billion. Rowan Cos. net income falls 31% (8:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Rowan Companies Inc. RDC, +4.43% on Tuesday said its third-quarter net income fell to $78.4 million or 69 cents a share, from $114.1 million or $1 a share in the year-ago period. Excluding a tax benefit, earnings totaled 54 cents a share in the latest quarter. Revenue dropped 18% to $1.23 billion. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 51 cents a share and revenue of $1.28 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. "While excess rig supply has, and will likely continue to, put pressure on day rates, we believe global demand for jack-ups and land rigs bottomed during the third quarter," the company said. Tenet loses a penny a share in quarter (7:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Tenet Healthcare Corp. THC, +1.76% said Tuesday that it lost $3 million, or 1 cent a share in the third quarter. In the same period a year ago, Tenet earned $104 million, or 22 cents a share. Net operating revenue rose 5.2% to $2.24 billion, compared to $2.13 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated, on average, a loss per share of 2 cents and sales of $2.23 billion. ICE reports higher quarterly profit (7:46 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- IntercontinentalExchange Inc. ICE, +1.50% Tuesday reported third-quarter net income of $86.9 million, or $1.18 a share, compared with $75 million, or $1.04 a share, in the same quarter in 2008. Total revenue rose 27% to $256.3 million, the exchange operator said before the opening bell. The consensus Wall Street profit estimate was $1.15 a share, according to a Thomson Reuters poll of 18 analysts. Cameron International net income falls 23% (7:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Well driller Cameron International CAM, -1.67% said Tuesday its third-quarter net income fell 23% to $124.9 million, or 56 cents a share, from $163 million, or 71 cents a share in the year-ago period. The latest period included a pretax charge of 2 cents a share. Excluding the charge, earnings were 58 cents a share. Revenue dropped 18% to $1.23 billion. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 51 cents a share and revenue of $1.28 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Cameron said it expects 2009 earnings of $2.26 to $2.30 a share. Wall Street analysts expect year-end earnings of $2.22 a share. Marvel's third-quarter earnings decline (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Marvel Entertainment Inc. MVL, +1.31% said Tuesday that its third-quarter earnings fell to $20.4 million, or 26 cents a share, from $50.6 million, or 64 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. The company, which owns popular comic-book icons such as Spider-Man, Iron Man and X-Men, reported that sales declined to $106 million from $182 million. Marvel also said that it still expects its deal to be acquired by Walt Disney Co. DIS, +1.93% to close by the end of the year. American Tower Corp. profit rises (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- American Tower Corp. AMT, +0.72% said on Tuesday that its third-quarter profit rose to $67.6 million, or 17 cents a share, from $60.6 million, or 15 cents a share a year ago. Revenues climbed to $444.1 million, from $409.3 million a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the company to earn 17 cents a share. AmerisourceBergen powers past earnigs target (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Tuesday its fourth-quarter net income rose 13% to $130 million, or 44 cents a share, from $115 million, or 37 cents a share in the year-ago period. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 40 cents a share and revenue of $18.1 billion, according to a survey of analysts by FactSet Research. Revenue increased 9% to $18.7 billion. Operating income rose 11% to $224.6 million. AmerisourceBergen Corp. said it expects 2010 operating income of $1.82 to $1.92 a share, compared to the Wall Street expectation of $1.83 a share. Frontier Comm earnings per share rise to 17 cents (7:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Frontier Communications FTR, +2.49% said Tuesday that third-quarter earnings were $52 million, or 17 cents a share, compared to $47 million, or 15 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue fell to $527 million compared to $558 million, down 6%. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated, on average, earnings per share of 15 cents and sales of $531 million. Emerson ups dividend as profit falls 26% (6:52 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- St. Louis conglomerate Emerson EMR, +1.49% said fiscal fourth-quarter net income dropped 26% to $506 million, or 67 cents a share, as sales fell 21% to $5.32 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected a profit of 60 cents a share on sales of $5.38 billion. It announced a 1.5% increase in the dividend to 33.5 cents a share, payable on Dec. 10 to holders on record on Nov. 13. Underlying sales, which strips out currency swings and asset sales, are expected to drop 5% to 7% in fiscal 2010 with a flat to slightly down operating profit margin. Dana Holding narrows quarterly loss (6:49 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Dana Holding Corp. DAN, +3.08% reported a third-quarter net loss of $46 million, or 45 cents a share, narrower than the company's loss of $264 million, or $2.66 a share, seen in the same period during 2008. Both quarterly losses included dividend payments on preferred stock amounting to $8 million. The Maumee, Ohio-based supplier of automotive parts had quarterly sales of $1.33 billion, down 31% from the prior year's $1.93 billion. On a quarter-to-quarter basis, sales improved 12%, Dana said. Analysts had been looking for a quarterly loss of 5 cents a share, according to data compiled by FactSet Research. Dana noted that third-quarter gross margin widened to 6.2% from 2.5% a year earlier, reflecting cost-cutting efforts and higher pricing. "We remain on target to achieve our 2009 objectives for cost reductions, pricing improvements, and cash generation," said Jim Sweetnam, Dana's president and chief executive, in the earnings release. Westlake profit rises 8.8% (6:17 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Westlake Chemical Corp. WLK, +2.91% said Tuesday that its third-quarter net income rose 8.8% to $29.8 million, or 45 cents a share, from $27.4 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier. The group said revenue fell 41% to $632.6 million, but its cost of sales declined faster, shrinking 44% to $560 million. The group said its earnings also benefited by around 4 cents a share from a lower effective tax rate. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings of 20 cents a share. Westlake said revenue was higher compared to the second quarter, due to higher prices for most of its major products. Metro's net profit fell to 72 million euros (3:20 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- German retailer Metro AG(DE:MEO)said Tuesday its third-quarter net profit declined to 72 million euros ($106 million) from 183 million euros in the same period a year ago. Revenue fell 4.6% to 15.6 billion euros from a year ago. Ebit before special items amounted to 357 million euros from 361 million euros in the same quarter a year ago. ING to sell adviser network to Lightyear Capital (3:02 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- ING, ING, +0.06% (NL:INGA)the Amsterdam financial-services giant, definitively agreed to sell its adviser network and three of the network's five broker-dealers to the New York private equity firm Lightyear Capital LLC. Terms weren't disclosed. In a statement on Tuesday, Lightyear said that Valerie Brown, chief executive of ING Advisor Network, would continue to run the business. The three broker-dealers Lightyear is acquiring are Financial Network Investment Corp., Multi-Financial Securities Corp., and PrimeVest Financial Services Inc. For the year ended June 30, the broker-dealers, operating within ING Advisor Network, posted gross revenue of $653 million with account assets of $70.2 billion, and employed 5700 representatives. Subject to conditions including regulatory clearance, the companies hope to close the deal in the first quarter. BMW's third-quarter profit tumbles 74% (2:53 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- German carmaker BMW(DE:BMW)said Tuesday its third-quarter net profit dropped 74% to 78 million euros ($115 million) from the same period a year ago. Revenue fell by 6.6 % to 11.76 billion euros. BMW said "it cannot be assumed that an enduring recovery has taken hold." The carmaker expects the number of cars it sells in 2009 to be between 10% and 15% lower than in the previous year. In that case, BMW will report a positive result for the financial year 2009, it said. Flagstar Bancorp loss widens; CEO named chairman (2:04 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Flagstar Bancorp Inc., FBC, -0.28% the Troy, Mich., bank-holding company, reported a third-quarter net loss of 64 cents a share, said its chairman retired, and said it would "better align expenses with revenues." In a statement on Tuesday, Flagstar reported a loss for the latest quarter of $298.2 million, compared with a loss of $62.1 million, or 79 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Shares outstanding at Sept. 30 rose to 468.5 million from 83.6 million. The company, which operates 176 banking offices in Michigan, Indiana and Georgia and 42 home-loan centers in 18 states, also said that President and Chief Executive Joseph P. Campanelli would add the post of chairman, succeeding Thomas J. Hammond, who retired. At Sept. 30, total assets rose to $14.82 billion from $14.16 billion at Sept. 30, 2008, and fell from $16.42 billion at June 30, 2009. Swiss Re returns to profit (1:56 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss Re(CH:RUKN)swung to a 334 million Swiss franc profit in the third quarter, helped by growing profits in property and casualty, a return to profit in life and health and fewer markets-related losses. Swiss Re had lost 304 million francs in the prior-year period, and the 2009 third quarter included 706 million francs of mark-to-market losses on corporate bond hedges and by impairments of 263 million francs, mainly in the securitized products portfolio. While the market fundamentals point towards higher prices for January renewals, restored industry capital and the absence of hurricanes may partially delay the market correction. Teva 3rd-quarter net up 2.9%, sales up 25% (1:53 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. TEVA, +0.29% the Jerusalem drugmaker, reported that third-quarter net income rose 2.9% on 25% higher sales. Earnings reached $649 million, or 72 cents a share, from $631 million, or 77 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Adjusted earnings were 89 cents, up 16%. Shares outstanding rose 9.3% to 915 million. Sales rose to $3.55 billion from $2.84 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 88 cents a share of profit on $3.65 billion of sales. Foreign-exchange translations knocked 6%, or $160 million, off the sales line, Teva reported on Tuesday. Sales of its flagship drug, the multiple-sclerosis treatment Copaxone, rose 38% in the quarter to $776 million. Sales of Azilect for Parkinson's disease rose 39% to $64 million. At Oct. 23, Teva had 210 product applications awaiting final clearance by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. UBS forecasts progress after $552 million loss (1:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- UBS UBS, +0.40% (CH:UBSN)said it swung to a 564 million Swiss franc loss ($552 million) in the third quarter, after taking 2.15 billion francs in charges as the value of UBS' own debt improved, the bank took a loss on the sale of UBS Pactual and on a loss on the conversion by the Swiss government of mandatory convertible notes. A better performance in the investment bank's fixed income, currencies and commodities business helped it to an underlying pretax profit of 1.56 billion francs. The company's outflows edged lower to 36.7 billion francs from 39.5 billion in the second quarter and 83.6 billion in the year-earlier period. It sees further progress in future quarters, particularly in 2010 but dependant on the market's performance. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Drug distribution giant AmerisourceBergen reported a 22% jump in per-share income for the fourth quarter on Tuesday, driven largely by a near-double-digit rise in sales. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% said net income was $130.1 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with $114.9 million, or 36 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales for the Chesterbrook, Pa.-based company were $18.7 billion, compared with the $17.2 billion from last year, a 9.1% rise. The company was expected to post earnings of 40 cents a share, according to a poll of analysts by FactSet Research. The upside surprise gave a lift to Amerisource shares, which were up 2.6% amid a down market. "We have great positive momentum going into the new fiscal year," Chief Executive R. David Yost, said in a press statement, "and in fiscal year 2010, we expect to achieve diluted earnings per share in the range of $1.82 to $1.92, an 8% to 14% increase over diluted earnings per share from continuing operations in fiscal 2009." The FactSet estimate calls for earnings of $1.84 a share for the year. Brian Sozzi, analyst for Wall Street Strategies, said in a note to clients that there may be some disappointment on the Street in the full-year forecast since, he noted, the consensus estimate had been $2.04. "But we hasten to indicate that AmerisourceBergen traditionally errs on the side of caution and then delivers upside relative to guidance," Sozzi wrote. He reiterated his buy rating on the stock. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’
title: AmerisourceBergen profits rise on sales growth

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Tuesday its fourth-quarter net income rose 13% to $130 million, or 44 cents a share, from $115 million, or 37 cents a share in the year-ago period. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 40 cents a share and revenue of $18.1 billion, according to a survey of analysts by FactSet Research. Revenue increased 9% to $18.7 billion. Operating income rose 11% to $224.6 million. AmerisourceBergen Corp. said it expects 2010 operating income of $1.82 to $1.92 a share, compared to the Wall Street expectation of $1.83 a share.
title: AmerisourceBergen powers past earnigs target

In Europe, BMW (BMW) and UBS UBS, +0.40% are slated to release third-quarter results. After Monday's closing bell, Stanley Works SWK, +1.56% and Black & Decker Corp. BDK announced that they will merge in an all-stock deal valued at $4.5 billion. Stanley will own 50.5% of the newly created company and Stanley Chairman and CEO John Lundgren will take over as CEO. Nolan Archibald, CEO of Black & Decker for 24 years, will become executive chairman for three years. Watch list Anadarko Petroleum Corp. APC, +2.56% reported its third-quarter net income fell to $200 million, or 40 cents a share, from $2.16 billion, or $4.58 a share, a year ago. Excluding one-time items, the company posted a loss of $51 million, or 11 cents a share. Revenue fell to $2.74 billion from $6.15 billion. F, +2.03% will be raising about $3 billion in fresh funds as part of its effort to improve its balance sheet. The automaker is also seeking to extend the maturity of its revolving credit facility to 2013 from 2011. Hanover Insurance Group THG, -0.08% swung to a third-quarter profit of $49.7 million, or 97 cents a share. In the year-earlier period, Hanover lost $61.8 million due to heavy investment losses and two hurricanes. The company said its net premiums written rose 5.7% to $688.8 million for the quarter. Synchronoss said net income was $3.1 million, or 10 cents a share, compared to net income of $2.3 million, or 7 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenue grew 26% to $33.1 million. title: Stocks in focus for Tuesday

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Fourteen states and the District of Columbia are suing Amgen Inc., claiming the company offered kickbacks to medical professionals to boost sales of its blockbuster anemia-fighting drug Aranesp. According to a statement issued Friday by New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo's office, the states filed a suit in federal court in Boston that accuses Amgen AMGN, +0.01% purchasing group International Nephrology Network and drug wholesaler ASD Healthcare of using kickbacks to encourage medical workers to bill third-party payers such as Medicaid for free samples of Aranesp. Among other incentives, the companies also allegedly offered paid vacations to prescribers to boost sales of the product, according to Cuomo's office. The multistate suit joins a whistle-blower suit filed in federal court in Massachusetts in 2006. ASD is a unit of drug-distribution giant AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Amgen denied the allegations late Friday. "We believe that the allegations are without merit, and we look forward to the opportunity to examine these matters with the states before the court," the company said in its own statement. "Because this lawsuit is now in litigation, we are limited in our remarks about matters pending before the court," Amgen added, saying that it has a compliance program and code of conduct, "and we expect that all of our employees follow it at all times." Parties to the complaint include the states of California, Delaware, Florida, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Michigan, Nevada, New Hampshire, New York, Tennessee and Virginia, along with the District of Columbia. According to Amgen's Web site, Aranesp had worldwide sales of $3.14 billion in 2008. The product has had declining sales in recent quarters due largely to tighter reimbursement and prescribing restrictions. Shares of Amgen were down 1% at $53.62 during a decidedly bearish session for the broader market on Wall Street. AmerisourceBergen shares were down 2% at $22.19. title: 14 states sue Amgen over alleged kickbacks

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- While not "The Da Vinci Code," the obscure footnotes of a company's financial statements hold information that David Trainer swears will tell you if a stock is worth buying or selling. He has the record to prove it. Trainer, president of New Constructs, a Nashville-based independent research firm, uses an intensely bottom-up approach to analyze stocks. Each month, from the 3,000 stocks his staff dives into, New Constructs produces a list of the 25 most attractive and most dangerous. If you bought the 25 most attractive each month and sold short the 25 most dangerous dating back to April 2006, your long/short strategy would be up 63%. That doesn't just beat the market, it kills it -- topping the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index's SPX, +1.38% return over the same period by 86 percentage points. Trainer's research process and dedication to rooting out what he calls the "truth" about a company's numbers is why he is part of a series of columns I am writing focused on interviews with outstanding money managers. Straight and narrow Trainer's philosophy is straightforward: "The economics of the business is what investors should care about, not the accounting," he said. "Accounting rules were actually not designed for equity investors," Trainer added. "They were designed for debt investors, so when you trust the financial statements on their face -- if you trust the net income number or you trust the cash flow statement number -- ... you are getting a very small piece of the overall picture with respect to the financial performance of the business." Trainer digs to determine the economics of a business, looking for "everything that helps you understand how much cash flow the company is generating based on how much cash flow was invested in the business." He frequently finds that good companies are bad stocks, improperly valued with what New Constructs labels "misleading earnings." That's where a company cites rising profits in its accounting, while the underlying figures Trainer's research show that economic earnings in fact are moving in the other direction. Couple an inflated stock valuation with misleading earnings, and you have a stock that's a candidate for New Construct's "most dangerous" list. Of the stocks on that list for this month -- and you can get free downloads of lists that are three months old or older at www.newconstructs.com -- Trainer said Red Hat Inc. RHT, +2.26% may be the epitome of the kind of trouble stocks that his research weeds out. "That's a company whose stock price implies that their profits will be 400% greater, and we show in our model that it would take them more than 100 years of profit growth to actually realize what is embedded into the value of the stock already," Trainer said. "They show their accounting earnings rose by $2 million last year, even though we show that their economic earnings fell by $10 million." Another dangerous stock is Sprint Nextel Corp. S, +0.41% which has been bouncing on and off the danger list for months, coming off whenever its price falls (so that its valuation improves). Now it's on the list. Said Trainer about the stock: "The economics of the business have been horrendous for a long time, and the valuation is already pricing in profit growth for more than we can see -- our model says for more than 100 years, which just means forget about it, it's over the top -- and the economics of the business just don't support [uninterrupted profit growth for the next century]. Appealing prospects On the flip side, two stocks from the most-attractive list include Dish Network Corp. DISH, +1.20% and McDonald's Corp. MCD, -1.28% Dish has a valuation that "implies that its profits are going to be 30% lower than they currently are ... forever, perpetually ... while we see that their profits are very strong and rising," Trainer said. McDonald's, he noted, is a stock with very low risk of being crushed by current market conditions. "No growth expectation is baked into the stock price and we believe the competitive position and the economics are very strong," he said. "If the market catches up to where we believe the profitability actually is, it could go up quite a bit." Trainer's research isn't foolproof. His system sometimes produces a clunker or a stock that the market can sustain or depress despite all of the obvious signs. Part of the problem, Trainer said, is that corporations can hide a lot of information in footnotes and statements. "In the last 10 years, corporations, auditors and Wall Street in many ways conspired together to try and make the financial statement, the accounting statement, do what they need [the numbers] to do, which is to help them sell stock," Trainer said. "Just like any salesman, you're going to put your best foot forward always, you're going to focus on the positives instead of the negatives, and so the accounting statements are essentially a sales tool." He added: "We make it our goal in life to go through and gather all of the relevant financial information in all the statements ... The income statement, the balance sheet, the cash-flow statement, even the statement of shareholder's equity, where they are burying some important details with respect to preferred stock that they don't want you to see." The research also can reveal industries where there are opportunities. The most attractive list favors energy and oil stocks and pharmaceuticals, including Chevron Corp. CVX, +1.73% Diamond Offshore Drilling DO, +2.95% and VAALCO Energy EGY, -1.87% on the energy side, and Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. BMY, +1.09% AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% Cubist Pharmaceuticals Inc. CBST and Questcor Pharmaceuticals Inc. QCOR on the biotech/pharma front. Yet neither industry is a slam dunk, Trainer said. The dangerous stocks list included Allscripts-Misys Healthcare Solutions MDRX, +0.73% and Northeast Utilities NU, -7.41% "So much of the propaganda machine with respect to investing is trying to get you to start with a supposition [such as energy and pharma being hot industries]," Trainer said. "It's just not that simple." More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Related Topics Mutual Funds Investing U.S. Stocks Exchange Traded Funds
title: Stock sleuth exposes winners and traps

content: Pre-open movers U.S. stock futures on Tuesday added to early gains after a slew of positive economic data, including an August jump in retail sales. Futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 40 points to 9,590.0. Those for the S&P 500 gained 4.3 points to 1,047.8, while Nasdaq 100 futures rose 6 points to 1,694.00. See Indications Global markets European shares edged lower on Tuesday after a disappointing sentiment reading from Germany, with autos and financials under notable pressure. See Europe Markets for more. Asian markets ended mostly higher Tuesday, with Japanese shares rebounding from the previous session's tumble as overnight gains on Wall Street and a weaker yen spurred risk appetite See Asia Markets for more. Broker action Goodrich Corp. GR, +5.88% was cut to neutral from buy at Bank of America Merrill Lynch, though the broker upped the company's price target to $60 from $53. "We still believe the company's diversification across defense, aftermarket and OEM sales position it well in the current aerospace cycle. However, we believe the recent run-up in the stock price reflects this reality," the broker said. Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% was upped to buy from neutral at Goldman Sachs which also lifted price targets on Cardinal, AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% and McKesson MCK, +0.15% It's expecting more stable fundamentals heading into 2011 for the drug distributors. UBS upgraded eBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% to buy from neutral Tuesday, saying that comparable sales may be starting to turn a corner. The broker said recent data from top eBay vendor ChannelAdvisor and other channel checks show comparable sales rose 4.6% in August, following a 10% decline in the first quarter and a 5% decline in the second quarter. Breaking news - See News Viewer for the latest E-Trade Financial ETFC, +3.38% said on Tuesday that delinquencies of 30 to 89 days on its home equity portfolio remained flat between June 30 and Aug. 31. The company said its home-equity portfolio represents its biggest exposure to loan losses. Home-equity loans from 30 to 179 days delinquent, what the company calls "at risk" delinquencies, fell 7% between June 30 and Aug. 31. Among other data the firm posted Tuesday, it said it expects net chargeoffs of $350 to $375 million during the current quarter. Best Buy Co. BBY, +2.09% the largest U.S. electronics chain, said Tuesday that its second-quarter profit dropped 22%, hurt by lower U.S. demand for video games, digital cameras and music products. Kraft Foods KFT may sell assets like Maxwell House and Oscar Mayer to raise enough cash to finance an acquisition of Cadbury CBY, -5.18% (CBRY), the New York Post reported, citing sources familiar with the matter. A formal bid for Cadbury may be launched next week, the report added. Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. TMO, +0.26% CEO Marijn Dekkers will leave the laboratory equipment manufacturer to join Germany's Bayer AG (BAY), where he will take over as CEO next year, the two companies said. Dekkers will succeed Werner Wenning as chief executive of Bayer in October 2010. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. title: Bayer, Best Buy, eBay in focus

title: Cardinal Health upped to buy at Goldman

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - AmerisourceBergen Corp. on Thursday said it swung to a third-quarter profit on the back of strong generic drug sales. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% gave up early gains to close down 2.6% at $20.95 but are still up 11% since the beginning of the year. The Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical services company posted earnings of $118.8 million, or 40 cents a share, vs. a loss of $108 million, or 34 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations came in at 42 cents a share. Revenue, benefiting from new business wins, rose 2.2% to $18.4 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of 39 cents a share, on average, with sales of $17 billion. For the year, said it expects earnings per share to be at the high end of its $1.59 to $1.65 forecast. Wall Street previously forecast a 2009 profit of $1.63 a share. title: AmerisourceBergen swings to profit

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Thursday its fiscal third-quarter earnings were $118.8 million, or 40 cents a share, compared to a loss of $108 million, or 34 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations were 42 cents a share in the most recent quarter. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of 39 cents a share, on average. Revenue rose 2.2% to $18.4 billion. For the year, the Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical services company said it expects earnings per share to be at the high end of its $1.59 to $1.65 forecast. Shares of AmerisourceBergen rose 3.6% in premarket trading to $21.
title: AmerisourceBergen swings to a quarterly profit
