content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Given the surge that U.S. stocks have enjoyed, maybe mutual-fund investors should just call it a year. The market's performance over the last three months is closer to what you'd see in a runaway bullish 12-month period. Diversified U.S. stock funds rose 17.6% in the second quarter on average, according to preliminary results from investment researcher Morningstar Inc. The group is up a no-less impressive 7.1% in the first six months of 2009. In fact, while U.S. stocks lagged their international counterparts, every domestic stock-fund category that Morningstar tracks enjoyed double-digit quarterly gains, and all but real-estate focused funds are up for the year. See story on international stock-funds' quarterly results. But the rally since early March, while heartening, hinged on the good fortune of lower-quality, smaller-capitalization stocks. Such higher-risk holdings typically lead the market once it hits bottom, but they may not have much more juice left. "Low-quality has panned out very well," said Paul Nolte, director of investments at money manager Hinsdale Associates. "But going forward you're not going to get the economic expansion that's going to allow lower-quality companies to benefit. They're going to have to come up with real earnings and real growth." That's easier said than done, with the U.S. economy still anemic. At this point in the cycle, the market should begin to favor larger, better-capitalized companies that can deliver the earnings growth investors seek. Yet even a rotation to higher-quality leadership will still leave investors far from whole: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index SPX, +1.38% gained a robust 15.9% in the quarter, including reinvested dividends, but the benchmark needs to advance 60% in the next six months just to break even for the decade. Such a turbocharged performance would be extremely unlikely, to say the least. Instead, what U.S. investors could see, according to Standard & Poor's Inc., is a 10%-15% decline in stock prices followed by a rally that pushes the S&P 500 to about 955 by year-end. The index closed at 919 on June 30. "I keep biting my nails, wondering when this correction is going to come," said Sam Stovall, S&P's chief investment strategist. "We expect to see a correction over the next three months that will bring the S&P 500 down to between 800 and 850." Sizing up funds For the past three months, however, small stocks were the big story. Small-cap funds gained 21.5% on average in the quarter, led by small value's 22.2% rise. Standouts included Aegis Value Fund AVALX, +1.74% up 48.5%, and Wasatch Micro Cap Value Fund WAMVX, +0.90% up 40%. Large- and midcap offerings followed with their own strong showings. Large-cap funds collectively added 16.2%, with large-blend and large-value each up 16.4% and large-growth up 15.6%. Among the top performers were the hardest-hit funds of 2008, such as Vanguard Capital Value Fund VCVLX, +1.01% up 39.1%, Yacktman Focused Fund YAFFX, +1.21% up 36.9%, Legg Mason Value Trust LMVTX, +1.40% gaining 29.4%, and Longleaf Partners Fund LLPFX, +1.04% rising 26.6%. Midcap funds averaged an 18.4% gain, with midcap-blend up 19.5%, midcap-value adding 18.9% and midcap-growth up 17%. Notables in these categories included a 41.9% gain for Kinetics Small Cap Opportunities Fund KSCOX, +0.91% and a 38.1% advance for Fidelity Leveraged Company Stock FLVCX, +1.93% The biggest U.S. stock funds, meanwhile, matched the market's faster pace -- and at times outran it. Dodge & Cox Stock Fund DODGX, +1.26% soared 23.1%, well ahead of the 16.4% average gain for its large-cap value peers. American Funds' Growth Fund of America AGTHX, +1.55% rose 16.7% and Fidelity Growth Company Fund FDGRX, +1.63% added 15.9% -- slightly better than their large-cap growth category's 15.6% return. Additionally, the S&P 500-tracking Vanguard 500 Index Fund VFINX, +1.38% and the exchange-traded S&P 500 SPDR ETF SPY, +1.28% both finished in line with the index, gaining around 16%. Worst to first The rally's lower-quality nature attracted bargain hunters and propelled last year's worst-performing sectors into the first tier. Real-estate funds led the pack with a 29.6% quarterly gain; financial-services funds were up 27% and natural resources offerings added 18.7%. "We continue to be bullish on commodity companies, especially those that help get that commodity out of the ground," said Jerry Jordan, manager of Jordan Opportunity Fund JORDX a large-cap growth portfolio that gained 25.4% in the quarter. Natural-resources holdings in his fund include Schlumberger Ltd. SLB, +2.48% BHP Billiton Ltd. BHP, +2.16% and Diamond Offshore Drilling Inc. DO, +2.95% The quarter's other noteworthy sectors included technology and communications, each of which gained about 20% in the 13-week period. Both tech and telecom are attractive to Emmanuel Ferreira, manager of Oppenheimer Quest Opportunity Value Fund QVOPX, +0.11% a moderate-allocation fund that added about 8% in the quarter. Among his favorites: Take-Two Interactive Software, Inc. TTWO, +0.33% ; Research in Motion, Ltd. RIMM and Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, +1.30% "They're companies with interesting business characteristics that afford them tremendous earnings generation," Ferreira said. The weakest sectors were those that investors consider defensive -- health care, utilities -- but even those added 11% and 13%, respectively. And for managers who expect choppier trading days ahead, safer, dividend-paying stocks are better. "Utilities have been bypassed in this low-quality rally," said Barry James, manager of James Balanced Golden Rainbow Fund GLRBX, +0.64% which gained 6.1% in the quarter. He includes a telecom in that group, Centurytel Inc. CTL, +1.36% which sports a 9% dividend yield. The health-care business is under pressure, but Chris Rowane, manager of Huntington Mid Corp America Fund HUMIX is avoiding mainstream pharmaceutical companies. Instead, he's concentrating on niche players such as Cephalon Inc. CEPH which is developing drugs to treat neurological disorders and cancer, and to manage pain. "Higher-quality securities will benefit as investors look a little closer at companies," said Rowane, whose fund posted a 16.7% quarterly gain. "We're looking at companies that have sustainable revenue growth as well as enhanced earnings." 'New normal' The market's stellar advance in the quarter is signaling some investment professionals that the worst is over and, quite possibly, good times are set to roll again. Financial advisers' confidence in the U.S. economy and stocks hit its highest level in June since October 2007, according to Rydex|SGI Advisor Benchmarking, though the indicator is still squarely in "neutral" territory. Individual investors aren't so sure. For the year through June 24, a net $6 billion in new money had been invested in U.S. stock funds, according to the Investment Company Institute, an industry trade group. That's healthier than a year ago at this time, when investors had pulled a net $30 billion out of the stock market, but still weak. "People realize the financial world is not going to come to an end," said David Kelly, chief market strategist for J.P. Morgan Funds. "At the same time we're still in a nasty recession." For investors, this transition will be challenging. Bill Gross, managing director at bond-fund giant Pimco and manager of its flagship Total Return Fund PTTAX, +0.10% (up about 13% in the quarter), has been speaking out lately about how to invest in what is being called the "new normal" -- a protracted period of stricter government regulation, tighter credit, slower economic growth, cautious consumers, rising longer-term bond yields and muted stock returns. Read about bond funds' quarterly performance. "The 'new normal' will not be investor-friendly," Gross wrote in a recent commentary posted on Pimco's Web site. "The outlook for risk assets -- stocks, high-yield bonds, and commercial and residential real estate will involve just that -- risk. Investors should stress secure income offered by bonds and stable, dividend-paying equities." That said, individual investors shouldn't give up on asset diversification, but they'd do well to upgrade portfolios with higher-quality stocks -- large or small. "Quality," in Wall Street parlance, is just another word for what really matters to investors, particularly in taxing times: Earnings. See related story on MarketWatch's 2009 investment ideas. "Companies with stronger balance sheets, liquidity characteristics and consistent earnings growth will be better positioned to withstand any near-term volatility and take advantage of an eventual economic recovery," Brian Belski, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer Asset Management Inc., wrote in a recent research report. The Oppenheimer report highlighted several stocks that sport earnings growth and free-cash-flow greater than the S&P 500, but trade at cheaper price-earnings ratios. These include AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Archer Daniels Midland Co. ADM, +1.33% CenturyTel Inc., Church & Dwight Co. CHD, +2.27% Omnicom Group Inc. OMC, +0.04% and United Technologies Corp. UTX, +1.10% Investors can review their mutual-funds' portfolios for high-quality bias, and find others with sturdy, stalwart holdings. As the year progresses, it's worth remembering an old Wall Street adage: When earnings growth is everywhere, the market prices it like water. When growth is scarce, the market prices it like diamonds. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage
title: Low-quality stocks bring funds high-quality gains

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Tuesday that it is splitting its common stock two for one and raising its dividend 20% to 6 cents a share on a post-split basis beginning in the fiscal third quarter. AmerisourceBergen reaffirmed its fiscal year 2009 expectations for diluted earnings per share from continuing operations in the range of $3.18 to $3.30, or $1.59 to $1.65 on a post-split basis, over the $2.89, or $1.44 on a split-adjusted basis, in fiscal year 2008 for the pharmaceutical services company.
title: AmerisourceBergen splits 2 for 1, lifts dividend

content: Samsung's profit drops but beats estimates (9:28 PM ET) TOKYO (MarketWatch) -- Samsung Electronics(KR:005930) SSNG reported Friday a first-quarter net profit of 619.2 billion won ($462.6 million), down from 2.188 trillion won a year earlier but up from a loss of 22.2 billion won in the previous quarter. The results beat market expectations for a profit of 149 billion won, according to analysts polled by Dow Jones. The memory chip maker's sales climbed 8.5% to 18.57 trillion won for the first quarter. Shares of Samsung Electronics fell 2.4% Friday morning in Seoul. Korea's Hynix posts wider loss as DRAM prices drop (8:47 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hynix Semiconductor Inc. HXSCF said Thursday its first-quarter net loss totaled 1.18 trillion won ($883 million), compared to a net loss of 675.6 billion won in the same period a year earlier, according to Dow Jones Newswires. Hynix said its average selling price of dynamic random access memory chips fell 7% in the quarter compared to the prior period, while its NAND flash memory chip prices rose 10% in the same period. Hynix posted an operating loss margin of 39% for the quarter, narrowing from 53% in the prior period. Netflix CEO: Streaming-only rental not in works (6:34 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35% Chief Executive Reed Hastings told analysts the company has no current plans to offer stream-only rental subscriptions, contrary to some concerns. Hastings said on a conference call that the online DVD rental pioneer has considered the idea "from time to time," but for now, "the combination of DVD rental and streaming is what our customers are interested in." Netflix CEO: Kiosks will be main competition (6:27 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35% Chief Executive Reed Hastings said Thursday that the online DVD rental pioneer expects $1 kiosks to be its main competitor by the end of 2009, surpassing video stores. A growing number of customers who cancel their Netflix subscriptions cite kiosks as a reason why they dropped the service, Hastings explained. Commenting during a conference call with analysts, Hastings said Netflix is not overly concerned about the kiosks, despite their increasing ubiquity, because the kiosks focus on new release DVDs, which only account for about a third of Netflix's rentals. "Our differentiators continue to be our vast selection, over 100,000 titles, the convenience of mail and streaming," he said. Eastman Chemical profit clipped by tough economy (5:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Eastman Chemical Co. EMN, +1.34% reported late Thursday first-quarter net income fell to $2 million, or 3 cents a share, from $133 million, or $1.68 a share, a year ago. Excluding one-time items, earnings per share from continuing operations fell to 25 cents a share from $1.48 a year earlier. Revenue for the three months ended March 31 fell 35% to $1.13 billion as a global economic downturn cut into demand for chemicals and specialty coatings. The latest results also include $26 million in restucturing charges. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the company to post earnings of 16 cents a share on $1.34 billion in revenue. Shares of the Kingsport, Tenn.-based company gained 26 cents to close at $33.11 ahead of the report. KLA-Tencor swings to quarterly loss; rev falls 49% (5:25 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- KLA-Tencor Corp. KLAC, +2.29% on Thursday evening swung to a fiscal third-quarter net loss to $82.8 million, or 49 cents a share. Last year, the chip-equipment maker earned $111 million, or 61 cents a share. Its loss on an adjusted basis was $58.3 million, or 34 cents a share, for the most recent period. Revenue dropped 48.6% to $310 million from $602 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had projected a loss of 26 cents a share on $300 million in revenue. Federated Investors Q1 net earns $35.1 million (5:00 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Federated Investors Inc. FII, +1.55% late Thursday said first-quarter net income attributed to Federated was $35.1 million, or 34 cents a share, down from $55.8 million, or 54 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Total revenue at the investment management firm rose to $310.6 million from $305.7 million last year. Total managed assets were $409.2 billion, up 21% from the same period a year ago. Average managed assets were $411.7 billion, up 28% from quarter ended in March 2008. CORRECT: Burlington Northern profit dips (4:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corp. BNI reported late Thursday first-quarter net income fell to $293 million, or 86 cents a share, from $455 million, or $1.30 a share, a year ago. The latest results included one-time losses of 27 cents a share stemming from an unfavorable coal-rate case and interest rate hedges. Revenue for the three months ended March 31 fell 20% to $3.42 billion from $4.26 billion a year earlier as a steep economic downturn bit into freight volumes. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the Fort Worth, Texas-based railroad to earn $1 a share on $3.72 billion in revenue. Burlington Northern shares rose 2.1% ahead of the report to close at $67.85. (Updated to correct earnings per share figure.) Interactive Brokers profit drops 54% (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Interactive Brokers Group IBKR, +2.31% on Thursday reported a first-quarter profit of $155.1 million, or 30 cents a share, down from $340.6 million, or 66 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the electronic market maker and broker fell to $296 million from $528 million in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a profit, on average, of 47 cents a share on sales of $414 million. "Our strict risk controls have not completely immunized us from the secondary effects of the financial crises as our results have been largely impacted by competitive pressures on spreads," CEO Thomas Peterffy said. "Exchange listed options are one of the few life rafts still afloat and more and more traders are trying to hold onto it." AmEx reports 56% drop in quarterly net income (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- American Express AXP, +1.16% said late Thursday that first-quarter net income came in at $437 million, down 56% from a year earlier when the credit card company made $991 million. Net income attributable to common shareholders was 31 cents a share, versus 85 cents a year earlier. Income from continuing operations was $443 million, or 32 cents a share. American Express was expected to make 12 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 19 analysts in a Thomson Reuters survey. "While we did see some recent improvement in early delinquency rates, overall credit indicators reflected rising unemployment levels and the broad-scale weakness in the economy," AmEx Chief Executive Kenneth Chenault said. U.S. lending write-off rates on a managed basis could level off during the fourth quarter, but will rise in the second and third quarter, he added, while noting the company is still very cautious about the economic outlook. More cost cuts are planned for the second quarter, he said. AmEx intends to repay the government's investment of preferred shares and warrants, "if permitted by our supervisors and if supported by the results of the stress assessment," he added. AmEx shares rose 5% in after-hours action. Amgen reports lower profit, cuts sales view (4:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Amgen Inc. AMGN, +0.01% the world's largest biotech company, reported late Thursday its quarterly profit fell 7% from a year-ago and cut its full-year sales outlook. Amgen posted first-quarter net income of $1 billion, or 98 cents a share, compared to net income of $1.1 billion, or $1.01 a share, a year ago. Amgen said its adjusted per-share profit was $1.08. Revenue fell 8% to $3.3. For 2009, Amgen pegged revenue between $14.4 billion and $14.8 billion, down from its previous forecast of $14.8 billion to $15.2 billion. It kept its adjusted profit forecast of $4.55 to $4.75 a share. Ahead of the earnings report, Amgen shares closed up 4% at $46.82. The stock is down 19% so far this year. Microsoft earnings slip in third quarter (4:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Microsoft Corp. said Thursday that earnings fell 32% for their third fiscal quarter. The software giant MSFT, +2.10% reported net income of $2.98 billion, or 33 cents a share, compared to net income of $4.39 billion, or 47 cents a share, for the same period the previous year. Revenue slipped 6% to $13.65 billion. Analysts were expecting earnings of 39 cents a share on revenue of $14.1 billion, according to consensus forecasts from FactSet Research. Netflix profit rises 68%, ups year-end forecasts (4:17 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Online DVD rental pioneer Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35% said Thursday that its first-quarter profit rose 68% as the company surpassed the 10 million subscriber mark and cut costs during the period, topping the average estimate of Wall Street analysts. The company also lifted its revenue and subscriber estimates for 2009. Netflix said it earned $22.4 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with a profit of $13.3 million, or 21 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. Excluding stock-based compensation, Netflix said it would have earned 40 cents a share in the latest three months. Revenue rose 21% to $394 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research were expecting a profit of 33 cents a share, excluding stock-based compensation, on $391.1 million in revenue. Netflix paid $25.79 to acquire each subscriber, down from $29.48 a year earlier, the company reported. In the second quarter, Netflix still expects revenue of $403 million to $409 million, with a total of 10.4 million to 10.6 million subscribers by June 30. For the year, it raised its revenue outlook to a range of $1.63 billion to $1.67 billion from its previous forecast of $1.58 billion to $1.635 billion. The company now anticipates that it will end 2009 with 11.2 million to 11.8 million customers, up from the earlier estimate of 10.6 million to 11.3 million subscribers. Chubb reports quarterly net income of $341 mln (4:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chubb Corp. CB, -1.08% said late Thursday that first-quarter net income came in at $341 million, or 95 cents a share, down 49% from a year earlier when the property and casualty insurer made $664 million, or $1.77 a share. Operating earnings, which exclude after-tax realized investment gains and losses, were $514 million, or $1.43 a share, Chubb reported. Chubb was expected to make $1.38 a share, according to the average estimate of 20 analysts in a Thomson Reuters poll. Net written premiums for the first quarter decreased 7% to $2.7 billion. Excluding the effect of currency fluctuation, premiums were down 2%. Chubb's combined ratio was 88.1% in the first quarter, compared to 83.9% in the same period of 2008. Amazon earnings jump in first quarter (4:07 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Amazon.com Inc. said Thursday that earnings rose 24% for the first quarter on strong sales growth. For the first quarter, Amazon AMZN, +1.11% reported net income of $177 million, or 41 cents a share, compared to net income of $143 million, or 34 cents a share, for the same period the previous year. Revenue grew 18% to $4.89 billion. Analysts were expecting earnings of 31 cents a share on revenue of $4.75 billion, according to consensus forecasts from FactSet Research. Asset managers see mixed stock moves after results (12:58 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Three asset managers that announced their results before Thursday's trading saw different moves in their stocks during the day. Shares of Invesco Ltd. IVZ, +1.68% and AllianceBernstein AB, +1.90% were down about 8% and 15% respectively by midday, while Janus Capital Group's JNS stock was up roughly 6%. Profit plunged at all three firms, but while Janus reported quarterly net outflows of $900 million and said the situation had stabilized, AllianceBernstein saw net outflows of $20 billion. Invesco saw net inflows of $9.3 billion, but fees earned from investment management fell 41%. CORRECT: Exelon net up 23% on 3.5% higher revenue (11:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Exelon Corp., EXC, +1.22% the Chicago power provider, reported first-quarter earnings rose 23% on 3.5% higher revenue. Earnings were $712 million, or $1.08 a share, compared with $581 million, or 88 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Adjusted profit was $1.20 versus 93 cents. Revenue reached $647 million from $625 million. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of $1.11 of profit. (Corrects to show earnings rose.) Supervalu shares surge 16% on earnings report (10:02 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Supervalu Inc. SVU, -1.42% shares surged 16% early Thursday after the supermarket chain reported stronger financial results than analysts expected. Supervalu reported a net loss of $201 million, or 95 cents a share, compared to a year-earlier profit of $156 million, or 73 cents a share. But excluding non-cash charges, Supervalu said it earned 87 cents a share, compared to the 79 cents a share analysts had forecast, according to FactSet Research. Supervalu posted sales of $10.8 billion. The grocer, which owns regional chains Albertsons, Jewel-Osco and Sav-A-Lot, said it remains in compliance with all debt covenants. Investors have been concerned about Supervalu's heavy debt load. Supervalu shares rose to $16.97 in recent trades. Energy stocks rise out of the gate (9:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy stocks rose in early action on Thursday as investors eyed earnings updates from ConocoPhillips COP, +0.95% Occidental Petroleum OXY, +2.87% National Oilwell Varco NOV, +2.45% and others. The Amex Oil Index XOI, +2.04% rose 1.7%. The Amex Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% advanced 0.9%. ConocoPhillips rose 3% to $39.19. Occidental Petroleum OXY, +2.87% rose 6 cents to $64.81. Diamond Offshore DO, +2.95% rose 3.3% to $74.37. National Oilwell Varco NOV, +2.45% fell 3.6% to $31.79. China Life Insurance first-quarter net up 55% (9:25 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- China Life Insurance Co. LFC, +0.50% (HK:2628), the nation's largest life insurer with a roughly 40% market share, reported Thursday first-quarter net income climbed 55% from the year-earlier quarter, as a rebound on the Shanghai stock market bolstered investment revenue. Net income totaled 5.39 billion yuan ($789 million), compared to 3.47 billion yuan a year earlier, the company said in a statement to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange Thursday. China Life said it recorded a gain of 841 million yuan on its financial assets in the quarter, compared to a 5.5 billion yuan loss a year earlier. McClatchy's loss exceeds Wall Street estimate (9:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The McClatchy Co. MNI, +0.65% said Thursday it swung to a first-quarter loss of $37.7 million, or 45 cents a share, from a loss of $993,000, or 1 cent a share in the year-ago period. Adjusted loss in the latest period totaled 28 cents a share. Revenue at the Sacramento, Calif. company dropped 25% to $366 million. Analysts expected a loss of 3 cents a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Nucor posts loss, sees deeper loss in next quarter (9:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Nucor Corp. NUE, +2.98% said it swung to a first-quarter loss of $189.6 million, or 60 cents a share, from a profit of $409.8 million, or $1.41 a share in the year-ago period. Sales fell 47% to $2.65 billion. Analsyts expected Nucor to lose 56 cents a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. The Charlotte, N.C. company's steel mill utilization rate decreased to approximately 45% in the first quarter from 92% in last year's first quarter. While the company declared cash of $1.9 billion, it expects to post a second-quarter loss greater than the first quarter. "We will update our guidance midway between the first and second quarter earnings releases," the company said. Ensco net off 19% on 9.6% lower revenue (9:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Ensco International Inc., ESV, -0.90% the Dallas oil-services provider, reported first-quarter net income fell 19% on 9.6% lower revenue. Net income was $222.1 million against $273.7 million in the year-earlier period. Profit attributable to Ensco was $220.7 million, or $1.56 a share, compared with $272 million, or $1.88. Revenue fell to $514.1 million from $568.5 million. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of $1.52 a share of profit on sales of $516.8 million. Ball earnings per share down 14% (8:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Ball Corp. BLL, +1.33% said Thursday that first-quarter earnings were $70 million, or 73 cents a share, compared to $84 million, or 85 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Sales were $1.6 billion compared to $1.7 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated, on average, earnings per share of 76 cents and sales of $1.7 billion. "On a comparable basis, our diluted earnings per share were 77 cents in the quarter, down slightly from our record first quarter results of 80 cents in 2008," said Chief Executive David Hoover. Marshall & Ilsley swings to quarterly loss (8:38 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Marshall & Ilsley Corp. MI on Thursday said it swung to a first-quarter net loss of $116.9 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with net income of $146.2 million, or 56 cents a share, in the same quarter the previous year. The Milwaukee-based bank said the latest quarter's results included a tax benefit of 19 cents a share and dividends paid to the Treasury Department of 9 cents a share. The company also booked a loan loss provision of $478 million, while net charge-offs in the first quarter totaled $328 million. Cooper Industries net income drops by 35% (8:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cooper Industries Inc. CBE, +50.00% said first-quarter net income fell to $100 million, or 59 cents a share, from $153.4 million, or 86 cents a share in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income totaled 47 cents a share. Revenue fell 19% to $1.26 billion from $1.55 billion. Analysts expected net income of 47 cents a share on revenue of $1.32 billion, acording to a survey by FactSet Research. The company cut 600 jobs during the quarter. "While we are seeing some signs of stabilization in our markets, we expect to continue to focus on rightsizing our businesses for current market conditions," the company said. Janus profit falls 93% (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Janus Capital Group JNS reported Thursday a 93% fall in first quarter profit, to $2.7 million, or 2 cents a share, from $37.4 million, or 23 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Continuing operations generated profit of 2 cents compared to 24 cents. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected, on average, a profit of 7 cents a share. The Denver-based asset manager said the results exclude expected goodwill and intangible asset impairment charges of $900 million to $1 billion, or $5.74 to $6.37 per share. Assets under management fell 10% during the quarter, to $110.9 billion. Assets are down 41% since the end of the first quarter of 2008. Union Pacific net off 18%, revenue down 20% (8:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Union Pacific Corp., UNP, +2.81% the Omaha railroad giant, reported first-quarter net income fell 18% to $362 million, or 72 cents a share, from $443 million, or 85 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell 20% to $3.42 billion from $4.27 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 68 cents of profit on revenue of $3.52 billion. National Oilwell Varco net income rises 19% (8:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- National Oilwell Varco NOV, +2.45% said Thursday first-quarter net income rose to $470 million, or $1.13 a share, from $398 million, or $1.11 a share in the year-ago period. Revenue at the oil service giant rose to $2.2 billion from $1.6 billion, reflecting extra business from its acquisition of Grant Prideco. National Oilwell was expected to earn $1.07 a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. New capital equipment orders totaled $240 million, net of orders removed from backlog of $32 million. "Our solid backlog for drilling equipment enabled our company to generate strong earnings in the first quarter, despite a sharp downturn in drilling activity," the company said. UPS revenue falls 14%, warns on Q2 profit (8:01 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- United Parcel Service Inc. UPS, +1.93% said Thursday that first-quarter net income fell 56% to $401 million, or 40 cents a share from $906 million, or 87 cents a share in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income for the latest period totaled 52 cents a share. The Atlanta-based delivery giant said revenue dipped 13.7% to $10.9 billion. Analysts expected net income of 55 cents a share and revenue of $11.5 billion, according to a survey of analysts by FactSet. The company expects second-quarter earnings of 45 to 55 cent a share, compared to the latest estimate of 65 cents a share. Goodrich net beats view; '09 net outlook sharpened (7:56 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Goodrich Corp., GR, +5.88% the Charlotte, N.C., supplier of systems and services for application in aerospace, defense and homeland security, reported first-quarter net income of $173.8 million against $162.4 million in the year-earlier period. Net attributable to Goodrich was $169.8 million, or $1.35 a share, against $157.9 million, or $1.23, in the year-earlier period. Sales fell to $1.7 billion from $1.75 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of $1.08 of profit on $1.69 billion. The company lowered the top end of the range of its earnings estimate for the full year. Goodrich now expects to earn $4.50 to $4.75 a share, compared with its previous estimate of $4.50 to $4.90. It cut its sales estimate for 2009 to $6.9 billion; it had estimated a range of $7.1 billion to $7.2 billion. FactSet's survey is looking for profit of $4.65 a share on sales of $7.11 billion. International Game Tech net income falls by half (7:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- International Game Technology IGT, +0.94% said second-quarter net income fell by nearly half to $38.3 million or 13 cents a share, from $68.4 million or 22 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Reno, Nevada company was expected to earn 22 cents a share, according to a survey of Wall Street analysts by FactSet Research. Invesco profit plummets (7:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Invesco Ltd. IVZ, +1.68% reported an 80% fall in first-quarter profit on Thursday, to $30.7 million, or 8 cents a share, from $155.2 million, or 39 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected, on average, profit of 13 cents a share. Total operating revenues were $548.6 million, down 40% from the same period last year. The Atlanta-based asset manager said assets under management fell 2.5% during the quarter, to $348.2 billion, from $357.2 billion on Dec. 31, 2008. Assets are down 26% from the end of the first quarter of 2008. Invesco reported an 82% year-on-year drop in its fourth-quarter results. Occidental Petroleum net income declines 80% (7:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Occidental Petroleum Corp. OXY, +2.87% said first-quarter net income fell to $368 million, or 45 cents a share, from $1.85 billion, or $2.24 a share in the year-ago period. Excluding items, earnings in the latest period totaled 50 cents a share. The Los Angeles-based energy company said year-over-year oil and gas production rose by 8% and it made "significant progress" in its cost reduction efforts. CEO Ray Irani said the company faced "volatile market conditions." Oil and gas earnings fell to $545 million from $2.9 billion, reflecting lower crude oil and natural gas prices, and higher depreciation, depletion, amortization and impairment rates. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of 39 cents a share for Occidental, a component of the Amex Oil Index XOI, +2.04% according to a survey by FactSet Research. CIT loss grows, firm suspends dividend (7:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CIT Group Inc. CIT, -0.06% said Thursday that its first quarter loss grew to $438.1 million, or $1.30 a share, compared with a year-earlier net loss of $238.7 million, or $1.35 a share. Stock outstanding doubled as part of CIT's capital-raising efforts. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected a per-share loss of 46 cents. The firm also said it is suspending its common dividend. L-3 unveils profit jump (7:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- L-3 Communications LLL, +2.65% said Thursday that its first-quarter profit rose to $199 million, or $1.66 a share, from $189 million, or $1.51 a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected, on average, profit of $1.63 a share. The New York-based defense contractor said net sales increased 4% to $3.6 billion. Funded orders for the first quarter decreased 8% from the year-ago period, to $3.8 billion, while funded backlog increased to $11.7 billion at March 27 from $11.6 billion at Dec. 31, 2008. Shares of L-3 closed Wednesday at $73.90, up 1.8% on the day. Zimmer Holdings net earings fall to $202.2 million (7:38 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Zimmer Holdings ZMH on Thursday said net earnings fell to $202.2 million, or 91 cents a share, in the first quarter from $239.3 million, or $1.02 a share, in the same period a year ago. Adjusted net earnings were $210 million, or 95 cents a share, compared to $244.3 million, or $1.04 a share, the previous year. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research produced a consensus forecast of 94 cents a share. First-quarter net sales fell 6.3% to $993 million. The Warsaw, Ind.-based maker of orthopedic devices and surgical products reaffirmed 2009 sales and earnings guidance. It expects full-year revenues to grow 1% to 3%. Adjusted earnings are projected to be in a range between $3.85 and $4 a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect earnings of $3.88 a share. NCR swings to 1st-quarter loss; revenue off 15% (7:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- NCR Corp., NCR, +2.04% the Dayton, Ohio, producer of technology including automatic teller machines and retail workstations, swung to a first-quarter loss of $15 million, or 9 cents a share, from net income of $48 million, or 27 cents, in the year-earlier period. The adjusted loss from continuing operations was 9 cents against profit of 21 cents. Revenue slipped to $1.01 billion from $1.18 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of a loss of 1 cent a share on sales of $1.06 billion. Laboratory Corp. net income up 1.9% (7:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Laboratory Corp. LH, +0.14% said Thursday second-quarter net income rose to $132.9 million, or $1.22 a share from $130.3 million, or $1.14 a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 4.8% to $1.16 billion. Analysts expected earnings of $1.22 a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. CME Holdings profit falls 30% (7:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CME Group Holdings. CME, +1.83% said on Thursday that its first quarter net income was $199 million, or $3 a share, compared to $284 million, or $5.25 a share a year ago. The firm's revenue for the quarter was $647 million, vs. $625 million a year ago. On an adjusted basis, the company said it earned $3.20 share versus $5.24 a share a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the company to earn $3.23 a share on an adjusted basis, in the latest quarter. CORRECT: AmerisourceBergen net income rises (7:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Thursday second-quarter net income rose to $143.4 million, or 95 cents a share, from $133.9 million, or 83 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $17.3 billion from $17.8 billion. The Valley Forge, Pa. company said it expects 2009 earnings of $3.18 to $3.30 a share, compared to its earlier view of $3.08 to $3.25 a share. (Updated to correct year-ago net income figure.) Hershey reports profit rise (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Hershey Co. HSY, +0.72% said Thursday that profit for its first quarter, which ended on April 5, was $75.9 million, or 33 cents a share, compared to $63.2 million, or 28 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income was 38 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected, on average, adjusted earnings of 34 cents a share. Consolidated net sales were $1.24 billion in the first quarter, compared to $1.16 billion in the first quarter of 2008. The firm said it expects full-year net sales growth of 2% to 3%, but that year-on-year pension and commodity cost increases will be "significant." The Hershey, Pa., based candy maker added that it has confidence that earnings per share from operations will increase, though less than its long-term objective of 6% to 8%. Philip Morris profit dips 12% (7:20 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Tobacco company Philip Morris International Inc. PM, -0.39% said Thursday that first-quarter net profit attributable to the company fell 11.8% to $1.48 billion, or 74 cents a share, from $1.67 billion, or 79 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter dropped 7.4% to $13.29 billion. The group said that excluding the impact of currency moves, earnings for the quarter rose 12.7%. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 69 cents a share. Philip Morris said net revenue, excluding excise taxes rose 6.3%, helped by favorable pricing and the acquisition of Rothmans Inc., Canada. The company reaffirmed its forecast for 2009 earnings per share of $2.85 to $3.00. Philip Morris said it spent $1.3 billion in the quarter to repurchase 36.7 million shares and declared a regular quarterly dividend of 54 cents. EMC Corp. Q1 net falls 23% (7:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- EMC Corp. EMC, +9.92% said first-quarter net income fell to $194.1 million, or 10 cents a share, from $251.7 million, or 12 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Hopkinton, Mass. tech firm said revenue dipped to $3.15 billion from $3.47 billion. Analysts expected net income of 12 cents a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. PNC 1st-quarter net $1.03-share vs $1.09 (7:03 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- PNC Financial Services Group Inc., PNC, +1.20% Pittsburgh, reported first-quarter net income of $530 million, or $1.03 a share, against $384 million, or $1.09, in the year-earlier period. Revenue more than doubled to $3.87 billion from $1.82 billion. Net interest income more than doubled as well, to $2.31 billion from $854 million. The provision for possible losses on bad loans rose to $880 million from $151 million. Marriott makes second-quarter, 2009 forecasts (6:58 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- While conceding that making forecasts in the current business climate is "very difficult," Marriott International Inc. MAR, +1.55% projected it would show a second-quarter profit in a range of 23 cents to 25 cents a share. The forecast was given as representing the adjusted profit from continuing operations attributable to Marriott shareholders. Analysts' consensus forecast, as derived in a poll by FactSet Research, stands at 26 cents a share for the June quarter. On the same adjusted basis, Marriott management said earnings "could total" 88 cents to $1.02 a share for all of 2009, as opposed to analysts' consensus view of 88 cents a share. According to FactSet, Marriott in February had set forth its 2009 profit target in a range of 86 cents to $1.04 a share. Fifth Third earns $50mln before preferred dividend (6:58 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Fifth Third Bancorp FITB, +0.60% said Thursday that its first-quarter net profit fell 83% to $50 million from $286 million a year earlier. After $76 million of preferred dividends, primarily related to the issuance of $3.4 billion in preferred stock to the U.S. Treasury, the group said it made a loss attributable to common shareholders of $26 million, or 4 cents a share. The result followed a loss of around $2.1 billion in the final quarter of 2008. The group said income benefited by roughly 18 cents a share from several one-off items. Analysts polled by FactSet had been expecting a loss of 27 cents a share. Bunge swings to $195 million loss (6:56 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Commodity and agribusiness giant Bunge Ltd. BG, +1.20% on Thursday swung to a first-quarter net loss of $195 million, or $1.76 a share, after posting net income of $289 million, or $2.10 a share, in the same quarter a year ago. The company said net sales fell 26% to $9.198 billion in the first quarter versus a year ago amid soft demand in agribusiness. Bunge said it expected a "solid second-half performance," but downgraded its full-year earnings forecast from $6.90 to $7.60 per share to $4.90 to $5.40 per share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast full-year earnings of $6.73 a share. Marriott posts net loss as revenue, RevPAR drop (6:51 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Marriott International Inc. MAR, +1.55% reported a first-quarter net loss of $25 million, or 6 cents a share, a reversal from $120 million, or 33 cents a share, earned in the first three months of 2008. The Bethesda, Md.-based hotel company's quarterly revenue dropped about 15%, to $2.5 billion from $2.95 billion in the prior year. On an adjusted basis to factor out restructuring costs, other charges and certain tax items, Marriott said it would have had a profit of $85 million, or 24 cents a share for the three months ended March 27. The consensus of 17 analysts polled by FactSet Research had been for Marriott to generate quarterly earnings of 14 cents a share. The adjusted profit came in higher than management had forecast in February, Marriott said. Reflecting the downturn in the global economy, the company said revenue per available room fell 19.6% in the latest quarter from the previous year. NII Holdings profit down on currency swings (6:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Latin American mobile operator NII Holdings NIHD, +9.33% said its first-quarter profit dropped 34% to $70.6 million, or 43 cents a share, while revenue slipped 3% to $961 million. The company blamed weak Latin American currencies for the profit fall. It added 266,000 net subscribers to its network, bringing its ending subscriber base to 6.5 million, a 28% increase in the ending subscriber base compared to the end of first quarter 2008. Thermo Fisher first-quarter earnings slump (6:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Thermo Fisher Scientific TMO, +0.26% on Thursday said first-quarter net income fell to $148.9 million, or 35 cents a share, from $229.7 million, or 53 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Adjusted net income, which includes amortization of acquisition-related intangible assets, fell to $261.8 million, or 62 cents a share, from $318.5 million, or 73 cents a share a year ago. An analyst survey by FactSet Research produced a consensus forecast of 70 cents a share. Revenues fell 12% to $2.26 billion. Citing world economic conditions, the company lowered 2009 revenue guidance by $400 million to $9.6 billion to $9.9 billion, and cut its full-year earnings guidance by 20 cents to a range of $2.80 to $3.10 a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet were looking for full-year earnings of $3.15. Reliance Infrastructure FY net up 5%; shares jump (6:26 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- India's Reliance Infrastructure Thursday said its profit for the year ended March 31 rose 5% as it sold more electrical energy and after a sharp increase in revenue for its engineering and constuction division. Net income rose to 11.39 billion rupees ($226 million) from 10.85 billion rupees. The company earned 98.59 billion rupees in revenue in the year ended March 31, higher than the 64.48 billion rupee revenue a year earlier. Shares of the Sensex-constituent company jumped 6.7% after the results were declared. Fiat reports $536 million loss as sales slump 25% (6:25 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Italian automaker Fiat(IT:F)swung to a first-quarter loss of 411 million euros ($536 million), as revenue dropped 25% to 11.3 billion euros. The sales drop was most notable in construction equipment and trucks, the company said, while market declines for automobiles and agricultural equipment "were more contained." It did see an improvement through the rest of the year and expects a profit over 100 million euros while demand for its products will drop around 20%. It said final terms on an alliance with Chrysler continue to be negotiated with the U.S. Treasury and other stakeholders. If negotations are successful, final terms will be set on or before April 30. RadioShack profit climbs 11%, margin strengthens (6:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Consumer electronics retailer RadioShack RSH, -0.07% said Thursday that its first-quarter net profit rose 11% to $43.1 million, or 34 cents a share, from $38.8 million, or 30 cents a share, as revenue grew 5.6% to $1 billion. Same-store sales for company-operated stores were up 5% from a year earlier, the retailer added. CEO Julian Day said the company's wireless business and sales of digital converter boxes helped drive the result and added that operating margin improved to 8% from 6.4%. Analysts had, on average, been expecting the group to report earnings of 20 cents a share on revenue of $944 million, according to a FactSet survey. SunTrust Banks loses $815 million on impairments (6:15 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- SunTrust Banks STI, +2.22% said it swung to a first-quarter loss of $815.2 million, or $2.49 a share, from a year-earlier profit of $290.6 million, or 81 cents a share. The Atlanta bank said it took a $714.8 million, or $2.03 a share, goodwill impairment charge on its mortgage and commercial real estate-related assets. Excluding that, it would have lost 46 cents a share on higher recession-related costs, the firm said. The bank recorded a provision for loan losses of $994.1 million, which exceeded net charge-offs of $610.1 million by $384.0 million and increased the allowance for loan and lease losses to $2,735.0 million, or 2.21% of total loans. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had forecast a loss of 56 cents a share. Danaher profit and sales drop 13% (6:07 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Danaher DHR, +1.44% said its first-quarter net profit dropped to $237.7 million, or 72 cents a share, from $276.5 million, or 83 cents a share, with sales falling 13% to $2.63 billion. "Few of our businesses have been immune to this unprecedented downturn and as a result we continue to deploy cost reduction actions across the company," CEO H. Lawrence Culp said in a statement. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings of 73 cents a share. CNH Global swings to loss; recovery months away (5:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- CNH Global CNH, +26.92% a maker of agricultural and construction equipment, said it swung to a first-quarter net loss of $126 million, or 53 cents a share, from a profit of $112 million, or 47 cents a share, earned in the year-earlier quarter. Sales dropped 25% to $3.27 billion. The company said the results were affected by the "negative global economic conditions," the continued deterioration of the global construction equipment market and the strong U.S. dollar. It also said that although there are some signs that the rate of decline in orders may be moderating, economic recovery appears to be at least nine months away. It anticipated equipment operations sales to fall 15% to 25% this year and plans to continue to adjust production to align with demand. Mizuho says 2008 net loss may tally $5.9 billion (3:46 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Mizuho Financial Group Inc.(JP:8411)said Thursday it expects a net loss of 580 billion yen ($5.92 billion) in the fiscal year which ended March 31, revising down its earlier forecast for a 100 billion yen profit. Mizuho said its securities valuation loss for the recently-completed fiscal year is estimated at 442.5 billion yen. Sodexo first-half net income unchanged at EUR219M (2:59 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Sodexo(FR:SW), the French food provider of food and facilities-management services, on Thursday reported fiscal first-half net income of 219 million euros ($285 million), unchanged over the same period a year ago. Analysts surveyed by Dow Jones were calling for net income of 211 million euros. Sodexo said first-half revenue rose 7.8% (after consolidation of acquisitions) and organic growth -- revenue excluding acquisitions and currency fluctuations -- rose 3.7%. In the same period a year ago, the company reported organic growth of 9.2%. Sodexo said in the current economic climate "caution is required" but confirmed its objectives set in November 2008 for organic-revenue growth between 2% and 5% and consolidated-revenue growth between 4% and 7%. Debenhams profit up 25%, won't pay dividend (2:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. department store operator Debenhams(UK:DEB)said Thursday that its fiscal first-half net profit rose 25% to 81.2 million pounds ($117.7 million) as revenue edged up 3.4% to 1.06 billion pounds. The group said trading conditions across the sector were difficult, with comparable sales down 3.6%, but that profit growth had been driven by better management of costs and stock levels and a rise in gross margin. Debenhams said it won't pay an interim dividend because it wants to focus on reducing leverage and maintaining investments in higher returning projects. In the first seven weeks of its fiscal second-half, Debenhams said comparable sales rose 1.9% and gross margin was also higher than a year earlier. Lonmin production down 8%, sticks to sales view (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Platinum miner Lonmin(UK:LMI)said Thursday that total tones mined in the fiscal second quarter fell 8% to 2.7 million, due to the planned closure of its Marikana opencast operations. The group maintained its guidance for fiscal 2009 sales of around 700,000 ounces of platinum. The group said Platinum sales in the first half of the fiscal year were around 45% of the full-year target for its core Marikana operations and were ahead of its initial expectations. The group has also completed a $575 million debt refinancing package, which lengthens the tenure of its banking facilities. Schroders pretax profit down 71% after outflows (2:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. fund manager Schroders(UK:SDR)said Thursday that its first-quarter pretax profit fell 71% to 12.2 million pounds ($17.7 million). Excluding exceptional items such as redundancy costs, the group said pretax profit was 36.1 million pounds. Assets under management at the end of March stood at 103.1 billion pounds, compared to 110.2 billion pounds at the end of December following outflows from its institutional fund management business. "The high level of volatility in financial markets in the first quarter is likely to persist and continue to affect investor demand. Against this background, we have reduced our staff costs and taken actions which will lead to a reduction in other costs later in the year and into 2010," the group said. Hyundai Motor first-quarter profit tumbles 43% (2:09 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- South Korean automaker Hyundai Motor Co. HYMLF, -11.11% on Thursday reported a 43% decline in first-quarter profits in the wake of the impact on sales from the global economic downturn, according to reports. Net income dropped to 225 billion won ($166.5 million) -- slightly ahead of expectations -- from 392.7 billion won in the year-earlier period. Revenue dropped 26% to 6.03 trillion won. Despite the fall in profit, Hyundai stock rose 3.6% in Seoul late afternoon trading. Credit Suisse swings back to profit in Q1 (1:06 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Credit Suisse Group said Thursday it swung back to black in the first quarter, as its investment-banking business returned to "significant profitability." The banking giant made 2.01 billion Swiss francs in net income, compared with a loss of 2.15 billion Swiss francs in the year-earlier period. Its Tier 1 capital ratio stood at 14.1% at the end of the quarter, it said. Mizuho to post $5 billion-plus loss in fiscal 2008 (12:30 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Mizuho Financial Group Inc.(JP:8411)is likely to post to a net loss of more than 500 billion yen ($5.1 billion) in the fiscal year which ended March 31, owing to a surge in costs related to bad loans, according to a report Thursday by Kyodo News. The bank, one of Japan's three largest, last year reported fiscal 2007 net income fell by almost half from a year earlier. Shares of Mizuho were down 2.6% in early Thursday afternoon trade in Tokyo. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. on Thursday reported a 7% rise in second-quarter profit, citing a double-digit surge in the sale of generic drugs and strong cost-control measures. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% shares gained 2% to $35.41. The Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical services company posted a profit of $143.4 million, or 95 cents a share, up from $133.9 million, or 83 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $17.3 billion from $17.8 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a profit, on average, of 89 cents a share with total sales of $17.9 billion. AmerisourceBergen said it expects 2009 earnings of $3.18 to $3.30 a share, up from its earlier view of $3.08 to $3.25 a share. Wall Street previously forecast a profit of $3.18 a share. "The increase in our expectations ... is primarily the result of less outstanding shares, now expected to be lower by 6 percent to 7 percent compared to last fiscal year, and of reduced interest expense, now expected to be comparable to the prior fiscal year interest expense of $64 million," CEO David Yost said in a statement. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock
title: Drug sales boost AmerisourceBergen profit

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Thursday second-quarter net income rose to $143.4 million, or 95 cents a share, from $133.9 million, or 83 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $17.3 billion from $17.8 billion. The Valley Forge, Pa. company said it expects 2009 earnings of $3.18 to $3.30 a share, compared to its earlier view of $3.08 to $3.25 a share. (Updated to correct year-ago net income figure.)
title: CORRECT: AmerisourceBergen net income rises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies made notable moves in the stock market on Wednesday: Advancers: Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% shares climbed 5.3% following the company's launch of a new version of its iPod shuffle with four times the memory capacity of its predecessor. See full story. Big Lots BIG, +2.64% rose 6.6%. J.P. Morgan raised its rating on the discount closeout retailer to overweight from neutral. Financials: Morgan Stanley MS, +1.98% rose 9% and Comerica CMA, +1.76% added 8.7% after Goldman Sachs identified a group of banks that it says are in good capital shape and are likely to pay off government TARP money ahead of rivals. J.P. Morgan JPM, +1.82% added 6.6%, Bank of New York Mellon BK, +1.82% rose 9.2% and U.S. Bancorp USB, +0.86% gained 16%. Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% shares advanced 7%. The automaker said recent changes made in its labor contract with the United Auto Workers will narrow the pay gap enjoyed by foreign competitors and save $500 million or more a year. See full story. Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. HOV, +0.55% jumped 10%. The home builder's first-quarter loss widened to $178.4 million, or $2.29 a share, from $168.8 million, or $2.07 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $373.8 million from $1.09 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated a loss of $1.74 a share on revenue of $405.7 million. J. Crew Group Inc. JCG rose 8.6%. The retailer posted a smaller-than-expected fourth-quarter loss. The company sees adjusted earnings of 7 cents to 12 cents a share in the first quarter, compared with Wall Street's estimate of 11 cents a share. JetBlue JBLU, +0.74% advanced 12%. The low-cost airline got a boost from an upgrade at Bank of America-Merrill Lynch. Office Depot ODP, +0.94% jumped more than 10%, the biggest gainer in the S&P 500. Rival Staples SPLS said that its fourth-quarter profit dropped 14% and declined to provide an outlook. Sirius XM Radio SIRI, +1.05% rose 6.6%. The satellite-radio provider reported late Tuesday that its fourth-quarter loss widened as revenue more than doubled. On a pro forma basis, the company reported adjusted operating earnings for the first time. And the company closed the second and last phase of the planned investment by Liberty Media Corp. LINTA "These transactions resolve the uncertainty surrounding" the debt of the parent and its subsidiaries that matures in 2009, Chief Executive Mel Karmazin said. UBS UBS, +0.40% (UBSN) rose 2.6% earlier. The bank's 2008 net loss was 1.19 billion Swiss francs ($1.02 billion) wider than previously reported, at 20.89 billion francs, partly because of the inclusion of its $780 million settlement with U.S. authorities. The loss, which had previously been pegged at 19.7 billion francs, also included the impact of the Swiss National Bank's valuation of around $7.8 billion of securities not yet transferred by UBS to the SNB. Vail Resorts MTN, -0.91% jumped 11%. The ski-resort operator said its fiscal second-quarter earnings rose to $60.5 million, or $1.65 a share, from $51.3 million, or $1.31 a share, in the year-ago period. It also lowered its income outlook for 2009 and plans salary cuts. Decliners Casinos: MGM Mirage MGM, +2.70% shares and Las Vegas Sands Corp. LVS, +1.58% shares each lost earlier advances and were down 3.1% and 4.2%, respectively. Both companies had their ratings cut by Moody's as gaming revenues in Las Vegas continue to deteriorate. Moody's lowered its probability of default and corporate family ratings of Las Vegas Sands to B3 from B2. Also, the agency cut MGM Mirage's probability of default rating to Caa2 from Caa1 and its corporate family rating to Caa1 from B3. The outlook for both companies is negative. Exelon EXC, +1.22% lost 5.4%. Deutsche Bank downgraded the electric power giant to hold from buy. Halliburton HAL, +1.93% lost 5.9%. It plans to issue $2 billion in senior notes in two tranches. Health care: Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% lost more than 11% and McKesson MCK, +0.15% dropped 15%, among the biggest losers in the S&P 500. Reports said McKesson shares were being hit by financial concerns about drugstores, the drug wholesaler's customers. Pharmaceutical-services company AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% fell 8.4%. HSBC Holdings HBC, +3.60% shares slumped 13%. Investors continued to re-evaluate prior expectations that Europe's largest bank was better positioned than its ailing peers. See London Markets. LG Display LPL, +0.67% declined 7% while Philips Electronics PHG, +0.79% rose 5.1%. Phillips sold its remaining stake in LG for 630 million euros ($803 million). Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. TTWO, +0.33% slumped 7.3%. The video-game publisher reported a wider fiscal first-quarter loss on a lighter slate of game releases. For the quarter ended Jan. 31, the loss was $50.4 million, or 66 cents a share, compared with $38 million, or 52 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Excluding costs related to stock options and other items, the company would have lost 52 cents a share. Sales rose nearly 7% to $256.8 million. Analysts were expecting a loss of 73 cents a share on revenue of $207.2 million, according to Thomson Reuters. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Wednesday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% affirmed its fiscal 2009 outlook Thursday and said shareholders approved a proposal to redeem the company's shareholder rights, or "poison pill," agreement. The pharmaceutical services company expects fiscal 2009 earnings from continuing operations of $3.08 to $3.25 a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimate fiscal 2009 earnings of $3.19 a share. AmerisourceBergen said the proposal to redeem the shareholder rights agreement is not binding on the company, and that the board will take the voting results under advisement.
title: AmerisourceBergen affirms outlook, may redeem 'poison pill'

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Managed health-care giant UnitedHealth Group and pharmaceutical-services company AmerisourceBergen Corp. both maintained their annual outlooks, as UnitedHealth reported a drop in its quarterly profit while AmerisourceBergen saw a small increase. Minneapolis-based UnitedHealth UNH, -2.06% said fourth-quarter earnings fell to $726 million, or 60 cents a share, from $1.22 billion, or 92 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. The latest results included a charge of 18 cents a share to resolve class-action litigation; excluding that, adjusted earnings were 78 cents a share. Consensus expectations were for earnings of 76 cents a share, according to FactSet Research. Fourth-quarter revenue rose to $20.5 billion from $18.7 billion. The company also said it was sticking with its previously announced estimate of full-year 2009 earnings of $2.90 to $3.15 a share. It said it expects "meaningful" growth in its government-sponsored businesses and said there's strong interest in its Medicare market offerings and continued expansion from its state and public health program relationships. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said that profit in its fiscal first quarter ended Dec. 31 rose to $111.1 million, or 72 cents a share, from $109.8 million, or 66 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose to $17.34 billion from $17.28 billion, driven by generic drug distribution and specialty distribution and related services. The company reaffirmed its fiscal year 2009 guidance, with per-share profit from continuing operations estimated to be in the range of $3.08 to $3.25, representing a gain of as much as 12% from last year. Revenue is expected to rise between 1% and 3%. Profit was driven in part by a double-digit increase in the sale of generic drugs, especially its proprietary PRxO Generics Solution, as well as by expense control, the company said.
