title: UnitedHealth, AmerisourceBergen reaffirm forecasts

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Thursday that profit in the fiscal first quarter ended Dec. 31 rose to $111.1 million, or 72 cents a share, from $109.8 million, or 66 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $17.34 billion from $17.28 billion. The Company reaffirmed its fiscal year 2009 guidance, with per-share profit from continuing operations estimated to be in the range of $3.08 to $3.25.
title: AmerisourceBergen maintains outlook as profit rises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Thursday's session are Google, Microsoft, Nokia and Advanced Micro Devices. Google GOOG, +2.71% is projected to report fourth-quarter earnings of $4.97 a share, according to a survey by Thomson Reuters. Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% is forecast to post second-quarter earnings of 50 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Finnish telecom giant Nokia NOK, +0.74% is expected to report earnings of 38 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters estimated Advanced Micro Devices AMD, +2.45% to post a fourth-quarter loss of 54 cents a share. Analysts predicted Capital One Financial Corp. COF, +1.64% to report earnings of 33 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to Thomson Reuters. KeyCorp KEY, +1.45% is likely to post a loss of 2 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. Janus Capital Group JNS is expected to post fourth-quarter earnings of 4 cents a share, according to analysts polled by FactSet Research. Fifth Third Bancorp FITB, +0.60% is projected to post fourth-quarter earnings of a penny a share, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. Analysts, on average, see Synovus Financial Corp. SNV, +1.18% reporting a loss of 49 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to Thomson Reuters. CIT Group CIT, -0.06% is expected to report a loss of 48 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Comerica Inc. CMA, +1.76% is likely to post earnings of 24 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimate SunTrust STI, +2.22% to post fourth-quarter earnings of 11 cents a share. BB&T Corp. BBT, +0.99% is forecast to report fourth-quarter earnings of 47 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. AmeriSourceBergen ABC, +1.29% is projected to post first-quarter earnings of 69 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Federated Investors Inc. FII, +1.55% is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 52 cents a share, according to analysts polled by FactSet Research. Analysts polled by FactSet Research see Lockheed Martin LMT, +0.78% reporting fourth-quarter earnings of $1.91 a share. Union Pacific UNP, +2.81% is projected to report earnings of $1.24 a share in the fourth quarter, according to a consensus survey by FactSet Research. Southwest Airlines LUV, +1.83% is forecast to post fourth-quarter earnings of 5 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Sherwin-Williams SHW, +1.78% is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 53 cents a share, according to analysts polled by FactSet Research. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated Exelon Corp. EXC, +1.22% to post fourth-quarter earnings of $1.04 a share. Analysts predicted Consolidated Edison ED, +0.49% to report earnings of 68 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to FactSet Research. Intuitive Surgical ISRG, +2.59% is likely to post fourth-quarter earnings of $1.28 a share, according to analysts polled by FactSet Research. Baxter International Inc. BAX, +1.86% is expected to report earnings of 89 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to a consensus survey by FactSet Research. UnitedHealth Group UNH, -2.06% is projected to post fourth-quarter earnings of 78 cents a share, according to analysts polled by FactSet Research. Overseas, investors will keep an eye on Korean electronics behemoth Samsung Electronics Ltd. SSNGY, +0.00% which is scheduled to release fourth-quarter earnings. Asia's two largest telecom companies SK Telecom SKM, +1.77% and KT Corp. KTC, +3.02% will report fourth-quarter results as well and Italian automaker Fiat (F) FIADF which recently struck a deal to take a 35% stake in Chrysler, is also slated to detail fourth-quarter earnings. After Wednesday's closing bell, Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% reported a fiscal first-quarter profit of $1.61 billion, or $1.78 a share, on revenue of $10.17 billion. During the same period a year ago, Apple earned $1.58 billion, or $1.76 a share, on revenue of $9.6 billion. The results beat the estimates of analysts surveyed by FactSet Research, who forecast Apple to earn $1.29 a share on $10.16 billion in revenue for what is typically the company's busiest business period of the year. The company didn't give any more comments about the health of Chief Executive Steve Jobs, who is taking a medical leave from Apple until late June. Full story on Apple's earnings Watch list Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corp. BNI reported a fourth-quarter profit of $615 million, or $1.79 a share, up from $517 million, or $1.46 a share, a year ago. Revenue rose to $4.37 billion from $4.25 billion a year earlier. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a profit, on average, of $1.77 a share on sales of $4.45 billion. Citigroup C, -1.11% said Richard Parsons, lead director and chairman of the board's nomination and governance committee, will succeed Sir Win Bischoff as chairman of the board, effective Feb. 23. Bischoff will not stand for re-election to the board at the next annual meeting and will retire from Citi later this year. Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% plans to book $170 million in fourth-quarter charges. Continental said it will record a loss of $125 million from a fuel derivative contract with a bankrupt counterparty and $44 million in pension plan settlement charges resulting from pilot retirements in 2008. The other charges include the write down of auction-rate securities and severance charges. EBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $367 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with earnings of $531 million, or 39 cents a share, for the same period last year. Excluding charges related to stock options, the company said it would have earned $524 million, or 41 cents a share, for the recent period. Revenue fell more than 6% to $2.04 billion. Analysts were expecting earnings of 39 cents a share on revenue of $2.1 billion, according to consensus estimates from FactSet Research. More details on why eBay earnings fell in fourth quarter Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% said it will stop production at five factories in a bid to consolidate manufacturing operations. The chip maker said the affected facilities include two in Penang, Malaysia, one in Cavite, Philippines, a facility in Hillsboro, Ore., and one in Santa Clara, Calif. The changes could affect between 5,000 and 6,000 employees, although not all of them will be asked to leave the company, Intel said. Full story on Intel's latest restructuring move OfficeMax Inc. OMXS30, +1.54% named Bruce Besanko as chief financial officer, effective Feb. 16. Besanko, 50, most recently served as CFO of the now-defunct Circuit City Stores Inc. Phillips-Van Heusen Corp. PVH, +5.15% has eliminated about 250 salaried positions, or 10% of total salaried workforce, and about 150 hourly manufacturing jobs in line with its restructuring effort. As part of the belt-tightening, the company is downsizing its retail operations and shutting down domestic production of machine-made neckwear. The clothing manufacturer also projected a loss of 74 cents to 79 cents a share in the fourth quarter and earnings of $1.69 to $1.74 a share in 2008. On an adjusted basis, Phillips-Van Heusen expects to earn 25 cents to 30 cents a share in the fourth quarter and $2.90 to $2.95 a share for the full year. It forecast fourth-quarter revenue of $585 million to $590 million and about $2.5 billion for 2008. Sanmina-SCI Corp. SANM, +0.77% reported it swung to a first-quarter net loss of $25.3 million, or 5 cents a share, from a net income of $7.9 million, or a penny a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue decreased to $1.42 billion from $1.78 billion a year ago, the electronics contract manufacturer said. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast earnings of a penny a share on revenue of $1.48 billion. In the second quarter, the company is targeting revenue of $1.3 billion and plans to breakeven on per-share basis. Seagate Technology STX, +2.87% reported a fiscal second-quarter loss of $496 million, or $1.02 a share, based on preliminary results. That compares with a profit of $403 million, or 73 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Revenue was $2.27 billion, down from $3.42 billion last year. The company's results included charges that accounted for a loss of 79 cents a share. Analysts had expected the disk drive maker to report a loss of 5 cents a share, on revenue of $2.46 billion. More details on Seagate's big quarterly loss SLM Corp. SLM, +1.91% more commonly known as Sallie Mae, reported fourth-quarter "core earnings" net income of $65 million, or 8 cents a share, down from $117 million, or 19 cents a share, last year. Earnings on a "core" basis exclude the effect of accounting for derivatives. After the payment of preferred dividends, the educational lender reported a quarterly loss of $243.3 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with a loss of $1.64 billion, or $3.98 a share, a year ago. Williams-Sonoma Inc. WSM, +1.77% will trim about 1,400 jobs, or 18% of its work force worldwide, as a cost-cutting measure. Williams-Sonoma said it hopes to reduce fiscal 2009 expenses by about $75 million. The company sees fourth-quarter earnings at the low end of its previously announced 10-cents to 30-cents-a-share range. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks in focus for Thursday

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Thursday that it continues to expect 2009 earnings per share to be in a range of $3.08 to $3.25, an increase of 7% to 12% over the $2.89 from continuing operations in fiscal 2008. Also unchanged are expectations for total revenue growth of between 1% and 3%. Assumptions reflect the 3% negative impact from the loss on July 1, of a large retail drug chain; operating margin expansion in the low to mid single digit range; and free cash flow in the range of $460 million to $535 million, which includes capital expenditures in the $140 million range.
title: AmerisourceBergen affirms 2009 earnings-per-share forecast

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Friday's session are J.C. Penney, Agilent, Abercrombie & Fitch and Citigroup. J.C. Penney JCP, -0.98% is expected to post third-quarter earnings of 55 cents a share, according to a consensus survey by FactSet Research. Agilent Technologies Inc. A, +0.75% is projected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 59 cents a share. Abercrombie & Fitch Co. ANF, +2.41% is forecast to post earnings of 72 cents a share in the third quarter. After Thursday's closing bell, The Wall Street Journal reported top executives at Citigroup C, -1.11% bought about 1.2 million shares. Citi's Chief Executive Vikram Pandit bought 750,000 shares, and the head of the institutional clients group, John Havens, acquired 250,000 shares, according to the Journal. See related story Watch list AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s ABC, +1.29% board raised the quarterly dividend by 33% and approved a new stock buyback program. The board raised the dividend to 10 cents from 7.5 cents. The dividend will be paid Dec. 8 to stockholders of record as of Nov. 24. Also, the board approved a $500 million share buyback program. Brunswick Corp. BC, +1.71% will close its boat plant in Cumberland, Md., and transfer production to a plant in Ashland City, Tenn. The closure will affect 115 jobs, the company said. The plant closure is expected by the end of the year. El Paso Electric EE, +0.79% named David Stevens chief executive officer, effective Nov. 17. Stevens succeeds J. Frank Bates, who has served as interim president and CEO since February 2008. He was previously president and CEO of Cascade Natural Gas Corp. E-Trade Financial Corp. ETFC, +3.38% said it will retire all $450 million of its 6.125% subordinated notes due 2018. The move is in connection with the issuance of 25 million shares of E-Trade common shares Nov. 18 at an effective issue price of $18 a share. These notes are a part of the mandatory convertible debt securities the financial firm had issued in November 2005. It was required to attempt a remarketing to purchasers willing to pay par for the notes but due to the current credit market turmoil, E-Trade was not able to successfully remarket the notes, according to E-Trade. Kohl's Corp. KSS, +1.47% reported a third-quarter profit of $160.2 million, or 52 cents a share, down from $194 million, or 61 cents a share, a year ago. Sales fell less than 1% to $3.8 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a profit of 52 cents a share on sales of $3.88 billion. Kohl's warned that it expects to post a profit of 90 cents to $1.05 a share in the fourth quarter, down from a prior range of $1.26 to $1.34 a share due to what the company described as "the most challenging" holiday season in years. Wall Street previously targeted earnings of $1.27 a share. Nordstrom Inc. JWN, +1.06% said its third-quarter profit fell to $71 million, or 33 cents a share, from $166 million, or 68 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated a quarterly profit of 32 cents a share. Revenue fell to $1.81 billion from $1.97 billion last year. The company sees earnings of 35 cents to 45 cents a share for the fourth quarter, and $1.87 to $1.97 a share for the year. Analysts estimate earnings of 70 cents a share in the fourth quarter, and $2.21 a share for the year. OfficeMax Inc. OMXS30, +1.54% said it will cut 245 jobs from its corporate staff and field management in North America. The company expects to save about $20 million from the cuts, and pay out $8.5 million in severance costs. The company employs about 36,000 workers. Wynn Resorts Ltd. WYNN, +3.59% will offer 5 million in common shares in conjunction with its inclusion in the S&P 500. Deutsche Bank Securities Inc. and Banc of America Securities LLC are acting as joint book running managers and underwriters for the deal. They also have an option to purchase up to an additional 750,000 shares to cover over-allotments. Wynn plans to use the funds for general corporate purposes, including repayment of debt. title: Stocks in focus for Friday

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said late Thursday its board raised its quarterly dividend by 33% and approved a new stock buyback program. The board raised the dividend to 10 cents from 7.5 cents. The dividend will be paid Dec. 8 to stockholders of record as of Nov. 24. Also, the board approved a $500 million share buyback program.
title: AmerisourceBergen ups dividend, OKs $500 mln share buyback

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies were making notable moves in the U.S. stock market Thursday: Advancers Alcatel-Lucent ALU, +1.21% rallied 9.5% Thursday after it posted a 43% fall in third-quarter adjusted operating profit as its core carrier division sunk into the red in the first earnings report under new Chief Executive Ben Verwaayen. "Our profitability remains unsatisfactory," said Verwaayen, the former chief executive of BT Group PLC BT, +1.06% (BT.A), who took up the reins at the French telecommunications equipment maker at the start of September. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said its third-quarter earnings were $115 million, or 73 cents a share, compared to $88 million, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue was $16.66 billion compared to $15.20 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated earnings per share of 71 cents and sales of $17.46 billion. "We expect diluted earnings per share for fiscal year 2009 to be in a range of $3.08 to $3.25, which represents an increase of 7% to 12% over the $2.89 from continuing operations in fiscal 2008," said Chief Executive David Yost. Allied Waste Inc. AW surged 17% after it reported its third-quarter net income quadrupled to $112.5 million, or 26 cents a share, from $27.2 million, or 5 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding one-time items, adjusted earnings from ongoing operations were 28 cents a share, up from 24 cents a year ago. Revenue rose to $1.61 billion from $1.56 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had predicted earnings of 26 cents a share on $1.59 billion in revenue. Atmel Corp. ATML jumped 13.3% after it said its board rejected a takeover offer from Microchip Technology Inc. MCHP, +0.22% and ON Semiconductor ONNN The board called the $5-a-share, or $2.3 billion, offer "inadequate" for several reasons. See full story CA CA, +1.25% was up 9.3% after it reported its fiscal second-quarter net income rose to $209 million, or 39 cents a share, from $137 million, or 26 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue increased to $1.11 billion from $1.07 billion. The company earned 41 cents a share on an adjusted basis. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast the company to report earnings of 37 cents a share on revenue of $1.12 billion. The company also said it will buy back up to $250 million in common shares. Cameron International Corp. CAM, -1.67% surged 11.4%. The Houston provider of flow-equipment products and services for energy and process applications reported its third-quarter net income rose 10% on 27% higher revenue. Earnings reached $166.3 million, or 73 cents a share, from $150.7 million, or 65 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $1.5 billion from $1.19 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 71 cents of profit on $1.49 billion of revenue. The company expects to earn 74 cents to 76 cents a share in the fourth quarter and $2.67 to $2.69 in 2008. The figures exclude a charge of about 9 cents that Cameron will take to end its U.S. pension plans. FactSet's survey was looking for 78 cents for the quarter and $2.68 for the year. CBS Corp. CBS, -0.94% was up 8.1%. The New York-based broadcaster swung to a $12.46 billion third-quarter loss, reflecting a $14.12 billion noncash pretax charge stemming from an assessment of impairments to goodwill and intangible assets, on 2.9% higher revenue. In the year-earlier period, CBS earned $343.3 million. On a per-share basis, the loss was $18.58 versus profit of 48 cents. Adjusted earnings from continuing operations fell to 43 cents a share from 50 cents. Shares outstanding fell 6.2% to 670.9 million. Revenue reached $3.38 billion from $3.28 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 41 cents of profit on $3.38 billion of revenue. CME Group CME, +1.83% reported its third-quarter net income fell to $169 million, or $2.81 a share, from $202 million, or $3.87 a share, in the same quarter a year ago. The company earned $4.13 a share on an adjusted basis in the quarter. Revenue increased to $681 million from $565 million a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast CME Group to report earnings of $3.99 on revenue of $623.8 million. CVS Caremark Corp. CVS, -0.80% added 11.4% after it said its third-quarter net income rose to $732.5 million, or 51 cents a share, from $686.6 million, or 47 cents a share. Adjusted earnings from continuing operations were 60 cents a share, up 20%. Revenue edged up to $20.86 billion from $20.5 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet were looking for the Woonsocket, R.I., drugstore retailer to earn 59 cents a share. Delta Air Lines Inc. DAL, +1.63% rose 19.5%, after news it and Northwest Airlines Inc. NWA have combined to form the world's largest airline by traffic. On Wednesday, the Justice Department cleared Delta's acquisition of Northwest, the last barrier to the deal. The new airline will go by the Delta name and be headquartered in Atlanta. DTE Energy Co. DTE, +0.38% said third-quarter profit fell to $177 million, or $1.08 a share, from $197 million, or $1.19 a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated a quarterly profit of 88 cents a share. Revenue rose to $2.34 billion from $2.13 billion. The company estimates operating earnings of $2.80 to $3.20 a share for the year. Analysts forecast $2.97 a share. Equity Residential EQR, +0.11% reported its third-quarter funds from operations rose to 65 cents a share from 58 cents a share in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had forecast FFO of 63 cents a share. Its net income fell to $178.2 million from $457.7 million. Earnings available to common shares were 64 cents compared with $1.62 a year earlier. Revenue increased to $538.3 million from $501.1 million. Genelabs Technologies Inc. GNLB the Redwood City, Calif., biotechnology firm, skyrocketed 430.4% after it definitively agreed to be acquired by GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.79% (GSK) for $1.30 a share cash, or $57 million. The UK health-care giant is paying 5 1/2 times Genelabs' closing price on Wednesday of $0.23 a share. Genelabs's 52-week high was $2.02, touched exactly one year ago. In a statement late on Wednesday, GlaxoSmithKline said the deal will strengthen its effort to develop therapies against the hepatitis C virus. Genelabs' board has approved the deal and urges holders to approve it. The companies said they hope to close the purchase in December. Hanesbrands Inc. HBI, +0.22% rose 9.5% after it said its third-quarter net income fell to $15.9 million, or 17 cents a share, from $38.9 million, or 40 cents a share. Profit was hurt by restructuring charges and the bankruptcy of regional retailer Mervyn's. Hanesbrands, maker of Hanes underwear and Champion sportswear, said sales were unchanged from a year ago at $1.15 billion. Iron Mountain Inc. IRM, +0.46% said its third-quarter net income fell to $11 million, or 6 cents a share, from $51 million, or 25 cents a share, in the third quarter of 2007. Consensus expectations were for net income of 21 cents a share, according to FactSet Research. The Boston-based data-protection-and-storage firm said a sharply rising dollar undercut net income, resulting in a net non-cash charge of 17 cents per share, as the company marked dollar-denominated third-party and intercompany debt to market. Third-quarter revenue rose to $784 million from $702 million. Maxim Integrated Products Inc. MXIM, +2.15% said its fiscal first-quarter profit fell to $67.6 million, or 21 cents a share, from $83.6 million, or 25 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $501.2 million from $524.1 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated 26 cents a share on revenue of $503.6 million. MetLife Inc. MET, -0.02% said third-quarter net income came in at $630 million, down from $1.02 billion a year earlier. Profit from continuing operations was $1.03 billion, or $1.42 a share. Operating earnings, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses, were $639 million, or 88 cents a share. The insurance and annuity giant was expected to make $1.02 a share, according to FactSet. Murphy Oil Corp. MUR, +1.85% reported its third-quarter net income nearly tripled to $584.4 million, or $3.04 a share, from $199.5 million, or $1.04 a share, a year ago. Revenue rose to $8.19 billion from $4.78 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had predicted the company would earn $2.78 a share on $6.93 billion in revenue. Nintendo Co. NTDOY, +2.02% rose 6.9% after it said its net income for the six months ended Sept. 30 increased 9.4% to 144.83 billion yen ($1.34 billion) on strong demand for its gaming machines. Sales improved 20.4% to 836.88 billion yen. But the company cut its full-year net income forecast to 345 billion yen from 410 billion yen earlier because of a strengthened yen. The company also cut its annual dividend forecast to 1,630 yen from 1,680 yen earlier. Staples Inc. SPLS jumped 15.6%. It expects to report third-quarter earnings of 21 cents to 22 cents a share. Excluding one-time charges, the company forecast 41 cents to 42 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research expect earnings of 41 cents a share. Tesoro Corp. TSO, +0.00% reported its third-quarter net income rose to $259 million, or $1.86 a share, from $47 million, or 34 cents a share, a year earlier. The results benefited from a one-time accounting change that added 29 cents a share. Revenue rose to $8.7 billion from $5.9 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet had predicted the company would report earnings of $1.31 a share. TRW Automotive Holdings Corp. TRW, -3.33% leaped a16.1% after it swung to a third-quarter net loss of $54 million, or 53 cents a share, from profit of $23 million, or 22 cents a share. The Livonia, Mich., auto-parts supplier generated sales of $3.59 billion, up from $3.5 billion a year earlier. The consensus of analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had been a loss of 9 cents a share. TRW expects to generate 2008 earnings of 90 cents to $1.10 a share, including restructuring and asset-impairment charges. Unisys Corp. UIS, +2.38% added 10.8% after it said its third-quarter losses deepened to $34.7 million, or 10 cents a share, from $31 million, or 9 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue dipped to $1.31 billion from $1.39 billion. The Blue Bell, Pa. technology firm said the latest period included $3.7 million of pretax retirement-related income compared with $22.8 million of pretax retirement-related expense in the year-ago period. Foreign currency exchange rates had an approximately 2% favorable impact on revenue in the current quarter. Visa Inc. V, +2.25% added 7.0% after it narrowed its fourth-quarter loss to $356 million, or 45 cents a share, from $1.66 billion a year ago. Excluding one-time items, the credit card company earned 58 cents a share during the latest quarter. Revenue came in at $1.71 billion, up from $1.46 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a profit of 56 cents a share with revenue of $1.68 billion. Waste Management Inc. WMI, +1.37% rose 5.1% after it said its third-quarter net income rose 11.5% to $310 million, or 63 cents a share, from $278 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.6% to $3.53 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting the waste collection and recycling group to earn 62 cents a share in the latest quarter on sales of $3.52 billion. WPP WPPGY (WPP) rose 9.8% after it said its third-quarter profit rose 16% to 1.7 billion pounds ($2.9 billion). Revenue in constant currency rose 6% while comparable revenue climbed 3%. Year-to-date, headline operating margins were flat with a year earlier, with comparable revenue falling below expectations. This is mainly due to the third-quarter performance when the "Beijing Bounce" did not materialize to the extent forecast, WPP said. Decliners Ameriprise Financial Inc. AMP, +0.67% shed 12.8% after it swung to a third-quarter loss of $70 million, or 32 cents a share, from a profit of $237 million, or 83 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The company reported core operating earnings of $1.04 a share for the latest quarter. Revenue fell to $1.68 billion from $2.17 billion last year. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated a quarterly profit of 74 cents a share on revenue of $1.93 billion. Assurant Inc. AIZ, +0.53% plunged 24.9%. The New York-based insurer swung to a third-quarter net loss from a year-earlier profit on investment impairments and losses from storms. The loss was $111.4 million, or 95 cents a share, compared with net income of $187.2 million, or $1.56, in the year-earlier quarter. The investment losses totaled $194.5 million after tax. The catastrophe losses totaled $86.2 million net of reinsurance. Operating profit, which excludes investment gains and losses and other special items, was 70 cents a share against $1.63 a year earlier. Avon Products Inc. AVP, -1.05% lost 15.4%. It said its third-quarter net income doubled to $223 million, or 52 cent a share, from $139 million, or 32 cents, in the year-ago period. The cosmetics maker said revenue grew 13% to $2.6 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research forecast earnings of 43 cents a share. Eastman Kodak EK was down 5.7%. It said its third-quarter net income tripled to $101 million, or 35 cents a share, from $32 million, or 11 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted profit was 22 cents a share, compared with 46 cents. Changes to the company's post-employment boosted earnings in the latest quarter by 31 cents a share, offset by restructuring costs of 16 cents a share. Revenue fell 5% to $2.41 billion from $2.53 billion. Analysts expected the company to earn 23 cents a share on revenue of $2.55 billion, according to a survey by FactSet. Hartford Financial Services HIG, -0.41% plunged 51.6%. It swung to a third-quarter net loss of $2.6 billion, or $8.74 a share, from net income of $851 million, or $2.68 a share, in the third quarter of 2007. Excluding most realized investment gains and losses, Hartford had a loss of $422 million, or $1.40 a share, in the latest period. The loss was pegged at 59 cents a share by analysts in a FactSet survey. International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. IFF, +1.37% fell 6.9% after it reported its third-quarter net income of $57.7 million, or 73 cents a share, as opposed to $58.8 million, or 67 cents, in the year-earlier period. The New York-based company generated sales of $617.5 million, up 6% from $583.3 million, partly reflecting currency translations. Average shares outstanding fell 10%. Adjusted to factor out one-time items, the company earned 75 cents a share in the latest quarter, up from 71 cents a year earlier. International Paper Co. IP, +2.00% said third-quarter earnings fell to $149 million, or 35 cents a share, from $227 million, or 51 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Memphis paper and packaging company said sales rose 23% to $6.8 billion from $5.54 billion. On an adjusted basis, International Paper earned 84 cents a share, while analysts polled by FactSet expected earnings of 77 cents a share. JDS Uniphase JDSU lost 8.5% after it said its fiscal first-quarter net loss widened to $16.4 million, or 8 cents a share, from $6.9 million, or 3 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Revenue was $380.7 million, up from $356.7 million. Adjusted profit was 11 cents a share. Analysts expected earnings of 9 cents a share on revenue of $386.1 million, according to Thomson Reuters. Motorola Inc. MSI, +1.29% slipped 5.3% after it swung to a third-quarter net loss of $397 million, or 18 cents a share, from a profit of $60 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier. The loss included 23 cents-a-share of charges, write-downs and other one-off items. Analysts polled by FactSet had been expecting earnings of a penny a share. Sales fell 15% to $7.48 billion, with sales in its mobile devices segment dropping 31% to $3.1 billion. Motorola said it still intends to separate the business, but is no longer targeting the third quarter of 2009 due to the weak economic environment. Newell Rubbermaid Inc. NWL, +0.79% the Atlanta consumer-products company, reported third-quarter net income fell 68% on 4.3% higher sales. Net income was $55 million, or 20 cents a share, against $170.2 million, or 61 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were 36 cents versus 52 cents. Sales reached $1.76 billion from $1.69 billion. Sales excluding the effect of acquisitions rose 0.4%. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 34 cents of profit on $1.79 billion of sales. Pioneer Corp. PNCOF, -6.98% (6773) lost 7.9% after it reported its July to September net loss widened from the year-earlier period to 45.23 billion yen ($459.8 million). The company also upped its estimate of its net loss for the fiscal year ending March 31, putting it on track for a fourth straight annual loss, and it said President Tamahiko Sudo would step down. Prudential Financial PRU, +0.63% plummeted 18.1% after it posted a loss of $108 million, or 23 cents a share, for the third quarter, compared with a profit of $860 million, or $1.88 a share, a year earlier. Sales were $6.15 billion, down from $6.78 billion. The company said operating earnings, which exclude investment losses, were 74 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had forecast the company would earn 96 cents a share. RealNetworks Inc. RNWK, -4.37% swung to a net loss of $4.5 million, or 3 cents a share, from earnings of $4.3 million, or 3 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 5% to $152 million. Analysts were looking for a net loss of 3 cents a share on revenue of $153.5 million, according to consensus estimates from Thomson Reuters. Royal Dutch Shell RDS.A, +1.16% RDS.B, +1.13% reported a 22% rise in third-quarter profit as rising prices and improved profit from refining and marketing overcame a drop in production. Read the article. Sanmina-SCI Corp. SANM, +0.77% reported a fourth-quarter profit of $22,000, or break-even on a per-share basis, compared with a loss of $1.07 billion, or $2.03 a share, a year ago. Excluding one-time items, Sanmina earned $24 million, or 5 cents a share. By that measure, the company met the estimate of analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Revenue totaled $1.7 billion versus $1.75 billion. The electronics contract manufacturer also named Hari Pillai president and chief operating officer. Standard Pacific Corp. SPF, +33.33% skidded 13.8%. The Irvine, Calif., home builder reported late on Wednesday a wider third-quarter net loss on 38% lower revenue. The backlog of homes as of Sept. 30 was 1,248, down 48% from 2,421 a year earlier. The value of the backlog was $395.7 million down 59% from $966.4 million. The company said it has $712 million of homebuilding cash on the balance sheet. Symantec Corp. SYMC, +0.82% dropped 17.6% after it said fiscal second-quarter net income more than doubled to $140 million, or 16 cents a share, from $50.4 million, or 6 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $1.52 billion from $1.42 billion. Excluding special items, security and storage software maker Symantec said earnings were 37 cents a share. Analysts had estimated 35 cents a share and $1.54 billion in revenue, according to FactSet Research. Unilever UN, +1.04% UL, +0.83% (ULVR) said third-quarter profit jumped 72% to 1.7 billion euros ($2.2 billion). Adjusted pretax profit climbed 97% to 2.5 billion euros, topping analyst expectations of 2.2 billion euros. The Anglo-Dutch food and household products group said pricing actions and accelerated cost savings more than offset continued increases in commodity costs. "This year we now expect to deliver underlying sales growth well in excess of our long-term target range of [3% to 5%], together with an underlying improvement in operating margin for the year," said CEO Patrick Cescau. Wells Fargo & Co. WFC, +1.81% said it has issued 25,000 preferred shares to the Treasury for a total of $25 billion. The issuance is part of the Troubled Asset Relief Program, under which the Treasury is investing in U.S. financial firms to stabilize the financial markets. The preferred stock pays cumulative dividends of 5% a year for the first five years and 9% annually thereafter. As part of the deal, the Treasury also received warrants to purchase 110.26 million shares of Wells Fargo at $34.01 apiece. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Thursday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) - AmerisourceBergen Corp.'s fourth-quarter net income posted a better-than-expected gain in fourth-quarter earnings, sending shares of the drug distribution giant higher in early trading. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% said net income was $114.9 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with $87.6 million, or 50 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales for the Valley Forge, Pa.-based drug distributor were $17.2 billion vs. last year's $16.3 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected earnings of 71 cents a share on sales of $17.5 billion. The company said it expects next year's earnings to come in at $3.08 to $3.25 a share. The FactSet estimate is for $3.19 a share. Shares were up at the outset, swung to a loss by midday, then closed higher by 3% to $30.18 amid a broad market rally. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date
title: AmerisourceBergen earnings jump; shares climb

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. [s :ABC] said Thursday that third-quarter earnings were $115 million, or 73 cents a share, compared to $88 million, or 50 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $16.66 billion compared to $15.20 billion last year in the same period. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated, on average, earnings per share of 71 cents and sales of $17.46 billion. "We expect diluted earnings per share for fiscal year 2009 to be in a range of $3.08 to $3.25, which represents an increase of 7% to 12% over the $2.89 from continuing operations in fiscal 2008," said Chief Executive David Yost.
title: AmerisourceBergen earnings jump in quarter

content: Samsung Electronics shares drop as profit growth disappoints (10:01 PM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Samsung Electronics SSNLF, -3.07% Friday reported a lower-than-expected 51% jump in second-quarter profit, sending the South Korean electronics giant's shares down 3.4% in Seoul trading. Net income jumped 51% to 2.14 trillion won ($2.12 billion) from 1.42 trillion won in the year-ago quarter, but fell 2% from the January-March period. A Reuters poll expected net income of 2.3 trillion won. Quarterly sales grew 24% on-year to 18.14 trillion won, boosted by strong growth in liquid crystal display televisions and mobile handsets. Eastman reports 9.5% gain in earnings (5:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Eastman Chemical Co. EMN, +1.34% reported late Thursday second-quarter net income of $115 million, or $1.48 cents a share, up from $105 million, or $1.19 a share, in the year-ago quarter. Excluding one-time items, Eastman earned $1.53 cents a share. Revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose 3.4% to $1.83 billion from $1.77 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had predicted the Kingsport, Tenn.-based chemical producer would earn $1.53 a share on $1.8 billion in sales. Eastman shares closed ahead of the report with a 1.4% loss at $66.38. Republic Services second-quarter net income slides (5:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Republic Services Inc. RSG, +1.11% late Thursday reported its second-quarter net income fell to $62.3 million, or 34 cents a share, from $87.2 million, or 45 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $827.5 million from $808.4 million a year ago, the waste collection services company said. At the same time, the company affirmed its 2008 earnings outlook of $1.78 to $1.82 a share and noted that margins are remaining steady despite pressure from diesel fuel costs. The board also approved a 12% increase in the quarterly dividend to 19 cents a share. The dividend will be paid on Oct. 15 to shareholders of record on Oct. 1. Federated quarterly net income rises 5% (4:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Federated Investors FII, +1.55% said late Thursday that second-quarter net income came in at $58 million, or 58 cents a share, up 5% from a year earlier when the asset-management company made $55.3 million, or 54 cents a share. Federated was expected to make 60 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 11 analysts in a Thomson Reuters survey. Assets under management were $333.5 billion at the end of June, up 28% from a year ago and down 1% from the end of the first quarter. Synovus quarterly net income drops 93% (4:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Synovus Financial SNV, +1.18% said late Thursday that second-quarter net income came in at $12.1 million, or four cents a share, down 93% from a year earlier when the lender made $162.8 million, or 49 cents a share. The company was expected to make 13 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 22 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Nonperforming loans were $627 million in the second quarter, an increase of $111 million from the first quarter of 2008, the company said. The rate of increase in nonperforming loans slowed in the second quarter, the company noted. Crocs slashes profit targets; shares plunge (4:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Crocs Inc. CROX, +1.18% late Thursday slashed its financial targets due to soft demand for its colorful rubbery sandals and other footwear. Its shares plunged 44% after its stock had been halted for trading in after-hours action. For the quarter ended June 30, Crocs said earnings would be between 3 cents and 7 cents a share and revenue would be in the range of $218 million and $223 million. The company had previously estimated its earnings would be in the range of 42 cents to 47 cents a share and revenue would be $247 million to $258 million. "While we did experience solid sell-through with many of our major accounts, retailers across the board were extremely cautious with their level of reorders, choosing to operate with leaner inventories versus a year ago," CEO Ron Snyder said in a statement. Crocs shares traded at $4.75 in recent trades, well off its 52-week high of $75.21 last October. Chubb quarterly net income falls 34% (4:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chubb Corp. CB, -1.08% said late Thursday that second-quarter net income came in at $469 million, or $1.27 a share, down 34% from a year earlier when the insurer made $709 million, or $1.75 a share. Operating profit, which excludes net realized investment gains and losses, was $518 million, or $1.40 a share, in the latest quarter. Chubb was expected to make $1.47 a share, according to the average estimate of 19 analysts in a Thomson Reuters survey. Results were dented by unusually high catastrophe losses and one big surety loss, Chief Executive John Finnegan said in a statement. Chubb shares slipped 6.5% to $44.51 in light after-hours trading. Burlington Northern Santa Fe profit drops 19% (4:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCSICO (MarketWatch) -- Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corp. BNI reported late Thursday second-quarter net income fell to $350 million, or $1 a share, from $433 million, or $1.20 a share, a year ago. The latest results include one-time charges that reduced earnings by 34 cents a share. Revenue for the railroad rose nearly 17% to $4.48 billion from $3.84 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet had forecast the Fort Worth, Texas-based company would report earnings of $1.32 a share on $4.42 billion in revenue. Burlington Northern shares closed ahead of the report with a 1.2% drop to $98.77. Macau, tax benefit boost Wynn Resorts (4:22 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Brisk business in Macau and a tax benefit helped lift Wynn Resorts Ltd. to sharply higher profit in the second quarter even as the economic downturn dragged down revenue at its Las Vegas property, the company said Thursday. Wynn WYNN, +3.59% earned $272 million, or $2.42 a share, on the period, up from $89.6 million or 82 cents in the year-ago period. Adjusted to exclude a $140.7 million tax benefit, the company would have earned $1.11 a share. Revenue came in at $825.2 million, up from $687.5 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had been for the gambling giant to earn 93 cents a share on revenue of $828 million. After losing 8% in the regular session, shares of Wynn spiked about 5% to $96 in after-hours action. BMC Software earnings fall on acquisition charges (4:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- BMC Software reported Thursday that earnings for its first fiscal quarter fell due to acquisition charges while revenue climbed 14%. For the period ended June 30, the software maker BMC, -2.86% reported earnings of $1.2 million, or 1 cent a share, compared to earnings of $55.2 million, or 27 cents a share, for the same period last year. Excluding charges related to its acquisition of BladeLogic, the company said earnings would have been $82 million, or 43 cents a share, for the recent period. Revenue grew to $437.5 million from $385 million last year. Analysts were expecting earnings of 43 cents a share on revenue of $432.6 million, according to estimates from Thomson Reuters. Flextronics reports 21% earnings increase (4:12 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Flextronics International FLEX, +0.12% on Thursday reported a fiscal first-quarter profit of $130 million, or 16 cents a share, compared to earnings of $107 million, or 17 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. The electronics contract manufacturer said revenue for the quarter ended June 27 rose to $8.35 billion from $5.16 billion a year ago. Excluding one-time items, Flextronics would have earned $227 million, or 27 cents a share. By that measure, Flextronics met the estimates of analysts surveyed by FactSet Research who also forecast the company to report $8.31 billion in revenue. For its second quarter, Flextronics expects to earn between 23 cents and 26 cents a share on sales in a range of $8.5 billion to $9 billion. Crude closes higher after losing $20 in seven days (2:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Crude-oil futures rose for first time in three sessions, up 0.8% following their $20 decline over the past seven sessions that had sent the benchmark contract to its lowest level in seven weeks. Meanwhile, natural gas prices slumped after government data showed U.S. inventories rose more than expected last week. Crude oil for September delivery gained $1.05, or 0.8%, to end at $125.49 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. September natural gas fell 55.8 cents, or 5.7%, to $9.23 per million British thermal units. Vivendi first-half revenue rises 10.2% (12:39 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Vivendi Sa(FR:012777)said Thursday its revenues for the first half of 2008 totaled 11.27 billion euros ($17.7 billion), compared to 10.22 billion euros for the first half 2007, an increase of 10.2% or a 12.3% rise in constant currency terms. The media giant said that for 2008, it expects "to deliver a profit growth similar to 2007, at constant perimeter." For the second quarter, Vivendi's revenues totaled 5.99 billion compared to 5.20 billion euros a year earlier, marking an increase of 15.1%, or 17.4% in constant currencies. Among its units, Universal Music Group saw a 2.4% decline in revenue, while the Canal+ Group grew 4.6%. Vivendi Games saw the largest revenue drop, at 11.2%, though that decline was only 3.1% after factoring out foreign-exchange effects. Occidental sees bidding for Iraqi oil fields later this year (12:19 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Occidental Petroleum OXY, +2.87% CEO Ray Irani said Iraq's larger oil fields will likely draw formal participation from a consortium of large Western oil producers later this year, as the war-torn country moves to ramp up its economy. "There are some very large fields in Iraq which are going to become available," Irani told Wall Street analysts on a conference call. "The huge ones will be run by...the oil majors and companies our size. No one company is going to get a field of 20 billion barrels or more, period." Occidental also sees an opportunity to run smaller fields in Iraq on its own. Iraq has identified eight of the giant fields, with a formal bidding process starting later this year and going through a good part of 2009, Occidental said. National City swings to loss, but shares rise (11:01 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of troubled bank National City Corp. NCC, -0.16% were up Thursday after the company reported a second-quarter loss of $1.76 billion, or $2.45 a share. "Credit quality deteriorated, but there are some signs of stabilization in the nonprime mortgage book," wrote BMO Capital Markets analyst Lana Chan in a research note Thursday morning. "With the capital raise, National City's capital ratios are among the strongest of its peers," the analyst said. "We continue to believe that the improved capital base and higher reserves ... will allow National City to proactively work through losses in its higher-risk loan portfolio." (Pulse corrected to reflect National City swung to a quarterly loss.) Qualcomm, Nokia, Amazon lead early tech action (9:39 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Technology stocks put in a mixed performance in Thursday's trading session, with Qualcomm Inc. QCOMM Nokia Corp. NOK, +0.74% and Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +1.11% highlighting the early action. Qualcomm shares surged $8.81, or almost 20%, to $53.60 and Nokia rose $1.08 a share, or more than 4%, to $27.82 after the telecom giants ended a long-running patent distpute. Amazon shares rose $7.08, or 10%, to $77.49 after the online retailer reported a second-quater profit that more-than-doubled from a year ago. However, the broader tech sector was in the red, as the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ fell 7.5 points to 2,318. Occidental Petroleum gains as energy sector advances (9:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Occidental Petroleum Corp. OXY, +2.87% moved higher on its better-than-expected earnings on Thursday as the energy sector gained along with the price of crude. The Amex Oil Index XOI, +2.04% rose 0.5% to 1,300. The Amex Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% rose 0.9% to 600. Smith International SII, +0.97% fell 1.8% to $78.21. Crude futures rose $1.34 to $125.78. Occidental Petroleum rose 2.5% to $74.05. Franklin Resources profit falls 14% (9:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Asset manager Franklin Resources BEN, +1.67% said Thursday its fiscal third quarter profit fell 14%, to $403.3 million, or $1.71 a share, compared to $468.4 million, or $1.86 a year ago. revenue fell to $1.52 billion, from $1.64 billion. Cooper Industries' second-quarter profit falls on charges (8:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cooper Industries Ltd. CBE, +50.00% said Thursday that its second-quarter net income fell to $161.9 million, or 92 cents a share, from $209.2 million, or $1.12 a share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding items, Cooper's earnings rose to 97 cents a share from 78 cents. The Houston electrical products and tool manufacturer said revenue increased 18% to $1.72 billion from $1.46 billion. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research expected earnings of 91 cents a share. Cooper forecasts 2008 earnings of $3.61 to $3.71 a share, with revenue growth of 12% to 14%. It projects a third-quarter profit of 92 cents to 97 cents a share. Alaska Air reports $1.74 in second-quarter earnings a share (8:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Alaska Air Group Inc. ALK, +0.63% said Thursday that second-quarter earnings rose to $63.1 million, or $1.74 a share, compared to $46.1 million, or $1.13 a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding special items, the company reported a loss of $14.1 million, or 39 cents a share, compared to a net income of $47.2 million, or $1.16 a share, in the period a year ago. Because of surging crude-oil prices the company's fuel-hedge portfolio increased dramatically, resulting in a $155.3 million mark-to-market gain in the period. Total operating revenue rose to $930.8 million, compared to $904.4 million a year ago. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated a loss of 14 cents a share on sales of $940.4 million. Laboratory Corp. reports lower earnings on charges (8:46 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Laboratory Corp. of America Holdings LH, +0.14% early Thursday reported second-quarter net income of $104.2 million, or 92 cents a share, compared with $128.7 million, or $1.05 a share, for the same quarter in 2007. Excluding various charges, the company would have reported adjusted earnings of $1.24 a share versus $1.09. Revenue for the quarter climbed 10% to $1.15 billion. Shares for the quarter were reduced from 114 million, from 122 million in the 2007 period. The company said it now sees 2008 adjusted earnings per share of between $4.54 and $4.66. Ensco second-quarter profit climbs to $297 million (8:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Ensco International Inc. ESV, -0.90% said Thursday its second-quarter profit totaled $297 million, or $2.07 a share, from $254 million, or $1.72 a share, in the same quarter a year before. Analysts had expected earnings on average of $1.98 a share, according to a FactSet Research survey. Operating revenue for the quarter was $637 million compared to $549 million in the year-ago period. Level 3 narrows second-quarter loss (8:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Level 3 Communications Inc. LVLT said Thursday that it lost $33 million, or 2 cents a share, in its second quarter, compared to the year-earlier loss of $202 million, or 13 cents a share. Total revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose to $1.09 billion from the year-ago $1.05 billion. The company also raised its 2008 free cash flow guidance from breakeven to positive for the remainder of the year. Ashland net income slips (8:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Chemical company Ashland Inc. ASH, +1.04% on Thursday said its fiscal third-quarter net income fell to $72 million, or $1.13 a share, from $100 million, or $1.58 a share, in the year-ago period. On a continuing operations basis, it earned $1.03 a share. Sales rose to $2.2 billion from $1.98 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 87 cents a share on sales of $2.11 billion, according to FactSet Research. For the rest of 2008, the company expects its operating income in its performance materials business be down significantly versus the June 2008 quarter. In its water technologies business it expects price increases announced in June should fully offset previously announced raw material increases. Ashland expects its distribution unit's performance to be hurt by weakness in North American industrial output, but expects to "significantly" improve results from the fourth quarter last year. However it is "unlikely" the unit will achieve another sequential quarterly increase, Ashland said. Rohm & Haas second-quarter profit 75 cents a share (8:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Rohm & Haas Co. ROH, +0.42% said Thursday its second-quarter profit totaled $147 million, or 75 cents a share, from $160 million, or 74 cents a share, in the same quarter a year before. Analysts had expected adjusted earnings on average of 86 cents a share, according to a FactSet Research survey, compared to actual adjusted earnings of 82 cents a share. Sales for the quarter were $2.57 billion compared to $2.19 billion in the year-ago period. "The external environment remains very uncertain and challenging. We are successfully navigating these challenges ... and are making necessary investments to stay on track with our Vision 2010 strategic plan," said CEO Raj Gupta. ProLogis reports lower funds from operations (8:24 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- ProLogis PLD, +0.74% on Thursday said funds from operations, a key profitability measure for real estate investment trusts, in the second quarter fell to $1.06 a share from $1.16 in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had been looking for FFO of $1.04 a share, on average. The company reiterated its full-year outlook for FFO ranging between $4.65 and $4.85 a share, while the consensus estimate is $4.78 a share. AutoNation's second-quarter profit declines (8:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AutoNation Inc. AN, +2.03% said Thursday that its second-quarter net income fell to $51.8 million, or 29 cents a share, from $77.3 million, or 37 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Earnings from continuing operations declined to 29 cents a share from 38 cents a share. A FactSet Research survey of analysts, on average, projected earnings of 31 cents a share for the quarter. The Fort Lauderdale, Fla., automotive retailer said revenue fell to $3.91 billion from $4.48 billion. Shares of AutoNation ended Wednesday at $9.39. Union Pacific net income up 19% (8:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Union Pacific Corp. UNP, +2.81% said second-quarter net income rose 19% to $531 million, or $1.02 a share, from $446 million, or 82 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Omaha, Neb. railroad giant said revenue rose 13% to $4.56 billion. Analysts expected earnings of 92 cents a share on revenue of $4.5 billion, on average. "Although high fuel prices and a soft economy present challenges, we remain committed to ongoing productivity and customer service initiatives as we look forward to achieving a record year," the company said. CORRECT: Medco Health 2nd-period net up 22% (8:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Medco Health Solutions Inc., MHS the Franklin Lakes, N.J., pharmacy-benefits manager, reported second-quarter net income rose 22% on 16% higher revenue. Earnings reached $262.7 million, or 51 cents a share, from $214.9 million, or 38 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were 56 cents against 43 cents. Revenue rose to $12.77 billion from $11.05 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of 53 cents of profit for the quarter. For 2008, Medco lifted its earnings estimate and now projects $2.10 to $2.13 a share. That's up 29% to 31% from 2007. And it compares with the company's previous estimate of $2.07 to $2.11 a share. On an adjusted basis, the company expects to earn $2.30 to $2.33 in the year. That's up 26% to 28% from 2007. And it compared with the previous estimate of $2.27 to $2.31 a share. FactSet's survey is looking for $2.28 a share. (Corrects FactSet estimate for the quarter.) UST's quarterly net income slips (8:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- UST Inc. UST, +0.69% on Thursday said second-quarter net income slipped to $139.7 million, or 94 cents a share, from $140 million, or 87 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, the tobacco company earned 95 cents a share. In the most recent second quarter shares outstanding were 148.6 million vs. 161.1 million a year earlier. Net sales rose to $506.2 million from $491.3 million. Analysts, on average, expected the company to earn 94 cents a share on sales of $512.3 million, according to FactSet Research. For the year, the company remains on track to deliver its previously released adjusted non-GAAP diluted earnings per share target of $3.65, with a range of $3.60 to $3.70, including plans to increase smokeless tobacco promotional support to address increased competitive activity and the current economic environment. Smoking bans in the U.K., Germany and Western Europe have contributed to industry-wide declines in cigarette consumption, and U.S. and Europe industry-wide cigar volumes have been hurt both by smoking bans and the economic slowdown. Separately, it's going to delist from the New York Stock Exchange, saying its ADR program is small and accounted for less than 5% of the total trading volume. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. swung to a fiscal third-quarter loss of $108 million, which it blamed on workers compensation services provider PMSI, leading the Valley Forge, Pa. firm to sell the unit for at least $40 million. But the sale, plus better-than-expected performance in continuing operations helped the company to a gain of more than 9% at one point in early trading. AmerisourceBergen's ABC, +1.29% loss amounted to $108 million, or 67 cents a share, after earning $129.9 million, or 69 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. AmerisourceBergen took a $222 million charge on PMSI during the third quarter and reached a deal to sell it to H.I.G. Capital for $40 million, in addition to up to $10 million more in adjustments. "We were very disappointed with PMSI's performance in this quarter, and after re-evaluating our alternatives, we decided to sell the PMSI workers' compensation business in order to focus our full attention on our pharmaceutical distribution and related businesses and allow H.I.G. to focus on the opportunities at PMSI," Chief Executive R. David Yost said in a statement. The company said, however, its core drugs distribution business had an "excellent" quarter in a soft pharmaceutical market, as it earned 70 cents a share. AmerisourceBergen said it had above-market revenue growth, solid manufacturer price appreciation and "outstanding" expense management. Revenue rose 10% to $18 billion from $16.3 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 66 cents a share, according to FactSet Research. The company raised its continuing operations profit forecast to a range of $2.81 a share to $2.89 a share from $2.77 a share to $2.87 a share. For fiscal 2009, the company expects to deliver low double-digit growth in earnings per share from continuing operations. AmerisourceBergen shares rose $3.15, or 7.9%, to close at $43.15. title: AmerisourceBergen swings to $108 million loss, to sell unit

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% on Thursday posted a fiscal third-quarter net loss of $108 million, or 67 cents a share. In the year-ago period it earned $129.9 million, or 69 cents a share. On a continuing operations basis the pharmaceutical services company earned 70 cents a share, including 3 cents a share in special charges. Revenue rose to $18 billion from $16.34 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 66 cents a share, according to FactSet Research. The company raised its continuing operations profit forecast to a range of $2.81 a share to $2.89 a share from $2.77 a share to $2.87 a share. The new range implies a fiscal fourth quarter profit range of 65 cents to 73 cents a share. For fiscal 2009, the company expects to deliver low double-digit earnings per share from continuing operations growth.
title: AmerisourceBergen swings to quarterly net loss

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. reported a 3% uptick in fiscal second-quarter earnings on Wednesday, but the drug distribution giant's outlook for fiscal 2008 disappointed investors and the company's shares slipped. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% reported net income of $133.9 million for the quarter ended March 31, or 82 cents a share, compared with $129.5 million, or 68 cents a share for the same period a year ago. Sales for the Valley Forge, Pa.-based company were $17.8 billion compared with last year's $16.5 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the company to earn 77 cents a share for the quarter. But the company lowered its forecast for full-year earnings to a range of $2.77 to $2.87 a share, down from its previous range of $2.77 to $2.95 a share. The FactSet estimate was for $2.86 a share. Shares ended trading Wednesday down 3.6% to $39.48. The stock drop may be the result of investors getting jittery over the industry's outlook. Wall Street analysts expressed concern that growth prospects for AmerisourceBergen and others may be dimming. Bank of America's Robert Willoughby said in a note to clients that a small-market growth rate for pharmaceuticals could have an adverse effect on stocks. "While a pathway to continuing double-digit [earnings per share] growth remains clear through cost and capital structure leverage, and [return on invested capital] may actually be higher, fears of lower top-line growth may continue to be an overhang near term," Willoughby said. Another irritant to investors may be AmerisourceBergen's decision to not sell off its troubled PMSI division, analysts say. The medical products supplier has been considered an underperformer. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins?
