title: AmerisourceBergen posts higher profit, trims outlook

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies were among those that made notable moves in the U.S. stock market Wednesday. Advancers Amazon.com AMZN, +1.11% is largely expected to show a healthy increase to its bottom line when it reports first-quarter results Wednesday afternoon, but investors who have become accustomed to the breakneck earnings growth seen over the last few periods may be in for a disappointment. See full story. American Water Works Co., AWK, +1.16% the Voorhees, N.J., water and wastewater utility company, priced late on Tuesday an initial public offering of 58 million shares at $21.50. The deal value at that price is about $1.25 billion. At the end of March, American Water Works had set an initial price range of $24 to $26 for the deal. RWE, RWEOY, -0.24% (703712)the Essen, Germany, energy company, is offering all the shares in the IPO and receives all proceeds. Arkansas Best Corp., ABFS the Fort Smith, Ark., transportation-holding company, reported first-quarter net income rose 78% on 4.6% higher revenue. Becton, Dickinson & Co., BDX, +2.01% the Franklin Lakes, N.J., health-care-products provider, reported fiscal second-quarter net income rose 14% on 11% higher revenue, and it lifted its outlook for the full fiscal year. Boeing Co.'s BA, +2.46% first-quarter earnings jumped 38% to $1.21 billion, or $1.62 a share, from $877 million, or $1.13 a share, a year earlier, helped in part by its commercial airplane and defense businesses. Earnings from continuing operations were $1.61 a share for the quarter. The Chicago defense and aerospace company's revenue increased to $15.99 billion from $15.37 billion a year ago. Boeing expects the first flight of its next generation plane, the 787 Dreamliner, to occur in the fourth quarter, with first deliveries to begin in the third quarter of 2009. Boeing also backed its 2008 earnings forecast of $5.70 to $5.85 a share. For 2009, Boeing expects earnings of $6.80 to $7 a share on strong production program performance and decreases in R&D and pension expense. Broadcom Corp. BRCM reported first-quarter net income of $74.3 million, or 14 cents a share, on revenue of $1.03 billion. Analysts had expected the company to report earnings of 27 cents a share on revenue of $991.3 million, according to FactSet Research. See full story Cymer Inc.'s CYMI, +0.00% first-quarter net income fell 36% to $12.9 million, or 41 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 35 cents a share. EMC Corp.'s EMC, +9.92% first-quarter net income fell 14% to $268.8 million, or 13 cents a share, from $312.6 million, or 15 cents, a year earlier. Results for the latest quarter included a $79.2 million non-cash charge for in-process research and development resulting from acquisitions. Excluding this charge, earnings were 16 cents a share. The Hopkinton, Mass., data systems company said revenue grew 17% to $3.47 billion from $2.98 billion a year ago. See full story. Federal-Mogul Corp. FDML on Wednesday traded on a major stock exchange for the first time in six years, moving from over-the-counter obscurity to post an opening day gain on the Nasdaq after years of toiling in bankruptcy. See full story. GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.79% first-quarter profit fell to 1.37 billion pounds ($2.7 billion), down 9%, as revenue edged 2% higher to 5.69 billion pounds. The U.K. drugmaker's adjusted earnings of 25.6 pence a share was ahead of consensus estimates of 24.6 pence a share on revenue of 5.59 billion pounds. Generic competition and an Avandia sales drop hit results, Glaxo said, despite revenue growth from Advair, vaccines and consumer health products. It still sees a mid-single digit percentage decline in adjusted EPS at constant exchange rates for the year. Host Hotels & Resorts Inc.'s HST, +0.38% first-quarter net income fell 67% to $61 million, or 11 cents a share, from $187 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier. Earnings from continuing operations were 11 cents a share, compared with 7 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Bethesda, Md., lodging real estate company said revenue increased 2.8% to $1.06 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected earnings of 8 cents a share on revenue of $1.07 billion. Funds from operations were 33 cents a share against 30 cents. For the second quarter, Host expects earnings of 35 cents to 37 cents a share and funds from operations of 54 cents to 56 cents a share. Industrial Distribution Group Inc.: IDGR The two-month bidding contest continues for the Atlanta supplier of maintenance and other products and services to manufacturers and other industrial users. Late on Tuesday, the company said affiliates of Luther King Capital Management definitively offered to acquire IDGR for $12.10 a share cash. That's up from Luther King's previous bid of $11.70 a share, which had been subject to a due-diligence financial review. Based on more than 9.6 million shares outstanding the new bid is valued at $116 million. The move by Luther King, Fort Worth, Texas, followed a proposal on Monday by Platinum Equity to buy Industrial Distribution for $11.80 a share. Invitrogen Corp.'s IVGN first-quarter net income rose to $59.7 million, or $1.19 a share. Excluding items, per-share earnings rose to $1.55. The San Diego research products maker's revenue rose 14% to $350.2 million. The mean estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Financial were earnings of $1.13 on revenue of $333.2 million. Level 3 Communications Inc. LVLT reported a loss of $181 million, or 12 cents a share, for the first quarter. In the same period a year ago Level 3 had a loss of $91 million, or 6 cents. Level 3 reiterate its 2008 estimate of earnings before interest, taxes depreciation and amortization of $950 million to $1.10 billion. CEO James Crow said, "The pricing environment for our core communications services continued to be positive." Molex Inc. MOLX fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 23% due to restructuring charges. The electronics manufacturing company reported earnings of $50.3 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $65.3 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding charges earnings for the recent period were 37 cents a share. Revenue grew nearly 2% to $822.3 million. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 35 cents a share on revenue of $838.5 million, according to Thomson Financial. Moody's Corp. MCO, +1.48% first-quarter earnings fell 31% to $120.7 million, or 48 cents a share, from $175.4 million, or 62 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The New-York corporate finance, banking and managed funds provider said revenue in the recent quarter slipped to $430.7 million from $538 million. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected 49 cents a share on revenue of $500 million. Moody's also affirmed its 2008 earnings guidance of $1.90 to $2 a share. Northwest Pipe Co. NWPX, -2.32% first-quarter net income rose 11% to $5.1 million, or 54 cents a share, from $4.5 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier. The Vancouver, Wash., maker of welded steel pipes and other products said sales rose 3.6% to $94 million from $90.7 million a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were looking for 53 cents a share on sales of $91 million. The company reported a backlog of $195 million as of March 31. Pepsi Bottling Group Inc.'s PBG, +7.14% first-quarter net income fell 3.4% to $28 million, or 12 cents a share, from $29 million, or 12 cents, a year erlier. The results for the latest period included a charge of $2.5 million from restructuring charges and an asset disposal charge. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected, on average, earnings of 12 cents a share. The Somers, N.Y., bottler of PepsiCo PEP, -0.03% beverages said revenue increased 7.5% to $2.65 billion from $2.47 billion a year ago. Worldwide physical case volume increased 2% and the company said every country had positive volume growth. Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc. PPDI first-quarter profit fell to $40.1 million, or 33 cents a share. Excluding charges, the company earned 44 cents a share. Revenue rose to $396.2 million from $332.3 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated 43 cents a share on revenue of $369.2 million. Philip Morris International Inc. PM, -0.39% first-quarter net income rose 29% to $1.87 billion, or 89 cents a share, from $1.45 billion, or 69 cents a share, at the same point a year ago. Revenue rose 17.6% to $15.6 billion. Adjusted earnings per share rose 31% to 89 cents. Analysts had been expecting earnings per share of 77 cents a share, according to data compiled by FactSet. The tobacco firm lifted its 2008 earning per share forecast to a range of $3.18 to $3.24 a share, from a revised 2007 pro-forma adjusted base of $2.79. The new guidance reflects favorable currency, business momentum and increased reinvestment in some key markets. Separately, the Lausanne, Switzerland, tobacco producer, agreed to acquire a number of brands from Imperial Tobacco Group ITY (IMT)of Bristol, U.K., for 254 million euros ($405 million). C.H. Robinson Worldwide Inc. CHRW, +2.20% reported first-quarter net income rose to $86.3 million, or 50 cents a share, on revenue of $1.96 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research forecast the trucking and transport company would earn 48 cents a share on $1.86 billion in sales. Ryder System Inc. R, +2.28% first-quarter profit rose to $56.1 million, or 96 cents a share, from $51.3 million, or 84 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $1.54 billion from $1.59 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 88 cents a share on revenue of $1.54 billion, according to FactSet Research. The transportation and supply chain management provider said it expects "current difficult industry and market conditions to continue for the near term." For the second quarter it expects to earn $1.10 to $1.20, and is targeting 2008 profit of $4.55 to $4.75. Analysts polled by FactSet expect it to earn $1.16 a share in the second quarter and $4.58 a share for the year. Schering-Plough Corp.'s SGP, -1.28% first-quarter net income fell 48% to $291 million, or 15 cents a share, from $565 million, or 36 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding accounting adjustments and acquisition-related items, earnings for the period were 53 cents a share. The Kenilworth, N.J., pharmaceutical company said sales rose 57% to $4.66 billion from $2.98 billion. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected earnings of 37 cents a share on revenue of $4.52 billion. Skyworks Solutions Inc. SWKS, +1.41% said its fiscal second-quarter profit rose to $16.7 million, or 10 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the company earned 16 cents a share. Revenue rose to $201.7 million from $180.2 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated 14 cents a share on revenue of $199.6 million. The company forecast an adjusted profit of about 17 cents a share for the fiscal third quarter on revenue of about $210 million. Analysts expect a profit of 15 cents a share on revenue of $207.6 million. Tupperware Brands TUP, +2.33% reported its first-quarter net income rose to $32.1 million, or 51 cents a share. Excluding certain items, earnings were 56 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast earnings of 48 cents a share. Revenue climbed to $543.4 million from $456.9 million a year earlier, the Orlando, Fla., consumer-goods company said. Tupperware expects second-quarter sales to increase 14% to 16% while earnings are expected to come in at 55 cents to 60 cents a share. The company also raised its 2008 estimate to sales growth of 13% to 15% from 8% to 10%. Earnings for the year are expected to range from $2.44 to $2.54 a share. Analysts are projecting $2.54 a share. VMware Inc. VMW, +1.10% reported first-quarter profit of $43 million, or 11 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the virtualization software developer earned $88 million, or 22 cents a share, to meet the estimates of analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. The company expects its second-quarter sales to rise about 55% from the $297 million it reported for the year-earlier period. See full story WellPoint Inc.'s WLP first-quarter profit fell 25% to $588.1 million, or $1.07 a share, from $783.1 million, or $1.26 a share, a year earlier. The company also cut its earnings forecast for the full year, citing higher medical costs and a lower level of favorable prior year reserve development. The latest period included net realized investment losses of 6 cents a share. Revenue increased 3.1% to $15.55 billion. See full story. Yum Brands Inc. YUM, +1.04% posted first-quarter profit of $254 million, or 50 cents a share, up from $194 million, or 35 cents, in the year-ago period. Knocking out a one-time gain, Yum earned 42 cents a share. Sales rose 8% to $2.41 billion. Same-store sales, those at outlets open more than a year, climbed 4% worldwide. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated Yum to earn 41 cents a share on revenue of $2.3 billion. Yum also raised its full-year 2008 EPS forecast from $1.85 to $1.87 per share. See full story Zebra Technologies Corp., ZBRA, +2.38% the Vernon Hills, Ill., provider of specialty digital-printing and automatic-identification solutions, reported first-quarter net income rose 3.5% on 18% higher revenue. Separately, Zebra said Chief Financial Officer Charles Whitchurch, 61, would retire after 17 years in the post. Zebra named Michael C. Smiley, 48, to succeed Whitchurch. Smiley joins from Tellabs Inc., TLAB the Naperville, Ill., telecom-equipment provider, where he held a number of financial and operations positions. Decliners Ameriprise Financial Inc.'s AMP, +0.67% first-quarter net income rose 16% to $191 million, or 82 cents a share. Adjusted profit for the latest period was 89 cents a share, compared with 88 cents a year earlier. The Minneapolis financial services company said revenue increased 3% to $2.09 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 97 cents a share on revenue of $2.18 billion. Ameriprise was cut to market perform at Wachovia. AmerisourceBergen Co.'s ABC, +1.29% fiscal second-quarter net income rose to $133.9 million, or 82 cents a share, from $129.5 million, or 68 cents, a year earlier. The Valley Forge, Pa., drug services firm said revenue increased 8% to $17.85 billion from $16.51 billion, helped by an increased in the pharmaceutical distribution segment. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected per-share earnings of 77 cents on revenue of $17.5 billion. Biogen Idec Inc. BIIB, +0.74% first-quarter profit rose to $163.1 million, or 54 cents a share, from $131.5 million, or 38 cents, a year earlier. Total revenue climbed to $942.2 million from $715.9 million. It raised its 2008 forecast to profit of $2.28 to $2.48 a share. Excluding items, profit for the year will be $3.25 to $3.45 a share. See full story. Delta Air Lines Inc.'s DAL, +1.63% first-quarter loss widened to $6.39 billion from $130 million a year earlier. The third-largest U.S. carrier posted a per-share loss for the quarter of $16.15. Excluding special items, Delta's net loss was $274 million, or 69 cents a share. A Thomson Reuters survey of analysts, on average, had projected a first-quarter loss of 49 cents a share. The Atlanta airline incurred a noncash goodwill impairment charge of $6.1 billion. Total operating revenue rose to $4.77 billion from $4.24 billion. Delta expects domestic capacity in the second half of 2008 to decline by 9% to 11%, and system capacity to be between flat and down 2%. Eaton Corp., ETN, +1.09% the Cleveland industrial manufacturer, late on Tuesday priced its planned public offering of 17.5 million shares at $84. The company's shares closed on Tuesday at $85.09. Foundation Coal FCL first-quarter net income fell 75% to $6.1 million, or 13 cents a share, from $24.6 million, or 53 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $412 million from $395 million. Adjusted earnings fell to 19 cents a share from 54 cents. General Dynamics Corp. GD, +1.67% reported Wednesday first-quarter net income rose 32% from the year-earlier quarter, bolstered by higher operating profits in its aerospace and combat systems businesses. See full story. MetLife Inc. MET, -0.02% authorized a new $1 billion share buyback. The life insurer can repurchase stock under this authorization after it completes the $1 billion plan announced Jan. 15. Mothers Work Inc. MWRK swung to a net loss in its fiscal second quarter of $390,000, or 7 cents a share, from a year-earlier profit of $2.6 million, or 41 cents a share, due to a weak retail environment and unseasonably cold weather. The Philadelphia maternity-apparel retailer's sales for the quarter ended March 31 were down 3.4% to $139 million, while same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, declined 1.7%. Mothers Work said it opened 10 stores and closed 16 during the second quarter. For the third quarter, the company set a sales target of $150 million to $153.5 million and an earnings goal of 61 to 76 cents a share. For 2008, the company set a target of 5 to 36 cents a share, far below its projection, made in January, of 72 cents to $1.20 a share. Norfolk Southern Corp. NSC, +1.35% reported first-quarter earnings of $291 million, or 76 cents a share, as revenue rose 11% to $2.5 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had predicted the Norfolk, Va., railroad would earn 77 cents a share on $2.36 billion in revenue. See full story Northrop Grumman Corp., NOC, +1.28% the Los Angeles aerospace and defense giant, said late on Tuesday that it received an 89-month $1.16 billion contract to provide the U.S. Navy with a new maritime intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance system. Northwest Airlines Corp.'s NWA first-quarter loss widened to $4.14 billion, or $15.78 a share, from $292 million, or $3.34 a share, a year ago, hurt in part by a $3.9 billion noncash goodwill impairment charge and higher oil prices. The carrier said Wednesday that revenue increased 8.8% to $3.13 billion from $2.87 billion a year ago. Northwest expects its merger with Delta to generate more than $1 billion in annual revenue and cost synergies from "more effective" aircraft use and other items. The two airlines expect the regulatory review process to last from six to eight months and anticipate closing the deal in late 2008. Praxair Inc., PX, +1.51% the Danbury, Conn., provider of industrial gases and surface coatings, reported first-quarter net income rose 16% on 22% higher sales, and it raised its outlook for the year. Rockwell Automation Inc. ROK, -0.29% on Wednesday posted a lower-than-expected profit decline for the quarter, sending its shares down more than 8%. See full story. Sigma-Aldrich Corp. SIAL reported a first-quarter profit of $84.5 million, or 64 cents a share, on revenue of $569.6 million. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for 63 cents a share on sales of $557 million. The St. Louis chemical company raised its 2008 targeted earnings range to $2.57 to $2.67 a share. Wall Street had projected a profit of $2.61 a share for the full year. Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. SSCI, +0.49% reported its first-quarter loss shrank from a year ago but the loss was more than Wall Street had targeted. The maker of cardboard boxes and other packaging reported a loss of $13 million, or 6 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected a loss of 3 cents. Sales were flat at $1.8 billion as a slowing U.S. economy and rising commodity costs offset box-price increases, the company said. Looking ahead, Smurfit-Stone said second-quarter earnings should be better than the first quarter. UBS UBS, +0.40% will scale back its investment banking arm, reducing risk and pulling out of some businesses, after a "disastrous" performance in 2007. In a speech published on the firm's Web site, CEO Marcel Rohner said the division will no longer benefit from cheap funding from the wealth management arm and will have to generate its own capital for future growth. It will also no longer "offer everything to everyone," he added. In a separate speech, incoming Chairman Peter Kurer said the firm needs to better separate the roles of executives and the board of directors. As an initial step, Kurer said the Chairman's Office will be abolished and its authorities will be allocated among several committees, all of which will have a majority of independent directors. United Parcel Service Inc.'s UPS, +1.93% first-quarter net income increased 7.5% to $906 million, or 87 cents a share, from $843 million, or 78 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding an impairment charge related to aging jet aircraft, adjusted earnings for the year-ago period were 96 cents a share. The Atlanta package delivery company said revenue for the period increased 6.5% to $12.68 billion from $11.91 billion a year earlier. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected earnings of 87 cents a share on revenue of $12.31 billion. The company expects second-quarter net income of 97 cents to $1.04 a share. UPS also cut its 2008 earnings forecast to $3.90 to $4.20 a share from $4.30 to $4.50 a share. VF Corp. VFC, +0.61% reported first-quarter net income rose almost 8% from a year ago, topping Wall Street's expectations. The company also backed its 2008 profit forecast despite some expected weakness in the second quarter. XL Capital Ltd. XL, -0.16% first-quarter net income came in at $244.4 million, down 57% from a year earlier when the insurance and reinsurance company made $562.5 million. Net income available to common-share holders was $1.20 a share, down from $3.06. Earnings excluding net realized investment gains and losses were $276.9 million, or $1.57 a share, compared with $540 million, or $3.01 a share. The company was expected to make $2.27 a share, according to FactSet. See full story Yahoo Inc. YHOO first-quarter net income rose to $542 million, or 37 cents a share, from $142 million, or 10 cents a share in the year-earlier period. The recent period's earnings include a gain of $401 million related to the IPO of Alibaba.com, in which Yahoo has an ownership stake. Revenue rose to $1.82 billion from $1.67 billion. Yahoo's net revenue, which excludes payments made to other Websites to acquire traffic, rose to $1.35 billion. Excluding special items, earnings were 11 cents a share. Analysts had estimated Yahoo would post earnings of 9 cents a share and $1.32 billion in net revenue, according to Thomson Financial. title: Wednesday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Wednesday's session are Apple Inc., Anheuser Busch Cos., and Amazon.com Inc. Apple AAPL, +0.78% is expected to report fiscal second-quarter earnings of $1.06 a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Anheuser Busch BUD, +0.28% is forecast to post earnings of 71 cents a share in the first-quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Amazon.com AMZN, +1.11% is estimated to report a profit of 32 cents a share in the first quarter, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Air Products and Chemicals Inc. APD, +1.24% is expected to report earnings of $1.21 a share in the fiscal second-quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. AmerisourceBergen Corp. GENZ is likely to report a first-quarter profit of 91 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Philip Morris International Inc. PM, -0.39% is expected to report a first-quarter profit of 77 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Ryder System Inc. R, +2.28% is forecast to post earnings of 88 cents a share in the first quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Rockwell Automation Corp. ROK, -0.29% is estimated to report a fiscal second-quarter profit of $1.01 a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. United Parcel Services Inc. UPS, +1.93% is forecast to post earnings of 87 cents a share in the first quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. WellPoint Inc. WLP is projected to post a first-quarter profit of $1.20 a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Aflac Inc. AFL, +0.48% is expected to report a first-quarter profit of 95 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Amerigroup Corp. AGP is forecast to post earnings of 58 cents a share in the first quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Allstate Corp. ALL, +0.20% is estimated to report a $1.63 a share profit in the first quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. C.R. Bard Inc. BCR is projected to post a first-quarter profit of $1.05 a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Noble Corp. NE, +3.06% is forecast to post earnings of $1.33 a share in the first quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Pulte Homes Inc. PHM, +1.41% is expected to report a first-quarter loss of 76 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, +1.30% is estimated to report a fiscal second-quarter profit of 52 cents a share excluding stock option costs, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Varian Medical Systems Inc. VAR, +0.92% is projected to post a fiscal second-quarter profit of 51 cents a share according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Varian Inc. VARI is expected to report a fiscal second-quarter profit of 66 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Xilinx Inc. XLNX, +1.25% is expected to report a fiscal fourth-quarter profit of 36 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Alliance Data Systems Corp. ADS, -4.07% is likely to report a first-quarter profit of 99 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Allegheny Technologies Inc. ATI, +3.91% is expected to report a first-quarter profit of $1.48 a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Becton, Dickinson and Co. BDX, +2.01% is estimated to report a fiscal second-quarter profit of $1.04 a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Delta Air Lines Inc. is expected to report a loss of 50 cents a share in the first quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Level 3 Communications Inc. LVLT is likely to report a first-quarter loss of 11 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Northwest Airlines Corp. NWA is forecast to report a first-quarter loss of 30 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Schering-Plough Corp. SGP, -1.28% is projected to report first-quarter earnings of 37 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. After Tuesday's closing bell, VMware Inc. VMW, +1.10% reported a first-quarter profit of $43 million, or 11 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the virtualization software developer would have earned $88 million, or 22 cents a share, to meet the estimates of analysts surveyed by FactSet Research, who forecast a profit of 22 cents a share on revenue of $422.7 million. The company said it expects its second-quarter sales to rise about 55% over the $297 million it reported in the same period a year ago. See full story Watch list Ameriprise Financial Inc.'s AMP, +0.67% first-quarter net income rose 16% to $191 million, or 82 cents a share, from $165 million. Adjusted operating income for the period was 89 cents a share, compared with 88 cents a share a year earlier. The Minneapolis financial services company said total net revenue increased 3% to $2.09 billion from $2.03 billion in the year-ago period. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 97 cents a share on revenue of $2.18 billion. Broadcom Corp. BRCM reported first-quarter net income of $74.3 million, or 14 cents a share, on revenue of $1.03 billion. Analysts had expected the company to report earnings of 27 cents a share on revenue of $991.3 million, according to a survey by FactSet Research. See full story C.H. Robinson Worldwide Inc. CHRW, +2.20% reported first-quarter net income rose to $86.3 million, or 50 cents a share, on revenue of $1.96 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research forecast the trucking and transport company would earn 48 cents a share on $1.86 billion in sales. Cymer Inc.'s CYMI, +0.00% first-quarter net income fell 36% to $12.9 million, or 41 cents a share, from $20.3 million, on revenue of $124. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 35 cents a share on revenue of $119 million. For the second quarter, Cymer expects total revenue to be comparable to first-quarter revenue and gross margin of about 48%. Invitrogen Corp.'s IVGN first-quarter net income rose to $59.7 million, or $1.19 a share. Excluding items, per-share earnings rose to $1.55.The San Diego research products maker's revenue rose 14% to $350.2 million. The mean estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Financial were for per-share earnings of $1.13 on revenue of $333.2 million. MetLife Inc. MET, -0.02% said its board of directors authorized a new $1 billion share buyback plan. The life insurer can repurchase stock under this authorization after the completion of an earlier $1 billion plan that was announced on Jan. 15. Molex Inc. MOLX saw earnings drop 23% in its third fiscal quarter thanks to large restructuring charges. The electronics manufacturing company reported earnings of $50.3 million, or 28 cents a share, compared to earnings of $65.3 million, or 35 cents a share, for the same period last year. Excluding charges for restructuring and tax adjustments, the company said earnings for the recent period would have been 37 cents a share. Revenue grew nearly 2% to $822.3 million. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 35 cents a share on revenue of $838.5 million, according to Thomson Financial. Norfolk Southern Corp. NSC, +1.35% reported first-quarter net earnings of $291 million, or 76 cents a share, as revenue rose 11% to $2.5 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had predicted the Norfolk, Va.-based railroad would earn 77 cents a share on $2.36 billion in revenue. See full story Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc. PPDI said its first-quarter profit fell to $40.1 million, or 33 cents a share. Excluding charges, the company would have reported a profit of 44 cents a share in the latest quarter. Revenue rose to $396.2 million from $332.3 million a year ago. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated a quarterly profit of 43 cents a share on revenue of $369.2 million. Skyworks Solutions Inc. SWKS, +1.41% said its fiscal second-quarter profit rose to $16.7 million, or 10 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the company would have reported a profit of 16 cents a share in the latest quarter. Revenue rose to $201.7 million from $180.2 million a year ago. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated a quarterly profit of 14 cents a share on revenue of $199.6 million. The company forecast an adjusted profit of about 17 cents a share for the fiscal third-quarter on revenue of about $210 million. Analysts expect a profit of 15 cents a share on revenue of $207.6 million. Sigma-Aldrich Corp. SIAL reported a first-quarter profit of $84.5 million, or 64 cents a share, on revenue of $569.6 million. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for a profit, on average, of 63 cents a share on sales of $557 million. The St. Louis-based chemical company raised its 2008 targeted earnings range to $2.57 to $2.67 a share. Wall Street previously projected a profit of $2.61 a share for the full year. Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. SSCI, +0.49% reported a narrower first-quarter loss from a year ago but the loss was more than Wall Street had targeted. The maker of cardboard boxes and other packaging reported a loss of $13 million, or 6 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected a loss of 3 cents, on average. Sales were flat at $1.8 billion as a slowing U.S. economy and rising commodity costs offset box-price increases, the company said. Looking ahead, Smurfit-Stone said second-quarter earnings should be better than the first quarter. Tupperware Brands TUP, +2.33% reported its first-quarter net income rose to $32.1 million, or 51 cents a share. Excluding certain items, earnings were 56 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast earnings of 48 cents a share. Revenue climbed to $543.4 million from $456.9 million a year earlier, the Orlando, Fla.-based consumer-goods company said. Tupperware expects second-quarter sales to increase 14% to 16% while earnings are expected to come in between 55 cents a share to 60 cents a share. The company also raised its 2008 guidance to sales growth of 13% to 15% from the previously announced 8% to 10% increase. Earnings for the year are expected to range from $2.44 to $2.54 a share. Analysts are projecting a profit of $2.54 a share. VF Corp. VFC, +0.61% reported first-quarter net income rose almost 8% from a year ago, topping Wall Street's expectations. The company also backed its 2008 profit forecast despite some expected weakness in the second quarter. VF had first-quarter net income of $149 million, or $1.33 a share, up from $138.3 million, or $1.20 a share, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 10% to $1.85 billion. Greensboro, N.C-based VF sells brands such as Wrangler, North Face, Vans, and Nautica. It said 2008 earnings will be 10% higher than last year, while earnings will be up 9%. VF's forecast for the second quarter is below expectations. The company pegged earnings at 80 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect $1.01. VF shares are up 14% this year. Yum Brands Inc. YUM, +1.04% posted a first-quarter profit of $254 million, or 50 cents a share, up from $194 million, or 35 cents, in the year-ago period. Knocking out a one-time gain, Yum would have earned 42 cents a share. Sales rose 8% to $2.41 billion. Same-store sales, or those at outlets open more than a year, climbed 4% worldwide. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated Yum to earn 41 cents a share on revenue of $2.3 billion. Yum also raised its full-year 2008 EPS forecast from $1.85 to $1.87 per share. See full story XL Capital Ltd. XL, -0.16% said that first-quarter net income came in at $244.4 million, down 57% from a year earlier when the insurance and reinsurance company made $562.5 million. Net income available to common shareholders was $1.20 a share, down from $3.06 a share in the same quarter of 2007. Earnings excluding net realized investment gains and losses were $276.9 million, or $1.57 a share, compared with $540 million, or $3.01 a share, for the prior year quarter, XL reported. The company was expected to make $2.27 a share, according to the average estimate of 17 analysts in a FactSet survey. See full story Yahoo Inc. YHOO said its first-quarter net income rose to $542 million, or 37 cents a share, from $142 million, or 10 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. The recent period's earnings include a gain of $401 million related to the IPO of Alibaba.com, in which Yahoo has an ownership stake. Meanwhile revenue in the period ended in March rose to $1.82 billion from $1.67 billion. Yahoo's net revenue, or revenue excluding payments made to other Web sites to acquire traffic, rose to $1.35 billion. Excluding special items, Yahoo said earnings were 11 cents a share. Analysts had estimated Yahoo would post earnings of 9 cents a share, and $1.32 billion in net revenue, according to Thomson Financial. title: American Health Packaging recalls heparin sodium vial products

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies were among those making notable moves in the U.S. stock market Monday. Advancers Amgen Inc. AMGN, +0.01% shares were slightly higher. It said the Food and Drug Administration cleared updated safety information, including an updated boxed label warning that certain anemia drugs - such as its Aranesp and Epogen products -- shorten overall survival or time-to-tumor progression in some cancer patients. Amgen said it is informing health-care professionals about revisions to the U.S. prescribing information. LMI Aerospace Inc.'s LMIA shares jumped 12%. fourth-Fquarter net income rose 43% to $3.8 million, or 34 cents a share, from $2.7 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial expected 34 cents a share. The St..Louis engineering services company said sales increased 81% to $54.6 million from $30.2 million. LMI affirmed its 2008 sales estimate of $241 million to $259 million. Longs Drug Stores Corp. LDG, -22.86% shares gained. It named Todd Vasos executive vice president and chief operating officer, responsible for store operations, marketing, merchandising, construction and loss prevention. McDonald's MCD, -1.28% shares rose 3.6%. February global same-store sales rose 11.7% from a year ago, on a benefit of about 4 percentage points from an extra day due to the leap year. The Oak Brook, Ill., fast-food retailer said systemwide sales for its worldwide restaurants increased 19.9% in February, or 13.2% in constant currencies. See full story. Motorola Inc. MSI, +1.29% shares were up. It said Stu Reed, president of Motorola's mobile-devices business, is resigning, effective immediately. Reed is the latest in a string of high-profile executives to leave the Schaumburg, Ill., company. Nationwide Financial Services Inc. NFS, -5.50% shares soared 24%. Nationwide Mutual Insurance Co., Nationwide Mutual Fire Insurance Co. and Nationwide Corp. proposed to acquire the Class A shares for $47.20 a share each. As of Dec. 31, NFS had 46.7 million Class A shares outstanding, representing 33.7% equity ownership and 4.8% of the voting power. NFS's board named a panel of its independent directors to consider the proposal. Six Flags SIX, +1.12% shares advanced 4.9%. Fourth-quarter net loss narrowed to $126.9 million, or $1.39 a share, from $189.7 million, or $2.09 a share, a year earlier, due in part to increased attendance and guest spending. The amusement part operator said revenue increased 7.5% to $112.1 million from $104.3 million. Six Flags said attendance increased 4% to 2.8 million from 2.7 million the previous year. Decliners AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% shares moved lower. UBS upgraded the pharmaceutical distributor to neutral from sell, citing valuation. "While, we are still cautious on the group as we don't expect branded manufacturers to raise prices ahead of the election in the third quarter, we think some of these concerns are priced in at current levels," the broker said. Private-equity giant Blackstone Group BX, +1.36% shares fell 3.1%. It reported a fourth-quarter loss before Monday's opening bell as global funding for leveraged buyouts dried up as a result of what it called a "meltdown" in the credit markets. See full story. Shares of Blue Nile, NILE an online retailer of jewelry and diamonds, fell 6.3%. It said Monday that Chief Financial Officer Robin Easton resigned to pursue other interests. The company said Terri Maupin, its vice president of finance, will take over Easton's responsibilities. Boeing Co. BA, +2.46% shares moved lower. It may protest the U.S. Air Force's decision to choose a tanker made by Northrop Grumman Corp. NOC, +1.28% and EADS EADSY, -0.45% to replace the nation's aging airborne tanker fleet. Boeing's comments come after meeting with Air Force officials Friday for a debriefing on why the company didn't win the multibillion-dollar contract. Chevron Corp. CVX, +1.73% shares fell. The company and its partners have approved the construction of the Platong Gas II project in the Gulf of Thailand, with an estimated development cost of $3.1 billion. Chevron also said it would build a liquefied natural gas plant based on its Wheatstone reservoir offshore Western Australia. Shares of Countrywide Financial Corp. CFC, +5.04% fell 7.1%, undermined by a weekend report that the FBI is investigating the possibility of securities fraud. See full story. Fannie Mae FNM, -11.67% shares lost 5.8%. It named Jacqueline Wagner as senior vice president and chief audit executive. Wagner will prepare and present the annual audit plan to the board's audit committee and provide periodic updates on the status and overall operation of the internal audit department. See full story. Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% shares fell. Volvo Car Corp.'s Volvo Cars of North America LLC named Doug Speck president and chief executive. He succeeds Anne Belev, who joined Ford as director of global marketing. Volvo Cars, a unit of Ford Motor, also said it will relocate its headquarters to Rockleigh, N.J., from Irvine, Calif., by year's end. The move will affect fewer than 80 employees. Eli Lilly & Co. LLY, +0.47% shares moved lower. It will stop developing its AIR Insulin program, resulting in a first-quarter charge of $90 million to $120 million, or 5 cents to 7 cents a share. The pharmaceutical company said the decision is related not to the product's safety but to increasing uncertainty in the regulatory environment. ExpressJet Holdings Inc. XJT shares fell. It swung to a fourth-quarter loss of $31.7 million, or 60 cents a share, from a profit of $22.8 million, or 39 cents a share, a year earlier. The Houston airline said that excluding special charges, it posted a loss of $27.6 million, or 52 cents a share, for the latest quarter. Revenue rose 2.3% to $436 million from $426.4 million. MBIA MBI, +0.11% shares tumbled 9.8%. Elaborating on its earlier request to Fitch Ratings to withdraw insurer financial strength ratings on six of its units, MBIA noted that Fitch's rating process differs from that of other rating firms. It also pointed out that Fitch's coverage of the underlying credit quality of transactions that MBIA insures is limited, which could lead to "misinterpretation" in turbulent times. See full story. Occidental Petroleum OXY, +2.87% shares fell. It and Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Co. agreed to jointly evaluate and participate in development of upstream and downstream hydrocarbon projects within and outside the Middle East. Terms were not disclosed. Southwest Airlines LUV, +1.83% shares moved lower. Officials in the Federal Aviation Administration allowed the carrier to bypass critical safety inspections for years, USA Today reported. In addition, the officials ignored safety violations, leaked sensitive data to the Dallas carrier and tried to intimidate a pair of FAA inspectors to head off investigations, the newspaper reported, citing government documents. Thornburg Mortgage Inc. TMA shares plunged 33%. It restated its 2007 net loss at $1.3 billion, or $10.94 a share, from a loss of $875 million, or $7.48 a share, reported previously, according to a regulatory filing. Thornburg also said it has received default notices for a total of about $130 million from Natixis Securities North America Inc., (012068) which is acting as an agent for Natixis Financial Products Inc., ING Financial Markets LLC, ING, +0.06% and Goldman, Sachs & Co. GS, +1.00% See related story Vail Resorts' MTN, -0.91% shares fell. Fiscal second-quarter net income fell to $51.3 million, or $1.31 a share, from $53 million, or $1.35 a share, a year earlier, due in part to higher operating expense. The Broomfield, Colo., ski resorts company's net excluding stock-based compensation expense fell to $52.5 million, or $1.34 a share, from $54.1 million, $1.38 a share, a year earlier. Washington Mutual Inc.'s WM, +1.13% shares fell 5.5%. Fitch downgraded Washington Mutual's long-term issuer default rating to BBB from A- and Wells Fargo's WFC, +1.81% individual rating to A/B from A. Fitch placed Bank of America Corp. BAC, +2.04% and Citigroup C, -1.11% on watch for possible downgrade. Wyeth WYE shares fell. It is investing $280 million to build a plant in China that will primarily produce infant-formula milk powder. China is now the fastest-growing market for Wyeth's worldwide nutritional business, the group said. title: Monday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: Pre-open moves U.S. stock futures pointed to tentative gains after the last week's stumble on data showing the second straight drop in monthly employment. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets European markets were fairly flat, though miners declined as U.S. growth worries curtailed sentiment. Asian markets fell on a weak financial sector. Japanese data showed a surprise rise in machinery orders, which are a key barometer of corporate spending. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action UBS upgraded pharmaceutical distributor AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% to neutral from sell, citing valuation. See Upgrades/Downgrades: The Internet's most complete source for analyst comment. Breaking news: See Market Pulse for all the latest Besieged subprime lender Countrywide Financial Corp. CFC, +5.04% is being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for possible securities fraud, The Wall Street Journal reported over the weekend. Carlyle Capital Corp., the Guernsey, Channel Islands, affiliate of the Washington private-equity firm Carlyle Group, CARYF said its lenders had reduced the amount they're willing to lend against the company's portfolio of U.S. government agency AAA-rated residential-mortgage-backed securities. MBIA Inc. MBI, +0.11% expects $200 million in mark-to-market losses from its credit derivative business, and said that Fitch Ratings' insurer financial strength ratings can cause serious volatility in how the company is viewed in the equity markets. In a letter from Chairman and Chief Executive Jay Brown, the company said it was an appropriate time to request that Fitch no longer provide its IFS ratings. Officials in the Federal Aviation Administration allowed Southwest Airlines LUV, +1.83% to bypass critical safety inspections for years, according to a report in USA Today. McDonald's Corp.'s MCD, -1.28% February global same-store sales rose 11.7% from a year ago, benefiting from an extra day due to the leap year. Six Flags Inc.'s SIX, +1.12% fourth-quarter net loss narrowed to $126.9 million, from $189.7 million a year earlier, due in part to increased attendance and guest spending. Retail gasoline prices rose 9 cents in the past two weeks to $3.19 a gallon for self-serve regular, according to the Lundberg Survey of 7,000 stations. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- UBS upgraded pharmaceutical distributor AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% to neutral from sell, citing valuation. "While, we are still cautious on the group as we don't expect branded manufacturers to raise prices ahead of the election in the third quarter, we think some of these concerns are priced in at current levels," the broker said.
title: AmerisourceBergen upgraded to neutral at UBS

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) - AmerisourceBergen Corp. reported Thursday that first-quarter net income dipped while sales exceeded expectations, and a reduction in the company's shares outstanding helped boost per-share profit. In addition, while AmerisourceBergen has consolidated its position in its core distribution business, the company has retained Citigroup to help divest its PMSI workers'-compensation operations. The company characterized the quarterly performance of that unit as "disappointing" and said it's reviewing initial bids for the division. The Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical distributor ABC, +1.29% posted net of $109.8 million, or 66 cents a share, compared with $122.2 million, or 63 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 3.9% to $17.37 billion from $16.73 billion. One-time gains, including a litigation settlement, tacked on roughly 4 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected the drug-distribution giant to post earnings of 62 cents a share on sales of $17 billion for the quarter. AmerisourceBergen said it expects full-year earnings to come in at $2.77 to $2.95 a share, bracketing the Thomson Financial estimate of $2.86. But the company said it expects operating revenue to grow a little faster than previously forecast - in a range of 7% to 9%, up from previous expectations of 5% to 7%. Shares of AmerisourceBergen were up 17 cents to $45.93 at the close. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you
title: AmerisourceBergen earnings slip; sales exceed estimate

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Thursday's session are Microsoft, Ford, E-Trade, AT&T, and Lockheed Martin. Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% is projected to report earnings of 46 cents a share in the fiscal second quarter, according to analysts polled by Thomson Financial. Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% is expected to post a loss of 19 cents a share in the fourth quarter. E-Trade Financial Corp. ETFC, +3.38% is forecast to report a loss of $2.90 a share in the fourth quarter. AT&T Inc. T, +0.25% is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 71 cents a share. Lockheed Martin Corp. LMT, +0.78% is projected to post earnings of $1.69 a share in the fourth quarter. Sun Microsystems Inc. JAVA is estimated to post earnings of 30 cents a share in its fiscal second quarter. US Airways Group LCC, +0.15% is forecast to post a loss of 76 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Kimberly-Clark Corp. KMB, +0.61% is expected to report earnings of $1.11 in the fourth quarter. Union Pacific Corp. UNP, +2.81% is projected to report fourth-quarter earnings of $1.77 a share. Hershey Co. HSY, +0.72% is expected to post earnings of 55 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Ameriprise Financial Inc. AMP, +0.67% is estimated to post earnings of $1.03 a share in the fourth quarter. Xerox Corp. XRX, -0.24% is projected to post fourth-quarter earnings of 41 cents a share. Northrop Grumman Corp. NOC, +1.28% is expected to report earnings of $1.31 a share in the fourth quarter. Consolidated Edison Inc. ED, +0.49% is forecast to report earnings of 61 cents a share in the fourth quarter. McGraw-Hill Cos. MHP, +0.00% is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 52 cents a share. Broadcom Corp. BRCM is projected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 32 cents a share. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% is estimated to post earnings of 62 cents a share in the fiscal first quarter. Danaher Corp. DHR, +1.44% is forecast to report fourth-quarter earnings of $1.12 a share. Amgen Inc. AMGN, +0.01% is projected to post earnings of 97 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Hartford Financial Services HIG, -0.41% is expected to report earnings of $2.49 a share in the fourth quarter. Franklin Resources Inc. BEN, +1.67% is estimated to report earnings of $1.90 a share in the fiscal first quarter. After Wednesday's closing bell, EBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% said fourth-quarter net income rose to $530.9 million, or 39 cents a share, compared with $346.5 million or 25 cents a share for the same quarter the previous year. Revenue grew nearly 27% to $2.18 billion. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 45 cents a share on revenue of $2.14 billion. The company also announced that John Donahoe will become president and chief executive on March 31, succeeding Meg Whitman, who is retiring. See full story Watch list Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% said Chief Executive Steve Jobs in 2007 continued with his tradition of taking just $1 a year in salary. Apple made Jobs' salary public in a proxy statement filed in advance of the company's shareholders meeting, set for March 4. The proxy statement also said that Jobs gained $14.6 million on paper for exercising stock options that were set to expire in 2007. Avis Budget Group Inc. CAR, -0.99% said its board approved the repurchase of up to $50 million in common stock. The provider of vehicle rental services reiterated its 2007 forecast for $405 million to $410 million of earnings before, interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. The company expects to report 2007 pretax income, excluding items, of about $195 million. Ball Corp.'s BLL, +1.33% board approved the buyback of up to 12 million shares. The plastics and aluminum container maker said the repurchase authorization replaces all previous authorizations. Cabot Corp.'s CBT, +2.14% fiscal first-quarter net income fell to $36 million, or 56 cents a share, from $54 million, or 79 cents a share, a year earlier, due to a time lag in feedstock-related adjustments and higher feedstock costs. The company said net sales rose to $711 million from $655 million a year ago. Analysts expected earnings of 31 cents a share on revenue of $672 million. Capital One Financial Corp. COF, +1.64% said fourth-quarter net income came in at $226.6 million, or 60 cents a share, down from $390.7 million, or $1.16 a share, a year earlier. "As the economy has weakened, we have selectively pulled back loan growth and maintained appropriately conservative underwriting standards," said Richard Fairbank, Capital One's Chief Executive. Business software maker Citrix Systems Inc. CTXS, +1.20% said its fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose to $63 million, or 33 cents a share, compared to $53 million, or 29 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. Revenue rose 25% to $400 million. Gilead Sciences Inc. GILD, +0.82% swung to a fourth-quarter profit of $401.6 million, or 41 cents a share, from a loss of $1.67 billion, or $1.81 a share, a year earlier. The biopharmaceutical company said revenue rose to $1.09 billion from $899.2 million a year ago. Analysts had expected earnings of 40 cents a share on revenue of $1.09 billion. Hexcel Corp.'s HXL, +0.67% fourth-quarter net income declined to $13 million, or 13 cents a share, from $17.7 million, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier, hurt by one-time items from the termination of the company's U.S. defined pension plan. The structural and composite materials company said sales grew to $317.6 million from $262.9 million. Analysts had expected earnings of 19 cents a share on revenue of $303 million. Hexcel reaffirmed its 2008 earnings estimate of 90 cents to 95 cents a share. LSI Corp. LSI, -0.35% said its fourth-quarter net loss widened to $2 billion, or $2.88 a share, from $59 million, or 14 cents a share. Revenues rose to $741 million from $524 million a year ago. Analysts had estimated a profit of 7 cents a share on revenue of $714 million. The company sees first-quarter revenue of $620 million to $650 million and an adjusted profit of 5 cents to 9 cents a share. Electronic equipment maker Molex Inc. MOLX reported fiscal second-quarter net earnings of $59.2 million, or 33 cents a share, down from $66.2 million, or 36 cents, a year ago. Revenue rose 0.5% to $841.6 million. Analysts had expected the company to report earnings of 33 cents a share on $824.8 million in revenue. Online DVD rental pioneer Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35% said its fourth-quarter net income rose to $15.8 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with a profit of $14.9 million, or 21 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose to $302.4 million from $277.2 million. Analysts were expecting a profit of 14 cents a share on revenue of $301.7 million. See full story Noble Corp. NE, +3.06% reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $347.4 million, or $1.29 a share, up from $199.7 million, or 74 cents, a year ago. Revenue rose to $831.6 million from $558.8 million. Analysts had expected the offshore rig operator to report earnings of $1.29 a share on $837 million in revenue. Pactiv Corp. PTV reported net income in the fourth quarter rose to $59 million, or 45 cents a share, from $52 million, or 39 cents a share, in the year earlier period. The maker of Hefty bags and other consumer-packaging products said sales totaled $876 million, up from $738 million a year ago. Analysts had forecast earnings of 43 cents a share on revenue of $868 million. The company expects first quarter earnings in 30 cents to 33 cents a share range and $2.00 to $2.10 a share for 2008. Analysts are forecasting earnings of 43 cents a share in the first quarter and $2.04 a share for 2008. QLogic Corp. QLGC, +0.12% reported a fiscal third-quarter net income of $31.9 million, or 23 cents a share, compared with $35.5 million, or 22 cents a share, in the year earlier period. Revenue rose marginally to $158 million from $157.6 million a year ago, the maker of storage network infrastructure components said. Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, +1.30% reported quarterly net income of $767 million, or 46 cents per share, compared with a profit of $648 million, or 38 cents per share for the same quarter last year. The company also reported revenue of $2.44 billion, compared with $2.02 billion for the year-ago period. Analysts had expected to the company to report earnings of 53 cents a share on revenue of $2.41 billion. See full story Ryland Group Inc. RYL swung to a fourth-quarter loss of $201.9 million, or $4.80 a share, from a year-earlier profit of $87.2 million, or $1.98 a share, hurt in part by pretax charges related to inventory value adjustments and write-offs. The homebuilder and mortgage-finance company said revenue fell to $854.1 million from $1.35 billion a year ago. See full story Sanmina-SCI Corp.'s SANM, +0.77% fiscal first-quarter net income slid to $7.92 million, or 1 cent a share, from $28.2 million, or 5 cents a share, a year earlier, hurt in part by weakness in its PC business. Analysts had predicted earnings of 3 cents a share for the quarter. The electronics contract maker said revenue fell to $2.53 billion from $2.78 billion a year ago. The company expects fiscal second-quarter adjusted earnings of 3 cents to 5 cents a share on revenue of $2.4 billion to $2.5 billion. Symantec Corp. SYMC, +0.82% said its fiscal third-quarter net income rose to $132 million, or 15 cents a share, compared to $117 million, or 12 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. Revenue rose to $1.52 billion. Analysts had estimated Symantec would post earnings of 28 cents a share on $1.45 billion in revenue. See full story Security Capital Assurance SCA, -0.36% said it won't try to raise new capital because turmoil in the bond insurance industry has made the plan impractical. The bond insurer said it will continue to pursue the other elements of its plan including buying reinsurance to free up extra capital and restructuring certain insured obligations. Stryker Corp. SYK, +1.87% said fourth-quarter net income rose to $276.1 million, or 66 cents a share, from $227.9 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier, due in part to increased sales. Analysts had predicted 66 cents a share for the quarter. The medical technology company's sales rose to $1.66 billion from $1.4 billion a year earlier. The company expects 2008 earnings from continuing operations of about $2.88. THQ Inc. THQI said it lowered its fiscal third-quarter earnings estimate to 22 cents a share from 61 cents a share and said it plans to close its Concrete Games studio. THQ said the lower earnings would results from about $20 million in accelerated amortization related to the underperformance of some game titles, as well $27 million in other noncash charges. Excluding stock-based compensation expense, THQ expects third-quarter earnings of 23 cents a share. THQ raised its revenue guidance for the quarter to $509 million from $490 million due to better-than-expected sales of WWE SmackDown and MX vs ATV titles. Varian Inc.'s VARI fiscal first-quarter net income rose to $17.6 million, or 57 cents a share, from $15.4 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier. The scientific instrument and vacuum technology supplier said sales increased to $237.4 million from $217.9 million. Analysts had expected earnings of 64 cents a share on revenue of $234 million. Varian Medical Systems Inc. VAR, +0.92% said its fiscal first-quarter earnings increased to $55.5 million, or 43 cents a share, from $49.5 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $458.5 million from $387.9 million a year ago. The company expects second-quarter earnings of 51 cents a share and revenue growth of $14% to 16%. Western Digital Corp. WDC, +1.62% reported a second-quarter profit of $305 million, or $1.35 a share, on revenue of $2.2 billion. During the same period a year ago, the computer hard-disk drive maker earned $128 million, or 57 cents a share, on $1.4 billion in sales. The results topped the estimates of analysts, who forecast Western Digital to earn $1.04 a share on $2.06 billion in revenue. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks in focus for Thursday

content: Pre-open moves Stock market futures rose Tuesday after a late charge in the previous session and board room shakeups at Bear Stearns and Starbucks, while the housing market was back in focus after a big loss for KB Home. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets European shares showed gains as investors moved into defensive health-care and telecoms stocks. Asian stocks traded mixed, with Tokyo ending in positive territory after a late-session rally from Sony Corp. SNE, +0.54% See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action Starbucks SBUX, -0.02% was upgraded to neutral from sell by Banc of America Securities, which said the departure of Jim Donald and appointment of Howard Schultz as chief executive could be the first step to the company more consistently returning cash to shareholders. Goldman Sachs, in a note on health-care services firms, downgraded Medco Health Solutions MHS, +0.00% to neutral from buy and Kendle International KNDL to sell from neutral, citing valuations in both cases. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% was upgraded to neutral from sell, after a 19% decline from April highs and a more constructive view of the drug distribution sector. See Upgrades/Downgrades: The Internet's most complete source for analyst comment. Breaking news: See Market Pulse for all the latest James Cayne is stepping down from his role as CEO of Bear Stearns Cos. BSC, +1.30% but will remain as chairman of the group, according to a report in the Wall Street Journal. Cayne is responding to shareholder pressure after the firm was hit hard by the subprime mortgage crisis, the newspaper reported, citing unnamed sources. KB Home's KBH, +2.60% fiscal fourth-quarter loss widened to $772.7 million, or $9.99 a share, from a year-earlier loss of $49.6 million due to a non-cash charge of $514.2 million to establish a valuation allowance related to its deferred tax assets. The Los Angeles-based home builder said total revenue declined 31% to $2.07 billion from $3.01 billion. On average, analysts had expected a loss of $1.08 a share on revenue of $1.77 billion. Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% has agreed to buy Norwegian search software provider Fast Search & Transfer for $1.2 billion. The offer represents a 42% premium to the previous closing price. Microsoft said it's received irrevocable undertakings to accept the offer from shareholders representing 37% of the shares. Supervalu Inc.'s SVU, -1.42% fiscal third-quarter net income increased 25% to $141 million, or 66 cents a share, due in part to lower costs. Sales for the quarter ended Dec. 1 declined 4.2% to $10.21 billion as identical-store sales rose 0.5%, excluding fuel costs. Analysts had predicted earnings of 63 cents a share on revenue of $10.2 billion. Supervalu predicted fiscal 2008 earnings of $2.71 to $2.77 a share, down from its prior estimate of $2.73 to $2.83 a share. Wine maker Constellation Brands Inc.'s STZ, +3.37% fiscal third-quarter net income rose to $119.6 million, or 55 cents a share, from $107.8 million, or 45 cents, a year earlier, helped in part by lower acquisition-related integration costs and restructuring charges. The profit matched market expectations as sales fell to $1.41 billion from $1.83 billion. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets N.Y. Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Bear Stearns, Starbucks, Microsoft, KB Home in focus

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Goldman Sachs, in a note on health-care services firms, downgraded Medco Health Solutions mhs to neutral from buy and Kendle International kndl to sell from neutral, citing valuations in both cases. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% was upgraded to neutral from sell, after a 19% decline from April highs and a more constructive view of the drug distribution sector.
title: Goldman cuts Medco, Kendle, ups AmerisourceBergen

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% was upgraded to buy from neutral at Banc of America Securities, with the broker saying management is executing well in a difficult time for the company and industry. "A commitment to returning more of its operating cash flow to shareholders while unit growth is low is refreshing, and it positions the company to grow EPS more rapidly as volumes pick up over the course of 2008," the broker said.
title: AmerisourceBergen upped to buy at B. of A. Securities

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Thursday that its board has hiked the quarterly dividend to 7.5 cents a share from 5 cents. The dividend will be payable Dec. 3 to shareholders of record on Nov. 19. The Valley Forge, Pa. pharmacy services firm also said that its existing stock-buyback program has been increased by $500 million.
title: AmerisourceBergen hikes dividend, buyback

content: Con Edison profits rise 35% on rate increases (5:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Consolidated Edison Inc. ED, +0.49% the power company that serves most of New York City, reported late Thursday third-quarter net income rose to $312 million, or $1.15 a share, from $231 million, or 92 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended Sept. 30 rose nearly 6% to $3.6 billion from $3.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast the utility would earn $1.06 a share on $3.51 billion in revenue. Shares fell 1.7% to close at $46.27 ahead of the report. CORRECT--Napster cuts loss to $5.1 million as sales rise 24% (4:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Napster Inc. NAPS, +0.00% on Thursday reported a second-quarter loss of $5.1 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with a loss of $9 million, or 21 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the digital-music service provider rose 24% to $31.6 million from the same period last year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast Napster to lose 15 cents a share on $30 million in revenue. Napster said it ended the quarter with about 750,000 paid subscribers, down from 770,000 in its fiscal first quarter. Going forward, Napster expects to report third-quarter sales of $33 million. (This corrects an earlier version which reported too many paid subscribers for Napster's quarter.) CBS CEO: 'No material impact' foreseen if writers strike (4:48 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- CBS Corp. Chief Executive Les Moonves told analysts Thursday that the company foresees "no material impact" on its financials should there be a strike by Hollywood screenwriters. Moonves, speaking following CBS's CBS, -0.94% release of third-quarter results, said the network has "a full slate" of programming "ready to go" should the Writers Guild of America stage a walkout, as many observers expect, possibly as early as Friday. Moonves added that CBS's slate of comedies repeats "extremely well." Las Vegas Sands swings to third-quarter loss (4:38 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Las Vegas Sands Corp. LVS, +1.58% had a third-quarter loss of $48.5 million, or 14 cents a share, for the period ended Sept. 30, the company said after the close Thursday. A year ago, the Las Vegas-based resort operator reported net income of $97.3 million, or 27 cents a share. Sales were $694.3 million vs. last year's $578.9 million. Excluding various charges, the company would have reported earnings of $41.8 million, or 12 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 31 cents a share on sales of $783 million. Shares ended trading Thursday down $7.78, or 5.9%, to $125.30. After hours, the stock dropped another 17% to $104.07. Napster cuts loss to $5.1 million as sales rise 24% (4:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Napster Inc. NAPS, +0.00% on Thursday reported a second-quarter loss of $5.1 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with a loss of $9 million, or 21 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the digital-music service provider rose 24% to $31.6 million from the same period last year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast Napster to lose 15 cents a share on $30 million in revenue. Napster said it ended the quarter with about 755,000 paid subscribers, down from 770,000 in its fiscal first quarter. Going forward, Napster expects to report third-quarter sales of $33 million. Electronic Arts swings to a loss on accounting change (4:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Electronic Arts Inc. swung to a loss for its second fiscal quarter due to a change in how it accounts for revenue from sales of certain types of video games. For the period ended Sept. 30, the video game publisher ERTS reported a loss of $195 million, or 62 cents a share, compared to earnings of $22 million, or 7 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenue slipped to $640 million from $784 million. The company said the accounting change resulted in a $296 million increase in deferred net revenue that will be recognized in future periods. Analysts were expecting earnings of 20 cents a share on revenue of $896.2 million, according to data from Thomson Financial. ACS reports 8 percent increase in first-quarter profit (4:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCSICO (MarketWatch) - Affiliated Computer Services reported net income of $66.1 million on revenue of $1.49 billion for the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared to a profit of $61.4 million on revenue of $1.38 billion for the same period last year. The company also reported an adjusted non-GAAP earnings per share of 77 cents. Analysts had expected the company to report earnings per share of 84 cents on revenue of $1.49 billion. Leapfrog Enterprises narrows loss on higher toy margins (4:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Leapfrog Enterprises Inc. LF a maker of technology-based learning toys, late Thursday reported a narrower third-quarter loss on declining sales. Leapfrog reported a net loss of $2.8 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $49.7 million, or 79 cents a share, in last year's same period. For the three months ended Sept. 30, Leapfrog said sales fell 22% to $144 million due to fewer sales of toys the company is phasing out. On a brighter note, the company said its gross margin improved to 42.2% of sales vs. 26.6%, helped by lower charges for excess and obsolete inventory and purchase-order cancellations. Looking ahead, Leapfrog said it 2007 revenue will be 10% to 15% below 2006. It estimates a significant improvement in gross margin and net losses. CBS profit rises 8.3% (4:11 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- CBS Corp. reported a higher third-quarter profit on Thursday even as revenue decreased. The New York-based media conglomerate CBS, -0.94% said it earned $343.3 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with a profit of $316.9 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Revenue slipped 3% to $3.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had, on average, been expecting CBS to post a profit of 43 cents as share on revenue of $3.33 billion. In 2007, CBS expects revenue to fall 2-3%, reflecting the divestiture of "lower-margin, slower-growth assets" including 39 radio stations, nine television stations, UPN, and the non- renewal of several of its urban outdoor transit contracts. GlobalSantaFe Corp. up 3% after earnings (2:31 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- GlobalSantaFe Corp. GSF, +0.28% shares rose 3% to $83.37 in recent trades on the heels of its earnings update after the bell on Wednesday. Robert Van Batenburg of Louis Capital Markets said in a note to clients said the oil service firm turned in "blow out results" amid rising remand for its deep-water business and a slight uptick in bidding for Gulf of Mexico work in the last four weeks. Rowan's third-quarter income rises 50% (9:47 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Rowan Cos. RDC, +4.43% the Houston provider of contract energy-drilling services, reported third-quarter net income rose 50% on 20% higher revenue. Profit was $130.8 million, or $1.16 a share, compared with $87 million, or 78 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. The earnings reflected gains on asset sales of 1 cent a share in the latest period and 2 cents a year earlier. The year-ago number also included 1 cent of profit from discontinued operations. Revenue reached $502.2 million from $417.1 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of $1.14 of profit on $530 million of revenue. Rowan's offshore- rig utilization was 99% during the third quarter of 2007, up from 91% in third-quarter 2006, with the day rate up 8% to $11,400. Rowan's land-rig utilization was 96% during the quarter, down from 98% a year ago. Administaff profit edges higher (9:38 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Administaff Inc. said Thursday that its third-quarter profit grew modestly on greater use of its human resource services by small and medium-sized businesses across the U.S. The Houston-based firm NSP, +2.05% said net income was $12.2 million, or 45 cents a share, compared with a prior-year profit of $12.1 million, or 43 cents a share. Revenue rose 13.3% to $383.4 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a profit of 43 cents a share on revenue of $382.1 million. Energy shares fall as Exxon Mobil weighs on sector (9:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy shares fell Thursday as lower-than-expected earnings from sector giant Exxon Mobil XOM, +2.47% weighed. Exxon Mobil fell 2.4% to $89.77 in early trades. The Amex Oil Index XOI, +2.04% dropped 0.8% to 1,484. The Amex Natural Gas Index XNG, +2.25% dropped 0.8% to 569. Tesoro TSO, +0.00% fell 3.4% to $58.48 after its earnings update. Sunoco SUN, -0.47% gave up 4% to $70.55 after its profit report. Marathon Oil MRO, +5.29% dipped 22 cents to $58.91. Williams WMB, +0.32% rose 25 cents to $36.74. Washington Post reports lower third-quarter income (9:33 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Washington Post Co.'s WPO third-quarter earnings fell to $72.5 million from $73.3 million, a year earlier. On a per-share basis, earnings for the quarter were unchanged from the year-ago period at $7.60 a share. The company said results for the most recent quarter included a 62 cents a share gain from the sale of property at its television station in Miami. In addition, the Washington publisher said revenue rose to $1.02 billion from $946.9 million, boosted by higher test preparation revenue, and strong growth in its education and cable television divisions. CenturyTel reports higher third-quarter earnings (9:23 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- CenturyTel CTL, +1.36% the Monroe, La., provider of communications, high-speed Internet and entertainment services, reported third-quarter earnings were up 48% on 14% higher revenue. Earnings reached $113.2 million, or $1.01 a share, from $76.3 million, or 64 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were 97 cents a share compared with 66 cents. Revenue reached $708.3 million from $619.8 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 89 cents of profit on $682 million of revenue. PG&E profit drops 29% after year-ago gains (9:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Utility PG&E Corp. PGE, +0.00% said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit fell 29% to $278 million, or 77 cents a share, from $393 million, or $1.09 a share, a year earlier. Total operating revenue for the period rose 3.5% to $3.28 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting earnings of 86 cents a share on revenue of $3.5 billion. The company said the result leaves it on track to meet expectations of earnings in the upper half of its guidance range of $2.70 to $2.80 per share. The drop in earnings from a year ago was mainly due to several one-off gains in the year-ago quarter. The company also reaffirmed its guidance for 2008 earnings of $2.90 to $3 a share. Sempra Energy's third-quarter earnings decline (9:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sempra Energy SRE, +0.81% said Thursday that its third-quarter net income fell to $305 million, or $1.15 a share, from $653 million, or $2.49 a share in the year-earlier period, which included $1.21 a share in gains. Earnings from continuing operations were $1.24 a share. Revenue declined slightly to $2.66 billion from $2.69 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of $1.03 a share and revenue of $2.84 billion, on average. Sempra Energy also said it expects to report full-year earnings of more than $4 a share, compared to previous guidance of $3.75 to $3.95. Analysts are expecting $3.95 a share in earnings for 2007. Analyst praises Exxon's overseas refining and marketing (9:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Lehman Brothers analyst Paul Cheng on Thursday said in a note to clients that Exxon Mobil's XOM, +2.47% results, "will have a slightly negative impact on the stock due to lower than expected oil and gas production volume as well as slightly lower than consensus earnings." He said it's unclear if there are any "one off" operating items included in the result such as assets sales gain, foreign exchange, or inventory gain/(loss) since the oil giant does not break out these items as specials. Exxon Mobil beat his target of $1.67 a share with earnings of $1.70 a share, "primarily driven by a better than expected international refining and marketing results." Mylan reports higher profit, helped by Matrix acquisition (9:11 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Mylan Inc. MYL, +1.65% reported higher fiscal second-quarter earnings early Thursday, due largely to the recent acquisition of Matrix. For the quarter, Mylan posted net income of $149.8 million, or 60 cents a share, compared with $77.5 million, or 36 cents a share, for the same period last year. Excluding various charges, Mylan would have reported adjusted earnings of 31 cents a share. Revenue jumped to $477.1 million, from $366.7 million. A poll of analysts by Thomson Financial saw the generic drugmaker posting adjusted earnings of 25 cents a share, on revenue of $471 million.
