Lawsuits drive Health Net to loss (9:06 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- The settlement of a trio of class-action lawsuits drove Health Net deep into the red in the third quarter, the HMO said Thursday. Health Net HNT, +0.00% reported a loss of $103.8 million, or 93 cents a share, on the period -- a turn from a profit of $90.9 million, or 76 cents a share, in the same quarter of 2006. Included in the latest numbers is the impact of $296.8 million in pretax charges from its agreement to settle the suits, along with a proposed resolution of regulatory problems with the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance and various other litigation matters. FTI Consulting swings to a gain (9:03 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- FTI Consulting Inc. FCN, +0.73% said Thursday its third-quarter net income rose to $22.9 million, or 50 cents a share, from a loss of $286,000, or a penny a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $253.3 million from $162 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 48 cents a share and revenue of $237.3 million, on average. Rite Aid October same-store sales inch higher (8:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Drugstore operator Rite Aid Corp. RAD, +0.60% on Thursday said October same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least one year, rose 0.4%. Pharmacy same-store sales increased 1.3%, which included a negative impact of about 429 basis points from new generic introductions. Front-end same-store sales, which include general merchandise, fell 1.4%. For the four weeks ended Oct. 27, total drugstore sales rose 50.7% to $1.99 billion compared to $1.32 billion for the same period last year. Prescription revenue accounted for 69% of drugstore sales, and third party prescription revenue represented about 96% of pharmacy sales. Total sales include all of the stores operated during the period, including stores acquired in the Brooks Eckerd acquisition on June 4, while same-store sales figures exclude these acquired operations. Regal Beloit's third-quarter earnings rise (8:57 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Regal Beloit Corp. RBC, +4.86% said Thursday its third-quarter profit rose to $31.2 million, or 92 cents a share, from $29.7 million, or 89 cents per share, in the year-earlier quarter. A Thomson Financial poll of analysts had predicted earnings of 92 cents a share. The Beloit, Wisc.-based maker of power-generation products said net sales increased to $449.4 million from $419.3 million the year before. It forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 67 to 74 cents a share. PSEG net income rises 35% (8:56 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Public Service Enterprise Group PEG, +1.78% on Thursday said third-quarter net income rose to $506 million, or $1.99 a share from $374 million, or $1.48 a share in the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations rose to $500 million, or $1.97 a share, from $372 million, or $1.47 a share. Excluding an item, operating earnings for the latest period rose to $2 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of $1.81 a share, on average. The Newark, N.J. utility increased its 2007 earnings forecast to $5.15-$5.45 a share, from $4.90-$5.30 a share. Dominion third-quarter income more than triples (8:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dominion Resources Inc.'s D, -0.53% third-quarter income more than tripled to $2.32 billion, or $7.24 a share, from $654 million, or $1.85 a share, a year earlier. Operating earnings, which, in the most recent period, excluded items such as a a $1.4 billion net benefit from the sale of a unit, were $1.72 a share, compared to $1.88 a share in the year-earlier period. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of $1.70 a share and revenue of $3.64 billion. The Richmond, Va., utility holding company said operating revenue fell 10% to $3.59 billion from $3.97 billion a year ago. The company increased its quarterly common stock dividend rate 11% to 79 cents per share and set a policy to achieve a 2010 payout ratio of 55%. Dominion also said it is "well positioned" to achieve its operating earnings forecast of $6.10 to $6.25 per share next year. Radian swings to 3rd-quarter loss on negative net revenue (8:38 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Radian Group Inc., RDN, +0.32% the Philadelphia credit-risk-management company, swung to a third-quarter loss from a year-earlier profit on negative total revenue. The loss totaled $703.9 million, or $8.78 a share, compared with net income of $112 million, or $1.36, in the year-earlier period. The total revenue figure was a negative $104.4 million compared with a positive $321.8 million. The negative revenue reflected a change in the fair value of derivatives of a negative $643.9 million. Despite the loss, Radian's book value is $42.86 a share "and we are well positioned with our strong capital and liquidity position to weather the challenging credit cycle," Chief Executive S.A. Ibrahim said in a statement. "While mortgage-insurance credit losses will continue to impact our results for the foreseeable future, I'm encouraged by the positive trends in mortgage insurance penetration and by the resiliency of our financial guaranty business." Progress Energy reports flat third-quarter earnings (8:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Progress Energy Inc.'s PGN, -0.73% third-quarter earnings remained flat at $319 million, as revenue rose 12%. On a per-share basis, earnings decreased to $1.24 from $1.27 a year ago, as the number of average weighted shares outstanding rose. The energy company said third-quarter ongoing earnings rose to $1.14 a share from $1.09 last year, helped by favorable weather, lower income taxes at the core businesses and increased wholesale sales. Core ongoing earnings for the third quarter, which exclude ongoing earnings from the coal and synthetic fuels operations, rose to $1.21 a share from $1.06 a share a year earlier. Revenue for the full year rose to $3.1 billion from $2.78 billion a year ago. For the full year, the company reaffirmed its core ongoing earnings view of $2.70 to $2.90 a share. Blockbuster posts wider third-quarter loss (8:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Blockbuster Inc.'s BBI, +4.00% third-quarter net loss widened to $35 million, or 20 cents a share, from a year-earlier loss of $24.7 million, or 15 cents a share. The Dallas video retail chain said revenue fell 5.7% to $1.24 billion from $1.31 billion a year ago, due to the closure and sale of 526 company-operated stores worldwide. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected a loss of 18 cents a share and revenue of $1.28 billion. Worldwide same-store rental revenues for the period were up 1.1% from the year-ago period. The company has implemented a plan to reduce annual overhead costs by about $45 million through the elimination of "staffing and operational redundancies and through improvements in other operating efficiencies." Blockbuster also said it will concentrate on the growth of its total membership, as opposed to only its online subscriber count. Morningstar's net income rises 47% (8:09 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Investment research firm Morningstar Inc. MORN, +0.72% Thursday said its third-quarter profit rose to $19.9 million, or 41 cents a share, from $13.5 million, or 29 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Chicago-based company's revenue rose to $111.9 million from $81.8 million a year earlier. Quarterly results included $10.2 million in revenue from acquisitions over the past year, Morningstar said. Assets under management in its investment-consulting business climbed to $91.4 billion from $47.6 billion the prior year. More than 20% of revenue is coming from outside the U.S., said Chief Executive Joe Mansueto in a statement. The stock closed Wednesday up 1.9% to $74.42. International Game Technology fourth-quarter income rises (8:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- International Game Technology IGT, +0.94% said Thursday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose to $122.6 million, or 38 cents a share from a year-ago $114.9 million, or 33 cents a share. Revenue increased in the latest three months to $353.3 million from $333.8 million in the year-earlier period. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 38 cents a share. The stock closed Wednesday at $43.61. Smith & Nephew profit drops 86% after charges (7:58 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Medical technology group Smith & Nephew(UK:SN) SNN, -0.78% said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit fell 86% to $13 million, or 1.6 cents a share, from $92 million, or 9.8 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the period rose 24% to $845 million. Trading profit, which excludes restructuring, acquisition and legal costs, rose 28% to $169 million. "Trading conditions across the business continue to be characterised by good volume growth tempered by a tight pricing environment in some geographies," Smith & Nephew said. Shares in the group fell 3.5% in London trading. Williams net income nearly doubles; sets 2008 profit range (7:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Williams Companies Inc. WMB, +0.32% on Thursday said third-quarter net income nearly doubled to $198 million, or 33 cents a share, from $106.2 million, or 18 cents a share in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 38 cents a share, on average. Williams boosted its 2008 segment profit target for exploration and production to $1 billion to $1.3 billion from $950 million to $1.25 billion. "Higher expected net realized prices and production volumes, partially offset by higher costs, are the factors driving the increase," the company said. For 2008, it sees profit of $1.50 to $1.90 a share, compared to the analyst target of $1.81 a share. Separately, Williams Partners L.P. WPZ, -0.03% said it'll pay $750 million to buy from Williams Companies a membership interest in the limited liability company that owns the Wamsutter systems. Cameron Int'l 3rd-quarter net up 69% on 21% higher revenue (7:46 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Cameron International Corp., CAM, -1.67% the Houston provider of flow equipment products, systems and services to worldwide oil, gas and process industries, reported that third-quarter net income rose 69% on 21% higher revenue. Earnings reached $150.7 million, or $1.31 a share, from $89.3 million, or 78 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were $1.14 against 80 cents. Revenue rose to $1.19 billion from $978.8 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of $1.09 of profit on $1.21 billion of revenue. At Sept. 30, the backlog totaled $4.13 billion, up 4% from the end of the second quarter and up 22% from the end of third-quarter 2006. Cameron estimates earnings for 2007 at$4.24 to $4.27 a share. Thomson's estimate is $4.17. Cameron also reduced the amount of pre-tax charges it expects to record for its plan to end its pension plan to $67 million from $85 million. It will take the charges from the fourth quarter of 2007 through the first quarter of 2009. It will need to add $10 million to $15 million to the plan in late 2008 or early 2009. Owens Corning posts profit, sees weak U.S. housing market (7:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Owens Corning OC, -1.47% on Thursday reported third-quarter net income of $112 million, or 86 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, it earned 40 cents a share. Net sales fell to $1.27 billion from $1.39 billion. The Toledo, Ohio-based company, which recently emerged from bankruptcy, said third-quarter results reflected continued weakness of the U.S. new residential construction market, partially offset by stronger global markets in its composites business. As part of Owens Corning's annual operations planning, the company said it is evaluating various cost-reduction projects to deliver significant savings in operating and corporate costs. These projects include capacity and job cuts, elimination of operational costs, and reduced general corporate expenses. Some of these cost-reduction projects have begun, Owens Corning said. The majority of the projects are expected to be completed by the end of the fourth quarter, resulting in a leaner cost structure that better positions the company to compete in a weaker housing market in 2008. This cost-reduction initiative is intended to reduce company-wide operating costs by about $100 million. The company no longer believes that it will surpass its earlier EBIT guidance from continuing operations of $365 million. Based on the deeper and prolonged weakness in demand for building materials in the U.S., the company now believes $335 million is a more appropriate estimate for 2007 adjusted EBIT from continuing operations. Timberland profit, sales slip; sees soft market conditions (7:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Timberland Co. TBL, +0.70% on Thursday said third-quarter net income fell to $25.9 million, or 42 cents a share, from $55.6 million, or 88 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding restructuring costs mostly related to the company's decision to close certain retail locations, it earned 49 cents a share. Revenue fell to $433.3 million from $503 million. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 49 cents a share on revenue of $437 million, according to Thomson Financial. For the fourth quarter, Timberland anticipates revenue declines in the mid-single digit range reflecting soft market conditions in the U.S. and Europe and operating margin declines in the range of 200 basis points, excluding restructuring costs. For 2008, Timberland is targeting mid-single digit first half revenue declines and improved operating results. The footwear and apparel maker expects soft market trends will be offset by its "efforts to drive operational efficiencies" and its decision to close about 50 retail stores by the end of the first quarter of 2008. The company also said it would realign its U.S sales team and global product development organization to "eliminate redundancies and improve efficiencies." Eastman Kodak back to profit, while sales slip (7:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Eastman Kodak Co. EK on Thursday reported third-quarter net income of $37 million, or 13 cents a share, swinging from a net loss of $37 million, or 13 cents a share, for the same period last year. In its quarterly report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Rochester, N.Y., camera and film company said its net sales for the period ended Sept. 30 totaled $2.58 billion, slightly lower than the $2.6 billion reported for the third quarter of 2006. Kodak also said earnings from continuing operations swung to $29 million, or 12 cents a share, from a loss of $53 million, or 29 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 27 cents a share. Nymex Holdings net income rises 54% (7:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Nymex Holdings Inc. NMX, +8.20% said Thursday third-quarter net income rose 54% to $62.57 million, or 66 cents a share, from $40.7 million, or 47 cents a share. Revenue rose to $173.2 million from $138.3 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 64 cents a share and revenue of $171.4 million, on average. The parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange OK'd a special dividend of $100 million and set plans for a work force reduction of 120 people over the next five quarters. It also hired Cushman & Wakefield to evaluate a sale of its headquarters in Lower Manhattan. MarineMax 4th-quarter net off 47% on 1.7% lower revenue (7:12 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- MarineMax Inc., HZO, +2.10% the Clearwater, Fla., recreational-boat retailer, reported fiscal fourth-quarter fell 47% on 1.7% lower revenue. Earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30 were $6.6 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with $12.6 million, or 66 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell to $318.2 million from $323.6 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate of 20 cents of profit on $305 million of revenue. Same-store sales fell 1% for the quarter. MarineMax said that "visibility is limited but industry data suggests that retail sales have not improved." For fiscal 2008, MarineMax estimates earnings per share of 60 cents to 80 cents on a decline in the low sing-digits percent in same-store sales. Thomson's survey is looking for 77 cents. Amerisource Bergen net income falls 28% (7:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Amerisource Bergen ABC, +1.29% on Thursday said net income fell 28% to $87.6 million, or 50 cents a share, from $122 million, or 61 cents a share for its fourth-quarter ended Sept. 30. The Valley Forge, Pa. pharmacy services firm said revenue rose 5% to $16.39 billion. Earnings from continuing operations were 63 cents a share, which included a write-down of 10 cents a share for the market value of its tetanus-diphtheria vaccine inventory and a benefit of 3 cents a share from special items. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 64 cents a share and revenue of $16.47 billion, on average. The company forecast 2008 earnings of $2.77 to $2.95 a share, compared to the analyst target of $2.88 a share. I2 profit up 17%, plans review of strategic options (7:09 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Supply chain company i2 Technologies Inc. ITWO said Thursday that its third-quarter profit rose 17% to $5.3 million, or 17 cents a share, as it also revealed a strategic review of options, including the possible sale of the group. Revenue slipped 7% to $66.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 12 cents a share on revenue of $64 million. The group said it's formed a committee of independent directors to consider different strategic options. It added the review is expected to conclude at the end of January. The company said it expects earnings for the year in the range of 55 cents to 65 cents a share. Alliant Techsystems net up 28%, lifts FY view (7:07 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Alliant Techsystems ATK reported second-quarter net income rose 28% to $51.2 million, or $1.44 a share, and increased its guidance for the year. Sales rose 24% to $1.03 billion during the quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of $1.39 a share. For the year, it expects earnings between $6.20 and $6.30 a share, including the 9-cent charge taken in the quarter for the write-off of debt issuance, which is 5 cents a share better than a previous forecast. Sales are now seen above $4.1 billion, from a previous view of $4 billion to $4.1 billion at the Minneapolis weapons and space systems maker. Myriad Genetics narrows loss, says CFO to leave (7:02 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Myriad Genetics Inc., MYGN, -0.40% the Salt Lake City biotech company, narrowed its third-quarter loss on 44% higher revenue. The net loss was $8 million, or 18 cents a share, compared with $12.4 million, or 31 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached $48.3 million from $33.5 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call estimated a loss of 23 cents a share on revenue of $48 million. Iinitial sales of the company's newest product, TheraGuide 5-FU, are "encouraging," Myriad Genetics said. The company also said Chief Financial Officer Jay Moyes decided to retire "to pursue his passion -- race car driving." Jim Evans, currently vice president of finance, succeeds Moyes as CFO. Capella Education net up 70% as enrollment grows (6:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Capella Education CPLA, +1.33% said third-quarter net income rose 70% to $5.1 million, or 29 cents a share, with revenue up 26% to $55.5 million as enrollment increased 23.8%. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 26 cents a share on revenue of $54 million. For the fourth quarter, it expects enrollment up 22.5% to 23.5%, revenue up 25.3% to 26.3% and operating margins between 18% and 19%. Oshkosh profit jumps 74% following acquisition (6:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oshkosh Truck Corp OSK, +1.35% said Thursday that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 74% to $85.4 million, or $1.14 a share, from $49.2 million, or 66 cents a share, a year ago. Net sales rose 98% to $1.79 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of $1.07 a share on revenue of $1.85 billion. Revenue growth was due to the acquisition of JLG Industries, which contributed $840 million of sales, as well as further growth from its defense business. Oshkosh also reaffirmed its guidance for 2008 earnings of $4.15 to $4.35 a share. EDO 3rd-quarter net jumped on 39% higher revenue (6:40 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- EDO Corp., EDO the New York developer of solutions for defense electronics, communications and other applications, reported that third-quarter net income jumped on 39% higher revenue. Profit reached $11.2 million, or 49 cents a share, from $2.1 million, or 11 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted for tax benefits, the latest earnings were 30 cents a share against break-even a year earlier. Sales rose to $256.8 million from $184.4 million. Revenue excluding acquisitions rose 13%. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 39 cents of profit on $267 million of revenue. EDO has agreed to be acquired by ITT Corp. ITT, +2.13% for $56 a share. EDO shares closed on Wednesday at $58. Hornbeck profit climbs 21% (6:27 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Hornbeck Offshore Services Inc. HOS, +2.11% said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit rose 21% to $28.9 million, or $1.09 a share, from $23.9 million, or 86 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter rose 22% to $94.7 million. The company, which provides offshore supply vessels, said revenue was boosted by the contribution of recently acquired and newly constructed vessels. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of 83 cents a share on revenue of $89 million. Hornbeck said it now expects earnings for the year in the range of $3.28 to $3.52 a share. Genesee & Wyoming returns to profit in third quarter (6:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Genesee & Wyoming GWR, +0.93% said it posted a third-quarter profit of $16.2 million, or 42 cents a share, with revenue up 8% to $131 million. The company lost $12.1 million, or 29 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. The owner and operator of short line and regional freight railroads earned 43 cents a share from continuing operations when excluding asset sales and tax benefits. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of 40 cents a share. "In light of the difficult freight environment, we are generally pleased with our third quarter financial results," said GWI Chief Executive Officer John C. Hellmann. PharmaNet swings to profit (6:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- PharmaNet Development Group Inc. PDGI said Thursday that it swung to a third-quarter net profit of $6.8 million, or 36 cents a share, from a loss of $0.3 million, or a penny a share, a year earlier. Total revenue for the quarter rose 20.5% to $124.4 million. Earnings from continuing operations were 37 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 30 cents a share. The company, which provides drug development services to the pharmaceutical sector, also said its backlog rose to $472.5 million at the end of the quarter from $444 million at the end of the second quarter. The group cuts its earnings guidance for the year to a range of 53 cents to 59 cents from a range of 58 cents to 64 cents. But it also raised its guidance for adjusted earnings to a range of $1.22 to $1.29 a share from a range of $1.12 to $1.24 a share. Randgold 3rd-quarter net off 9.5% on 12% higher gold sales (6:13 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Randgold Resources Ltd., GOLD, +1.12% (UK:RRS)the London gold miner, reported third-quarter net income fell 9.5% on 12% higher gold sales. Earnings were $11.5 million against $12.7 million in the year-earlier period. Pretax profit was flat at $18.3 million. Gold sales reached $70.7 million from $63.2 million. The company produced 110,247 ounces of gold in the period, up 3% from 107,002 ounces a year earlier. The total cash cost per ounce produced was $346, up 14% from $304 a year earlier. Portland General Electric profit doubles on tax change (5:43 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Portland General Electric Co.'s POR, +0.57% third-quarter earnings doubled to $20 million, or 32 cents a share, from $10 million, or 16 cents a share, a year earlier. The Oregon utility company cited an $18 million benefit from a state utility income-tax law. The company's quarterly revenue rose 17% to $435 million from $372 million. Looking ahead, the company reaffirmed its 2007 earnings guidance of $2.25 to $2.35 a share, including one-time items totaling 41 cents a share from a deferral of excess power costs. For 2008, the company expects earnings of $1.75 to $1.85 a share. On average, analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial expect earnings of $2.10 for 2007 and $1.97 for 2008. Profit at medical equipment maker Beckton Dickinson up 44% (5:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Becton Dickinson and Co. BDX, +2.01% the New Jersey medical-equipment maker, said fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose 44% to $251 million, or 99 cents a share, with revenue up 13% to $1.65 billion. From continuing operations, profit rose 15% to 98 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 97 cents a share on revenue of $1.63 billion. For fiscal 2008, the company expects earnings up 10% to 12% from the $3.84 per share it earned in fiscal 2007. Lenovo Group net up nearly three fold to $103M in quarter (5:04 AM ET) Lenovo Group Ltd.(HK:992), makers of the ThinkPad line of laptop computers, said Thursday that net profit for its fiscal second quarter ending Sept 30. surged almost three-fold on strong PC shipments in China and overseas. Lenovo, which ranks as China's top computer maker, reported quarterly net profit of $105.26 million, up from $37.89 million a year ago. Revenue for the three-month period reached $4.43 billion, rising from $3.7 billion a year ago. In the first half, worldwide PC shipments rose 23%, with shipments to North America up 14%, shipments to China up 30% and shipments to the rest of Asia up 18%. Lenovo said its total global PC market share gained 0.6 percentage point to 8.2%. Lenovo shares fell 2.1% in Thursday trade after rising 151.6% so far this year. Bally Technologies swings to 4th-quarter net; revenue up 31% (4:57 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Bally Technologies Inc., BYI, +0.62% the Las Vegas producer of gambling equipment, swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter profit from a year-earlier loss on 31% higher revenue. Bally also affirmed its outlook for the coming fiscal year. And it said that on Nov. 2 it expected to file its reports for the quarter ended March 31 and the year ended June 30 with the Securities and Exchange Commission. For the fourth quarter ended June 30, profit was $18.5 million, or 33 cents a share, against a loss of $12 million, or 23 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted for stock-based compensation, results were profit of 37 cents against a loss of 19 cents. Shares outstanding rose 8.2% to 56.4 million. Revenue rose to $202.4 million from $154.9 million. British American Tobacco profit up 35% (3:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British American Tobacco(UK:BATS)said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit rose 35% to 600 million pounds ($1.24 billion) as revenue grew 5.8% to 2.59 billion pounds. Cigarette volumes rose slightly in the quarter, but were still down 1% for the first nine months, hurt by supply chain disruptions in the Middle East as well as heavy trade buying at the end of 2006. Profit benefited from lower raw materials and employee costs. The group said it still expects profit growth to slow in the fourth quarter due to increased spending on marketing and the timing of price increases in Brazil. Drew Industries 3rd-quarter net up 60%, sales off 4.1% (3:39 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Drew Industries Inc., DW, +0.00% the White Plains, N.Y., producer of parts for recreational vehicles and manufactured homes, reported third-quarter net income rose 60% on 4.1% lower sales. Earnings reached $11.1 million, or 50 cents a share, from $6.9 million, or 32 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales fell to $173.4 million from $180.7 million. Cost-cutting was "a significant factor" in the higher profit, President and Chief Executive Leigh Abrams said in a statement. New products, greater market share and acquisitions helped offset "continued weakness in both the RV and manufactured-housing industries," he said. Sales in October were level with those of the year-earlier month. That's the first month in 2007 that sales didn't decline from the year earlier, Drew said. ICI pretax climbs 18%, to top 2007 forecast (3:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Imperial Chemical Industries(UK:ICI), which has agreed to be bought by Akzo Nobel AKZOY, -1.20% said third-quarter adjusted pretax profit rose 18% to 177 million pounds on a 5% rise in comparable sales from continuing operations. "The third quarter was particularly strong with good underlying sales performances from Specialty Starches, Specialty Polymers and Decorative Paints in Asia & Latin America," the company said, adding that cost controls and selective price rises helped trading margins rise by nearly a percentage point to 13.3%. ICI said it expects its fourth-quarter and 2007 results to top previous expectations. ICI expects the Akzo Nobel acquisition to close on Jan. 2. Unilever profit up 37%, sales climb strongly in Africa, Asia (3:34 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Household products and food group Unilever(UK:ULVR) UL, +0.83% said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit rose 37% to 1.01 billion euros from 737 million euros as revenue for the period rose 1% to 10.24 billion euros. Underlying sales were up 4.5%. Revenue fell 0.6% in Europe and 2.3% in the Americas, but this was more than offset by strong growth in Asia and Africa, with India and China showing particularly strong growth. Commodity prices pressures have increased sharply, but have been offset through increased prices which helped raise the group's margin by 0.2 percentage points. Earnings were also boosted by increased an increased contribution from joint ventures and lower financing costs. Unilever said it remains confident it will meet its targets for 2007. Dentsply 3rd-quarter net up 33%; year outlook increases (3:20 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Dentsply International Inc., XRAY, +0.72% the York, Pa., provider of dental-care products, reported third-quarter net income rose 33% on 12% higher sales. Earnings reached $65.7 million, or 42 cents a share, from $49.4 million, or 31 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose to $488.1 million from $435.7 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate of 38 cents of profit on $477 million of sales. Dentsply increased its estimate of full-year earnings to $1.62 to $1.66 a share from $1.60 to $1.64. Thomson's survey is looking for $1.64. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Amerisource Bergen ABC, +1.29% on Thursday said net income fell 28% to $87.6 million, or 50 cents a share, from $122 million, or 61 cents a share for its fourth-quarter ended Sept. 30. The Valley Forge, Pa. pharmacy services firm said revenue rose 5% to $16.39 billion. Earnings from continuing operations were 63 cents a share, which included a write-down of 10 cents a share for the market value of its tetanus-diphtheria vaccine inventory and a benefit of 3 cents a share from special items. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 64 cents a share and revenue of $16.47 billion, on average. The company forecast 2008 earnings of $2.77 to $2.95 a share, compared to the analyst target of $2.88 a share.
title: Amerisource Bergen net income falls 28%

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are likely to see active trading during Thursday's session are Exxon Mobil, Sprint, Trump Entertainment, and PG&E. Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, +2.47% is expected to post earnings of $1.75 a share in the third quarter, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Sprint Nextel Corp. S, +0.41% is forecast to report third-quarter earnings of 22 cents a share. Trump Entertainment Resorts Inc. TRMP is projected to post earnings of 14 cents a share in the third quarter. PG&E Corp. PCG, +1.60% is estimated to report earnings of 86 cents a share in the third quarter. AmerisourceBergen Corp.) ABC, +1.29% is projected to report earnings of 64 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Callaway Golf Co. ELY, +0.62% is estimated to report third-quarter earnings of 2 cents a share. Marathon Oil Corp. MRO, +5.29% is forecast to post third-quarter earnings of $1.38 a share. AstraZeneca Plc. AZN, -0.46% is expected to report earnings of 92 cents a share in the third quarter. VeriSign Inc. VRSN, +1.86% is projected to report earnings of 27 cents a share in the third quarter. Big 5 Sporting Goods Corp. BGFV, +0.69% is estimated to report third-quarter earnings of 30 cents a share. Napster Inc. NAPS, +0.00% is expected to report a loss of 15 cents a share in the fiscal second quarter. Bebe Stores Inc. BEBE, -7.76% is expected to report earnings of 17 cents in the fiscal first quarter. Peet's Coffee & Tea Inc. PEET is estimated to post earnings of 11 cents a share in the third quarter. CVS Caremark Corp. CVS, -0.80% is expected to report third-quarter earnings of 44 cents a share. World Wrestling Entertainment Inc. WWE, -0.30% is forecast to report third-quarter earnings of 9 cents a share. Blockbuster Inc. BBI, +4.00% is projected to post a loss of 18 cents a share in the third quarter. Timberland Co. TBL, +0.70% is expected to post third-quarter earnings of 49 cents a share. CBS Corp. CBS, -0.94% is estimated to post earnings of 43 cents a share in the third quarter. Blackboard Inc. BBBB is expected to report third-quarter earnings of 22 cents a share. Nymex Holdings Inc. NMX, +8.20% is forecast to post third-quarter earnings of 64 cents a share. OfficeMax Inc. (OMX) OMXS30, +1.54% is estimated to report earnings of 64 cents a share in the third quarter. Scotts Miracle-Gro Co. SMG, +1.25% is projected to post a loss of 11 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Eastman Kodak Co. EK is expected to report earnings of 27 cents a share in the third quarter. Consolidated Edison Inc. ED, +0.49% is expected to post earnings of $1.06 a share in the third quarter. Medco Health Solutions Inc. MHS, +0.00% is expected to report third-quarter earnings of 79 cents a share. Getty Images Inc. GYI is estimated to post third-quarter earnings of 43 cents a share. Denny's Corp. DENN, +0.59% is expected to post earnings of 4 cents a share in the third quarter. Watch list After Wednesday's closing bell, Navteq Corp. NVT, -10.00% said its earnings jumped 47% in the third quarter thanks to a strong rise in sales. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Navteq reported earnings of $39.9 million, or 40 cents a share, compared to earnings of $27.1 million, or 28 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenue rose 51% to $214.8 million. Analysts were expecting earnings of 30 cents a share on revenue of $193.6 million. Advanced Auto Parts Inc.'s AAP, +2.22% third-quarter earnings rose to $59 million, or 57 cents a share, from $58.9 million, or 56 cents a share, a year earlier. The auto parts retail chain said revenue increased 5.3% to $1.16 billion from $1.1 billion a year ago. Same-store sales increased 1.1% for the quarter. Analysts had expected earnings of 58 cents a share on revenue of $1.14 billion. Advanced Auto Parts expects fourth-quarter earnings of 36 cents to 40 cents a share, based on same-store sales growth of up to 2%. Aon Corp.'s AOC, -3.71% third-quarter net income came in at $204 million, or 64 cents a share, up 92% from a year earlier when the insurance broker made $106 million, or 32 cents a share. Aon was expected to make 59 cents a share. Organic revenue growth, which excludes recent acquisitions and divestitures and currency fluctuations, came in at 6%. The insurer also said it will eliminate 2,700 jobs as part of a new re-organization plan. The company's restructuring plan will result in pretax charges of roughly $360 million. Aon said the plan should deliver $50 million to $70 million of savings in 2008. The company has almost completed an earlier re-organization that was launched in November 2005. Allied Waste Industries Inc. AW posted a third-quarter profit of $17.8 million, or 5 cents a share, down from $62.9 million, or 17 cents a share, a year ago. Sales at the nation's second-biggest garbage hauler rose 2% to $1.56 billion thanks to higher prices. Analysts had expected a profit of 22 cents a share on sales of $1.6 billion. See full story Amdocs Ltd. DOX, +0.80% reported fourth-quarter net profit of $96.2 million, or 43 cents a share, up from $76 million, or 35 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue totaled $726.7 million in the quarter, rising from $665.4 million a year ago. Analysts had projected earnings of 54 cents a share on revenue of $731 million. The company forecast revenue in fiscal first quarter in the $735 million to $745 million range with earnings at 43 cents to 46 cents. Analysts expect earnings of 56 cents a share and $754 million in revenue. Caci International Inc.'s CAI, +1.97% fiscal first-quarter net income fell 2.7% to $18.3 million from $18.8 million a year ago. The provider of information technology products and services said earnings remained flat at 60 cents a share. Analysts had predicted earnings of 58 cents a share for the quarter. The company's revenue rose 18% to $553.6 million from $467.6 million, helped by contract awards and an increase in funding orders. Caci said it expects 2008 earnings of $2.50 to $2.80 a share. The company expects revenue of $2.25 billion to $2.35 billion. Conseco Inc. CNO, -0.87% swung to a third-quarter loss of $53.7 million, or 29 cents a share, from a profit of $48.4 million, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier as it incurred a loss from a coinsurance transaction, higher insurance policy benefits expenses and litigation settlement costs. The insurance holding company said revenue rose 5.1% to $1.18 billion from $1.12 billion a year ago. Net operating loss was $25.6 million, or 14 cents a share, compared with an operating profit of $52.8 million, or 35 cents a share, in the prior-year period. Analysts had expected earnings of 26 cents a share on revenue of $1.16 billion. Duke Realty Corp. DRE, +0.80% said funds from operations rose to $99.9 million, or 68 cents a share, from $97.5 million, or 65 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Net income for the period fell to 39 cents a share from 45 cents a share a year ago. Revenue from continuing operations grew to $223.5 million from $218.5 million last year. Analysts had expected funds from operations of 67 cents a share, net earnings of 20 cents a share, and revenue of $202.6 million. The company forecast fourth-quarter funds from operations between 78 cents and 82 cents a share. Endurance Specialty Holdings Ltd. ENH said its third-quarter profit rose to $131.4 million, or $1.81 a share, from $128.2 million, or $1.74 a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts had expected a profit of $1.56 a share. Total revenue fell to $461 million from $463.3 million a year ago. General Growth Properties Inc. GGP, -0.44% swung to a third-quarter profit of $21.2 million, or 9 cents a share, from a year-earlier loss of $8.16 million, or 3 cents a share. Funds from operations were 83 cents a share, compared with 65 a share in the year-earlier period. The real estate investment trust said revenue climbed 16% to $864.3 million from $746 million. Analysts had expected FFO of 78 cents a share and earnings of 9 cents a share, on revenue of $678 million. For 2007, the company expects core funds from operations of $3.26 to $3.29 a share. Helix Energy Solutions Group Inc.'s HLX, +1.05% third-quarter net income rose 45%, helped by better-than-expected results in its contracting services business. The energy services company's earnings rose to $83.8 million, or 88 cents a share, from $57.8 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts had predicted third-quarter earnings of 80 cents a share. Revenue increased 23% to $460.6 million from $374.4 million a year ago, the company said. Helix expects fourth-quarter per-share earnings of 85 cents to $1.05. Analysts predict earnings of $1 for the period. JDS Uniphase Corp.'s JDSU fiscal first-quarter loss narrowed to $6.9 million, or 3 cents a share, from $17.4 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier, helped by higher revenue from its optical communications unit. The technology networking equipment maker's revenue for the quarter ended Sept. 29 increased 12% to $356.7 million from $318.1 million a year ago. Analysts had predicted first-quarter earnings of 6 cents a share and revenue of $355.9 million. JDS Uniphase expects second-quarter non-GAAP revenue of $372 million to $394 million. Analysts predict revenue of $393 million for the period. MetLife Inc. MET, -0.02% said third-quarter net income came in at $985 million, slightly lower than a year earlier when the life insurance and annuity company made $999 million. Net income available to common shareholders was $1.29 a share, in line with the same period last year, MetLife reported. Operating earnings available to common shareholders, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses and other items, came in at $1.16 billion, or $1.52 a share, the company reported. Analysts had expected MetLife to make $1.39 a share. Penn Virginia Corp. PVA, +0.63% reported its third-quarter net profit narrowed to $17.1 million, or 45 cents a share, from $22.9 million, or 61 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $215.8 million in the quarter from $188.4 million a year ago, the gas and oil company said. Analysts had forecast earnings of 43 cents a share on revenue of $198 million. Prudential Financial PRU, +0.63% said third-quarter net income came in at $860 million, down 25% from a year earlier when the life insurance and retirement savings giant made $1.152 billion. Net income available to common shareholders was $1.88 a share, vs. $2.38 a year ago. Analysts had expected the insurer to make $1.73 a share. Prudential said full-year 2007 adjusted operating income will likely be in a range of $7.45 to $7.60 a share, up from a previous forecast of $7.20 to $7.40 a share. Rambus Inc.'s RMBS, +0.67% third-quarter loss narrowed from a year ago, when the company incurred $23.8 million in restatement and related legal expenses. The technology licensing company's loss was $6.5 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with a loss of $22.6 million, or 22 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue decreased 9% to $41.7 million from $45.9 million a year ago, on a 15% decline in royalty revenue, the company said. Southwestern Energy Co.'s SWN, +0.23% third-quarter net income rose 52% to $51 million, or 30 cents a share, from $33.5 million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier. The natural gas company said operating revenue climbed 77% to $297.6 million from $168.4 million. Analysts had expected earnings of 27 cents a share on revenue of $259 million. Southwestern attributed the results to growth in production volume from its Fayetteville Shale project and higher realized natural gas prices. The company said it expects to invest $1 billion in its Fayetteville Shale project in 2007. Oil refiner and marketer Sunoco Inc. SUN, -0.47% reported third-quarter net income fell to $216 million, or $1.81 a share, from $351 million, or $2.76, a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended Sept. 30 rose 10% to $11.5 billion from $10.5 billion. Analysts had predicted the company would post earnings of $2.14 a share on $9.5 billion in revenue. See full story New products in its Colonial lines and improving performance of its UK Unum segment helped employee benefits provider the Unum Group UNM, +0.68% generate third quarter net income of $187 million, or 52 cents per share. That was up from a net loss of $63.7 million, or 19 cents a share, a year ago. The firm said it was revising its full year 2007 operating earnings guidance to a range of $2.14 to $2.17 a share. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks in focus for Thursday

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are likely to see active trading during Wednesday's session are JPMorgan Chase & Co., Coca-Cola Co., eBay Inc., and Teradyne Inc. JPMorgan Chase & Co. JPM, +1.82% is forecast to report earnings of 90 cents a share for the third quarter, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Coca-Cola Co. KO, +0.25% is expected to report earnings of 68 cents a share in the third quarter. EBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% is expect to post third-quarter net earnings of 33 cents a share. Teradyne Inc. TER, +1.96% is forecast to report third-quarter net earnings of 18 cents a share. Abbott Laboratories ABT, +1.16% is expected to post net earnings of 66 cents a share in the third quarter. Gannett Co. GCI, +0.50% is forecast to post third-quarter net earnings of $1 a share. E-Trade Financial Corp. ETFC, +3.38% is expected to report net earnings of 10 cents a share in the third quarter. United Technologies Corp. UTX, +1.10% is expected to report net earnings of $1.16 a share in the third quarter. Washington Mutual Inc. WM, +1.13% is forecast to report third-quarter earnings of 27 cents a share. Logitech International SA LOGI, +0.30% is expected to report fiscal second-quarter earnings of 27 cents a share. Watch List After Tuesday's closing bell, Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% the world's No. 1 chipmaker, reported a 43% increase in third quarter profit, boosted by strong demand in the computer market. The technology giant posted earnings per share of 31 cents, up more than 40% from the same quarter last year, and higher than the consensus Wall Street estimate of 30 cents. Analysts were expecting revenue of 9.6 billion for the quarter, according to Thomson Financial. It also named Stacy Smith as the company's new CFO and announced that it plans to cut 2,000 jobs in the fourth quarter, reducing its total headcount to about 86,000. See full story. French hotels group Accor S A ACRFF, -0.98% reported third-quarter revenue of 2.1 billion euros, up 7.9% from 1.95 billion euros a year ago. It expects to report 870 million euros to 890 million euros in pre-tax income for the full year. The outlook takes into account expectations for continued strong demand in the fourth quarter, marketing expenditure related to launch of new hotel brands, and the disposals of Go Voyages, Red Roof Inn and the Italian food services business, said Accor. AMB Property Corp. AMB, +0.00% said its third-quarter net income rose to $73.1 million from $33.4 million a year ago. After the payment of preferred stock dividends, the company posted earnings per share for the quarter of 69 cents, up from 33 cents in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $166.3 million from $180.3 million a year ago. Analysts estimated earnings of 53 cents a share, funds from operations of 82 cents, and revenue of $176.9 million. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said it determined it cannot report its recently spun-off institutional pharmacy business as discontinued operations, and provided guidance accordingly. The company said it expects full-year earnings from continuing operations of $2.58 to $2.66 a share, including 8 cents a share from the institutional pharmacy business through the July 31 spin-off date. The range implies fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations of 59 cents to 67 cents a share, including a 1 cent a share contribution from the institutional pharmacy business. Bank of the Ozarks Inc. OZRK, +2.01% raised its quarterly dividend to 12 cents a share. The dividend will be paid Nov. 2 to shareholders of record as of Oct. 26. Bon-Ton Stores Inc. BONT said it doesn't expect to achieve its previously stated full-year fiscal 2007 earnings guidance, based on year-to-date third-quarter results and "continued general softness in the retail environment." In August, the department store chain predicted full-year earnings of $2.75 to $2.90 a share. Analysts expect year earnings of $2.44 a share. The company plans to update guidance Nov. 29. CBS Corp. CBS, -0.94% said it extended the employment agreement for Chief Executive Les Moonves to Sept. 30, 2011. Under the agreement, Moonves gets a salary of $3.5 million a year, compared with $5.9 million in his previous contract, which included $2.9 million in deferred compensation. Moonves will be eligible for an annual performance bonus and equity-based compensation that ties the value of the agreement to the performance of CBS shares. See full story. Champion Enterprises Inc.'s CHB, +0.22% third-quarter net income rose 43% to $12.9 million, or 17 cents a share, from $9.02 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier. The prefabricated-housing company said sales increased 3% to $357.7 million from $346.5 million. Analysts expected earnings of 14 cents a share on revenue of $369 million. Revenue from its manufacturing unit rose 11% to $260.4 million from $293.4 million, while Champion's international unit jumped to $85.3 million from $30.9 million. Retail revenue fell 42% to $18.2 million from $31.4 million. Countrywide Financial Corp. CFC, +5.04% said it will incur a pre-tax restructuring charge of $125 million to $150 million stemming from lower mortgage market origination volumes. Of the total amount of the pre-tax restructuring charge, about $57 million is expected to be recognized in the quarter ending Sept. 30, with the remaining expected to be reflected primarily in the following quarter. Crown Holdings Inc. CCK, +1.20% said its third-quarter net income rose to $92 million, or 56 cents a share, compared with $85 million, or 50 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue grew to $2.15 billion from $2 billion a year ago. Analysts estimated earnings of 58 cents a share on revenue of $2.17 billion. CSX Corp. CSX, +2.58% posted a third-quarter profit of $407 million, or 91 cents a share, up from $328 million, or 71 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding 24 cents a share from discontinued operations, the most recent quarterly profit came in at 67 cents a share. Revenue for the railroad operator rose 3% to $2.5 billion, as improved revenue per unit more than made up for a decline in volume. Analysts had expected a profit of 62 cents a share on sales of $2.49 billion. Standard & Poor's upgraded its outlook on Delta Air Lines Inc.'s DAL, +1.63% credit ratings to positive from stable, citing the carrier's "strong earnings, cash flow generation, and debt reduction." S&P affirmed its B corporate-credit ratings for Delta. "High fuel prices and potentially softening demand as a result of the weak economy may make these targets challenging," S&P said in a statement. Fulton Financial Corp.'s FULT, +0.11% third-quarter net income fell 31% to $33.6 million, or 19 cents a share, from $48.3 million, or 28 cents a share, a year earlier on a $16 million charge related to mortgage banking operations at Resource Bank. The financial holding company's net interest income decreased 2.8% to $122.4 million from $125.9 million a year ago. Fulton increased its provision for loan losses to $4.61 million from $555,000 a year ago. Total assets reached $15.4 billion as of Sept. 30, up from $14.9 billion a year earlier, the company said. IBM Corp. IBM, +0.60% reported a third-quarter profit from continuing operations of $2.36 billion, or $1.68 a share, on $24.12 billion in revenue. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast a profit of $1.67 a share on $24.09 billion in sales. Among its main business areas, IBM said its total services revenue reached $13.67 billion and the company reported new services bookings of $11.8 billion. See full story Linear Technology Corp. LLTC said earnings for its first fiscal quarter slipped more than 4%. For the period ended Sept. 30, the semiconductor manufacturer reported earnings of $91.5 million, or 40 cents a share, compared to earnings of $112.4 million, or 37 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenue fell to $281.5 million from $292.1 million last year. Analysts were expecting earnings of 38 cents a share on revenue of $282 million. Marathon Oil Corp. MRO, +5.29% said shareholders of Western Oil Sands Inc. approved the proposed purchase of the company. The deal is expected to close Thursday, it said. News Corp.'s NWS, +1.90% MySpace and eBay Inc.'s EBAY, +0.32% Skype agreed to put Internet calls into MySpace's instant-messaging feature to attract more users and boost distribution of their two services, The Wall Street Journal reported on its website Tuesday. The companies will share revenue from the partnership but other terms weren't disclosed, said the newspaper. NovaStar Financial Inc. NFI, +0.90% agreed to sell its mortgage servicing rights and advances related to Saxon Mortgage Services Inc. for about $175 million to reduce debt. The residential mortgage portfolio manager expects to significantly reduce its servicing work force of about 300 people following the transaction, which is scheduled to close Nov. 1. The deal doesn't include the NovaStar servicing platform or preclosing liabilities, the company said. Seagate Technology Inc. STX, +2.87% said its fiscal first-quarter net income rose to $355 million, or 64 cents a share, from $19 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $3.29 billion from $2.79 billion a year ago. Analysts estimated earnings of 64 cents a share on revenue of $3.22 billion. Spansion Inc.'s SPSN, +0.65% third-quarter loss widened to $71.6 million, or 53 cents a share, from a year-earlier loss of $22.1 million, or 17 cents a share. The flash-memory chip-maker said sales fell 9.4% to $611.1 million from $674.7 million. Analysts expected a loss of 54 cents a share on revenue of $633 million. Spansion expects fourth-quarter sales of $640 million to $700 million. Gross margin in the fourth quarter is expected to be about flat. Steel Dynamics Inc.'s STLD, +3.56% third-quarter net income fell 15% to $100.6 million, or $1.06 a share, from $118.7 million, or $1.09 a share, a year earlier. Results from the most recent period include about 1 cent a share in purchase accounting adjustments from the company's July acquisition of The Techs. The steel company's revenue rose 27% to $1.16 billion from $911.9 million in the year-ago period. Analysts expected per-share earnings of $1.06 on revenue of $1.04 billion. Steel Dynamics said it expects fourth-quarter per-share earnings of $1.02 to $1.07, excluding any impact from the planned acquisition of OmniSource Corp. Usana Health Sciences Inc.'s USNA, +0.76% third-quarter net income rose 10% to $11.3 million, or 68 cents a share, from $10.2 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier on stock repurchases and a lower than expected effective tax rate. Earnings from continuing operations rose to 70 cents a share from 56 cents. The nutritional, personal care and weight-management product provider's sales increased 15% to $106.2 million from $92 million a year ago. Analysts predicted third-quarter earnings of 66 cents a share and revenue of $106.4 million. Usana Health expects fourth-quarter earnings of 66 cents to 68 cents a share and revenue of $108 million to $110 million. Analysts predicted net income of 68 cents a share and revenue of $112 million. Yahoo Inc. YHOO said its fiscal third-quarter profit fell 5% from the period a year earlier, as the flagging Internet company undertook a broad reorganization under its new CEO. It said net income for the period ended in September fell to $151.3 million, or 11 cents a share, from $158.5 million, or 11 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. Meanwhile total revenue rose to $1.77 billion from $1.58 billion. Analysts expected Yahoo to report earnings of 8 cents a share, and net sales of $1.24 billion. See full story More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks in focus for Wednesday

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch)-- AmerisourceBergen Corp. said late Tuesday it determined it cannot report its recently spun-off institutional pharmacy business as discontinued operations, and provided guidance accordingly. The company said it expects full-year earnings from continuing operations of $2.58 to $2.66 a share, including 8 cents a share from the institutional pharmacy business through the July 31 spin-off date. The range implies fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations of 59 cents to 67 cents a share, including a 1 cent a share contribution from the institutional pharmacy business.
title: AmerisourceBergen gives 2007 guidance incl. discontinued ops

content: Palm swings to a loss in first quarter (4:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Palm Inc. swung to a loss during the first fiscal quarter as sales of its line of smartphones slowed. The wireless device maker PALM, -2.60% reported a net loss of $841,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter ended Aug. 31. For the same period last year, the company said earnings were $16.5 million, or 16 cents a share. On a non-GAAP basis, the company said earnings were $9.7 million, or 9 cents a share, for the recent quarter. Revenue came up slightly to $360.8 million from $355.8 million last year. Analysts were expecting earnings of 8 cents a share on revenue of $360.3 million, according to consensus estimates from Thomson Financial. AmerisourceBergen buys Bellco Health at a lower price (3:43 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Monday that it bought privately held Bellco Health, a distributor of branded and generic drugs, for a revised price of about $190 million in cash. AmerisourceBergen, a pharmaceutical services company based in Valley Forge, Pa., said the original deal price in March was $235 million, but cited a now-resolved regulatory issue and other business matters for the new, lowered price. AmerisourceBergen said it expects the deal to be neutral to 2008 earnings per share and about 5 cents accretive to 2009 earnings per share. The company reiterated its forecast for 2007 earnings from continuing operations, which is for a range of $2.50 to $2.58 per share, including a net benefit of 5 cents from special items. Acxiom: 1Q net loss reduced by 24/c in items (1:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Acxiom Corp. ACXM, -19.04% said Monday that it expects second-quarter revenue and earnings to improve compared with its fiscal first-quarter results. The information-management company said revenue in the first quarter was $338.2 million and income from operations was $4.1 million. Its net loss was $11.5 million for the period, and the per-share loss of 15 cents included $26.5 million, or 24 cents a share, in unusual expenses related to a previously planned acquisition by private-equity firms Silver Lake and ValueAct Capital. Earlier Monday, Acxiom reached an agreement under which it will receive $65 million in cash for the termination of the merger agreement. Thor Industries quarterly profit rises to $50.3 Mln (12:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Thor Industries Inc. THO, +2.47% on Monday reported fiscal fourth-quarter net earnings of $50.3 million, or 90 cents a share, compared with $43.5 million, or 77 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue at the recreational vehicles and commercial buses was $754.9 million, down 6.2% from $805.3 million in the year-ago period. Walgreen profit hurt by lower generic reimbursements (8:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Walgreens WAG on Monday said fiscal fourth-quarter net income fell to $396.5 million, or 40 cents a share, from $412.3 million, or 41 cents a share. Net sales rose to $13.42 billion from $12.17 billion. Analysts, on average, expected the drugstore operator to earn 47 cents a share on revenue of $13.54 billion, according to Thomson Financial. Same-store sales, or sales at drugstores open longer than a year, rose 6.3%, while front-end same-drugstore sales rose 6.1% in the quarter. "This quarter was negatively impacted by lower generic drug reimbursements, combined with higher salary and store expenses, and higher advertising costs," said Chairman Jeffrey Rein. "Our expenses weren't in line with the level of reimbursements we were receiving. Managing both expenses and lower reimbursements on some generic drugs is my top priority. We're going to fix this, and at the same time continue our aggressive growth plan." Walgreens said it expects more than $2 billion in capital investments for fiscal 2008. This reflects expenditures for new stores, technology and a new distribution UnitedHealth announces new Medicare plans for 2008 (7:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- UnitedHealth Group UNH, -2.06% on Monday said it launching several new Medicare plans for 2008, ahead of the open enrollment period, which starts Nov. 15. The health insurer, based in the Minneapolis area, said that the new plans include the only Medicare Advantage plans carrying the AARP name, and new Part D drug plans with zero dollar copays for generic drugs through preferred mail. UnitedHealth said for 2008, its Evercare business is expanding the availability of its special needs plans for people with chronic health conditions from seven to 34 states, as well as introducing the first-ever Evercare Health Plan for people with Alzheimer's disease and related dementia in Maricopa County, Ariz. The company also said the private fee for service plans offered by Secure Horizons will be offered in more than 1,600 counties in the U.S., with competitive benefits and new programs including access to 24 hour Nurseline services as well as the Health Allies discount program in all markets. Citigroup sees 3rd-quarter earnings down 60% (7:16 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Citigroup, C, -1.11% the New York financial-services giant, expects to report that third-quarter earnings will drop about 60% from a year earlier due to "dislocations in the mortgage-backed-securities and credit markets, and deterioration in the consumer-credit environment." The decline "was driven primarily by weak performance in fixed-income credit-market activities, write-downs in leveraged loan commitments, and increases in consumer-credit costs," Chairman and Chief Executive Charles Prince said in a statement. Citi sees a write-down of $1.4 billion pretax, net of underwriting fees, on funded and unfunded highly leveraged finance commitments. And it expects losses of $1.3 billion pretax, net of hedges, on the value of subprime mortgage-backed securities warehoused for certain securitizations; and $600 million pretax in fixed-income credit trading due to significant market volatility and the disruption of historical pricing relationships. Credit Suisse still expects to report third-quarter profit (2:48 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss banking group Credit Suisse CS, +1.27% said Monday that it remained profitable in the third quarter, though its investment banking result has been impacted by recent market turmoil. The bank said there is no indication that its net profit from continuing operations will be outside of a 20% range above or below 1.3 billion Swiss francs. The statement came as rival UBS UBS, +0.40% said it will post a loss of between 600 million francs and 800 million francs mainly due to losses related to the subprime mortgage market. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Monday that it bought privately held Bellco Health, a distributor of branded and generic drugs, for a revised price of about $190 million in cash. AmerisourceBergen, a pharmaceutical services company based in Valley Forge, Pa., said the original deal price in March was $235 million, but cited a now-resolved regulatory issue and other business matters for the new, lowered price. AmerisourceBergen said it expects the deal to be neutral to 2008 earnings per share and about 5 cents accretive to 2009 earnings per share. The company reiterated its forecast for 2007 earnings from continuing operations, which is for a range of $2.50 to $2.58 per share, including a net benefit of 5 cents from special items.
title: AmerisourceBergen buys Bellco Health at a lower price

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading in Friday's session are Procter & Gamble Co., Weyerhaeuser Co., and Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. Brookfield Asset Management Inc. BAM, +0.59% is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 26 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson Financial. EOG Resources Inc. EOG, +1.40% is expected to post earnings of $1.04 a share for the second quarter. Hercules Offshore Inc. HERO, +0.00% is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 67 cents a share. KeySpan Corp. 519421, -4.01% is expected to post earnings of MetroPCS Communications Inc. PCS is expected to report second-quarter earnings of 13 cents a share. NovaStar Financial Inc. NFI, +0.90% is expected to post a loss of $2.28 a share for the second quarter. Procter & Gamble PG, +0.56% is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 66 cents a share. Tim Hortons Inc. THI is expected to post earnings of 34 cents a share for the second quarter. Washington Post Co. WPO is expected to report second-quarter earnings of $8.33 a share. Weyerhaeuser WY, -0.06% is expected to post earnings of 39 cents a share for the second quarter. After Thursday's closing bell, Network Appliance Inc. NTAP, +3.73% gave a preliminary first-quarter earnings report, and said its results would come in lower than expected due to weak sales in the U.S. and Europe. See full story. Countrywide Financial Corp. CFC, +5.04% the largest U.S. mortgage lender, tried to soothe liquidity concerns as one of its smaller rivals teeters on the brink of bankruptcy. See full story. Take-Two Interactive Software TTWO, +0.33% said it would delay the release of its highly anticipated "Grand Theft Auto IV" video game by as much as six months, and also lowered its forecasts through the end of its fiscal year. See full story. Watch list Activision Inc. ATVI, +2.26% swung to a profit in its first fiscal quarter thanks to surging sales of its video-game titles, which include the popular "Guitar Hero" franchise. See full story. Biotechnology company Alkermes Inc. ALKS, -2.14% said it swung to a profit in its fiscal first-quarter, as sales rose 34%. Cambridge, Mass.-based Alkermes said net income for the period ended June 30 rose to $8.75 million, or 8 cents a share, from a loss of $715 thousand, or 1 cent a share in the period a year earlier. Meanwhile revenue rose to $68.94 million from $51.54 million. Garbage hauler Allied Waste AW posted a second-quarter profit from continuing operations of $91.7 million, or 21 cents a share, up from $36.5 million, or 7 cents a share, a year ago. The most recent quarter included a 2-cent per-share tax related gain. Sales rose 2.3% to $1.56 billion, up from $1.52 billion last year thanks to higher prices. American Home Mortgage Investment Corp. AHM which has already stopped making new loans because of a funding crisis, told its employees that it will shut down Friday, Newsday reported on its Web site. Company founder Michael Strauss said in an email to employees that the Melville, N.Y., lender "has been forced to close," the newspaper said. Calls to company spokeswoman Mary Feder weren't returned. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% entered an accelerated repurchase agreement with Bank of America to buy back 5.45 million shares of its common stock for $250 million in cash, or $45.91 a share. Audible Inc.'s ADBL second-quarter net loss narrowed to $125,000, or 1 cent a share, from $2.18 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier, boosted by new, higher-revenue members. The Wayne, N.J., Internet-delivered spoken audio content provider's revenue increased 36% to $25.9 million from $19.1 million in the year-ago period. Boston Scientific Corp.'s BSX, +2.40% Endosurgery unit will remain part of the company, instead of being spun off in a public offering. The Natick, Mass., medical products company said it expects the unit to generate $1.4 billion in revenue this year, compared with the company's 2006 revenue of $7.82 billion. The company said it will have more to say about the divestiture and head count reduction plans next quarter. Bristow Group Inc.'s BRS, -0.15% fiscal first-quarter net income rose 32% to $22.7 million, or 75 cents a share, from $17.2 million, or 73 cents a share, a year earlier, on strong interest income and boosts from unconsolidated affiliates. The Houston oilfield helicopter transport company's revenue for the quarter ended June 30 increased 11% to $245 million from $221.1 million. Cabela's Inc. CAB, -2.17% reported second-quarter net earnings of $11.3 million, or 17 cents a share, up 35% from $8.36 million, or 13 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Sidney, Neb.-based sporting goods retailer said revenue rose to $451.2 million from $387.3 million. CBL & Associated Properties Inc.'s CBL, -5.23% second-quarter net income fell 21% to $22.7 million, or 17 cents a share, from $28.6 million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier, due to higher interest and depreciation expenses. Results from the latest quarter were reduced by $2 million for the write-off of costs from the redemption of preferred shares, and $534,000 for an income-tax provision. The year-earlier results included a gain of 13 cents a share from discontinued operations. The Chattanooga, Tenn., real estate investment trust said revenue increased 4.7% to $246.5 million from $235.3 million. Chemtura Corp. CEM, +1.12% swung to a second-quarter loss of $2 million, or 1 cent a share, from a year-earlier net income of $1 million, or less than 1 cent a share, a year earlier, as costs rose 11%. The company recorded adjusted per-share earnings of 18 cents. The Middlebury, Conn., specialty chemical company's revenue grew 9.1% to $1.06 billion from $971 million. Costs grew to $793 million from $713 million in the year-ago period. Chesapeake Energy Corp. CHK, +1.00% said net income in the second quarter rose to $518.1 million, or $1.01 a share, from $359.9 million, or 82 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. The Oklahoma City-based oil and gas producer said revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose 33% to $2.1 billion. Excluding special items, the company earned 71 cents in the most recent quarter. Chiquita Brands International Inc.'s CQB, +31.42% second-quarter net income fell 62% to $8.6 million, or 20 cents a share, from $22.9 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier, as expenses rose 3.2%. The latest quarter included a charge of $3 million, or 7 cents a share, related to the settlement of U.S. antitrust litigation. The Cincinnati produce company's net sales rose 2.2% to $1.26 billion from $1.23 billion in the year-ago period. Expenses grew to $1.22 billion from $1.18 billion. Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group Inc. DTG, +0.85% said it plans to eliminate about 25% of the management positions at its headquarters in Tulsa, Okla., as well as other support staff. The personnel changes are effective immediately, the company said. EOG Resources Inc.'s EOG, +1.40% second-quarter net income fell 7.4% to $307.1 million, or $1.24 a share, from $331.4 million, or $1.34 a share, a year earlier, hurt by a 31% increase in operating expenses. The Houston energy company's revenue rose 15% to $1.06 billion from $919.1 million a year earlier. GSI Technology Inc.'s GSIT, -3.01% first-quarter net income fell 50% to $1.05 million, or 4 cents a share, from $2.11 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier, as revenue dropped 19%. The Santa Clara, Calif., company's revenue declined to $11.3 million from $14 million in the year-ago period. Healthtronics Inc.'s HTRN second-quarter net income fell 87% to $179,000, or 1 cent a share, from $1.37 million, or 4 cents a share, a year earlier, as revenue fell 2.5%. The Austin, Texas, urology products company's revenue dropped to $35.6 million from $36.5 million in the year-ago period. InterMune Inc.'s ITMN second-quarter loss narrowed to $19.8 million, or 58 cents a share, from $44 million, or $1.33 a share, a year earlier, on a $10 million development milestone payment. The year-ago loss included a $30 million provision related to a settlement with the government, the Brisbane, Calif., biotechnology company said. Revenue increased 5.1% to $25.4 million from $24.1 million a year ago. Kosan Biosciences Inc.'s KOSN second-quarter loss widened to $10.8 million, or 25 cents a share, from $6.79 million, or 20 cents a share, a year earlier. The Haywood, Calif., biotechnology company said revenue fell 17% to $2.21 million from $2.67 million a year ago. Long Drug Stores Corp. LDG, -22.86% July same-store drug store sales rose 1.7% from a year ago. The Walnut Creek, Calif., drug-store chain put sales from continuing operations for the four weeks ended July 26 at $359 million, up 2.9% from $349 million a year earlier. Second-quarter comparable sales increased 1%, while total sales increased 2.9% to $1.2 billion, the company said. Maxim Integrated Products Inc. MXIM, +2.15% reported its fiscal fourth quarter sales grew 4% to $531.1 million from $510.6 million a year ago. The chipmaker didn't report a per-share figure due to a pending review of its stock-option accounting. Maxim also said it's increased its quarterly dividend by 20%. A cash dividend for the fourth quarter of $0.1875 per share will be paid on September 7 to stockholders of record on August 23. Based in Sunnyvale, Calif., Maxim makes so-called analog chips used in diverse markets, such as automotive, computing, portable consumer electronics and telecommunications infrastructure. Molina Health Care Inc. MOH, +2.64% said its second-quarter profit rose slightly, while sales rose 27%. Long Beach, Calif.-based Molina said net income for the period ended June 30 rose to $13.31 million, or 47 cents a share, compared to $13.15 million, or 47 cents a share in the period a year earlier. Meanwhile revenue rose to $613.89 million, from $484.63 million. Multi-Fineline Electronix Inc. MFLX swung to a fiscal third-quarter loss of $6.71 million, or 27 cents a share, from a profit of $8.29 million, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier, on a substantial sales decline to its largest customer. The loss also includes a $4.8 million charge related to Multi-Fineline's conditional offer to acquire MFS Technology Ltd. The Anaheim, Calif., flexible circuit boards maker's sales for the quarter ended June 30 fell 20% to $104.1 million from $130.3 million a year ago. National Fuel Gas Co.'s NFG, +0.41% second-quarter net income grew to $46.8 million, or 55 cents a share, from a year-earlier profit of $111,000, or less than 1 cent a share. Excluding reversal of a reserve, income was $42 million, or 49 cents a share. The Williamsville, N.Y., energy company's operating revenue increased to $463.1 million, from $415.5 million a year earlier. Newpark Resources Inc.'s NR, +0.62% second-quarter net income declined 11% to $5.3 million, or 6 cents a share, from a year-earlier profit of $5.93 million, or 7 cents a share. Net income from continuing operations grew to $8.24 million, or 9 cents a share, from $6.86 million, or 8 cents a share a year earlier. The Metairie, La., oil-field machinery company's revenue grew nearly 4% to $167.1 million, from $160.7 million a year earlier. Odyssey Re Holdings Corp. ORH, -50.00% said its second-quarter profit fell compared to the period a year earlier. Stamford, Conn.-based Odyssey Re said net income for the period ended June 30 fell to $145.5 million, or $2.02 a share, compared to $207.6 million, or $2.87 a share in the period a year earlier. Meanwhile revenue fell to $1.39 billion from $1.62 billion. Openwave Systems Inc. OPWV named new senior managers as the software company reported a wider fiscal-fourth-quarter loss. Openwave posted a net loss of $91.8 million, or $1.11 a share, compared with a net loss of $5.1 million, or 6 cents a share, in last year's same period. The wider loss was partly due to discontinued operations and other special items. For the three months ended June 30, Openwave reported revenue of $68.1 million, down from $83.5 million a year ago. On the executive front, Dr. Jean-Yves Dexmier was named chief financial officer, replacing Harold Covert, who has decided to leave for personal reasons. John Boden, a former Nortel executive, was named senior vice president of product management. Michael Wallis-Brown, a former Nokia executive, was tapped to be general manager for the Asia-Pacific region. Playtex Products Inc.'s PYX, -5.19% second-quarter net income rose 50% to $15.6 million, or 24 cents a share, from $10.3 million, or 16 cents a share, a year earlier, as revenue rose 31%. Excluding items, Playtex earned 26 cents a share. The Westport, Conn., company's revenue grew to $235.7 million form $180.3 million in the year-ago period. On average, analysts expected per-share earnings 20 cents on revenue of $223.9 million, according to a poll by Thomson Financial. The company said it is "on target" to meet its full-year guidance. Walter Industries Inc.'s WLT, -0.15% second-quarter net income dropped 72% to $18.1 million, or 34 cents a share, from $64 million, or $1.24 a share, a year earlier, due in part to increased production costs and lower sales prices in certain units. The Tampa-based coal, natural gas and homebuilding company's income from continuing operations fell to $17.8 million, or 33 cents a share, from $44.2 million, or 86 cents a share, a year earlier. The company's revenue fell 7% to $296.5 million from $319 million in the year-ago period, due to lower metallurgical coal sales prices and volumes at Natural Resources and higher demurrage charges. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh 2 sexy ways to get paid to save What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks in focus for Friday
