content: Universal Health Services quarterly profit falls 14% (6:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Universal Health Services Inc. UHS, -2.45% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $52.1 million, or 97 cents a share, down 14% from $60.3 million, or $1.04 a share, during the year-ago period. Adjusted income from continuing operations was $42.6 million, or 79 cents a share, compared with $44.5 million, or 78 cents a share, last year. The King of Prussia, Pa-based hospital company said revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose to $1.18 billion from $1.05 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 83 cents on revenue of $1.2 billion. Curtiss-Wright's quarterly profit rises slightly (6:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Curtiss-Wright Corp. CW, +2.69% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $21.4 million, or 48 cents a share, up from $21.1 million, or 48 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Roseland, N.J.-based maker of flow control and motion control products said revenue in the three months ended June 30 rose 18% to $365.6 million from $309.6 million in the same period last year. Analysts poled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 48 cents on revenue of $339 million. Curtiss-Wright now expects 2007 earnings of $2.10 to $2.20 a share on revenue of $1.5 billion to $1.52 billion. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of $2.16 on revenue of $1.43 billion. Frontier Airlines swings to quarterly loss as revenue rises (6:12 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Frontier Airlines Holdings Inc. FRNT, +0.00% late Thursday reported it swung to a first-quarter net loss of $3.48 million, or 10 cents a share, from net earnings of $3.96 million, or 10 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The current results include a non-cash mark to market derivative loss which increased fuel expense by $3.7 million, $2.2 million of start-up costs for Lynx Aviation, and $1.4 million in accelerated depreciation for the company's seat replacement project. The items increased Frontier's net loss by 20 cents a share, the company said. The Denver-based carrier said revenue of the three months ended June 30 rose to $344.8 million from $304.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 4 cents. The airline said its unrestricted cash position as of June 30 was $215.4 million compared with $276.5 million last year. For the second quarter, Frontier said it expects per-share earnings, excluding special items, of 5 cents to 10 cents. FalconStor Software swings to second-quarter profit (6:04 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- FalconStor Software Inc. FALC, +0.00% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $1.38 million, or 3 cents a share, versus a year ago-net loss of $1.3 million, or 3 cents a share. Pro forma net income, which excludes stock-based compensation expense, was 6 cents a share versus 2 cents a share last year. Revenue for the quarter ended June 30 rose 40% to $17.8 million from $12.7 million for the same period a year ago, the Melville, N.Y.-based provider of disk-based data protection products said. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 5 cents on revenue of $17 million. Meritage Homes swings to quarterly loss; sees difficult 2007 (5:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Meritage Homes Corp. MTH, +1.57% late Thursday reported it swung to a second-quarter net loss of $56.6 million, or $2.16 a share, from net earnings of $77.1 million, or $2.82 a share, during the year-ago period. Excluding certain charges, adjusted earnings were $13 million, compared with $82 million last year. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based home builder said revenue for the three months ended June 30 fell to $568.7 million from $914.7 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share loss of $1.59 on revenue of $584 million. Meritage reported net orders for 1,734 homes, down 18% from 2,116 a year ago. The company said it closed 1,858 homes in the quarter, down 32% from 2,722 last year. Meritage said its results reflect deterioration in market conditions, with reduced market valuation of properties in California, Florida, Nevada and Arizona. In a statement, Meritage Chairman and Chief Executive Steven Hilton said, "We expect the remainder of 2007 will be difficult, but take confidence in our sound strategy, strong organization, proven record of success, and solid franchise that includes some of the historically best homebuilding markets in the country." Celestica swings to a profit as revenue falls 13% (5:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Celestica Inc. CLS, +0.68% (CA:CLS)late Thursday said it swung to a second-quarter net profit of $24.9 million, or 11 cents a share, from a year-ago net loss of $30.3 million, or 13 cents a share. Adjusted earnings for the quarter were $4.9 million, or 2 cents a share, versus $29.1 million, or 13 cents a share, for the same period last year. The Toronto-based provider of electronics manufacturing services said revenue in the period ended June 30 fell 13% to $1.94 billion from $2.22 billion in the second quarter of 2006. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 6 cents on revenue of $2.05 billion. Celestica expects third-quarter adjusted earnings of 4 cents to 12 cents a share on revenue of $2 billion to $2.2 billion. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of 10 cents on revenue of $2.15 billion. Eastman Chemical profit slips 8%, sees slightly better 3Q (5:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Eastman Chemical Co. EMN, +1.34% said late Thursday net income in the second quarter fell to $105 million, or $1.22 a share, from $114 million, or $1.37 a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Excluding $16 million in depreciation costs and asset impairment charges, the chemical maker said profits would have totaled $1.34 a share. Sales fell 1.8% to $1.9 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of $1.31 a share on sales of $1.89 billion. The Kingsport, Tenn. company forecast solid third quarter results in all segments except its business selling specialty polymers to overseas customers, and "continued high and volatile raw material and energy costs." It forecast third-quarter earnings per share excluding special items to be "slightly above" third-quarter earnings of $1.24. Analysts forecast $1.17 a share. Shares fell 3.3% in normal trading. Riverbed Technology swings to a profit as revenue jumps (5:33 PM ET) SAN SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Riverbed Technology Inc. RVBD said late Thursday it swung to a second-quarter net profit of $3.95 million, or 5 cents a share, from a year-ago net loss of $6.1 million, or 46 cents a share. Excluding the impact of stock-based compensation and related payroll taxes, Riverbed posted income of 16 cents a share versus a loss of 9 cents a share last year. The San Francisco-based company, which provides products for wide-area distributed computing, said revenue in the three months ended June 30 rose to $54 million from $18 million in the year-ago quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 13 cents on revenue of $50 million. Roper Industries quarterly profit rises 27%; boosts outlook (5:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Roper Industries Inc. ROP, +1.52% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $61.2 million, or 66 cents a share, up 27% from $48.1 million, or 53 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Sarasota, Fla.-based diversified industrial manufacturer said revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose to $530.6 million from $425.3 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 65 cents on revenue of $513 million. Additionally, Roper said it now expects full-year 2007 per-share earnings of $2.60 to $2.66, up from its previous outlook of $2.54 to $2.64. The company also said it now sees 2007 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $520+ million, up from its prior view of $510+ million. For the third quarter, Roper said it expects earnings of 67 cents to 69 cents a share. Celanese swings to a loss on charges; revenue rises 7% (5:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Celanese Corp. CE, +0.47% late Thursday said it swung to a second-quarter net loss of $117 million, or 76 cents a sharem form a year-ago net profit of $103 million, or 60 cents a share. Excluding pre-tax expenses of $265 million primarily related to debt refinancing, $74 million associated with a long-term management compensation program, and $32 million of other adjustments, the company posted a per-share profit of 84 cents. The Dallas-based chemical; company said revenue in the three months ended June 30 rose 7% to $1.56 billion from $1.46 billion in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 83 cents on revenue of $1.56 billion. Celanese said that, due to uncertainty regarding the timeline of repair and expected restart date of its Clear Lake acetic acid unit, it's unable to provide short-term financial guidance. Lithia Motors quarterly profit falls 33% (5:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Lithia Motors Inc. LAD, +1.41% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $7.94 million, or 38 cents a share, down 33% from $11.9 million, or 56 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Income from continuing operations was $10.7 million, or 50 cents a share, compared with $12.1 million, or 57 cents a share, last year. The Medford, Ore.-based operator of automotive franchises said revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose to $885.1 million from $801.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 54 cents on revenue of $887 million. Additionally, Lithia Motors said it expects full-year 2007 earnings from continuing operations of $1.60 to $1.80 a share, assuming a steady pace of acquisitions and dispositions. Aspen Insurance's quarterly profit rises 13% (5:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Aspen Insurance Holdings AHL, -0.33% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $114.7 million, or $1.19 a share, up 13% from net earnings of $101.8 million, or $1.01 a share, during the year-ago period. Operating income came in at $1.14 a share versus 98 cents a share last year. The Bermuda-based insurer said net written premiums in the three months ended June 30 fell to $418.5 from $500.1 million in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of $1.11. The combined ratio for the second quarter of was 88.4% versus 81.6% for the same quarter in 2006. Mettler Toledo's quarterly profit rises 18% (5:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Mettler Toledo International MTD, +0.55% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $41 million, or $1.07 a share, up 18% from $34.8 million, or 84 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding amortization of purchased intangibles, the company earned $1.09 a share versus 86 cents a share last year. The Columbus, Ohio-based instrument supply company said revenue in the three months ended June 30 rose to $430.5 million from $389.2 million in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of $1.03 on revenue of $420 million. Mettler-Toledo raised its 2007 earnings forecast to a range of $4.28 to $4.33 a share, and raised its adjusted earnings forecast to $4.35 to $4.40 a share. For the third quarter, the company expects earnings of $1.02 to $1.05 a share, and adjusted earnings of $1.04 to $1.07 a share. Analysts are expecting a third-quarter profit of $1.05 a share and a 2007 profit of $4.29 a share. Allegheny Energy almost doubles profit on higher prices (5:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Allegheny Energy AYE on Thursday posted a second-quarter profit of $77 million, or 45 cents a share, up from $31.1 million, or 18 cents a share, a year ago, due to higher prices and cost cutting. Operating revenue rose to $826.5 million from $722.2 million a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected the Greensburg, Penn.-based electric utility to post a profit of 30 cents a share on sales of $760 million. IDT quarterly loss narrows as revenue rises (4:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Integrated Device Technology Inc. IDTI, +2.96% late Thursday reported a first-quarter net loss of $1.1 million, or a penny a share, compared with a net loss of $1.56 million, or a penny a share, during the year-ago period. On a pro forma basis, earnings were $44.1 million, or 22 cents a share, vs. $50.6 million or 25 cents a share, last year. There were 193.3 million shares outstanding during the quarter vs. 198.7 million a year ago. The San Jose, Calif.-based semiconductor company said revenue rose to $199 million from $185.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 20 cents on revenue of $198 million. Cohu's quarterly profit falls 57% (4:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cohu Inc. COHU, +1.47% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $2.02 million, or 9 cents a share, down 57% from $4.72 million, or 21 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Net income for the second quarter of 2006 benefited from a $3 million gain on the sale of the company's Littleton facility, Cohu said. The Poway, Calif.-based maker of semiconductor test handling equipment said revenue for the three months ended rose to $66.4 from $61.9 million in the comparable period last year. BlackRock strategist sees further U.S. market decline (4:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stocks are more than halfway through a selloff, but investors should expect further softness and volatility over the next several weeks as the market tries to find a bottom, said Bob Doll, global chief investment officer of equities at BlackRock Inc. BLK, +2.59% "The amount of decline is more than half over," Doll said in a telephone interview. "I don't think it's going to spread to more than 10%." Doll reiterated an earlier prediction that the S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38% will end the year around 1550, about 4.5% higher than its Thursday close at 1482.66. QLogic's quarterly profit falls 9.9% (4:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- QLogic Corp. QLGC, +0.12% late Thursday reported first-quarter net earnings of $19 million, or 12 cents a share, down 9.9% from $21.1 million, or 13 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, the company earned 20 cents a share versus 21 cents a share last year. The Aliso Viejo, Calif.-based maker of storage network infrastructure components said revenue for the three months ended July 1 rose 2% to $139.8 million from $136.7 million in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 20 cents on revenue of $143 million. Genesis Microchip swings to quarterly loss, revenue falls (4:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Genesis Microchip Inc. GNSS late Thursday reported it swung to a first-quarter net loss of $10.7 million, or 29 cents a share, from net earnings of $1.44 million, or 4 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The pro forma loss was $6.7 million, or 18 cents a share. The Santa Clara, Calif.-based maker of microchips used in flat-panel television and monitors said revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose to $44 million from $55.9 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share loss of 21 cents on revenue of $42 million. Gross margins for the quarter were 38.5%, the company said. Additionally, Genesis Microchip said it expects second-quarter gross margins of 36% to 38% and revenue of $50 million to $55 million. Genworth quarterly net up 22%; housing may trim 2007 results (4:33 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Genworth Financial Inc. GNW, +1.07% said second-quarter net income came in at $387 million, or 86 cents a share, up 22% from a year earlier when the insurer made $317 million, or 68 cents a share. Income from continuing operations was $321 million, or 72 cents a share, the company added. "We are affirming our outlook for full-year operating earnings per diluted share of $3.15 to $3.25; however, given the dynamics in the U.S. housing market, we feel a conservative stance is appropriate which could take full-year 2007 results to the lower end of the range," Michael Fraizer, chief executive of Genworth, said in a statement. KLA-Tencor profit up 11% on higher chip-equipment sales (4:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- KLA-Tencor Corp. KLAC, +2.29% late Thursday said its fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 11% on higher sales of its equipment to make computer chips. KLA-Tencor reported net income of $147 million, or 75 cents a share, up from $132 million, or 65 cents a share, a year ago. For the three months ended June 30, the company posted sales of $736 million, up from $579 million a year ago. San Jose, Calif.-based KLA-Tencor is one of the nation's biggest chip-equipment suppliers. Compuware's quarterly profit tumbles (4:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Compuware Corp. CPWR, -11.67% late Thursday reported fiscal first-quarter net earnings of $189,000, or breakeven a share, down from $29.3 million, or 8 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Detroit-based software company said revenue in the three months ended June fell to $279.4 million from $296.3 million in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, breakeven earnings of a per-share basis and revenue of $282 million. "Based on a detailed analysis, the company has confirmed that it has a serious sales execution problem," said Chairman and Chief Executive Peter Karmanos in a statement. "In response, we have worked very hard to develop a new sales model that will cost less and will be more agile in responding to the needs of the marketplace and in fixing the company's problem." Embarq quarterly profit falls; boosts 2007 outlook (4:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Embarq Corp. EQ, +0.00% late Thursday reported second-quarter net earnings of $176 million, or $1.15 a share, down from $216 million, or $1.44 a share, during the year-ago period. The Overland Park, Kan.-based local phone company said revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose to $1.61 billion from $1.58 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of $1.12 on revenue of $1.59 billion. Additionally, Embarq said it has raised its 2007 outlook, and now expects operating income of $1.51 billion to $1.56 billion, telecommunications segment revenues of $5.87 billion to $5.92 billion, and capital expenditures of about $865 million. The company also said it now expects access lines to decline at a low to mid 6% rate for the year. Revenue climbed to $24.5 billion from $23.3 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been for the company to earn 71 cents a share on revenue of $24.85 billion. McKesson MCK, +0.15% also said that it still expects to earn between $3.15 and $3.30 a share on the full fiscal year. (Corrects diluted EPS figures.) McAfee posts double-digit profit, sales growth (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - McAfee Inc. said Thursday its second-quarter profit and sales exceeded expectations, though it cautioned the results are preliminary pending a future restatement due to past stock-option grants. Santa Clara, Calif.-based McAfee MFE, +0.60% a maker of security software, said net income for the period ended in June rose 57% to $49.4 million, or 30 cents a share, compared to $31.4 million, or 19 cents a share in the period a year earlier. Meanwhile revenue grew 13% to $314.3 million. Excluding certain items, McAfee said earnings were 41 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of 37 cents a share, on revenue of $306 million. McAfee said the results are only preliminary, as it will need to restate past results to record charges related to past granting of stock-based compensation. "McAfee believes this restatement is likely to result in aggregate non-cash charges in the range of $100 million to $150 million," the company said in a statement, adding that it intends to make the restatement "as soon as practicable." "For the second half, we anticipate that consumer confidence in Continental Europe will remain solid, but uncertain in the U.K.," said CEO Jean-Noel Labroue in a statement. Publicis says sales growth hit by U.S. (2:58 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Publicis Groupe PUB, -1.52% (FR:012057)Thursday said organic revenue growth in its second quarter had been hit by slower economic performance in the U.S., unfavorable comparisons and problems relating to its healthcare marketing businesses. The Paris-based advertising and marketing group, which owns the Saatchi & Saatchi advertising agency, media planner Zenith Optimedia and digital agency Digitas, said organic revenue growth for the first half of 2007 was 1.6%, compared with 6.8% in the year earlier period and below analyst expectations around 3%. The company said it expected to achieve organic revenue growth of between 4% and 5% for the full year. Net profit rose 1% to 198 million euros, on sales up 6% to 2.2 billion euros in the second quarter. Japan Sony's first-quarter net profit more than doubles (2:57 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Japanese electronics giant Sony Corp. SNE, +0.54% (JP:6758)Thursday said its net profit more than doubled in the fiscal first-quarter because of a weaker yen against the U.S. dollar and the euro, although operating losses widened at its gaming division. Net profit for the April-June period jumped to 66.5 billion yen ($540 million), or 32.25 yen a share, from 32.3 billion yen. Sales rose 13.3% to 1.98 trillion yen. Sony left its May forecast of net profit and sales unchanged despite the positive impact on its profitability from the weaker yen, as it's "more cautious about the business environment for the remainder of the fiscal year for the electronics and game segments compared to our May forecast". Sony's shares closed 1.1% higher in Tokyo, before the results were announced. Thomson narrows loss during first half (2:54 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Thomson TMS, -25.00% (FR:018453), the French electronics firm, said it narrowed its first-half loss to 20 million euros from 71 million euros, with revenue virtually flat at 2.65 billion euros. Restructuring charges from its DVD services unit and "disappointing" results from its arm that sells equipment to broadcast and networks, was offset in part by the DVD services arm, film services, network services and licensing. It also said it's examining offers for the European AVA operations and the US AV operations. Bradford & Bingley lending hits record high (2:50 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. mortgage provider Bradford & Bingley(UK:BB)said Thursday that its first-half net profit more than doubled to 129 million pounds from 54.8 million pounds. Excluding charges in the year-ago period, underlying profit rose 10% to 129 million pounds, with gross new residential lending rising 51% to a record of 7.2 billion pounds. The lender said it's planning to buy back 250 million pounds worth of shares. "The fundamentals of the housing and mortgage markets remain strong. However, the five increases in interest rates since August last year are now showing signs of slowing the rate of growth in the residential mortgage markets," Bradford & Bingley said. Lufthansa quarterly profit more than doubles (2:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German flag carrier Deutsche Lufthansa AG(DE:823212)said second quarter net profit more than doubled on strong passenger numbers, after it raised its guidance for 2007 on strong first-half figures. Net profit for the three months to June 30 totaled 438 million euros, up from 183 million euros. The figure beat analysts' forecasts of 291 million euros. Late Wednesday, the airline raised its full year guidance after reporting a sharp jump in first-half net profit to 992 million euros. ABB profit nearly doubles on power infrastructure demand (2:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss-Swedish engineering firm ABB Ltd. ABB, +0.76% said second-quarter net income nearly doubled to a stronger-than-forecast $729 million from $367 million, with revenue up 27% to $7.14 billion and orders up 26% to $8.67 billion. The company said it's continuing to benefit from increased global investments in energy efficiency as well as power and industrial infrastructure. It also said it's told the U.S. Department of Justice and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission about suspect payments made by employees of company subsidiaries in Asia, South America and Europe, in particular Italy, that may have broken bribery laws. Hyundai Motor Co reports 2Q net profit up 52% (2:44 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- South Korea's leading car maker, Hyundai Motor Co., reported Thursday net profit for the second quarter climbed 52% from a year earlier, bolstered by strong domestic sales and cost cutting. Hyundai, ranked sixth worldwide in terms of sales, reported net profit for the three-month period ending June 30 of 611.5 billion won ($666.15 million), up from 403.1 billion won a year earlier. Analysts had expected net profit of 520.3 billion won, according to consensus estimates compiled by Dow Jones Newswires. The car and truck maker reported quarterly sales climbed 15% to 8.027 trillion won, up from 7.003 trillion won a year earlier. DSM ups earnings outlook for the year, reports 70% net fall (2:42 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Holland's DSM(NL:00982)lifted its earnings outlook after reporting a 70% decline in second-quarter profit to 47 million euros, with sales up 3% to 2.2 billion euros. Excluding a 110 million euro impairment of the book value of its anti-infectives arm, and profit at the maker of nutritional and pharma ingredients and chemicals would've climbed 4% to 158 million euros, on volume increases from its nutrition business and a "sudden and strong" increase in penicillin prices. DSM now expects its annual operating profit to be within 3% of 790 million euros, vs. an earlier target of being within 5% of 760 million euros. Liberty International profit jumps on higher rent, lower tax (2:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. property group Liberty International Plc(UK:LII)said Thursday that its first-half net profit rose 42% to 500 million pounds. Net rental income for the period grew 7% to 174 million pounds. The rise in profit also reflects a low tax charge, said Liberty, which specializes in retail property. The group proposed a 20% increase in the interim dividend to 16.5 pence a share. "In our opinion, prime regional shopping centres continue to be a very attractive sector of the U.K. property market on a long-term view and are currently valued on an extremely defensive basis when compared with other sectors," Liberty said. Rolls Royce profit falls as raw materials costs rise (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. aerospace company Rolls Royce Group(UK:RR)said Thursday that its first-half profit fell 51% to 303 million pounds ($625 million), while revenue rose 5.9% to 3.59 billion pounds. Underlying profit before tax rose 17% to 380 million pounds, the company said. "Despite the challenges of increasing raw material costs and the effects of a weakening dollar, the group is well placed to deliver growth in underlying profit and, before pension scheme injections, a positive cash flow in 2007," Rolls Royce said. The group's order book grew by 9 billion pounds to 35.1 billion pounds, driven by international growth. BT profit up 31% after tax gain, broadband growth (2:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. telecoms company BT Group(UK:BT.A)said Thursday that its fiscal first-quarter net profit rose 31% to 607 million pounds from 464 million pounds as revenue grew 3.5% to 5.03 billion pounds. The group said its profit included a net gain of 119 million pounds, mainly due to a tax credit. Pretax profit before exceptional items rose 3% to 658 million pounds. New wave revenue, which is from networked IT services and broadband operations, rose 11% to 1.82 billion pounds. Broadband connections stood at 11.2 million, up 2.5 million from a year earlier. Kingfisher like-for-like sales up 2.6%, weather hits U.K. (2:09 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. home improvement retailer Kingfisher(UK:KGF)said Thursday that total sales in the 10 weeks to July 14 rose 7.2%, with like-for-like sales in the period rising 2.6%. International like-for-like sales rose 6% in the period. U.K. sales, however, were hit by the recent bad weather, falling 1.5% on a like-for-like basis, with the sale of outdoor products particularly badly affected. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Shares of AmerisourceBergen Corp. slipped Thursday after the drug distributor said third-quarter profit increased 9%, slightly off analysts' average earnings forecast. The Valley Forge, Pa.-based company ABC, +1.29% reported net income of $129.9 million, or 69 cents a share, for the three months ended June 30, compared with $119.5 million, or 58 cents, eanred in the third quarter of fiscal 2006. Quarterly revenue was up 7% to $15.4 billion from the prior year's $14.4 billion. The company's net earnings included a one-time gain of 9 cents a share from special items, leaving AmerisourceBergen with earnings of 60 cents a share. Analysts, on average, had been expecting a per-share profit of 61 cents on revenue of $16.81 billion, according estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. That sent AmerisourceBergen's shares down as much as 4% in morning action. AmerisourceBergen and nursing-home operator Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% are in the process of spinning off their respective institutional pharmacy businesses into a new entity called PharMerica Corp., shares of which will trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker "PMC." The PharMerica spin-off is expected to take place on July 31, AmerisourceBergen said. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh
title: AmerisourceBergen shares lower in wake of quarterly results

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% on Thursday said fiscal third-quarter net income rose to $129.9 million, or 69 cents a share, from $119.5 million, or 58 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Results in the most recent quarter included a net benefit of 9 cents a share from special items. Revenue rose to $16.45 billion from $15.69 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 61 cents a share on revenue of $16.81 billion, according to Thomson Financial. The pharmaceutical services company expects earnings for the fiscal year in a range of $2.60 to $2.68 a share, from the previous range of $2.50 to $2.65 a share. The new range includes a net benefit of 5 cents a share in special items, including an expected 1 cent charge in the September quarter, and continues to reflect expected earnings of 9 cents to 11 cent from the PharMerica institutional pharmacy business for the entire fiscal year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expect it to earn $2.56 a share for the fiscal year, on average. AmerisourceBergen expects to spin off the PharMerica institutional pharmacy business on a tax-free basis on July 31.
title: AmerisourceBergen profit and revenue rise

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Standard & Poor's said it will add Kyphon Inc. KYPH to the S&P MidCap 400 index Wednesday, replacing Triad Hospitals Inc. TRI, +0.31% Triad is being acquired by Community Health Systems Inc. CYH, -3.65% in a deal expected to close by Wednesday. The S&P SmallCap 600 Index will add MedCath Corp. MDTH to the index Wednesday, replacing Digene Corp. DIGE which is being acquired by Qiagen N.V. The SmallCap 600 will also add PharMerica Corp. PMC, +9.64% to the index July 31, replacing Pope & Talbot Inc. POP Amerisourcebergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% is spinning off its Pharmerica Long-Term Care unit, and Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% is spinning off its Pharmacy Services operations, and those business will combine to form PharMerica Corp. Pope & Talbot was ranked 600th in the index at the close of business Tuesday. Finally, Universal Electronics Inc. UEIC, +0.68% will replace Armor Holdings Inc. AH, +3.65% in the S&P SmallCap 600. Armor Holdings is being acquired by BAE Systems Plc BAESY, +1.65% -Jonathan Vuocolo; 201-938-5400; AskNewswires@dowjones.com More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you
title: S&P: Kyphon to replace Triad on MidCap 400

content: A delay in changing the way Medicaid reimburses for generic drugs provides a reprieve for pharmacies, which nonetheless face a risk of lower payments as a result of the new method, according to Wall Street analysts. Pharmacy benefit managers should see little or no effect and drug distributors only secondary results from the new pricing model, while independent drug stores and at least one nursing home pharmacy appear more vulnerable to new reimbursement caps, known as federal upper limits. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services late Monday provided a timeline for switching to Average Manufacturer Prices, or AMP, for covering generic drugs in Medicaid, the federal-state health insurance program for the poor and disabled. The new policy emerged from the Deficit Reduction Act of 2005, which required a revised definition of the Average Manufacturer Price and a new formula for calculating federal reimbursement limits. Pharmacies will not be subject to the new caps until the end of this year, which is six months later than the government had previously indicated and an entire year later than lawmakers had originally contemplated, Morgan Stanley analyst David Veal said in a note. The new policy was mandated by the Deficit Reduction Act of 2005. CMS expects to publish the final regulation on July 2. Drug makers are to report their September AMPs in late October, and retail pharmacies can expect that Medicaid reimbursement for generic drugs based on those prices to take effect on Dec. 30, CMS said. The delay not only preserves the current generics earnings stream, based on the more lucrative Average Wholesale Price model, for another six months, it also postpones adoption of the rules until closer to the time that many state legislatures reconvene, "potentially allowing lawmakers to boost dispensing fees more immediately to offset the potential reimbursement cuts," Veal said. "At a higher level, however, the delay merely postpones the inevitable changes that, depending on the content of the final regulations, may pose a risk to earnings for pharmacy operators that serve Medicaid beneficiaries," he said. Morgan Stanley believes nursing home pharmacy Omnicare Inc. OCR may be at the highest risk among stocks it covers, given that some of its Medicare prescription-drug-benefit contracts use Medicaid upper limits as a key benchmark. Drug distributors have indirect exposure through their independent-pharmacy customers, which serve a greater proportion of Medicaid patients than do chain drug stores, according to Veal. Morgan Stanley owns at least 1% of Omnicare shares and at least $1 million of its debt, and has a recent investment-banking relationship with the company. The firm also has ownership positions in and business relationships with other companies in the pharmaceutical supply chain. JPMorgan analyst Lisa Gill noted that the final regulation to be published soon will determine exactly what the AMP calculation includes. CMS published the proposed rule last December, and it remains to be seen what changes the agency may implement based on responses it received. "Retail pharmacies are projected to bear brunt of the reimbursement impact," Gill said, noting that industry trade groups and others had expressed concern to CMS that lower reimbursement could threaten the survival of independent community pharmacies and to beneficiaries' access to medications. JPMorgan sees no direct threat to drug wholesalers or pharmacy benefit managers, although the wholesalers could feel an indirect hit if pharmacy reimbursement declines dramatically. CMS indicates it expects less than a 1% reduction in retail pharmacy revenue as a result of the new rule, Gill said in a note. The big three PBMs have virtually no exposure to the Medicaid market, although the publication of AMP pricing data could increase transparency around generics pricing. Commercial adoption of the pricing methodology is difficult to predict, as there is "a significant degree of uncertainty around a new benchmark for PBM contracts," she said. The big three PBMs are Medco Health Solutions Inc. MHS Express Scripts Inc. ESRX and CVS Caremark's Caremark business. The big wholesalers are AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC Cardinal Health Inc. CAH and McKesson Corp. MCK Eric Coldwell of Robert W. Baird noted that while he hasn't anticipated a material risk to drug distributors from AMP, it has been a sector risk given concerns about the effect on customer bases. "While we cannot know the ultimate impact of the reimbursement change, at a minimum the clarified timeline suggests an additional six-month breather from what most observers expected," he wrote. Adam Fein, president of pharmaceutical supply-chain consulting firm Pembroke Consulting Inc., said on his weblog that in the next few years, the true effects of AMP will become clearer. "List minus" pricing models, such as Average Wholesale Price minus a certain percent, will "continue to be under tremendous pressure" among private payors, who have historically followed government pricing models, he said. "Cost plus" models help give payors better control over costs in the pharmacy supply chain, he wrote. Large drug store chains and mass merchants will benefit from accelerated consolidation of retail pharmacies, Fein predicted. The role and compensation paid to drug wholesalers may change as manufacturers pay closer attention to accounting of fees and discounts, he said. -Contact: 201-938-5400
title: Pharmacies get reprieve on Medicaid drug-pricing change

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Shares of Medco Health Solutions Inc. set a fresh 52-week high Thursday after the company was awarded what analysts called a "major win," a three-year contract to provide mail and specialty pharmacy benefits to government employees. The contract, which is expected to add some $2 billion in revenue and as much as 20 cents a share to Medco's results in 2008, prompted numerous analysts to raise their earnings forecasts and price targets. Raymond James analyst Michael Baker, citing enhanced 2008 earnings visibility and the potential for additional contract wins, lifted his rating to outperform from market perform. Shares of the pharmacy benefit manager MHS rose to trade for as much as $80.90 before closing the session at $78.24, up $1.15. The contract for The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association's government-wide service benefit plan, also known as the Federal Employee Program, covers more than 4 million federal employees, retirees and their families, Franklin Lakes, N.J.-based Medco said. FEP renewed the retail side of the contract, estimated to be worth $4 billion annually, with CVS Caremark Corp. CVS, -0.80% Caremark has been administering FEP's retail pharmacy benefit management program since 1993; it took the mail portion away from Medco during the 2005 through 2007 period. "FEP's move to split the contract between two vendors had been discussed in the market, but is a surprise nonetheless," noted Cowen & Co. analyst Kemp Dolliver. He doesn't expect other employers to follow suit. The contract goes into effect Jan. 1, 2008 and runs through the end of 2010. CIBC World Markets analyst Charles Rhyee further modeled the impact on Medco's drug distributor, AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% whose 2008 per-share earnings he expects will see an added 2 cents. Meanwhile, he expects McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% the distributor for CVS' PBM operations, to be negatively impacted by about a penny a share. AmerisourceBergen shares slipped 3 cents to close at $51, while McKesson shares finished at $61.09, down 97 cents. CVS shares rose 32 cents to end at $37.57. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000
title: Medco Health shares boosted by government contract

content: It was a week of stock-market records, at least for shares not related to technology. The S&P 500 Index closed above its March 2000 high for the first time, marking a milestone of some kind. It's been more than seven years since market commentators seriously used the word "bubble" when referring to stock prices. Some may be scratching their heads and wondering if it's time to start doing so again. But unlike 2000, tech stocks are bringing a dose of sanity. The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index, while hitting a six and a half-year high, remains well below its 2000 record. On Friday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% closed at 13,668.11, up 1.2% for the week, while the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% rose to 1,536.34, marking a 1.4% gain for the week. The Nasdaq $COMPQ meanwhile, closed at 2,613.92, up 2.2% for the week. There was plenty of other news, even though there were only four working days. Dell Inc. DELL reported results along with job cuts, and investors bought the stock in response, but some analysts said the stock is now overvalued and lowered their ratings. Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT, +1.37% scaled back its expansion plans, paring what had once seemed like a never-ending and unfettered expansion spree. Investors pushed up the stock price and analysts welcomed the news. There was also a confab in Southern California known as D: All Things Digital, which offers a chance for Silicon Valley luminaries to expound on issues and problems confronting the industry. It was a hot ticket for movers and shakers, but offered little hard news for investors. Still, it was difficult to deny the pure entertainment value of seeing Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% founder Bill Gates and Apple Inc. AAPL, +0.78% impresario Steve Jobs on the same stage, ribbing each other, discussing 30 years of rivalry and predicting bright times ahead for the technology industry. They weren't wearing shades. -- Christopher Noble, assistant managing editor Best of rivals Bill Gates and Steve Jobs on one stage, in public, talking about technology: A dream pairing that was the marquee event at this year's D: All Things Digital conference. The conference featured little breaking news, but many attention-grabbing and entertaining exchanges from some of the biggest names in technology. Read commentary about the Gates/Jobs meeting. Wachovia buys again Wachovia Corp. WB, +3.87% a bank that has been acquisition-happy recently, did another deal this week, snapping up brokerage company A.G. Edwards for nearly $7 billion. The cash and stock deal makes Wachovia, once a regional bank anchored in North Carolina, into the country's second-biggest retail broker. The deal also touched off speculation that other midsize brokers may soon be acquired. Read about the prospects for midsize brokerage companies. S&P 500 joins the record club The S&P 500 set a few closing records this week, the first times it has done so since March of 2,000. It was the second of the major indexes to surpass its high from 2000, trailing the Dow Jones Industrial Average but handily beating the Nasdaq Composite Index. Is this a bearish signal for stocks? Read column about whether Nasdaq's relative weakness is bearish. Look out below? Home prices fell in the first quarter, even in parts of the San Francisco Bay Area, according to one set of data released this week. Prices dropped 1.4% in the quarter, the first year-over-year decline since 1991. The data was seen as reinforcing other data that show a dramatic weakening in the U.S. housing market. Read about home prices falling. A different Big Three Drug wholesales Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% and AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% are the three in question. It turns out they control about 90% of the revenue in the wholesale drug market and exert significant influence on pricing and the fate of small and midsize competitors. Read special report about the Big Three drug wholesalers. Big oil going green? Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, +2.47% said that it never set out to become public enemy No. 1 in the global climate-change debate. But the oil giant's chief, speaking at the annual meeting, said that there is still a debate about climate change and defended the company's plans to keep funding research on the topic. Read about Exxon Mobil's annual meeting. Gas-saving secrets If you have to drive and are looking for more tips on how to save gas, look no further. Beyond tire pressure, minimizing idle time and tune-ups, here are five ideas for how to save fuel, as well as time and money. Don't forget, there's always walking and biking. Get five little-known tips to improve mileage. Legacy of bankruptcies This week Northwest Airlines NWA came out of bankruptcy, an auspicious development for the airline, and also for the industry as a whole. It means that for the first time in about five years, not a single major U.S. carrier is bankrupt. Read about the airline industry's challenges. Will the three bears get the porridge? The headwinds that have been slowing the U.S. economy over the past year are beginning to shift, dispelling fears of a recession or protracted slump. Meanwhile, the inflation picture continues to brighten. But will the so-called Goldilocks economy prevail, or will the Three Bears be back? Read Capitol Report on the U.S. economy. Oil prices going up ... or down? The price difference between crude traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange and the IntercontinentalExchange has touched its widest level ever. World events and market dynamics pushed Nymex futures down almost 5% in May, but had the opposite effect on Brent prices, pushing them up to nearly $72 per barrel. Read Myra Saefong's Commodities Corner. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000
title: The week's top news and analysis, May 28 - June 1

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- They are known as the "Big Three" in the pharmaceutical wholesale industry, and their control over the market is drawing the attention of lawmakers, the scrutiny of regulators and the wrath of smaller rivals who say they've had enough. Behemoths Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% and AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% have a virtual lock on the wholesale drug market with at least 90% and as much as 95% of all revenue. Collectively, the trio is expected to hit the quarter-trillion-dollar mark this year in sales. The three companies now are in the enviable position of controlling sales to pharmacies and other outlets, as well as being drugmakers' biggest customers. Regulators are concerned that because the Big Three control both the sell and buy sides of the equation, they could form both a potential monopoly and oligopoly, in antitrust parlance. A monopoly puts market clout into the hands of one entity, and an oligopoly means heavy market power put in the hands of a select few. "Ninety percent is a market that we would consider to be oligopolistic in nature," said Michael Moiseyev, assistant director for the Federal Trade Commission's bureau of competition. "Ninety percent is a zone where further consolidation is problematic." While these pharmaceutical middlemen have amassed massive sales and market clout, there is no indication they have violated any statutes, experts say. But by holding massive buying and selling power, they're making federal officials nervous -- again. And the companies' size and market control stands out all the more starkly against a backdrop of rising health-care costs. These companies have grown far faster than the FTC anticipated when the agency last visited them just a few years ago. In the late 1990s, the FTC said no to McKesson's plan to buy Amerisource and Cardinal's dreams of owning Bergen Brunswig. As a concession, the FTC allowed Amerisource and Bergen Brunswig to merge in 2001, and could live with the fact the three collectively controlled roughly 80% of all drug wholesaling. Since then, however, it appears that all three have continued to steamroll and virtually corner that market. Recent efforts to quash the reimportation of drugs probably have strengthened the position of the Big Three. Drug reimportation, designed to help consumers save money by getting pharmaceuticals overseas, likely would have cut into the sales of these wholesalers. But a Senate bill, passed last week, effectively prevented that from happening. "I can't say whether the market is more competitive with the three of them," said Moiseyev, who worked the FTC's cases involving McKesson and Cardinal. Four out of five McKesson, Cardinal and Amerisource essentially have secured the wholesale drug market, and they're close to having a similar standing over all prescriptions sold in the U.S. Some retailers and other end-users have direct ties to manufacturers, but it is estimated four out of every five drugs sold in the nation pass through the hands of the Big Three. Various estimates on the Big Three's share of just the wholesale market alone hover around 90%, though some say it is up to 95% by now, much of it due to dozens of acquisitions. Those purchases continue at a brisk pace, though they're now branching out into other fields with more recent buyouts such as distribution of medical devices and services for drugmakers. How did they get so big? See related story on acquisitions by these companies. There are few significant pharmaceutical distributors left for them to buy. Amerisource did, however, announce on March 28 it is trying to complete a deal for one of the last remaining major regional wholesalers, Bellco Health. The ever-expanding market share of all three companies has competitors crying foul for a number of reasons. For one, rivals say, the Big Three's market share could grow even more under a rule that would require their smaller wholesalers to provide documentation of where a drug has been, known as "pedigree." Amerisource, Cardinal and McKesson would be exempt from that rule, putting smaller rivals at a disadvantage. Further, drugmakers prefer to deal with the Big Three. Small wholesalers who try to deal directly with major drugmakers often find themselves steered toward McKesson, Cardinal or Amerisource for product. That puts these smaller players in the unusual predicament of relying on their much larger rivals for their livelihood. Under normal circumstances, economies of scale would help keep prices down with the size that the Big Three offer. But they're increasingly dictating prices and terms. In nearly all cases, Cardinal, McKesson and Amerisource are mandating that customers buy large amounts of product in bulk. Since the Big Three have most of the access to the drugs, customers feel compelled to comply. Sal LaDuca, president of QK Healthcare, a small wholesaler based in Ronkonkoma, N.Y, says the Big Three's marketing clout manifests itself in numerous ways. For example, generic drugmakers often will sell to anyone, but the Big Three's access to popular brand drugs such as Viagra allows them to charge more for generic goods. "They're able to demand that because they have these proprietary items," he said. "That's their game." In addition, wholesalers don't capture the same attention that producers or retailers get; they often are considered the unsexy conduit between the two. As a result, the Big Three have flown under the radar to a large extent, and so it's unclear how much of an effect they have on pricing. Anecdotal evidence suggests these wholesalers could add as much as 25% to the price of drugs. "I've heard everything from a few percent to 20%, but I honestly don't know," said Fred Gebhardt, a writer who covers drug wholesalers for the trade magazine Drug Topics. "I don't know if anybody even has the data to build a reasonable model for that kind of setup. Everybody agrees that you get higher prices from an oligopoly, but I don't know how much higher." FTC probe Recent concerns have prompted the FTC to reopen the file on at least the two biggest players in this troika, McKesson and Cardinal. McKesson's most recent annual 10K, filed May 9 with the Securities and Exchange Commission, says the FTC has requested documents as "part of a non-public investigation to determine whether the company may have engaged in anti-competitive practices with other wholesale pharmaceutical distributors in order to limit competition for provider customers seeking distribution services." Last year's filing from Cardinal used virtually identical language to disclose its situation. Both companies have said the probe has been ongoing since December 2004, when they first were contacted by the FTC. Neither McKesson nor Cardinal would comment on the matter. It's unclear whether Amerisource is part of that same investigation. The company will only say it hasn't had any FTC requests that it feels it must disclose. And neither Moiseyev nor other FTC officials would comment directly on the probe, except to confirm McKesson's and Cardinal's statements, and to say their investigation hasn't been completed. While the FTC is investigating Cardinal and McKesson, it hasn't put the kibosh on any of their acquisition plans. Since late 2004, the two companies have taken part in nine acquisitions. And all three have made more than 100 acquisitions since 1980, with the bulk of them in the past 10 years. In one of its purchases, McKesson obtained an FTC waiver on a waiting period so it could buy wholesaler D&K Healthcare Resources Inc. in mid-2005, several months after the company disclosed the FTC probe. The deal was completed in little more than a month for $427 million. FTC officials had no comment on the D&K deal. Biggest in Fortune 500 The Big Three are dominant players by any corporate yardstick. From 2002 to 2005, they were the largest of all health-care companies in sales among the Fortune 500, all consistently ranking in the top 30. For 2006, McKesson and Cardinal remained the top two health-care firms, ranking 18th and 19th, respectively. Amerisource ranks 29th and is now the fourth-largest health-care firm in sales, having been eclipsed by insurer UnitedHealth Group Inc. UNH, -2.06% Similarly, UnitedHealth has grown tremendously in the past year due mostly to merger activity. During calendar 2006, McKesson, Cardinal and Amerisource generated $213 billion to $218 billion of drug sales in the U.S., which represents roughly 80% of all pharmaceuticals sold in the nation. IMS Health says total U.S. sales during that period were $275 billion, some of which went directly to retailers from pharmacies. (None of the Big Three report on a calendar-year basis. Their revenue is the sum of quarterly sales during calendar 2006, in order to measure that against the IMS total.) Thanks to a number of acquisitions, McKesson's fiscal 2007 revenue reached $93 billion, the company reported recently. Projections from Thomson Financial show that Cardinal's sales should hit $88.5 billion and Amerisource will reach $67 billion. Amerisource's income, however, will be augmented by another $2 billion with the company's planned Bellco buyout. With sales growth ranging from 6% to 10% for the Big Three, that comes out to a collective $250.8 billion in revenue this year. Provided those 2007 estimates ring true, the three companies' sales will have grown a collective 70% in the six years since the AmerisourceBergen merger was approved. Although the Big Three have captured massive market share, their bottom lines might seem weak. Gross margins were in the 3.5% to 6.5% range for the three, but net margins often amount to less than 1%. With added bulk, though, comes profit growth. For both 2007 and 2008, the Big Three are expected to hit gains near or past double digits in earnings. It's why size clearly matters for not only the Big Three, but also their buyers. Drugmakers prefer to deal in bulk, thus leading them to deal with Cardinal, Amerisource and McKesson. In turn, the Big Three often require minimum purchases themselves, a practice that's already driven up prices and choked off avenues of supply for a number of smaller users such as clinics, doctor's offices or small pharmacies. Drugless in Seattle Doug Beck works part time running a small pharmacy for Schick Shadel Hospital, a 26-bed substance-abuse treatment center in the Seattle area. Patients who come in may need antibiotics or blood-pressure medication, but demand is not high. The hospital handles about $2,000 a month in products. Beck used to get his medicines via McKesson, but he says the wholesaler cut him off because he wasn't ordering enough. He went down the street to a retailer, White Center Pharmacy, for what he needed and ended up paying 25% more for it. "It was frustrating to me because [McKesson] delivers to White Center Pharmacy. They drive right by our facility, so it wasn't like it was any added cost for them," Beck said. "And they needed a minimum of $10,000 a month to justify, I don't know, the guys picking it off the shelf or inventory control. I don't know what all it was. They didn't share that." McKesson responded that such minimum-purchase agreements are part of the normal course of business for many distributors. Amerisource also commented on this issue, saying it requires a minimum order from its customers, and added: "In order to serve our customers most efficiently and provide the best value, we prefer to serve our customers as the primary vendor." Some observers of the wholesaling business say the Big Three got to where they are in some measure because of natural market forces. "The three biggest wholesalers have a very compelling service package," said Adam Fein, president of Pembroke Consulting, a Philadelphia-based consultant that specializes in distribution and marketing. "They've been very successful at what they've done, and customers -- whether it is pharmacies or hospitals -- have decided that's where they want to purchase their drugs." But the Big Three's influence has grown to the point where drugmakers feel obligated to use them, said Drug Topics' Gebhardt. "If you've got an aggressive wholesaler that's on, say, a regional basis, who's going out and trying to grab market share, it's going to hurt your established Big Three relationships," Gebhardt said. "It's worth a lot to you, the manufacturer, to keep those Big Three national wholesalers happy." Supply cut off And small wholesalers, who sometimes are the only means of getting products to small, independent pharmacies, can find themselves getting squeezed when they rely on competitors for business. Bob Drucker, president of wholesaler RxUSA in Port Washington, N.Y., says Big Pharma's reluctance to take on new distributors forced him to rely on the Big Three for product. That pipeline slowed to a trickle a couple of years ago before being shut off entirely last year. Now he's scrambling for product from other small wholesalers. Drucker says Cardinal and Amerisource stopped selling him product years ago. Up until last year, Drucker was using McKesson. When McKesson was sending him product, it was only a fraction of the orders he requested, he says. In 2005, he asked McKesson for $697.3 million worth of product that he planned to move, but says the wholesaler delivered only $172.2 million. That means Drucker didn't get to sell $525 million worth of pharmaceuticals, or 75% worth of his orders, leaving his customers and a number of patients scrambling. "We did $295 million [in total sales]. We could have done $1 billion," Drucker said. "The little guys who are independents are dying like flies." For the first two months of 2006, Drucker got only 10% of the requested orders from McKesson before the wholesaler cut off his supply in anticipation of new provisions of the Prescription Drug Marketing Act going into effect. Those provisions were blocked by an injunction, but would have required that Drucker provide "pedigree," which is essentially an individual itinerary on each drug that document where the product had been. McKesson reasoned that it would not be able to supply that information, Drucker said. RxUSA has filed a lawsuit against the Big Three and a number of pharmaceutical manufacturers, claiming they are monopolizing drug sales. Several defendants involved said they expect to prevail on motions calling for dismissal of the case. RxUSA also was the lead plaintiff in the litigation that prompted a federal judge last year to put a hold on the drug marketing rule. McKesson wouldn't respond directly, but said in court documents on Drucker's case that the lawsuit is flawed and the sheer number of companies named in the lawsuit -- 23 in all -- couldn't possibly form a monopoly. The company says drugmakers and large wholesalers are perfectly within their rights to not sell RxUSA any product. "Further, no wholesaler defendant controls access to pharmaceuticals," McKesson's response says. "The manufacturers of those products choose what drugs to make, to whom they wish to sell them, and in what quantities." Many drugmakers would not comment for this story because they are named as defendants in Drucker's lawsuit. Those who would talk say it's too costly for them to maintain a vast network of distributors. They prefer to have just a handful of wholesalers dispensing their products. "It's easier to deal with three people than 300 people," said Bryant Haskins, Pfizer PFE, +0.54% spokesman, who said the bulk of the company's business goes through the Big Three. "We think we have a very effective system." Pricing challenged A challenge of sorts is being mounted against the drug pricing system by retail behemoth Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT, +1.37% Wal-Mart is large enough to buy enough bulk shipments of certain types of generic drugs so that it can sell them at its stores for $4. But it's not the only retailer waging a fight against the current pricing system. Seattle-based BC Drugs, a small independent pharmacy, fills prescriptions on a cash-only basis, says co-owner George Butchko. BC doesn't take insurance, and thus is able to keep the price of drugs such as lisinopril, a popular blood-pressure medication, at $15 a month, roughly half of what is charged at other pharmacies. While many retailers get virtually all their product from one or all of the Big Three, BC relies on AmerisourceBergen for about two-thirds of its product and secondary wholesalers for the rest, Butchko says. Under the drug marketing act's requirement for "pedigree" - which primary wholesalers like Amerisource won't have to provide -- he feels many smaller wholesalers will go out of business and his prices will go up. "I know that having so many different sources to order from, that I've seen in the year that I've been here, [AmerisourceBergen] prices drop because they really have to be competitive with the other wholesalers that we have," Butchko said. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh
title: Growing share of 'Big Three' drug wholesalers gets attention

content: LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Growth by acquisition has been the watchword of the "Big Three" of pharmaceutical distribution -- McKesson Corp., Cardinal Health Inc. and AmerisourceBergen Corp. This troika of middlemen have amassed a quarter-trillion dollars in sales, thanks in large part to more than 100 buyouts since 1980, at least 57 of which have taken place in this decade. There may be even more purchases, but they say a number go unreported. Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% has been the busiest by far, with 65 purchases since 1980, nearly half of those since the beginning of 2000. Merger activity is so engrained in Cardinal's culture that the practice occupies its own page on the company's Web site. During 2000 and 2001, Cardinal averaged an acquisition once every six weeks. A key rival was taken out of commission in February 2001 when Cardinal acquired Bindley Western Industries, one of the bigger regional firms that rivaled the Big Three. McKesson's MCK, +0.15% merger activity hasn't been as prolific -- or so it appears. The company has reported 23 purchases since 1983, 16 of which took place since 2000. One of its biggest took place in January 1999, when it began to take shape with the purchase of HBO & Co., and then it bought D&K Healthcare Resource, another major regional wholesaler, in July 2005. But McKesson says there may be more. The company points out that it does not report any buyout it considers to be "non-material." While Amerisource's ABC, +1.29% purchases have been fewer, they've been more concentrated. In its present form and former incarnations, Amerisource and Bergen Brunswig, the company has made 15 purchases since 1999. All but two, however, have taken place since 2003. Most significant was its announcement in March it was buying Bellco Health, eliminating another major regional rival.
