title: How the 'Big Three' got bigger: acquisitions

content: Advancers ABN Amro ABN shares rose 5.2% after a consortium led by the Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) said it may bid around $100 billion for the company. See full story. Advanced Medical Optics EYE shares gained 8.8% after the company reported first-quarter earnings jumped on 5.6% higher sales, and it affirmed its outlook for 2007 adjusted earnings. Earnings reached $12.1 million, or 20 cents a share, from $2.6 million, or 4 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings were cut by a total of 3 cents a share due to two special items: an in-process-R&D charge tied to the acquisition of WaveFront Sciences, and an unrealized loss on derivative instruments. Sales climbed to $251.7 million from $238.2 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 16 cents of earnings on $242 million of sales. Aftermarket Technology Corp. ATAC shares jumped 11% Wednesday. Late Tuesday, the Downer's Grove, Ill.-based company reported first-quarter net earnings of $9.67 million, or 44 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $3.2 million, or 15 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Alcoa Inc. AA shares rose 5.3% after the company said it plans to explore the disposition of its packaging and consumer businesses. These businesses generated about $3.2 billion in revenue in 2006, roughly 10% of the company's total for the year. In addition, the Dow component also said it's looking at strategic alternatives for its AFL Wire Harness and Aluminum Casting operations, which had combined revenue of about $1.6 billion in 2006. The company expects to complete the process by the end of the year. Amazon.com AMZN shares soared 27% after the company reported that first-quarter profit more than doubled and sales jumped 32% as it sold more goods through its Web site. See full story. Arkansas Best ABFS shares moved up 5.9% after the company said its first-quarter net income dropped 22% to $4.8 million, or 19 cents a share, as tonnage declines at its ABF Freight Systems unit continued into 2007. The quarter also included a 3 cents a share charge for pension settlement accounting. Revenue fell to $422.6 million from $425 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 15 cents a share. Asset Acceptance Capital Corp. AACC shares rallied 16% after the company said it plans to recapitalize its balance sheet and return $150 million to shareholders. Asset Acceptance said it will repurchase up to $75 million of its shares through a combination of a Dutch auction tender offer, and purchases from its largest shareholder, chief executive and chief financial officer -- who own 50.5% of the company's stock -- following the tender offer. The balance of the $150 million return of capital to shareholders will be paid in the form of a special one-time cash dividend, the company said. Baker Hughes BHI shares gained 7.8% after the company said its first-quarter net income rose 10% to $365 million, or $1.17 a share, with revenue up 20% to $2.47 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of $1.10 a share. The oil services group said revenue outside North America should grow between 19% and 21% in 2007, while U.S. revenue is expected to rise 7%. Capital spending is expected to be between $1.0 billion and $1.2 billion, it added. Bally Total Fitness Holding BFT shares jumped 18% after the company said it has agreed to sell its 16 Toronto facilities to Extreme Fitness Inc. and GoodLife Fitness Centres Inc. Proceeds from the transactions are estimated to be about C$19.6 million ($17.6 million). BioDelivery Sciences International Inc. BDSI shares rose 30% after the company said its Phase III study showed patients treated with Bema Fentanyl showed a statistically significant improvement on the primary efficacy endpoint of reduced pain intensity. Bema Fentanyl consists of a dissolvable polymer disc that can be applied to the inner lining of the cheek to deliver the opioid Fentanyl to cancer patients. Carter's Inc. CRI shares moved up 6.8% after the company said first-quarter earnings fell 39% to $9.61 million, or 16 cents a share. The Atlanta marketer of clothes for babies and young children said sales rose 5% to $320.1 million. Chaparral Steel Co. CHAP shares rallied 12% after the Midlothian, Texas-based company announced that its board has initiated a review of strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the company, and has hired Goldman, Sachs & Co. to assist in the review. Chaparral said it does not plan to disclose developments unless and until its board approves a definitive transaction. Cheesecake Factory CAKE shares gained 9% after the company said first-quarter net income was flat at 24 cents a share. C.H. Robinson Worldwide CHRW shares surged 11% after the company posted first-quarter net income of 42 cents a share, up from 33 cents in the year-earlier period. Sales rose to $1.62 billion from $1.50 billion. Corning Inc. GLW shares added 5.3% after the company said it earned 20 cents a share in the first quarter, up from 16 cents in the year-earlier period. The New York specialty glass company said that excluding charges, it earned 28 cents a share. Sales climbed to $1.31 billion from $1.26 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was earnings of 26 cents on revenue of $1.29 billion. CV Therapeutics Inc.'s CVTX shares gained 9% after the company posted a first-quarter loss narrowed to 93 cents a share from $1.57 a share. The company posted revenue of $15.3 million vs. $5.1 million. Desert Community Bank DCBK shares surged 20% after the Victorville, Calif.-based company agreed to be acquired by East West Bancorp Inc. EWBC for $24 a share, or $142.6 million. Industrial Services of America IDSA shares jumped 47% after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $793,080, or 22 cents a share, up from $416,526, or 12 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Louisville, Ky.-based logistics management services company posted revenue for the three months ended March 31 of $17.9 million vs. $14.5 million. Shares of K2 KTO surged 20% after the company agreed to be acquired by Jarden Corp. JAH for $15.50 a share of cash and stock The companies said in a statement that Jarden will pay $10.85 a share cash plus 0.1086 of its shares for each K2 share. They valued the deal at $1.2 billion, including Jarden's assumption of K2's debt. K2 shares closed on Tuesday at $12.58 each, indicating a takeover premium of 23%. O'Reilly Automotive Inc.'s ORLY shares gained 5.8% after the company said first-quarter net income rose 19% to $48.4 million, or 42 cents a share, from $40.6 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier. The Springfield, Mo., auto parts retailer said sales increased 14% to $613.1 million from $536.5 million a year ago. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial predicted first-quarter earnings of 40 cents a share and revenue of $600.1 million. O'Reilly Automotive's same-store sales increased 6.8% in the first quarter. Pixelworks Inc.'s PXLW shares rose 9.4% after the company reported its first-quarter loss narrowed to 25 cents a share from 69 cents. Revenue fell 34% to $24 million. Riverbed Technology Inc. RVBD 23% after the company swung to a first-quarter profit of 5 cents a share, from a year-ago loss of 36 cents a share. Revenue tripled to $42.8 million from $13.7 million. Teledyne Technologies TDY shares rose 11% after the company said it sees earnings of 58 to 61 cents a share for the second quarter, above Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 57 cents a share in the June period. Weatherford International Ltd. WFT shares gained 6.7% after the company reported first-quarter net income for the three months ended March 31 rose 39% to $281.6 million, or 81 cents a share, from $203.3 million, or 57 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue increased to $1.9 billion in the quarter from $1.5 million a year ago. Adjusted earnings were 76 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 77 cents a share, on average. XenoPort XNPT shares jumped 44% after the Santa Clara, Calif.-based biopharmaceutical company announced top-line results from a Phase III clinical trial of XP13512 for the treatment of symptoms of primary restless legs syndrome. The company said the drug candidate demonstrated statistically significant improvements compared to placebo on both of the co-primary endpoints of the trial. Ronald Barrett, chief executive of XenoPort, called the results "very encouraging" and a "major advance for XenoPort." XL Capital Ltd.'s XL shares added 6.5% after the company reported first-quarter net income rose 20% to $562.5 million, or $3.06.The Bermuda insurance and reinsurance company's revenue rose 0.4% to $2.48 billion. Decliners Akamai AKAM shares fell 10% after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $19.2 million, or 11 cents a share, up 67% from $11.5 million, or 7 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, the company posted a profit of $50.7 million, or 28 cents a share. The Cambridge, Mass.-based software company said revenue in the three months ended March 31 rose 53% to $139.3 million from $90.8 million in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 28 cents on revenue of $139 million. All American Semiconductor Inc. SEMI shares plunged 49% Wednesday after the filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC shares fell 7.2% Wednesday after the company said fiscal second-quarter net income rose to 68 cents a share from 61 cents in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $16.51 billion from $15.22 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 67 cents a share on revenue of $16.7 billion, according to Thomson Financial. Charles & Colvard Ltd. CTHR shares sank 26% after the Morrisville, N.C.-based company late Tuesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $339,284, or 2 cents a share, down from $1.52 million, or 8 cents a share, in the year-ago period. For the three months ended March 31, revenue decreased 28% to $5.78 million from $8.01 million a year ago. Charles & Colvard, which makes moissanite, said separately that it has approved the repurchase of up to 1 million shares of common stock over the next 12 months. Checkfree Corp.'s CKFR shares slipped 5.8% after the company said third-quarter net income fell to 33 cents a share from 40 cents in the year-earlier period. The latest adjusted earnings were 49 cents a share. Revenue rose to $230.2 million from $226.9 million. Corporate Executive Board Co. EXBD shares sank 18% after the Washington-based company reported first-quarter net earnings of $19.4 million, or 50 cents a share, up 13% from $17.1 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 18.5% to $124.5 million from $105.1 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 49 cents on revenue of $127.5 million. For the rest of 2007, the company sees per-share earnings of 42 to 45 cents for the second quarter, 55 to 61 cents for the third quarter and 63 to 70 cents for the fourth quarter. Cymer Inc.'s CYMI shares lost 6.3% after the company said first-quarter net income fell 1.4% to $20.3 million, or 52 cents. The San Diego maker of laser-light sources for semiconductor manufacturing said revenue fell to $126.7 million from $127.1 million. E.W. Scripps Co. SSP said first-quarter net income fell to $68.5 Hilb Rogal & Hobbs Co. HRH shares dropped 7.2% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $25.2 million, or 69 cents a share, down 2.7% from the year-earlier period. The Richmond, Va., insurance and risk management company said revenue rose to $198.2 million from $183.8 million. Hutchinson Technology Inc. HTCH shares dropped 14% after the company swung to a fiscal second-quarter loss of 14 cents a share from a year-ago profit of 29 cents a share. The Hutchinson, Minn., supplier of suspension assemblies for disk drives said sales for fell 8.4% to $170.7 million. Leadis Technology Inc.'s LDIS shares lost 11% after the company said its first-quarter loss widened to 19 cents a share, from a year-earlier 10 cents a share. Revenue dropped to $13.7 million from $24.1 million. Siemens AG's SI U.S.-listed shares fell 5.4% after the German industrial conglomerate said Chief Executive Klaus Kleinfeld will leave when his contract expires at the end of September.See full story. Sun Microsystems Inc. SUNW shares dropped more than 11% on massive trading volume Wednesday after the hardware giant reported weak sales of computer servers in the just-ended quarter and issued a disappointing forecast for the current period. See full story. Travelzoo Inc. TZOO shares tumbled 24% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of fell to 25 cents a share from 24 cents in the year-ago period. The New York Internet media company posted revenue for the three months ended March 31 of $19.7 million vs. $16.9 million. Western Union WU shares fell 5.8% after the company said its revenue growth in the first quarter was slightly slower than expected due to ongoing challenges in the U.S. domestic, Mexico, and U.S. outbound markets. The company also said it saw lower revenue from its Internet service in the U.S. Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Wednesday's biggest stock gainers and decliners

content: Alcon quarterly profit rises 17%; revises 2007 outlook (6:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Alcon Inc. ACL, -0.75% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $346.2 million, or $1.14 a share, up 17% from $295.7 million, or 95 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Excluding a charge related to the impairment of certain assets, adjusted earnings were $367 million, or $1.21 a share. The Swiss eye-care company posted revenue for the three months ended March 31 of $1.32 billion vs. $1.16 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had estimated first-quarter earnings of $1.16 a share on revenue of $1.3 billion. Additionally, Alcon said it now expects 2007 per-share earnings of $5.08 to $5.18, or $5.15 to $5.25 on an adjusted basis, on revenue of $5.4 billion to $5.48 billion. In February, the company forecast 2007 per-share earnings of $5.10 to $5.20 on revenue of $5.35 billion to $5.45 billion. Pulte Homes swings to quarterly loss, revenue falls (5:53 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Pulte Homes Inc. PHM, +1.41% late Wednesday reported a first-quarter net loss of $85.7 million, or 33 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, the Bloomfield, Mich.-based home builder posted net earnings of $262.6 million, or $1.01 a share. Revenue in the three months ended March 31 fell to $1.87 billion from $2.96 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share loss of 37 cents on revenue of $1.72 billion. Net new home orders for the quarter totaled 8,499 homes, valued at $2.9 billion, down 21% from last year, the company said. The backlog as of March 31 was valued at $4.7 billion, or 13,334 homes, compared with a value of $7.1 billion, 19,940 homes, a year ago. Additionally, Pulte Homes said it expects second-quarter per-share results to range from breakeven to a loss of 10 cents, exclusive of any additional land-related charges. CoStar quarterly profit slips (5:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CoStar Group Inc. CSGP, +1.87% after Wednesday's closing bell reported first-quarter net earnings of $1.81 million, or 9 cents a share, down from $1.86 million, or 10 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Bethesda, Md.-based provider of information services to commercial real estate professionals said revenue in the quarter rose to $44.8 million from $37.3 million in the same quarter last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 8 cents on revenue of $44.4 million. CoStar expects second-quarter earnings of 2 cents to 6 cents a share, and still expects 2007 earnings of 50 cents to 60 cents a share. The company also forecast second-quarter sequential revenue growth of 5% to 6%, and 2007 revenue growth of 20% to 22% year-over-year. Duke Realty quarterly earnings surge on land sale gains (5:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Duke Realty Corp. DRE, +0.80% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings available to common shareholders of $73.9 million, or 49 cents a share, up from $12.6 million, or 8 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The current results include 35 cents per share from a higher level of gains on the disposition of depreciable properties as well as higher gains on the disposition of land and held for sale properties, the company said. Funds from operations available to common shareholders came in at $92.5 million, or 62 cents a share, up from $74.4 million, or 50 cents a share, last year. The Indianapolis-based real estate investment trust said revenue from continuing operations in the three months ended March 31 rose to $229.9 million from $202.3 million in the comparable period a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 11 cents on revenue of $202 million. Additionally, Duke Realty said it still sees 2007 FFO of $2.62 to $2.76 a share. For the second quarter, the company said it expects per-share FFO of 58 cents to 61 cents. Tupperware quarterly profit rises 23% (5:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Tupperware Brands Corp. TUP, +2.33% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $19.6 million, or 32 cents share, up 23% from $16 million, or 26 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, the company posted a profit of 36 cents a share. The Orlando, Fla.-based maker of kitchenware, cosmetics and personal care products said revenue for the 13 weeks ended March 31 rose to $456.9 million from $423.7 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of 30 cents a share on revenue of $437 million. Tupperware now expects 2007 earnings of $1.69 to $1.74 a share, or $1.84 to $1.89 a share excluding items, on revenue of $1.85 billion to $1.87 billion. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of $1.75. Stanley Works almost doubles profit, sales rise 10% (5:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Stanley Works SWK, +1.56% on Wednesday posted a first-quarter profit of $68 million, or 80 cents a share, up from $38 million, or 45 cents a share, from continuing operations a year ago. Sales rose 10% to $1.06 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected a profit of 78 cents a share on revenue of $1.03 billion. The company said strong demand for its tools from industrial markets in North America and Europe helped make up for continued weakness in the U.S. retail and construction markets. Stanley Works reaffirmed 2007 estimates in a range of $4.00 and $4.10 a share. For the second quarter, the company is looking for earnings of $1 a share, 2 cents higher than Wall Street targets. Amerigroup quarterly profit falls 43% (5:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Amerigroup Corp. AGP late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $21.3 million, or 40 cents a share, down 43% from $37.3 million, or 71 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Virginia Beach, Va.-based managed-care company said revenue for the three months ended March 31 rose 24% to $832.3 million from $673.9 million in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of 34 cents a share on revenue of $824 million. Amerigroup said membership increased 21.2% from last year to 1.33 million. The company also reaffirmed its 2007 earnings forecast of $1.81 to $1.96 a share. Wendy's reports profit drop, says may put itself up for sale (5:17 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Wendy's International Inc. WEN, +0.75% late Wednesday reported a 71% drop in first-quarter profit and said it was considering strategic options to enhance shareholder value, including the possible sale of the company. After the closing bell, the fast-food chain operator said it earned $14.7 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $51.2 million, or 45 cents a share, in the same period of 2006. Total revenue was $590.2 million vs. $578.7 million the year before. Total revenue rose to $16.51 billion from $15.22 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 67 cents a share on revenue of $16.7 billion, according to Thomson Financial. Citing a gain related to an antitrust settlement, the drug wholesaler raised its forecast for fiscal 2007 to a range of $2.50 to $2.65 a share from a range of $2.45 to $2.60. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expect it to earn $2.58 a share for the year, on average. Freeport-McMoRan earnings lag estimates (7:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc. FCX, +4.90% said it earned $476.2 million, or $2.02 a share, in the first quarter, compared with $251.7 million, or $1.23 a share, in the same period a year ago. The mining giant, which completed the acquisition of Phelps Dodge Corp. on March 19 to create the world's biggest publicly-traded copper company, said revenue rose to $2.30 billion from $1.09 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for earnings of $2.07 a share and revenue of $2.87 billion. Freeport expects sales for 2007 of 3.9 billion pounds of copper, 1.9 million ounces of gold and 70 million pounds of molybdenum. Based on that projection, it expects to generate cash flow of more than $5.3 billion in 2007. Capex is forecast at about $1.6 billion. Shares closed Tuesday down 1.4% at $69.36. CORRECT: AirTran tops view by 2c as it returns to profit (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AirTran Holdings AAI, +0.00% said it earned $2.4 million, or 3 cetns a share, in the first quarter of 2007, after a loss of $8.81 million, or 10 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. The Orlando, Fla. parent of AirTran Airways said revenue climbed to $504.5 million from $416 million a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for earnings of 1 cent a share and revenue of $504.3 million. (An earlier version of this item incorrectly reported the company's revenue for both periods.) Weatherford net income rises 39% (7:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Weatherford International Ltd. WFT, +0.88% said Wednesday first-quarter net income for the three months ended March 31 rose 39% to $281.6 million, or 81 cents a share, from $203.3 million, or 57 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue increased to $1.9 billion from $1.5 million. Adjusted earnings were 76 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 77 cents a share, on average. Corning tops earnings estimates; sales rise to $1.31 billion (7:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Corning Inc. GLW, +1.94% said it earned $327 million, or 20 cents a share, in the first quarter, up from $257 million, or 16 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. The New York-based specialty glass company said that excluding special charges, it would have earned 28 cents a share. Sales climbed to $1.31 billion from $1.26 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for earnings of 26 cents a share on revenue of $1.29 billion. The company said it expects second-quarter earnings of 30 to 33 cents and sales of $1.40 to $1.45 billion. Thomson Financial is looking for earnings of 30 cents a share and sales of $1.42 billion. Shares closed Tuesday up 1.8% at $23.73. Lear first-quarter profit $49.9 mln vs $17.9 mln (7:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Lear Corp. LEA, +3.01% Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $49.9 million, or 64 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $17.9 million, or 26 cents a share. The latest results include restructuring costs of $15.8 million and other special items totaling $10/7 million. Sales fell in the three-month period to $4.41 billion from $4.68 billion a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 19 cents a share in the March period. Southfield, Mich.-based Lear attributed the decline in sales to lower production in North America and the divestiture of its European interior business but said it saw improvement in its core businesses due to a solid performance in the seating segment. For the full year, the company now expects core operating earnings of $580 million to $620 million, about $20 million above its prior forecast, with net sales of about $14.8 billion. Lear shares closed Tuesday at $35.66, down 7 cents. Tribune launching stock buyback at $34 a shr (7:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Tribune Company TRB, -14.29% said Wednesday it would repurchase up to 126 million common shares for $34 each in deal worth about $4.3 billion. Shareholders will have the opportunity to tender some or all of their shares at a price of $34 per share in cash. The tender offer is being made as part of the merger agreement between Tribune, the Tribune Employee Stock Ownership Plan, the ESOP's merger subsidiary and an affiliate of Sam Zell. The tender offer commenced Wednesday and will expire on May 24. Moody's profit up 20% as ratings, research revenue grow (7:12 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Moody's Corp. MCO, +1.48% said first-quarter net income rose 20% to $175 million, or 62 cents a share, with revenue up 32% to $583 million. Raings revenue grew 36% and research revenue rose 25%. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 58 cents a share. Moody's said results for the rest of the year should be in line with previous guidance. It sees low-teens percent revenue growth for the year. PepsiCo's quarterly net income rises 16% (7:05 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- PepsiCo Inc. PEP, -0.03% reported first-quarter net income of nearly $1.1 billion, or 65 cents a share, up from $947 million, or 56 cents, earned in the same period during 2006. Quarterly revenue generated by the Purchase, N.Y.-based supplier of soft drinks and snacks reached $7.35 billion from the prior year's $6.72 billion. There were about 1.3% fewer weighted average shares outstanding in the latest quarter as a result of PepsiCo's ongoing share-repurchase program. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of 61 cents a share on revenue of $7.18 billion, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. Volumes grew by 7% in the company's snacks business during the latest quarter, while beverages grew by 3.5%. Management also affirmed PepsiCo's 2007 profit outlook, forecasting earnings of at least $3.30 a share; Wall Street's average stands at $3.32 a share. Shares of PepsiCo dipped 18 cents to finish Tuesday's trading at $66.41. Waddell & Reed profit up 16.7%, assets hit record level (6:55 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Mutual fund company Waddell & Reed Financial Inc. WDR, +2.38% said its first-quarter net income rose 16.7% to $28.7 million, or 35 cents a share, from $24.6 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. Operating revenues rose 9% to $189 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting earnings of 36 cents a share on revenue of $195 million. The company said assets under management reached $50 billion for the first time in its history during the quarter. The company said net sales through the advisory channel were disappointing, with outflows of $132 million. Net sales in the wholesale, channel, however, were strong at $704 million, implying a 26% annualized organic growth rate. K2C quarterly profit rose 31% (6:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Sporting goods company K2, Inc. KTO, +24.44% said first-quarter net income rose 31% to $4.8 million, or 9 cents a share, from $3.6 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier. Adjusted profit climbed to $7.1 million, or 14 cents a share, from $5 million, or 10 cents a share. Sales improved 7% to $373 million, driven by the marine, outdoor, apparel and footwear segments. For fiscal 2007, the company expects GAAP earnings in the range of 73 cents to 77 cents a share and sales of $1.46 billion to $1.51 billion. Separately Jarden Corp. JAH said it's acquiring K2C in a deal worth $1.2 billion. Constellation Energy 1st-quarter net up; affirms for year (6:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Constellation Energy, CEGR3, -0.03% the Baltimore electricity supplier, reported first-quarter net income up 72% on 4% higher revenue, and it affirmed its earnings estimate for the year. Earnings reached $195.7 million, or $1.07 a share, from $113.9 million, or 63 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were $1.03 versus 61 cents. Revenue rose to $5.06 billion from $4.86 billion. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 95 cents of profit on $5.36 billion of revenue. Constellation Energy expects second-quarter earnings of 55 cents to 75 cents a share and affirmed that it should earn $4.30 to $4.65 for the year. EnCana quarterly profit falls on one-time charge (6:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Canadian energy company EnCana Corp. ECA, +4.56% said first-quarter net income fell 66% to $497 million, or $1.10 a share, from $1.5 billion a year earlier, hurt by a $423 million after-tax loss due to mark-to-market accounting of commodity price hedges. Operating earnings rose 24% to $858 million, due to higher natural gas production, improved heavy oil differentials, strong refinery margins and gains from the company's hedging program. BioDelivery Sciences Phase III trial shows positive results (6:39 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- BioDelivery Sciences International Inc. BDSI, +2.27% said its Phase III study showed patients treated with Bema Fentanyl showed a statistically significant improvement on the primary efficacy endpoint of reduced pain intensity. Bema Fentanyl consists of a dissolvable polymer disc that can be applied to the inner lining of the cheek to deliver the opioid Fentanyl to cancer patients. Great Atlantic & Pacific 4th-quarter loss eases; sales flat (6:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co., GAP, +2.27% the Montvale, N.J., supermarket subsidiary of Germany's Tengelmann Group, reported a narrower fiscal fourth-quarter loss on about flat total sales and 1.5% lower comparable-store sales. For the 12 weeks ended Feb. 24, A&P reported its loss shrank to $7.2 million, or 17 cents a share, from $39.1 million, or 95 cents, in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-operating special items, A&P had a loss from operations of $7.6 million against earnings of $1.7 million. Sales were flat with a year earlier at about $1.61 billion. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of a loss of 9 cents on revenue of $1.6 billion. (Adds Thomson estimates.) Advanced Medical Optics net jumps on 5.6% higher sales (6:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Advanced Medical Optics Inc., EYE, -0.28% the Santa Ana, Calif., maker of devices for ophthalmic surgery and products for eye care, reported first-quarter earnings jumped on 5.6% higher sales, and it affirmed its outlook for 2007 adjusted earnings. Earnings reached $12.1 million, or 20 cents a share, from $2.6 million, or 4 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings were cut by a total of 3 cents a share due to two special items: an in-process-R&D charge tied to the acquisition of WaveFront Sciences, and an unrealized loss on derivative instruments. Sales climbed to $251.7 million from $238.2 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 16 cents of earnings on $242 million of sales. The company expects to earn an adjusted $1.40 to $1.55 a share in 2007 on sales of $1.15 billion to $1.18 billion. Thomson's survey expects $1.39 and $1.15 billion. CORRECT: Host Hotels & Resorts profit improves (6:32 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Host Hotels & Resort HST, +0.38% said first-quarter net income rose to $187 million, or 35 cents a share, from $172 million, or 44 cents a share, as revenue grew to $1.04 billion from $825 million. The lodging real estate investment trust said funds from operations rose to 30 cents a share from 27 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected an FFO of 28 cents. It expects "meaningful" growth in the fourth quarter special dividend and sees comparable hotel revenue per available room to grow 6.5% to 8% for the year and an FFO between $1.76 and $1.84 a share. (Corrects the profit from the first-quarter of 2006.) Reddy Ice loss widens after acquisitions, rising costs (6:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Reddy Ice Holdings Inc. FRZ said Wednesday that its first-quarter net loss widened to $10.2 million, or 47 cents a share, from $8.2 million, or 39 cents a share, a year earlier. The result was due to additional costs associated with acquisitions as well as an increase in energy costs and continued weakness in the group's non-ice operations. Revenue for the period rose 4.9% to $47 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting a loss of 39 cents a share on revenue of $47 million. The company said its board has approved an increase in the annual rate at which it expects to pay dividends to $1.68 a share from $1.60. Reddy Ice reaffirmed its 2007 guidance for earnings in the range of 87 cents to $1.06 a share and revenue in the range of $360 million to $370 million. Regis' quarterly profit fell 71% on one-time charge (6:27 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Regis Corp. RGS, -0.98% a Minneapolis-based operator of haircare salons, said third-quarter net income fell 71% to $5.3 million, or 12 cents a share, from $18.6 million, or 40 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding a $19.6 million impairment charge, the company would have earned 55 cents a share. Sales climbed 8% to $655 million. The average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for earnings of 54 cents a share and sales of $652 million. The company updated its outlook for the fourth quarter. It said it now expects revenue in the range of $663 million to $675 million, same-store sales flat to 2% higher and earnings in the range of 53 cents to 60 cents a share. It left its fiscal-year outlook unchanged. WellPoint tweaks full-year profit outlook (6:23 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- WellPoint Inc. WLP said it's raised its 2007 profit outlook. As revised, the health-benefits company now expects net income of $5.54 a share for the year, representing 15% growth over 2006. The company also anticipates generating earnings of $1.35 a share for the second quarter. Analysts' average forecasts, as compiled by Thomson Financial, stand at $1.36 a share for the current quarter and $5.55 a share for the year. In addition, WellPoint's now shooting for full-year operating revenue of about $61.1 billion, with yearend medical enrollment pegged at 35.5 million members, up by 4% or 1.4 million members for 2007. Analysts are, on average, looking for revenue of nearly $62 billion. The company also said it plans to exhaust during 2007 the remaining $2.3 billion in stock repurchases as authorized by the WellPoint board, subject to market conditions. PRA International profit halves after restructuring charge (6:17 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Clinical research group PRA International PRAI said Wednesday that its first-quarter net profit roughly halved to $3 million, or 12 cents a share, from $6.1 million, or 25 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue at the group rose 23% to $85.1 million. Excluding restructuring and amortization charges, earnings for the quarter were 17 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting earnings of 19 cents a share on revenue of $85 million. Gross new business awards in the quarter rose 44% to $125 million. PRA reiterated its 2007 guidance for earnings of 48 cents to 58 cents a share. Adjusted earnings for the year are expected to be in the range of 80 cents to 90 cents a share. WellPoint's net income rises 7% (6:13 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- WellPoint Inc. WLP reported first-quarter net income of $783.1 million, or $1.26 a share, up from $731.8 million, or $1.09 a share, earned in the same period during 2006. Quarterly revenue reached $15.08 billion, up from the prior year's $13.84 billion, as premiums rose 9.4% to $13.76 billion. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of $1.26 a share on revenue of $15.08 billion, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. There were some 6.9% fewer diluted shares outstanding in the latest quarter. Indianapolis-based WellPoint also said medical enrollment totaled 34.9 million members as of the end of March, up 717,000 from the same date in 2006. The company's benefit expense as a percentage of premiums increased to 83.1% from 81.3% in the 2006 first quarter. Shares of WellPoint lost 72 cents to end Tuesday's trading at $82.24. Praxair quarterly profit rose 18%, tops consensus forecasts (6:12 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Praxair, Inc. PX, +1.51% an industrial gas company, said first-quarter net income rose 18% to $265 million, or 81 cents a share, from $225 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales climbed 7% to $2.2 billion, due to higher overall pricing and volumes across all major end markets. The average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for earnings of 80 cents a share and sales of $2.2 billion. Praxair said it expects second-quarter earnings in the range of 83 cents to 87 cents a share. For 2007, the company sees sales growth of 8% to 10% and earnings in the range of $3.35 to $3.50 a share. Becton, Dickinson profit jumps 57% (5:57 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Medical products manufacturer Becton, Dickinson and Co. BDX, +2.01% said its fiscal second-quarter net income rose 57.4% to $242.5 million, or 95 cents a share, from $154.1 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the three months ending March 31 grew 10.7% to $1.58 billion, helped by a favorable currency impact of around 3%. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting earnings of 91 cents a share on revenue of $1.57 billion. Earnings from continuing operations rose 12% to 92 cents a share. The firm said revenue rose across all its medical, diagnostics and biosciences divisions. Becton, Dickinson said it expects earnings per share from continuing operations for fiscal 2007 to be in the range of $3.76 to $3.80 a share. Arkansas Best profit drops on tonnage decline, pension deal (4:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Arkansas Best ABFS said its first-quarter net income dropped 22% to $4.8 million, or 19 cents a share, as tonnage declines at its ABF Freight Systems unit continued into 2007. The quarter also included a 3 cents a share charge for pension settlement accounting. Revenue fell to $422.6 million from $425 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 15 cents a share. Game Group profit soars after new console launches (2:57 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. computer and video game retailer Game Group GMG, -0.12% said Wednesday that its net profit for the year ended Jan. 31 jumped to 21.1 million pounds ($42.2 million) from 2.7 million pounds as sales grew 24.2% to 801.3 million pounds. Like-for-like sales rose 16.2%. The company said sales growth was helped by the launch of new products, including Nintendo's Wii console and the improved supply of Microsoft's MSFT, +2.10% Xbox360 console. Gross margin edged up to 27.2% from 27.0% as better use of promotions helped offset a higher proportion of hardware sales, which have a lower margin. The group said like-for-like sales in the 12 weeks to April 21 were up 44% due to the launch of Sony's PS3 machine. Baker Hughes reports 10% profit rise, 20% revenue climb (2:57 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Baker Hughes BHI, +4.27% said its first-quarter net income rose 10% to $365 million, or $1.17 a share, with revenue up 20% to $2.47 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of $1.10 a share. The oil services group said revenue outside North America should grow between 19% and 21% in 2007, while U.S. revenue is expected to rise 7%. Capital spending is expected to be between $1.0 billion and $1.2 billion, it added. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - AmerisourceBergen Corp. closed down more than 7% Wednesday after the drug distributor posted a slight rise in second-quarter profit but said one of its facilities has been temporarily barred from distributing certain controlled substances and chemicals. Shares of AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% fell $4.04, or 7.2%, to finish the session at $52.32. DEA action The Drug Enforcement Administration has temporarily suspended the license of AmerisourceBergen's distribution center in Orlando, Fla., related to DEA controlled substances and listed chemicals, claiming the company failed to prevent controlled substances, specifically the cough suppressant and painkiller hydrocodone, from reaching four Internet pharmacies from Jan. 1, 2006 through Jan. 31, 2007. Hydrocodone is sold under the brand names Vicodin and Lortab and its abuse, according to the DEA, has been escalating in recent years. AmerisourceBergen said it's not doing business with any of the four customers cited by the agency; all of them held active DEA licenses to sell controlled substances at the time AmerisourceBergen sold product to them, the company said. The suspension could affect some 1,400 customers in Florida, the company said late Tuesday. Alternative arrangements will be made for affected customers if the suspension isn't lifted soon. "We do not expect this temporary suspension to have a material impact on earnings," Chief Executive David Yost said on a conference call. A.G. Edwards analyst Andrew Speller said that although consolidated operations won't be materially impacted, "...we believe investors fear that the DEA may shut down other AmerisourceBergen facilities due to what is alleged to be ineffective controls against diversion of controlled substances," he wrote in a research note to clients. Quarterly numbers On Wednesday, Valley Forge, Pa.-based AmerisourceBergen posted net income of $129.5 million, or 68 cents a share, For the quarter ended March 31, up from $129 million, or 61 cents, earned in the second quarter of fiscal 2006. The year-earlier quarter's profit included a gain of 6 cents a share for various items. Quarterly revenue jumped to $16.51 billion, up from the prior year's $15.22 billion. Operating revenue was $15.28 billion, 9% higher than the nearly $14.1 billion in the year-ago quarter. Analysts, on average, had been anticipating that the drug wholesaler would turn in earnings of 67 cents a share on revenue of $16.7 billion, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. Earnings in the company's PharMerica business lagged in the second quarter due to lower-than-expected performance in the PMSI workers' compensation business, which was attributed to increased competitive pressure on customer pricing. The PharMerica business consists of the PharMerica Long Term Care institutional pharmacy business, which is being spun off in combination with the comparable division at Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% to form a stand-alone institutional pharmacy, and PMSI, the workers' compensation business. "AmerisourceBergen's gross margin was essentially flat year over year, which masked improvements for its core distribution business," Banc of America analyst Robert Willoughby said in a research note, taking his price target on the stock to $53 from $49. There were about 9% fewer average shares outstanding in the latest quarter than a year earlier, the company's results showed. Citing a gain related to an antitrust settlement, AmerisourceBergen also raised its fiscal 2007 forecast for net earnings to a range of $2.50 to $2.65 a share from $2.45 to $2.60 a share. The Thomson Financial-derived average estimate stands at $2.58 a share. title: AmerisourceBergen profit rises, license suspended

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% on Wednesday said fiscal second-quarter net income rose to $129.5 million, or 68 cents a share, from $129 million, or 61 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Total revenue rose to $16.51 billion from $15.22 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 67 cents a share on revenue of $16.7 billion, according to Thomson Financial. Citing a gain related to an antitrust settlement, the drug wholesaler raised its forecast for fiscal 2007 to a range of $2.50 to $2.65 a share from a range of $2.45 to $2.60. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expect it to earn $2.58 a share for the year, on average.
title: AmerisourceBergen profit rises

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% late Tuesday said the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration temporarily suspended its Orlando distribution center's license to distribute DEA-controlled substances and listed chemicals. The company said the agency asserted that AmerisourceBergen didn't maintain effective controls against diversion of controlled substances, specifically hydrocodone, to four Internet pharmacies between Jan. 1, 2006 and Jan. 31, 2007. AmerisourceBergen, which said it will cooperate to resolve the temporary suspension, noted that it is not doing business with any of the four customers cited by the DEA, and all of the pharmacies mentioned held active DEA licenses to sell controlled substances at the time AmerisourceBergen sold products to them. -Contact: 201-938-5400 More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers

content: AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% acquired privately held Xcenda LLC, a Tampa pharmaceutical services company, for about $25 million. The company said Xcenda joins its AmerisourceBergen Specialty Group unit and will enhance its existing manufacturer services businesses. AmerisourceBergen, a Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical service company, expects the acquisition to be immaterial to its fiscal 2007 earnings. -Contact: 201-938-5400 More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle
title: AmerisourceBergen to buy Xcenda LLC for $25 mln cash

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cardinal Health Inc. on Thursday said its net earnings in the latest quarter more than doubled as a result of the previously announced divestiture of its pharmaceutical technologies and services unit. Separately, the health-care products and services provider CAH, +0.94% said it has agreed to sell the business to private equity company Blackstone Group for $3.3 billion in cash. The sale is expected close early in Cardinal's fiscal fourth quarter. "Both the price and the timing are very positive signs for the company," Deutsche Bank analyst Ross Muken wrote in a research note, "as the price is well above Street expectations and the timing is far earlier than the expected mid-calendar 2007 timeframe." Cardinal unveiled plans to divest its PTS unit and focus on its core businesses at the end of November. The unit employs more than 10,000 people around the world and has a net book value of roughly $2 billion. See full story. Shares rose 3.4% to close at $72.42. Dublin, Ohio-based Cardinal, best known for its drug-distribution business, reported net income rose of $739.3 million, or $1.80 a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31, up from $304 million, or 70 cents, earned in the same period during fiscal 2006. The latest profit included a $425-million tax gain from the planned sale of its pharmaceutical technologies and services, or PTS, business. On a continuing-operations basis, earnings amounted to 77 cents a share, and Cardinal said it earned 83 cents a share excluding special items. Revenue rose to $21.78 billion from $19.35 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting Cardinal to report earnings of 78 cents a share on revenue of $21.52 billion. In its health-care supply chain services-pharmaceutical segment, quarterly revenue grew 13%, while revenue in its health-care supply chain services-medical segment rose 6%. The company's clinical technologies and services division posted a 10% revenue gain, and revenue in the medical products manufacturing segment rose 15% in the quarter. On Thursday the company also said it agreed to buy SpecialtyScripts Pharmacy in a move to broaden its specialty pharmaceutical service offerings for drugmakers. Terms were not disclosed, but Chief Executive Kerry Clark on a related conference call called the acquisition "relatively small, but strategic." Cardinal Health also backed its profit forecast of $3.25 to $3.40 a share for fiscal 2007, excluding the impact of proceeds from the sale of its PTS business. Analysts are currently looking for $3.36 a share in earnings, on average. A day earlier, fellow drug wholesaler AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said its profit rose 26% in the latest quarter. The company also lifted its full-year earnings outlook above the average forecast on Wall Street. See full story. Robert Baird analyst Eric Coldwell subsequently lifted AmerisourceBergen's price target to $59 from $55 and reiterated a rating of outperform; the stock ended the session at $53.02, up 2%. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid
title: Cardinal Health profit more than doubles on unit sale

content: Cabot quarterly income rises; revenue gains (10:07 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cabot Corp. CBT, +2.14% Wednesday evening said first-quarter net income grew, as revenue gained, to $54 million, or 79 cents a share, from $24 million, or 35 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. The Boston-based specialty chemicals company said quarterly revenue increased to $655 million from $587 million in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected revenue of $629 million. Cabot added that some of the benefits experienced during the first quarter are "unlikely to be sustained," and said certain items added to earnings by 20 cents to 25 cents per share. Swift quarterly income falls; revenue declines (8:53 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Swift Transportation Co. SWFT Wednesday evening said fourth-quarter net income fell, as revenue declined, to $23.4 million, or 31 cents a share, from $39.3 million, or 53 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year.
