Revenue rose to $5.63 billion from $5.06 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 61 cents a share on revenue of $5.67 billion. Global same-store sales rose 6.3%. Piper Jaffray earnings lifted by higher-than-expected revs (8:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Piper Jaffray Cos. PJC, +3.10% said it earned $20.6 million, or $1.15 a share, in the fourth quarter, up from $16.4 million, or 87 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Earnings from continuing operations rose to $1.49 a share, including a 73 cents benefit from a reduction in a litigation reserve. Revenue rose 24% to $146.6 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 70 cents a share, on revenue of $127.4 million. Investment banking revenue rose 25% to $91.7 million, as equity financing revenue rose 60%, advisory services revenue climbed 8% and fixed income financing revenue rose 19%. Shares closed Tuesday up 1.6% at $70.99. Abbott Labs swings to loss on acquisition-related charge (8:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Abbott Laboratories ABT, +1.16% Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $476.2 million, or 31 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $976.4 million, or 63 cents a share. Excluding items in both periods, the company earned $1.15 billion, or 75 cents a share, in the latest quarter, down slightly from a profit of $1.18 billion, or 76 cents a share, last year. Items in the latest quarter included a charge of $1.3 billion, or 85 cents a share, related to the company's Kos acquisition, as well as costs related to asset impairment from the generic introduction of Biazin XL, intellectual property litigation and acquisition integration activities. The company also noted the latest results include stock compensation expense totaling $40 million, or 3 cents a share. Sales increased 2.8% in the latest three months to $6.22 billion from $6.05 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 74 cents a share in the December period on revenue of $6.18 billion. Looking ahead, the company forecast operating earnings of $2.77 to $2.83 a share for 2007. Including an anticipated net gain of $2 per share related to the planned sale of its core laboratory and point of care diagnostic businesses to General Electric, partially offset by costs from acquisition integration and other activities, it sees GAAP (generally accepted accounting principles) earnings of $4.77 to $4.83 a share for the year. The company expects sales growth of 13% to 15% in 2007 with global sales of Humira, a treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, projected to exceed $2.7 billion. The stock closed Tuesday at $53.38, up 6 cents. ExpressJet net income falls 8% (8:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - ExpressJet Holdings Inc. XJT said Wednesday its fourth-quarter net income fell 8.3% to $22.8 million, or 39 cents a share, from $24.9 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue at the Houston-based regional airline, which operates flights for Continental Airlines Inc. CAL, -0.62% rose 5.1% in the three months ended Dec. 31 to $425.8 million from $405 million. ExpressJet said it and Continental have agreed to submit their 2007 rates dispute to binding arbitration. Express Scripts sends proxy materials to Caremark holders (8:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Pharmacy-benefits manager Express Scripts Inc. ESRX, -0.93% on Wednesday said it will send its proxy materials to shareholders of larger rival Caremark Rx Inc. CMX, -9.09% in connection with Caremark's special shareholders meeting scheduled for Feb. 20. Express Scripts is seeking to acquire Caremark, despite an existing bid from drug store operator CVS Corp. CVS, -0.80% St. Louis-based Express Scripts urged Caremark shareholders to vote against CVS' offer and criticized the Caremark board for refusing to engage in talks. Allegheny Tech fourth-quarter net $167.1 mln vs $118.8 mln (7:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Allegheny Technologies Inc. ATI, +3.91% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $167.1 million, or $1.63 a share, up from a year-ago profit of $118.8 million, or $1.17 a share. Last year's results included a gain of $20.9 million, or 21 cents a share. Sales jumped 56% in the latest three months to $1.4 billion from $894.4 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of $1.61 a share in the December period on sales of $1.26 billion. Looking ahead, the Pittsburgh-based specialty metals producer said it expects capital spending of between $400 million and $450 million in 2007, excluding expansion of its STAL joint venture in China. The stock closed Tuesday at $94.38, up 2.4%. McCormick net income slips, sales rise (7:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - McCormick & Co. MKC, +0.42% on Wednesday said its fourth-quarter net income fell to $83.1 million, or 62 cents a share, from $88.1 million, or 65 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding charges related to its restructuring and other items, the company earned 72 cents a share. Net sales rose to $803.7 million from $737.1 million. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 70 cents a share on revenue of $782 million, according to Thomson First Call. The Sparks, Md.-based spice maker expects 2007 sales to grow in the 4% to 6% range. Profit for the year, including restructuring charges, is expected to be $1.67 to $1.71 a share. AmerisourceBergen lifts fiscal 2007 earnings view (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Wednesday reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $122.2 million, or 63 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $97.3 million, or 46 cents a share. Total revenue, including bulk deliveries to customer warehouses, rose 14% to $16.73 billion in the latest three months from $14.65 billion in the same period a year earlier. Operating revenue jumped 16% in the quarter to $15.7 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 56 cents a share in the December period on revenue of $16.93 billion. The Valley Forge, Pa., drug services provider attributed the year-over-year profit growth to a strong performance in its traditional distribution business and continued strength in its specialty distribution business. Looking ahead, the company lifted its earnings outlook for fiscal 2007 to $2.45 to $2.60 a share from its previous projection of $2.40 to $2.55 a share. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for earnings of $2.50 a share for the year. AmerisourceBergen sees operating revenue growth of 9% to 11% for the year. It also disclosed plans to buy back between $450 million and %500 million worth of its common stock in fiscal 2007. The stock closed Tuesday at $48.07, up 1.1%. Unisys earns 6 cents a share vs. First Call 5 cents (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Unisys Corp. UIS, +2.38% said it earned $21.3 million, or 6 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, after a loss of $31.1 million, or 9 cents a share, in the same period a year ago, with the turnaround partly due to restructuring measures. Revenue fell 1% to $1.55 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 5 cents a share on revenue of $1.557 billion. Blue Bell, Pa.-based Unisys said it's still targeting a total of 5,600 job cuts as part of its restructuring program and has cut 4,900 of those so far. It is aiming to cut about 450 jobs in the first quarter and the remaining 250 in the second quarter. The company expects cuts made in 2006 to generate savings of about $280 million in 2007. Shares closed Tuesday down 1% at $8.13. Ashland profit drops 26% on industrial production softness (7:13 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Ashland Inc. ASH, +1.04% reported a 26% profit decline to $49 million, or 75 cents a share, while revenue rose 7% to $1.81 billion. The chemicals company said excluding adjustments for selling Ashland Paving and Construction, it would've earned 81 cents a share. Softness in U.S. industrial production adversely affected Ashland Distribution's results, the company said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 76 cents a share. Hershey profit and sales slide (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Hershey Co. HSY, +0.72% on Wednesday said fourth-quarter net income fell to $153.6 million, or 65 cents a share, from $170.4 million, or 69 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Results include 2 cents a share in charges relates to its business realignment plan. Net sales fell to $1.34 billion from $1.35 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 71 cents a share on revenue of $1.37 billion, according to Thomson First Call. The chocolate and candy maker backed its long-term expectations of sales growth of 3% to 4% and per-share profit growth from operations of 9% to 11%. For 2007, Hershey forecast net sales growth in the 3% to 4% range, and earnings per share from operations in the 7% to 9% range. Smurfit-Stone swings to profit as revenue rises (6:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Smurfit-Stone Container SSCI, +0.49% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $22 million, or 9 cents a share, vs. a loss of $92 million, or 36 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding a charge from the closure of container plants and headcount reductions and a gain related to foreign currency translation, earnings would have been 8 cents a share. Revenue rose to $1.82 billion from last year's $1.65 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 6 cents a share and revenue of $1.77 billion, on average. The Chicago packaging company said it expects first-quarter results to be hurt by lower mill production, higher energy use, increasing fiber costs and the timing of employee benefit expenses, but sees earnings rebounding in the second quarter. The stock closed Tuesday up 14 cents at $10.23. Corning swings to profit, beats expectations (6:53 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Corning Inc. GLW, +1.94% said it swung to a fourth-quarter net profit of $646 million, or 41 cents a share, from a year-ago loss of $33 million, or 2 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter rose 14.1% to $1.37 billion. Excluding one-off items, Corning said it earned $488 million, or 31 cents a share in the quarter, exceeding its own guidance and the 28 cents-a-share estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The materials and fiber optics group said it expects the overall market for LCD glass substrate to grow in the mid-30 percent range, driven by continued demand for LCD televisions, and added its own LCD glass volume is expected to grow at the upper end of this range. The firm added it expects to see significant growth in its heavy-duty diesel products, due to new U.S. emissions regulations that became effective Jan. 1. Overall, Corning said it expects first quarter sales to be in the range of $1.26 billion to $1.31 billion, with earnings in the range of 24 cents to 27 cents a share. Terra Industries sees quarterly revenue down 5%, profit flat (6:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Terra Industries Inc. TRA, +6.67% said it expects fourth-quarter revenue to be around 5% lower than the $464.8 million it reported in the third quarter due to lower revenue from methanol products. The fertilizer producer said net income for the quarter should be roughly flat from the third quarter as a higher income tax expense offsets higher gross profit per ton from its major fertilizer products. Separately the firm said its Terra Capital subsidiary will issue $330 million of senior notes due in 2017. Terr said it will sue the proceeds to repay existing notes as well as to pay related premiums, fees and expenses pursuant to a cash tender offer announced earlier in January. First Cash profit grows 26%, plans new stores (6:27 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- First Cash Financial Services Inc. FCFS, +2.01% said its fourth-quarter net profit rose 25.5% to $9.7 million, or 30 cents a share, from $7.7 million, or 23 cents a share a year ago. Revenue at the pawn store and check-cashing company rose 46.6% to $88.2 million, with same-store revenue rising 9%. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 30 cents a share on revenue of $84 million. The firm also reaffirmed its guidance for 2007 earnings in a range of $1.25 to $1.30 a share. First Cash said it plans to open a combination of 75 to 80 pawn and cash advance stores in 2007, alongside 3 to 5 new Auto Master dealerships. Air Products 1st-quarter net up 27%; year outlook increased (6:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Air Products & Chemicals Inc., APD, +1.24% the Lehigh Valley, Pa., producer of atmospheric, process and specialty gases, performance materials, and equipment and services, reported that first-quarter earnings rose 27% on 21% higher revenue. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, net income reached $230.3 million, or $1.03 a share, from $180.7 million, or 80 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $2.43 billion from $2.02 billion. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced consensus estimates of 93 cents of profit on $2.29 billion of revenue. Air Products estimated fiscal second-quarter earnings would range 98 cents to $1.03 a share. First Call estimates 98 cents. And the company increased its outlook for fiscal 2007 earnings to $3.98 to $4.10 a share, compared with fiscal 2006's $3.29. The year-ago figure is $3.50, adjusted for a cost-reduction plan. For fiscal 2007, First Call projects $3.96. (Adds fiscal 2007 First Call estimate.) Regis Corp.'s CEO 'encouraged' about prospects for recovery (6:20 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Regis Corp. RGS, -0.98% reported net income of $26.9 million for the second quarter ended Dec. 31, off from $27.3 million in the same period in fiscal 2006. Earnings per share were 59 cents in both reporting periods, reflecting slightly fewer average shares outstanding in the latest quarter. On an adjusted basis to exclude a tax benefit, Regis said it earned 54 cents a share in the latest quarter. As previously reported, the Minneapolis-based operator of hair-care salons generated quarterly revenue of $657 million, up 8% from the prior year's $606.6 million. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of 54 cents a share on revenue of $655 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. "We are encouraged by the initial signs of recovery in our business," said Paul Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive. For the third quarter, management pegged the company's earnings at 50 cents to 56 cents a share, with full-year profit projected at $2.10 to $2.24 a share. The First Call-derived average forecasts stand at 53 cents and $2.18 a share, respectively. Shares of Regis added 32 cents to end Tuesday's trading at $40.62. Wellpoint profit climbs 23% in line with expectations (6:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Health benefits company Wellpoint Inc. WLP said its fourth-quarter net income rose 22.9% to $801.1 million, or $1.28 a share, from $652 million, $1.04 a share a year ago. Total operating revenue at the firm rose 28.7% to $14.32 billion, driven by new enrollments, pricing discipline and the addition of the New York state prescription drug contract in 2006. The firm said its profit included 1 cent a share of net investment gains. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of $1.27 a share on revenue of $14.51 billion. Wellpoint said it continues to expect 2007 earnings of $5.53 a share, with operating revenue of around $61.9 billion. The company also said it expects to return excess capital to shareholders in 2007 through its share buyback program. Praxair profit climbs on higher margin business, cost cuts (6:11 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Industrial gasses firm Praxair Inc. PX, +1.51% said fourth-quarter net income rose to $269 million, or 82 cents a share, from $214 million, or 65 cents a share, with sales climbing to $2.12 billion from $2.02 billion. A mix of higher-margin business and substantial cost savings from productivity programs lifted profit, the company said. It expects earnings of $3.30 to $3.45 a share in 2007 on revenue growth between 8% and 10%. Analysts polled by Thomson First call expected earnings of 78 cents in the fourth quarter and $3.38 for 2007. SAP: license restatement is bookkeeping issue (4:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Business software provider SAP AG SAP, +1.13% (DE:716460)said Wednesday that the 30 million euro ($39 million) restatement of its third-quarter license revenue was a bookkeeping issue that would not impact cash flow at the firm. SAP said the restatement was due to a new contract with a U.S. customer that was undergoing a major restructure. SAP said it replaced existing contracts with a new contract allowing the customer to give back previously purchased software, which could then be repurchased by the customer at a future date. SAP added it did not return any cash to the customer and will book the sales when the customer repurchases the software. Arkansas Best profit declines on trucking industry downturn (4:14 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Transportation holding company Arkansas Best ABFS said fourth-quarter net income dropped to $14.2 million, or 56 cents a share, from $30.2 million, or $1.20 a share, with revenue declining to $449 million from $467 million. A "sudden and dramatic" reduction in business during October and partly in November that mirrored conditions throughout the trucking industry hurt the firm. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 90 cents a share. Yahoo Japan reports fiscal third-quarter net rises 20% (3:07 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Yahoo Japan Corp. [ s: jp:4689] said Wednesday strong performance at its online shopping and auction businesses helped lift group net profit 20% in the December-ending fiscal quarter. Net profit for the third fiscal quarter rose to 15.17 billion yen ($125.39 million) from 12.65 billion yen in the year-ago period. Revenue for the period increased to 54.52 billion yen from 46.62 billion yen a year earlier. The internet firm forecast group net profit of between 14.25 billion yen and 15 billion yen for March-ending quarter. The company said online advertising revenue amounted to about 40% of income, however total advertising decreased as a portion of overall sales owing to lower fees and stagnant growth in the national advertising market. Revenue from its job search and real estate operations, as well as its online auction service, helped offset the drop in advertising revenue. Yahoo Japan's online auction service is a market leader in Japan. Yahoo Japan's two major stake holders are Softbank Corp. with a 41% shares and U.S Yahoo which holds a 33% stake. Oberthur sales up 15%, sees second half profit topping first (2:32 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oberthur Card Systems(FR:012413)said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter sales rose 15.4% to 155 million euros ($201 million) due to increased demand from the payments and mobile communications industry. Oberthur, which manufactures SIM cards for mobile phones as well as credit cards, said the volume of cards shipped in the quarter rose 53% to 89 million units. Sales in the mobile sector were driven by higher demand in the U.S. and South America, while demand for payment cards was strongest in Europe. The company said it profit in the second half of the year will exceed the first half after it recovered from a slump in trading. Oberthur added it plans to pursue a cost-cutting plan in 2007 to offset continued price pressure. SAP: 2007 operating margin to fall on mid-market investment (2:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Computer software maker SAP SAP, +1.13% (DE:716460)said 2007 operating margins would fall, as the company invests 300 million to 400 million euros ($518 million) over the next eight quarters to address additional opportunities in the mid-market segment. Operating margin will fall to between 26% and 27%, from 27.3% in 2006, with license revenue up 12% to 14% at constant currencies, compared to 12% growth in 2006. The company reported fourth-quarter profit and sales figures in line with its warning from a few weeks ago, with net income up 29% to 799 million euros, and revenue up 7% to 3 billion euros. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Don’t ever do this with your credit card Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Adobe Inc. ADBE, +1.67% shares rose 5.8% Wednesday after the company named Mark Garrett, an EMC Corp. EMC, +9.92% executive, as its new chief financial officer, more than two weeks after the software maker said it had completed an internal review of its stock-options practices. See full story. Affymax Inc. AFFY, +0.65% shares rose 6.1% after the company was initiated with an outperform rating at Cowen & Co. RBC Capital Markets also began coverage of the company with an outperform rating and set a $44 price target. Albemarle Corp. ALB, +3.55% shares added 6.6% after the company reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $63 million, or $1.29 a share, compared with $32.2 million, or 67 cents a share, on the back of a $5.4 million tax benefit and lower costs of good sold. Allegheny Technologies Inc. ATI, +3.91% shares gained 5.6% after the company posted a 41% surge in fourth-quarter profit on the back of strong demand for titanium and nickel alloys from the aerospace and defense markets. See full story. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% shares rallied up 8.1% after the pharmaceutical services company posted a 26% rise in first-quarter profit and lifted its 2007 earnings outlook above Wall Street's forecast. See full story. Ametek AME, +1.36% shares advanced 6.4% after the Paoli, Pa., maker of electronic instruments posted a fourth-quarter profit of $47.8 million, or 45 cents a share, up from year-ago earnings of $36.9 million, or 35 cents a share. Sales rose 19% in the quarter to $480.7 million. The company sees earnings of $1.93 to $1.97 a share for fiscal 2007, surrounding Wall Street's current consensus estimate of $1.95 a share. Artic Cat ACAT, +0.00% shares rose 8.6% after the Thief River Falls, Minn., maker of snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles reported third-quarter earnings of $8.2 million, or 43 cents a share, on sales of $228.1 million. These results include 2 cents a share in stock option expense and an income tax benefit of 3 cents a share. Conolog Corp. CNLG shares soared 86% after the company said its CM-100 direct substation communicator system has received final testing approval. The CM-100 is scheduled to ensure delivery to customers by the third quarter, the company said. Conolog makes electronic and electromagnetic components and subassemblies for telephones, radio and microwave transmissions. Corning Inc. GLW, +1.94% said it swung to a fourth-quarter net profit of $646 million, or 41 cents a share, from a year-ago loss of $33 million, or 2 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter rose 14.1% to $1.37 billion. Excluding one-off items, Corning said it earned $488 million, or 31 cents a share in the quarter, exceeding its own guidance and the 28 cents-a-share estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The materials and fiber optics group said it expects the overall market for LCD glass substrate to grow in the mid-30 percent range, driven by continued demand for LCD televisions, and added its own LCD glass volume is expected to grow at the upper end of this range. The firm added it expects to see significant growth in its heavy-duty diesel products, due to new U.S. emissions regulations that became effective Jan. 1. Overall, Corning said it expects first quarter sales to be in the range of $1.26 billion to $1.31 billion, with earnings in the range of 24 to 27 cents a share. EZCorp EZPW, +1.54% shares jumped 12% after the Austin, Texas-based provider of credit and other financial services late Tuesday reported fiscal first-quarter net earnings of $9.76 million, or 23 cents a share, up from $6.76 million, or 17 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $91.7 million from $75.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast a per-share profit of 20 cents on revenue of $85.5 million. The company expects fiscal second-quarter earnings of 23 cents a share, and fiscal 2007 earnings of 85 cents a share. Hyperion Solutions Corp. HYSL shares moved up 18% after the company agreed to acquire privately held Decisioneering Inc. to gain access to its risk analysis software. Hyperion, a business management software maker, which employs 2,700 workers, plans to run Decisioneering, which employs 75 workers, as an independent unit in Denver. No job cuts are expected. Hyperion declined to disclose the terms of the deal, which is expected to close within the next month. The company also said its second-quarter earnings rose 34%, boosted by growth in software license and maintenance and service revenue. The company had second-quarter earnings of $21.5 million, or 36 cents a share, compared with $15.5 million, or 25 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 rose 20% to $222.9 million from $185.5 million a year ago. Software license revenue rose 14% to $84.9 million, and maintenance and service revenue rose 24% to $138 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial expected, on average, earnings of 44 cents a share on revenue of $212 million. Integrated Device Technology Inc. IDTI, +2.96% IDT, -4.57% shares added 5.6% after the company reported a third-quarter net loss of $1.94 million, or a penny a share, down from $42.3 million, or 21 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Introgen Therapeutics Inc. INGN, +2.56% shares moved up 7.9% after the company said Wednesday a preclinical study with INGN 241 in combination with Genentech Inc.'s DNA, -1.03% Avastin showed "synergistic activity" resulting in "a curative therapeutic effect" in the treatment of lung cancer. The new data were published in the journal Molecular Therapy. Introgen said the study showed that the combination of INGN 241 and Avastin was "very effective" and blocked tumor angiogenesis. In the study, tumors completely regressed within the first four weeks of treatment and no additional growth was observed after cessation of therapy, the company said. Level 3 Communications LVLT shares gained 5.2% after the company was initiated with an outperform rating at Cowen & Co. National Interstate's NATL, +2.86% shares advanced 23% after the Richfield, Ohio-based insurance company late Tuesday forecast fourth-quarter net income in a range of 54 cents to 60 cents a share and full-year 2006 net income of $1.80 to $1.86 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for fourth-quarter earnings of 51 cents a share and 2006 earnings of $1.75 a share. The company expects gross premiums written of $61.5 million in the fourth quarter, and $305.5 million for 2006. OSI Systems OSIS, +2.61% shares added 6.5% after the company said it expects revenue of about $137 million for the second quarter, a level that would represent growth of 17% from year-ago levels. The company also disclosed plans for a restructuring, saying it will reduce its global workforce by 8% and consolidate certain facilities. It's targeting annual cost savings of between $15 million and $17 million from these moves. OSI expects to record a charge of between $31 million and $34 million in the second quarter from asset impairment and the recording of additional inventory reserves. Excluding items, it sees a breakeven performance in the quarter on an operating basis. Hawthorne, Calif.-based OSI withdrew its earnings outlook for fiscal 2007 but backed a forecast for revenue of between $535 million and $545 million for the year. Shares of Parametric Technology Corp. PMTC rose 7.2% after the business software maker reported that its fiscal first quarter earnings doubled compared to the year-earlier period. PTC said GAAP net income rose to $15.2 million, or 13 cents per diluted share, compared to $7.5 million, or seven cents per diluted share in the year-earlier period. Revenue grew 15% to $221.7 million, the company said, while total software license revenue grew 14% to $66.6 million. RF Micro Devices RFMD shares surged 14% after the company said fiscal third-quarter net income rose sharply to $59.3 million, or 26 cents a share, from $14.7 million, or 7 cents a share, a year earlier. The Greensboro, N.C., mobile communications technology company said results were driven by strength at the world's leading handset manufacturers, market share gains in RF semiconductors and high demand for the company's cellular transceivers and transmit modules. Results from the latest quarter included other income of $1.3 million, whereas the year-ago quarter included other income of $298,000. Excluding items such as share-based compensation, amortization, an impairment charge, a gain on sale of substantially all Bluetooth assets, and restructuring charges related to sale of substantially all Bluetooth assets RF Micro Devices earned 16 cents a share, up from 8 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 rose 35% to $281.1 million from $208 million. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 13 cents a share on revenue of $273.2 million. Third-quarter results also beat the company's internal projections. Rockwell Medical Technologies' RMTI, -1.70% shares rose 11% after the Wixom, Mich.-based pharmaceutical company reported favorable results from pre-clinical safety studies for its iron-delivery product, soluble ferric pyrophosphate. Rockwell said it's preparing to begin human clinical trials consisting of a nine-month dose ranging study followed by a final clinical study. Upon favorable results, the company said it expects to receive Food and Drug Administration market approval for SFP sometime thereafter. Seagate Technology STX, +2.87% shares added 8.3% after the company said its fiscal second-quarter net income fell 51.2% to $140 million, or 23 cents a share, from $287 million, or 57 cents a share a year ago. Excluding a $76 million charge related to an acquisition of Maxtor and $29 million for the early retirement of 8% notes, earnings were $236 million, or 39 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 29 increased 30.3% to $3 billion from $2.3 billion a year earlier, said the Scotts Valley, Calif., provider of hard disc drives. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial predicted second-quarter earnings of 32 cents a share, on revenue of $2.93 million. Analyst estimates exclude integration and retention costs and amortization of intangibles. Sun Micro SUNW, +5.56% shares surged 8.5% after the hardware maker issued an upbeat fiscal second-quarter report and bullish forecast. See full story. Transcend Services' TRCR shares jumped 37% after the Atlanta-based company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $762,000, or 10 cents a share. In the same quarter last year, the company posted a net loss of $444,000, or 6 cents a share. Revenue rose to $8.95 million from $7.3 million. Transcend Services provides medical transcription services to the healthcare industry. TransDigm Group TDG, +2.04% shares leapt 12% after the Cleveland-based maker of aircraft components forecast fiscal first-quarter net earnings of 43 cents a share, or adjusted earnings of 46 cents a share, on revenue of $123 million. TransDigm also said it now expects fiscal 2007 earnings of $1.68 to $1.80 a share, or adjusted earnings of $1.79 to $1.91 a share, on revenue of $500 million to $510 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are forecasting 2007 earnings of $1.68 a share on revenue of $533 million. TRM Corp. TRMM, +0.00% shares rocketed up 50% after the company said it's sold its TRM Ltd. unit, which owns its ATM business in the U.K. and Germany, to NoteMachine Ltd. for 47.1 million pounds ($92.6 million). Portland, Ore.-based TRM said net proceeds from the sale were used to pay down debt. NoteMachine is a portfolio company of Rutland Partners LLP, a private equity partnership. "The sale of our European ATM business is a component of our ongoing efforts to simplify our business operations," said Jeff Brotman, TRM president and chief executive, in a statement. Vertrue VTRU shares rose 9.2% after the Norwalk, Conn.-based Internet marketer reported fiscal second-quarter net earnings of $8.7 million, or 74 cents a share, up from $7.66 million, or 66 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $178.6 million from $160.1 million. The company expects fiscal 2007 earnings of $3.30 to $3.40 a share on revenue of $748 million to $758 million. Yahoo YHOO shares added 7.5% after the company reported fourth-quarter profit plunged 61% from a year ago, when it booked a large one-time investment gain. The Internet bellwether was also hurt by higher costs for employee stock options. See full story. Decliners Advanced Micro Devices AMD, +2.45% shares tumbled 8.5% Wednesday, hit by a rash of analyst downgrades, after the world's No. 2 maker of chips in PCs and corporate servers signaled its profit margins are suffering.. See full story. Cognex Corp. CGNX, +2.40% shares lost 5.2% after the company was downgraded to market perform from outperform at Barrington Research. GeoMet GMET, -14.89% shares dropped 6.8% after the company said late Tuesday it was hit with unfavorable litigation results in two separate matters. First, the company disclosed a temporary injunction was issued against it in Tazewell County, Va., that halts construction of a 12 mile pipeline meant to interconnect its Pond Creek field with an interstate pipeline operated by East Tennessee Natural Gas. In addition, the company said a previous ruling in its favor in Texas was reversed by an appeals court. GeoMet plans to consider its legal options going forward in the matter, which involves the sale of its interests in the White Oak Creek properties in Texas. Hoku Scientific Inc. HOKU shares fell 7.3% after the company reported a third-quarter net loss of $1.25 million, or 8 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, the Kapolei, Hawaii-based company posted net earnings of $202,000, or a penny a share. Mothers Work MWRK shares tumbled 15$ after the company said its first-quarter net income rose to $1.4 billion, or 23 cents a share, from $428 million, or 8 cents a share, a year ago. Adjusted earnings -- calculated before debt extinguishment losses and stock compensation expense -- amounted to 48 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting the company to post earnings of 32 cents a share. Mothers Work said that it is currently exploring ways to refinance the remaining $90 million of its 11.25% senior notes. Its net sales dipped 1.9% to $148.5 million from $151.4 million in the quarter. Weaker-than-expected sales trends have continued January, the company said, noting that last year's sales benefited from warmer than normal weather. For the second quarter, the company is targeting net sales of $145.0 million to $149.5 million range. The retailer said that it's targeting 2007 adjusted earnings per share of between $2.51 and $3.10. Norfolk Southern Corp. NSC, +1.35% shares sank 5.8% after the company said its fourth-quarter net income rose 6% on continued demand for freight rail transportation. The results, though, were weaker than analysts' expectations. Norfolk Southern, the third railroad company to report earnings this week, said net income rose to $385 million, or 95 cents a share, from $362 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier. The Norfolk, Va., company said revenue rose 2.7% to $2.32 billion. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 96 cents a share on revenue of $2.39 billion. Pactiv Corp. PTV shares lost 8.5% after the company reported fourth-quarter net income of $52 million, or 39 cents a share, up from $35 million, or 25 cents, in the year-ago period. See full story. QLogic Corp. QLGC, +0.12% shares fell 5.3% after the company said third-quarter net income fell 79% to $35.5 million, or 22 cents a share, from $166.2 million, or $1.02 cents a share, a year earlier. The company recorded a $130 million one-time gain on the sale of some operations in the year-earlier quarter. The Aliso Viejo, Calif., storage network infrastructure components company's revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 grew to $157.6 million from $129.2 million in the year-ago period. The company recorded adjusted per-share earnings, excluding stock-based compensation and other items, of 28 cents. On average, analysts expected adjusted per-share earnings of 26 cents on revenue of $153.4 million, according to a poll by Thomson Financial. SAP AG SAP, +1.13% shares sank 7.8% after the world's largest maker of business software said operating margin will likely fall short of expectations as it steps up spending to try and revitalize sales. See full story. TNS Inc. TNS shares dropped 14% after the company said it has rejected the $16-a-share acquisition proposal from a group led by John McDonnell Jr., the company's former chief executive. TNS said it concluded that the offer "was inadequate and substantially undervalued the company." More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Wednesday's biggest stock gainers and decliners

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Shares of AmerisourceBergen Corp. ended Wednesday at their highest closing level ever after the pharmaceutical services company posted a 26% rise in first-quarter profit and lifted its 2007 earnings outlook above Wall Street's forecast. The shares finished the session at $51.96, up more than 8%, after earlier trading as high as $52.25. Valley Forge, Pa.-based AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% said its first-quarter net earnings rose to $122.2 million, or 63 cents a share, from $97.3 million, or 46 cents a share, a year earlier. Total revenue, including bulk deliveries to customer warehouses, rose 14% to $16.73 billion in the latest three months, from $14.65 billion in the same period a year earlier. Operating revenue jumped 16% to $15.7 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected revenue of $16.93 billion. AmerisourceBergen attributed the profit growth to a strong performance in its traditional distribution business and continued strength in its specialty distribution business. The company also lifted its earnings outlook for fiscal 2007 to $2.45 to $2.60 a share, from its previous estimate of $2.40 to $2.55 a share. Wall Street's average estimate is $2.50 a share for the year. "The PharMerica Long Term Care business, which the company currently expects to spin off on a tax-free basis to our shareholders by the end of March, continues to represent 9 cents to 11 cents of our earnings expectations for all of fiscal year 2007," Chief Executive David Yost said. The unit is being combined with Kindred Healthcare Inc.'s KND, +0.00% institutional-pharmacy business to form an independent, publicly traded institutional pharmacy, the second-largest in the country, with revenue of $1.9 billion a year. AmerisourceBergen backed its forecast for operating revenue growth of 9% to 11% in 2007, and said it still plans to buy back between $450 million and $500 million of its common stock in fiscal 2007. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Don’t ever do this with your credit card
title: AmerisourceBergen surges on results, outlook

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Wednesday reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $122.2 million, or 63 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $97.3 million, or 46 cents a share. Total revenue, including bulk deliveries to customer warehouses, rose 14% to $16.73 billion in the latest three months from $14.65 billion in the same period a year earlier. Operating revenue jumped 16% in the quarter to $15.7 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 56 cents a share in the December period on revenue of $16.93 billion. The Valley Forge, Pa., drug services provider attributed the year-over-year profit growth to a strong performance in its traditional distribution business and continued strength in its specialty distribution business. Looking ahead, the company lifted its earnings outlook for fiscal 2007 to $2.45 to $2.60 a share from its previous projection of $2.40 to $2.55 a share. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for earnings of $2.50 a share for the year. AmerisourceBergen sees operating revenue growth of 9% to 11% for the year. It also disclosed plans to buy back between $450 million and %500 million worth of its common stock in fiscal 2007. The stock closed Tuesday at $48.07, up 1.1%.
title: AmerisourceBergen lifts fiscal 2007 earnings view

content: SAN FRANISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% and Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% after Monday's closing bell said Gregory Weishar has agreed to become chief executive of a new concern to be formed by the proposed combination of the companies' institutional pharmacy businesses into a new, independent, publicly traded company. Weishar is CEO and president of PharmaCare Management Services Inc., a CVS Corp. CVS, -0.80% unit. The new company will be named "PharMerica Corp." and will be based in Louisville, Ky. The transaction creating the new company is expected to be complete by the end of March.
title: Amerisource, Kindred: Weishar to be CEO of new company

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Longs Drug Stores Corp. LDG, -22.86% said it's agreed to buy four retail pharmacies from AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% for an undisclosed price. The retail pharmacies average approximately 1,800 square feet, with three in Hawaii and one in California.
title: Longs Drug Stores to buy 4 pharmacies from AmerisourceBergen

content: Emcore swings to quarterly profit (9:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Emcore Corp. EMKR, +0.88% late Monday said it swung to fourth-quarter profit of $78.1 million, or $1.47 a share, boosted by the sale of the company's electronics materials and device unit and its interest in GELcore LLC. In the same period last year, the Somerset,N.J.-based maker of semiconductor components posted a net loss of $4.61 million, or 10 cents a share. Excluding the gain from the sale of the GELcore interest and the electronics and device unit, among other items, the company reported a net loss of $8.9 million vs. a net loss of $5.1 million last year. Revenue for the period rose 5.7% to $35.4 million from $33.5 million. Emcore expects first-quarter revenue of $38 million. Celgene sees 2006 revenue below Wall Street's outlook (8:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Celgene Corp. CELG, +0.90% Monday evening said preliminary 2006 revenue reached $890 million, and adjusted per-share income almost tripled. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for annual revenue of $897 million. The Summit, N.J.-based pharmaceutical concern added that it expects 2007 revenue of $1.3 billion, and adjusted earnings per share of $1. Wall Street is looking for 2007 revenue of $1.375 billion, and per-share income of $1.09. Lawson Software swings to quarterly loss (6:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Lawson Software Inc. LWSN Monday evening said it swung to a loss for the second-quarter, as the company recorded items such as acquisition-related costs and expenses, of $3.51 million, or 2 cents a share. During the same period in the prior year, the company reported net income of $6.56 million, or 6 cents a share. Excluding items, quarterly per-share income fell to 3 cents from 8 cents in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 4 cents. Lawson said quarterly revenue rose to $184.5 million from $89 million in the prior year, while analysts had expected $180 million. For the third quarter, the St. Paul, Minn.-based enterprise software company said it sees revenue of $181 million to $189 million, excluding $2 million of deferred revenue. Lawson sees the quarterly per-share result ranging from loss of a penny to breakeven, or per-share income of 2 cents to 3 cents before items. Wall Street is looking for third-quarter revenue of $194 million and per-share income of 6 cents. Emageon offers 2007 outlook (4:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Emageon Inc. EMAG, +0.09% after Monday's closing bell said it expects 2007 per-share income of 24 cents to 29 cents, and revenue from current business of $136 million to $140 million. The provider of enterprise medical information technology systems sees annual earnings per share excluding charges for depreciation, amortization and stock-based compensation of 79 cents to 87 cents. The company added that it has begun expressing its financial outlook only in terms of its expectations of its organic business, rather than factoring in assumptions about possible acquisitions. Spectrum Control quarterly income rises; revenue gains (4:06 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Spectrum Control Inc. SPEC, +21.36% after Monday's closing bell said fourth-quarter net income rose, as sales gained, to $2 million, or 15 cents a share, from $1.12 million, or 8 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. The electronic control products and systems manufacturer said quarterly revenue rose to $35 million from $25.4 million in the prior year. Credit Suisse raises 3M price target to $95 (11:21 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Credit Suisse hiked its price target on 3M Corp. MMM, +1.38% to $95 from $88, saying the diversified manufacturer should outperform other specialty chemicals companies this year. Credit Suisse analyst John McNulty expects 3M's sales to rise 4.2% this year and earnings per share to increase 10%, helped by strong sales of its parts for LCD screens, the impact of its 17 acquisitions last year, and plant expansion in many of its units, he wrote in a note to investors. 3M shares fell 26 cents to $77.16. Skechers USA boosts fourth-quarter earnings view (9:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Skechers USA Inc. SKX, +1.38% Monday lifted its outlook for the fourth quarter to earnings of 28 to 31 cents a share on revenue of between $295 million and $300 million. The Manhattan Beach, Calif., footwear provider previously forecast a profit of 22 to 27 cents a share for the period on revenue of $255 million and $265 million. For the full year, the company now sees earnings of $1.55 to $1.58 a share on revenue of between $1.196 billion and $1.201 billion. Skechers' prior projection for fiscal 2006 was for a profit ranging from $1.49 to $1.54 a share on revenue of $1.156 billion to $1.666 billion. The stock closed Friday at $32.53, down 1.5%. Coventry Health affirms earnings outlook (9:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Coventry Health CV.H, +0.00% said it still expects fourth quarter earnings of 96 to 97 cents a share. The Bethesda, Md. managed health care company also affirmed its 2007 earnings forecast of $3.82 to $3.95 a share. The stock closed Friday up 20 cents at $49.64. Sandler O'Neill ups 4Q profit estimate for J.P. Morgan Chase (9:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sandler O'Neill analysts Jeff Harte and Devin Ryan on Monday increased their fourth-quarter earnings target for J.P. Morgan Chase JPM, +1.82% by 2 cents a share to 97 cents a share, compared to the average forecast of 94 cents a share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Sandler O'Neill cited more favorable capital markets revenue assumptions, fatter investment banking revenue from the year-ago period, and improved retail financial services net income driven by a reversal of the prior quarter's extremely weak mortgage servicing revenue. Schnitzer Steel first-quarter profit $21 mln vs $42 mln (8:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Schnitzer Steel Industries Inc. SCHN, +2.86% Monday reported first-quarter earnings of $21 million, or 69 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $42 million, or $1.34 a share. The year-ago results included a gain of $34 million related to an asset disposition as well as a charge of $11 million from an investigation reserve. Excluding items, Portland, Ore.-based Schnitzer earned $19 million, or 61 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $510 million from $341 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 99 cents a share in the November period on revenue of $511.9 million. The company said it saw lower volumes and higher costs per ton in the latest quarter due to the installation of mega-shredders at its metals recycling facilities in the Oakland and Boston areas. In addition, margins were hurt by higher raw material costs in the quarter, and its auto parts business saw lower vehicle purchases due to higher prices. The stock closed Friday at $37.72, down 2.7%. OSI Restaurant 3rd-period net off 41%, sales up 8.9% (8:47 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- OSI Restaurant Partners Inc., OSI, -2.84% the Tampa, Fla., operator of casual-dining restaurants under brands including Outback Steakhouse, Carrabba's Italian Grill, and Cheeseburger in Paradise, among others, reported that third-quarter earnings fell 41% on 8.9% higher sales. On Nov. 6, OSI said that it would be acquired by an iunvestor group for $40 a share and that it would restate its financials to correct errors in its liability for unearned revenue for unredeemed gift cards and certificates as well as certain other matters. Earnings fell to $17.3 million, or 23 cents a share, from $29.5 million, or 38 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue increased to $950.6 million from $872.9 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced consensus estimates of 32 cents of profit on $940 million of revenue. Morgan Stanley signs on for US Airways debt underwriting (8:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- US Airways Group Inc. LCC, +0.15% said Monday Morgan Stanley MS, +1.98% has been added as joint lead arranger with Citigroup to underwrite the airline's $7.2 billion debt financing for its proposed merger with Delta Air Lines DALRQ Brazil's GOL cuts earnings forecast as load factor drops (8:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Brazil's low-cost airline GOL Linhas Aéreas Inteligentes GOL, +4.76% said Monday its passenger traffic rose 48% in December while its capacity rose 65% for the month, compared to the same period last year. That caused its load factor, or percentage of seats filled with paying passengers, to fall to 67.4% from 75.2%. GOL also forecast a drop in fiscal year earnings to 3.15 to 3.30 reals a share, down from 3.40 to 3.65 reals a share. Affymetrix sees fourth-quarter revenue of about $100 mln (8:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Affymetrix Inc. AFFX Monday forecast revenue of about $100 million for the fourth quarter. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for revenue of $99.5 million in the December period. The Santa Clara, Calif., biotechnology company plans to release its results for the fourth quarter and full year after the closing bell on Feb. 7. The stock finished Friday at $21.72, down 2.4%. AmerisourceBergen reaffirms fiscal 2007 profit view (8:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Monday reaffirmed its outlook for earnings of $2.40 to $2.55 a share for fiscal 2007. The company also lifted its outlook for operating revenue growth in the December quarter to 16%. For fiscal 2007, it sees operating revenue growth of 9% to 11%, up from a prior projection of 7% to 9%. It expects earnings for the December quarter to be higher than the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 54 cents a share. The Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical services provider also forecast spending between $450 million and $500 million on share buybacks in fiscal 2007. The stock closed Friday at $45.73, down 1.2%. Applebee's to hit high end of 2006 earnings target (8:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Applebee's International Inc. APPB, +0.00% on Monday said it expects 2006 earnings to be at or slightly above the high end of its previously stated estimate of $1.10 to $1.13 a share, excluding impairment charges. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call are forecasting $1.12 a share, on average. The Overland Park, Kanasas restaurant chain said it continues to expect 2007 earnings of $1.15 to $1.20 a share, compared to the Wall Street target of $1.17 a share. St. Jude Medical to beat 4Q analyst targets (8:03 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- St. Jude Medical STJ, -0.32% on Monday said it expects fourth-quarter earnings of 42 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 39 cents a share, on average. The St. Paul, Minn. medical device company will report net sales of approximately $864 million for the fourth quarter, an increase of more than 9% compared to the year-ago period and approximately $20 million above current analysts' consensus revenue estimates, the company said. Group 1 sees FY07 profit of $4-$4.25 a share (7:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Group 1 Automotive Inc. GPI, +3.01% Monday said it expects earnings of $4 to $4.25 a share for fiscal 2007. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of $4.28 a share for the year. The Houston-based automotive dealership operator expects revenue of around $600 million for 2007. The company also said it plans to continue to evaluate its dealership portfolio and dispose of underperforming stores. It estimates it will record between $5 million and $10 million in associated disposition charges for the year, primarily from sale-leaseback exit costs. The stock closed Friday at $49.81, down 2.5%. Human Genome backs 2006 forecasts (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Human Genome Sciences Inc. HGSI on Monday said it expects 2006 results to be in line with prior forecasts, including net cash burn of less than $125 million. The Rockville, Md.-based drug development company said it has completed its facilities consolidation program and expects to record a non-cash charge to the fourth quarter of 2006. For 2007, it expects net cash burn to be in the range of $145 million to $165 million. Revenue is expected to increase by about 50% from 2006 to 2007, but total expenses, research and development expenses and general and administrative expenses are expected to remain about flat from 2006 to 2007. Human Genome said it expects cash and investments at year-end 2007 to total in the range of $560 million to $580 million. Chief Executive H. Thomas Watkins will give a presentation to analysts and investors at the J.P. Morgan Healthcare conference on Jan. 10. Extreme Networks to restate income on stock option expense (7:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Extreme Networks Inc. EXTR, +0.82% on Monday said it expects to take charges for an options restatement. It'll also evaluate any other unrecorded adjustments previously determined to be immaterial. The company said reports of its independent registered public accounting firm relating to fiscal periods 2000 through 2005 and the first, second and third quarters of 2006 should no longer be relied upon. Nu Horizons profit climbs 59%, but sales fall sequentially (7:05 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Nu Horizons Electronics NUHC said third-quarter ending Nov. 30 net income rose 59% to $2.4 million, or 13 cents a share, with sales up 26% to $186 million. From the last quarter, however, sales fell at the electronic components distributor, due to a decline in the company's systems business related to a substantial customer-specific decrease, as well as to market weakness related to some end customer and manufacturing channel inventory builds. MarineMax sees deeper first-quarter loss, cuts outlook (6:48 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- MarineMax Inc. HZO, +2.10% said it's lowering its profit outlook for fiscal 2007. As revised, the Clearwater, Fla.-based recreational boat retailer sees earnings in a range of $1.40 to $1.50 a share for the year ending Sept. 30, down from a range of $2.05 to $2.15 a share previously. Analysts' average view stands at $2.11 a share, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. MarineMax cited recently incurring greater marketing and promotional costs, which pinched on operating margins. As a result, the company sees a first-quarter loss of 20 cents to 25 cents a share; the First Call-derived average forecast stands at a loss of 6 cents. "It is clear that the marine industry is experiencing increased softness," said William McGill, chairman, president and chief executive. Shares of MarineMax lost 28 cents, or 1.1%, to end Friday's trading at $24.77. United Health to affirm earnings estimates (6:46 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- UnitedHealth Group Inc., UNH, -2.06% the Minnetonka, Minn., health insurer, said that at a presentation set for Wednesday at the JPMorgan Health Care Conference, it would affirm its earnings estimates of Dec. 19. The company disclosed the planned affirmation in a Securities and Exchange Commission Form 8-K. UnitedHealth had forecast 2007 net income of $4.7 billion to $4.75 billion on revenue of $79.5 billion. That revenue figure was up from the $79 billion it forecast when the company reported its third-quarter results and was ahead of the then-current $77.91 billion forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The current First Call estimate for UNH's 2007 revenue is $78.46 billion. The company also had backed its 2006 profit target, pegged in a range of $4.14 billion to $4.16 billion. The forecasts, UnitedHealth said, were based on expectations for "gains from increasing market share and strong operating margins" across its business units. At the time, UnitedHealth also outlined the size of further noncash charges to be taken in connection with its review of historical stock-option practices. Before taxes and using current accounting practices, the charges for stock-based compensation expense were likely to range from $400 million to $600 million for the period 1994-2005 as well as from $25 million to $60 million for 2006, the company said. AvalonBay raises 2006 earnings forecast, offers 2007 outlook (6:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- AvalonBay Communities Inc. AVB, +0.25% raised its forecast for 2006 earnings per share to a range of $3.54 to $3.58, from a range of $3.49 to $3.53. The forecast includes 18 cents a share of one-off items, principally from gains on the sale of land. The company, which owns 167 apartment communities in the U.S., maintained its 2006 funds from operations forecast for a range of $4.36 to $4.40 per share. For 2007, AvalonBay said it expects earnings per share to be in a range of $3.66 to $3.90 and funds from operations to be $4.68 to $4.92 a share. The company added it plans to issue up to 4 million shares in conjunction with its inclusion in the S&P 500 Index, which is expected to occur at the close of the market on Jan. 9. RadioShack forecasts profit rise, same-store sales fall (5:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Consumer electronics retailer RadioShack Corp. RSH, -0.07% said fourth-quarter net income will rise from the $51 million it earned in the year-ago quarter, but said same-store sales will drop. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected, on average, the company to make $49.4 million in the quarter. The profit rise will be in part by improved margin and inventory management combined with reduced SG&A expenses. It's forecasting a 7.8% drop in same-store sales, or down 5.5% after excluding a reclassification of the sale of prepaid wireless airtime. It said in the five weeks between Thanksgiving and New Year, adjusted comparable store sales dropped 2.5%. Same-store sales will be affected in the first quarter, as it was "highly promotional" in the comparable period of 2006, the company said. Its cash balance was approximately $450 million at the end of 2006, an improvement of around $225 million from last year. LSE to release earnings early to fight Nasdaq bid: report (3:00 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- The London Stock Exchange(UK:LSE)is set to publish its third-quarter earnings early in an attempt to help fight off Nasdaq Stock Market's NDAQ, +3.27% 2.7 billion pound hostile takeover bid, according to a report in the Telegraph newspaper. The exchange will publish the figures before Thursday, when Nasdaq's offer is due to close, in order to give shareholders as much information as possible, the newspaper reported. The quarterly figures were originally due to be published at the end of January.
