title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Monday reaffirmed its outlook for earnings of $2.40 to $2.55 a share for fiscal 2007. The company also lifted its outlook for operating revenue growth in the December quarter to 16%. For fiscal 2007, it sees operating revenue growth of 9% to 11%, up from a prior projection of 7% to 9%. It expects earnings for the December quarter to be higher than the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 54 cents a share. The Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical services provider also forecast spending between $450 million and $500 million on share buybacks in fiscal 2007. The stock closed Friday at $45.73, down 1.2%.
title: AmerisourceBergen reaffirms fiscal 2007 profit view

content: Charles River backs 2006 outlook; issues 2007 forecast (5:48 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Charles River Laboratories International Inc. CRL, +0.53% after Wednesday's closing bell said it still sees 2006 per-share earnings from continuing operations of $1.73 to $1.79 on revenue that's up 6% to 8%. The Wilmington, Mass.-based biotechnology company also said it now expects 2006 pro forma per-share earnings from continuing operations of $2.15 to $2.21, from its previous outlook of $2.12 to $2.18. The forecast was revised to exclude amortization of intangible assets related to acquisitions, the company said. For 2007, Charles River said it expects per-share earnings from continuing operations of $2.11 to $2.21, or $2.43 to $2.53 on a pro forma basis, on revenue that's up 9% to 12%. HomeBanc confirms fourth-quarter loss forecast (5:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- HomeBanc Corp. HMB, -0.35% after Wednesday's closing bell said it still expects a fourth-quarter net loss attributable to common shareholders of 6 cents to 10 cents a share. The Atlanta-based real estate investment trust also confirmed it sees estimated loan production volume by HomeBanc Mortgage Corp. of $1.1 billion to $1.2 billion for the quarter. HomeBanc said it still expects a REIT investment portfolio of $5.8 billion to $6 billion as of Dec. 31. The company said it continues to consider a range of strategic alternatives and expects to complete the process during early 2007. SuperValu raises fiscal 2007 outlook; updates quarterly view (5:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Supervalu Inc. SVU, -1.42% after Wednesday's closing bell said it now expects fiscal 2007 per-share earnings of $2.32 to $2.43, up from its previous range of $2.18 to $2.41. The Minneapolis-based supermarket operator also narrowed its 2007 pro forma outlook, saying it now sees per-share earnings of $2.66 to $2.74. The previous pro forma earnings outlook was $2.62 to $2.80 a share for the year. Additionally, Supervalu said it expects third-quarter earnings of 52 cents to 56 cents a share, or 60 cents to 63 cents a share before adjustments. For the fourth quarter, the company said it sees earnings of 59 cents to 66 cents a share, or 67 cents to 72 cents a share before adjustments. Energen affirms 2007 earnings outlook (2:43 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Energen Corp. EGN, +3.42% said Wednesday it still expects 2007 per-share earnings of $3.80 to $4.20 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently forecasting 2007 earnings of $4.01 a share. The Birmingham, Ala.-based company said its outlook was based on certain assumptions, including that existing hedge position covers about 70% of estimated 2007 production. Energen also said it expects 2007 production will be flat relative to 2006, with a "significant level of activity" devoted to developing its proved undeveloped reserves to set the stage for future production growth. The company estimated that 2008 production will range from 97 Bcfe to 99 Bcfe, and that 2009 production will exceed 100 Bcfe. CPI International shares rise on fourth-quarter results (10:38 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CPI International Inc. CPII shares rose 13% to $15.24 in Wednesday morning trade after the Palo Alto, Calif.-based provider of microwave and radio frequency products late Tuesday reported fiscal fourth-quarter net earnings of $6.19 million, or 35 cents a share. In the same quarter last year, the company posted a net loss of $2.4 million, or 19 cents a share. Revenue rose to $82.6 million from $74.9 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast a per-share profit of 25 cents on revenue of $83.3 million. In fiscal 2007, CPI expects earnings of $1.24 to $1.30 a share on revenue of $350 million to $355 million. Net stocks open higher, Yahoo, Monster in play (9:41 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of large Internet companies were trading mostly higher Wednesday, with Yahoo Inc. YHOO gaining 1% on a new alliance with IBM to deliver a free, corporate search product and Yahoo video's expanded relationship with ABC News. Google Inc. GOOG, +2.71% shares were trading 0.7% higher after it announced a new program to let its employees auction their vested stock options to the highest institutional bidder. Shares of Monster Worldwide Inc. MNST, +1.72% were off, fractionally, after disclosing the results of its stock options probe, which has so far tamped down any positive effect of a Piper Jaffray & Co. analyst noting how the Monster.com jobs board operator seems on track for a fourth-quarter in-line with expectations. Shares of eBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% gained 1% early after its Skype Internet telephone division began selling its first-ever subscription plan, which charges $35 a year for unlimited calling to anyone in North America. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones Internet Index DJI_DJINET and the technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ both began the day on the upside. Alpharma sees 2007 earnings $1.15-$1.30 a share (9:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Alpharma Inc. ALO, -1.52% Wednesday said it expects earnings of $1.15 to $1.30 a share for fiscal 2007. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of $1.42 a share for the year. Fort Lee, N.J.-based Alpharma said its view assumes revenue growth of between 15% and 20% in its pharmaceuticals business. The company also said it's agreed to repurchase 22% of its outstanding stock from A.L. Industrier ASA. The deal calls for Alpharma to buy all of its Class B shares from A.L. Industrier at $25.50 each. Alpharma said the repurchase would add 10 to 15 cents a share to its 2007 earnings outlook if the transaction is completed by early January. The stock closed Tuesday at $24.39, up 3.7%. Progressive Corp. November net premiums fall 3% (8:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Progressive Corp. PGR, +0.81% on Wednesday said November net premiums written fell 3% to $959.2 million. Net income for the month rose 58% to $131.9 million, or 17 cents a share, from $83.3 million, or 10 cents a share. Guidance Software IPO prices below its range (8:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Guidance Software GUID priced its initial public offering at $11.50 per share, below its $12.50-$14.50 range, for its stock market debut Wednesday, according to the syndicate desk at Morgan Stanley. The IPO raised nearly $58 million by offering 5 million shares. It's the second tech firm to debut on Wednesday along with IPGPhotonics IPGP, +3.37% Health Net sees FY07 profit of $3.65 a share (8:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Health Net Inc. HNT, +0.00% Wednesday said it now expects earnings of $3.65 a share for fiscal 2007, up from a prior forecast for a profit of $3.60 a share, reflecting the impact of completed and anticipated share repurchases. The Los Angeles managed health-care company said it bought back 2.8 million of its shares on the open market during the fourth quarter through Dec. 12. It expects to lower its diluted share count in 2007 to about 114 million. The company anticipates revenue of between $14 billion and $15 billion for 2007 with commercial per member per month premium yields projected to rise about 9% from year-ago levels. The stock closed Tuesday at $45.83, up 41 cents. Pixelworks' Alley to resign as president/CEO (8:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Pixelworks Inc. PXLW, +3.48% Wednesday said Allen Alley plans to resign from the president and chief executive officer positions, effective Dec. 31. Hans Olsen, currently an executive vice president and chief operating officer, will serve in both roles on an interim basis until a successor is named. The Tualatin, Ore., semiconductor maker has formed a search committee to fill the positions of president and CEO. Also, the company said it now expects revenue of $28 million to $30 million for the fourth quarter, a forecast that's within its previously disclosed outlook. The stock closed Tuesday at $2.43, down 3 cents. AmerisourceBergen reiterates 2007 profit target (8:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% said Wednesday it continues to expect fiscal 2007 earnings of $2.40 to $2.55 a share. The company said it's planning to spin off its PharMerica Long Term Care unit in March. The unit will account for 9-11 cents a share in earnings in 2007, AmerisourceBergen said. Hilton sets three-year growth targets; 2007 outlook affirmed (6:19 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Hilton Hotels Corp. HLT, +0.57% affirmed its 2007 financial targets, including growth rates for management/franchise fees, margins and revenue per average room, known as RevPAR. The Beverly Hills, Calif.-based hotels operator, during its 2006 investor day, also said it anticipates adding some 120,000 rooms globally between 2007 and 2009. The proportion of room growth from international markets will, Hilton said, increase "gradually" over that span, in line with the company's recently announced development deals for full-service and mid-scale properties throughout India and China. Looking out to 2009, Hilton set earnings targets of $1.70 a share and $2 a share, respectively, assuming the company generates compounded annual RevPAR growth rates of 7% and 9%. In addition, the company projected growth rates in recurring earnings per share of 16% to 22% through 2009 as well as 12% to 17% in operating income. Shares of Hilton eased 3 cents on Tuesday to end at $33.57. Safran shares slide 5% after cutting earnings expectations (3:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Shares in French aircraft-engine and mobile phone maker Safran(FR:007327)fell around 5% in early trading Wednesday after the firm announced late Tuesday that the results for its Defense Security and Communications branches will be significantly lower than its previous target. The defense division will be hit by the correction of "unexplained" accounting entries first announced on Friday, as well as revised margins on certain long term contracts. The communications division's performance will be impacted by a sharp downturn in mobile phone business during the last quarter. Safran said it has revised its 2006 objectives to consolidated sales of 11 billion euros and an operating margin of around 4%. Separately Safran said it has asked KPMG to conduct a fraud investigation into the accounting irregularities found in the files of Sagem Defense Securite's former chief financial officer. These irregularities could impact Sagem Defense's finances by around 100 million euros. Whitbread 39-week comparable sales up 3.9% (2:48 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Whitbread Plc(UK:WTB) WTBCF, -1.82% of the U.K., with interests in lodging; restaurants, pubs and coffee bars, and health and fitness, reported sales from continuing businesses for the 39 weeks ended Nov. 30 rose 10.1% from a year earlier, with comparable sales up 3.9%. "We are driving rapid expansion" in Premier inns and Costa coffee bars, and the turnaround at the David Lloyd fitness centers "is encouraging," Chief Executive Alan Parker said in a statement. He said he was "particularly pleased by the first signs of improvement at Pub Restaurants." AMEC sees 2006 profit below expectation, plans restructure (2:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. Engineering group AMEC(UK:AMEC)said Wednesday that its 2006 pretax profit will likely be 15 million pounds below prior expectations due to restructuring and litigation costs as well as project delays and low activity in the firm's nuclear business. The company also announced cost saving and restructuring plans to focus on its core businesses. Under the plans AMEC will sell certain units including building and civil engineering and property development. It will focus on high value industries such as oil and gas, mining, nuclear and wind energy. AMEC also said it plans to buy back up to 100 million pounds worth of shares during 2007. Inditex profit up 22%, fourth quarter meeting expectations (2:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Spanish retailer Inditex(ES:ITX)said Wednesday that its net income for the first nine months of 2006 rose 22% to 634 million euros as revenue also rose 22% to 5.67 billion euros. The company said sales were helped by the opening of 326 new stores, bringing the total to 3,018 stores in 64 countries. The operator of Zara, Pull and Bear and Massimo Dutti stores said that same-store sales have been in line with expectations since the start of the fourth-quarter. Intertek sees progress continuing from first half (2:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Intertek Group(UK:ITRK)said Wednesday that the good progress the group made in the first half of the year has continued into the second half. The quality and safety services group said it is benefiting from strong global trade, health and environmental regulations and an increasing trend for companies to outsource their safety and quality services. The firm said its three main divisions are expected to achieve similar growth in the second half of the year to the first, while revenue at its government services unit will fall due to the previously announced termination of certain contracts. Intertek said 80% of its earnings are in U.S. dollars, but it does not expect the recent dollar weakness to significantly impact the year's results. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmericsourceBergen Corp. on Wednesday backed its profit forecast for the full-year 2007 period. The distributor of drugs and medical supplies is still expecting to report earnings for the period of $2.40 and $2.55 a share, with its PharMerica Long-Term Care unit representing between 9 cents and 11 cents a share. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of $2.48, according to Thomson First Call. The Valley Forge, Pa.-based company ABC, +1.29% is spinning off the PharMerica unit in its fiscal second quarter, part of a recently inked agreement with Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% under which the two companies agreed to combine their respective institutional-pharmacy businesses into an independent, publicly traded company. The transaction will create the nation's second-largest institutional pharmacy, with annual revenue of $1.9 billion a year. AmerisourceBergen also reiterated its expectation that operating revenue will rise between 7% and 9% over the $56.7 billion reported for 2006, and said it still sees free cash flow ranging from $425 million to $500 million. The company also said it still expects to spend $450 million to $500 million to buy back its shares in 2007. The outlook was reiterated in conjunction with the company's annual investor meeting. Shares of AmerisouceBergen closed higher by 1.6% at $47.30. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage
title: AmerisourceBergen backs 2007 forecast

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% said Wednesday it continues to expect fiscal 2007 earnings of $2.40 to $2.55 a share. The company said it's planning to spin off its PharMerica Long Term Care unit in March. The unit will account for 9-11 cents a share in earnings in 2007, AmerisourceBergen said.
title: AmerisourceBergen reiterates 2007 profit target

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Thursday it increased its quarterly dividend to 5 cents from 2.5 cents. The Valley Forge, Penn., pharmaceutical services company said the dividend is payable Dec. 4, to stockholders of record Nov. 20.
title: AmerisourceBergen raises quarterly dividend to 5c from 2.5c

content: Consolidated Edison quarterly earnings fall (8:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Consolidated Edison Inc. ED, +0.49% late Thursday said third-quarter net earnings fell to $231 million, or 92 cents a share, from $285 million, or $1.17 a share, in the prior year, partly due to costs related to summer power outages and milder weather than last year. The New York-based electric utility said revenue rose 3% to $3.44 billion from $3.34 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share earnings of $1.06, on revenue of $3.24 billion. The company backed its 2006 per-share earnings outlook of $2.75 to $3.00. Camden Property swings to quarterly income on sale gain (7:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Camden Property Trust CPT, +0.14% Thursday evening said it swung to third-quarter net income, as the company recorded a gain of $2.07 per share from gain the sale of land, operating properties, joint venture properties and discontinued operations, of $125.5 million, or $2.07 a share. During the same period in the prior year, the net loss was $2.32 million, or 5 cents a share. The real estate company engaged in the multifamily apartment communities said total property revenue for the quarter rose to $154.6 million from $136.6 million in the prior year. Camden added that quarterly per-share funds from operations rose to $1.24 from 76 cents in the prior year. For 2006, per-share FFO is expected to be $3.82 to $3.88. For the fourth quarter, per-share FFO is expected to be from 81 cents to 87 cents. Camden sees per-share income of $3.60 to $3.66 for 2006, and of 17 cents to 23 cents for the fourth quarter. Chemture quarterly loss narrows (7:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chemtura Corp. CEM, +1.12% late Thursday said its third-quarter net loss narrowed to $34.7 million, or 14 cents a share, compared with $118.9 million, or 50 cents a share, in the prior year. The Middlebury, Conn.-based chemical company said revenue fell slightly to $917 million from $918.4 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected revenue of $900 million. Public Storage quarterly income falls; expenses rise (7:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Public Storage Inc. PSA, -0.86% Thursday evening said third-quarter net income fell, as depreciation and amortization rose, to $81.2 million from $128.3 million during the same period in the prior year. The net result for shareholders swung to a loss of $6.08 million, or 4 cents a share. In the prior year, shareholders had income of $79.3 million, or 62 cents share. The real estate investment trust that develops self-storage facilities said quarterly revenue rose to $221.4 million from $208.7 million in the prior year. Quarterly per-share funds from operations decreased to 77 cents from 97 cents in the prior year. Osiris Therapeutics quarterly loss widens on charges (7:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Osiris Therapeutics Inc. OSIR, +0.57% late Thursday reported a third-quarter net loss of $15.6 million, or 75 cents a share, compared with $4.68 million, or 52 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Baltimore-based biotechnology posted revenue of $2.54 million vs. $284,000. Osiris said the third-quarter loss was largely driven by the recognition of non-recurring, non-cash charges associated with the completion of its initial public offering and clinical trial activity. Total non-cash charges relating to the IPO recognized during the quarter were $7 million, the company said. Excluding non-recurring, non-cash IPO related charges, the loss for the quarter was $8.6 million, Osiris said. Odyssey Re reports quarterly net income of $60 million (6:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Odyssey Re Holdings ORH, -50.00% said late Thursday that third-quarter net income came in at $60 million. That's up from a net loss of $121.7 million a year earlier, when the insurance and reinsurance company was hit by Hurricane Katrina and other storms. Net income available to common shareholders was 81 cents a share, up from a net loss of $1.90 a share. Operating income, which excludes net realized investment gains and losses, was $56.6 million, or 79 cents a share. The company was expected to make 75 cents a share, according to the average estimate of four analysts in a Thomson First Call survey. Net premiums written fell 9% to $573.5 million in the period, Odyssey said, noting "increased competitive market conditions across the insurance and reinsurance industries." Interline Brands quarterly earnings rise (6:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Interline Brands Inc. IBI, -3.74% late Thursday said third-quarter net earnings rose to $14.2 million, or 43 cents a share, from $9.72 million, or 30 cents a share, in the prior year, boosted by strong revenue growth. Excluding items, the Jacksonville, Fla.-based marketer and distributor of maintenance products posted per-share earnings were 43 cents vs. 33 cents last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share earnings of 40 cents. Revenue rose 39% to $314.2 million from $225.8 million. Analysts had forecast revenue of $313 million. The company sees 2006 per-share earnings of 93 cents to 95 cents, or $1.32 to $1.34 excluding items. Interline backed its fourth-quarter earnings outlook of 33 cents a share to 35 cents a share. Alkermes shares fall on earnings release (6:27 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Alkermes Inc.'s ALKS, -2.14% shares fell 4% to $15.60 in after-hours trading Thursday. After the bell, the Cambridge, Mass.-based biotechnology company said second-quarter net earnings fell to $3.7 million, or 4 cents a share, from $11.8 million, or 12 cents a share, in the prior year, as expenses rose. Excluding share-based compensation, among other items, per-share earnings were 10 cents vs. 12 cents last year. Revenue rose 31% to $61.2 million from $46.7 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share loss of 4 cents, on revenue of $51.8 million. The company raised its 2007 revenue outlook to $206 to $228 million, from its prior view of $200 to $222 million. Alkermes also increased its per-share pro forma earnings outlook to a range of 25 cents per basic share to 30 cents per basic share. The company had previously expected earnings of 5 cents per basic share to 10 cents per basic share. Gemstar-TV quarterly income falls, revenue declines (6:04 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc. GMST after Thursday's closing bell said third-quarter net income fell to $17.5 million, or 4 cents a share, from $51 million, or 12 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year, which included a $51.1 million income tax benefit. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of a penny. The media company said quarterly revenue fell to $148.9 million from $152.5 million in the prior year. Syntax-Brillian swings to quarterly profit; shares rise (5:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Syntax-Brillian Corp.'s BRLC shares rose 20% to $7.52 in after-hours trading Thursday. After the bell, the Tempe, Ariz.-based maker of high-definition televisions swung to first-quarter net profit of $3.8 million, or 7 cents a share, boosted by strong sales. In the same period last year, the company posted a net loss of $658,000, or 2 cents a share. Revenue more than tripled, rising to $87 million from $27.4 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share earnings of 1 cent, on revenue of $75.3 million. The company expects second-quarter revenue of $160 million to $170 million, excluding Vivitar operations, and of $178 million to $190 million including them. For 2007, Syntax-Brillian sees revenue of $490 million to $520 million excluding Vivitar, and of $565 million to $605 million including it. Neurocrine shares fall; quarterly result swings to a loss (5:53 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Neurocrine Biosciences Inc. NBIX, +0.12% shares fell 22% to $8.60 in after-hours trading Thursday. The biopharmaceutical concern said it swung to a third-quarter net loss, as revenue plummeted from last year's result that included a $50 million milestone payment, of $39.1 million, or $1.03 a share. During the same period in the prior year, net income was $26.2 million, or 68 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share loss of 91 cents. Neurocrine said quarterly revenue fell to $1.07 million from $64.7 million in the prior year, while analysts had expected $3 million. Also Thursday, Neurocrine said the Food and Drug Administration has requested further analyses and modifications of analyses previously submitted on indiplon capsules to treat insomnia. The company said it has elected to conduct an additional 3-month safety and efficacy study to supplement the reanalysis and provide additional support for the resubmission, targeted for the summer 2008. CORRECT: Hain Celestial quarterly profit jumps; backs view (5:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hain Celestial Group Inc. HAIN, +0.69% after Monday's closing bell reported first-quarter net earnings of $9.03 million, or 23 cents a share, compared with $6.89 million, or 18 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Melville, N.Y.-based organic food and personal care products maker posted revenue of $210.2 million vs. $161.1 million. Adjusted earnings were 25 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast first-quarter earnings of 23 cents a share. The quarterly gross margin was 28.1% compared with 28.5% a year ago. Also, Hain Celestial said it still expects fiscal 2007 earnings of $1.15 to $1.19 a share on revenue of $880 million to $900 million. (Corrects First Call estimate.) Avanex quarterly loss narrows; shares rise (5:40 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Avanex Corp.'s AVNX shares rose 13% to $1.71 in after-hours trading Thursday. After the bell, the Fremont, Calif.-based maker of fiber optics products said its first-quarter net loss narrowed to $9.8 million, or 5 cents a share, compared with a net loss $16.9 million, 12 cents a share, in the prior year. Excluding share-based payments, among other items, the company's per-share loss narrowed to 3 cents vs. 10 cents last year. Revenue rose 23% to $50.9 million from $41.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share loss of 2 cents, on revenue of $49.2 million. The company sees second-quarter revenue of $52 million to $55 million, and expects gross margin to improve. Red Robin shares fall; quarterly income declines (5:38 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Red Robin Gourmet Burgers Inc. RRGB, -0.51% shares fell 20% to $37 in after-hours trading Thursday. The casual dining company said third-quarter net income fell, as results included charges related to the acquisition of 11 restaurants, to $5.99 million, or 36 cents a share, from $6.47 million, or 39 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Excluding items, quarterly per-share income rose to 47 cents from 45 cents in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 43 cents. Red Robin said quarterly revenue rose to $148.6 million from $114.2 million in the prior year, and Wall Street was looking for $148 million. For the full year, the company lowered its view for revenue to a range of $611 million to $613 million, and for net income to a range of $1.62 to $1.67 per share. The company's prior annual outlook for revenue was $615 million to $618 million, with net income of $1.74 to $1.83. Red Robin expected fourth-quarter revenue of $156 million to $158 million, and net income of 33 cents to 38 cents per share. Nationwide Financial quarterly net income slides 4% (5:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Nationwide Financial Services NFS, -5.50% said late Thursday that third-quarter net income came in at $159.5 million, or $1.06 a share, down 4% from a year earlier, when the life insurance and retirement savings company made $166.7 million, or $1.08 a share. Operating earnings, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses, were $154.7 million, or $1.03 a share, the company reported. Nationwide was expected to make 98 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 19 analysts in a Thomson First Call survey. "We're on track to meet our full-year expectations, and these results validate the progress we've made in strengthening our core businesses, particularly in our individual product lines, where sales have significantly improved over the last several quarters," Chief Executive Jerry Jurgensen said in a statement. CORRECT: Atmel Q3 sales rise 6% (5:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Atmel Corp. ATML said late Thursday its third-quarter sales rose 6% to $443 million from the same period a year ago. San Jose, Calif.-based Atmel, which makes microcontroller and memory chips used in a range of applications, didn't provide net income data due to its ongoing review of its stock-option accounting. Atmel said revenue for the current quarter will fall 3% to 8% from the quarter ended Sept. 30. (Previous version reported incorrect revenue figure). Macrovision quarterly earnings rise; updates 2006 outlook (5:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Macrovision Corp. MVSN after Thursday's closing bell reported third-quarter net earnings of $6.4 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with $6.1 million, or 12 cents a share, in the prior year, as revenue and expenses rose. Excluding amortization and equity-based compensation, among other items, the Santa Clara, Calif.-based technology company posted per-share earnings of 23 cents vs. 14 cents last year. Revenue rose 25% to $58.1 million from $46.6 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share earnings of 22 cents, on revenue of $58 million. The company raised its 2006 per-share earnings outlook by 3 cents to a range of $1.13 to $1.17 excluding items, and narrowed its revenue view to $243 million to $247 million. For the fourth quarter, Macrovision sees per-share earnings of 39 cents to 43 cents excluding items, on revenue of $70 million to $74 million. The company also said the Securities and Exchange Commission has ended a probe into Macrovision's stock option practices and has recommended no enforcement action. Aquantive shares fall after quarterly results report (5:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Aquantive Inc. AQNT shares fell 15% to $24.50 in after-hours trading Thursday. The digital marketing company said third-quarter net income rose, as revenue gained, to $13.6 million, or 16 cents a share, from $9.44 million, or 13 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Aquantive said quarterly revenue rose to $111 million from $78.8 million in the prior year. The company backed its view for 2006 revenue of $420 million to $430 million, and net income of 54 cents to 58 cents per share, or 67 cents to 71 cents before stock-based compensation. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for annual revenue of $430 million, and per-share income of 59 cents. Cephalon quarterly profit surges; raises 2006 outlook (5:09 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cephalon Inc. CEPH after Thursday's closing bell reported third-quarter net earnings of $95.7 million, or $1.43 a share, compared with $29.3 million, or 50 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Frazer, Pa.-based biotechnology company posted revenue of $482.3 million vs. $309.5 million. Adjusted sales for the quarter were $457.2 million and basic adjusted income was $1.78 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast third-quarter earnings of $1.16 a share on revenue of $435 million. Cephalon said it has raised its 2006 outlook, and now expects total adjusted sales of $1.66 billion to $1.68 billion and basic adjusted earnings of $5.10 to $5.20 a share. The company had previously forecast adjusted sales of $1.53 billion to $1.58 billion and basic adjusted earnings of $4.10 to $4.30 a share. Additionally, Cephalon said it expects 2007 adjusted sales of $1.68 billion to $1.73 billion and basic adjusted earnings of $4.50 to $4.60 a share. Six Flags quarterly income falls, revenue declines (5:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Six Flags Inc. SIX, +1.12% after Thursday's closing bell said third-quarter net income fell, as revenue declined and expenses rose, to $164.7 million, or $1.08 a share, from $195.7 million, or $1.29 a share, during the same period in the prior year. Six Flags said quarterly revenue fell to $540.7 million from $546.1 million in the prior year. Sina quarterly earnings rise (5:00 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sina Corp. SINA, +4.55% after Thursday's closing bell reported third-quarter net earnings of $10.7 million, or 19 cents a share, compared with $9.1 million, or 16 cents a share, in the prior year, on the back of higher advertising revenue. Excluding stock-based compensation, among other items, the China-based online media company posted per-share earnings of 25 cents. Revenue rose 13% to $56.1 million from $49.6 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share earnings of 18 cents, on revenue of $53 million. The company sees fourth-quarter revenue of $53 million to $56 million, with advertising revenue between $34 million and $35 million and non-advertising revenue between $19 million and $21 million. Cognizant Technology third-quarter profit climbs, tops view (6:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- IT services provider Cognizant Technology Solutions CTSH, +1.04% said third-quarter net income climbed to $61 million, or 40 cents a share, from $40.6 million, or 28 cents a share, with revenue up 60% to $378 million. On an adjusted basis, it would've earned 45 cents a share, the Teaneck, N.J. company said. Adjusted fourth-quarter earnings are seen at 47 cents a share and revenue is expected to be at least $405 million, up 57% from last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected third-quarter earnings per share of 38 cents and fourth-quarter earnings per share of 41 cents. Driller Todco profit nearly triples during the third quarter (6:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Todco THE, -0.40% said third-quarter income rose to $55.5 million, or 92 cents a share, from $19.1 million, or 31 cents a share. Revenue climbed to $242 million from $141 million. Rig activation expenses rose to $13 million, or 13 cents a share, during the quarter. Improved utilizations and dayrates drove the profit rise, the drilling services company said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 80 cents a share. Westlake Chemical profit climbs 42%, tops forecast (6:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Westlake Chemical WLK, +2.91% said third-quarter net income rose 42% to $61.7 million, or 95 cents a share, with sales rising to $672 million from $605 million. Increased selling prices and improved feedstock trading results outpaced higher feedstock costs, the Houston company said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call, on average, expected earnings of 86 cents a share. Swift Energy's quarterly revenue jumps 72% (6:21 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Swift Energy Co. SFY, -0.17% reported third-quarter net income of $50.8 million, or $1.68 a share, up from $27.5 million, or 92 cents, earned in the same period last year. Quarterly revenue jumped 72%, reaching $173.3 million. Analysts, on average, had been looking for the Houston-based energy company to tally earnings of $1.32 a share on revenue of $151 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Growth came against diminished activities during the hurricane-affected third quarter of 2005, Swift Energy noted. Production for the latest quarter grew to 18.8 billion cubic feet equivalent, a company record. This was 15% higher than output for the 2006 second quarter and 39% higher than for last year's third quarter, the company said. Swift Energy also revised higher its target for full-year production to a range of 70 billion to 71 billion cubic feet equivalent. Northwest Natural Gas loss widens in seasonally weak period (6:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Northwest Natural Gas Co., NWN, -0.09% the Portland, Ore., natural-gas utility, reported a wider third-quarter net loss. The loss widened to $9.7 million, or 35 cents a share, from $8.7 million, or 31 cents, in the year-earlier period. "Northwest Natural typically posts losses during the third quarter, reflecting low summertime use of natural gas, with stronger earnings performance expected during the winter months," the company said in a statement. Revenue rose 8% to 114.9 million from $106.7 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced a consensus estimate of a loss of 31 cents for the company. LHC Group profit more than doubles (6:16 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Home nursing agency LHC Group LHCG, +2.45% said third-quarter income more than doubled to $5.2 million, or 30 cents a share, from $2.35 million, or 14 cents a share. From continuing operations, earnings rose to 29 cents a share from 20 cents a share. Revenue rose to $58.1 million from $38.6 million on growth in home-based services. Hypercom profit, sales decline (6:15 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Hypercom Corp. HYC a provider of electronic payment products and services, said third-quarter net income fell to $346,000, or one cent a share, from $3.5 million, or 7 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 14.8% to $56.7 million due to a decline in multi-lane product sales. The companys said it sees fourth-quarter revenue in the low-to-mid $60 million range. It expects fiscal 2007 revenue to rise between 9% and 12%. Stage Stores Oct same-store sales fell 2.5%; Gulf area cited (6:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Stage Stores Inc., SSI, -0.46% the Houston retailer, reported October total sales increased 7.6% to $103.6 million from $96.3 million in the year-earlier month. Comparable-store sales -- revenue from stores open at least a year -- decreased 2.5% versus the year-earlier post-hurricanes Katrina and Rita increase of 14.9%. Stores in market areas other than the Gulf Coast generally achieved comparable-store-sales increases during the month, Stage Stores said. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced a consensus estimate of a decline of 3.7% for the month. Becton, Dickinson edges past estimates with profit rise (5:33 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Medical device maker Becton, Dickinson BDX, +2.01% said fourth-quarter profit rose to $174 million, or 68 cents a share, from $149 million, or 58 cents a share, with revenue up 8% to $1.49 billion. From continuing operations excluding items, it would've earned 85 cents a share compared to 76 cents last year, the company said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected earnings of 84 cents a share. It's forecasting fiscal 2007 earnings from continuing operations of between $3.69 to $3.75 a share, up 12% to 14% from fiscal 2006. Analysts expected 2007 earnings of $3.62 a share. PMI Group insurer profit rises, tops forecast (5:04 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Residential mortgage insurer PMI Group PMI, +0.00% said third-quarter profit rose to $104.2 million, or $1.16 a share, from $95.7 million, or 97 cents a share, on improved performance in all segments and a lack of a Hurricane Katrina impact. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected earnings of $1.14 a share. Net premiums written rose to $212 million from $206 million. Mazda Motor operating profit for 1H jumps 43% to 69.76B yen (3:48 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Mazda Motor Corp.(JP:7261)reported Thursday operating profit for the September-ending first half jumped 43% from a year earlier, as improved vehicles sales in North America and Europe, along with a weaker yen, helped offset higher raw material prices and a drop in Japanese sales. Mazda also lifted its full year net profit forecasts. The Hiroshima-headquartered automaker reported operating profit for the April to September period was 69.76 billion yen ($595 million), up from 48.78 billion in the year-earlier period. Net sales were 1.521 trillion yen, up 12.5% from a year earlier. Mazda said net profit for the period fell 12.5% to 27.21 billion yen from a year earlier after it booked a one-off pension-related gain. For the full-year ending March 31, Mazda raised its operating profit outlook to 148 billion yen, an increase from its earlier estimate of 135 billion yen. Mazda revised its full year net sales forecast to 3.15 trillion yen from an earlier estimate of 3.10 trillion yen. A consensus forecast of analysts polled by Thomson Financial had put full year net sales at 3.142 trillion yen. Net profit for the full year is now forecast at 82 billion yen, up from 75 billion yen forecast earlier. BMW profit, sales slip; currency effects continue to hurt (2:58 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German carmaker BMW Ag(DE:519000)on Thursday said third-quarter profit slipped 0.7% to 452 million euros, or 0.69 euros a share. Group revenue fell 1.4% to 11.56 billion euros after auto sales dropped 5.3% to 11.09 billion euros. BMW said auto deliveries dipped 5.5% to 323,064 vehicles in the quarter. Auto production also fell, down 3.9% to 323,143 units. BMW said that its auto division was once again burdened by currency effects and rising raw material prices in the quarter. It added that deliveries of the MINI brand were slowed down by construction work at its Oxford plant. Imperial Chemicals profit climbs 50% (2:54 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Imperial Chemical Industries Plc(UK:ICI)said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit rose 50% to 147 million pounds ($280 million) as sales grew 1.8% to 1.39 billion pounds. Adjusted net profit excluding one-off gains rose 19.4% to 111 million pounds. Growth was driven by higher sales at the group's National Starch unit as well as rising paint sales in Latin America and Asia, partly offset by weaker paint sales in North America. The company said it remains confident that full year profit will be in line with previous expectations, although demand for paint in North America is expected to remain weak and it continues to experience rising raw materials prices. J.D. Wetherspoon quarterly sales rise 9.7% (2:48 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British pub chain J.D. Wetherspoon(UK:JDW)on Friday said first-quarter sales increased 9.7% to 220.4 million pounds, with comparable sales up 9.2%. At England's and Wales' non-smoking pubs, comparable sales rose 11.8%. On a two year basis, which compares the pubs to a period prior to conversion to non-smoking, comparable sales rose 2.2%. Wetherspoon said it saw a rise in underlying costs, primarily related to labor and power, in October and that the full impact of the higher costs would be felt in the remainder of the year. BASF net profit down 24.1%, hit by one-off items (2:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Chemicals group BASF(DE:515100)said its third-quarter net income fell 24.1% to 613 million euros ($780 million), while sales rose 28.4% to 13.30 billion euros. The group said adjusted income from operations rose 22% to 1.6 billion euros, boosted by recently acquired business including Engelhard and Johnson Polymer. Net profit was reduced by one-off charges. BASF said it expects demand to remain strong in the fourth quarter. The group said raw material costs remain high, putting pressure on margins, and geopolitical tensions have also made raw materials prices highly volatile. BASF added it still expects to report sales of more than 50 billion euros for the year and an increase in income from operations before special items. Carphone Warehouse profit falls, sees stable mobile market (2:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British mobile-phone retailer and broadband provider Carphone Warehouse Plc(UK:CPW)on Thursday said first-half net profit fell to 691,000 pounds from 24.6 million pounds a year earlier. Group revenue climbed 40.2% to 1.8 billion pounds. Retail sales rose 28.2% to 857.5 million pounds. Subscription connections rose 17.1% to 1.82 million. Carphone said that it's actively engaged with mobile-phone operator Vodafone Group Plc(UK:VOD) VOD, +0.54% regarding the development of a pan-European framework agreement. Carphone said it sees no change in the dynamics of the mobile phone market and that competition between players remains as strong as ever. It added it expects demand over the holiday period to be good, despite a tough comparable period. Credit Suisse profit dips 1%, tops market forecasts (2:27 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss banking group Credit Suisse CS, +1.27% said Thursday that its third-quarter net income dipped 1% to 1.89 billion Swiss francs ($1.51 billion), beating the consensus forecast of 1.64 billion francs. The bank said pretax profit from continuing operations at its investment banking unit fell 19% to 758 million francs, mainly due to lower revenue from equity trading, which was partly offset by growth in fixed income revenues. Pretax profit from the group's wealth management unit fell 5% as expenses edged higher. Credit Suisse also gave a bullish outlook, saying it sees further upside potential in equity market valuations and adding that it has a strong pipeline of new business. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. said Thursday net profit rose in its fiscal fourth quarter due to the strength of its pharmaceutical-distribution business. The drug-distribution company ABC, +1.29% said it made $122 million, or 61 cents a share, in the three months ended Sept. 30. In the year-ago fourth quarter, earnings came to $19.5 million, or 9 cents a share. The profit included a charge of 34 cents a share related to the early retirement of debt, as well as 4 cents for facility consolidations, employee severance and other costs. Net interest expense totalled $9.4 million in the prior fourth-quarter period while the latest quarter included $808,000 of net interest income. Quarterly revenue generated by Valley Forge, Pa.-based AmerisourceBergen rose to $15.64 billion from $13.92 billion. Analysts had been expecting AmerisourceBergen to post, on average, revenue of $15.28 billion, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Operating revenue in its pharmaceutical-distribution business was $14.4 billion in the latest quarter, up from $14.2 billion in the third quarter and up 13% over the year-ago fourth quarter. "The real surprise was an 11-basis point increase in the distribution operating margin, ending a deteriorating trend and ahead of internal expectations," Bank of America analyst Robert Willoughby, who rates AmerisourceBergen neutral, wrote in a research note. In the company's PharMerica divison, which includes its long-term care pharmacy and workers' compensation businesses, operating revenue in the latest quarter came in at $422 million, down sequentially from $424 million but up 5% on a year-over-year basis. AmerisourceBergen recently inked a definitive agreement with Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% whereby the two will combine their respective institutional-pharmacy businesses into an independent, publicy traded company. The transaction, expected to close in the first quarter of 2007, will create the second-largest institutional pharmacy, with annual revenue of $1.9 billion a year. Fellow drug distributor McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% on Tuesday reported a higher quarterly profit thanks to a one-time gain, cost controls and more sales of higher-margin drugs that offset a charge for discontinued operations. See full story. Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% last week posted a 19% rise in first-quarter profit, driven by the strength of it pharmaceutical-distribution business, and backed its forecast for fiscal 2007. See full story. For its part, AmerisourceBergen forecast earnings of $2.40 to $2.55 a share for fiscal 2007, including between 9 cents and 11 cents from its PharMerica Long Term Care business. Shares of AmerisourceBergen ended Thursday down 86 cents at $46.28. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Don’t ever do this with your credit card Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers
title: AmerisourceBergen posts higher quarterly profit; shares dip

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% Thursday reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $122 million, or 61 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $19.5 million, or 9 cents a share. The year-ago results reflect a charge of $110.9 million related to early retirement of debt. Total revenue reached $15.64 billion in the three months ended Sept. 30, up from $13.92 billion in the same period a year earlier. Operating revenue jumped 13% in the quarter to $14.64 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 56 cents a share in the September period. Looking ahead, the Valley Forge, Pa., drug services provider forecast earnings of $2.40 to $2.55 per share in fiscal 2007. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of $2.41 a share for the year. The stock closed Wednesday at $47.14, down 6 cents. (A previous version of this item incorrectly reported the company's total revenue figure.)
title: CORRECT: AmerisourceBergen fourth-quarter net $122 mln

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Thursday's session are Electronic Data Systems Corp., Caremark Rx Inc. and Whole Foods Market Inc. AmeriSourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% is expected to report earnings per share for the fourth quarter of 56 cents, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. CA CA, +1.25% is expected to post second-quarter per-share income of 20 cents. Caremark Rx Inc. CMX, -9.09% is expected to post income of 63 cents per share for the third quarter. Computer Sciences Corp. CSC, +3.70% is expected to post second-quarter earnings pf 71 cents per share. Consolidated Edison Inc. ED, +0.49% is expected to report per-share income of $1.06 for the third quarter. CVS Corp. CVS, -0.80% is expected to post third-quarter per-share income of 32 cents. Electronic Arts Inc. ERTS is expected to report second-quarter per-share income of 2 cents. International Paper Co. IP, +2.00% is expected to post per-share income of 43 cents for the third quarter. Univision Communications Inc. UVN, +0.00% is expected to post third-quarter earnings of 28 cents per share. Whole Foods Market Inc. WFMI is expected to report earnings of 29 cents per share for the fourth quarter. After Wednesday's closing bell, EDS EDS reported a huge growth in its fiscal third-quarter profit after the computer services and consulting giant said it had stopped losses on a U.S. military contract that had hampered its results a year ago. See full story. Watch list Allied Waste Industries Inc. AW reported a 24% jump in third-quarter profit, driven mostly by higher prices for its garbage hauling services. See full story. American Eagle Outfitters AEOS said October same-store sales rose 8%, below the average estimate of 9.9%. Total sales rose 18% to $186.4 million. The company also raised its raised its outlook for third-quarter earnings to a range of 64 cents to 65 cents a share, compared with its prior view of 61 cents to 63 cents a share. See After Hours column. AmSouth Bancorp. ASO, -3.41% said three banking companies have agreed to buy 52 of its branches in Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee. The divestitures were required by the Justice Department and Federal Reserve System in connection with AmSouth's planned merger with Regions Financial Corp. RF, +1.64% Andersons Inc. ANDE, +1.74% reported third-quarter net earnings of $8.39 million, or 51 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, Andersons posted a net loss of $636,000, or 4 cents a share. Defense contractor Caci International Inc. CAI, +1.97% said net earnings in its fiscal first quarter fell 1.7% to $18.8 million, or 60 cents a share, from $19.1 million, or 62 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter, dragged down by higher interest expense and income taxes. Revenue increased 10.5% to $467.6 million. Caremark CMX, -9.09% reported a 25% rise in third-quarter net earnings, as additional Medicare Part D services revenue helped drive its retail sales division. See full story.See After Hours column. DTE Energy Co. DTE, +0.38% reported a vast improvement in third quarter profits, as better results in its flagship electric utility boosted results from the year-ago quarter, when energy trading contracts shrank profits. See full story. Excel Technology Inc. XLTC said it has terminated its merger agreement with Coherent Inc. COHR, +4.08% due to a prohibition order from the German Federal Cartel Office. Coherent had agreed to buy Excel for roughly $376 million, or $30 a share in cash. ExpressJet Holdings Inc. XJT said traffic in October rose 9.1% to 850.8 million revenue passenger miles. Load factor, or the percentage of the plane filled with passengers, rose 0.8 percentage points to 77.5%. FMC Corp. FMC, +4.73% said it swung to third-quarter net income, as revenue gained and charges fell, of $35.1 million, or 89 cents a share. During the same period in the prior year, the net loss was $4.4 million, or 12 cents a share. Guess Inc. GES, -0.81% said third-quarter net income rose, as revenue gained, to $48.4 million, or $1.05 a share, from $20.7 million, or 46 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Analysts had expected per-share income of 72 cents. Guitar Center Inc.'s GTRC reported net earnings of $11.3 million, or 38 cents a share, compared with $14.4 million, or 51 cents a share, in the same period last year, as expenses rose. Revenue rose 12% to $472.7 million from $421.1 million. Hot Topic Inc. HOTT lowered its fourth-quarter earnings expectations after reporting that October same-store sales fell more than Wall Street expected. Sales at stores open longer than a year tumbled 7.2%, deeper than the 5.7% decline estimated by analysts. See After Hours column. InfoSpace Inc. INSP, -20.00% reported that it swung to a third-quarter loss, hurt by the loss of a major revenue-producing partner and restructuring charges. The mobile content provider reported a loss of $46.7 million, or $1.49 per share for the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared to a profit of $11.3 million, or 32 cents a share, a year ago. See After Hours column. Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% reported third-quarter net earnings of $2.94 million, or 7 cents a share, compared with $16.4 million, or 43 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The healthcare services company posted revenue of $1.06 billion vs. $951.3 million. Maxim Integrated Products Inc. MXIM, +2.15% said its fiscal first-quarter net income was $107.5 million, or 33 cents a share, versus $105.5 million, or 31 cents a share, in last year's same period. Sales rose 18.5% to $502.7 million. Plexus Corp. PLXS, +2.10% said fourth-quarter net income rose, as revenue gained, to $42.6 million, or 91 cents a share, from $10.5 million, or 24 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Quarterly revenue rose to $396.9 million from $322.2 million, while analysts had expected $397.8 million. Prudential Financial Inc. PRU, +0.63% reported a 13% drop in third-quarter net income after the giant life insurance and annuity company's tax bill jumped. See full story. Ruth's Chris Steak House Inc. RUTH, +1.24% said third-quarter net income rose, as revenue gained, to $2.33 million, or 10 cents a share, from $1.23 million, or 2 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Excluding items, quarterly per-share income from continuing operations fell to 8 cents from 10 cents in the prior year. Skyworks Solutions Inc. SWKS, +1.41% shares rose after the company said fourth-quarter per-share income, before items, rose to 7 cents from 4 cents in the prior year, while analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected 5 cents. Skyworks said quarterly revenue rose to $193.1 million from $190.2 million in the prior year. Oil refiner Sunoco Inc. SUN, -0.47% reported third-quarter net earnings of $351 million, or $2.76 a share, up from $329 million, or $2.39, a year earlier. Revenue totaled $10.5 billion, up 13% from $9.3 billion a year ago. See full story. UnumProvident Corp. UNM, +0.68% reported a third-quarter net loss of $63.7 million, or 19 cents a share, after the disability insurer had to pump more than $200 million into reserves to cover claims that have been reassessed. A year ago, UnumProvident generated a net profit of $52.6 million, or 17 cents a share. ValueClick Inc. VCLK reported third-quarter profit rose 52%, exceeding expectations, as it benefited from the growth in online advertising. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, profit rose to $16.8 million, or 17 cents a share, from $11 million or 13 cents a share a year ago. See After Hours column. Wyndham Worldwide Corp. WYN, +1.45% said it earned $92 million, or 45 cents a share, in the third quarter, down from $121 million, or 60 cents a share, in the prior year's period. Revenue for the quarter was $1.05 billion, up 10%. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: Stocks expected to move Thursday

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- McKesson Corp. on Tuesday followed the lead of a drug-distributor rival and reported higher profit thanks to a one-time gain, cost controls and more sales of higher-margin drugs that offset a charge for discontinued operations. McKesson MCK, +0.15% reported that net income for its fiscal second quarter totaled $229 million, or 75 cents a share, compared with $167 million, or 53 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $22.4 billion from $21.3 billion. The company's earnings got a boost from a one-time gain in securities-litigation reserves, worth 28 cents a share, but also were hurt by a charge worth 19 cents a share related to discontinued operations. Stripping out one-time items on the income statement, the company would have earned 66 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected McKesson to earn 58 cents a share on sales of $23.1 billion. In a written statement, San Francisco-based McKesson said that overall pharmacy distribution sales climbed 5%, and that operating earnings jumped by 29%. A greater mix of higher-margin generic drugs helped the company to a bigger gain, and cost controls enforced by the company helped as well. McKesson shares had ended the day down 60 cents, or 1.2%, at $50.09. The company raised its fiscal 2007 outlook to a range of $2.65 to $2.75 a share. The First Call projection now stands at $2.69 a share. McKesson follows the lead of rival Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% which last week reported a 19% gain in first-quarter profits thanks to big gains in its drug distribution business. The other big name in drug distribution, AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% is expected to report similar gains when it reports fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Don’t ever do this with your credit card S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh
title: McKesson follows rival's lead as earnings jump

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - McKesson Corp. and AmerisourceBergen Corp. are expected to each report next week that earnings rose almost 20% on a per-share basis, driven by improving profits in drug distribution. Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% the most diversified of the three companies, on Friday reported a 19% rise in its fiscal first quarter that was powered by its drug distribution business. See full story. "Shares of purer distributors McKesson MCK, +0.15% and AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% may fare better based on our take of Cardinal's quarter," Banc of America analyst Robert Willoughby wrote in a note to investors. "We expect national drug distributors to meet or exceed [Wall Street] expectations," Robert W. Baird analyst Eric Coldwell wrote in a recent research note. He is forecasting a strong quarter from McKesson, with earnings-per-share upside, while he expects AmerisourceBergen to meet consensus estimates and issue an "attractive" full-year outlook for 2007. McKesson is set to report results for its fiscal second quarter after the close of trading on Tuesday. It's seen posting earnings of 58 cents a share vs. 49 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call, with revenue rising to $23.11 billion from $21.61 billion. Investors may be looking for further comment from the San Francisco-based firm about a lawsuit, in which it is a defendant, concerning published benchmark drug prices A proposed settlement by list publisher First DataBank is expected to reduce average wholesale prices by an estimated 4% to 5%. McKesson has said it believes the claims against it have no merit. Thursday will bring fiscal fourth-quarter numbers from AmerisourceBergen. The company is expected to report a profit of 56 cents a share compared with 48 cents a share the year before. Analysts are looking for revenue to rise by 10%, to $15.28 billion from $13.92 billion. AmerisourceBergen should benefit from its market-leading specialty distribution as well as its leading position among independent pharmacies, according to Citigroup analyst Oksanna Butler. The company earlier this week inked a definitive agreement with Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% whereby the two will combine their respective institutional pharmacy businesses into an independent, publicy traded company. The transaction, which is expected to be complete in the first quarter of 2007, will create the second-largest institutional pharmacy, with annual revenue of $1.9 billion a year. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: McKesson, AmerisoureBergen profits seen up on distribution

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% on Friday said it has completed the acquisition of Health Advocates Inc. for around $83 million in cash. Chesterbrook, Pa.-based Amerisource expects the new business to add slightly to fiscal 2007 earnings. Health Advocates is a Tampa, Fla.-based provider of Medicare set-aside cost containment services with revenue of $20 million over the past 12 months.
title: AmerisourceBergen completes acquisition of Health Advocates

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% said Friday it's Canadian subsidiary has acquired Rep-Pharm Inc. for $48 million. Valley Forge, Pa.-based AmerisourceBergen, a pharmaceutical services company, does not expect the acquired company to be material to its earnings. Based in Oakville, Ontario, Rep-Pharm generated annual revenue of more than $600 million.
title: AmerisourceBergen acquires Rep-Pharm for $48 milion

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% shares edged 39 cents higher to $43.29 on Thursday after the company said its board has authorized the buyback of up to $750 million worth of its common stock. The Valley Forge, Pa., provider of pharmaceutical services said the repurchase program will begin upon completion of its current buyback plan, which has about $238.7 million remaining. As of July 31, the company had about 201.6 million outstanding shares.
title: AmerisourceBergen board oks $750 mln buyback program

content: Advancers AES Corp. AES, +1.25% shares rose 10% Monday after the company said its second-quarter net income about doubled to $169 million, or 25 cents a share, from $85 million, or 13 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue at the Arlington, Va., power company rose 15% to $3.04 billion from $2.65 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 17 cents a share. AES forecast 2006 earnings from operations of $1.05 a share, up from 96 cents previously, and adjusted earnings of $1.01 a share. It said revenue would rise 7% to 8%, an increase from a previous outlook of 4% to 5%. DeVry DV, +2.94% shares surged 8.1% after the company was upgraded at Lehman Bros. to equal weight from underweight. The firm cited the company's new management team. En Pointe Technologies Inc. ENPT, +0.00% shares jumped 51% after the Los Angeles-based provider of information technology products reported third-quarter earnings of $1 million, or 14 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $100,000, or a penny per share. Revenue rose 3% in the latest three months to $95.6 million from $92.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The company cited strong sales in June and better margins for the higher profit. Fairchild Corp. FA, +0.00% shares rose 14.1% after the company said FA Holdings LLC has offered to buy the company's outstanding stock for $2.73 a share in cash in a going-private transaction. FA Holdings is led by Jeffrey Steiner, Fairchild's chairman and chief executive, and Philip Sassower, chairman of Phoenix Group LLC, said McLean, Va.-based Fairchild. Fairchild said its board has made no decisions regarding the offer, and warned stockholders that "there can be no assurance that any definitive agreement will be executed Kindred Healthcare KND, +0.00% shares gained 6.7% after the company signed a non-binding letter of intent with AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% to combine their institutional pharmacy businesses, PharMerica Long-Term Care and Kindred Pharmacy Services into an independent, publicly traded company. The new company would be the second largest in the institutional pharmacy services market and is expected to have revenues of around $1.9 billion. Preliminary synergy cost savings from the combination are estimated to be approximately $30 million. LoJack Corp. LOJN shares moved up 11% after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $5.5 million, or 29 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $5 million, or 26 cents a share. Revenue at the Westwood, Mass.-based maker of car theft prevention technology products rose 15% to $56.7 million from $49.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Pro forma earnings, excluding stock-based compensation expense, totaled $6.1 million, or 32 cents a share, in the latest quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 28 cents a share in the June period on revenue of $54.4 million. Marvel Entertainment Inc. MVL, +1.31% shares gained 7% after the company lifted its profit outlook for the year as it reported second-quarter net profit that fell 37% to $16.3 million, or 19 cents a share, from $25.8 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. The results for the most recent quarter included a charge of 1 cent a share. The average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 11 cents a share. Revenue slipped 4% to $84.4 million. Marvel upgraded its earnings outlook for the year to the range of 50 cents to 60 cents a share from an earlier forecast of 46 cents to 57 cents a share - citing lower taxes in the second quarter and the positive impact of share repurchase activity. Opinion Research Corp. ORCI shares soared 87% after the company agreed to be acquired by infoUSA Inc. IUSA, +1.50% for $134.3 million, including the assumption of debt. The deal values Opinion Research at $12 per share. Syneron Medical Ltd. ELOS shares rose 16% after the Israeli developer of medical aesthetic devices reported second-quarter earnings rose 29% on 37% higher revenue. Earnings reached $8.9 million, or 32 cents a share, from $6.9 million, or 25 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were 41 cents against 34 cents, reflecting stock-option expense in the latest period and a charge for a patent-lawsuit settlement a year earlier. Revenue rose to $27.5 million from $20.1 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced a consensus estimate of 39 cents on $27 million of revenue for the company. Decliners American Vanguard AVD, +2.28% shares lost 7.3% Monday after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $3.3 million, or 23 cents a share, on sales of about $42.7 million. The Newport Beach, Calif., developer of agricultural products said it saw higher freight, delivery and warehousing costs in the quarter, as well as greater interest expense due to increased debt levels and higher interest rates. Camtek Ltd. CAMT, +1.50% shares fell 6.3% after the company reported its second-quarter earnings more than tripled on 67% higher revenue. Profit reached $5.2 million, or 17 cents a share, in the quarter, up from $1.5 million, or 5 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue was $27.9 million versus $16.8 million. Camtek forecast third-quarter revenue of $26 million to $30 million and affirmed its previous estimate of $100 million to $110 million for the year. The company also said it remains comfortable with its outlook for revenue of between $100 million and $110 million for the year. Clinical Data Inc. CLDA shares lost 7.6% after the company named C. Evan Ballantyne senior vice president and chief financial officer. Ballantyne succeeds Israel Stein, who was serving in the CFO position on an interim basis. Ballantyne most recently served a senior vice president and chief financial officer of ZymeQuest Inc., a private medical technology company. CommScope Inc. CTV, +0.68% shares fell 7.2% after the company said it's offered to purchase Andrew Corp. ANDW for $9.50 per share in cash. The bid is valued at roughly $1.7 billion, including the assumption of $186 million in debt. CommScope said the proposal represents a premium of roughly 36% over the existing merger agreement between Andrew and ADC Telecommunications Inc. ADCT which values Andrew shares at $6.97 each based on Friday's close for ADC's stock at $12.22. Andrew shares finished Friday at $7.89, down 1.5%. CommScope said it believes the acquisition of Andrew would add to earnings in the first year after closing, excluding special items. CommScope, which said it would finance the deal through a combination of cash on hand and debt, has requested a response to its offer from Andrew by 5:00 PM Eastern Time on August 11, explaining its proposal will expire at that time. See full story. Conn's Inc. CONN, +5.10% shares dropped 14% after the company reported its second-quarter sales results and lowered in full-year earnings forecast. The Beaumont, Texas-based retailer of appliances and consumer electronics reported second-quarter sales of $163.7 million, up 13.8% from $143.8 million last year. Same-store sales rose 7.2% in the period ended July 31, the company said. The company said it remains confident in its fiscal 2007 same-store sales forecast. Conn's also lowered its fiscal 2007 earnings forecast to a range of $1.60 to $1.75 a share from a range of $1.85 to $1.90 a share, citing "changes in its operating environment." The company said in a statement it is facing "considerable head winds" in fiscal 2007. El Paso Corp. EP, +0.00% shares dropped 5.2% after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $150 million, up from a year-ago loss of $238 million. After payment of preferred dividends, the company posted net income available to common shareholders of $141 million, or 21 cents a share, up from a year-ago equivalent loss of $246 million, or 38 cents a share. The latest results include a $27 million, or 2 cents a share, gain on derivatives used to hedge the price risk of natural gas and oil production. Operating revenue reached $1.21 billion in the three months ended June 30, up from a total of $1.17 billion in the year-ago period. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 18 cents a share in the June period on revenue of $1.17 billion. Emmis EMMS, -0.65% shares tumbled 19% after Chief Executive Jeff Smulyan withdrew his offer of $15.25 a share to take the radio broadcaster private. See full story. Hansen Natural Corp. HANS shares sank 26%reported second-quarter earnings up 85% on 83% higher net sales. Explaining the results, the company cited in particular sales of Monster brand energy drinks, which more than doubled. Net income reached $28.2 million, or 28 cents a share, from $15.2 million, or 16 cents, in the year-earlier period. Net sales, which are sales after subtracting promotional allowances, rose to $156 million from $85.4 million. Gross sales, before promotional allowances, rose 78% to $182.1 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced a consensus estimate of 28 cents a share on revenue of $157 million for the company. See full story. Los Angeles-based insurer Mercury General Corp. MCY, +1.37% shares lost 10% after the company said its second quarter profit slipped to $37.8 million, or 69 cents a share, from a profit of $73.6 million, or $1.35 a share a year ago. The latest results reflect net realized investment gains, net of tax, of $2.8 million, or 5 cents a share. The company said net premiums written rose 3.3% in the quarter to $753.8 million from $729.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of $1.23 a share in the June period. The stock closed Friday at $55.47, up 14 cents. Mylan Laboratories MYL, +1.65% shares tumbled 13% Monday after the Food and Drug Administration allowed another company to sell a generic version of the pain reliever as well. See full story. Radio One Inc. ROIAK shares sank 13% after the company reported its second-quarter net income of $8.1 million, or 8 cents a share, down from $19.8 million, or 19 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell 4% to $97.8 million from $101.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 12 cents a share on revenue of $99.7 million. "Last quarter, we said that the second quarter could be the bottom for the radio industry and for Radio One, and, on its face, this quarter was pretty disappointing," said Alfred Liggins, III, Radio One's chief executive and president, in a statement. Reliv International RELV, -3.78% shares slumped 35% after the Chesterfield, Mo., nutritional supplement maker reported a decline in its second-quarter results, blaming a disappointing performance in the U.S. TNS Inc. TNS shares lost 23% after the Reston, Va., provider of data communications services reported an adjusted profit for the second quarter that fell short of Wall Street's consensus view, said it expects adjusted earnings for the full year to decline between 22% and 30%, and unveiled plans to separate the chairman and chief executive officer positions going forward.
