title: Monday's biggest stock gainers and decliners

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stocks closed with moderate losses Monday, pressured by investor wariness a day ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary-policy decision and by a supply disruption at a BP-run oil field in Alaska that touched off a rally in crude futures. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% closed 20.97 points lower at 11,219.38. The S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38% and the Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPX respectively, finished down almost 3.59 points at 1,275.77 and 12.55 points lower at 2,072.50. Volume was light, with 1.34 billion shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, where declining stocks outnumbered rising shares by 5 to 3. There were 1.44 billion shares traded on the Nasdaq market, with 19 falling stocks for every 10 shares trading higher. "We're not in a bull market, and we're not in a bear market," said Al Goldman, A.G. Edwards' chief market strategist. "We're in a turtle market. "A turtle waddles around in the muck of all kinds of problems." Investors are still adjusting to new Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke and are uncertain how to read his signals. But many think the Fed will break Tuesday from the steady stream of quarter-percentage-point increases that have been put in place since June 2004. 'We're not in a bull market, and we're not in a bear market. We're in a turtle market.' Al Goldman, A.G. Edwards The overnight bank lending rate now stands at 5.25%. Although equities investors want to see a pause in rate hikes Tuesday, few are expecting the market to rally much if the central bank takes a break. Marc Pado, U.S. market strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald, said a rate pause is already priced into stocks. A.G. Edwards' Goldman added that the market's focus after the Fed meeting is likely to shift to the U.S. economic slowdown, and particularly to the question, "Are we in for a soft landing or a hard landing?" He also said that recent data show economic cooling, but whether the slowing is significant or minor is open to debate. Alaskan chill News over the weekend of a BP pipeline shutdown in Prudhoe Bay sent crude futures rallying. "This is a psychological negative," said Goldman. "We've anticipated possible supply problems in the Middle East. But this is the U.S.A. Right now, the market is acting like it's easier to go down than up." The shutdown is to deprive world markets of 400,000 barrels of oil a day. Escalating violence in the Middle East added to investors' worries. Overnight, Israeli forces took on Hezbollah fighters near the Mediterranean coast, while air strikes continued. There was little market reaction to news from the Federal Reserve that consumers took on a a bigger-than-expected $10.3 billion in new debt in June, the Federal Reserve said Monday, nearly double what they'd taken on in May. The MarketWatch forecast, based on a survey of economists, called for consumers to take on $3.4 billion in new credit. Other markets BP's problems at Alaska's Prudhoe Bay, and the resulting pressure on supply, sparked a crude rally. The September contract closed $2.22, or 3%, higher at $76.98 a barrel. See full story. The dollar was higher, as many foreign-exchange traders leaned toward the likelihood that the Fed will not lift rates Tuesday. Although a pause wouldn't support the dollar against its rivals, market players didn't wish to push it lower after a steep decline Friday. The dollar late in the day was up 0.3% at 115.03 yen, as the euro fell 0.2% to $1.2847. See full story. Treasury prices were lower, sending yields higher, as traders adjusted positions ahead of Tuesday's Fed decision. However, bond traders were cheered by the prospect of a possible cessation in rate increases. See full story. The 10-year benchmark note closed down 5/32 at 101 18/32 with a yield TNX, -1.23% of 4.923%. Gold futures tracked crude oil into positive territory. The December contract closed up $3.50 at $659.50 an ounce. See full story. Stocks on the move The oil sector was active as investors monitored BP's supply problem and the consequent crude rally. See full story. Shares of BP BP, +2.37% closed 2.9% lower at $70.45. Other oil majors were higher, including Dow component Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, +2.47% which ended 0.8% higher at $69.23, as well as Chevron Corp. CVX, +1.73% up 1.8% at $66.83. Dow component Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% was under pressure, after Prudential cut its earnings and revenue forecasts for the chip manufacturer. The stock closed down 1% at $17.29. Shares of Dell Inc. DELL dropped 1.7% to $22.05. The company was described as being "in serious trouble" in a Barron's Online story over the weekend. AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% closed 1% higher at $43.18, while Kindred Healthcare Inc. KND, +0.00% moved up 6.7% to $30.94. The two companies have signed a letter of intent to combine their two institutional pharmacy businesses. title: U.S. stocks lower on eve of FOMC; rates loom large

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. and Kindred Healthcare Inc. said Monday they have agreed to combine their institutional pharmacy businesses into a separate public company that would become one of its industry's largest players. The tentative deal was viewed as positive on Wall Street, giving investors a way to see the value of Kindred's pharmacy division while allowing AmerisourceBergen to focus on its core distribution business. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% of Chesterbrook, Pa., and Kindred KND, +0.00% of Louisville, Ky., said they expect to sign a definitive agreement on or about Sept. 30, and complete the deal in the first quarter of 2007. Kindred's stock rallied 6.7% to close at $30.94, while shares of AmerisourceBergen added 1.1% to end the session at $43.18. Their newly created company would be second only to Omnicare Inc. OCR, +0.00% as the nation's top provider of drugs and prescription services to hospitals, nursing homes and other clients. Under the plan, PharMerica Long-Term Care and Kindred Pharmacy Services would be separated from their respective parent companies via tax-free spin-offs. The businesses would be combined in a stock swap, with each side owning 50% of the shares. The new company is expected to generate revenues of about $1.9 billion, with preliminary cost savings estimated at about $30 million. "It's about providing the best of the best of what each company has," Dave Yost, chief executive of AmerisourceBergen, said in an interview. PharMerica and Kindred Pharmacy would each make a one-time cash distribution of $150 million to their respective parent companies. They would fund the distribution by borrowing $150 million each, giving the new company $300 million of new debt. With a customer base of 330,000 licensed beds in 41 states, earnings before interest and income taxes are forecasted at $75 million. Kindred CEO Paul Diaz said the new company would look to further grow the size of the new company both organically and through additional acquisitions. "As we put together the capital structure, we have been careful to ensure there was lots of financial flexibility," Yost said, noting that such financial leverage would enable the company to seize on any acquisition opportunities. Stifel Nicolaus noted the combined company would act as a more significant national competitor for Omnicare, whose shares were off 1% in afternoon trade, at $46.12. "However, investors should keep in mind the new company will only be about 30% of Omnicare's size in terms of pharmacy revenue," analyst Jerry Doctrow wrote in a morning note, "and the strategy for the new pharmacy seems to endorse many of the advantages that Omnicare already has or is pursuing in terms of scale, repackaging/automation, increased technology and related services." Morgan Stanley analyst David Veal said, in the near term, he expects few changes to the competitive landscape. It will take at least six months for the deal to close, he wrote in a note to investors. "Second, we believe that fully realizing the scale benefits of the new company, which are in our view the linchpin for renewed strategic momentum, will take time." The combination does not include AmerisourceBergen's workers' compensation business, which is reported in its PharMerica segment, nor Kindred's hospital, nursing center or contract rehabilitation businesses. The deal requires regulatory review by the Federal Trade Commission, and the Securities and Exchange Commission, and a favorable determination by the Internal Revenue Service. The parties hired Heidrick & Struggles to conduct a national search for a chief executive officer and chief financial officer to lead the new public company, though Yost said "talent from within" would be considered for all phases of leadership. Deutsche Bank Securities is acting as financial adviser to AmerisourceBergen and Lehman Brothers is acting as Kindred's financial adviser. title: AmerisourceBergen, Kindred set pharma-services merger

title: BP, Andrew, Marvel Entertainment in the spotlight

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) - U.S. stock market futures sagged on Monday, with a rally in crude-oil futures and nervousness ahead of a Federal Reserve interest rate decision weighing. S&P 500 futures dropped 4.70 points at 1,281.30 and Nasdaq 100 futures shed 6.25 points at 1,509.25. Dow industrial futures slumped 38 points to 11,240. Overseas, the Nikkei 225 tumbled 2.2% in Tokyo, and the German DAX 30 lost 1.6%. On Friday, markets couldn't hold early gains despite jobs data that raised hopes the Federal Reserve would pause its interest-rate hike agenda. For the week, the Dow industrials rose 0.2%, the S&P 500 rose 0.1% and the Nasdaq Composite gave up 0.4%. See Market Snapshot. Ahead of Tuesday's Fed decision, some traders may be focusing more on the 0.4% average hourly earnings growth than the lower-than-forecast 113,000 jobs growth. "It may be the oil story that's exacerbating things, but people are sitting there thinking, 'Why on earth did the Bank of England lift interest rates? What if the Fed does the same,'" said Tom Hougaard, market strategist for City Index, a U.K. spread betting firm. The Bank of England last week unexpectedly lifted its key interest rate. The European Central Bank did likewise, though the ECB hike was expected. Crude-oil futures soared over 2% on Monday before paring gains after BP BP, +2.37% started shutting down a key oil field representing 8% of daily U.S. production. BP is shutting down its Prudhoe Bay oil field in Alaska, taking some 400,000 barrels a day of crude oil off the world market, following the discovery of a corroded pipeline and a small leak. Crude for September delivery shot up $1.12 to $75.88 a barrel in morning electronic trading, after reaching a high of $76.67 earlier in the session. BP shares lost 1.8% to $71.24 in pre-open trading on Inet. See BP story. In other oil companies seeing early activity, Total SA TOT, +2.65% slipped 24 cents to $67.20, Dow component Exxon Mobil XOM, +2.47% added 31 cents to $69 and Valero Energy VLO, +2.76% gained 1.5% to $67.20. Meanwhile, copper production could be impacted if, as expected, workers at the key Escondida mine in Chile strike. The mine is majority owned by BHP Billiton BLT, +1.93% and 30% held by Rio Tinto RIO, +2.65% See metals story. Rio Tinto's U.S.-listed shares slid 1.7% to $207.88 on Inet. The U.S. dollar was relatively steady, edging up vs. both the euro and the Japanese yen. Hansen Natural Corp. HANS plunged 18% to $32.97, and was the most-active stock trading on Inet, after the beverage maker reported revenue that fell just short of expectations, and was the target of a negative report in the Wall Street Journal. Elsewhere, Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% may sell profitable Land Rover together with Jaguar to drum up interest, The Sunday Times (of London) newspaper reported, citing unnamed sources. Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A, +1.04% BRK.B, +1.43% said late Friday that second-quarter profit climbed 62% as investment income climbed and as the company's insurance business sold more hurricane coverage at higher prices. Also late Friday, CEO Jeff Smulyan withdrew his $15.25 a share offer for radio broadcaster Emmis Communications EMMS, -0.65% Affiliated Computer Services Inc. ACS, +8.70% the Dallas provider of business-process-outsourcing and information-technology solutions, said it would complete its inquiry into its stock-option-granting practices in September and update investors on the size of the charge it would take for the compensation. The company said that its disclosure on this matter in its Securities and Exchange Commission Form 10-Q filed in May cannot be relied upon. AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% and Kindred Healthcare KND, +0.00% agreed to merge their institutional pharmacy businesses into a new, publicly traded company with annual revenue of $1.9 billion. content: Panera Bread quarterly income rises (8:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Panera Bread Co. PNRA Tuesday evening said second-quarter revenue rose as net income grew to $14.1 million, or 44 cents a share, from $10.4 million, or 33 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share result of 44 cents. The St. Louis-based bakery and cafe chain said quarterly revenue rose to $197.1 million from $140.2 million in the prior year. Analysts had expected a result of $199 million. Panera sees third-quarter earnings per share of 34 cents to 37 cents, with analysts looking for 44 cents. For the full year, the company sees earnings per share of $1.93 to $2, while analysts are looking for $2. Supertex quarterly earnings rise (7:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Supertex Inc.'s SUPX shares fell 8.7% to $32 in after-hours trading Tuesday after the company released first-quarter earnings of $4.9 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with $2.8 million, or 21 cents a share, in the same period last year. Excluding stock-based compensation, the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based maker of mixed signal semiconductors reported per-share earnings of 39 cents. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected per-share earnings of 37 cents. The company said quarterly revenue rose 54% to $24.6 million vs. $16 million. The polled analysts had forecast revenue of $25 million. Land America quarterly earnings rise (7:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - LandAmerica Financial Group Inc. LFG, +3.41% after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter earnings of $35.6 million, or $2.06 cents a share, compared with $30.2 million, or $1.70 cents a share, in the same period last year. The Richmond, Va.-based insurer said quarterly operating revenue rose 2% to $971.1 million vs. $952.4 million. CORRECT: QLogic quarterly earnings fall (7:06 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- QLogic Corp.'s QLGC, +0.12% shares rose 3% to $17.16 in after-hours trading Tuesday after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $21 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with $41.8 million, or 23 cents a share, in the same period last year. Foundry posts partial results; sales miss forecast (4:20 PM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Foundry Networks Inc. FDRY said late Tuesday that second-quarter revenue rose 12% to $108.4 million from a year ago, but the company did not release other details in light of an ongoing investigation into its practice of issuing stock options. Sales fell short of the Wall Street's target of $116.2 million, according to the consensus of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Revenue was also lower than the $114 million generated in the 2006 first quarter. Foundry said it would release further financial details after its probe is complete. Endesa said its profit benefited from 225 million euros of gains from asset sales, 197 million euros of higher compensation in Spain and Portugal and 118 million euros related to a write-up in valuation in Italy. Endesa also raised its performance targets, saying it now aims to achieve net income of 3 billion euros in 2009 compared to its prior target of 2.2 billion euros. Endesa, which is a takeover target for both E.On EON, +1.19% and Gas Natural, also said it plans to pay total dividends of 9.9 billion euros in the 2005-2009 period, compared to its previous target of 7 billion euros. 888 Holdings Q2 revenue rises as number of players slips (3:03 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Online gaming company 888 Holdings(UK:888)said Tuesday that second-quarter net gaming revenue rose 23% to $80 million, due to a 48% increase in poker revenue to $35 million. Revenue from casino gaming rose 9% to $45 million. The number of active players in the quarter fell 9% to 281,000, which 888 attributed to the soccer World Cup. 888 said that overall, trading in the first half of the year has been in line with expectation and it remains confident of making further progress in the second half of the year. Arm Holdings profit, revenue rise (2:55 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Chipmaker Arm Holdings Plc ARMHY (UK:ARM)said second-quarter pretax profit rose 17% to 23 million pounds ($42.6 million) as revenue rose 14% to 65.7 million pounds. Analysts were expecting pretax profit of 22.5 million pounds, with revenue in a range of 63.1 million pounds to 64.6 million pounds, according to AFX News. The growth in revenue was due to an increase in the number of licenses the company issued and higher royalties. Arm said it signed 45 license agreements in the quarter. Arm said it remains confident of achieving strong growth for the year, in line with market expectations. Sharp Corp. profit rises 23% on brisk flat-screen sales (2:50 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Sharp Corp., the world's largest maker of LCD televisions, said Tuesday afternoon that net profit for the quarter ended June 30 rose 23% on year to 23.9 billion yen ($205 million). The Osaka-based firm said that strong demand for its flat-screen TVs and mobile phones was behind the growth, which was roughly in line with analysts' expectations. Operating profit rose 14% to 40.43 billion yen, while sales grew 13% to 693.72 billion yen, the company said. Schwarz Pharma profit climbs on Pfizer rights payment (2:39 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German drugmaker Schwarz Pharma(DE:722190)said its first-half profit jumped to 37.3 million euros ($47 million) from 2.1 million euros on an upfront payment from Pfizer Inc. for fesoterodine rights. Revenue slipped 1.1% to 483 million euros. For the year, it expects to break even on revenue of approximately 900 million euros. BP's adjusted profit climbs stronger-than-forecast 23% (2:24 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oil major BP plc BP, +2.37% (UK:BP)on Tuesday reported a stronger-than-forecast 23% increase in second-quarter profit on a replacement cost basis to $6.12 billion, as higher oil and gas prices and higher refining margins offset a decline in production. Analysts were expecting replacement-cost profit of $5.98 billion. Production slipped 2.2% to 4.02 million barrels of oil equivalent a day, after disposals and declining prodution from existing profit centers more than offset production growth at its jointly held TNK-BP Russian venture and from new profit centers. Excluding divestments and the impact of higher prices on entitlements, it's still holding to 2006 guidance of production between 4.1 million and 4.2 million barrels a day. It now expects capital expenditure to be between $15.5 billion and $16 billion for the year and divestment proceeds of more than $6 billion. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Republished to correct per-share result for 2005 third quarter SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. on Tuesday said its fiscal third-quarter net profit rose 26%, helped by lower interest and tax expenses and a rebound in its PharMerica division. Valley Forge, Pa.-based AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% said it made $119.5 million, or 58 cents a share, compared with last year's profit of $94.8 million, or 45 cents a share. Both quarters include one-time gains of a penny a share. Total revenue rose 13% to $15.69 billion vs. last year's $13.83 billion, while operating revenue rose to $14.45 billion from $12.6 billion. In its institutional pharmacy business, PharMerica, revenue rose 8% year-over-year and climbed 2.7% sequentiallly. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast a per-share profit of 53 cents on operating revenue of $15.1 billion. The company's stock added 24 cents to close at $43.75. AmerisourceBergen lifted its revenue projection for the year to a range of 12% to 13% from its previous range of 10% to 12%. That translates into a 9% to 11% fourth-quarter increase in revenue. That expected slower growth comes at the hands of two lost accounts worth about $1.5 billion in sales, the company said. The company is forecasting full-year earnings in a range of $2.16 to $2.24 a share, up from a previous projection of income in a range $2.06 to $2.21 a share. That assumes a fourth-quarter profit of 51 cents to 59 cents a share. At Thomson First Call, analysts targeted an average fourth-quarter profit of 55 cents share and full-year income of $2.06 a share. The company ended the quarter with a hefty $1.66 billion in cash. It also raised its expectations for cash flow from operations by $100 million to a range of $700 million to $800 million. Banc of America Securities lifted its 2006 per-share profit forecast to $2.19 from $2.16 but left its price target of $47 unchanged. "AmerisourceBergen's results should offer a lift for all of the [drug] distribution stocks, given the encouraging revenue trend," analyst Robert Willoughby wrote in a morning note. "Its shares should fare particularly well on indications that Medicare contributions will outweigh costs in coming quarters and that it plans to continue an aggressive share repurchase program, factors that should drive additional earnings-per-share growth." title: AmerisourceBergen profit surges 26%

The company reported diluted net income of 45 cents a share for the quarter. See corrected story. title: AmerisourceBergen profit surges 26%

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% on Tuesday said fiscal third quarter net income rose to $119.5 million, or 58 cents a share, from $94.8 million, or 45 cents a share. Total revenue rose to $15.69 billion from $13.83 billion. Anlaysts, on average, expected it to post a profit of 53 cents a share on revenue of $15.1 billion, according to Thomson Financial. The Valley Forge, Pa.-based company said it expects the fiscal year 2006 operating revenue growth to be in a range of 12% to 13%, up from its previous range of 10% to 12%, which assumes 9% to 11% growth in the fiscal fourth quarter. Expected slower growth in the coming quarter partially reflects the loss of two accounts. It now expects to earn $2.16 to $2.24 a share on a GAAP basis for the year, compared to its prior forecast of $2.06 to $2.21 a share.
title: AmerisourceBergen profit rises, updates forecast for year

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Higher quarterly profits are expected to be reported by drug distributors AmerisourceBergen Corp. and McKesson Corp. next week, reflecting a rise in pharmaceutical sales. "We're seeing a small uptick in the top line of drug distributors this quarter," Raymond James & Associates analyst John Ransom said. "The question is, how much will that drop to the bottom line?" AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% the third-largest drug distributor in North America, is due to report its fiscal third-quarter results on Tuesday. Analysts are looking for earnings of 53 cents a share compared with 46 cents a share last year. Revenue, meanwhile, is expected to rise 20%, to $15.1 billion from $12.6 billion. The company raised its full-year 2006 per-share profit estimate back in April, to a range of $2.06 to $2.21 from $1.98 to $2.13, and took its revenue growth forecast to 10% to 12% from 7% to 9%. Amerisource Bergen reports results for two segments: pharmaceutical distribution, which includes it drug, specialty and packaging groups, and PharMerica, which includes the long-term care pharmacy and workers' compensation businesses. The second-quarter performance of the PharMerica division was a source of concern to the company's watchers on Wall Street, and may prove to be so again in the latest quarter. See full story. "PharMerica remains weak given increased competition, reduced manufacturer rebates and some transitory expenses related to Medicare Part D implementation," Baird analyst Eric Coldwell wrote in note to investors ahead of the results. On Thursday, the larger and more diversified McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% will unveil numbers for its fiscal first quarter. The San Francisco company in late June affirmed its fiscal 2007 forecast, which included charges that will impact its first-quarter results. It included a $6 million pre-tax restructuring charge, and expenses associated with the acquisitions of HealthCom Partners LLC and RelayHealth Corp., all of which will impact McKesson's first-quarter operating profit in its provider technologies segment. It also contained a $19 million pre-tax restructuring charge associated with the sale of the company's automated prescription systems business unit, which will impact its first-quarter operating profit in its pharmaceutical solutions segment. See full story. McKesson is expected to post first-quarter earnings of 62 cents a share on revenue of $22.63 billion vs. 55 cents a share and $21.06 billion in the same period a year ago. title: AmerisourceBergen, McKesson to report

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Tuesday's session are Genentech Inc., Monster Worldwide Inc. and Secure Computing Corp. AAR Corp. AIR, +1.36% is expected to report earnings per share of 30 cents for the fourth quarter, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Acergy SA ACGY is expected to report second-quarter per-share income of 11 cents. Commerce Bancshares Inc. CBSH, +1.18% is expected to report second-quarter earnings per share of 79 cents. Ferro Corp. FOE, +0.30% is expected to post earnings per share of 25 cents for the first quarter. Gannett GCI, +0.50% is expected to report per-share income of $1.31 for the second quarter. Infosys Technologies Ltd. INFY, +0.90% is expected to post first-quarter earnings per share of 55 cents. Mercantile Bank Corp. MBWM, -2.49% is expected to report earnings per share of 64 cents for the second quarter. Nevada Gold & Casinos Inc. UWN, -5.19% is expected to post fourth-quarter earnings per share of 6 cents. Resources Global Professionals RECN, +0.62% is expected to post per-share income of 31 cents for the fourth quarter. Tekelec TKLC is expected to report first-quarter per-share income of 14 cents. See full story.See After Hours column. ABC, +1.29% said its AmerisourceBergen Canada Corp. subsidiary has agreed to buy Rep-Pharm Inc. Barnes Group Inc. B, +1.78% said its aerospace unit has signed a long-term agreement with Goodrich Corp.'s GR, +5.88% aerostructures division that will generate more than $300 million in sales. CLF, +5.30% said it has approved the buyback of up to an additional two million shares of its common stock. Constellation Brands Inc. STZ, +3.37% said it will spend about $89 million and cut about 236 jobs to integrate Vincor International Inc. into its operations. The company also raised its fiscal 2007 earnings outlook. See full story. Curis CRIS, -2.96% said the company and Genentech Inc. DNA, -1.03% have halted enrollment in the basal cell carcinoma Phase I clinical trial, and have decided not to move forward with the Phase I molecule in its current formulation. Under the agreement, P&G will develop and commercialize ARYx's drug, ATI-7505, for the treatment of gastrointestinal disorders such as gastroesophageal reflux disease and gastroparesis. REG, -0.07% said it now sees second-quarter funds from operations of 92 cents a share to 94 cents a share, up from the previous outlook of between 84 cents a share to 89 cents a share. content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% after Tuesday's closing bell said its AmerisourceBergen Canada Corp. subsidiary has agreed to buy Rep-Pharm Inc. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. The pharmaceutical services company said it expects the acquisition "will not be material to earnings", adding that it plans to complete it by Sep. 30. Rep-Pharm, based in Oakville, Ontario, generated revenue of more than $600 million during the last 12 months, AmerisourceBergen said.
title: AmerisourceBergen subsidiary to buy Rep-Pharm

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - McKesson Corp., Cardinal Health Inc. and AmerisourceBergen Corp. were added to Citigroup's research list on Wednesday. Analyst Oksanna Butler initiated coverage of McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% with a hold rating and a $52 price target, noting that in addition to its leading position in the drug distribution space, the San Francisco company boasts a high-margin, fast-growing healthcare technology business. Butler forecast first-quarter earnings of 64 cents a share, as well as $2.66 a share for the full-year 2007 period and $3.02 a share for 2008. Overall, Butler is looking for average earnings-per-share growth of 13% through fiscal 2009, driven primarily by high single-digit top-line growth enhanced by modestly expanding distribution margins. The company said in May it expects to post earnings between $2.55 and $2.70 a share for 2007. McKesson shares finished the session at $45.59, up 59 cents, or 1.3%. Butler started coverage of Cardinal Health Inc. CAH, +0.94% with a buy rating and a 52-week price target of $83. Cardinal Health shares added 57 cents to close at $67.30. The Dublin, Ohio, drug distributor is in the midst of a turnaround, Butler noted; it's not only recovering from numerous operating challenges over the last two years but is resolving an accounting probe. Butler forecast average earnings growth of 18% through full-year 2008 for Cardinal, with a fourth-quarter profit of 88 cents a share, full-year 2006 earnings of $3.11 a share, and a per-share profit of $3.74 for 2007. On Monday, Cardinal said it still expects to post 2006 per-share earnings, excluding one-time items, in the upper half of its $3.30 to $3.55 forecast range. It forecast 2007 earnings, excluding items, of $3.50 to $3.70 a share. Beginning in fiscal 2007, the per-share earnings outlook includes the impact of equity compensation, the company noted. Rounding out the group, Butler started coverage of AmerisourceBergen ABC, +1.29% with a buy rating and $49 price target. "The company's industry-leading specialty and robust generic distribution businesses, dominance among independent retailers, as well as further synergies anticipated from its 2001 merger with Bergen Brunswig, provide significant growth opportunities," Butler wrote in a note to investors. For the fiscal third quarter, Butler is looking for 53 cents a share in earnings, while the full-year 2006 forecast was set at $2.06 a share and 2007 earnings are expected to come in at $2.34 a share. Valley Forge, Pa., AmerisourceBergen is forecasting earnings from continuing operations of $2.06 to $2.21 a share for fiscal 2006. The stock added 23 cents to end Wednesday at $40.98. content: Granite Contruction quarterly loss narrows (8:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Granite Construction Inc. GVA, +4.67% late Wednesday reported a first-quarter net loss of $1.4 million, or 3 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $8.3 million, or 20 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Watsonville, Calif.-based contracting and construction materials company rose to $496 million from $420.9 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast a loss of 10 cents a share on revenue of $463 million. Forward Industries quarterly income falls (8:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Forward Industries Inc. FORD, +0.00% shares fell more than 40% in after-hours trading Wednesday. The company said second-quarter net income was $63,515, or a penny a share, down from $2.02 million, or 27 cents a share, during the same period last year. Forward said quarterly revenue was $6.46 million, down from $11.2 million last year. Friedman, Billings, Ramsey quarterly income rises (8:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Friedman, Billings, Ramsey Group Inc. FBR, +1.30% Wednesday evening said first-quarter net income $26.6 million, or 16 cents a share, down from $24.4 million, or 14 cents a share, during the same period last year. The investment bank said quarterly revenue was $338.7 million, up from $237.8 million last year. Republic Airways quarterly profit surges 14% (7:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Republic Airways Holdings Inc. RJET late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $16.9 million, or 39 cents a share, up 14% from $14.8 million, or 49 cents a share, last year. There were 42.9 million shares outstanding compared with 30.5 million last year. Revenue at the Indianapolis-based company rose 22.7% to $257.3 million from $209.8 million. Kirby quarterly income rises (7:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Kirby Corp. KEX, +3.57% after Wednesday's closing bell said first-quarter net income was $22.6 million, or 85 cents a share, compared with $13.3 million, or 52 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for per-share income of 80 cents. The maritime transportation company reported quarterly revenue of $224.9 million, up from $184.4 million last year. Analysts were looking for a result of $218 million. For the second quarter, the company sees per-share income of 85 cents to 90 cents, with analysts looking for 87 cents. FMC quarterly profit rises (7:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- FMC Corp. FMC, +4.73% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $67.7 million, or $1.71 a share, vs. $64.5 million, or $1.67 a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, earnings came in at $1.74 a share compared with $1.11 a share last year. Revenue rose to $594.1 million from $552.4 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of $1.40 a share on revenue of $592 million. FMC, a Philadelphia-based chemicals company, forecast second-quarter earnings of $1.40 to $1.50 a share excluding items, and raised its 2006 earnings forecast to $5.35 to $5.55 a share excluding items. Denny's swings to a quarterly profit (6:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Denny's Corp. DENN, +0.59% after Wednesday's closing bell said first-quarter net income was $712,000, or a penny a share. During the same period last year, the company reported a net loss of $1.46 million, or 2 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share loss of a penny. The restaurant operator said quarterly revenue was $248 million, up from $240 million last year. Analysts were looking for revenue of $247 million. Denny's affirmed its view for full-year per-share income of 2 cents to 6 cents, while analysts are looking for a result of 6 cents. Rainmaker Systems swings to quarterly profit (6:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Rainmaker Systems Inc. RMKR were up 8.8% at $5.17 in after-hours trading on Wednesday. Rainmaker reported first-quarter net earnings $820,000, or 6 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, Rainmaker posted a net loss of $2.51 million, or 27 cents a share. Revenue at the Campbell, Calif.-based provider of marketing services rose to $11.1 million from $6.42 million a year ago. Gross margin was 50% vs. 39%. Rainmaker said it now expects its 2006 revenue growth to exceed 30% on an annual basis. CORRECT: Pulte Homes quarterly profit surges 20% (5:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Pulte Homes Inc. PHM, +1.41% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $262.6 million, or $1.01 a share, up 20% from $218.2 million, or 83 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Bloomfield Hills, Mich.-based company rose 18% to $2.96 billion from $2.52 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast a per-share profit of 96 cents. For 2006, the company expects earnings of $6 to $6.25 a share. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of $5.98. (Corrects to reflect that the company earned $1.01 a share.) Cadence Design quarterly income rises (5:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cadence Design Systems Inc. CDNS, +1.74% shares rose 1.5% to $18.50 in after-hours trading Wednesday. The company said first-quarter net income was $21.8 million, or 7 cents a share, up from $1.02 million, or breakeven on a per-share basis, during the same period last year. On a pro forma basis, the software company reported per-share income for the quarter of 21 cents, compared with 15 cents last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 20 cents. Cadence said quarterly revenue was $328.2 million, up from $292.5 million. Analysts were looking for revenue of $321 million. For the second quarter, the company sees revenue of $340 million to $350 million, and per-share income of 9 cents to 11 cents, or 21 cents to 23 cents on a pro forma basis. Analysts are looking for quarterly revenue of $341 million, and per-share income of 22 cents. Platinum quarterly net income climbs 5% (5:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Platinum Underwriter Holdings PTP, -22.22% said late Wednesday that first-quarter net income came in at $77 million, or $1.16 a share, up 5% from a year earlier when the Bermuda-based reinsurer earned $73.1 million, or $1.49 a share. Net premiums written dropped 41% to $293.3 million. The combined ratio -- the cost of claims and expenses as a percentage of premiums -- was 85.2% in the first quarter, above the 84.5% ratio of the first quarter of 2005, the company reported. "Net premiums written and earned decreased significantly in our Finite Risk segment and to a lesser extent in our traditional segments reflecting our strategy of underwriting for profitability not market share, and a greater willingness on the part of our clients to retain risk," Chief Executive Michael Price said in a statement. Famous Dave's quarterly earnings rise; revenue up 15% (5:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Famous Dave's of America Inc. DAVE, +0.00% after Wednesday's closing bell reported first-quarter net earnings of $742,000, or 7 cents a share, compared with $533,000, or 5 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The results include $371,000, or 2 cents a share, of after-tax expense related to stock-based compensation. Revenue at the Minneapolis-based restaurant chain rose 15% to $27.1 million from $23.5 million. The company said quarterly comparable sales at company-owned restaurants increased 5.6% vs. a year ago. LSI Logic pegs potential sales loss of Apple iPod business (5:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- LSI Logic Corp. LSI, -0.35% said it may lose up to $40 million in sales in the second half of the year from the loss of some business to supply chip components for Apple Computer Inc.'s popular iPod music player. LSI Logic indirectly supplies Apple through its relationship with PortalPlayer Inc. PLAY, -1.21% a big provider of chips for the iPod. Last week, PortalPlayer said Apple AAPL, +0.78% will not use its next-generation chip in some flash-based iPods expected to be released later this year. The news led to a sell off in LSI Logic shares. Netgear quarterly profit rises 26% (5:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Netgear Inc. NTGR, +1.87% shares were up 11% to $21.99 in after-hours trading late Wednesday. After the closing bell, the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $9.87 million, or 29 cents a share, up 26% from $7.9 million, or 24 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, per-share earnings came in at 31 cents a share compared with 25 cents a share last year. Revenue at the Santa Clara, Calif.-based networking products company rose 17% to $127.3 million from $109 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 26 cents a share on revenue of $123 million. Netgear forecast second-quarter revenue of $125 million to $130 million. Analysts are looking for revenue of $123 million. The company also said Chief Financial Officer Jonathan Mather is leaving to pursue other opportunities. CACI International quarterly income rises (5:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CACI International Inc. CAI, +1.97% after Wednesday's closing bell said third-quarter net income was $21.4 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with a restated result of $20.3 million, or 66 cents a share, during the same period last year. The networking company said quarterly revenue was $435.4 million, up from $414.9 million in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected revenue of $455 million. For the fourth quarter, CACI sees revenue of $470 million to $490 million, and per-share income of 71 cents to 76 cents. Analysts are looking for revenue of $504 million. Aspen quarterly profit drops as reinsurer cuts cat exposure (5:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Aspen Insurance Holdings AHL, -0.33% reported a 12% drop in first-quarter net income late Wednesday after the Bermuda-based reinsurer cut back on the amount of catastrophe risk it underwrote. Net income came in at $61.8 million, or 59 cents a share, versus $70.1 million, or 98 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Operating earnings, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses, were $61.7 million, or 59 cents a share, versus $72.1 million, or $1.01 a share. Net premiums written in the period dropped 29% to $451.9 million, Aspen said. Chief Executive Chris O'Kane said the reinsurer arranged a "major reduction" in its property catastrophe exposures in the quarter -- beyond what the company had originally planned. Catastrophe reinsurance pricing, which didn't improve much at the start of 2006, began to increase considerably as the quarter progressed, he explained. "We are encouraged by this trend and believe it will enable us to replace considerable parts of the business we have rejected with similar exposures at much better prices as the year advances," he added. BA, +2.46% said Wednesday its first-quarter net income rose to $692 mllion, or 88 cents a share, compared with $535 million, or 66 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. The aerospace company said the 2006 first-quarter results include a benefit of 3 cents a share from tax settlements. Revenue rose 12% to $14.26 billion from $12.68 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 76 cents a share and sales of $14.53 billion. Boeing, based in Chicago, affirmed its 2006 outlook for revenue of $60 billion and earnings of $3.25 to $3.45 a share; it also backed a 2007 revenue estimate of $63.5 billion-$64.5 billion and earnings estimate of $4.10 to $4.30 a share. Rollins profit falls, sales rise (7:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Rollins Inc. ROL, +1.11% said Wednesday that first-quarter net income fell to $10.9 million, or 16 cents a share, from $11.6 million, or 17 cents, a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended March 31 increased to $194.2 million from $183.9 million in last year's first quarter. The Atlanta pest-control company said a seasonal loss at the recently acquired Industrial Fumigant Co. business hurt earnings. T. Rowe Price net income totals $116.7 mln (7:39 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- T. Rowe Price Group Inc., a Baltimore-based asset manager, Wednesday said first-quarter net income rose to $116.7 million, or 84 cents a share, from $94 million, or 69 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call, on average, had expected 82 cents. Revenue totaled $429 million , compared with $357 million in the year-earlier quarter. Shares of T. Rowe TROW, +2.06% closed down 15 cents at $83.52 on Tuesday. Biogen Idec posts profit, backs full-year view (7:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Biogen Idec Inc. BIIB, +0.74% Wednesday said first-quarter earnings rose to $123 million, or 36 cents a share, from a year-ago profit of $43 million, or 12 cents a share. Excluding merger-related accounting impacts and employee stock option expense, the company earned 55 cents a share. Total revenue rose to $611.2 million from $587.8 million, helped by sales of Rituxan and Avonex. Analysts, on average, were expecting it to post a profit of 48 cents a share, excluding stock option expense, on revenue of $637.2 million, according to Thomson First Call. The drug maker backed its 2006 non-GAAP earnings forecast for the year of a range of $1.95 to $2.10 a share. Allegheny Tech improves 1Q earns on 18% sales jump (7:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Allegheny Technologies Inc. ATI, +3.91% Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $102.5 million, or $1 a share, up from a year-ago profit of $61 million, or 61 cents a share. Sales rose 18% in the latest three months to $1.04 billion from $$879.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 70 cents a share in the March period on revenue of $923.7 million. The Pittsburgh specialty metals producer said its key growth markets - aerospace and defense, chemical process industry, oil and gas, electrical energy, and medical - remained strong in the first quarter, and that it believes overall results in its flat rolled products business, which saw flat sales in the period, will improve significantly in the second quarter. The stock closed Tuesday at $73.10, down 1.9%. American Home Mortgage earns $1.02 (7:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- American Home Mortgage AHM said it earned $54.5 million, or $1.02 a share, in the first quarter, compared with $125.4 million, or $2.99 a share, in the same period a year ago. The company said the year-earlier comparison would be $1.24 on an adjusted basis. Revenue stood at $233.1 million, compared with $235.3 million a year ago, or $164 million on an adjusted basis. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 86 cents a share on revenue of $183.6 million. The Melville, N.Y. company said it still expects 2006 earnings of $4.85 to $5.15 a share, compared with a First Call estimate of $4.62. It also announced that it is increasing its quarterly dividend to 96 cents a share. Phoenix Cos Inc. swings to a loss on asset management charge (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Phoenix Cos. Inc. PNX, -1.57% on Wednesday said first-quarter net income fell to $1.7 million, or 2 cents a share from $9.4 million, or 9 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Hartford, Conn. insurance firm reported a total segment loss of $6.2 million, or 6 cents a share because of a non-cash charge in its asset management unit. Total segment income last year was $16.8 million, or 16 cents a share. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 22 cents a share. The company said the quarter was "challenging" with its first segment loss since 2002, but the results "are not indicative of the underlying strengths of the business or our prospects for the year." The company said it's pursuing a closed block transaction and that its targets for the year remains unchanged except for an adjustment to its return on investment to reflect the charge in its asset management unit. Air Products & Chemicals net income, revenue rise (7:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Air Products & Chemicals APD, +1.24% said Wednesday second-quarter net income rose to $204 million, or 89 cents a share, from $175.3 million, or 75 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue at the industrial gas provider rose 16% in the three months ended March 31 to $2.32 billion from $2 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 87 cents a share and revenue of $2.18 billion. Air Products, of Lehigh Valley, Pa., forecast third quarter earnings of 88 cents and 92 cents a share and 2006 earnings of $3.40 to $3.50 a share. P.F Chang's posts in-line quarter; offers 2006 profit view (7:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch)-- P.F. Chang's China Bistro Inc. PFCB said Wednesday first-quarter net income fell to $9.8 million, or 36 cents a share from $10.8 million, or 40 cents a share a year ago. The restaurant group said revenue rose to $228.6 million from $194.2 million. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 36 cents a share on revenue of $228.7 million. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company is forecasting earnings per share of $1.31 a share in 2006, a decline over the $1.40 a share booked in 2005. P.F. Chang's said the fall is due to stock-option expensing. Revenue for the year is expected to rise 18% to $954 million. The First Call average estimate is for full-year earnings of $1.38 a share on revenue of $959.5 million. On Tuesday, the stock rose 82 cents to $46.02. Jones Apparel posts profit, "cautious" on year (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Jones Apparel Group Inc. JNY on Wednesday said first-quarter net income fell to $25.8 million, or 22 cents a share, from $87 million, or 71 cents a share. Excluding the imact of a loss on the sale of its Polo Jeans Co. business, severance and other expenses related to its strategic review, and a change in accounting principle, Jones Apparel earned 66 cents a share. Net sales fell to $1.2 billion from $1.34 billion. Analysts, on average, expected the company to post a profit of 53 cents a share on revenue of $1.17 billion, according to Thomson First Call. The apparel maker, which is considering putting itself up for sale, said it is comfortable with its stated cost reduction goal of about $30 million in 2006 and over $100 million annually by the end of 2007. Jones Apparel, whose brands include Gloria Vanderbilt, Nine West and Easy Spirit, said it has a "cautious" outlook for the year, and forecast earnings for the year of $2.19 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast $2.23 a share. Sprint Nextel 1Q earns $419M vs $472M (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sprint Nextel Corp. S, +0.41% Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $419 million, or 14 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $472 million, or 31 cents a share. Net operating revenue increased 66% in the latest three months to $11.55 billion from $6.94 billion in the same period a year earlier. The company noted the year-ago results don't include the Nextel operations. The latest results include a charge of 19 cents a share from merger-related amortization costs and a charge of 2 cents a share for additional unspecified special items. Sprint Nextel said its adjusted earnings, excluding items, totaled 35 cents a share for the March quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 37 cents a share in the latest quarter on revenue of $11.4 billion. The Reston, Va., communications giant said it saw strong services demand in the quarter with revenue from its wireless business rising 13% overall to $8.5 billion in the quarter. Long distance revenue fell 3%, however, to $1.7 billion in the latest period, while revenue from local communications edged 1% higher to $1.6 billion. The company also maintained its financial outlook. The stock closed Tuesday at $25.03, up 18 cents. Lear Corp. net income rises (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Auto parts maker Lear Corp. LEA, +3.01% said Wednesday that first-quarter net income rose to $17.9 million, or 26 cents a share, from $15.6 million, or 23 cents a share, for the first quarter of 2005. Sales in the three months ended April 1 rose 9% to $4.68 billion from $4.29 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 6 cents a share, before items, and sales of $4.51 billion. Lear also backed its previous 2006 earnings outlook. Waters earns 42 cents vs. 38 cents, sales up 8% (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Waters Corp. WAT, +0.04% said it earned $44.2 million, or 42 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared with $46.6 million, or 38 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding special items, earnings rose to 50 cents a share from 39 cents, the Milford, Mass. industrial company said. Sales rose 8% to $290 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 42 cents a share on sales of $277.7 million. Shares closed Tuesday down 1% at $43.55. Diamond Offshore Drilling profit up nearly 5x (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Diamond Offshore Drilling DO, +2.95% on Wednesday said first-quarter net income rose to $145.3 million, or $1.06 a share from $30.1 million, or 23 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue nearly doubled to $447.7 million from $258.8 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 98 cents a share and revenue of $427.9 million. The Houston firm cited record-high average dayrates and rig utilization for the company's entire fleet. The company said its order backlog is at about $5 billion, up from $1 billion last year. Tellabs earnings, revenue rise (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Tellabs TLAB reported first-quarter earnings of $52.4 million, or 11 cents a share, vs. earnings of $700,000, or breakeven on a per share basis in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 14 cents a share. Revenue rose to $514.7 million from last year's $435.6 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 12 cents a share and revenue of $494.7 million, on average. The networking company's stock closed Tuesday up 73 cents at $15.81. Yankee Candle posts in-line quarterly profit, revenue beats (7:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Yankee Candle Company Inc. YCC, +0.32% said Wednesday first-quarter net income rose to $12.5 million, or 30 cents a share compared with $10.8 million, or 23 cents a share a year ago. Excluding a one-time tax benefit, the maker of premium scented candles said earnings came in at 25 cents a share. Sales rose 12% to $133.9 million. Same-store sales for the period rose 1%. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 25 cents a share on sales of $125.5 million. The South Deerfield, Mass. company said it expects second-quarter earnings in the range of 18 cents to 20 cents a share on sales growth of around 6% to 8%. The First Call average estimate is for earnings of 21 cents a share on revenue of $116.3 million. On Tuesday, the stock rose 17 cents to $29.03. Mesa Air net falls, revenue higher (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Mesa Air Group Inc. MESA said Wednesday second-quarter net income fell to $5.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from $10.8 million or 26 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue at the regional air carrier grew 18% to $312.1 million from $263.8 million in the three months ended March 31. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 30 cents a share. CBS posts profit, backs full year view (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CBS Corp. CBS, -0.94% on Wednesday said first-quarter net earnings fell to $226.9 million, or 30 cents a share, from $585 million, or 72 cents a share. Earnings from continuing operations rose to $232 million, or 30 cents a share, from $220 million, or 27 cents a share, a year earlier. Proforma results for 2005 are adjusted for the separation from Viacom Inc. VIA, +1.80% and exclude a net gain on investments. Revenue rose to $3.58 billion from $3.45 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to post a profit of 28 cents a share on revenue of $3.51 billion, according to Thomson First Call. The media giant said it is on track to deliver low single-digit growth in revenues and mid single-digit growth in operating income and earnings per share for the year. Colgate-Palmolive profit, sales rise (7:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Colgate-Palmolive Co. CL, +1.24% said Wednesday that first-quarter net income rose to $324.5 million, or 59 cents a share, from $300.1 million, or 53 cents, a year ago. Excluding restructuring charges, earnings would have been 70 cents a share, or 4 cents ahead of analysts' average view. Sales for the three months ended March 31 advanced to $2.87 billion from $2.74 billion in last year's first quarter, and ahead of analysts' view for $2.84 billion in sales. The New York consumer-goods company attributed the results to solid gains in worldwide sales and volume. Moody's net income rises 23% (7:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Moody's Corp. MCO, +1.48% on Wednesday said first-quarter net income rose 23% to $146.2 million, or 49 cents a share, from $118.7 million, or 39 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue advanced to $440.2 million from $390.5 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 49 cents a share and revenue of $451.8 million. Moody's said it continues to expect 2006 growth in non-GAAP diluted earnings per share in the low double-digit percent range, excluding adjustments related to legacy tax matters and expensing of stock-based compensation. Moody's plans to take 13-15 cents a share this year for stock-based compensation costs. PepsiCo 1Q earns $1.02B vs $912M (7:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- PepsiCo Inc. PEP, -0.03% Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $1.02 billion, or 60 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $912 million, or 53 cents a share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $7.21 billion from $6.59 billion in the same period a year earlier. Overall volume rose 7% in the quarter. The company said the latest results include a $50 million pre-tax gain related to the sale of shares in The Pepsi Bottling Group PBG, +7.14% The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 58 cents a share in March period on revenue of $7.03 billion. The Purchase, N.Y., soda maker also reaffirmed its outlook for earnings of at least $2.93 per share in 2006. The stock closed Tuesday at $57.50, up 23 cents. CBiz earnings rise on 10% jump in revenue (7:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CBiz Inc. CBIZ said Wednesday first-quarter net income rose to $12 million, or 16 cents a share from $8.2 million, or 10 cents a share a year ago. The business services group said income from continuing operations came in at 17 cents a share. Revenue rose 10.3% to $171.1 million, with revenue from newly acquired operations contributing $3.7 million, or 2.4% to revenue growth. Chief executive Steven Gerard said the company remains on track to achieve its goal of a minimum 20% to 25% increase in earnings per share in 206 compared with the 28 cents per share reported for 2005. On Tuesday, the stock closed unchanged at $8.67. Manor Care profit, sales fall (7:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Manor Care Inc. HCR, +0.00% said Wednesday that charges hurt first-quarter net income, as it fell to $25 million, or 30 cents a share, from $40.4 million, or 46 cents, a year ago. Sales for the three months ended March 31 declined to $869.3 million from $879.2 million. Analysts expected the Toledo, Ohio, healthcare provider to post earnings, on average, of 50 cents a share on sales of $862.4 million. First Midwest profit affected by options expensing, dilution (7:04 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- First Midwest Bancorp Inc. FMBI, +0.45% reported first-quarter net income of $25.8 million, or 55 cents a share, little chnaged from $25.2 million, or 55 cents, earned in same period during 2005. Adjusted to exclude costs of expensing stock options, the Itasca, Ill.-based company said earnings would have been 56 cents a share for the latest quarter. Dilution from the issuance of 4.4 million common shares used in the financing of First Midwest's acquisition of Bank Calumet also affected results. Analysts, on average, had been looking for a profit of 57 cents a share. Assets as of March 31 totaled nearly $8.72 billion, up from $6.91 billion a year earlier. Shares of First Midwest eased 5 cents to end Tuesday's trading at $36. Private Business Inc. files $86M offering (7:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Private Business Inc. PBIZ on Wednesday filed to raise up to $86 million in a stock offering. Shares closed at $1.75 on Tuesday. CORRECT: American Tower 1st-period loss narrows, rev up 74% (7:01 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- American Tower Corp., AMT, +0.72% the Boston owner, operator and developer of broadcast- and wireless-communications sites in the U.S., Mexico and Brazil, reported a narrower first-quarter loss on 74% higher revenue. The loss narrowed to $2.6 million, or 1 cent a share, from $31.6 million, or 14 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached $320.4 million from $184.4 million. For the second quarter, American Tower estimates profit from continuing operations of $1 million to $3 million on revenue of $317 million to $322 million. On Tuesday, the company's shares rose 45 cents, or 1.4%, to $33.19. (In fourth sentence, corrects to show profit estimate is from continuing operations and corrects figures in revenue outlook.) Engelhard reports 19% increase in profit (6:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Engelhard Corp. EC, +3.54% said first-quarter net income rose 19% to $69 million, or 55 cents a share, with revenue up 43% to $1.46 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings of 52 cents a share from the Iselin, N.J.-based chemicals firm that separately rejected a bid from BASF. Potash quarterly profit slips, sales drop 7% (6:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Fertilizer company Potash Corp of Saskatchewan Inc POT, -2.17% said first-quarter net income declined to $125.5 million from $131.3 million a year earlier. Earnings per share rose to $1.19 from $1.15, reflecting the value of a reduced share base following the repurchase of 9.5 million shares in 2005. Sales declined 7% to $861 million on lower volumes. Offshore volumes dropped 48% as shipments to China, India and Brazil by Canpotex, the offshore marketing agent for Saskatchewan potash producers, dropped from 1.18 million to 0.13 million tonnes. Potash said it expects second-quarter earnings of $1.25 to $1.50 a share. Harleysville Group's quarterly net growth tops 80% (6:34 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Harleysville Group Inc. HGIC reported first-quarter net income of $21.7 million, or 70 cents a share, up from $12 million, or 39 cents, earned in the same period in 2005. The cumulative effect of an accounting change for share-based payments added 3 cents to per-share net earnings for the latest quarter, and operating earnings amounted to 62 cents a share, the Harleysville, Pa.-based property and casualty insurer said. Quarterly revenue reached $239.5 million from $232.7 million. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of 55 cents a share on revenue of $239 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Shares of Harleysville Group added 47 cents, or 1.6%, to end Tuesday's trading at $29.85. Monster Worldwide profit more than doubles (6:25 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Online recruitment company Monster Worldwide MNST, +1.72% said first-quarter net income more than doubled to $42.3 million, or 32 cents a share, with revenue up 28% to $292 million. From continuing operations, it earned 29 cents a share, topping Thomson First Call-compiled analyst forecasts of 27 cents a share. Second-quarter earnings from continuing operations are seen between 29 cents and 30 cents a share, with revenue between $293 million and $300 million, and 2006 earnings from continuing operations are seen between $1.25 and $1.29 a share, on revenue between $1.18 billion and $1.22 billion. EnCana swings to quarterly profit, helped by accounting gain (6:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Canadian gas producer EnCana Corp ECA, +4.56% sait it swung to a first-quarter net profit of $1.47 billion, or $1.70 a share. In the same quarter a year ago, the company posted a loss of $45 million, or 5 cents a share. The profit figure benefited from an accounting gain of $830 million. EnCana said gas and liquids sales from continuing operations rose 6% in the quarter to 4.32 cubic feet of gas equivalent. The company lifted its quarterly dividend 33% to 10 cents a share and said it was on track to achieve its 2006 guidance for North American sales' growth of 7%. Regis Corp. updates fourth quarter, issues FY-2007 outlook (6:22 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Regis Corp. RGS, -0.98% said up to $25 million, or 54 cents a share, will be added to the hair-salon operator's profit for the fourth quarter ending June 30 as a result of a fee to be paid by Alberto-Culver ACV, +3.75% over the companies' recently terminated merger pact. Accordingly, Regis pegged its fourth-quarter profit forecast in a range of $1.12 to $1.16 a share, up from 64 cents earned in the same period during fiscal 2005. "Operationally, our fourth-quarter outlook remains unchanged," Regis said. The company also issued projections for fiscal 2007, with earnings pegged in a range of $2.22 to $2.34 a share and consolidated revenue estimated at $2.6 billion. Analysts, on average, are looking for Regis to earn 60 cents a share in the fourth quarter and $2.42 a share for fiscal 2007, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. WellPoint 1st-period net up 20%, revenue up 26% (6:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- WellPoint Inc., WLP the Indianapolis health-benefits provider, reported first-quarter net income rose 20% on 26% higher revenue. Net reached $731.8 million, or $1.09 a share, from $611.7 million, or 98 cents, in the year-earlier period. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced a consensus estimate for WellPoint of $1.07. Revenue reached $13.82 billion from $10.94 billion. The company estimates profit of $1.14 a share for the second quarter and $4.63 for the full year. Thomson First Call's estimates: $1.13 and $4.57. WellPoint shares fell 76 cents, or 1.1%, to $70.74 on Tuesday. Regis Corp. posts above-consensus adjusted profit (6:14 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Regis Corp. RGS, -0.98% reported net income of $18.6 million, or 40 cents a share, for the third quarter ended March 31, reversing a year-earlier loss of $16.6 million, or 37 cents a share. The hair-care salon operator's profit for the latest quarter would have been 48 cents a share if a charge associated with its previously announced merger termination with Alberto-Culver ACV, +3.75% is excluded, but Minneapolis-based Regis also said fourth-quarter results will benefit from a merger-termination fee paid by Alberto-Culver. The loss in the year-earlier third quarter reflected a $38.3 million goodwill-impairment charge, Regis said. Third-quarter revenue reached $604 million from $557.3 million, up 8%, but same-store sales eased 0.4%. Analysts, on average, had been looking for a profit of 47 cents a share on revenue of $605 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Shares of Regis added 25 cents to end Tuesday's trading at $34.96. Ipsco quarterly profit rises, sales jump 18% (6:13 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Steel mill products maker Ipsco Inc IPS, +54.55% said first-quarter net income rose to $150.7 million, or $3.12 a share, from $154.8 million, or $3.06 per share, a year earlier. Sales jumped 18% to $903 million due to the ongoing strength of the plate, energy, tubular and large diameter pipe markets. Ipsco said it sees second-quarter earnings in the range of $2.60 to $2.80 a share. It added it expects robust demand for steel mill products for all of 2006. Serologicals quarterly net rises, sales slip 2.8% (6:07 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Serologicals Corp SERO a developer of consumable biological products, said first-quarter net income rose to $2.8 million, or 8 cents a a share, from $1.9 million, or 5 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue slipped 2.8% to $55 million, primarily because of the divestiture of certain bioprocessing product lines. Serologicals earlier this week agreed to be acquired by Millipore MIL, -3.92% for about $1.4 billion. Baker Hughes quarterly profit almost doubles (5:51 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oil services company Baker Hughes Inc BHI, +4.27% said first-quarter net income almost doubled to $339.2 million, or 99 cents a share, from $179.8 million, or 53 cents a share, in the year earlier quarter. The average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 79 cents a share. Revenue climbed 26% to $2.06 billion on a strong performance in its drilling and production services units. In 2006, the group said it expects revenue to rise 23% to 25% and sees earnings from continuing operations at $7 to $7.39 a share. Baker Hughes guided to capex of $750 million to $780 million for the year. CORRECT: First American profit falls 12%, revenue climbs 18% (5:10 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- First American FAF, +0.98% said first-quarter net income slipped 12% to $69.7 million, or 71 cents a share, with revenue up 18% to $2 billion. The Santa Ana, Calif.-based business information provider said it was pleased wtih revenue growth in its title insurance, specialty insurance, property information, and risk mitigation and business solutions segments. But an increase in the loss provision rate for the title insurance operations and continued investments in new business initiatives hurt profits, it said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 75 cents a share. (Corrects to use net income instead of pretax figure.) Pages Jaunes quarterly sales rise 6.8% (2:34 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Pages Jaunes Group, a spinoff of France Telecom FTE, +0.55% (FR:013330)on Wednesday said first-quarter consolidated sales rose 6.8% to 209.4 million euros. Minitel sales dropped 35.5% to 10 3 million euros while Internet sales jumped 20.4% to 63.5 million euros. Imperial Tobacco pretax up 13% as cigarette volumes rise (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Imperial Tobacco ITY (UK:IMT)said first-half pretax profit rose 13% to 547 million pounds after cigarette volumes increased by 9% to 86.3 billion, driven by growth in Asia, Eastern Europe, Africa and the Middle East. It's lifting its interim dividend by 12% to 18.5 pence a share. The company said it grew market in the U.K. and also increased share in Germany despite a challenging market there. Infineon quarterly loss narrows, sales rise 24% (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German semiconductor manufacturer Infineon Technologies AG IFX, -8.16% (DE:623100)on Wednesday said its second-quarter loss narrowed to 26 million euros ($32 million), or 0.03 euros a share, from 114 million euros, or 0.15 euros a share, a year earlier. Infineon swung to an EBIT profit of 28 million euros compared to a loss of 117 million euros in the year-ago period. Revenue climbed 24% to 1.99 billion euros on higher sales in the memory products and the automotive, industrial and multimarket segments. In the third quarter, Infineon said it expects EBIT and revenue to decline at its two logic divisions from the second quarter. Infineon reiterated that its memory chip unit will be spun off into a separate entity name Qimonda effective May 1. ABN Amro profit rises 12%, to cut 2,400 IT jobs (2:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Dutch bank ABN Amro ABN, +8.33% (NL:30110)on Wednesday reported a 12.1% increase in first-quarter net profit to 1 billion euros, on consumer and commercial banking organic growth and the first-time inclusion of Italy's Banca Antonveneta in its results. But loan loss provisions jumped to 331 million from 99 million euros on consumers in Latin America, Asia and Holland. Analysts polled by AFX News were looking for earnings between 967 million and 1.12 billion euros. ABN also announced it would cut 2,400 IT jobs in Holland, the U.S., Brazil and the U.K., while hiring 900 in India. Combined with a new centralized IT function, ABN expects to save an additional 150 million euros by 2008, at a charge of 125 million to 150 million euros.
